editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: ANOTHER COLLECTION OF Philoophical CONFERENCES OF THE French Virtuoi, UPON QUESTIONS of all SORTS; For the Improving of Natural Knowledg. Made in the Aembly of the Beaux Eprits at Paris, by the mot Ingenious Perons of that Nation.
Render'd into Englih, By G. HAVERS, Gent. & J. DAVIES of Kidwelly, Gent.

LONDON, Printed for Thomas Dring and John Starkey, and are to be old at their Shops at the George in Fleet-treet neer Clifford's-Inn, and the Mitre between the Middle-Temple-Gate and Temple-bar. 1665.
IMPRIMATUR,

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p:
THe good Reception a Volume of the like Conferences appears to have found lat year by the peedy ditribution of the Copies, hath given encouragement to the Verion and Publication of this; wherein I aure my elf the Readers will not find themelves wore entertain'd at the econd Coure then they were at the firt; the Quetions here being proportionably more Philoophical, and choen from uch Subjects as are mot inquir'd into at this day by the Curious of our own Nation, who undoubtedly will find ome contentment (if not atisfaction) in reading what the Virtuoi of our Neighbour-Nation have dicours'd touching thoe Matters. I have often heard it poken to the Commendation of an Eminent Peer in the lat Reign, That for an hour or two together he made the mot agreeable Converation in the World; but if, upon parting, any one of the Company happened to reflect upon what he had heard, he could not remember the leat particular paage, aving that he had pent uch a portion of Time very deliciouly. 'Twas a happy Faculty for the Man; for he did his buines by it, and partly ow'd his Promotion to this Talent. I hall pronounce no otherwie upon him but thus, That perhaps (as Tully aid in almot a like cae) he was a better Gallant than a Wie Man hould be: At leat, this way of conuming Time, argued a great Dieae in Mens Minds, when they could be contented to feed upon Air, and were o queamih as not to be able to bear the wholom Diet of olid Dicoure. 'Tis too apparent that the ame Humor is till
predominant in thee our days, wherein Gaming makes the whole Convere amongt the Gentry, who, like rapacious Animals, meet together but to prey upon one another, whilt old Stories, or News, and (for want of matter o innocent) Detractions, Deriions, and Abues are the only things that furnih talk to the Plebeians. Thus we live, and yet pretend to be Reaonable Creatures; whilt true and olid Reaon is almot as obcurely dicernable in our Commerce, as Sene and Motion are in Sponges and Oiters. But 'tis hop'd the better practice of ome Excellent Perons amongt our elves, may contribute much to the Reformation of this; and to help it forward, it cannot but do ome good (by exciting us to emulation) to ee what been already done by ome Gentlemen of France, to whoe excellent Wits the World is beholden for thee Conferences.

div.head: CONFERENCE CI. I. Of Sleep, and how long it ought to be. II. Which is the tronget thing in the World.
div.p:
The econd aid, That Privations are undertood by their Habits; and therefore Sleep, which is a privation of Sene, cannot
be better known than by the functions of the outward Senes, which o long as an Animal exercies it is aid to be awake, and to leep when it ceaes to employ the ame. And being Senation is perform'd by means of the animal Spirits, refin'd out of the natural and vital, and ent from the Brain into the Senories, which Spirits receive the pecies of the enible object, and carry it to the Inward Sene, the common Arbiter and Judg of all external objects; hence, when thoe Spirits happen to fail, or the Common Sene is bound up, the other external Senes cannot dicharge their offices: Upon which account the Philoophers have defin'd Sleep, The ligation of the Firt Sene; or, The ret of the Spirits and Blood: And the Phyitians, The ceation of all outward Senes for the health and repoe of an Animal; hereby ditinguihing it from the ceation of the outward Senes in Swoonings, Falling-icknes, Apoplexie, Lethargy, Carus, Coma, and uch orts of morbifick and praeternatural leep, produc'd by caues acting rather by an occult and omniferous property, then by exces of cold or moiture; otherwie Winter, Ice, and the coldet things, hould caue leep; Wine, Annis, Opium, Henbane, and abundance of hot Medicaments, hould not be Narcotick, as experience evinces them to be. But natural leep is produc'd by vapours elevated from the aliments into the brain; which moreover performing in us the office of a Ventoe or Cupping-glas, draws to it elf thoe humid vapours, condenes them by its coldnes, and reolves them into a gentle dew, which falling upon the rie or beginning of the Nerves, obtructs the paage to the animal Spirits, the intruments of Senation and voluntary Motion, which it hinders; though not Motion, o much as Senation; becaue the Nerves of the hinder part of the Brain, detinated to Motion, being harder, do not o eaily imbibe thoe vapours, as thoe of the fore-part, detinated to Senation: But when the Heat and Spirits, whereof there had been an abumption, are again ufficiently repair'd, they move anew toward the Brain, where they reolve thoe dews which topp'd the paage, and hindred the commerce of the vital Spirits with the animal; whereupon we naturally and without violence awake: So likewie, the violence of an extrinecal object importunately triking the external Senes, obliges the Soul to end other Spirits to the aitance of the few remaining therein, and which before this upply apprehend objects only confuedly.

The Third aid, Sleep is not the Quiecence of the animal Spirits, for thee are active, and form Dreams whilt we leep; nor of the vital, which have no relaxation or ret o long as the Animal hath life; much les of the natural, Nutrition being perform'd bet during leep, which is the caue why leeping fattens. Neither is the Brain's humidity the caue of leep, as 'tis commonly held; but the defect of vital heat in the Heart, in a ufficient degree for performing the functions of the outward
Senes. Moreover the udden eizing and abruption of leep, which we oberve, cannot be produc'd but by a very movable caue, uch as the gros vapour of aliments is not; but the vital heat is, being carried into all parts of the body in an intant: Whence it is that we oberve the ame to be more pale during leep, (as having les of the aid heat) than during Evigilation.

The Fourth aid, That indeed the adequate caue of leep is not a vapour ariing from the aliments, ince it is procur'd by abundance of other caues, which produce no evaporation; as Wearines, Muique, Silence, and Darknes: Neither is it the above-mentioned deficience of Vi •• l Heat, which indeed is neceary to the Organs, inamuch as they are endu'd with life, but not to make them capable of ene; there being ufficient in them even during leep, when the parts are found hot enough for Senation, if heat were the caue thereof, as it is not: But the right caue conits in the Animal Spirits, for which, as being the noblet intruments of the Body, I conceive there is a particular faculty in the Brain, which adminiters and governs them, ending them to the Organs, when there is need of them; and cauing them to return back, in order to be retor'd and uppli'd: As there is a particular faculty in the Heart, over-ruling and moving the Vital Spirits as it pleaes; ometimes diffuing them outwards in Joy, Anger, and Shame; ometimes cauing them to retreat, in order to uccour the Heart in Sadnes, Grief, and Fear.

The Fifth aid, The Empire of Sleep, whom Orpheus calls King of Gods and Men, is o weet, that Not to be of its party is to be an enemy to Nature: 'Tis the charm of all griefs both of body and mind; and was given to man, not only for the refrehment of both, but chiefly for the liberty of the Soul; becaue it makes both the Mater and the Slave, the poor and the rich equal: 'Tis a ign of health in young people, and caues a good contitution of Brain, trengthning the ame, and rendring all the functions of the mind more vigorous; whence came the aying, That the Night gives counels; becaue then the Mind is freed from the tyranny of the Senes, it reaons more olidly, and its operations are o much the more perfect as they are more independent on matter; and 'twas during the repoe of leep that mot of the Extaies and prophetical Viions happened to the Saints. Moreover frequent leep is a ign of a very good nature: For being conciliated only by the benignity of a temper moderately hot and moit, the Sanguine and Phlegmatick, whoe humour is mot agreeable, are more inclined thereunto than the Bilious and Melancholly, in regard of their heat and drines, which reolve and diipate the animal Spirits, as a vapourous humidity hinders their effuion, by the obtruction which it caueth in the original of the Nerves; or, which is mot probable, becaue the clouds of thoe vapours occupying the ventricles of the Brain, by their humidity moiten and relax the animal
Spirits, which remain immovable till they be deliver'd from the importunity of thoe vapours; which moreover more eaily acending, when the Body is at ret, it happens that Sleep is frequently caus'd, not only by watchings, cares, labour, bathing, heat, and other things which diipate the Spirits; but alo by ounds, gentle murmurs of water, frictions, and motions, ilence, and darknes; unles we had rather ay, That the animal Spirits, being mot ubtle and luminous bodies, retire inwards during the darknes, which is contrary to them.

The Sixth aid, That Sleep being not only a depravation but a total privation of actions, ince a thing exits but o far as it acts; at the ame proportion that we love our own Being, we ought to hate Sleep, and love Watching. The great George Catriot, the courge of the Turks, never lept more then two hours; and the Poets had reaon to term Sleep, The Image of Death, which the Scripture alo exprees by Sleeping. As therefore Death is to be avoided as much as poible, o alo ought Sleep; were it not that both of them, being inevitable evils, all we can do is to keep as far off them, and uffer our elves to be led as little to them, as may be. The Poets themelves eem willing to imprint in us a horror of Sleep, when they feign it the Son of Hell or Erebus, and Night, the brother of Death, the father of Morpheus, and that his Palace was amidt the darknes of the Cimmerians. Moreover, the mot imperfect Animals leep more then others, which is the reaon Zoophytes, or Plant-animals, as the Sponge, Coral, and Oiters, leep continually; Snails, and ome Flys, three or four months; Bears, longer then other Animals; and amongt thee, Birds, as partaking more of the nature of Heaven, leep les then four-footed Beats: A Child, o long as it approaches a betial life in its Mothers belly, and for the firt years, leeps more than when 'tis grown to Manhood; and being again become by Age a Child, leeps more than formerly, till he comes to the lat leep of death, which reduces him to nothing. Women, phlegmatick perons, drunkards, and block-heads, leep more then Men, ober, and witty perons. For we are no more to refer to the abue of thee Times in leeping very much, then to other Vices of the Age; amongt the ret, Idlenes, Eating and Drinking, wherein there is none ober at this day but exceed their jut meaure.

Upon the Second point it was aid, That Strength, as well as mot other things in the World, Which is the tronget thing in the World. hath not an abolute but only a relative Being, a thing being called trong, in comparion of others which are les o. Thus Antaeus was trong in repect of all other men; but weak, compared to Hercules: And as Achilles was invulnerable in every other part aving the heel; o Nature eems to have left in us a certain weaknes and defect in ome parts, wherein ome are more tender then others: So that 'tis hard to find one thing alike powerful towards all men, ince
by reaon of our everal inclinations every one is differently affected: The Ambitious will hold for Honours; the Amorous, for Women, the Drinker, for Wine; and Truth, which in the Scripture was judg'd tronget by King Darius, who propos'd the preent Problem to his four Courtiers, would poibly be deemed the weaket in the Judgment of the mot; for to them that hould take her part, the ame quetion might be put which Pilate ask'd our Lord, What is Truth? It is o frequently diguis'd by lying, in moral matters; o invelop'd in darknes, and ubject to the deceit of our Senes in natural things, that as it is the leat undertood, o we may ay 'tis the leat follow'd; our inclinations never tending towards an unknown object. The tronget thing therefore is that which hath mot power to incline our Will towards it elf; which Will following the counel of the Undertanding, as again this acts not but by the pecies wherewith the Imagination upplies it, 'tis to the Imagination that I acribe the greatet trength in the world; ince all other things borrow all their power from the Imagination, by the opinion of Honour, Profit, and Pleaure, which that Faculty makes us conceive therein; and, on the contrary, the ame Imagination ruines and detroys the force of all things accounted the mot powerful, whilt it coniders them with a different bias: 'Tis by it that one abhors nothing more then Women, whom o many others idolatrize: Pleaures, Honours, Riches, and all the Goods of Fortune, are but o many croes and punihments to thoe who have conceiv'd an averion againt them: Death it elf, as terrible as it is, oftentimes is depis'd and ought after out of a powerful conideration of Honour; this too being nothing ele but a Fancy, magnifi'd by the opinion rais'd of it in the world: Even Virtue draws all her power from Imagination alone; for many a one thinks he embraces her quite naked, whilt, like Ixion, he embraces nothing but a cloud and a phantam, and yet is as well atisfi'd with this as if he had a perfect fruition of her.

The Second aid, That the olution of this Problem depends upon the undertanding of the term [Strength]: If it be taken for a certain quality and power which renders things active, that mut be the tronget thing in the world which acts with mot efficacy and power upon the mot excellent things: But foramuch as there are as many orts of agents, as there are degrees of Being in Nature, in Morals, and in Trancendants, and we may compare things together which are of a different genus; yet there being no congruity and proportion but between thoe which are of the ame pecies, 'tis hard to know abolutely which is the tronget thing, ince every one hath a vertue wholly peculiar, becaue it hath a proper nature, which is the principle and caue of the diverity of motions and actions. According to which ditinction I am of opinion, That of agents purely natural Fire is the tronget, ince it alters and detroys all natural
Bodies; and its quality, Heat, is the mot active of all. Amongt living things Man is the tronget, inamuch as he renders himelf mater of all the fiercet Animals, which he knows how either to ubdue or tame. Amongt men Kings are the tronget, ince they dipoe of our Goods, Lives, and Wills. Moral agents are different in force and activity, according to the divers contitution of ubjects upon which they act, and make a different impreion. Honety alone acts upon very few pirits; Pleaures, upon mot; Interet, upon all: Nevertheles ince they act only by the opinion which they produce either of an honet, profitable, or delightful Good, this Opinion and Imagination mut be the tronget of all moral agents. Amongt the actions of the Imagination, which are the Paions, that of Love is the tronget, becaue it erves for a foundation to all the ret; it being true, that we fear, deire, and hate nothing, but o far as we love ome other thing; o that he who can be free from this Paion, would be exempt from all others. Amongt Trancendents Truth is tronget; not that which is ill defin'd, The conformity of our ndertanding with the thing known; ince there are things above us which urpas the reach of our capacity, and yet ceae not to be true: But this Truth is a property and affection of Entity, wherewith it is convertible; and, conequently, cannot be truly defin'd, no more then the other Trancendents; ince a Definition requires a Genus, which being uperiour, and more common, cannot be aign'd to Entity, or Truth, which is the ame with Entity; otherwie there hould be omething more general then Entity; which is aburd. And although the nature of this Truth is not ditinctly known, nevertheles the virtue of its effects is very enible; for it acts every where, and in all; yea, above the tronget things in the world, whoe actions depend upon the verity of their Eence, which they uppoe. And as this Verity is the Principle of the actions of all Agents, o it is the End and Firt Mover, which gives rie to all their inclinations, whereby they all tend towards one Good, which is nothing ele but Truth, which gives weight and value to Goodnes: But the force of Verity appears principally in that it acts upon the mot excellent thing in the World, to wit, the Undertanding, which it convinces by its light, wherewith it extorts conent; and this o much the more as the Undertanding is perfect; as we ee in the Undertandings of the Wie and Learned, who more eaily uffer themelves to be overcome by Truth, than the Vulgar; and in thoe of Angels and Intelligences, who likewie yield to Truth. And becaue Verity and Entity are the ame thing, therefore God, who poees Entity Originally, is alo the Prime Verity, which our Lord attributes to himelf in the Gopel, when he aith, That he is the Truth and the Life. For whereas Truth is oft-times altered and clouded in the world, and frequently produces Hatred, the mot infamous of all Paions; 'tis a defect not found but in diolute Spirits, who cannot upport
the brightnes of it, and hate its light becaue it dicovers their faults: Yea, even when men contradict the Truth, and follow the deprav'd motions of their mot diorderly Paions, 'tis allways under an appearance of Goodnes and Truth. But if the hadow and appearance alone of Truth, hath o great an Empire over our minds, as is een in the mot erroneous Opinions, which never want followers; with more jut reaon mut it elf, when known, be invincible, and the tronget thing in the World.

In concluion, were propos'd amongt the tronget things, Time, which conumes all; Death, which overthrows all the Powers of the Earth; Place, which embraces all in it elf; and Neceity, o potent that it is not ubject to any Law, but gives the ame to all other things, which cannot avoid its Empire; inomuch that the Ancients eteem'd the Gods themelves not exempted from it, but ubject to the neceity of a Detiny.

div.head: CONFERENCE CII. I. Of the Gowt. II. Which Condition is mot expedient for the acquiition of Wiedom, Riches or Poverty?
div.p:
THe Gowt, (called Arthritis, or Morbus Articularis) is the general name of all aches of the Joynts caus'd by fluxion,
Of the Gowt. which gave it the name of Gowt; and is different, according to the divers connexions of the Bones, and the Parts which it afflicts, being term'd Podagra in the Feet, Chiragra in the Hand, and the Ichiatick ach (by the vulgar, Schiatica) in the Hip. Nevertheles every Articular Pain is not the Gowt, as appears by Contuions, Luxations, Wounds, and the Pains of Women after Child-birth; in Virgins after their Evacuation; and in Bodies infected with the French Dieae: But 'tis a Grief of the Parts indu'd with ene which are about the Joynts, accompanied ometimes with welling, and caus'd by the fluxion of a harp and erous humour, tranmitted out of the Veins and Arteries, into thoe Parts whoe motion it hinders; and becaue the Feet are mot remote from the ource of heat, therefore Nature commonly drives thither the matter of this Malady, whereunto they are more dipos'd then other Parts, as well by reaon of their compoition of Nerves, Tendons, Veins, Arteries, Membranes, and Ligaments, permatick and cold parts; as of their continual motion, which gives occaion to the fluxion: Hence the Gowt begins uually at the Feet, epecially at the great Toe, whoe motion is greatet; which hinders not but that it begins too in the Hand, Knee, and Hip, and ometimes in the Sides; and if the matter abound, ometimes it eizes upon the Joynts with
uch violence as would make Nature uccumbe, were the fits continual, and not periodical, as they are; giving to ome an interval of a year; to others, of ix months, or les, according as there needs time for collecting the humour in thoe parts. The caue of this vehement pain is the acrimony of the corroive and mordicant humour, which makes a olution of the parts, whoe coldnes renders this evil almot incurable, and makes it lat fourty days; the pain not being appeaable, aving when the caue which produces it is reolv'd, whereunto the coldnes of its ubject is not proper.

The Second aid, That in the Gowt, as in all orts of Fluxions, four things are to be conider'd; the Matter which flows, the Place whence it comes, the Way by which it paes, and the Parts upon which it falls. As for the firt, the Gowt hath ome Matter; not being, as ome hold, a imple Intemperies, which could not ubit o long, nor caue uch pungent pains, much les a tumour, as it happens ometimes in the part afflicted, which cannot proceed but from the affluence of Matter: This Matter ome affirm to be Wind, or Flatuoity, with as little reaon; for then it might eaily be reolv'd, and would caue only a pain of ditenion. Mot hold that 'tis the four Humours, arguing from the diverity of Symptomes of this Dieae, and the various manner of curing; ome being eas'd by hot Aliments and Medicaments, others by cold: And latly, from the different colour of the tumours, appearing ometimes red, white, or of ome other colour, by reaon of the blood, phlegm, or other humours which produc'd them: But though a very acute pain may in this malady, as it doth in all others, attract the humours which abound in the body, and o caue a tumour; yet this humour which makes the inflation, cannot be the caue of the Gowt; ince at the beginning, and before the parts are inflated, the pains are very great; but ceae and diminih upon the appearing of the Tumour. Some have held it to be Blood alone; others, Melancholy; ome, Bile, in regard of its mobility and activity; many, following the authority of Fernelius, that 'tis a cold, phlegmatick, and erous humour, and that every Gowt is cold. Mercurialis oberving that Blood could not caue uch great pains, that Melancholy was too heavy and thick to be active, Bile too ubtile to decend, and Phlegm too cold to excite uch pungent pains and udden motions, which cannot proceed from a cold caue; conceiv'd it was Phlegm mingled with Bile, the latter erving as a Vehicle to the former, and that former to precipitate and make this latter decend. Some others, confeing their ignorance, acknowledg, Qu' on n' y void goutte, that they ee not a jot in this Matter; referring this Dieae to occult and malignant caues, acting by an unknown property, as contagious and venemous dieaes do. I conceive it to be a alt humour, ubtile, and picquant, partaking of the nature of Salts, which are all corroive; which acrimony and mordacity of this
humour is caus'd by the Salt or Tartar contain'd in its ubtance, or deriv'd to the Aliments (whereof the humours are produc'd) from the Earth, which is full of uch Salt, Nitrous, or Tartareous Spirits, without which it would be unfruitful and barren, as is een in Earth whence Saltpeter is extracted, which can never produce any thing. This Nitrous Spirit being all drawn out of the Earth by the Plants which erve us for food, and not being tameable by our heat, much les convertible into our ubtance (for an Animal is nourih'd with what is weet, and hath had life, wherewith thee Mineral Spirits were never provided) if the natural Faculty be trong, it expells them with the other unprofitable Excrements of the firt concoction, and Urine and Sweat; and ometimes forms the Stone in the Kidneys, Bladder, or other Parts: But if it happens, either through the weaknes of the expulive Faculty, or the quality of the Matter, or ome other defect, that this Tartareous Spirit is not expell'd, then it is carry'd with the Blood into the Parts, and being unfit for nutrition, tranpires by the Pores, if it be ubtil enough; or ele, in cae it be thick, and cannot be reolv'd, flows back into the great Veels, and thence into the Joynts, where ometimes it is coagulated into knots and grits, and turn'd into a hard matter, like chalk or plaiter, (which hews, that the four Humours are not the matter thereof, ince the ame do not uppurate) rendering then the Gowt incurable, and the Reproach of Phyians, becaue they find no Cure for it; no more than for that of old Men, thoe who have a dry Belly, and who live diorderly: But 'tis curable, aith Hippocrates, in young people, in uch as have no gritts or hardnees form'd in the Joints, thoe who are laborious, obedient, and to whom ome great Evacuations arrive, many having been cur'd of it by a Dyenterie. As for the Place where it is form'd, and the Way whereby the Matter which caues this Evil, decends; mot, with Fernelius, conceive 'tis the Head, not the internal part of the Brain, whoe Excrements are eaily voided outwardly by the Notrils; or inwardly, by the Infundibulum or Tunnel, and other Cavities; but the outward part between the skull and the skin; which being too thick and compact to give iue to the phlegmatick and erous humours there collected, being begotten of the Excrements of the Jugular Veins, which are expanded over all thee Parts, thoe erous and thin humours glide down between the Skin, and other Feguments, into the Joints: But the Place of this Nitrous Matter above-mentioned, are the Vicera of the Liver and Spleen, which generate this Matter two ways. 1. By the vitioity of Aliments impregnated with this Nitrous Spirit, which they plentifully attracted from the Earth; whence it is that Wine, which hath more of this Spirit and Tartar then any other Aliment, is, by conent of all, very hurtful to the Gowt. 2. By their proper vitioity; namely, a hot and dry Intemperies; whereby, intead of concocting, they adure the Blood, and o fix that alt
eroity, which is the Salt or Tartar extracted out of its ubtance: Unles you had rather ay, That as in the Kidneys of Perons ubject to the Stone, there is a certain arenaceous or lapidifick contitution, proper for producing the Stone; o in the Vicera of thoe who are ubject to the Gowt, there is a particular arthritical dipoition, apt to beget that tartareous matter which produces it. The Way whereby this Matter is expell'd is the Veins and Arteries; thee Veels manifetly welling when the fits of the Gowt begin. Moreover, as this Dieae unexpectedly invades, by a udden afflux of the Matter; o it uddenly changes place, epecially by means of Refrigerants and Repercuives, which drive the Gowt from one Foot to the other, or into the Hand, and other Parts; which cannot be done but by the Veins and Arteries. Latly, The Parts upon which this Matter falls, and which are about the articulations, are membranous and enible, becaue the Membranes being the firt ubject of Touch, ought to be alo of Pain, a Symptom thereof.

The Third aid, That the greatet difficulty was, Why this matter rather falls upon the Joints than other Parts, which are not incommoded therewith, neither the Nerves nor the Veins through which it paes, no more than the Membranes and enible Parts; beides thoe which are about the Joints: The caue whereof may be, That as in health the Parts by a trange property attract uch humours as are fit for their nutrition; the Lungs, bilious Blood; the Spleen, melancholy Blood; the Kidneys, erous; the other carnous Parts, temperate Blood: o in icknes, and ill contitution of the Body, ome of thee Parts attract from all the ret certain humours wherewith they have mot affinity: So in the new Dieae call'd Plica Polonica, the vicous and glutinous humour which produceth it, is chiefly carri'd to the hair, which it knotteth and inta • gleth together; and to the nails of the Hands and Feet, which it makes hard and black: And in the cure of Fracture of Bones, the Stone call'd Oteocolla taken inwardly is carried towards the broken Bones, and caues them to re-unite. In like manner, the Humour producing the Gowt hath ome affinity with the Bones of the Joints, epecially with their Epiphyes.

The Fourth aid, That the Gowty have wherewith to comfort themelves; not o much for that they foretel the changes of the Air and Seaons, as for that this Dieae is a token of health, and an evidence of the trength and vigour of Nature, which from the noble Parts drives the vicious humours upon the Joints. But amongt its antecedent caues, the Air is not to be forgotten; epecially the hot and moit Air of the Spring, thawing the Humours lately congeal'd by the Winter; to the vitioity of which Air, is that popular Gowt to be referr'd of which Athenaeus peaks in the econd Book of his Deipnoophits; which lated twenty years, and afflicted two thirds of Men, Women, and Beats; although ome attributed it to the want of Mulberries,
which fail'd during thoe twenty years, and which, they ay, are good againt the Gowt, becaue they looen the Belly, and correct the heat of the Stomach. Women, as Hippocrates aith, are exempt from the Gowt, aving in the uppreion of their Evacuations; Children, before the ue of Venery; and Eunuchs, always; although the intemperance and luxury of all of them hath produc'd contrary experiences, as well in this Age as in that of Seneca; which made the Poets ay, That the Gowt was the Daughter of Bacchus and Venus; the firt, engendring plenty of crude humours; the econd, debilitating the heat, and cooling the Body; which being render'd laxe, the humours fall more eaily upon the Joints. And to hew the oddnes of this Dieae; Anger, Fear, and Joy have oftentimes both given and cured it, the Humours being extreamly agitated by thoe Paions.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, That Wiedom being a Habit mix'd of Science and Virtue, Which Condition is mot expedient for the acquiition of Wiedom, Riches or Honour? Poverty gives much more dipoition to either than Riches; the Mind of a Poor Man being more capable of Knowledg than that of a Rich; either for that Nature compenates the want of the Goods of Fortune with thoe of Nature; or becaue Neceity and Hunger harpens and renders them more ubtile; or ele becaue being free from the cares and pains caus'd by the conervation or acquiition of Riches, they have a more calm Spirit, and more capable of the Sciences, which require quiet and tranquillity of Mind. And as for Virtue, whoe paths are o thorny, Poverty hath alo many more accees thereunto than Riches, not only in the Law of Grace, in which our Lord aith, That 'tis eaier for a Cammel, or a Cable, to pas through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the Kingdom of Heaven; whereof nevertheles the gate is the practice of Virtues: but likewie in the moral ene of this preent life, in which Poverty and affliction, according to the Scripture, gives Undertanding and Prudence, teaches Temperance, Sobriety, and Chatity (its ineparable companion) diciplines us to Patience, and to uffer couragiouly the mieries of Life, the frequency whereof renders the Mind invincible. On the contrary, Riches are amot always accompanied with Vices mot repugnant to Wiedom; as, amongt others, with Preumption, Vanity, Voluptuounes, and Delicacy; the firt of which is oppoite to Science; for Pride proceeds only from Ignorance; the econd to Virtue, which the Poet calls maculine and laborious. Moreover, Nature hews us of what quality Riches are; for the and that produces Gold is always extreamly barren and naked of all orts of Fruits; and o are the Minds of thoe that poes it; and 'tis oberv'd. That rich Nations, and uch as live in a good oil, are the mot vicious, lazy, and dull; whereas thoe who are in an unkind Land, are ordinarily more virtuous addicted to Indutry.

The Second aid, That as the Goods of Fortune, no les than thoe of the Body, are referr'd to thoe of the Mind, as the Means to their End; in like ort, the inconveniences both of Fortune and Body are hinderances in acquiring thoe Goods of the Soul, which are the perfection of its two principal Faculties, the Undertanding and the Will; namely, Knowledg and Virtue: For Knowledg, and the Arts call'd Liberal, require a generous and liberal, not a ordid and low Soul, like that of a Poor Man (whom Alciat's Embleme very well repreents, by a Lad with one hand tretch'd up into the Air, with Wings fatened to it, intimating a deire to fly higher; but the other hand fatened to a heavy Stone, hinders him:) For their Spirit being loaden with miery, thinks of nothing but of the means how to live, and to be deliver'd from the heavy yoak of Neceity, which deprives them of the means of having either living or dumb Teachers; yea, makes them depie all the rigours of Laws, and oft-times abandons them to Rage and Depair, which makes them hate their mierable life, and renders them maters of thoe of others: Hence not only Mutinies, Seditions and Revolts are commonly made by the Poor and Mierable, lovers of Innovation, wherein they are ure to loe nothing, and may poibly gain; but alo are almot the ole Authors of Thefts, Murders, and Sacriledges. Whereas Rich Perons, having from their birth receiv'd uch good Intruction as the poor want, are more tay'd in their Actions, and better inclin'd to Honety and Virtue, which without Fortunes or Etates can never produce any thing great and coniderable; whence, in our Language, Riches are jutly tiled Means; without aitance whereof, Jutice can neither render to every one what belongs to him, nor repel the Enemies of the State by a jut War, whereof Money is the Sinew and principal Strength. Upon this account they are ought after by all the World, and are not only the end of the noblet part of Morality and Oeconomy, (Families, which are the Pillars of a State, not being preerv'd but by the lawful acquiition of Wealth; in which, for this reaon, ome Politicians place Nobility; but all agree, that they erve for an Ornament thereunto and heighten its lutre); but thoe who have parted with them cannot live without them, but are contrained to beg of others. And in Policy, whether Riches be acquired or come by ucceion, they are always in eteem; as on the contrary, Poverty is diparag'd with reproach, and is a ign either of baenes of Extraction, or of Negligence and profuion. Hence a Poor Man is as unfit to be truted with a Publick Charge, as with a um of Money; and 'tis not without reaon, that he who is ditres'd with Poverty is extreamly aham'd of it, this defect hindring and being a remora to all his deigns: Whereas Riches raie the Courage, incite to great Attempts, and erve for a pur to Virtue, which thrives by Praie and Glory, but freezes and languihes by the Contempt and Deriion ineparable from Poverty; which
indeed hath been commended by the ame Sacred Mouth which requires us to turn the other cheek to him that trikes us upon the one; yet this hinders not, but that (peaking naturally, as we do here) 'tis better to defend ones elf, than to be beaten patiently.

The Third aid, That in matter of Wiedom we ought to refer our elves to the wiet of all Men, Solomon; who prays God to give him neither Riches, for fear of Pride; nor Poverty, for fear of becoming a Thief; but a middle Etate: For, as too great Plenitude and an Atrophy are equally contrary to Health, which conits in a moderation and temper of qualities; o the condition of Perons extreamly Rich, and that of Begger (the degree here under conideration) is equally an enemy to Wiedom: And if in any cae we ought to deire the Golden Mediocrity, 'tis in the acquiition of Wiedom, epecially of Virtue, which conits in Mediocrity; either extreme whereof, is the Territory of Vice.

div.head: CONFERENCE CIII. I. Of Glas. II. Of Fucues, or Cometicks.
div.p:
AS there is in all ublunary Bodies a vital and celetial Spirit, without which neither Food nor Phyick hath any virtue, and which is the principle of all actions and motions of mix'd Bodies; Of Glas. o all thoe Bodies have in them an incorruptible Matter, partaking of a celetial Nature, which the Chymits call Virgin-Earth, and is the Matter whereof Glas is form'd, being found in all orts of Bodies capable of calcination and vitrification; but chiefly in Nitre, Saltpetre, Sand, Shels, certain Stones, Wood, and Plants, from which they draw Glas, different in beauty, according to the Matter whence it is extracted by means of a mot violent fire, which reolving the compound, conumes all its parts except that vitreous matter, which is proof againt its violence. We owe its Invention, by Pliny's tetimony, to certain Merchants of Nitre, who having landed in Phoenicia of Syria, bordering upon Judaea, near a Lake call'd Cendevia, which is at the foot of Mount Carmel, whence flows the River Belus or Pagida, of mall extent; and making their Kitchin upon the Sand of this River, us'd ome clods of their Nitre, as a Trevet for their Kettle; and the heat of the fire melting the Sand and Nitre into Glas, they took notice of it, and publih'd the Invention. Afterward Moulds were found out, wherein to cat it into all orts of figures; Pipes or Tubes to run it in; others to blow it, and give it all orts of Colours, which almot miraculouly arie from the very ubtance of the Glas, without other mixture, only by the wind and blat manag'd according to the
rules of Art; as alo Mills, to calcine and pulverie Gravel, Stones, or Sand; amongt which, that of Vilturne in Italy, and of Etampes in France, is mot excellent for this ue; for which likewie they imploy the Ahes of a Plant call'd Salicot, (Salt-wort, or Glas-wort) which grows in Provence and Languedoc, nam'd likewie Soude, becaue heretofore it erv'd only to glae earthen Pots.

The Second aid, As there are but two things that can open Bodies in order to their eparation, namely, Water and Fire; which is verifi'd by the proofs made by Refiners of Gold and Silver; o there are but two things to eparate, to wit, the Volatil, and the Fix'd. Fire commonly eparates the Volatil, uch as ulphureous and aqueous things are; and Water eparates the Fix'd, as the Salt from the earthy parts. Of Fix'd things, ome are o in part, as the ame Salt; others intirely, or altogether, as Earth; which is either limy, clayie, or andie, which lat pecies is made of the two former, as is een in Rivers, where the Water having wah'd away the fat part, nothing remains but the Sand: By which means Nature renders Valleys and low Places more fruitful; and men, by her example, have oftentimes rais'd, meliorated, and render'd low and marhy places, formerly unprofitable, fit for culture, by tirring the Earth during the Rain and Floods, which by this means carries away all the fat and unctuous parts from the higher places into the lower, rendring the Mountains and Hills andy, and conequently unfruitful and barren. For, as Sand is incorruptible, being neither putrifi'd by Water nor conum'd by Fire; o neither can it generate any thing, nor be turn'd into any other nature, like other pecies of the Earth, which erve for nutriment of Plants and ome Inects, and for the production of Animals. On the contrary, it preerves things buried in it, as appears by Mummies kept in it for two or three thouand years; and Fruits, which are kept no way better than in Sand. Now, as Sand is the Matter of Glas (for any Sand melted in the Fire vitrifies) o Glas uits with the nature of its Principle, being, like it, incorruptible and eternal; yea, being it elf one of the Principles of Nature, according to modern Chymits, who reckon four; namely, Mercury, reembling Water; Sulphur, or Oyl, correponding to Air; Salt, to Fire; and Glas, to Earth; which Glas is found clean and pure in the centre of all mix'd Bodies, there being nothing but may be reduc'd into ahes, and no ahes but of which Glas may be made, which they call a hining and not burning Fire, having affinity with that of Heaven, as the Fire kindled in Sulphur, and any oylie Matter, is both burning and hining; and that which is in Lime and Salts is burning, and not hining, uch as is een in Potential Cauteries, but not (as others have aid) in Coals, which have ome although a weak light. Glas wants but one thing, and that is the removing its brittlenes or fragility; were it not for which, it would be the mot precious thing in the World.
Of the poibility hereof a certain Artit having hewn a tryal to Tiberius, hath rais'd a deire in others to make like attempts, which have hitherto been unuccesful. Moreover, the Tranparence of Glas, caus'd by the implicity and tenuity of its parts, is incompetible with the conitence which renders things ductile and malleable, which is a tenacious vicoity, and oleaginous humidity, from whence opacity proceeds; as appears by Horns and colour'd Glas, which is les tranparent then other, by reaon of the unctuoity of the Sulphur employ'd to give it that extraneous colour.

The Third aid, That Archimedes, in his Fabrick of a Glas-Sphere, was as judicious, in reference to the matter he choe, as the form; ince the Matter of the Heavens being incorruptible and diaphanous, they cannot be repreented better than by Glas, which hath both thoe qualities. Moreover, all the perfectet Bodies of Nature are of a vitreous ubtance; as, amongt others, the firt of all the Heavens, call'd the Crytalline. 'Tis held, That the glorified Bodies are luminous and tranparent, and (according to ome) of a vitreous Nature; which is the utmot perfection of every Body, and hall be alo communicated to the Earth at the lat Judgment, to be executed by Fire, which brings Mettals to their highet degree of excellence; for by the help of Lead, Gold it elf is turn'd into Glas, o pure and perfect, that in the Apocalyps Paradie is pav'd with uch Glas of Gold; and in Ezechiel, God's Throne is made of it; the word Hamal being a fit Etymologie for our Emah (or, Enamel) which is nothing but Glas. And the affinity or correpondence of Mettals with Glas is o great, that, like them, it is extracted out of Sand, elaborated in a Furnace, receiving the alliances of Nitre, Copper, and the Load-tone, which they mingle in its Mine, to get an attractive quality of Glas as well as of Iron. With purifi'd Glas, call'd Sal Alcali, they counterfeit the Diamond, Emerald, Turcoie, Ruby, and other precious Stones. The Eye it elf, the noblet part of Man, ymbolies with Glas, by that crytalline humour wherein the point of the viual ray terminates. But as all things in the World, like Fortune which governs them (whom the Poet decribes of Glas) are no ooner arriv'd to the point of their perfection, but they are mot ubject to be corrupted; o Fragility is ineparable from Glas, arriv'd to that high degree; which proceeds from the connexion of the Fix'd and the Volatil, which cannot but be brittle between two bodies extreamly arid, as the ahes of Glas-wort and Fern are with Sand.

The Fourth aid, That as Gold is the Mater-piece of Nature, o is Glas of Art, which cannot produce any thing more noble. Hence in France the making of it is permitted only to the Nobles or Gentry, as a mark of the noblenes of Glas, the fairet and cleanet of all Bodies, as partaking the mot of Light, the noblet and divinet of all ublunary Bodies, to which alone its affords paage through its imperceptible pores, being by that
means the mot ueful and delightful piece of Architecture; the beauties and proportions whereof cannot be een but by Light, half of which Lattices intercept, but Glas communicates intire; erving, moreover, to correct the defects of ight in old men, by Spectacles; and of the Countenance, in Looking-glaes; by means of which, Man perfectly knows himelf. But to judg how Glas may be malleable, we mut know that it is compos'd of two Subtances; the one, Earthy; the other, Gummous, erving for cement to unite thoe dry parts, whoe connexion in any Body whatoever is impoible, but by aerious humidity, without which the Earthy parts would fall to dut. Now to remedy the brittlenes of Glas, 'twere expedient to find out two Matters whoe union might be cloer, or to link them together better by ome more humid and oleaginous Matter than the ordinary, which would no more hinder the tranparence of Glas than it doth that of Talk, which is wholly oleaginous in its ubtance, and nevertheles diaphanous and flexible. The Fire likewie, being very harp and violent, conumes almot all the moiture of Glas, and makes it more brittle, for which reaon it ought to be moderated.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, As Beauty is the mot excellent quality of the Body, Of Fucues, or Cometicks. and the mot apparent token of the Beauty and Goodnes of the Soul; o is it the mot deired: Love, the trancendent of all concupicible Powers, being it elf nothing ele but a deire of Beauty; and Good, the object of the Will, being nothing ele but the ame with Fair. But this Paion is mot conpicuous in Women, who have receiv'd Beauty as all their portion from Nature, and that wherein all their power and authority over Men conits. Now Beauty being ubject to the detiny of all other things, 'tis reaon that Art upply the defects of Nature, for preerving that rich treaure from the injuries of Time and Years, by variety of Paints; as ineparable from the perons of Women, as the deire of being fair is natural to them. Moreover, lpian, in Lib. 25. Sect. 4. ff. De auro & argento legato, has given them a more particular property in their Cometicks, than in their Cloaths and Jewels, reckoning thee only amongt external Ornaments, but Paints and Pomatums in the Inventory of their Feminine Accoutrements, as things annex'd to their Bodies, and making up part of its hape and eence. Thee Cometicks, beides Contentment and good Nourihment, the natural and internal Principles of Beauty, (amongt the pecies of which Nourihment, Aes milk was us'd by Poppaea, Nero's Mitres) may be divided into uch as only cleane the pots and obcurities of the kin, uch as polih it, give it lutre, take away wrincles, often and mooth it; and uch as colour it. The firt are the mot innocent, being nothing but imple Waters ditill'd of Flowers, as Lillies, Nenufar, Bean-flowers, Primroe, eeds of Cucumber and Melon, roots of
Dock, Serpentine, Cuckow-pint, Solomon's-Seal, Gladon, Kidney-beans, Lupines, the Liquor ditilling from the branch of a Vine wounded, Juice of Limons ditill'd in Balneo-Mariae, and May-dew. Of the econd ort, the gentlet are Whites of Eggs, Conummates of Veal, Sheeps-marrow, Snail-water, the Oyls of Almonds, Seeds of Gourd, Myrrh and Camphire, and above all, the no les famous than rare Oyl of Talk, the Philoophers Stone of all Cometicks. As for colouring materials, there are but two orts in Europe, where Beauty conits in a lively Whitenes; namely, Whites and Reds: Reds are made of Sanders temper'd in Vinegar, the havings of Brail or Alkanet, in Allum-water; or, of Vermillion. Whites are made commonly of Sublimate, Cerue, or Spanih-white, wah'd in the water of wild Taney, or of Pearls calcin'd and apply'd as Vermillion, by thoe who account nothing in Nature more precious than Beauty. The Teeth, Hair, and Hands, as they contribute to Handomnes, o they have their peculiar Cometicks. The Teeth are polih'd by Powders and Opiates; epecially by Acidum of Sulphur, and the Spirit of Vitriol mingled with common Water. The Hair receives uch colour as is mot agreeable in each Country: In Italy mot Women guild theirs with an ounce of Honey, a drachm of Saffron, and the yolk of an Egg mingl'd in Barbers-uds; or ele they rub the Comb well with Oyl of Matick and Tartar. On the contrary, at Ragua they black the Hair with Litharge, Black-lead, or with leaden Combs. In France they powder them, to make them white. At Tunis, and throughout all Barbary, the Women black the ends of their Fingers, Nails, and Lips with green Walnut-hells, as our Ladies and Courtiers lay black patches upon their Faces, to heighten or et off its whitenes the more. In fine, there is no part of the Body but receives its Fucus and Colour; only the Eye, like the Soul, whoe Mirror it is, is ubject to no alteration of colour; from which Nature hath with good reaon left it exempt, that being unprepoes'd of any, it might be the judg of true Beauty.

The Second aid, 'Tis injurious to blame the Artificial Handomnes of Ladies, ince nothing can pleae us in any other things without it; Natural Beauty being like a rough Diamond, unles Art polih it, and give it a foil. That we differ one from another, we owe to Artifice; being all equal by Nature. The goodliet Palaces appear o only by reaon of their incrutations of Marble, Guildings, and Pictures; and Painting it elf, whoe excellence is nothing but the cunning mixture of Colours, is heighten'd and preerv'd by the uperinduction of Varnih. Muick is flat without Quavers and Sharps, which are diguiings of the Voice. All the Arts erve for nothing but the ornament and embelihment of Man. What is Eloquence, with all its flowers and colours of Rhetorick, but a Fucus of natural Dicoure? or Pleading, but the Art of etting off a Fact well, and rendring
it plauible? The Complements and Civilities of Courts, what are they ele but a cloaking and diguiing of the thoughts? The truth is, Life being nothing but a Comedy, wherein the habits, actions, and dicoures are only diguies; are we to think it trange that Women, who allways play one of the principal parts in it, ometimes borrow Masks to diguie their Countenances? And if the ininuations and praies, made ue of by Men to cares them, are nothing but flatteries, why hould not they too reciprocally endeavour to deceive Men, whilt they repreent for the object of their Lies only the Image of Artificial Beauty?

The Third aid, That the Countenance being the Tablet and Mirror of the Soul; as Hypocriie and Lying in the Soul, is contrary to Candour and Sincerity, without which there would be no confidence nor true Friendhip in the World, but perpetual diimulations and diffidences; o a Fucus upon the Face is unlawful, and the more pernicious in that it is a peaking Lye: For as a Liar peaks otherwie than he thinks, and hath another thing in his Mind than upon his Tongue; o a painted Face appears outwardly wholly other then what it really is; unjutly covering, under the plaiter and tincture of a Fucus, its natural imperfections and defects; which to go about to mend, is to reit the Wiedom of God, the Author thereof, who dipoing all things wiely, hath perhaps deny'd the advantage of Beauty to certain Perons, out of fore-ight that they would abue it; and who otherwie having imprinted the Character of his Divinity upon our Countenances, the Peron that paints and diguies the ame, eems to be ingrateful, and unworthy of uch a favour; yea, to deprive himelf of all credit among honet men: For, who will give belief to the Words of one that wears a Lye upon his Fore-head? Beides that in time thoe Mixtures alter and detroy the health of the whole Body; Sublimate (amongt the ret) the commonet of all Cometicks: Not to mention the danger of letting it get into the eyes, and more of wallowing it down, it wrinkles the skin, renders the eyes hollow, blacks the teeth, and corrupts the breath.

The Fourth aid, ince Beauty is one of the four gifts of the Body, it ought not to be of wore condition than the other three, Health, Strength, and Goodnes of the Senes; but 'tis lawful to preerve and encreae the ame o far as we can, epecially that of the Viage, which being the Mirror of the Deity, hould be carefully adorn'd and embellih'd; conidering too, that our Lord commands us in the Gopel to wah our Faces, and uffer'd his own Feet to be annointed with precious Unguents; the ue whereof was common among the Ancients, who annointed the Head, and all the ret of the Body, with Aromatick Oyls and Compoitions, more for Beauty than for Health. And Phyick, in one of its parts call'd Cometica, treats of Fucues, and Ornaments of the Body and Face; which the Law approves in L. 21. ff. De Auro Mundo, making four orts of Fucus, namely, for
Pleaure, Health, Ornament, and Cleannes. Moreover, 'twould eem a contempt of that Divine Gift of Heaven Beauty, not to preerve it. And as no man, being to chue a dwelling-houe, but prefers a handom and agreeable one before another; o, if Souls had the choice of their Bodies when they come into the World, they would undoubtedly take the fairet and bet hap'd, becaue they might exercie their operations bet therein. And indeed the Soul is o curious of this Beauty, that as oon as any troke, or other external injury deforms the Body, it ceaes not to repair the ruines thereof; and without the continual indutry which he imploys, not only to re-etablih the perpetual deperdition of our triple ubtance, but alo to caue re-generation of the conumed fleh, the re-union of parts dijoyn'd by olution of continuity, and to reduce to a better conformation the depravations thereof, there would be more Monters than Men. Why then hould it be a crime for Art, which perfects Nature, to ait her in this work, by taking away what is uperfluous, or adding what is deficient; which are alo the two parts of Phyick.

div.head: CONFERENCE CIV. I. Of Tobacco. II. Whether the Invention of Guns hath done more hurt than good.
div.p:
THe Herb call'd by the Spaniards Tobacco, from an Iland of the ame name in the Wet-Indies,
Of Tobacco. wherein it grows in abundance, is nam'd by the Indians Petun; by others, for its great virtues, Herba Sancta; and Jean Nicot, Embaador of Francis II. having firt brought out of Portugal into France ome of the eed of it to Queen Catherine de Medicis, with the decription of its virtues, it became denominated from him in French Nicotiane, or Herbe a la Reine, (the Queens Herb;) as in Italy it was term'd Herbe de Santa Croce, (of Holy Cros) becaue a Cardinal of that name was the firt that brought it to Rome. Some others till call it Antarctical Bugloe, Henbane of Peru, and Indian Wound-wort. It grows, many times, to the height of three Cubits, with a traight and thick talk, o fat that it eems annointed with Honey; it ends forth undry large branches, with many leaves long and broad, rounder than thoe of great Comfrey, omewhat like thoe of great Peronata, or Bur-dock; flehy, fat, and little rough, of a pale green, unpleaing mell, and biting tate: On the top of the talk it hath many flowers, oblong, hollow, and large, in form of a Trumpet, of a white inclining to purple; to which ucceed little lender cods or huks, full of a brownih eed, maller than that of Poppey. Its root is thick,
hath everal lobes, is woody, yellow within, bitter, eaily eparating from its bark, and, like all Herbs hot and dry, (for this is o in the econd degree) it requires moit places and hadow, and delights to be cultivated. Moreover, 'tis kept in Gardens, as well for its beauty, as for its faculties of curing abundance of Maladies; to which 'tis the more proper, in that it hath an unctuoity familiar to our Body, whoe excrementitious humours (the eed of mot Dieaes) it potently reolves. For as Plants are of a middle nature between Minerals and Animals; o they are more proper and afe for the preervation and retoring of Man's health than Animals themelves, which by reaon of their imilitude act les on us; or than Minerals and inanimate Bodies, which through the too great diverity of their nature act with too much violence.

The Second aid, That this Herb heats, reolv's, deterges, and is omewhat atringent; whence it is, that its leafs apply'd hot to the head cure the Meagrim and old headach, proceeded from cold or wind; and if the pain be contumacious, you mut rub the place firt with oyl of Orange-flowers. Moreover, 'tis us'd for the Cramp, and all other pains ariing from the ame cold humour; particularly, for that of the Teeth, by filling them with the leaf bruis'd. Its decoction in common Water is good for maladies of the Breat of the ame kind, as the Athma, and old Coughs, cauing expectoration of the phlegm which produces it. Alo, Its moak taken by the noe, and wallow'd down by repiration, frequently cures the Athmatick, and uch as have ulcers in the Lungs; by the ame reaon that Galen aith, he aw a Baker's Wife cur'd of one, by frequent repiration of a hot and dry Air, which he attracted as he put her bread into the Oven, and took it out again. The leaves roated under the ahes, and apply'd hot with their ahes to the Navil, are good for the Wind-collick, and other obtructions of the Bowels proceeding from the aboveaid caues; epecially, for crudities of the Stomach. The Indian women make ue of it to kill worms, making their children take a very little quantity of it with Sugar; but more afely by applying the leafs to the Navil, and adding a very little of the juice in lotions. The ame, apply'd, helps the Stone-Collick, and is highly advantageous in trangulations of the womb, being laid likewie upon the Navil; and if Women have their uual woonings, the moak puff'd into their notrils fetches them again. They alo eae the pains of woln limbs, and cold Gowts. Scurf, Itch, Child-blanes, and clefts of the heels, proceeding from cold, are cur'd by being rub'd therewith, as alo venomous wounds and bitings: Whereof the Spaniards bear witnes, who eizing upon a part of the Indies, the Cannibals aaulted them with envenom'd Arrows, the wounds whereof they cur'd by prinkling them with prepar'd Sublimate; all their tock whereof being pent, the wounded dy'd, till it was found that the juice of Tobacco, apply'd, wrought the ame effect. Moreover, the leaves
top the blood of freh wounds, and agglutinate them. The juice heals old Ulcers, and prevents Gangreens. The Indian Priets, oberving all thee virtues, transferr'd them to the Myteries of their Religion: For being interrogated concerning the events of War, they uck the moak of this Herb with long Canes, then uffer themelves to fall down, and being afterwards awakened, relate wonders to their hearers, giving them to undertand that they have had divine Dreams. They make ue of it likewie, to recover wearines, and upport hunger, burning certain hells, and powdering them with equal quantity of thee leaves, of which they make pills, which they lay between the lower lip and the teeth, continually ucking their liquor, which, if it nourih not, at leat it takes away the ene of the inconveniences of hunger and thirt; which is an admirable ecret, whereby they travel two or three days together. Poibly by their example our Sailers, and Souldiers who have been at Sea, take Tobacco with o much pleaure, that ince they have once gotten a habit of it, they cannot be broken from it by the everet Laws: For to alledg the prejudice of exceive taking Tobacco, is of no more moment than what hould be aid againt Wine for its abue; it having been aid by many, That thoe things mut be excellent which are capable of being abus'd; and this may always be inferr'd from that immutable practice of Tobacco, That there is a great familiarity between it and our Nature; ince the Grand Signior cannot hinder his Turks from the ue of it, who nevertheles abtain from Wine.

The Third aid, That if ever Pliny's condemning and decrying Drugs and forreign Roots was reaonable, it was chiefly at the time when the Trade of the Indies tranmitted them to us in Europe, and, with their ue, new and unknown Dieaes: Amongt which Medicaments, Tobacco, as 'tis the mot common, o 'tis the more dangerous, in that a fale opinion of health and purgation gives it credit, although its temperament, hot and dry in a high degree, renders it not only contrary to young and cholerick people, and to the tomach, which it provokes to vomiting; but by a peculiar malignity 'tis an enemy to the Brain, cauing Stupefaction, Vertigo, Lethargy, and a dulnes of all its Powers, and by a violent deiccation poling its natural contitution: For 'tis o far from di-inebriating, that, on the contrary, by its harp and biting vapours it fills the head, and intoxicates much more; like Opium, the herb of which it reembles; neither of them erving for any thing but to trouble the Reaon; upon which account Tobacco is a worn enemy to Hellebore, which every one knows is the remedy for Folly, and promotes the good contitution of the Brain. As for the evacuation of phlegm, for which it is eteem'd; beides that 'tis a dangerous thing to purge uch as are in perfect health, as mot takers of Tobacco are; 'tis certain, that all ort of moak is bad for the Brain, which it clouds and dulls, by tirring the animal Spirits,
and filling the cavities of its Ventricles, which it alo infects by its mell, and pricks its Membranes by its Acrimony, ineparable from every kind of fume; it being found, that men have had black cirrhous pots in the Meninges, produc'd by the vapours of Tobacco they were accutom'd to take; which Cutom alo enuring Nature in that manner to evacuate the pituitous excrements, whereof the Brain is never detitute, if the ue thereof be at any time interrupted, great accidents happen by that defluxion, which had gotten a long coure that way, and turn'd the Cutom of it into Neceity; which ue. (beides) being hameful, and proper only to Rogues and Robbers, whom our Arrets comprie under the name of Takers of Tobacco; it eems that the name and effects of this Herb are of as bad an odour as its moak.

The Fourth aid, That the Brain being the ource not only of all cold maladies, but alo of mot affections of the Lungs, whoe cituation and pongy ubtance makes them the Emunctory of all the uperiour Parts; whence the Athma, Peripneumonia, Empyema, Phtiick, Cough, Orthopnaea, and other affections of the Breat, caus'd by defluxion of humidity falling from the Brain upon the Lungs; Phyick hath invented three orts of Remedies to divert the coure of thoe Excrements, namely, Errhines, Ptarmicks, and Apophlegmatims. Errhines compos'd of Rue, Gentian, Celandine, Origanum, and other deterive Simples, attract the phlegm adhering to the Membranes of the Brain, and evacuate it by the Noe. Ptarmicks, or Sternutatories, which are made of the above-mention'd things powder'd, or of Pepper and white Hellebore, Euphorbium, Catoreum, and Pyrethrum, by their acrimony timulating the expulive faculty of the Brain, to excretion of the pituitous Excrements which are in its Ventricles. Apophlegmatims, us'd either in Maticatories or Gargarims, or by rubbing the palate of the Mouth, are made of Matick, roated Raiins, Hyop, Origanum, bark of Caper-roots, Mutard, Turbith, and uch other things as melt and attenuate phlegm, and make it ditil down the Palate of the Mouth. Now Tobacco may erve for thee three Ues, being taken either by the Noe, or in the Mouth, as a Maticatory; but not in moak, which is an enemy to the Brain and Spirits.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, That Nature having given wild Beats Horns, Whether the Invention of Guns hath done more hurt than good. Claws, or Teeth for their defence, has yet produc'd Man wholly naked, and without any other Arms but thoe of Reaon; to hew, that being a Reaonable Animal, he needed no other arms to decide his Quarrels with his like, but Jutice and right Reaon. Nevertheles, Neceity having oblig'd him to defend himelf from Beats, Robbers, and Publick Enemies, he hath, intead of fifty-cuffs, tones, cudgels, and bones of Animals, his firt Weapons, made ue of Iron, framing
it into Swords, Axes, Spears, and Javelins; till encreaing in malice, to offend at greater ditance, he invented Slings and Balits, then ambulatory Machins to enter Places, and beat down the Walls of Cities: Yea, Fire was likewie brought into ue; by ome, that of Burning-glaes, with which Archimedes burnt the Ships of Marcellus, who beieg'd the City of Syracue; by others, Granado's, and Pitch-barrels et on fire, as Caear did at the Siege of Mareilles and Alexandria. But all this was nothing, in comparion to the Gun; which although, according to the Portugal Relations, invented in the 85. year of our Lord, in the Kingdom of China, where mot other Inventions began, by one of their Kings, nam'd Vitey, a great Magician; yet appear'd not in Europe till about the year 1350. when it was found out by one named Bertoldus, a German, occaionally, by the experience which he aw happen in a mixture of Sulphur and Nitre, inclos'd in a veel over the Fire, in order to an operation of Chymitry, whereof he made profeion. This michievous and diabolical Invention, having been hatch'd in the Country of the North, (whence the Scripture aures us that all evil is to come) was afterwards carried from thence into Italy, and then into France, Anno 1366. by ome Germans, who alo gave two pieces of Artillery to the Venetians who beieg'd Claudia Foa, a Town belonging to the Genoees, from whom it was preently taken by thee new Engines; which, although mall, and ill made, being only of Iron bow'd, and hoop'd together with Iron bands, yet fail'd not to produce their effect.

The Second aid, Since Kings are call'd Gods in Scripture, 'twas reaonable they hould be arm'd with Thunder, which might make them reverenc'd by others; there being no better expedient to preerve Majety, than Terrour. And as the depravation of men renders War in thee lat Ages as neceary as jut; o, without doubt, the mot powerful way of overcoming, mut alo be the mot advantageous and coniderable. This is it which hath made Artillery o eteem'd by Sovereigns, that they have lodg'd it in Arenals and Magazens with their Treauries, and given it in charge to great Maters, principal Officers of their Crown; making a hew of it to Strangers, as the abridgment of their Power, and a mark of their Soveraignty. Moreover, 'tis by this Cannon-Law that all their Quarrels are decided: Thee are the lat Embaadors which carry their Commands with execution; and thoe whoe ears are topp'd to their other Reaons, always find peremptory ones in the mouth of their Cannons. For as the Moaical Law was given amongt Thunders and Lightnings from Mount Sinai; and that of Chritianity confirm'd by a Tempet of Wind and Fire: In like manner, Princes at this day etablih not their Laws more powerfully than by help of the Thunder-claps of their Artillery; as the Conquet of the new World makes manifet, the eaines whereof is due only to this Invention, which made thoe Nations receive Laws of Religion
and State from uch as hot the firt Cannons amongt them, at the report of which they preently yielded; conceiving that there was omething divine in thoe Machins, which have likewie been the Keys of Gold, wherewith they have enriched Europe by another way of Alchimy than that to which the Diciples of this Science employ it. Moreover, by this Invention, which ecures Commerce, the boldnes has been taken to overrun the World, and depoil it of all its Riches; the Conquet whereof hath been more or les eaie, according as its ue was known or unknown to the invaded Nations. The truth is, he that hall make comparion of the ancient Machins, Rams, Slings, Balits, or Bows, with any Fire-Arms whatever, will find that theirs were but Childrens-play, in repect of our true Combates. And o far is this Invention from doing wrong to Valour, that (on the contrary) it advances the ame to its highet point: For if Valour appears only proportionally to the dangers it incurs, then there is mot room for the exerciing of it where the greatet are preent. Now the ruine of ome particular Perons, is not coniderable, in repect of the publick advantage, to which the good of every one, conider'd by himelf, is ubordinate; eeing that thee Arms erve as well for the Defenive as the Offenive, the one and the other being only repective, regard being had no thoe that employ them; that which erves for defence to one, being offence to the other. And beides, the Sword, which for o many Ages hath kill'd many more, would be more ubject to this blame. But, on the contrary, the excellence of a Weapon conits in killing and terrifying, ince 'tis an Intrument of War, whereof the principal end is to exterminate Enemies; for the fewer are left, the ooner it is ended; and in the peedy razing of their Fortrees, conits the beating down of their Pride and Confidence. Wherefore, eing no Invention in the World can be without its inconveniences, one or two cannot counter-balance the good which Artillery hath brought, by the Conquet of o many Kingdoms and Riches; o that if Arms are mot uefull for the preervation and amplification of a State, the Invention of the Gun mut be the more o, inamuch as it is the mot powerful Intrument of War, urpaing all other Arms in execution; and making a Prince not only obey'd during War, but alo repected and redoubted in Peace, during which 'tis employ'd to tetify the publick rejoycings and gladnees.

The Third aid, As Philoophy is the noblet exercie of Man, o Morality is the fairet part of Philoophy; whence Socrates acquir'd the honour of having brought it down from Heaven. The mot excellent part of Morality is the Politicks, of which the noblet piece is the Art Military, as Mechaniques are the noblet part of this Art. Hence Caear is more particularly exact in decribing the contruction of his Bridges, and other Engines, than his war-like exploits. Since then the Gun is without
dipute the goodliet part of the Mechanicks, it follows that the Gun and its Invention is the goodliet thing of the World. For the excellence of an Engine conits in moving a great weight peedily, and to the greatet ditance that may be, as the Cannon alone doth, whoe power would be judg'd impoible, did not Experience attet it: Nor doth its violence depend upon the ordinary rules of Nature, the Principle of the regular motion of every Body; but 'tis caus'd by the ame Nature contituted in a violent tate, in danger of admitting either a Vacuum or penetration of Dimenions; to avoid which, he ometimes breaks the Cannon; or, if the ame be too trong, he violently drives out the iron bullet, which hinders the free eruption of the inflamed matter, which, by reaon of the rarefaction of its parts, requiring 10000 times more place than before, and not finding the ame in the Cannon, iues forth to eek it; by the ame reaon that an Exhalation inflam'd in the middle Region of the Air, diengages it elf from its prion, by breaking the Cloud which holds it inclos'd in its belly, thereby forming the Lightnings and Thunders, whereof the hots of the Cannon are true Images upon Earth, where nothing comes nearer Thunder; and conequently the Power of God, who oftentimes imploys thoe Arms to punih the crimes of men: Whence Pagan Antiquity aign'd indeed everally a Trident, a Sythe, a Bow a Helmet, a Lance, a Club, a Sword, and uch other Intruments, to their fale Deities; but all attributed Thunder to the mightiet of the Gods.

div.head: CONFERENCE CV. I. Of Blood-letting. II. Which is the mot Excellent of the Soul's three Faculties, Imagination, Memory, or Judgment.
div.p:
BLood-letting, (whoe invention is fabulouly attributed to the Sea-hore, who finding himelf too full of Blood, Of Blood-letting. rubs himelf againt the harp points of Reeds or Canes, and afterwards tops the wound with mud) is celebrated either in the Arteries, and is call'd Arteriotomie; or in the Veins, and is term'd Phlebotomie; which Phyitians, by good right, hold with Galen (in the Book which he writ thereof againt Eraitratus) for a ingular remedy, and one of the readiet for all orts of Dieaes, epecially Inflammations, Fevers, Revulions or Derivations, griefs of the Eyes, difficulties of Urine, Pleuriie, Peripneumonie, Squinancy, Epilepie, Fractures, Luxations, and all acute Pains and Dieaes. And as there are two general and mot frequent
caues of Dieaes; namely, Plethora, or Repletion; and Cacochymia, or depravation of the Humours: Blood-letting is the remedy of the former, and Purgation of the latter: But Blood-letting is the bet and afet, cauing les agitation and diturbance in the Oeconomy of the Body than Purgatives, which are ordinarily violent, and enemies of Nature; yea, it erves not only to evacuate the juices which abound in exces, but ometimes remedies their depravation, by correcting the hot and dry Intemperies of the Bowels, which is the caue of Cacochymie; becaue Bleeding of its own Nature evacuates and makes revulion, but, by accident refrigerates, and takes away obtructions: Therefore Avicenna, and all his followers, enemies of Blood-letting, are ridiculous; alledging, That the Blood being (Fraenum Bitis) the bridle of choler, this becomes exaperated and enflam'd, the les Blood there is to retrain it. For if there be any Humour that keeps Choler in order, it mut be Phlegm, which is contrary thereto; and not Blood, which ymbolies with it by heat: But Blood-letting checks the impetuous motions of Choler, which it evacuates with the Blood, if it be in the greater Veels; and if out of them, as about the cavities of the Liver, it tempers them, correcting the ardent contitution of the Liver which produces it.

The Second aid, That by reaon of Contraries, affections againt Nature, as well as Health, have their eat in the Parts, Spirits, and Humours. The Parts are the eat of Maladies; the Spirits, of Symptoms and laeion of Functions; and the Humours, of the Morbifick caues, either antecedent or conjunct. And as thee humours, which are the ource and leven of mot Dieaes, being in a natural tate, are in their proper place, in the quantity and quality requiite to their Nature; o in a tate againt Nature, they are out of their due place, and offend either in quantity or quality. To thee three defects Phyick oppoes Revulion, Alteration, and Evacuation; this latter is done either by evacuating only the bad, by convenient ways in Purgation; or the good with the bad, Blood-letting, which is defin'd an Evacuation of all the humours of the Body, by ection of the Veels. For though the Blood be the Treaure of Life, the Source of all Paion, and (if we believe Galen) the Seat of the Soul; nevertheles, its corruption, as that of the bet things of the World, being o much the more dangerous as it is the mot perfect and temperate of all the Humours, it mut be preently evacuated out of the Body; not only in plenitude, where Nature requires nothing but to be dicharg'd; but alo in depravation of the Blood, by mixture of the other Humours corrupted; of which the les there is, the more eaily they are ubdu'd by Nature, which wants not trength to re-produce more laudable Blood than that from which he was unburden'd: But regard mut chiefly be had to the ditinction of Veins, according to the diverity of Dieaes. So the mot apparent Veins of the
arms are open'd when the Body is plethorick, without affection of any Part: If it be o by uppreion of the Moneths or Hemorrhoids, the Vein of the Foot mut be open'd: If it be by Choler, then that of the right arm: If by Melancholy, then that of the left arm, in regard of the ituation of the Liver and Spleen; as for the various communication of the Veels the Cephalick, Bailick, or Median are choen. Hippocrates opens the Vein of the Forehead call'd Praeparata, in pains of the Hinder part of the head; that of the Occiput, in fluxions of the Eyes; the Hypoglottides, or Veins under the Tongue, in the Squinancy, for derivation; that of the tip of the Noe, or great Canthus of the Eye, in its Inflammations; the Jugulares and Salvatella, thoe of the Temples; and, in brief, all others are open'd according to the undry intentions of the Phyitian.

The Third aid, That Blood-letting is the greatet of Remedies; there being none ooner communicated to all the Parts, which having need of nourihment, which is carried to them by the Veins, you cannot evacuate any one enibly, but that motion will be communicated with all the Blood in the other Veins; that is to ay, over all the Body. Its ue was anciently o rare, that Galen and the Greeks made concience of letting Children blood before fourteen years of Age; and Avenzoar was accounted too ventrous in Phlebotomiing his own Son at even. Hippocrates appoints it in four caes; in Inflammation, Metatais, Repletion, and Obtruction. 'Tis above all neceary, when the Body is too replete, evidenced oft-times by pontaneous evacuations at the Noe, and Hemorroids; whether this Repletion repect the Veels, which are too full, and in danger of breaking; or the natural trength, oppres'd under the weight of the humours: But it eems to me impertinent and unprofitable in cae of Cacochymie without Repletion, which requires Purgatives to purifie the anguinary mas, and not this bleeding Remedy: For, there being three principal eats of Cacochymie, to wit, the Firt Region, the Veins, and the Habit of the Body; Blood-letting is alike unprofitable to them all.
