As for the Firt Region, which is the ink and channel of the humours, Blood-letting cannot reach thither, without emptying all the Blood of the Body; and hould it penetrate thither, it would draw thoe excrementitious humours into the Veins, where they would corrupt the laudable Blood. But Cacochymie reiding in the Region of the Veins, Purgation (which only eliminates the corrupted humours, without the good and laudable) is more proper thereunto than Phlebotomie; which, on the contrary, ometimes evacuates the good juice, and not the vicious, when the ame is impacted and adherent to ome part remote from the open'd Vein. In fine, Blood-letting is as little profitable when the impurity is in the habit of the Body: Whence 'tis too hard to draw the humours into the Veins; but it is more expedient to reolve and make them tranpire by weats, exercie, abtinence, and other labours.

The Fourth aid, That Blood-letting is profitable in every vitioity of the Blood, which either is corrupted in ubtance and quality, or offends in quantity, or caueth a fluxion upon ome Part, or prees and loads it, or ele is too much inflam'd: Nevertheles with this precaution, that regard is to be had to the Dieae; the trength, temper, age, ex, habitation, cutom, and particular nature of the Patient. But generally, every great, hot, and acute Dieae requires Phlebotomie; which, on the contrary, is an enemy to cold Dieaes, and all crudities; becaue it refrigerates, by the los of heat and pirits flowing out with the Blood. Alo, diminution of trength, caus'd by any evacuation or reolution, prohibits bleeding; but not that where the trength is oppres'd by abundance of humours, which mut be preently eliminated. Children, who need Blood for their growth, as breeding Women do for the nourihment of their Child; old men, who want heat and Spirits; thoe who have mall Veins, or rare and oftih fleh; ought not to be let blood but with great precautions. Nor is Phlebotomie to be adminitred in great cold or great heat, nor after great watchings and labours. And although the quantity of Blood depends upon the trength, and the Dieae, yet 'tis afet to take rather les; but by no means to imitate the Ancients, who let Blood till the wooning of the Patient, in Inflammations, violent Pains, and very burning Fevers; which they ometimes cur'd by this coure, but commonly caus'd a cold Intemperies to the whole Body, during the remainder of life.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, That God having in the Univere imprinted an Image of his own Majety, Which is the mot excellent of the Souls three Faculties, Imagination, Memory, or Judgment? to the end to make himelf known to men, hath alo contracted the ame in each part thereof, wherein we oberve ome hadow of the ditinction of the Divine Eence into Three Perons: And 'tis with this Ternary Number that he hath as 'twere tamp'd for his own Coin the noblet parts of the World, which the Pythagoreans have alo for that reaon divided into three; namely, The Intellectual, which are the Heavens, (the place of Intelligences); the Elementary, and the Animal; each of which is again divided into three parts; The Intellectual or Celetial, into the Heaven of Planets, the Firmament, and the Empyreal; The Elementary, into the Air, Water, and Earth; And the Animal, into Vegetable, Senitive, and Rational, which is Man, who comprehends in himelf eminently all thoe parts of the World; the Elementary being in the Liver, the Animal in the Heart, the Intellectual in the Brain, wherein, as in its principal Sphere, the Rational Soul etablihes a particular World; every ones Head being a Globe, which is divided again into three parts, which are the Imagination, Memory, and Judgment: Amongt which, the Imagination, the principle of the others motion and action, repreents the animal World; Memory, erving for a ubject matter to receive the
impreions of the pecies conign'd to it, is the Elementary; and Judgment, the Intellectual. The three parts of each of which Worlds are again correpondent to the ame Faculties. The Imagination, upon account of the continual circumvolution of the Species, is the Heaven of Planets: The Memory, in reference to the fixation of the ame Species, is their Firmament: And the Judgment, the highet of thee Powers, is the Empyraeal. To the three parts of the Elementary, The Imagination, for its mobility and ubtilty, is like the Air; Memory, for its oft humidity, fitting it to receive all orts of Figures, may be compar'd to the Water; and Judgment, the bae and foundation of the ret, for the olidity of its conitence and iccity, ymbolizeth with the Earth. Latly, to the three parts of the Animal World; the Memory, receiving increae or diminution by humidity, the principle of vegetation, reembles the Vegetable; the Imagination, by its heat and activity, the Animal; and the Judgment, the Rational. And though thee three Faculties be united in the ubtance of the Soul, nevertheles they are different, not only in their temperaments, actions, and ages, but alo in their eats; as that of Memory is the hinder part of the Brain, which people cratch to call any thing to mind; that of Imagination is the forepart, whence they lift up their heads when they would vehemently imagine any thing; and that of Judgment is the middle part, which is the caue why in a deep tudy people hold down the head. But to make choice of each in particular, their operations mut be conider'd: Some make very much noie, and little action; as Advocates and Proctors of a Court, who make much a do to put a buines in order, to lay it open, and diget it, although without deciding any thing; and uch is the Imagination, which unites and compounds the Species, repreents them to the Judgment, carries them to the regiter of the Memory, or extracts them out by Reminicence. Others make little butle, and much action; as Judges; and o doth the Judgment. The lat have neither tir nor action; as the Regiters, who only trancribe what is dictated to them; and o doth the Memory, a paive Power. The Sciences themelves, which fall under the Juridiction of the Mind, are alo ubject to each of thee Faculties. Memory hath under it the Tongues, Grammar, Poitive Theologie, Hitory, Humanity, Law, Geography, Anatomy, Herbary, and almot all the Theory of Phyick. The Imagination hath Eloquence, Poetry, Muick, Architecture, Geodaeie, Fortifications, mot part • of the Mathematiques, and all the Arts whoe works depend only on the force of the Imagination. The Judgment hath Philoophy, Scholatical Divinity, the Practice of Phyick and Law, and all the Sciences which depend on oundnes of reaoning. Nevertheles, becaue it eems that the Judgment cannot judg to its own advantage without injutice, being both Judg and Party; 'tis bet to arbitrate in this ort, and ay, That the excellence and neceity of things being conidered, or o far
as they are for our profit, or that of others; for our own profit 'tis bet to have a good Judgment, and les of Memory or Imagination: For the Imagination erves more for Invention, and this to ruine its Author when it is detitute of Judgment; Memory to make a man admir'd; and Judgment, for conduct and government.

The Second aid, Since the Imagination gives the rie to all the motions of the Soul, by the Species which it upplies to it, wherewith it forms the Paions in the Inferior Appetites, Deires in the Reaonable Appetite, namely, the Will; and Notions in the Undertanding, which cannot know any thing but by the phantams or pecies forg'd in the Imagination; it mut be the mot excellent of all the Faculties of the Soul. Moreover, the Temper which contitutes it being the mot laudable, and the Age wherein it prevails being the mot perfect, its Actions mut alo be the mot ublime; ince being not performable but by help of corporeal Organs, the more perfect thee are, the more will the Minds actions be o too. Now the Qualities of the Imagination have much more conformity to the Soul, according to the Opinion of ome Ancients, of an igneous nature; and according to others, an Entelechie and continual motion, which either caues or depends on heat, the mot active quality of all, wherewith the Brain being impregnate, renders the Spirit more lively, quick in retorts, and in all that they call Pointe d' Eprit, or acumen; and inpiring Enthuiams to Poets. On the contrary, the Judicious, who want this Imaginative Virtue, are cold, heavy, and as tedious in converation, as the other are agreeable and welcome: Yea, the Judgment it elf ows all its advantage to it: For if it were equitable, it would regulate it elf only by the pecies which the Imagination repreents to it; and if it be corrupted, and without having regard to the pieces offer'd to its view, will follow its own entiments, it runs the hazard of committing a thouand extravagances and impertinences. Yea, all the Judicious Sciences are ambiguous, and their followers divided; a ure note of their weaknes, as well as of that of Judgment which guids them; ince Abtracted Truth, its Object being unknown, it mut leave the ame in perpetual darknes, unles it borrow light from the Imagination. Moreover, the Sciences, Arts, and Diciplines of this Faculty are all pleaant, and as delightful and certain, as thoe of Memory are labile, the Faculty only of Children and Liars. Yea, the maladies of the Imagination are in uch veneration, that Hippocrates calls them Divine, as having miraculous effects.

The Third aid, That there is no intire and perfect Good in this World, is verifi'd alo in the Goods of the Mind, which are not often poes'd by one ingle man, but every one hath his hare therein: For goodnes of Wit, coniting in the excellence of his three Faculties, Imagination, Memory, and Judgment, the firt of which forms the pecies, the econd preerves, and the
lat judges of, and frames its Notions from them; 'tis a very rare thing to find a man poeing thee three advantages in an excellent degree; beides that, they are incompatible in one and the ame ubject, inamuch as they depend upon the contrary temperaments. The Memory on a hot and moit, uch as that of Children; which nevertheles mut not be like water, which eaily receives, but retains not, all orts of Figures; but it mut be aerial, and have ome conitence and vicoity to retain the imprinted pecies. The Imagination requires a hot and dry temper, for fabricating and compoing abundance of pecies; like that of cholerick and young men, who are inventive and indutrious. The Judgment demands a contitution of Brain cold and dry, like that of melancholy and old men, to hinder the udden eruptions, or allies of the Mind; which therefore reaons better when the Body is at ret, than when it is in motion, which produces heat, as much an enemy to the operation of the Reaonable Soul, as profitable to thoe of the Senitive or Vegetative, whoe actions are perform'd by the Spirits, and Heat. But the Imagination cannot know any thing without Memory, which furnihes it with pecies; nor this remember, without help of the Imagination; nor the Judgment conceive and judg without the help of both. Nevertheles, as amongt Qualities there is always one predominant; o amongt thee three Faculties, one commonly excels the ret; and the Judgment is the more excellent, inamuch as 'tis peculiar to Man; whereas the Imagination and Memory are common to him with Beats. So that the Judgment is our proper good, and is better worth cultivating than the Memory, to which they who wholly addict themelves, are like bad Farmers, who improve others Commodities, and let their own perih. On the contrary, they who only form their Judgment, acquire the true Treaures of Wiedom, and may be aid rich of their own Stock: But great Memories are commonly like Aeop's Crow, adorn'd with borrow'd Plumes; and indeed raie admiration in the weak minds of the Vulgar, but not in thoe who are accutomed to olid Truths, the Principle whereof is the Judgment.

div.head: CONFERENCE CVI. I. Of Dew. II. Whether it be expedient for Women to be Learned?
div.p:
IF Pindar deem'd Water o good, that he thought nothing better to begin his Odes with; Dew, which is celetial Water, deerves to be eteem'd, Of Dew. ince it urpaes that as much as
Heaven, whence it comes, is elevated above the Earth. For Heaven is the ource of Dew, whence it ditills hither below, impregnated with all aethereal qualities and properties, incommunicable to any other thing; whether it come by a trancolation of uper-celetial Waters, which the Hebrews call Maim in the Dual Number, to ignifie the Waters on high and thoe below; or whether there be a Quinteence and Reolution of the Heavens whence it proceeds, like thoe Waters which Chymits ditil from Bodies put into their Alembicks, indu'd with their odour and other qualities, and ometimes augmented in virtues: Whence ome Divines endeavour to derive the reaon why Manna, which is nothing ele but Dew condens'd, for fourty years together wanting one Moneth, and allotted by God for utenance of his people, had all orts of Tates; for (ay they) Heaven, whence it fell, contains eminently, as the efficient equivocal caue, all the forms of things to whoe generation it concurs here below; and therefore God employ'd this Dew to repreent the everal kinds of each Aliment, And Honey, whoe weetnes is o familiar to our Nature, (yea, o priz'd by the Scripture, that God promies his people nothing o frequently, to raie their longing after the Land which he had promis'd them) what ele is it but this ame Dew condens'd and gather'd by the Bees, who rubbing their thighs upon the flowers and leaves of Plants on which this Liquor falls, load themelves therewith, and lodg it in their hives? Wherefore Naturalits eem too gros, in teaching, Dew to be only a Vapour rais'd from the Earth, by the heat which the Sun leaves in the Air at his etting, and; for want of other ufficient heat, unable to advance it elf higher than the tops of herbs: for its tenuity and effects manifet the contrary; its tenuity much exceeding that of Water; witnes their experiment, who make an egg-hell fill'd with Dew acend alone to the top of a Pike plac'd a little bowing in the Sun; which it will not do, if fill'd with common Water, how rarefi'd oever. Its effects alo are, to penetrate much more powerfully than ordinary Water; which is the reaon why it very peedily whitens whatever is expos'd to it, as Linnen and Wax; for the effecting of which, Rain requires thrice as long time: But its penetrativenes appears yet further, in that it diolves even Gold it elf; for which reaon ome have thought fit to wah everal times in it uch Medicaments as they would have penetrate, as well as others are wont to do in Vinegar.

The Second aid. If it uffic'd to peak of Dew in a Poetical way, I hould call it the weat of Heaven, ther pittle of the Stars, the dropping of the celetial Waters, or the crytalline humour which flows from the eyes or the fair Aurora; or ele that 'tis a Pearl-Garland, wherewith the Earth decks her elf in the morning, to appear more beautiful in the eyes of the Sun, and the whole Univere; to which if the Vapours erve for food, the Dew is its Nectar and Ambroia. But to peak more oberly,
I conceive it a thin and ubtle Vapour, rais'd by a moderate Heat; till either meeting ome Body, it adheres thereunto; or being attracted neer the Middle Region of the Air, 'tis condens'd by cold, and falls down again upon the Earth. Nevertheles, this Vapour proceeds not only from a humour purely Aqueous, but omewhat partaking of the Spirits of Nitre, Sugar, or a weet Salt; ince the thinnet part of it being evaporated, the ret remains condens'd upon leafs and tones, or becomes Honey and Manna; and whoo hall lightly pas his tongue over the leafs of Nut-tree, and other compact and cloe Plants, hall tate a weetnes upon them in temperate Climates or Seaons, which is nothing ele but an extract of this ame Dew. Moreover, the fertility which it caues in the Earth, its purgative and deterive virtue, ufficiently manifet this Truth. For Dew could not fertilie the Earth, if it were bare Water, detitute of all ort of Spirits; and particularly thoe of Nitre, which is the mot excellent Manure that can be ued to improve Land; for the Earth from which it is extracted remains barren, till it have been anew impregnated with thoe Spirits by the influx of Dew, to which they expoe it for ome time, that it may again become capable of producing omething. This purgative virtue, whereof not only Manna partakes (being a gentle purger, of eroities) but alo pure Dew, which ometimes caues a mortal Diarrhoea or Lax in Cattle, purging them exceively when it is not well concocted and digeted by the heat of the Sun, which conumes its uperfluous phlegm; and that deterive Faculty whereby Dew cleanes all impurities of the Body, which it whitens perfectly, cannot proceed but from that nitrous Salt, which, as all other Salts, is penetrative and deterive. Nor can that acending of the Egg-hell proceed from any other caue but the virtue of certain leight and volatil Spirits; which being actuated and fortifi'd by the heat of the Sun-beams, are et on motion; and flying upwards, carry the incloing hell with them; which an aqueous humour cannot do; becaue though the heat of the Sun could o ubtilie, attenuate, and rarefie it, as to render it an aery Nature, which is the highet point of rarity it can attain; yet it would not ooner attract the ame than the ret of the air; much les would it raie up the Egg-hell; but it would tranpire by little and little through the pores of the hell, or be expanded in it o far as it had pace, and at lat either break it, or be reolv'd into fume; Heat imprinting no motion in Water, but only rarifying and heating it by degrees; which is not ufficient to raie up the Veel which contains it, ince the ame being full of heated air, would remain upon the ground.

The Third aid, That all natural things being in a perpetual flux and reflux, to which this Elementary Globe upplies Aliments, to make them return to their Principle; Dew may be term'd the beginning and end of all things, the Pearl or Diamond which terminates the circular revolution of all Nature;
ince being drawn upwards by the Sun from the mas of Water and Earth, ubtilis'd into vapour, and arriv'd to the utmot point of its rarefaction, it becomes condens'd again, and returns to the Earth, to which it erves as perm, to render it fruitful, and to be transform'd upon it into all things, whoe qualities it aumes; becaue being nothing but a Quiteence extracted from all this Body, it mut have all the virtues thereof eminently in it elf. Moreover, anciently the ordinary Benedicton of Fathers to their Children was, that of the Dew of Heaven; as being the perm of Nature, the Firt Matter of all its Goods, and the perfection of all its ubtance, recocted and digeted in the econd Region of the Air: For the ame vapour which forms Dew in the Morning, being that which caues the Serein in the Evening; yet the difference of them is o great, that the latter is as noxious as the former is profitable; becaue the firt vapours which iue out of the boome of the Earth, being not yet depurated from their crude and malignant qualities, caue Rheums and Catarrhs; but thoe of the Morning being reolv'd of Air condens'd by the coldnes of the Night, have nothing but the weetnes and benignity of that Element; or ele the pores of the Body being open'd by the diurnal heat, more eaily receive the malignant impreions of extraneous humidity, than after having been clos'd by the coldnes of the night.

The Fourth aid, Although Vapour be an imperfect Mixt, yet 'tis as well as other perfect Bodies compos'd of different parts; ome whereof are gros others tenuious. The gros parts of Vapour being render'd volatile by the extraneous heat, wherewith they are impregnated, are elevated a far as the Middle Region of the Air, whoe coldnes condenes them into a cloud, which is ordinarily diolv'd into Rain, ometimes into now or hail; into the former, when the cloud before reolution is render'd friable by the violence of the cold, which expreing the humidity, cloes the parts of the cloud, and o it falls in flocks: and into the latter, when the ame cloud being already melted into rain, the drops are congeal'd, either by the external cold, or ele by the extream heat of the Air, which by Antiperitais augmenting the coldnes of the rain, makes it cloe and harden; which his the reaon why it hails as well during the ultry heats of Summer, as the rigours of Winter. And amongt the gros parts of the Vapour, uch as could not be alter'd or chang'd into a cloud, decend towards our Region, and there form black clouds, and mits or foggs: But the more tenuious parts of this Vapour produce Dew; in which, two things are to be conidered. I. The Matter. II. The Efficient Caue. The Matter, is that tenuious Vapour, o ubtil as not to be capable of heat, and too weak to abate it. The Remote Efficient Caue, is a moderate Heat; for were it exceive, it would either conume or carry away the Vapour; whence if comes to pas, that there is no Dew made but during the Spring and Autumn, which
are temperate, Seaons; but never in Winter or Summer, the former congealing thoe Vapours, and the latter diolving and conuming them. The Proximate Efficient Caue is the coldnes of the Night, which mut alo be moderate; otherwie it congeals them, not into Dew, but white-Frot, as it turns the Waters into Ice by the extream cold of the Air; which moreover mut be calm and erene, becaue if beaten and agitated by Winds, the Vapour cannot be condens'd, for the ame reaon which hinders running Waters from freezing, as tanding do; whence alo Dew is more frequent in low places than high. Now as Dew is form'd of Vapour alone; o if together with that tenuious Vapour, ome terrene but very fine parts be carried up, epecially towards the morning, there is produc'd a very weet juice, of which Honey is made; and when thoe terrene parts prevail above the humid parts of the Dew, there is made a les liquid juice call'd Manna, whereof the bet is found in Calabria; that of Brianon, and ome other places, being through want of heat les digeted than is requiite; or mingled with too many impurities, by the exces of that which attracted them too violently from the Earth: But the weetnes of this Honey and Manna proceeds from a mot perfect mixture of iccity with humidity, in a degree which is unknown to us.

The Second aid, That Women are of themelves prone enough to take the acendant over Men, without need of giving them that of Learning, which, puffing up the mind, would render them more proud and inupportable than before; the good opinion they would have of themelves, being inconitent with the Obedience to which they are bound. We read, That our firt Father Adam was indu'd with Knowledg, but not Eve; on the contrary, her ole deire to become knowing, by eating the forbidden Fruit, ruin'd the whole World. The active life of Huwifry, to which they are born; the tendernes of their Bodies, impatient of the labours and weat wherewith Science is acquir'd; the humidity of their Brain, which is an enemy to Science; and the weaknes of their capricious Spirit; are ufficiently trong Reaons to prohibit that Sex the Sciences, which require olidity of Judgment, always found wanting in the Writings of Women accounted the mot Learned: Becaue Judgment is an act of the Intellect, reflecting upon its Notions; which reflection depends upon a dry Temper, contrary to that of a Womans Brain, whoe Animal Spirits being obcur'd by the clouds of humidity, he hits well ometimes at the firt aay, but not in econd thoughts, which are always weaker than the firt; a mot ure mark of their weaknes: (On the contrary, the econd thoughts of Men prevail over the firt.) Whence it is that they are heady in their deires, and violent in their firt Paions, wherein ordinarily they have neither meaure nor mediocrity: Therefore a Woman always either hates or loves; he never knows a mean.

The Third aid, Since the more imperfect a thing is, the more need it hath of being perfectionated; were the Minds of Women weak and imperfect, as is pretended, it would follow, that they have more need of the Sciences to cover their defects. Had our firt Mother been indu'd with Knowledg, he would not o eaily have uffer'd her elf to be deluded by the fair promies of the Devil, who rightly judging, that Adam with all his Knowledg would have dicover'd his ubtilties, was aware of medling with him, but et upon the poor, ideot, and ignorant Woman. 'Tis therefore an injutice to require Women to be more perfect and wie than Men, and withal to interdict them the means of becoming o: For how hall they be virtuous, if they know not what Virtue is? which being a Habit of the Will (a Faculty of it elf blind, till illuminated by the advioes of the Intellect, which are acquir'd by the Sciences) 'tis impoible for them to attain it. Thoe who doubt let the knowledg of natural things might prejudice the honety and modety of that Sex, know not that the cognition of bad things, as well as of fale, is always honet and laudable; and that the Undertanding is no more oil'd therewith, than the Sun by hining upon dunghils. For though the Will receive tincture of goodnes and evil from the objects to which it tends, yet the Undertanding is not corrupted by the mot impure and abominable things which fall under its notice. Yea, ince Knowledg depends upon purity and implicity; which makes Divines ay, That Angels and eparated Intelligences are more perfect in their cognitions than Men; it eems, the afet coure Women can take for ecuring their purity and Chatity (their only Treaure) is, to make proviion of Learning and Knowledg. Moreover, 'tis a thing unheard of to this day, that a Woman was Learned, and not Chate and Continent; which the Ancients meant to repreent by Minerva the Goddes of Sciences, and the Nine Mues, all Virgins.

div.head: CONFERENCE CVII. I. Whether it be good to ue Chymical Remedies? II. Whether the Reading of Romances be profitable?
div.p:
ALL Sublunary Bodies having been created for the health of Man, who is the Rule of their Temperature, Whether it be good to ue Chymical Remedies? and the Judg and Arbiter of their Goodnes; Phyick coniders them either as Aliments, or Medicaments, or Poyons. Aliments preerve Nature, which aimilates them. Poyons detroy and corrupt it, by communicating their malignant qualities. Medicaments are between both; neither being converted into our
ubtance, as Aliments; nor corrupting it, as Poyons: but either evacuating the peccant humours, or altering Nature, to retore it to its natural temper, when they are rightly adminitred, and not otherwie; the former are call'd Purgative, the latter Alterative Remedies. All thee Remedies were firt found out by Experience, which gave place to the mot ancient Sect of Phyitians, call'd Emperica, invented by Acron, and afterwards upported by the two general Maxims of the Methodits, of whom Thealus was Authour; which were, To looen contipated Bodies; and, To top the fluxions of others. Latly, They have been authoriz'd by Reaon, joyn'd to Experience; which hath given place to the mot authentique Sect call'd the Dogmatits, or Rationalits, and Galenits, from their Author; proceeding upon Hippocrates's Principle, who cur'd Contraries by their Contraries; whereas the Chymits (call'd alo Hermeticks from Hermes Trimegitus, and Spagyricks from the buines of their Art, which is to eparate and conjoyn Bodies) cure like Maladies by like Medicaments; which they ay act by a propriety of their whole ubtance againt Dieaes; not by their temperament or various mixture of contrary qualities, which nevertheles are alone active; for no action can be between things perfectly alike, in regard one thing acts upon another only in order to aimilate the ame; o that if it be already like, there will not be any action. Moreover by the reaon of Contraries, ince Health is preerv'd by things of reembling Nature, it follows, That Dieaes mut be cur'd by their Contraries. And as Health conits in Mediocrity; o Sicknes, either in Exces or Defect: On which account, Phyick is defin'd Detraction and Addition, becaue it retrenches what is uperfluous, and upplies what is deficient. Now both Exces and Defect are increas'd by ue of things alike. Wherefore the Chymical Principle being overthrown, all the Remedies founded thereupon ought to be upected.

The Second aid, That thoe two Principles which eem contrary one to the other, are not o, if rightly undertood: For, when the Chymits ay, That Similia curantur imilibus, they peak not of Dieaes, as the Galenits do, with whom they agree, That the ame are augmented by ue of reembling things; but of the part dieas'd, which (being the Seat of Affections againt Nature) can alone be aid to be cur'd, and not the Dieaes; which being only a privation, errour, or diorder of the Body, cannot be capable of anation, but only the parts of the Body; which the Dogmatits, as well as the Chymits, cure by Remedies like in ubtance to the Nature of thoe Parts which they trengthen: For whatever is a Friend to Nature, call'd by Hippocrates, Morborum Medicatrix, is alo an Enemy to that which is againt Nature.

The Third aid, Since Remedies are the more excellent, by how much the neerer they come to our Nature; it follows, That Minerals, Metals, and all Foiles, precrib'd us by Chymitry,
having malignant and venomous qualities, are much more dangerous than the ordinary Remedies taken from Animals and Plants, which have life as well as we. However prepar'd, they always leave an evil tincture in the noble Parts, and whole Body, againt which they act with violence; which they have not only of their own Nature, altogether remote from ours; but alo from the Fire, which gives them an extraneous heat, contrary and detructive to ours; any dry heat being an enemy to the natural, which is humid and benign; and although they make ue of Medicines extracted from Vegetables, yet 'tis with as little ucces; ince their purgative virtue depends on their temperament, which is wholly detroy'd by their Ditillations and Extractions: Beides that, being all hot, they are unprofitable to all acute Dieaes (ordinarily hot, and always the mot dangerous) and noxious in Fevers, which are generally complicated with mot Dieaes. Moreover, all Remedies acting by the firt, econd, and third Qualities, which depend on a Matter temper'd after a particular Matter; therefore Mixts eparated from rheir Matter, which erves for a bae and foundation to the actions of the Form, loe their former force and virtue, which is more efficacious and enible in a material and gros ubject, as that of ordinary Remedies is, prepar'd by decoction or infuion, in Bolus, Powder, Opiate, Conerve, Lozenges, or uch other olid Body; than in an Eence, Spirit, or the like ubtil and tenuious Body; which freed from its groer parts, which erv'd to check it, flies like lightning into the Parts of the Body wherein the Morbifick caue reides, which it can never ubdue or eradicate, though its virtue hould not preently vanih, but be preerv'd in the Body; which, beides being accutom'd to material things, becaue they conerve and compoe it, it oftentimes receives great dammage from too ubtil things; on which account, the Air of the Supreme Region cannot be attracted by the Lungs.

The Fourth aid, That the Characteritical of a Good Medicament being to Cure Speedily, Certainly, and Pleaantly; the Chymical, being uch, ought to be not only employ'd, but alo preferr'd above others. The peedines of their Effect is from their Forms, which alone are active, epecially when depurated and looned from Matter, a Principle purely paive, and incapable of action. They are alo agreeable and ure, as being depriv'd of their impurities, malignant qualities, bad mells and tates, by means of the various degrees of Fire; whieh if it communicate an Empyreuma or Burntnes to thee Medicines, o it doth, not only to vulgar Remedies prepar'd by Fire, but alo to all our Meats and Aliments. Beides, many of thee Chymical Remedies are prepar'd with a moderate heat, as that of a Dunghill, Ahes, Balneum Mariae, which cannot give them uch Empyreuma: And hould they all have it, yet being but an extraneous and adventitious heat, 'tis eaily eparated from them, either of
it elf in time, or peedily by ablutions, wherewith even Precipitate Mercury is render'd very gentle, and Antimony void of all malignity. What is objected of the violence wherewith Mineral and Metallick Medicines act, by reaon of their diproportion to our Nature, is as little coniderable; ince Hippocrates, and the ancient Phyitians, us'd Euphorbium, Hellebore, Scammony, Turbith, Colocynthis, and uch other mot violent Remedies, which are till in ue; and Galen employ'd Steel, Sandarach, burnt Bras, and the like Medicines, taken from Minerals wholly crude, and without preparation, which was unknown in his time. Rondeletius ues crude Mercury in his Pills againt the Venereous Dieae, whereof this Mineral is the true Panacaea: Cardan and Matthiolus, crude Antimony; Gener, Vitriol; Fallopius, Crocus Martis againt the Jaundies; almot all Phyitians, Sulphur, againt the Dieaes of the Lungs; and uch Patients as cannot be cur'd by ordinary Remedies, they end to Mineral Waters. And ince not only Garlick, Onyons, and Mutard, which we ue in our Diet; but alo the Juices of Lemmons, Citrons, Berberries, and Cantharides, although corroive, are till in ue; why hould we not ue Chymical Medicines in mall quantity, purg'd from their corroion, and taken with convenient Waters and Vehicles?

The Fifth aid, There is in all natural things a certain fix'd Spirit, the ole principle of their Virtues and Operations; which being eparated from them, they remain only Carcaes without Souls: As is een in Earth, render'd barren by extraction of its nitrous Salt; in Wine dead or owre; and in the inipid phlegm of the ame Wine, eparated from its Spirit by Chymical ditillation, which eparates the good from the bad, the pure from the impure, the ubtil from the gros, the form from its more cras matter; in a word, the Spirit from its Body; which being impregnated with the virtue of the whole Mixt, reduc'd into a very narrow Volume, is very active and proper, not only to erve for Aliment to an Animal, which is nourih'd with this Spirit, the ret being unprofitable, and as uch converted into Excrements; but alo principally for the curing of Dieaes, by repairing and trengthning the fix'd Spirits, which are the true feats of Dieaes, as well as of Health; a Dieae being nothing but the laeion of the Functions, whereof the Spirits are the Principles; whereas ordinary Phyitians, intead of eparating the virtues of each Mixt, to oppoe the ame, as Specifical Remedies to all Dieaes, as the Chymits do, tifle and detroy them by the confus'd mixture of abundance of Simples and Drugs, whereof their Medicaments are compounded, which by this means acquire a new temperament and particular virtue, reulting from the ingredients, whoe qualities and properties are abated, or rather extinguih'd; in like manner as of the Elements united together is made a Compound wholly different from its principles. Wherefore we may jutly retort againt uch Remedies,
what they charge upon thoe of Chymitry; namely, That they are taken from dead Ingredients, corrupted and depriv'd, by the Fire, of their Radical Humidity, wherein, conited their prime purgative virtue, which is not o eaily diipated; ince when a Nure takes a Purge, the trength of the Phyick is convey'd by her Milk to the Child; and we feed he-Goats and Pullen with Purgatives, to render the Milk of the one, and the Fleh of the other uch. However, ince there, are o many incurable Dieaes, whoe caues are ufficiently known, but to which no Specifical Remedies are found; Chymitry, which opens the means thereunto by the olution of all Bodies, ought to be cherih'd, and not condemn'd, as it is by the ignorant or malicious, who mut at leat acknowledg it one of the members of Phyick, as belonging to Pharmacy, which conits in the choice and preparation of Medicaments, and is part of the Therapeutical Diviion. But we ay rather, That the three parts of Medicine, or its three ancient Sects, are the three parts of the World, Europe, Aia, and Africa; and Chymitry is that new World, lately dicover'd, not les rare and admirable than the others, provided it be as carefully cultivated, and recu'd out of the hands of Barbarians.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, That Truth is not the mot powerful thing in the World; Whether the reading of Romances be profitable. ince oftentimes Fables and Romances have more attractives, and no fewer followers than Hitories; as the Poets meant to ignifie by the Fable of Pigmalion, who fell in Love with a Statue. For Romances, which are nothing ele but the Images of a phantatick Beauty, are nevertheles lov'd and idolatris'd by abundance of Perons; not only for the Eloquence, whoe fairet lines are een in thoe fabulous Books; but for the Gracefulnes and Gallantry of the actions of their Peronages, which may erve for a perfect model of Virtue; which having never been found compleat in all points in any Illutrious Man, whoe Life is always blemih'd with ome pot, Hitory cannot give us a perfect example to imitate, unles it be aited by Romances; without which, Narrations purely Hitorical, decribing a naked fact, are but excarnated Sceletons, and like the firt lines of a Picture groly trac'd with a Crayon, and conequently diagreeable, if artifice give them not colour and hadows. Thus Xenophon, and in our times Don Guevara, aiming to draw the Model of a perfect Prince, one in the Peron of Cyrus, the other of Marcus Aurelius, have heap'd together o many contrarieties to Truth, that they have made rather Romances of them than Hitories. Thus Achilles's exploits appear far otherwie in Homer than in Dictys Cretenis; thoe of Charlemain, in Eginard and Arioto, than in the Annals: 'Tis to Romances that they owe half their Glory; and if their Example hath given any excitation to the Readers Spirits, 'tis what the Romances aim'd at, not the Hitories. The Romancer is the Mater and Contriver of his Subject; the Hitorian
is the Slave of it. And as by refraction of the viual rays, variouly reflected in a triangular Glas, is form'd an Iris of colours, which although not real yet ceae not to pleae; o by the variety of thoe accidents, variouly interwoven with the mixtures of Truth and Fiction, is form'd o agreeable a Medley, that it delights more in its Inventions than the Body of an uniform Hitory; from which Romances borrowing the mot memorable accidents, may be term'd the Eence and Abridgment of the ame, re-uniting all the Beauty, Pleaure, and Profit which they afford: For thee Books erve not only for delight, but profit; the one never being without the other; ince Fair, which is the object of Delight; and Good, of Profit; are reciprocal and ineparable: And the pleaure we take in any thing is an infallible mark of its goodnes and utility; which is o much the greater in Romances, as they intruct with pleaure, artificially marrying Benefit and Delectation. Under uppoed Names they freely tax, without incurring the envy or hatred of thoe whom they reprehend. Thus the Prophet Nathan by a Parable drew from David the condemnation of his Crime; which otherwie poibly he would never have own'd, or at leat would have excus'd in his own Peron. As for the abue and danger of reading thee Books, for the mot part fill'd with dihonet Loves 'tis common to them with the bet things of the World, that they may be turn'd to a bad ue: But if the Love be honet and lawful (as it proves always in concluion) the Romances deerve no blame for it; if unlawful, the Lovers have always an unhappy end; and Vices are never unpunih'd. 'Tis here that Ditributive Jutice is exactly kept; not by the blind Judgment of Fortune, but by the judicious choice of the Author; that the Good are always rewarded, and the Wicked punih'd. For the object of Romances, as well as of Hitories, is the decription of humane actions; which being mot often bad, by reaon of the depravation of Nature, they appear more candalouly in Hitory than in Romances. Why therefore do not their Cenors likewie procribe Hitories, o much more dangerous, as they afford us many true examples of Sacriledges, Parricides, Adulteries, and Incets, the Authors whereof have ecaped punihment. And not to peak of the dangerous Maxims of Tacitus and Polybius; Who would take the Fables of Herodotus, and the Prodigies of Livie, for more probable things then thoe of Romances? To omit the contrariety of Hitorians of the ame time; o that we may ay, That the truet amongt them is the mot likely.

The Second aid, If the Platonits aying be true, That there is nothing real in this World; but we perceive only hadows and phantams in this life, which the Scripture compares to a Dream; there will be little difference, as to realty, between a Hitory and a Romance. And though the one be a meer fiction, yet this will no more infer the depiing of it, than it doth of a Comedy, becaue the Actors are not the very Peronages; or of
a Landskip or Perpective well drawn, only becaue 'tis the Invention of the Painter, and not of Nature; whoe Works, as excellent as they are, yet yield to thoe of Art, which we eteem above the true and natural, from which the ame are counterfeited; our minds extreamly delighting in Imitations; whence it is that we o much eteem in their Copies and Repreentations uch things whoe Originals are diagreeable to us. But that which augments the glory of Romances is, that their declared enemies have not been able to encounter them but by Romances too; as Plato and Iocrates could not reprehend the Sophiters, but by making ue of their Eloquence.

The Third aid, That Romances are commonly either of the valorous Exploits of Knights, or of Amorous pa-times. The firt are for the mot part ridiculous, and full of Knights Errant, who force Enchanted Catles, kill Monters, Giants, and Men like Flies. The latter are infamous, contrary to Good Manners, and dangerous to young Perons, entertaining them in a looe Idlenes, the Mother of all Vices; beides the dangerous impreions thoe Lies leave in tender Minds, and which remain therein all their life after. But this belongs to all fabulous Dicoures, that they denote weaknes of Judgment in thoe addicted to them, and a diorderly Wit in their Authors. And ince, according to Phyitians, the firt degree of Folly is to imagine phantatical Opinions; and the econd, to tell them to others; the third (in my conceit) will be, to write them.

div.head: CONFERENCE CVIII. I. Of Talimans. II. Whether a Country-life or a City-life is to be preferr'd?
div.p:
TAliman (which the Chaldaeans call Tilmenaia; the Hebrews, Magen; the Greeks, Character) is an Arabick word, Of Talimans. form'd by tranpoition and addition to the beginning and end of the two Hemantical Letters Tau and Nun, of the Hebrew word Telem, which ignifies Image, Figure, or Character. For thoe Talimans (of which Zoroater is made the firt Author) are nothing ele but Images in relief, or engrav'd upon Medals or Rings, ordinarily of Mettal or precious Stones, in hape of Men or Animals, fabricated under certain Contellations and Apects of Stars, whoe influence they thereby receive and keep, being afterwards intead of the ame Stars; yea, with the greater virtue, in that the re-union of influences being made in one point, their activity is redoubl'd: As Burning-glaes take more heat from the Sun, than perhaps he hath himelf. Thee Figures act, as they ay, either upon mens minds, as to caue one to be lov'd,
honour'd, enrich'd, or fear'd; or upon their Bodies, as to cure them: Of which ome hadow is een in the magnetical cure of Wounds, by applying the Medicine to the Weapon that did the hurt, or to the bloody hirt. Or ele thee Figures act upon natural things, as to keep away from a place rain, hail, and wild or venomous Beats; only by natural means: For we peak not here of magical or diabolical Characters, whoe virtues for the mot part depend upon either a tacite or expres compact with the evil Spirit, who ometimes really produces thoe effects, often deludes our Senes; and not the Character, Word, Sound, Number, or uch other means, commonly inept, and uncapable of uch action. But we peak only of natural Agents, which acting almot all by a propriety of their whole ubtance, and by occult and ympathetical virtues, caue many trange effects, which the ignorant Vulgar incongruouly acribe to Magick or Sortilege. There might be doubt of the effect of thee Talimans, if divers Hitories did not give aurance thereof: For thoe Teraphins, uch as Laban's Puppets were, might be call'd Talimans, as the Brazen-Serpent and the Golden-Calf are by Marelius Ficinus; the one to preerve from the morures of Serpents, by its ight; the other to turn away the heats and droughts of the Scorpion, and of Mars. The Idols of the Pagans may alo be put in this rank, as Memnon's Statue in Aegypt, which mov'd and poke when hone upon by the Sun; that of Paphian Venus in Cyprus, upon which it never rain'd; the Palladium of Troy; the Ancilia or Bucklers of Rome, whick kept the Fortune of the Empire; the Dii Penates, figur'd by two Serpents; thoe call'd Averrunci, who kept away dometick misfortunes; Sejanus's Statue of Fortune, which the Emperours left to their Succeors; Virgil's brazen Fly and golden Horeleech, with which he hinder'd Flies from entring Naples, and kill'd all the Horeleeches in a Ditch; the Figure of a Stork, plac'd by Apollonius at Contantinople, to drive them away thence in the year 1160; and that wherewith he drove away Gnats from Antioch; thoe of Tripoli in Syria, and Hampts in Arabia, which were preerv'd from venomous Beats by the Taliman of a Scorpion engraven upon one of their Towers; that at Florence, made againt the Gowt, by a Carmelite nam'd Julianus Ritonius à Prato; thoe of Paracelus againt the Petilence; and infinite others; render their effects as common, as their exitence certain: Which is prov'd alo by the example of Gamahés or Camaien's, which are Stones naturally figur'd by the impreions of the Stars, which conequently may have influence upon Artificial Figures. For as the Sun may lighten or heat a mans Picture, as well as a Man; o may the Stars give their influences to the Figure of a Thing, as well as to the Thing it elf; epecially when the ubject is fitted thereunto, as the Taliman is; not only by its metallick matter, ymbolizing with that of the Star, both in colour and olidity; but epecially by the Figure imprinted
on it, which is like the Sign whoe influences it receives. For though the Contellation be not very like that Figure, yet in regard the Qualities of the Animal which the Figure repreents, are like thoe of the Sign, (whence the Contellations of the Zodiack are call'd, The Ram, the Bull, &c. not for the reemblance of uch Animals parts with thoe of thoe Signs) the Figure of the Animals attracts them of the ame Sign much more powerfully by ympathy. And indeed we ee many things have qualities conentaneous to the Figure they bear; as the Stone call'd Ophites, for the mall veins which cut it in form of little Serpents, cures their poyon; as alo the Stones of Maltha do, which bear the Figure of a Serpents-tongue; and the Herb call'd by that name: The Squill and the Poppy, which reemble the head, awage the pains thereof: Wild Taney and Eyebright cure the Eye, whereto they are like. But if it be aid, That 'tis not the Figure that acts in them, but a particular virtue depending on the temper of their Qualities; ince loing their Figure either by ditillation or infuion, (they ceae not to act, yea more effectually than before. I anwer, That in the pirits of thoe ame active qualities remains always the Form and Figure; as ome Chymits have reucitated Roes and other Flowers, by holding their ahes in a glas Phial, over a Candle.

The Second aid, That Talimans cannot produce the effects attributed to them; whether you conider them in their Matter and Subtance, or in their Figure. Not in the former; for any ort of Matter, as Wood, Wax, Stone, Metal, &c. are made ue of for cutting of thee Talimans; which, beides, loe their Name when they produce an effect by the virtue of their Matter; as a Scorpion engraven on a Bezoar-tone would not cure the bitings of that venomous Animal by its Talimanical Figure, no more than any other; but 'tis an effect depending on the Stone it elf. Nor do Simples cure by the reemblance between the Parts of our Body and their external Figure (of which we peak here), but by the virtue and property of their Subtance, which remains when they are powder'd and depoil'd of their Figure; which, moreover, is a Quality indeed, but no active one; being only a certain ituation and dipoition of Parts, and a mode of quantity; which depending on Matter, a purely paive thing, is as uncapable of any action by it elf, as the Figure which terminates it. But though the artificial Figure of a Taliman could act, it could produce no natural effect, becaue beyond its power; much les upon the Will, to incite Love or Hatred, as is pretended. For 'tis a ridiculous and groundles vanity to imagine a ympathetical Commerce between a Contellation and a Figure of an Animal, graven upon Copper, or uch other Matter, which is much les fit to receive the influences of the Stars to which uch Animal is ubject, than the Animal it elf, whoe skin tuff'd with traw were more proper to drive away
other Beats of the ame kind; there being nothing Living-creatures dread o much as the dead Bodies of their own kind.

The Third aid, It needs not to eek Reaons and Authorities to prove Talimans, either in Art or Nature; ince Man himelf may be aid to be the Taliman and Perfection of God's Works, plac'd by him at the Centre of the Univere; as of old Talimans were plac'd at the Foundations of Cities: His countenance being a Medal imprinted with all the Characters of the Stars, the two brightet of which are at the Eyes; Saturn at the Eye-brows, the Seat of Severity; Jupiter at the Fore-head, the place of Honour; Mars at the Noe, where Anger reides; Mercury in the Mouth, where Eloquence lies; Venus at the Chin, and rounding of the Cheeks, the pourfit of the grace of this Medal, which erves him for an Univeral Taliman, in its Beauty to procure Love; in its Majety, to caue Repect; not only to drive away Flies or Frogs, but to reign over all Animals, by the prerogative of this Face, before which they tremble. Are not his Hands (the Artificers of his Felicity) Talimans noted with the Characters of the Signs and Planets, which the Rules of Chiromancy uncypher? In the Right Hand are his Days and Years, (aith the Wieman) the Taliman of his long life; in the Left are Riches and Honours, the Taliman of his good Fortune. In hort, Is not his Soul the Taliman of his Immortality; which at the intant of its Creation receiving all the influences of the Deity, and retaining the Image thereof, hath been inerted into this Work, not to preerve it from Thunder and Tempets, which can touch only the leat part of it; but from Corruption and Extinction, to which all other Creatures are ubject.

The Fourth aid, He's too enual that impugns the truth of things, under pretext that they fall not under our Reaon; which though very weak and uncertain, abuing the principality which it uurps over all the Faculties, hath turn'd its denomination into Tyrannie: Whence if Experiences be alledg'd he denies them, becaue not able to accord them with the weaknes of her Judgment. Witnes what is een in all the admirable works of Nature and Art, in the Magnetical cure of Wounds, and that of Dieaes, by Amulets or Periapts; and what Cicero and all Antiquity affirms of Gyges's Ring, upon turning of the Stone whereof inwards, he became inviible; and returning it outwards, was perceiv'd. Such alo was Minerva's Shield, wherewith Pereus combated the Gorgons, which was of Glas, through which one might ee, without being een; as alo the Rings of thoe Mitrees of Alexander the Great, and Charlemain. For if it be aid of the firt, That Olympias hewing her elf tark naked to him, made him confes, That the great Beauty of all the parts of her Body was the only Taliman wherewith he enchanted Alexander: The ame cannot be aid of the latter; ince after his death the Talimanical Ring found under her Tongue caus'd Charlemain to love not only her, but alo the Lake of
Aix-la-Chapelle whereinto it was cat; and that which was found in the Foundations of the Walls of this City of Paris, under Chilperic, where there was a Fire engraven upon a Bras-plate, a Serpent, and a Rat; which having been remov'd from the place, the very next day a great Fire happened in the ame City. For if every thing below is as that which is above, and the effects of inferiour things proceed from the various configuration of the Celetial Bodies, as of the different combinations of the Letters of the Alphabet are compos'd infinite Books, there may be ome proportion and correpondence between thoe Celetial Figures, and uch as are made upon fit and uitable materials; the knowledg of which ympathetical Correpondences, is the true Magick; which is, by the tetimony of J. Picus Mirandula, the highet point of humane Knowledg, marrying Heaven with Earth; as black Magick is detetable, hameful, and ridiculous.

The Fifth aid, That every thing acts in the World by the firt or econd Qualities, or by its Subtance; whence proceed occult Properties and Sympathies: But Talimanical Figures cannot act by any of thee ways; for 'tis certain, that they act neither by heat, cold, hardnes, oftnes, or uch other firt or econd Quality, no more than by their Subtance, which is different in Talimans of Copper, Iron, Stone, &c. Although the Authors of this Art acribe the ame virtue to all, provided they be graven with the ame Figures, and under the ame Contellations and Apects of the Starrs, from whom alone they make them derive their, trange virtues; alledging, as a Principle, That there is nothing in the World but hath both its Contrary and its Like, as well in Heaven as on Earth; where we ee not only the Marigold and the Sun-flower follow the motion of the Sun; the Selenotrope, that of the Moon; the Cock proclaims the approach of the Sun: As alo, on the contrary, Dogs commonly run mad in the Dog-days, and Lions under the Sign Leo: But alo ome Perons beheld with an evil eye by ome Planets, others being propitious. So to cure hot and dry Dieaes they engrave their Talimans under a Contellation contrary to the Evil, as cold and moit; having regard to the Signs whereunto every Malady and dieas'd Part is referr'd; which is an Invention of Paracelus, who fancies Poles, a Zenith, a Nadir, an Equator, a Zodiack, and other phantatical Figures in our Bodies, anwering to thoe of Heaven, without the leat proof of his ayings.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, Since Man is compos'd of Body and Soul, Whether a Country-life or a City-life is to be preferr'd? the bet Life he can lead is that which is mot proper for the perfection and good of both. Such is the Country-life, being accompanied with the Goods of the Body, Fortune, and the Mind. Thoe of the Body, as Health and Strength, are poes'd with advantage by Ruticks, who know not o much as the Names of Dieaes; the caue whereof is their Exercie
and Labour, which diipates and reolves the humours that produce mot Dieaes; as alo the purity of the Air they breathe, which is the more healthful in that it hath free motion, and is les confin'd; for which reaon Phyitians end their recovering Patients to confirm their Health in the Air of the Country: Which alo upplies the Goods of Fortune, the true and natural Riches, to wit, the Fruits of the Earth, and the Spoils of Animals; Gold, Silver, and other artificial Goods, being but imaginary and ueles without thoe firt, whereunto they are ubervient. But above all, the Goods of the Mind, which conit in Knowledg and Virtue (the two Ornaments of its two chief Faculties, the Undertanding and the Will) may be acquir'd much more eaily in a Country-life, in regard of the purer Air, which begets like Spirits, as thee frame purer Species and Phantams, on which depend the actions of the Undertanding; which, beides, cannot meditate nor improve without ret and ilence, carce found in a civil and tumultuary Life, as that in Cities is, which hold our Minds as well as Bodies in captivity, depriving us of the free apect of Heaven, the riing and etting of the Sun and Stars, and of the means of conidering the Wonders of God in the production of Flowers, Fruits, and Plants. Hence the Poets feign'd the Mues, the Goddees of the Sciences, living in the Mountains of Helicon, and in Woods; not in the incloure of Cities, where Virtues are alo more difficultly practis'd than the Sciences, nothing of them being left there but hadows and phantams, which under veils of Diimulation, Hypocriie, Complements, and other tetimonies of Virtue, cover Injutices, Sacriledges, Impieties, and other Crimes unknown in the Country, where Simplicity and Innocence are ure tokens of true Virtue; which is alo better retain'd amongt the Thorns and Sweats of the Country, than in the Luxury and Idlenes of Cities. And if things may be judg'd of by their beginnings, the Sacred Hitory tells, That Cain, the firt Murtherer, was the firt that built a City, named Henoch, after the Name of his Son; as a little after did the firt Tyrant of the World, Nimrod, who built Niniveh. On the contrary, all holy Peronages have lead a Country-life: Adam was a Huband-man, and o was Cain, as long as he continu'd in the tate of Innocence, which as oon as he lot he deir'd to become a Burges. Jacob, and the twelve Patriarchs his Sons, were Shepherds; as alo the Kings, Saul and David; and the Prophets Amos, Eliha, and many others; in imitating whoe example we cannot erre.

The Second aid, That Man being a ociable and political Animal, the habitation of Cities is as conentaneous to his Nature, as the Country-life is repugnant to the ame. And therefore Men had no ooner dicover'd the inconveniences of the Rutick-life, but they unanimouly conpir'd to build Cities, to the end to upply one anothers Neceities, and defend themelves from wild Beats and their Enemies, to whoe fury they were
expos'd before they liv'd in ome Town, which is a Sacred Society or Unity of Citizens, all apiring to the conervation of the State, to the maintaining of the Laws and Jutice, and to the publick Ornament and Glory; making Arts and Diciplines flourih, and procuring Safety to all People, by the ditribution of Rewards to Virtue, and Punihment to Vices, which have not their effect but in publick: For our Lives would not differ from thoe of Brutes, if we were oblig'd to dwell in Dens, or wander up and down Woods, as the Barbarians of the new World do; whoe Brutality, Irreligion, Cruelty, Ignorance, and Miery, compar'd with the Politenes, Devotion, Humanity, Knowledg, and Happines of others, ufficiently manifet what difference there is between a City and a Country-life.

div.head: CONFERENCE CIX. I. Of Volcano's or Subterranean Fires. II. Which Age is mot deirable.
div.p:
THe effects of Volcano's and Subterranean Fires are no les manifet than their caue is unknown; Of Volcano's. although the deire of teaching us the ame, occaion'd the death of Pliny, by haying too neer approach'd the Fires of Mont Gibel (or Aetna), and made Empedocles cat himelf head-long into them: But the former did not attain it; and the latter left us nothing but his Pantofles. The Artifice of Man hath indeed excavated the entrails of the Earth, and decended into the Abyes of the Waters, to get out their mot hidden treaures; yea, he hath pervaded with his ight the vat expanes of Heaven, there to conider the Stars: But he hath not yet been able to familiarie the Fire to himelf, which like a Salvage-beat devours every thing it meets. Now although it be found almot in all places, yet Sicily nourihes it more than any; having amongt others the Mont Gibel, or Aetna, thoe of Hiera, Lipara, and many others in the Volcanian Ilands, which are adjacent to it; and of Stromboli, twenty Leagues ditant from thee. Such alo are thoe of Modena and Veuvius in Italy, which moak to this day; the three burning Mountains of Hecla, Sainte Croix, and Helga in Ie-land, which cat forth Flames only at their feet, (their tops being all cover'd with Snow) and whoe Fire is augmented by cating Water in, which erves it for Fewel. Such were alo that which, by the report of Tacitus in the fifteenth of his Annals, burnt the Territory of the bii under Claundius Nevo, and could never be extinguih'd with Water, but with Stones, Cloth, Linnen, and other dry things; that mention'd by Titus Livius, which in three days reduc'd into ahes three Acres of the Territory
of Calena, at this day Carignola in Campania; that which burnt for ixteen years together a great part of Scotland; and not long ince the Iland of St. George, which is one of the Aores; and divers other fat Lands near the Sea, which continually upplies unctuous matter to thee Conflagrations; whence the mot remarkable of them are een in Ilands, and other maritim places.

The Second aid, That the Pythagoreans, who place Fire in the entrails of the Earth, as its Centre, would not be o much at a los here, as thoe who with Aritotle hold, That it is there in a violent tate, and contrary to its Nature, which requires the highet part of the World. For ince nothing violent can be of long duration, How is it that Fire, the mot active of all the Elements, hath not hitherto been able to free it elf out of its Prion, and get out of this tate of confinement? 'Tis better therefore to ay, That Fire being the principal Agent of Nature, neceary to all orts of Generations which are made in all places, is likewie found every where, epecially in the Earth, where it is mot enible, and is preerv'd longet, in regard of the olidity of its Matter: For Fire cannot ubit without Matter, which erves it for Food and Aliment: Whence the Poets decrib'd Vulcan, the God of Fire, lame; intimating its need of fewel and utenance to upport it; none of which being found under the Orb of the Moon, above the higher Region of the Air, 'tis reaonable to judg, that there is no other Elementary Fire on high but that of the Sun; who by his heat, light, and other qualities, concurs more perfectly to the generation of all Mixts, than that inviible and imaginary Fire. 'Tis therefore neceary that Fire have Matter to feed upon; otherwie it dies and vanihes, not only in an Enemy-country, and among its Contraries, who endeavour to detroy it; but alo in its own phere or centre, wherever it be, ince it mut needs act there; otherwie it would be weaker in its Centre than out of it: But it cannot act upon it elf; for then it hould detroy it elf: But nothing acts upon it elf; and therefore it mut act upon ome ubject beides it elf. Wherefore the Matter of all Fire is any oylie, fat, and aerious Body; whence Ahes, wholly depoil'd of that unctuous humidity, are incombutible. That of Subterranean Fires is of two ort, Sulphur and Bitumen; both which are oberv'd plentiful in burning places. The Live or Foile Sulphur, which erves for Matter to thee Fires, is a terretrial fat or oyl, mingled with the lime of the Earth: For, the other ort of Sulphur, found on the urface of Stones, is nothing but the purer part of the former, which being ublim'd by heat, is top'd and condens'd by thoe olid Bodies into a Matter call'd Flowers of Sulphur; by which example Chymitry makes the like Flowers. The Bitumen is alo a fat juice; which is either liquid, like Oyl, call'd by ome Petroleum, and the Naphtha of the Babylonians; o inflammable that it attracts Fire at a ditance, and retains it in the Water, which erves it for
nourihment; as is een in that Bituminous Fountain which burns four Leagues from Grenoble in Dauphine, and many other, which cat forth both Flames add Waters at the ame Out-let. There is ome too, of the conitence of oft Wax; as that limy Bitumen floating upon the Lake of Sodome: Some other hard, like the Pit-coal, call'd Tourbe, whereof our Marhes are full; which is the mot general Matter of Subterranean Fires; to whoe violence the Nitre found there, may alo contribute: for as Bituminous Earth makes thee Fires durable, which otherwie could not ubit o long with Sulphur alone, which preently is evaporated and pent: So the Nitre and Saltpeter (wherewith the Earth is every where impregnated, and which hath been before hewn to be the caue of its fertility) is the caue of their impetuoity and violence, which the ituation of places may alo promote.

The Third aid, That the Earth, as well as the Air, hath three Regions in its profundity; the firt temper'd and alter'd either apparently or really, according to the various dipoition of the ambient Air: The econd or middle, extreamly cold: The third always hot and burning. And as the Matter of Thunder is a Sulphureous, Nitrous, and Bituminous Exhalation of the Earth, drawn up by the Sun to the middle Region of the Air, where 'tis inflam'd by Antiperitais of the ambient cold (becaue being in the next dipoition to Inflammation, the leat concurrent circumtance preently reduces that Power into Act:) So the incloed and difficultly evaporable heat of the Earth, finding the ame eaily-inflammable Matter there, namely, the Exhalations which iue from that third Subterranean Region upon the opening of Mines, which tetifie by their mell, thicknes, and other qualities, how much they partake of Minerals; thee hot and dry Exhalations acending to the econd Region of the Earth, there meet with cold Spaces, which being for the mot part hollow or cavernous, and tor'd with Sulphur, Bitumen, and other fat Earths, become inflam'd by the Antiperitais of cold and the proximity of thoe Materials. And becaue the Earth which feeds thee Fires conits of two parts; the one arid, and the other unctuous; this unctuoity approaching nearer the Fire, coming to be conum'd, the Fire mut needs be extinguih'd; till the heat, excited by the conflagration of many years, having attracted all the unctuoity of the neighbouring Earth, and this having by degrees impregnated that dry. Earth which the Chymits call Caput mortuum, it becomes again inflammable, and continues fir'd till the ame be deiccated again; and o forward in a circle; nothing hindring but that, as Plumeor Stone-allume is an eternally incombutible Wiek, provided it be upply'd with new Oyl when the former is pent, this Earth may do the like: Unles we had rather, that wie Nature dipenes combutible matter in the bellies of Mountains, after the manner of Vitruvius's his Lamps, which need filling but once a
year; and thoe Water-Receptacles for Birds, which are upply'd with freh as fat as the former Water is pent. Or ele, that Nature (excepting the extraordinary eruptions which eldome happen to thee flammivomous Mountains, and then only when the Fire cannot get iue but by violence) makes what the curious often apire to, an inextinguihable Fire, or perpetual Light, by reolving again into oyly and combutible matter that which was evaporated by Inflammation; as Water elevated in vapour by heat, falls down again in the ame form. The Architect, Nature, finding Cavities great enough in thoe vat Mountains to facilitate what Art finds impoible, by reaon of the malnes of Veels, which extinguih Fire when it hath not Air, or uffer its Matter to exhale when it hath; although S. Autin and Lodovicus Vives make mention, the former of a Lamp in the Temple of Venus, which could not be extinguih'd or conum'd, though neither Oyl nor Wiek were put to it; and the latter, of another burning Lamp found in a Sepulchre, where it had been fifteen hundred years, but upon admiion of Air forthwith went out. Although without recurring to this ubtilty, that of Fire, and its activity, is ufficient to attract or fetch in its ulphureous food; which being only an excrement of the Earth, and like the oot of our Chimneys, is found every where, but epecially in Mines, which are repair'd in les time than is believ'd, and whoe various qualities make the variety of thee Subterraneous Fires, of their duration, continuity, and interval; which ome have compar'd to Intermitting Fevers, excited in our Bodies by an extraneous heat, which holds the ame place in us as Fire doth in the Earth.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, That Age is the meaure of the Natural Mutations to which Man is ubject by the Principles of his Being, Which Age is mot deirable? and which differ according to every ones Nature; ome being Puberes, having a Beard and gray Hairs, and uch other tokens, ooner than others, according to the diverity of their firt conformation; whence aries that of their Diviion. Aristotle, following Hippocrates, divides them into Youth, Middle-age, and Old-age; that is to ay, the Beginning, Middle, and end: Or, according to Galen, into Infancy, Man-hood, and Old-age: According to mot, into Adolecence, Youth, Age of Conitence, and Old-age. Adolecence comprehends Infancy, which reaches to the eventh year; the Age of Puerility, to the fourteenth; Puberty, to the eighteenth; and that call'd by the general name, Adolecence, to the twenty fifth. Youth, which is the flower of Age, reaches from twenty five to thirty five. Man-hood and Conitence, from thirty five to fourty eight; when Old-age begins, which is either green, middle, or decrepit. Thee four Ages are the four Wheels of our Life, whoe Mutations they mark out: The firt, next the primordia's of generation, is hot and moit, ymboliing with Blood;
the econd, hot and dry, with Choler; the third, cold and dry, with Melancholy; the fourth, cold and moit; with Phlegm; which being contrary to the primogenial humidity, leads to death. Now if it be true, as 'tis aid, That Life is a Punihment, and a Summary of Mieries, Old-age, as neeret the haven and end of Infelicities, is the mot deirable. Moreover, being more perfect by experience, and alone fit to judg of the goodnes of Ages, which it hath run through, we mut refer our elves to the goodnes of its judgment, as well in this as in all other Points.

The Second aid, Since to live is to act, the mot perfect and agreeable of all Ages of Life is that in which we bet exercie the functions of Body and Mind; namely, Youth (which alone eems fit to dipute the Prize with Old-age) not only in regard of the health and vigour of the Body, wherein it urpaes that declining feeble Age; but alo of the actions of the Mind, which is much more lively in young, inventive, and indutrious Perons, than in the aged, whoe Spirit wears and grows wore with the Body; which hath given place to that mot true Proverb, That Old-men are twice Children. For 'tis to give Wiedom a hameful Extraction, and to make it the iue of Infirmity, to call that ripe which is rotten, and to believe that good counels proceed only from defect of natural heat; ince, according to his judgment who hath bet decypher'd Widom, this Old-age traces more wrincles in our Minds than Faces; and there are few Souls which by growing old become not owr and rancid, and acquire not many vices and ill habits; of which Covetounes alone, ineparable from Old-age, (and an Argument of weaknes of Mind, in heaping up with o much olicitude what mut oon be parted with) is not much les prejudicial to the State than all the diorders of Youth. But if the Chief Good conits in the Sciences, the Caue of Young-men is infallible; for acutenes of Wit, trength of Phancy, and goodnes of Memory (which wholly abandons Old-men), and ability to undergo pains and watchings, mut contribute to their acquiition. And if it conit in the ecret delight we take in exerciing virtuous Actions, Young-men, who, according to Chancellour Bacon, excel in Morality, will carry it above Old; it being certain, That the bet actions of our Lives are perform'd between twenty and thirty, or thereabouts, which was the Age at which Adam was created in Paradie; as our Saviour accomplih'd the Mytery of our Redemption at the Age of thirty three years, which hall be likewie the Age at which the Bleed hall rie to Glory, in which every one hall enjoy uch a perfect Youth as we acribe to Angels; and put off Old-age, which, not much differing from Death, may, like it, be term'd the Wages of Sin; ince, had our firt Parent perited in Innocence, we hould have poes'd a perpetual Youth. Moreover, 'tis at this Age that the greatet Men have appear'd: Few Old Conquerours have been een; if
any, he hath this of Alexander, That he apires to the Conquet of another World, not having long to live in this. Wherefore intead of pretending any advantage over other Ages, Old-men ought to be contented that we ue them not as thoe of Cea and the Maagetes did, who drown'd them; or the Romans, who cat them from a Bridg into Tyber, thinking it a pious act to free them from life, whoe length dipleas'd the Patriarchs, the Scripture aying, That they died full of (or, atiated with) days.

The Third aid, That the Innocence of Children hould make us deire their Age; conidering that our Lord requires us to be like them, that we may enter into his Kingdom. Moreover, Nature, unable to perpetuate Infancy, hath found no weeter Anodyne for the mieries and melancholy of Old-people than the ight of Children, and the memory of things done or learnt in their minority; which partakes the more of its ource, the Deity, the les 'tis remov'd from it.

The Fourth aid, Youth hath too many extravagances to be accounted happy; and 'twould be againt the order of Nature if (the Extreams) Infancy and Old-age contain'd more perfection than that which holds the Middle, wherein he hath etablih'd the Virtue of all things. The weaknes of the firt hews that it hath not wherewith to content it elf, but needs upport from others, and is therefore an object of Compaion, which never aries but from Miery. Its Innocence, proceeding only from impotence and imperfection of the Soul's operations, hath nothing commendable; and 'tis as much unable to will as do good: But true Innocence conits in the acting of difficult good. If Child-hood fear not the Future, it receives a preent Evil with more pain, and is as enible of the leat dicontents, as incapable of conolation, or prudence to avoid them; nor can it by hope anticipate or prolong the enjoyment of a future good. In hort, He cannot be happy who is not concious of his happines, as Children cannot be. Then for Old-age, 'tis a econd Childhood, and more to be pitied, in that it always grows wore, partakes all the defects of Nonage, and hath this wore, that its deires, awaken'd by the memory of pat contentments, upbraid its impotence; and the thirt of getting is at perpetual jar with the fear of leaving: Aches, the forerunners of Death, dayly attaque its patience; and there remains no cure of its Evils, but the extremity of all Evils, To be no more. Infancy is therefore like the Spring, which hath only Flowers, and expects Fruits hereafter; o that 'tis an Age of Hope without Enjoyment. Youth hath only Summer-fruits, of little lating. Old-age is a Winter, without either Flowers or Fruits, poeing only Evils preent, and oblig'd to fear all and loe all. But Man-hood, betwixt thee two, reembles Autumn, denoted by the Horn of Plenty, poees the felicity of Life, enjoys the Goods acquired, and by hope anticipates thoe to come; it hath a Soul commonly accordant with the Body, the Faculties of that making a weet harmony
with the Actions of this. On the contrary, the Soul in Child-hood eems not to be well in tune with the Body; in Adolecence 'tis always at dicord with the Appetites of Sene; and in Old-age it jars with it elf, and by a peedy eparation endeavours wholly to break the Conort, and have its part by it elf.

div.head: CONFERENCE CX. I. Of Mineral Waters. II. Whether it be better to give than to receive?
div.p: AS the goodnes of Common Waters is judg'd by their having neither colour, nor mell, nor tate, Of Mineral Waters. and the leat weight that may be, wanting all other virtues beides to cool and moiten; o, that of Mineral or Medicinal Waters depends upon the qualities of the Minerals wherewith they are impregnated, and by means whereof they purge and alter the Body; Humidity being eaily uceptible of extraneous qualities, and preerving the ame bet in a dene and gros ubject, as Water is. Thee Waters are either cold or hot; the former are drunk, and the latter erve for Bathing; as that of Aix in Germany; of Plombieres, in Lorrain; of Bourbon, in Bourbonnois; of Bagnieres and Barege, in Gacony; of Balleruc and Barbotan, in Languedoc; of Acqs and Teris, neer Bayonne; and abundance of other hot Baths caus'd by Subterraneous Fires. Of cold Waters, ome are acid and pungent to the tate, as the Vitriolate, uch as thoe of Spa in the Country of Liege, and of Ponges in Nivernois: Others are harp and rough; as thoe Springs of Forges and Montdor neer Rheimes, not long ince found by Sieur de la Framboiiere; thoe of Chateau Thierri, of la Here neer Béleme, whoe acidity likewie argues omething of Vitriol; and divers others, dicover'd daily by experience. Some are found heavy, tinking, fat, and impure; other leight, pure, clear, and weet. Some are alt or brackih; of colour reddih, green, black, and otherwie different, according as thee Waters are variouly mix'd; wherein Minerals are contain'd either in ubtance and their groer parts, or ele only their Spirits and ubtiler parts, o well blended as that there appears no extraneous Body at all; which mixtion depends on the Nature of Minerals, ome whereof are never perfectly mix'd with Water, by reaon of their hardnes; others, though oft and liquid, mix only confuedly, as oyly Bodies: Others mix eaily; as Spirits, in regard of their tenuity; and Salts, which melt in the Water.

The Second aid, That in this matter Experience is rather to be conulted than Reaon, which falls hort in the examen of
many Waters, of which Hitories are full; as of thoe of Nile in Aegypt, which make Women fruitful; of a Fountain in Arcadia, which prevents Abortion; of the River Styx in the ame place, and of Leontini in Sicily, which preently kill uch as drink thereof; of Cydnus in Cilicia, which cures the Gowt. Such alo is Fountain of de Jouvence in the Ile Bonica, which makes old men young again; that of Ie-land, which hinders gray hairs; the two of Baeotia, whereof one trengthens, the others abolihes the Memory; two others of the Fortunate Ilands, one of which caues Sardonian and mortal Laughter, unles the other be preently drunk of; and thoe of Thealy and Macedon, one whereof makes the Sheep that drink of it to have black Wooll, which the other makes white, and both mix'd together make it of everal colours; that of the Ile of Andros; and another a league ditant from Coblentz, which inebriate, having the tate of Wine, which the firt retained but for even days, and quitted when carried out of ight of a Temple of that Iland dedicated to Bacchus; the oylie Fountains of Zant; the red Spring of Aethiopia, which caues los of Judgment; as the Mad Lake in Preter John's Country alo doth, which thrice a day, and as often in the night, becomes blackih and harp, and returns as often to its own weetnes; the Sabbatical River mention'd by Joephus, which dries up every Sabbath-day (render'd credible by that of Varins neer Saumur, which hath its flux and reflux, as the Sea); the Water of the Babylonian Lake, which continues red eleven days in Summer; the Fountain of Dodona, o famous among the Poets, at which they lighted extinct Torches; like to another neer Grenoble, which at the ame tream ends forth Waters and Flames; and many others, which convert Wood and immers'd Bodies into Stone; the true caues whereof are altogether unknown.
