The Third aid, That Mineral Waters, though humid to the touch, are deiccative; as appears partly from their compoition of Mineral, deterive, and deiccative Spirits; and partly from their effects, which are to heal Ulcers, dry up Scabs and Putules, and correct the moit intemperies of the Stomach, and other lower Parts. Some argue them all hot, from their acrimony, virtues of penetrating, inciding, opening, attenuating, provoking Urine and Sweat, cleaning the Reins and Bladder; all ffects of heat. Others account them cold, becaue being drunk they caue hivering at Midummer, correct the heat of the Liver and Reins, cure hot Dieaes, prejudice cold, and generally hurt the Nervous Parts, to which, according to the Aphorim, Heat is friendly, and Cold hurtful: But though actually cold, yet they have ome have ome heat in power; and being compos'd of everal unlike parts, produce different and ometimes contrary effects: So Aloes and Rhubarb both looen and bind: All which effects may nevertheles be referr'd to three principal; namely, Refrigerating, Deoppilating or opening, and Strengthning. They refrigerate by their actual coldnes and the acidity of Vitriol,
which alo by vellicating the tomach, caues the great appetite we have during the the ue of thee Waters. They deoppilate, not o much by their quantity (which hath made ome erroneouly ay, that the ame proportion of common Water would work the ame effect as thee Medicinal Waters) as by their tenuity, which they have from the metalline Spirits, which make them penetrate and pas peedily over the whole Body. Latly, they trengthen by their atringency, (for all Atringents corroborate) which the Chymits attribute to their volatil Spirits, which, as they ay, joyn themelves to the fix'd Spirits of our Bodies.

The Fourth aid, That the three conditions of a good Medicament are, To Cure Speedily, Safely, and Pleaantly; as Mineral Waters do. They are familiar to us, by their nature of Water; Medicaments, by their compoition, which is dicover'd either by letting them ettle, or by evaporating, or by ditilling them; as alo by the mell, tate, and colour, which becoming black by the infuion of Galls; hews that there is Vitriol in them. And whereas the longet and mot difficult Maladies proceed from obtruction and cold, the hot or acute being peedily terminated, thee Waters are the mot effectual Remedy of both; for they penetrate, and, like a torrent, open not the great paages only, but alo the mall veins of the Meentery; and heat by their Spirits and Sulphur, which hath a heat very benign and friendly to the principal parts, epecially to the Lungs, whereunto it is a Balom and Specifical. Above all, they are admirable in curing Gravel, not only vacuating the gros and vicous humours, which are the matter of the Stone, but ometimes breaking and diolving the Stone in the Kidneys and Bladder; which, amongt others, thoe of Spà perform, by reaon of their abounding in Vitriol, whoe acidity and acrimony produces the ame effect upon Stones in the Body, as that of Vinegar doth upon Egg-hells, Pearls, and Corals.

The Fifth aid, That the ue of Natural Baths, whether hot or cold, may be eaily practied in undry Dieaes; but 'tis important to dicern the occaions of taking them by the mouth, and their differences. For, beides that their great quantity (the Italians precribing above 200 ounces a day, others 25 pound) ometimes overcomes the trength, and extinguihes the natural heat; ome have malignant Qualities, and Enemies to the principles of Life, not o much by reaon of their Metalline Spirits, diproportionate to our Bodies, as of the mixture of Mercury, Plater, and other Earths entring into their Compoition; whence many die by taking the Waters, or come back from them more infirm, by accidents following upon them, as Gowts, weaknes of Stomach, Imbecillity, Laitude, Livid Complexion, Dropie, and other more dangerous Evils than that for which they were recurr'd to.

The ixth aid, To the end the ue of thee waters may prove
healthful, regard is to be had to the Perons, the Dieaes, and the Nature of the waters. As for the firt; Children, old Men, breeding Women, and fat People, mut not take them without great neceity: For the econd; Mot waters are unprofitable, and ometimes contrary to the dieae; as, to the infirmities of the Breat, Fluxions, Ulcers of the Lungs, Epilepie, Apoplexie, Convulions, cold Maladies, and all others of the Brain and nervous Parts. If there happen a complication of Dieaes, ome of which require, others reject the ue of the Waters, regard mut be had to the mot urgent and dangerous. They have not always the ame effect; either becaue they are corrupted by Rain, or vehement Heat conumes their ubtilet Spirits, in which their chief virtue reides; which likewie depend on the Quality, Quantity, Time, Place, and Manner wherein they are to be us'd: For they mut be taken in the Morning, fating, in a hot and dry Seaon, as well becaue they are then puret and leightet, as becaue the Body better upports that quantity of cold Water, which relieves its natural Faculties languihing in great heat; and, if it may be, they mut be taken at the Spring, the Spirits being eaily diipated by tranportation. The Quantity, and Time of taking them, are not to be meaur'd by the number of Glaes or Days, but proportionated to the Dieae and its Caues, the dieas'd Parts, the Age, Temper, Cutom, and other Signs, from which Phyitians take their Indications: Which Conditions being well oberv'd, it may be aid, God hath not given Men any thing more profitable than thee Medicinal Waters, temper'd by Nature her elf, who makes us a free preent of them; their diproportion with our Bodies being the caue of their action upon them, (otherwie we hould turn them into our ubtance, as we do Plants and Animals); the bad uccees which happen by them being much more rare than thoe of any other Medicaments, although the mot rebellious Dieaes are commonly remitted to them.

The Second aid, Although to Give and to Receive be o difficult, that Seneca jutly complains, That we know not how to do either; yet the former is far more excellent, according to S. Paul's tetimony, who in the 20th of the Acts exhorts the Chritians to remember the Word of our Lord, That it is more bleed to Give than to Receive. For ince, according to the Maxim, A man cannot give what he hath not, nor receive what he hath already; Giving is a ign of Plenty and Perfection, as Receiving is of Want and Imperfection: Whence 'tis nobler to be lov'd than to love, becaue Love is the deire of a Good which we want, and is found in the Peron lov'd. Moreover, ince an Action is the more excellent, by how much 'tis more virtuous and honet; Giving, which is more virtuous becaue more difficult than receiving (as being contrary to our natural inclination of Getting) is alo more excellent. Wherefore Philophers reckon not amongt Virtues the habit of Receiving, as being wholly mercenary; but account Liberality and Magnificence a Royal and Divine Virtue: For, if to Receive were an act of virtue, as Aritotle holds, who places Liberality as well in Receiving as in Giving, it had not been a Virtue in Curius to refue the Treaures of the Samnites. But the action of Giving hath been honour'd, not only with the Name, but the Tokens and Ornaments of Virtue, Praie, and Honour; as Ignominy oftentimes adheres to thoe that Receive. Now an Action is the more virtuous, the more 'tis honour'd and commended; and ince many who Receive are aham'd of it, and unwilling to have witnees of this action, whereas all that Give derive glory for o doing; there can be no virtue in Receiving, becaue we are not aham'd of Virtue, but only of Vice.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXI. I. Of Antidotes. II. Which is mot communicative, Good or Evil.
div.p:
AS every thing hath its Contrary, o to Poions there are Counter-poyons, call'd Antidotes, Alexipharmaca,
Of Antidotes. or Alexiteria, of a middle nature between Medicaments and Poions, with which they mut have ome imilitude, that they may joyn with and encounter them in the Body. Such is Vipers Fleh, which enters into the compoition of Treacle, againt that Animal's bitings; in which Antidote divers other Poions are blended, which nevertheles being corrected one by another, they remain not only innocent, but erve to elude Poions which attaque men by trechery, eeeming Friends to them, that they may detroy them, more certainly than the good Wife mention'd by Auonius did, who having given her Husband Sublimate enough to kill him, and fearing 'twould fail of its effect, caus'd him to wallow down Quick-ilver, which comming to be joyn'd to the Sublimate, quell'd the trength of it, and by this means av'd the Man. Dieaes ariing from manifet qualities require contrary Remedies; as Plenitude, evacuation; a hot Ditemper, cold Correctives: But when the imperceptible puncture or biting of a Scorpion makes the whole Body well, or excites uch other ymptoms, then Remedies acting by firt and econd qualities being found unprofitable, we mut have recoure to Specificks, which act by an inexplicable Property of Subtance, of which rank are our Antidotes.

The Third aid, Phyick oppoes Poyon, either by Preervatives before 'tis taken, or Remedies afterwards. Preervation depends on the adminitration of the ix Not-natural things; as the avoiding of Air and Places infected, perfuming them by burning of Wild-Thyme, Mountain-Majoran, Southernwood, Kings Spear, or Cedar; annointing the Body with Roe-oyl, which is an Enemy to Serpents and venomous Creatures; and eating in Veels of Porcellane, and the like, which dicover Poions. Simple Preervatives are either appli'd outwardly, as the Topaz, Emerald, and other Amulets, worn next the skin; or inwardly, as Bezoar-tone, Bole-Armenick, Lemnian or Seal'd Earth, Vincetoxicum, Turnep, Dittany, Garlick, Rue, Citron, Pomegranate, &c. Of Compounds the mot famous is Theriaca, or Treacle, made of above a hundred Ingredients. When Poyon is already introduc'd into the Body, whether by biting, tinging, breathing, foam; or by the ight, as that of the Bailisk; or by the touch, as that of the Torpedo; or by the mouth; regard mut be had to three things. 1. To trengthen the Natural Heat, that it yield not, but may reit the Poyon; and to corroborate the Entrails, for fear they receive any malignant impreion. 2. To detroy the force of the Poyon. 3. To evacuate it peedily, either by attraction (as by Sucking or Cupping) or by Inciion and Ution, if the Poyon was receiv'd extrinecally; but if 'twas taken by the mouth, it mut be evacuated by Sweat, Urine, Siege, and Vomit, which is the peediet and afet, provided it be provok'd by familiar Medicaments, as Butter, Oyl, Milk, or the like unctuous things. Thee Antidotes are either general, reiting all orts of Poyons, trengthning the Heart and Spirits; or ele peculiar to ome certain Poyon. General, are Bleed Thitle, Angelica, Valerian, Dittany, Scabious, Devils-bit, Pimpernel, Tormentil, Rue, Scordium, Wood-orrel, Wormwood, Plantane, Marigold, Fluellin, Gentian, Juniper-berries, Bezoar, Treacle, Armenian and Lemnian Earths, the Horns of Hart and Rhinoceros, and Ivory. Of Particular, Mummy is good againt Tithymals; the Weeel and Man's Ordure, againt envenom'd Wounds, the Root of Dog-roe, againt the biting of a Mad-dog; the Flower of Water-Lilly, againt Hellebore; Cucumbers, againt Pharao's Figs; Wormwood, Garlick, and Mutard, againt Toad-tools; Long Birth-wort, againt Aconites; Vipers Fleh, and all Precious Stones, againt Mentrual Blood; Baulm and Endive, againt
Spiders; S. Katherine's Flower, and Dancing, againt the Tarantula; Sea-Crab, againt Night-hade; Citron-pill, againt Vomiting Nut; Origanum, or Wild-Majoran, againt Mezaereon; the Seeds of Winter-Cherry, againt Cantharides, and the Salamander's foam; a roated Fox, and Oiters, againt the Sea-Hare, Pigeons-dung, and Parley-eed, againt Mercury; Treacle, againt the Viper; Oyl of Scorpions and Waps, againt their Stingings, by ympathy drawing out the venomous Spirits, and rejoyning them to their firt Body. Of all which effects 'tis more expedient to admire, than unprofitably earch the Caue, which hath been hitherto unknown to the greatet Wits, and depends upon that of Sympathies and Antipathies.

The Fourth aid, There are two orts of Mitions in Nature; one, of Qualities; the other, of Subtantial Forms. In the firt, the Qualities being rebated by their mutual encounter, an agreeable harmony or temper reults, in which the prevailing Quality bears way, and makes a Temperament hot, cold, dry, or moit. In the econd, thee Qualities being alter'd, the Elementary Forms, which were contrary only by their adverary Qualities, unite and conpire into one particular Form, the Principle of Occult Properties, Sympathies, and Antipathies, according as their Forms are found Friends or Enemies. Thus in all Medicaments there is a temperament of Qualities, which is the caue that Pepper is hot, Lettuce cold, &c. and a temperament of Forms, which makes Agaric purge Phlegm; Sena, Melancholy; Rhubarb, Choler: ome Drugs, Cardiacal; others Cephalical, or Splenical. From the mixture of thee Forms aries the action of Antidotes and Poyon; and not from that of the Elementary Qualities, although they accompany their Forms, being their Servants and Vicegerents: Otherwie, did Poyons kill by exces of heat or cold, Pepper and Cucumber would be Poyon, as well as Opium and Arenick; and a Glas of Cold Water would be the counter-poyon of Sublimate: And nevertheles there are many Alexipharmaca which agree in firt qualities with the Poyons they encounter.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, Homer had reaon to et two Veels neer Jupiters Throne; Which is mot communicative Good or Evil? one full of Bitternes, the other of Sweetnes; wherewith he compounded all the Affairs of the World: Since by thee contrarieties of Good and Evil, Man's Life, and Nature it elf, is divided. For if the Principle of Good conit in Entity, according to Aritotle; and Evil, in Non-Entity; Privation which is the Principle of Non-entity, • nd conequently of Evil, is as well rank'd amongt Natural Principles as Matter and Form, which are the Foundations of Entity and Good. And we ee, Corruptions are as common as Generations, and Darknes as Light. But if we conider Evil in the vitioity of Entity, then, according to the Platonits, who call what is material and corruptible, Evil; what is piritual
and incorruptible, Good: Man, coniting both of a material and piritual Subtance, will be the Center where all Goods and Evils will terminate: In which repect he will be like the Tree of Knowledg of Good and Evil, plac'd by himelf in Paradie; or like that, to which David compares him, planted by the brink of Waters, which are Afflictions. For his Branches and upper Parts being deck'd with Flowers, Leaves, and Fruits, which are the three orts of Goods which attend him; his Flowers (whoe whitenes denotes the Innocence of his firt Age) are the Goods of the Body, which pas away with his Spring: His Leaves (whoe Verdure is the Symbol of Hope, which never leaves him till death, being fading, and ubject to be dipers'd by torms) are the Goods of Fortune: And his Fruits are the Goods of the Mind, Knowledg and Virtue, which are more avory and nutritive than the ret. But if we behold the Roots of this Tree, wherewith 'tis faten'd to the Earth, and which are the original of his Evils; ome ticking to that Stock of Adam, the ource of his Original Sin, which ends forth a thouand Suckers of all orts of Vices and Paions; others, to that Clay from whence he was extracted, and which is the Principle of all bodily Infirmities; we hall find that his good things are external, and communicated from elewhere; but his evil things are internal, and natural, and conequently more communicative: For as to Vices, the Evils of the Soul, bad Examples corrupt more than virtuous edifie: And for thoe of the Body, Dieaes are more eaily gotten than cur'd; and Health is not communicable to others; but Epidemical Dieaes are: A bad Eye, a tainted Grape, and a rotten Apple infects its neighbour, but by parity of Reaon might as well be preerv'd by it. The Evils of others not on'y do us ill by Compaion, which is a ort of Grief; but alo their happines caues in us Jealouie and Envy, the cruelet of all Evils. Beides, Good is rare, and conequently not communicative; and Poeion fills, but atisfies not. Nor is Metaphyical Good communicable, being an abtracted not a real Quality: And if Evil arie from the leat defect of a thing, and Good only from its abolute perfection; then ince nothing is abolutely perfect, Good is not communicated to any one thing here below; but, on the contrary, Evil is found in all.

The Second aid, That which hath no Being cannot be communicated: But Evil is not any thing real, and hath not any Efficient Caue, as was held by the Manichees and Pricillianits, condemn'd for etablihing two Principles, one of Good, the other of Evil, independent one on the other. For ince Good conits in the integrity and perfection of Parts, and of whatever is requiite to the Nature of a Thing, Evil is nothing but a Privation, a defect and want of what is requiite to its perfection. And, being a thing is communicated according as it hath more or les of eence, Good, which is convertible with Being, mut be more communicative than Evil, which is only a Being imperfect.
God, who poees Beeing and Goodnes primarily, communicates himelf infinitely; as doth alo Light, the mot perfect of all created Subtances. Moreover, the Nature of Good coniting in Suitablenes and Appetibility, by reaon of Contraries; that of Evil conits in Unfitnes and Averion; and if Evil be communicated, 'tis always under the mak and appearance of ome Good, which alone is communicative by nature.

The Third aid, Good is more difficult than Evil, which is commonly attended with Profit and Delight, and conequently more communicative. For Nature having implanted in us a love of our elves, doth alo intigate us to eek after all means that may tend as well to the preervation of our Nature, as to our Contentment; namely, Riches, Honour, Beauty, and all other Goods, either real or imaginary; which not being in our power, but almot all in others hands, cannot be much deir'd without in, nor poes'd without injutice, much les acquir'd by lawful ways, much rarer and longer than the unlawful and bad, which are many, and eaie, and conequently more frequent.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXII. I. Why Animals cry when they feel Pain? II. Whether it be expedient to have Enemies?
div.p: AS Speech was given Man to expres the thoughts and conceptions of his Mind, Why Animals cry when they feel Pain? o was Voice to all Animals, to ignifie the motions and inclinations of their Nature towards good and evil: But with this difference, That Voice is a Natural Sign, having affinity with the thing it ignifies; which Speech hath not, being an Artificial Sign, depending on the will and intitution of its Author. Hence it comes that there is great variety of Languages and Dialects among Men; but one ole fahion of forming the ame Voice amongt Animals; who being more enible of Pain than of Pleaure (the former detroying Nature, the latter giving only a urpluage of Goodnes) when the Evil is o great and preing that they cannot avoid it, impotence and weaknes makes them end forth Cries, to implore the help and aitance of their Fellows. For Nature having imprinted in all Creatures a Knowledg of Good and Evil, and conequently an inclination to the one, and an averion to the other; he hath alo given them means of attaining thereunto, to wit, Local Motion, to go thither of themelves; and a Voice to eek of others that Good they want, and deliverance from the Evil which prees them.

The Second aid, That only uch perfect Animals as have Lungs have the gift of Voice; others, detitute either of Lungs, as Fihes; or of Blood, as mot Inects, (having little heat, of which Blood is the foundation) have no need of Air, which is inpir'd only to cool and temper the exces of Natural Heat; and o for want of Air, which is the matter of Voice, are almot all mute, except the Dolphin, whoe Voice is like that of Man. Gras-hoppers, Flies, Bees, and other Inects, make a noie and ound indeed, by the colliion of the Air and their Wings, but have no Voice, which is defin'd, A ignificative ound made by the mouth of an Animal; and by Aritotle, The troak of the Air (attracted by repiration, and emitted by the Lungs) againt the Larynx, to expres omething. So that the Efficient Caue of Voice is the Soul; the Matter, Air; the Form, Sound, or the colliion of two olid Bodies; the End, to ignifie omething: And o Animals cry, to ignifie the grief they reent: But why they tetifie this grief by o different tones and accents, is as difficult to undertand, as the lat differences in which Philoophers have plac'd that diverity; as Howling, Barking, Bellowing. Braving, Roaring, Neighing, and uch other accents of Beats; the caue whereof is hitherto unknown.

The Third aid, Such Animals cry oonet and longet who have the tronget Imagination, the mot exquiite touch, the leat ability to uffer, and the leat concience, becaue mot uceptible of apprehenion and pain; and their Spirits being diffus'd in a les bulk, are aptet to be mov'd and gather'd together about the Heart; which by this means being unuually oppres'd, communicate the ene thereof to the Lungs, which uffering by ympathy, and being intruments for the hearts eventilation, perform their functions then with more peed and violence, by an irregular motion, forc'd by the preent Neceity, and the pain which prees them; and o the Air which was contain'd in their pongy ubtance, iues forth impetuouly, and by colliion with the Epiglottis and other oppoing parts, forms loud and reounding clamours: Whence we may judg, That the ecret intention of Nature, who dipoes thee Organs in uch ort that the Cry is a kind of interpreter of the Grief, was to give ome refrehment or ventilation to the Spirits thronged about the Heart, and alo intelligible tokens of the Evil uffer'd by the Animal, either to move the injurer to compaion, or ele to invoke the help of its own Species, or (by unknown intinct) that of the Author of Nature: For we ee that Animals, by the motives of natural intinct, run to the cries of thoe of their own kind. And ince the Holy Scripture tells us, That not only Birds, and all other Animals, but alo inenible things praie God; 'tis credible that in their anguihes they are lead by the ame Principle to cry to him to help and preerve the Work of his own Hand: Which is o true, that the wicked't Perons are forc'd by the interior motions of a hidden power to lift up their hands to Heaven in their
Afflictions, and implore Succour and Aitance from on High.

The Fourth aid, That the Sene of Touch is both more univeral and natural to Animals than any other; being the firt they have, and the lat they loe: The dolour thereof is expres'd with Cries; to which Man, having the mot exquiite Touch, and conequently being mot enible of pain, is alo more ubject than other Creatures. And if that Ancient aid true, That Tears are mute execrations of the Sorrows of Life, which we begin and end with them, Cries may be aid the more manifet and earnet, ince they pierce the clouds, and ee into acend to the the Throne of God, to demand uccour of him, when none is found upon Earth. 'Tis an impetuous ound utter'd by an Animal, unable to reit preent or imminent Grief: For 'tis proportional to the violence of the Paion. Love, which is the gentlet, renders it mooth and oft: Choler, the violentet, makes it more vehement: And Grief, the mot preing of all, and tending to the detruction of Being (which is equally abhor'd by all Creatures) arieth it to the highet tone of which 'tis capable: Whence even Speech, which being artificially divided into yllables and cadences is peculiar to man; yet in the precipitatenes of Grief, keeps not its meaures, but breaks into an inarticulate ound, like that of Animals. For explication whereof it mut be known, that the Cuticle, the chief eat of the Touch, and conequently of Pain, is the expanion of the Nerves, the conduits of the Animal Spirits, which in Pain either hrink inwards, and o caue tupefaction; or being irritated and ent by Nature to the aid of the hurt part, by Sympathy move the Diaphragma, and other nervous and membranous Parts: For, as of two Lute-trings et at the ame pitch, the one ounds upon the touching of the other; o in the Harmony of the whole Body, there may be the ame ympathy between the Spirits and the Parts; an evidence whereof is een in Tickling and Laughter, which is caus'd by the contraction of the Diaphragm; which is the reaon that the apect of uch as Laugh and Weep is much alike. And becaue in Grief the coarcted Spirits hinder repiration, and free motion of the Heart; ttherefore Nature, to eae her elf, drives them outwards with violence, and with them moit vapours which partly tranpire by the pores, and are partly condens'd in the Brain, whence they flow through the eyes in treams of Tears, which by this means greatly alleviate Grief, as the want of Them and Cries argues its vehemence: Beides that, they may erve Animals to terrifie their Enemies, or ele to implore the aitance of their Fellows; as we read of Elephants, that falling into a Ditch they call other Elephants to their aid.

Upon the Second Point 'twas aid, That 'tis proper to a wie man, Whether it be expedient to have Enemies? by God's Example, to draw Good out of Evil, and benefit from the mot pernicious things. So Phyitians turn the tronget Poyons into wholeom Remedies: Men ue the poils
of the fiercet Beats for nourihment, cloathing, and other purpoes of Life: And many great Peronages have taken occaion from bodily Dieaes, Shipwracks, Loes, Banihments, and other uch unkindnees of Fortune, to give up themelves wholly to Virtue, and the Knowledg of Things. Since then Enmity is the greatet of all Evils, as Unity is the mot excellent of all Goods, and the noblet of all Virtues, as having no Vicious Extremity, but being perfect by being boundles; 'tis a Point of great Wiedom to be able to draw ome benefit from ones Enemies; whereof the principal is, that they oblige us to tand upon our guard, to order our demeanour well, and o to frame our Lives, that they may have no hold againt us: For, as Friendhip is the Parent of Confidence and Liberty; this, of Negligence: So Enmity begets Diffidence, and this Circumpection, with a great deire of Virtue, and hame of Vice, whoe turpitude makes us bluh more in the preence of an Enemy than of a Friend, who being our other Self, complies with our humours and inclinations. And as Natural Agents are more vigorous in preence of their Contraries (whence Fire corches more in Winter than in Summer) o the preence of Enemies redoubles our trength and courage; their neighbour-hood obliges us to have always our Arms in our hands, and keep good Guard; which made Cato declaim againt thoe who raz'd the Cities of Carthage and Numantia, both Enemies to Rome.

The Second aid, That if a Man be vicious, 'tis more expedient that he have Enemies than Friends; thee too eaily adhering to his debauches; but thoe withdrawing him from them, either by reproaches, or by the example of a contrary life. If he be virtuous, his Enemies make his Virtue hine forth, whilt it erves him for a defence and apology againt all their accuations and calumnies; and he finds it his interet to continue his virtuous Practies, that he may till refute them; whereas the flatteries and compliances of his Friends inenibly corrupt him. Beides, eeing a virtuous Man cannot be aid abolutely perfect, but only to have fewer defects than another, his diembling or flattering Friends ometimes know them not; but an Enemy takes notice of them, and blazing them abroad, gives him warning to correct them. Yea, it eems a ign of a virtuous Man to have Enemies: For, beides that Virtue hath been always envy'd and hated, and the higher a Man is in merit and dignity above others, he hath the more Enemies; reemblance of Manners begets Friendhip, and diparity Enmity; and more without comparion are vicious than virtuous: But the vicious being unable to love any but thoe like themelves, hate all who follow not their example, as the virtuous do not, and o have the greatet part of the World againt them.

The Third aid, That Enmities can produce no good, ince either Vice, or Malice, or Ignorance is the caue; it not being poible but either he that is hated mut be vicious, or ele they
that hate him malicious or ignorant. For, as Friendhip is founded upon, and cannot ubit without Virtue; o neither can Enmity, without the Vice and Malice of him that hates, or his that is hated, or both together. And as the Effects of Amity are Union, Concord, Security, and Peace; o thoe of Enmity are Diviion, Dicord, Diffidence, Supicion, Treachery, Hatred, and other uch Effects, noxious not only to a private Peron, who cannot draw any benefit from what tends only to his ruine (as all Hatred doth); but alo prejudicial to the Publick, which is totally detroy'd by Enmity, which breaks the bonds of Civil Society. On the other ide, If all were Friends, one man would be a God to another (as that Ancient aid); and all men concurring together by mutual help, to the accomplihment of one anothers deigns, there would be no more difficulty in Affairs, becaue no oppoition; and the World would be nothing but a harmony of favourable Succees. Contrarily, 'tis Enmity makes one man a Woolf to another, a Stone of offence, and the Daemon of his bad fortune: For, the benefit of undertanding our own Vices by our Enemies reproaches, is not to be compar'd to that which we receive from the good counels of Friends, who are better qualifi'd for redreing our imperfections, becaue convere affords the means to know them; whereas the rude cenures and affronts of an Enemy, being never taken in good part, cannot any wie contribute to the correction of our Manners. A wie and virtuous Man, who voluntarily endeavours to practie Virtue in all occurrences, finds ways enough to do it, without waiting to be contrain'd thereunto by the injuries and cenures of Enemies: But the vitious will draw nothing from them but fewel to his rancour and revenge, without being intructed concerning his faults by the mouth of thoe whom he utterly disbelieves. However, we mut draw as much profit as we can from our Enemies; and 'tis the only comfort can be had againt Hatred, to make ue of it as an Antidote againt its own Poyon. But then, as 'twould be more expedient to have no Griefs or Poyons, than to be at the trouble of finding Anodynes and Counter-poyons; o we may be allow'd to derive ome remedy from Enmities againt their Michiefs, and make as much profit of Vice as 'tis poible; but 'twould be expedient to have neither Enemies nor Vices.

The Fourth aid, That Nature ubits only by Contrariety. That, of the Firt Qualities is the caue of all the Generations of Mixts in the great World. Man's Life lats only o long as the Natural Heat acts upon the Radical Moiture; when their combate is ended, he mut necearily die. His Undertanding hath no better means to obtain Truth, than by contrariety of Opinions; whereof Identity is as diagreeable to the Mind as 'tis to Nature: But his Will hath no more powerful Means to attain to Virtue than Reitance, which harpens the Courage, and enkindles Reoltion. Therefore God has given Man a dometick Enemy,
the Senitive Appetite; that it being continually at war with the Will, might erve to exercie it, and render its Victories more glorious; the Will, as well as the Undertanding, growing ruty when they want exerciing, which whets and trengthens them both. Hence S. Paul was not heard when he pray'd thrice to be delivered from the importunity of his Enemy; God judging it not expedient for his good; and having alo permitted Hereies in the Church, which the ame Apotle aith are neceary, to the end to prove the Faith of its Members.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXIII. I. Of the Iris, or Rain-bow. II. Whether the Reading of Books is a fitter way for Learning than Vocal Intructions?
div.p:
'TWas not without reaon that the Poets feign'd Iris to be the Daughter of Thaumas, or Thaumaia; that is to ay, Of the Rain-bow. of Admiration: thereby intimating our not knowing its caue: For Wonder is the Off-pring of Ignorance. Amongt many other things, Three we find to admire in it; its Matter, Form, and Colours. Its Matter is not a moit Cloud, as mot imagine; for (beides that then we hould ee Rain-bows more frequently than we do) a Cloud cannot reflect the Sun-beams with that variety or medley which we oberve therein: For there would be but one colour, if the Cloud were diaphanous; and otherwie, it will be black and dark. 'Tis not therefore in a Cloud that the Rain-bow is form'd, but in the falling drops of Rain; as we ee ome Fountains form one in the Air, by the ejaculation of the Water truck with the Sun-beams; as alo by the purting of Water out of the mouth, oppoite to the Sun: For an Iris is not viible, unles we be plac'd between the dropping Cloud and the Sun. If the Cloud be between our eye and the Sun, it will receive the Rays only on that ide which is next the Sun, and not on that ide which is towards us. Nor will any Iris appear, in cae the Sun be between the Eye and the Cloud: For, according to the common opinion, it cannot be een higher than three miles; but in this oppoition of the Sun, the Iris will be remote from us above 18 degrees, which make above 1100 miles, allowing 60 miles to a degree, according to Ptolomie. Hence the Rain-bow which appears before Noon, is always towards the Wet; as that which appears about or after Noon, is always towards the North, or the Eat; at which times we are between the Rain-bow, and the Sun. Hence uch as are in the fifth Climate can never ee one in the South. Now the urfaces of thee
drops of Water (which fall confuedly and diorderly) being irregular, and truck obliquely by the Sun-beams, they make a refraction of his Light, like that which is made by Diamonds cut into Faucets, but more permanent; becaue the drops of Water fall o wiftly and ucceively that they eem continuous. A Rain-bow then is nothing ele but the Light of the Sun, receiv'd in this falling Rain, and remitted to our eye by an Angle of refraction, different from that of its incidence; for if it were equal, the Image of the Sun would appear therein too, as we ee it doth in Parhelia's. Indeed we may ay, That the Rain-bow is an imperfect and begun Parhelion; the Light of the one being reflected regularly, and that of the other in confuion, and diorderly: And, That its Arch and circular Figure proceeds from the obliquity of the Sun-beams: Or ele, That he being a Spherical Body, cats his Rays circularly: Or, latly, from the Spherical or Parabolical form of the Cloud: Which is alo true in the Iris which is form'd in the night by the Moon-beams, receiv'd in a Cloud diolving into Rain; aving that her Rays, being not o trong and luminous as thoe of the Sun, illuminate only the urface of the Water, and therein paint a faint whitih colour, and not uch an enamel of colours as is een by day in the Solar Iris; which colours are nothing ele but an imperfect Light, which cannot be directly reflected to the eye, by reaon of the inequality of the Angles, and therefore at leat forms thee Colours; of which the three principal are, Yellow, or Citrinous, which is the highet; Blue, or Green, which is the middlemot; and Red, which is the lowet: Amongt which there are found divers others which partake of their extremities; the diverity whereof proceeds from the divers reception of the Rays in the Parts of the Cloud, differing in opacity; which not being great in the outmot part, the Sun-beams paint there a Yellowih colour; but greater in the middle, a Blew or Watchet; and greatet in the inmot or lowet part, a Red: as Experience hews us in the like ubjects, wherein Light diverly modifi'd, repreents very neer the ame variety of Colours; which although not real (as thoe which arie from the various mixture of the four Elementary Qualities) yet are not abolutely imaginary (as thoe are which are een by weak eyes about the flame of a Candle), but are true Colours, inamuch as they trike the Sight, which a enitive and corporeal Power, and are alike perceiv'd by all; nevertheles, they are les material than Elementary Colours, and are neerer akin to Light, not differing from the ame, aving inamuch as it is here received diverly in the eye, according to the rarity or denity, ituation, figure, and other qualities of the Object and Medium.

The Second aid, The Rain-bow (the fairet not only of all Meteors, but of all Nature's Works; being, according to the Cabbalits, the Throne of God, who, in the Apocalype, is repreented Crown'd therewith) doth not les dazle the Mind than
ravih the Eye; it being oberv'd, That the clearer things are to the Sene the obcurer they are to the Undertanding; and o on the contrary: For it cannot proceed from the different rarity and denity of the Cloud, which being never alike, but infinitely various, hould rather repreent a thouand different Figures and Colours; whereas the Rain-bow hath always a circular Figure, and the ame Colours. And as there may be found more Clouds in everal places, equally rare or dene, and equally ditant from the Sun (who enlightens Bodies equally ditant after the ame manner) o there hould be more Rain-bows at the ame time in everal places; which is contrary to experience: For we never ee two uniform Rain-bows at once; the other Bow, ometimes included in the firt, being not directly form'd by the Sun-beams, but by reflection of the Rays of the firt Bow upon a neighbouring Cloud; whence the Colours of uch econdary-Bow are not o lively as thoe of the firt, but are revers'd, the yellow being lowet, the Green always middlemot, and the Red uppermot: For o by the reaon of Catoptricks, we ee that the Species reflected have a different ituation from the Body which produces them (things on the right hand appearing on the left, and contrarily); and the hadows of Bodies which pas along the treet entring by a mall hole into a dark Chamber, revers'd.

The Third aid, Experience teaches us, That when Light paes out of a thinner Medium into a thicker (as out of Air into Water) if it fall obliquely upon that thicker Medium, it is broken or refracted: But if it pas quite through uch dener Medium, o that 'tis broken as well at its going out as at its entrance (epecially if the refraction in thee two places be great enough) then this Light is turn'd into Colours. This Natural Effect is a Principle of the Opticks, and is oberv'd not only in the Rain-bow, but alo in triangular Crytals, and Glaes fill'd with clear Water, and expos'd to the Sun; provided the Glas be of a conical Figure revers'd; that is, narrower at the bottome, and wider towards the top. This being premis'd, the Production of the Rain-bow eems to be thus: When a Cloud, already wholly turn'd into Water, and actually falling down in drops of Rain (which reach from the top of the Cloud to the Earth) is hin'd upon by the oppoite Sun, and the Spectator is plac'd between the Sun and the Rain, then the Sun-beams paing through thoe drops, are reflected, as by a Mirror, back again, by thoe which are more remote; and paing by the ides of thoe which are nearet (becaue from one and the ame part but one perpendicular Ray can fall upon a round Figure, as that of drops of Water is, all the other Rays being oblique) they mut of neceity be twice broken: Firt, as they are reflected by the remoter drops, and pas out of the Air comprehended between thoe remoter, into the other drops nearer us: And econdly, as they iue out of thee nearer drops, into the Air which is between them and us. And thus from this different fraction caus'd by the
various rarity and denity of the Air and Water, the diverity of Colours in the Rain-bow arieth. For, Water being not altogether diaphanous, but omewhat of a middle nature, between perfectly Tranparent and Opake, reflects part of the Rays which fall upon its urface, and lets the other part pas through; as 'tis oberv'd in Rivers and Ponds, upon which we ee the Suns Image by reflection, but Divers and Fih behold it by refraction. So 'tis with drops of Water; thoe neeret us reflect part of the Sun-beams towards the Sun himelf, without forming an Iris, becaue thee reflected Rays meet not other drops to refract them; but when part of thoe Rays, which pas'd through the mall intervals of the firt drops, are reflected by the other remoter from us, then thee reflected Rays lighting by the way upon the firt drops between which they had pas'd, they are broken thereby both at their going in and coming out, where they repreent the Iris, which conequently is form'd by Reflection and Refraction; reflection, by all the drops which receive Light, remitting the ame towards the Sun; and refraction of the ame Light o reflected, when by the way as it returns it meets thoe other drops of Water, which refract it twice, and give it the diverity of Colours, which arieth from the divers reception of the Light into thoe parts of Water, more or les dene and rare. But now to give account of the circular Figure of this Meteor, which is not only in appearance circular (as quare Towers eem round at a ditance) but is o really; 'tis requiite to take a certain poition of the Sun; and by one example 'twill be eaie to judg of others. Let us uppoe then that the Sun is at the Horizon, and conequently that all the Rays he ends directly upon the drops of Rain, as well the highet as the lowet, are parallel between themelves, and to the Horizon, (for the elevation of a Cloud, how great oever, being inconiderable in repect of the Sun's ditance from the Earth, hinders not but that all his Rays are always parallel between themelves) which being reflected, as hath been aid, the reflection of them will be alo parallel to the Horizon, or very neer o; for here we conider only that which is made by the middle of the drop, which is the tronget by reaon of its round figure; and this reflection being receiv'd by the uperior part of ome other drop which it finds in its way, and there twice broken, to wit, at its going in and coming forth; the two Refractions joyn'd together ditort the Ray about 45 degrees; that is to ay, the Ray thus twice broken will make with the lines parallel to the Horizon an Angle of 45. degrees, a <…> from on high downwards, and falling upon the Earth. And becaue all the drops make uch a Refraction as we have mention'd, therefore all uch Perons as hall be between the Sun and the drops of Rain, hall ee the Iris of the ame heighth, namely, of 45 degrees (although from everal tations); ome in the lower drops, namely, uch Perons as are neeret the Cloud; others, to wit, uch as are more remote,
in the higher drops; becaue they all ee it by Rays parallel between themelves, and conequently by equal Angles. Now the drops make refraction not only by their uperior parts, but alo by their ides and lower parts; whence thoe on either ide of the Spectator, ditant by an Angle of 45 degrees, will make him ee their refraction, and conequently the Iris on either ide under equal Angles; which being made on all ides about a right line drawn from the Sun to the Spectators eye, which may be call'd the Axis of the Iris, it necearily follows, That the Iris mut appear perfectly round about this Axis: So that the drops elevated above this Axis 45 degrees, will make the upper part of the Iris by the refraction of their uperior parts. Thoe on either ide, ditant likewie 45 degrees, will make the ides of the Iris by refraction of their parts which are at the remoter ides; and o of all the drops which hall be about the Axis, under equal Angles of 45 degrees. As for other drops neerer or further from the Axis and the Spectator, they will repreent an Iris to others who are not in the ame Axis, but neerer or remoter from the Cloud, and ituate in uch place that thoe drops appear ditant from the Axis by Angles of 45 degrees. So that as many Spectators as there are between the Sun and the Cloud, and not in the ame Axis; o many Axes mut be imagin'd, about which there are different Arches and Rainbows. Now in this Horizontal Poition the Bow appears a perfect Semi-circle, whoe Center is in the Horizon, at the Point where the Axis terminates. But when the Sun is in another Poition, as elevated ome degrees yet fewer than 45, then the Axis of the Iris coming from the Sun through the Spectator's eye, penetrates the Earth; and o the Center (which is always at the end of the Axis) is below the Horizon; and the portion of the Iris which we behold is les than a Semi-circle, greater than which it never appears, as Aritotle hath well oberv'd. For ince the Bow is always les than a Semi-circle whilt the Sun is elevated above the Horizon, it mut be a Semi-circle when he is in the Horizon, and none at all when he is below the Horizon, becaue he doth not then illuminate the Cloud: Hence 'tis eldome produc'd in Winter, becaue when it rains in that Seaon the whole Heaven is cloudy, and covers the Sun-beams; as neither in the Summer and Spring at noon, when the Sun is higher than 45 degrees, but only at Morning and Evening.

The Fourth aid, That if Aritotle's definition of the Rainbow be true, who defines it, An Arch coniting of divers colours, which the reflection of the Sun-beams repreents upon a hollow Cloud ready to diolve into Rain, we need not eek much for Material, Formal, and Efficient Caues (for he aigns no Final of it; but the Scripture doth, namely, to be a moral ign of the Covenant between God and Men.) Of the firt there is no doubt, unles amongt blind men, to whom only God can make a demontration of it; but the ret are very obcure: To judg
of which we mut oberve, That the Angle of Reflection is equal to that of Incidence; o that a right perpendicular Line, erected at the common point of Incidence and Reflection, will equally biect the Angle comprehended by the Ray of Incidence and that of Reflection; which is not true, unles when the Ray of Incidence is terminated by a very mooth and opake Body, as that of a Mirror: Whence 'tis infer'd, That a Cloud not having uch evennes or moothnes will not reflect the Light or Ray at an equal Angle, but will diipate and remit it elewhere: So that if one part of a Cloud, which is directly oppoite to the Sun and mooth, reflect the Ray directly; and another obliquely oppoite to him, di • ort and reflect it elewhere (as 'tis much more probable, than always to imagine Clouds exactly mooth, polih'd, and even) it appears, That there will not be form'd a Figure of an Arch uniformly colour'd, but rather a confus'd medley of colours. Beides, if Reflection repreent any thing, 'tis the ame thing that is oppoite, not another: But 'tis not the Sun that we behold in the Cloud, but a mixture of Colours, no wie like, nor o much as an imperfect repreentation of him, as ome have pleaed to affirm: For Reflection would hew us either the Sun, or an imperfect repreentation of him; not in the Cloud, but as far beyond it as the Object (the Sun) is from it. So that we hall explicate Aritotle better if we ay, That thoe Colours appear by irradiation; and, that the Light diverly receiv'd, and not reflected, makes the variety of this goodly Spectacle: For they who ay 'tis Refraction, are mitaken; for Refraction only alters the place of the Object repreented by the Species, which is broken by the occure of a Medium of unequal opacity; but doth not produce divers colours, uch as thoe of the Iris, which I conceive we may more afely admire, with many other of God's Works (indiputable tetimonies of his Power and our Weaknes) than vainly eek their Caues.

The Fifth aid, He conceiv'd no demontration more manifet to prove the manner of the Rain-bows production than the experiment of a Phial of Water, which, expos'd to the Sun upon ome olid Body, repreents the ame Colours with thoe of the Rain-bow: So that the ame thing is done in the Sky when the Sun-beams pas cros an aqueous and diaphanous Cloud, and are reflected to the other ide by another Cloud, whoe thicknes hath ome reemblance of olidity; and o 'tis not ufficient that uch aqueous Cloud be interpos'd between the Sun and the Eye, but there mut be alo another oppoite Cloud, dene enough to reflect thoe Rays of the Sun, who being hollow according to the figure of the Sky, imprints that lucid circular Figure, and gives it the name of a Bow.

The Sixth aid, That a Rain-bow may be foretold ome time before it happens, when the Wind comes from that Quarter where the Sun is, and a Cloud coming from the ame Quarter pas over our heads, and hed Rain as it paes: For if the Sun
appears at the ame time, you will ee an Iris as oon as the Cloud becomes oppoite to him; which Iris will be the more lively and colour'd, according as the falling Rain was greater, and the Sun happens to be clear; as alo o much more elevated as the Sun is depres'd. But if the Sun be 45 degrees high, you will ee no Iris, the Refraction not being then proper to produce it. If it happens after Rain, it ignifies fair weather, and the Sky clears up, in that Quarter whence the Wind blows. But if the Wind blow from the Quarter oppoite to the Sun, and drive a Cloud and Rain before it; and if the Sun alo appear at the ame time, then you will ee the Iris before the Rain, which we may foretel will fall upon the place whence the Iris is beheld, provided the Cloud can ubit any while, and be not too peedily reolv'd all into Rain at the place where it is een; for where ever an Iris is een, there it rains.

The Second aid, That written Dicoures are better digeted, and utain themelves better by their own weight, than words diguis'd by the maner of expreion, or cadence, getures, and other leights, which corrupt the implicity of things; whence the Comedian that comforted Demothenes, and reviv'd his lot deire of haranguing, made him confes, That one and the ame vere of Homer was another thing when well and when ill pronounc'd: And bad Poets fear nothing o much as that others hould read their Works; the Name which themelves give them
cauing others to judg them different from what they are; and the uddennes of pronuntiation not allowing the mind ufficient time to reflect upon them. Moreover, Books flatter much les, and have more univeral Precepts than Speech, which commonly affects complaiance, and the gaining of the hearers good will: Particularly in morality, Great Perons are better intructed and more plainly reprehended for their faults by Books than by Dicoures, which eldom tell them the truth freely, every one fearing the effects of hatred enuing it, which Books care not for. Beides, No dicipline is harder than Politicks; which being the Mitres of all others, may jutly give Law to them. And were the way of learning the Sciences by Books longer than that by the Voice, yet 'tis the afer, yea, almot that alone by which we reap benefit; all thoe that are Learned, having learn'd more by the Reading and Meditation of Books, than by having heard the Voice of their Maters in Schools, where oftentimes the noie is greater than the fruit. For, our Memories being treacherous, we never repeat things o well as we write them; and in cae of mitakes or omiions, we are aham'd to acknowledg our faults, but defend them with obtinacy; whereas we cruple not to correct a Writing, to view and review it, and, according to Horace's counel, keep it nine years before publihing. But Words are utter'd as oon as thought; and hence when we ee thoe fine Dicoures in Writing, which ravih'd all the World in the Chair and at the Bar, we are oftentimes aham'd of having admir'd them: Which perhaps as much or more kept Cicero from letting his Orations be read in his youth, as his pretended excue of reerving to himelf the liberty of contradicting himelf. Wherefore there being more to be learn'd in a well-digeted and exact Piece, Writing (which is ordinarily uch) mut alo be more proper for Intruction: Which is o true in the Mathematicks, to which alone the name of Dicipline belongs, that none ever preum'd either to teach or learn them by Speech alone.

The Third aid, That a good Comparion mut be of things alike; and o if we compare Speech and Writing, it mut be in repect of two things equally perfect in their kind; as an exact Dicoure, and an exact Writing. You mut alo bring two capacities of the ame pitch, and they mut have equal time to learn the ame thing; in which cae, the circumtances being the ame, there's no doubt but Speech is more advantageous thereunto than Writing, which is not abolutely neceary, as the Voice is, without which the latter is unerviceable; he who reads being unable to undertand any thing, unles he hath already heard it poken of. Hence one naturally deaf is uncapable not only of the Sciences, but alo of the ue of Reaon, yea, of Speech too: Whereas, on the contrary, ome born blind, and who conequently never read, have nevertheles prov'd very learned. And this prae-eminence of Speech above Writing, appears epecially
in that the latter cannot be expreed without the former. Whence ome jutly doubt whether dead Languages, even uch as are mot familiar to us, as Greek and Latine, are not lot as to their bet part, their pronunciation: So that the Greeks and Latines of Demothenes and Cicero's time, would poibly no more undertand us peaking Greek and Latine, than thoe of the preent Age: Whence 'twould not be knowing of things, to know them only by Books, by which alo none ever learn'd Languages, but only by Speech.

The Fourth aid, That this Quetion admits not of an abolute determination, in regard of the different capacities of Teachers and Learners, as alo of the Arts or Diciplines which are learn'd: For nimble Heads, and impatient of Labour, uch as the Cholerick and Sanguine commonly are, uit better with Vocal Intructions than with Reading; which, on the contrary is more pleaing and profitable to the Melancholy and Phlegmatick, who take more time for reflection and meditation upon what they read. Again, Such Diciplines as conit chiefly in Contemplation, as Divinity, Natural Philoophy; the pure Mathematicks; together with thoe which require great Memory, as Hitory and Law, have more need of Reading. But thoe that conit in Action are better learn'd by Speech, which hath more affinity with action, and ets it out better; Such is Oratory, the practical part of Phyick and Law, Mechanick Arts, and Handicrafts, which 'tis impoible to learn by Books, although one may be render'd more perfect therein by them.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXIIII. I. Of the Milky-Way. II. Which is mot powerful, Gold or Iron?
div.p:
THis Tract of the Sky is call'd the Milky-way from its whitenes; and having breadth, Of the Milky-way. is rather a Superficies than a Circle, although commonly o term'd. It paeth quite round the Heaven, and o (like the great Circles) is diviible into 360 degrees; but differs from them, in that it paeth not preciely through the Center of the World, but deviates omething from it. It cuts the Heaven into two Hemipheres, to wit, at this time, making one of the Sections at the lat degrees of Taurus and beginning of Gemini; and the other oppoite to it, at the end of Scorpio and beginning of Sagittary; at which place 'tis narrower by about two degrees than at Gemini, where it hath ten degrees of breadth, wherein it differs in everal places, making uch windings as Rivers have, and contracting or enlarging,
and dividing it elf in ome places; as particularly neer Cygnus, beyond the Tropick of Cancer, where it makes two Branches, one of which ends neer the Aequator, by the ide of Serpentarius; the other paing between Sagittary and Scorpio, by the feet of the Centaure, cros the Ship Argo (where 'tis broadet) goes by the Unicorn, over the head of Leo, to the feet of Gemini; from whence croing Bootes, Pereus, and Caiopaea, it returns to Cygnus. To peak nothing of the Poets Fables, who ay, That when Juno uckled Hercules, and dicover'd who 'twas, he pilt her Milk here; or, That 'tis the pace of Heaven which the Sun's Chariot burnt by the ill driving of Phaeton; That 'tis the place where Apollo fought with the Giants, or by which he return'd towards the Eat, to avoid eeing the crime of Thyetes; or ele, the Road of the Gods, leading to Jupiter's Palace; the Reidence of Heroes; the Manion of the Virtues; the High-way of Souls; and uch other Fables: Such as have thought it the Light of the Stars, whoe Splendour the Sun cannot Eclipe, by reaon of the Earths interpoition in the night-time, were greatly mitaken; For there are no Stars but what are enlightned by the Sun, who being 166 times bigger than the Earth, 'tis demontrated by the Opticks, That when an opake Body is plac'd before a luminous Body greater than it, the Rays of the luminous Body are united beyond the hadow which was made by the opake Body; as the Sun's Rays meet again beyond the Earth's hadow, which reacheth no further than the phere of Mercury, much les to the Starry Heaven, to hinder the Sun's Light from paing thither; this Sphere being ditant 2081 Semidiameters, each of which makes 860 German Leagues. Thoe who ay, 'Tis the place where the Element of Fire tranpires and purges its fuliginoities; or ele, a ort of Fire dener than the Elementary; are as little credible as thoe others who think the Sun ometimes made his coure in this Milky-way, as he doth now in the Zodiack, in which nevertheles he leaves no print of combution or light: Much les Theophratus, who aid, 'Twas the conglutination and oader of the two Hemipheres; and that at the place where they are united and oader'd together, this brightnes appears different from the ret of Heaven. But I conceive it to be nothing ele but a part of Heaven, more dene, and conequently more luminous than the others. For Heaven having a radical Light, the dener and cloer its parts are, they are the more luminous; as appears by the Stars, which are the dener parts of their Orb, not viible in regard of its rarity; and by Water, part of which condens'd by cold, reflects the Light, and appears white, the remainder of liquid Water abiding tranparent.

The Second aid, He judg'd no Opinion more ridiculous than Aritotle's, who held this Milky-way to be a Meteor hining not in Heaven, but in the Air, where 'tis fed by Exhalations plentifully upply'd from the Earth, whence they are attracted, and
fired by the Stars in this place. For if this Milky-way were of the nature of Comets or other lucid Meteors, it could not always ubit, but only while its matter lated; which, beides, would be more copious in ome eaons then in others, (as in Spring and Autumn, then in the droughts of Summer or frots of Winter, which cloes the pores of the earth); and o it would not have the ame permanent poition and figure, no more then denity, rarity, latitude and equality of its parts, o contant that on the ide of Caiopaea it always appears alike winding, and likewie in other places: though we hould grant the earth capable to upply fumes enough for feeding this o pacious circle; which yet the diproportion of this point of the World, compar'd to the vat extent of that circumference, palpably prov'd to be in the Firmament, allows not. For (beides that the diverity of Parallaxes would repreent it under everal Stars to the Inhabitants of everal places, if it were in the air; as it happens to Comets and other aerious impreions; and yet 'tis always een in the ame place and equally ditant from the fix'd Stars) its proper motion from Wet to Eat, whereby it moves one degree in a hundred years demontrats that 'tis in the eighth Sphere, whoe particular motion is the ame. And Galileo's Glaes, which have dicover'd abundance of Stars in this part, convincingly manifet that 'tis nothing but an aembly of almot innumerable mall Stars, which not being great enough to tranmit their light to us ditinctly, the ame is confounded and united together (as 'tis proper to all qualities, and o of Light, to aociate it elf to other light) and thus produces that whitenes which is a weak and imperfect light. For 'tis not enough that an object be luminous; it mut be great and large, or ele near the eye, to be viible: the Stars, as well as all other natural agents, having a phere of activity, beyond which their action is not enible: hence the Planets, and of them the Moon, as nearet us, eem greater than the fix'd Stars; whoe rayes being weakned by their ditance, cannot come directly to us, as thoe of the Planets do, but twinkle and parkle.

Now though Atrologers make but ix orts of fix'd Stars, according to their ix different magnitudes; (thoe of the firt being 170 times greater then the Earth, and thoe of the lat and ixt, 18 times) yet Tycho Brahe, Americus Veputius, and divers others, have dicover'd ome much les, and les luminous, then thee lat. Nor are they to be credited who have limited their number to 1022, which the Scripture aith is infinite and known to God alone, to whom the Prophet attributes it as a prerogative, to number them and call them by their names.

The Third aid, There are two orts of Milky-ways; one in the Air, and the other in the Heaven. The firt, of which alone Aristotle poke, is a light produc'd by exhalations either fired or irradiated, as in Comets: from which this milky way differs only upon account of its great extent caus'd by the plenty
of Exhalations attracted by a great number of Stars which are neer Caiopaea and the Poles, where alo this Way is brighter then in other places. The other Milky Way is part of the Heaven or Firmament, equally dividing the ame in two, as other Circles do; although 'tis rather a Zone or Space then a Circle, as well as the Zodiack, with whom it agrees in that it hath breadth as that hath, and is oblique to the Aequinoctial, having other Poles than thoe of the World: but differs in that 'tis not o broad, the Zodiack having ixteen degrees, and this commonly between eight and ten; for 'tis neither equally broad, nor luminous in all its parts; and its obliquity is much greater than that of the Zodiack, the middle of which recedes not from the Aequinoctial above 23 degrees and a half; but this about 56 degrees and a half towards the North, and neer 63 degrees towards the South. It differs alo from all the great Circles, in that it changes poition according to the motion of the Firmament; o that 'tis mov'd with two Motions, namely, that of the Firt Mover, from Eat to Wet, upon the Poles of the World, making an intire revolution in one day; and another proper to it elf, from Wet to Eat, upon the Poles of the Ecliptick, in the ame time with the Firmament; which motion the other Circles have not, being either not mov'd at all, as the Horizon and Meridian; or only by the motion of the Firt Mover, as the Aequinoctial, Ecliptick, Tropicks, and Colures.

Which is mot powerful, Gold or Iron? Upon the Second Point it was aid, That the Earth produces Metals to be imployed for everal ues, in order to humane Commerce and Society; which being founded upon Hope and Fear, Reward and Punihment, Gold and Iron, the two mot powerful Metals, are highly intrumental to the etablihing of the ame. Gold, which an Ancient call'd the Sun of the Earth, being the Star which gives light to our hope, and the weet influences of Reward: And Iron, by its obcure and livid colour being the dark Star of our fear and of death, whereof 'tis the mot uual Intrument: But as Fear is without comparion tronger than Hope (for the one tends to the preervation of Being, the other only to Well-being) o Iron, the Intrument of Terror, mut likewie have more powerful effects than Gold, which is only the object of Hope. Moreover, the Law relieves uch as the Jut Fear of Iron may have contrain'd to any thing, as being the greatet violence in the World; but not thoe whom the deire of Gold or hope of Gain hath engaged to any Affair. And indeed, all Earthly Powers are meaured only by the point of the Sword: Arms and Iron eem to be the hare of Kings and all the Nobility, as Gold that of Merchants and the Vulgar, from whom all Sovereigns know how to get it when they think fit. Beides, ince Gold hath need of Iron, not only for the digging of it out of the entrails of the Earth, but alo for defending and preerving it (an evidence of its weaknes) it may be aid the prey of him who knows how to manage Iron bet. And Solon had reaon to contemn the vanity
of Croeus, who made a hew of his riches as of his greatet power; foretelling him that it would become the booty of him that hould have a harper word. And Philip of Macedon never conquer'd o many places by trucket with Mules laden with Gold, as his Son did whole Kingdoms by the Sword. But what power can we give to Gold, which weakens and enervates its poeors; as appears by the Lacedemonians, who were maters of Greece whilt Iron alone was in ue with them, and were corrupted by the Gold which Lyander brought thither. The Captain in Tacitus had reaon to believe the Gauls of his time weak in war becaue they were rich. For what is commonly aid, That Gold is the inew of War, is true as to the power of levying and maintaining of men, but not as to the performing of great exploits and enterpries. Mercenary Souldiers and Venal Souls being ordinarily bae and of ill qualities; if they do any thing, 'tis forc'd and of little duration, nor do they continue longer then the Gold lats. Iron, on the contrary, is maintain'd by it elf and its own power. Every one fears to offend uch as have only Iron by their ide, as thoe by whom nothing is to be gotten, but much may be lot. For to ue Gold for repelling enemies and diverting them elewhere, contant experience manifets it a very dangerous remedy; ince beides the ignominy of becoming, as it were, tributaries, they are never driven o far but they oon return, more irritated with the thirt of this Gold then they were before with the honour of Victory. In fine, ince men yield ooner to violence then to gentlenes, Iron which contrains and forces is much more powerful then Gold which perwades, but chiefly in War, where the bravet and mot generous exploits are perform'd by open force and not by urpries and treacheries; he not being properly overcome who was willing to be o, and uffer'd him elf to be corrupted: but a Victory gotten by pure Valour, ordinarily takes from the enemies the deire of returning.

The Second aid, That Victory being the end of War, it matters not by what means that end is obtain'd, the eaiet and leat bloody of which are tratagems and urprizes; which, beides being the effects of Wit and Prudence, eem more proper to man then down-right force, wherein beats urpas us, and which is oftimes accompani'd with injutice. Wherefore Gold, whereby all ecret intelligences are contriv'd, eems to have the advantage of Iron; as lights in War are more efficacious then open force. As alo it makes les noie and hath more fruit; whereas Iron oftentimes equally ubdues and weakens both parties. And Victory, the thing aimed at by War, cannot be call'd uch, unles it be intire. Iron indeed ubdues bodies, not hearts; but Gold wins both together.

The Third aid, That Gold and Iron may be conider'd either imply as Metals, or ele as Intruments of civil life. In the former conideration Gold being of a more perfect nature, hath
alo more power then Iron the mot imperfect and terrene of all; beides, its ductility makes it more capable of extenion then any other; which is an evidence of its perfection. If they be conider'd as means and intruments detinated to the ue of life, which is the noblet end whereunto they can be imploy'd; Gold will till have the advantage over Iron; ince, if we credit the Chymits, potable Gold is profitably employ'd for health and the prorogation of life; and the ame Metal is alo the bond of humane ociety, which cannot ubit without commerce, nor this without money, for which Gold is the mot proper, as containing in mall bulk the value of all other Metals of lower alloy. Hence we ee the people commonly raie the price of it beyond what the Prince ets upon it; and 'tis as much deir'd by all the world, as Iron is abhorr'd; all Profeions and Trades aiming at the enjoyment of gold, which eems to be the ultimate end of all humane actions in this life, whatever diguies men aume under the pretexts of honour and vertue, whoe lutre is alo et off by that of Gold, employ'd for this purpoe to crown the heads of Monarchs, and to render divine worhip more magnificent.

The Fourth aid, That as Iron makes Hammers and Anvils which erve to give Gold what form we pleae; o 'tis every where the mater of gold, and conequently more powerful in Peace and War, affording Grates, Locks and Keys for ecuring Gold in the former, and Swords for defending it in the latter. For Gold erves only to make the poeor envi'd, and inflame the deires of uch as want it. 'Twas with Iron that the Romans became maters of the Gold of other Nations, and the Portugals conquer'd that of Peru, and the Swies overcame the Duke of Burgundy; the Hitory oberving that all their wealth was not worth the Gold wherewith the Burgundians had enrich'd their hores bridles.

The Fifth aid, That the end being not only more noble but alo more powerful then the means, Iron, which is commonly employ'd for the getting of Gold mut be alo inferior to it. And 'tis univerally acknowledg'd that Gold is the inew of War; it levies and keeps men together, it makes the Cannon move and all its train. 'Tis with Gold that we corrupt Spies, without whoe informations all Iron and trength would be oftentimes unprofitable. Wherefore ince Iron borrows its power from Gold; by the Philoophical Maxim, it hath les power then it.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXV. I. Of the caue of Vapours. II. Which is les culpable, Rahnes or Cowardice?
div.p: THe Firt aid, The material caue of Vapours is aqueous humidity; the efficient, external heat; the formal, Of the caue of Vapours. rarefaction; the final, is various, according to nature's different intentions: but commonly, the elevation of an aqueous body, which remaining in its firt conitence would weigh more then air, and conequently could not be carried to thoe higher places where 'tis needful for the generation of Mixts, which cannot be done without tranmutation of the Elements into the places, yea, and natures alo, one of another. So Roes in an Alembick would evaporate nothing, if they were depriv'd of all humidity, as appears in their dry'd Cakes; nor what humidity may be in them, without heat; which humidity is rarifi'd and carri'd upwards before it decends, being again condens'd into the water which reided in the Cake before its eparation by heat; which conequently is the mot evident caue of Vapours.

The Second aid, There are ome vapours that are hot and dry, as appears not only by the moak exhaling from boiling Pitch and other unctuous bodies; but alo by the vapours that iue out of the earth, which would never be inflam'd ome in the urface of the earth, others in the middle of the air, and others beyond the highet region, and even in the heavens, if they were only of the nature of water which quencheth intead of conceiving fire: as, on the other ide, Rain, Hail, Snow, Dew, and other aqueous and incombutible Meteors argue that all Vapours (of which they mut be produc'd) are not hot and dry. Whence I conclude that as the matter of vapours is various, o their other caues are all different, epecially the efficient. For the degree of heat that evaporates water will not make Oyl exhale; as we ee a great glas will be ooner evaporated then a poonful of the latter; and the Chymits make ue of a mall fire or even of the Sun to ditill their waters, but augment their fire, to extract Oyls. Moreover (as to the material caues) the vapours of hot and dry bodies are more gros and earthy; thoe of pure water more ubtle; and (as to the final) aqueons vapours erve to irrigate, unctuous to impinguate the earth.

The Third aid, 'Tis not credible that heat is the efficient caue of vapours, ince they abound more in Winter then Summer, and in les hot Climats then in uch where heat predominates, which have none at all; as Egypt and other places, where it never
rains. If you ay that there are no vapours there, becaue the Suns heat dipates as fat as it raies them, you imply heat contrary to vapours ince it diolves them and uffers them not to gather into one body.

The Fourth aid, Copiounes of vapours in cold Seaons and Regions makes not againt their production by heat; ince the heat which mounts them upwards is not that of the Suns rays, but from within the earth, which every one acknowledges o much hotter during Winter in its centre as its urface is colder; where the matter of vapours coming to be repercus'd by the coldnes of the air, is thereby condens'd and receives its form. On the contrary, in Summer the earth being cold within exhales nothing; and if ought iue forth, it is not compacted but diipated by the heat of the outward air.

The Fifth aid, That the thorough inquiition of the caue of vapours raies no fewer clouds and obcurities in the wits of men, then their true caue produces in the air: For if we attribute them to the Sun, whoe heat penetrating the earth or outwardly calefying it, attracts the thinner parts of the earth and water; this is contradicted by experience which hews us more Rain, Storms and violent Winds in the Winter when the Suns heat is weaket, then in the Shmmer when his rays are more perpendicular, and as uch ought to penetrate deeper into the earth, and from its centre or urface attract greater plenty of vapours: the contrary whereof falls out. It follows therefore that the Sun hath no uch attractive faculty. Nor is the coldnes and drynes of the earth any way proper for the production of uch humid ubtances as Vapours and Exhalations; the latter whereof being more ubtle, and conequently more moveable (as appears by Earth-quakes, Winds and Tempets, which are made with greater violence then Rain, Showers, or Dew) cannot be engendred of earth, much groer then water, which is held the material caue of vapour; otherwie, an exhalation being earthy hould be more gros then a vapour extracted out of water; which it is not. It remains then that the caue of vapours is the internal heat of the earth which being encreas'd from without by the cold of the ambient air, or exhaling all its pores open'd by the heat of the Sun, produces the diverity of Meteors. And this internal heat of the earth appears in Winter by the reaking of Springs, and the warmth of Caves and ubterraneous places; yea the Sea it elf, aid to upply the principle matter to thee vapours, is affirm'd hotter at the bottom, whither therefore the Fihes retire; and indeed it is o in its ubtance, as appears by its alt, bitternes and motion, whence 'tis call'd by the Latines Aetus. And as in the bodies of Animals, vapours iuing by the pores open'd by heat caue weat, and when thoe paages are topt by the coldnes of the outward air, their ubtler parts are reolv'd into flatuoities, and the more gros and humid are carried up to the Brain, by whoe coldnes
being condens'd they fall down upon other parts, and produce defluxions: o in the world, which, like us, conits of olid parts (earth and tones) of fluid (the waters) and of rapid (which are the mot ubtle and tenuious parts of the Mas) when thee lat happen to be aociated with others more gros they carry them up on high with themelves, where they meet with other natural caues of Cold and Heat which rarefies or condenes, and redouble their impetuoity by the occurrence of ome obtacle in their way: thee Spirits being incapable of confinement, becaue 'tis proper to them to wander freely through the World. Elementary qualities are indeed found joyn'd with thee vapours and exhalations; but are no more the caues of them then of our animal vital or natural pirits, which are likewie imbu'd with the ame.

The Sixth aid, That the general caue of vapours is Heaven; which by its motion, light, and influences, heating and penetrating the Elements, ubtilies them and extracts their puret parts: as appears by the Sea whoe altnes proceeds from the Suns having drawn away the lighter and freher parts, and left the groer and bitter in the urface, cold and heat condene and rarefie other, and by this Reciprocation the harmonious proportion of the four Elements is continu'd; ometimes tempering the Earths exceive drynes by gentle Dews or fruitful Rains, and ometimes correcting the too great humidity and impurity of the air by winds and igneous impreions, ome of which erve alo to adorn the World and intruct Men. And as thee vapours are for the common good of the Univere, in which they maintain Generations, and for preervation of the Elements, who by this means purge their impurities; o they all contribute to the matter of them. Fire forms mot igneous and luminous impreions; Air rarefi'd upplies matter for winds, as is een in the Aeolipila; and condens'd is turn'd into rain. But epecially water and earth (the groet Elements, and conequently, mot ubject to the impreions of outward agents) continually emit fumes or teams out of their boom, which are always oberv'd in the urface of the Terraqueous Globe, even in the clearet days of the year, and form the diverity of parallaxes. Thee fumes are either dry or moit; the dry arie out of the earth, and are call'd Exhalations; the moit are Vapours and iue from the water: yet both are endu'd with an adventitious heat either from ubterranean fires or the heat of Heaven, or the mixture of fire. A Vapour is les hot then an Exhalation, becaue its aqueous humidity abates its heat; whereas that of the latter is promoted by its drynes; which yet mut be a little eaon'd with humidity, the ole aliment and manion of heat, which hath no operation upon bodies totally dry; whence ahes remain incorruptible in the midt of flames and evaporate nothing. But whatever be the caue of thee vapours, they are not only more tenuious under that form, but alo after the reaumption
of their own. So Dew is a more potent diolver and penetrates more then common water; which ome attribute to the Nitre wherewith the earth abounds.

Upon the Second Point it was aid, Valour is a Virtue o high above the pitch of others, Which is les culpable, Rahnes or Cowardice? and o admir'd by all men, that 'twas it alone that deifi'd the Heroes of Antiquity: For Nature having given Man a deire of Self-preervation, the Virtue which makes him depie the apprehenion of uch dangers as may detroy him, is undoubtedly the mot eminent of all other moral vertues, which erve only as ornaments to his Being. But as every virtue conits in a mediocrity, and o hath two vicious extremities, Exces and Defect; o this is plac'd between two vices which may be aid equally blamable, ince between the two extremities and the middle the ditance is equal (otherwie it were not the middle, that is, not a vertue) and a point in which this vertue conits hath no latitude. And, though rahnes, which oftimes borrows the mak of generoity and valour, eems to approach neerer it then Cowardice; ince being only an exces of Valour, it may be more eaily reduc'd to mediocrity then the other which partakes not thereof at all; as dieaes ariing from repletion are eaier to be cur'd then thoe which proceed from inanition. Nevertheles to peak abolutely, Cowardice is not o vicious as Temerity; for if the one hath a fale appearance of Valour, the other hath a emblance of prudence and widom which is the rule and meaure of all virtues.
