And indeed, we ee mot wie men are a little cowardly; either their knowledg of things rendring them circumpect:, or experience of Fortune's blindnes and incontancy making them more ditrutful of her dealing, which they know is commonly unkindet to perons of merit; or ele the value they put upon Being encreaing their fear of Annihilation; although this fear is common to all Animals, and hath its foundation in Nature, and o is more excuable then the madnes of Temerity, the uual vice of fools and lunaticks, directly repugnant to our natural entiments. In a political conideration though both are punihable, yet Cowardice leat of the two, and is mot commonly excus'd, as in Demothenes; yea ometimes recompened, as in that Roman Conul to whom the Senate gave publick thanks for having fled at the defeat of Cannae: Where the temerity of young Manlius, though uccesful, cot him his head by the entence of his own Father.

The Second aid, That Cowardice and Temerity mut not be compar'd together if we would judge which is wore; for on the one ide the rah peron compar'd to the poltron eems courageous, and on the other the poltron appears prudent and well advis'd. But they mut be compar'd with Valour, of which that of the two which partakes leat is the mot vicious. Now, Valour conits in two points, to attempt and endure. The rah peron is bold in the onet, but gives ground at the brunt. The
poltron do's neither. He dares neither attempt nor bear up, and o is further from true fortitude then the Rah; and though they eem totally oppoite, yet the rah is oftentimes timerous, and Neceity or Depair ometimes renders the veryet coward bold.

The Third aid, If the Stoicks ay true, that Nature is the uret guide we can follow in all our actions, and that to live well and vertuouly is to live conformably to Nature; then Temerity which ubverts the entiments of Nature, by whom nothing is ought o much as elf-preervation, eems much more vicious then Cowardice, whoe fault is only too much indulgence and inclining to natural entiments, in preference of elf-preervation above all honours invented by men as incitements to contempt of death, and the means leading thereunto.

The Fourth aid. As right Reaon is the quare of Prudence, Equity of Jutice, and Moderation of Temperance; o firmnes and contancy of mind in attempting and enduring, is the ign of Fortitude and Courage, which is a vertue reiding in the Iracible appetite, moderating fear and rahnes, and coniting chiefly in not fearing dangers more then is fit, epecially thoe of War or which happen unexpectedly. For two kinds of things caue fear: ome are above us and inevitable; as Tempets, Thunders, Earth-quakes which a man may and ought to fear ometimes, unles we be inenible or eneles; others are ordinary, vincible, and not to be fear'd by the courageous. To whom three orts of people are contrary; namely, the furious, who fear nothing at all; the rah who venture at all, cating themelves inconiderately into all dangers; and the poltrons who never venture upon any. Thee tremble before and in the danger; thoe eem at firt to have a good heart, but when the danger appears begin to tremble and bleed at the noe: whereas he who is truly courageous attempts no danger inconiderately, but avoids it as much as he can handomely; but once engag'd, loes his life therein if he cannot come out of it with his honour. And though this vertue be generally eteem'd by all men, becaue mot erviceable for defence of States, and hath more plendor and hew then any other; yet 'tis les known and the raret of all; not many poeing it free from the interet of gain or vanity, anger, fear of infamy, contraint and other coniderations beides that of honety, which alone gives name and value to all vertuous actions. Rahnes paes among the vulgar for true Valour, though 'tis further from it then Cowardice; which being the daughter of knowledg and prudence, (as rahnes is of ignorance and brutality, and oftentimes of vanity) eems to come neerer that virtue then Temerity, which otherwie is incompatible with all other virtues, as being detitute of Prudence, which alone makes them what they are.

The Fifth aid, 'Tis impoible to determine of thee two Vices; which are equally oppoite to their middle vertue,
whatever fale appearance Temerity may have of the contrary. But the praie and blame of men proceeding commonly, though unjutly, from Succes; 'tis that alo which makes our actions approv'd and dicommended. So that the ame action will be accounted courageous, and as uch applauded in a young tout Captain who gets the better of his enemies, (properous Rahnes being rarely punih'd); and again term'd temerarious in the ame peron, if he happens to be worted. Yea men eteem and admire that mot which they leat expected, as mot remote from reaon without which the Vertuous acts nothing. Which teaches him to be contented with himelf, and not to make much account of blame and praie, which are not integral parts of vertue, but only erve to its ornament, as our Hair and Nails do to our perons.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXVI. Which Climate is mot proper for Long-life? (The econd Quetion is remitted to the next Conference; and 'tis Reolved for divers Reaons, that hereafter but one be handled at a time.)
div.p:
BEcaue amongt all Phaenomena or Apparences caus'd by the Celetial Bodies, the diverity of artificial Days is mot enible and known to the mot ignorant; therefore Atronomers make ue thereof to ditinguih the everal habitations of Mankind. This diverity of Days depends upon two Caues; the obliquity of the Ecliptick to the Equator, and the inclination of the Horizon or the Sphere to the ame Equator. For the obliquity of the Ecliptick makes the diurnal Parallels, which are Circles parallel to the Equinoctial, decrib'd by the Sun as he is carri'd about the Earth by the motion of the Firt Mover; the number of which is equal to that of the Days comprehended in half a year. And the obliquity of the Horizon is the caue that thee parallels are cut by it unequally. Otherwie if thee parallels were not different from the Equator, or (although different) if they were cut equally by the Horizon (as it happens in a Right Sphere) the Horizon which is a great Circle paing by the Poles of thee parallels, (which are the ame with thoe of the World) both the Days and Nights would be equal: o that where the Sphere is not inclin'd, as in the Right and Parallel Spheres, there is no inequality of Days, nor conequently of Climate (o call'd from its Inclination) but only in the oblique Sphere. 'Tis defin'd, a Region of Earth comprehended between two circles parallel to the Equator; in which there is the difference of half
an hour in the longet days of the year. It encompaes the Terretrial Globe from Eat to Wet, as a Zone doth, which differs from it only as the Zone is broader; whence there are many Climats in the ame Zone. The Ancients having regard only to o much of the Earth as they believ'd inhabited, made but even Climats, which they extended not beyond the places where the longet days are 16 hours, and denominated from the mot remarkable places by which they made them pas; as, the firt Northern Climat was call'd Dia Meroes, hy Meroe, which they began at 12 deg. 43 min. from the Aequinoctial, where the longet day hath 12 hours three quarters, and which at preent is the end of our firt Climat and beginning of the econd. This firt Climat paes by Malaca a City of the Eat-Indies, and begins at 4 deg. 18 min. Its middle, from which all Climats are reckon'd, hath 8 deg. 34 min. and its end, 12 deg. 43 min. The other ix Climats of the Ancients pas'd by Siene, Alexandria, Rhodes, Rome, Pontus Euxinus, and the River Borithenes. Ptolomy reckons twenty one, as far as the Iland Thule which lies in 63 deg. of Northern Latitude. Our modern Atronomers make twenty four, from the Aequinoctial to the Polar Circles; in each of which Climats the longet day of Summer encreaes half an hour above twelve, according as they approach nearer thoe Circles: beyond which to the Poles of the World they place ix more, not ditinguih'd by the variation of half an hour but of 30 days. So that there is in all, ixty Climats, 30 Northern and as many Southern, each comprehended by two Parallels: which Climats are eaily found by doubling the exces whereby the longet day urpaes twelve hours; the Product being the Climat of the place. As if you know the longet Summer day at Paris to be 16 hours, double 4, the exces above 12, and you will have 8, which is the Climat of Paris; and o of others. And though there be the ame reaon of Seaons and other variations in the Southern and Northern Climats, yet ince experience hews us that thoe of the South are not inhabited beyond the 8th, which is about the Cape of Good Hope, at the farthet point of Africa, (beyond which no Inhabitants are as yet dicover'd, it may eem that the diverity of Climats is not alone ufficient for long or hort life, but there are other caues concurring thereunto.

The Second aid, That ince a thing is preerv'd by that which produces it, the Sun and Stars, which concur to the generation of all living Creatures, mut alo contribute to their preervation and continuance in life; which being maintain'd by ue of the ame things (variety and change, though delightful, yet being the mot manifet caue of brevity of life) that Climat which is mot contant and leat variable will be the properet for longaevity, and o much the more if it uits with our nature; uch is the firt Climat next the Aequinoctial, where things being almot always alike, bodies accutom'd thereunto receive les inconvenience
thereby then under others, whoe inequalities and irregularities produce mot dieaes. The natural purity of the Air, promoted by the breath of a gentle Eat Wind there reigning continually; and the want of vapours and humidities, which commonly infect our Air, conduce greatly to the health of the Inhabitants; alo when the drynes and coldnes of their temper makes longer-liv'd, as appears by Ravens and Elephants, the mot melancholy of all Animals, which are common in thee parts where they live above 300 years. Moreover, Homer tetifies that Memnon King of Aethiopia liv'd 500 years; which (by the report of Xenophon) was the common age of mot men of the ame Country, where Francis Alvarez affirms in our time that he aw luty men at 150 years of age; and that in Aegypt which lies near it, there are more old men then in any place of the World; and that women are o fruitful there that they bring forth three or four children at a time, rather through the goodnes of the Climat then any nitrous vertue that is in the waters of Nilus. Hence poibly mot Doctors place the Terretial Paradie under the Aequinoctial, and the caue of our firt Fathers longaevity, who having been created under this Climat eem to have lot of its duration proportionably as they remov'd from the ame Northwards (whence all evil comes) and towards the Zones wrongfully call'd Temperate, ince more ubject to alteration then that call'd Torrid by the Ancients, who thought it unhabitable by reaon of extream heat; although the continual Flowers and Fruits wherewith the always verdant Trees are laden tetifie the contrary.

The Third aid, Since Heaven is immutable and always like to it elf, the Earth and Elements alone ubject to change; the length and hortnes of Life eems not to depend on Heaven but on Earth and the everal dipoitions of our Bodies: and the whole World being Man's Country, there is no place in it but is equally proper for his habitation, provided he be born there; becaue the Air he breathes and the Food he eats from his Nativity, altering his Body, at length make his temper uitable to that of the place of his Education; which therefore he loves above any other.

The Fourth aid, That Heaven remaining it elf immutable, is nevertheles the caue of motions and mutations here below; its light producing different effects in the Earth according as it is receiv'd, the mot enible whereof are heat, drynes, and other qualities which diverifie the Seaons and Zones; of which the two temperate, epecially the Northern eems mot habitable and proper for longaevity. 'Tis alo the mot populous, and its Natives are not only the mot healthy and luty, but alo the mot refin'd and civiliz'd of all others. Now of the Climats of this Zone, the eighth, wherein Paris lyes, eems to me the healthiet of all, as well for purenes of Air as all other Caues.

The Fifth aid, That the goodnes of Climats depends not o much upon Heaven as the ituation of each place in reference to the Winds, of which the Southern being the mot unhealthy, therefore Towns defended by Mountains on the South are very healthy, epecially if they lye towards the Eat, the Winds whereof are mot healthy. And this is the caue of the diverity oberv'd in Countries lying in the ame Climat, which experience not the ame changes: as the Ile of France is very temperate, and yet lyes in the ame Climat with Podolia (a part of Poland) where the cold is extreamly rigorous: and in the Ilands Bornaio and Sumatra men live commonly 130 years and are not black, as the Africans, whoe life is very hort, and yet they lye in the ame Climat, namely, under the Aequinoctial Line.

The Sixth aid, That Life being the continuance of the radical heat in Humidity, that Climat mut be properet for Longaevity which will longet preerve that conjunction. The violent heat of the Climats near the Equator conumes the radical moiture and makes the natural heat languih; although under the Line the coolnes of the nights twelve hours long, renders it more upportable: whereas in our longet Summer-days when the Sun is in Cancer, he is no more then 18 degrees from the Horizon and o diffues his rays upon the vapours hovering about the Earth, which reflecting the ame after a refraction make the nights almot always light, and conequently hot; there being no light without heat. On the contrary, the Northern parts towards the Pole, receiving the Suns rays only obliquely are very cold and unfit for long-life, combating the heat and deiccating the radical moiture. But the temperately hot are the mot healthy, epecially if the air (of greatet neceity to Life) be pure and not corrupted by vapours.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXVII. Which is mot neceary to a State, and mot noble, Phyick or Law?
div.p:
THee two Profeions are not abolutely neceary to the ubitence of a State, but only uppoe ome evil which they undertake to amend; Phyick the diorder of the humours in Mans body; and Law, that of Manners in the body of the State. So that if all people were healthy and good, both would be ueles, But the miery of our Nature having made us laves to our Appetite, and tributaries to Death and Dieaes which lead thereto; this adventitious neceity hath given rie to two powerful remedies againt thoe two evils; Phyick to oppoe the dieaes of the Body, and Law to repres the diorders of
our Paions: which being the ources of all michiefs, Law which retrains their coure, eems to have as much pre-eminence above Phyick, as the Body, which the latter governs, is inferiour to the Mind, which the former regulates. Moreover Health, the end of Phyick, is common both to Men and Beats, who have a better hare thereof, and have taught us the bet ecrets of Phyick: but to live according to right reaon, (which is the aim of Law) is peculiar to man; although oftentimes neither the one nor the other obtain its end.

The Second aid, Thee Diciplines are to be conider'd either according to their right ue, or as they are practis'd. Phyick, conider'd in its right adminitration, is the art of curing Dieaes and preerving Health, without which there is no pleaure in the World. Law, taken alo according to its intitution is that Tree of the Garden of Eden, which bears the knowledg of Good and Evil, Right and Wrong, as Phyick is the Tree of Life. Now if we compare them together, the latter which maintains the precious treaure of Health, is as the foundation upon which Law builds its excellent. Ordinances; for without Health, not only the adminitrations of Jutice but all employments of Arts and Exercies ceae. And though Laws and Jutice erve for the ornament of a State, yet they are not abolutely neceary to its conervation, there being ociety among Robbers; and many States having begun and ubited by Rapines, Violences and other injutices, but none without Health, which is the foundation of all goods, preerving the abolute Being of every thing, and by that means maintaining all the faculties of Body and Mind. Wherefore Phyick is profitable not only to the Body but alo to the Soul, whoe nature, faculties, and actions it contemplates. But if thee Arts be conider'd as they are practis'd now a days, 'tis certain that if there are Mountebanks, Ignorants, and Cheats who practie Phyick amongt a good number of good Phyitians; there are alo, Champertors, Forgers, and other uch black ouls, who live by fraud, which they exercie under the mak of jutice. We mut likewie ditinguih the bad judgments of certain Nations from the truth. For if the Romans ometimes banih'd their Phyitians and Chirurgians; this might be done out of ignorance, as when they aw the Gangren'd Leg of one of their Citizens cut off. And though they were for ome time without Phyitians, yet they were never without Phyick, at leat natural.

The Third aid, Law hath the pre-eminence above Phyick upon account of the great benefits it brings to a State, by delivering the ame from greater, more troubleome, and more incurable evils. And good (according to the Moral axiom) being the more divine by how much 'tis more common and diffus'd, it follows that Law is more divine then Phyick. For by checking our paions and obtructing the career of illegal Ambitions and Uurpations, it does good not only to private perons, as Phyick
doth, but alo to the whole Publick, which is engag'd by particular paions, whence Law-utes, Seditions, Wars, and other evils arie; which being publick are of more importance then thoe to which Phyick is deign'd, whoe whole buines is about the four humours, either to keep them in a jut temper, or reduce them to their natural tate, from which Dieaes debauch them. Beides, Phyick only cures the Body, whereas Law reprees the mind's diorders, and even the intentions. Latly, the evils Phyick defends us from, are of eaie cure, having all enible indications; but Law remedies uch as depend upon the thoughts and counels of men, impenetrable by ene. Moreover, Phyick regards only particular perons; but Law maintains a moral union and good intelligence between all the parts of a Commonwealth, namely, men of everal conditions, and keeps every one within the bounds of his own quality and tation; and o is like a Univeral Spirit or Intelligence preiding over all our motions, hindring ruptures and dienions (the bane of a State) as that doth vacuity, which tends to the detruction of the World.

The Fourth aid, That as the multitude of Phyitians in a City is a ign of a multitude of dieaes reigning therein; o the multitude of Laws and Judges argues corruption of manners. Wherefore both thee Profeions may eem equally ueles to a State free from wicked and mierable perons. And indeed we ee many Nations have wanted both: at Rome Phyitians were unknown for divers ages, and are o till in ome Countries: and mot States of the World dipene very well with the want of Lawyers, whoe contrary opinions are as detructive to the State, and particular perons, as the number of Phyitians is to the Sick. And as they are mot healthful who ue thee leat; o the mot flourihing States have fewet Lawyers; Wrangling, which is the daughter of Law, being the mot apparent caue of the diminution of the trength of Chritendom, where for ome Ages it hath reign'd; either by diverting the greatet number of its Miniters from the exercie of War, the principal means of amplifying a State, or by unprofitably taking up the people in Sutes. And therefore the Spaniards found no afer coure to preerve the new World to themelves, then by debarring all Lawyers entrance into it.

The Fifth aid, That this made for the Phyitians. For the Spaniards ent many of them to the new World, to dicover the imples there and bring them into Europe. Moreover, as 'tis more neceary to live and to live in health, then to live in ociety or riches (which are the things Law takes care of) o much doth Law yield to Phyick in this point, which Gods Word, who commands to honour the Phyitian, aith was created for neceity. Which as plainly decides the Quetion as that Reolution was worthy of the Fool of Fraceco Sforza Duke of Milan, which he gave in the like Dipute of preference between the
Phyitians and Advocates; That at Executions the Thief marches before the Hang-man. Moreover Kings, who are above Laws, ubject themelves to thoe of Phyitians, whom Julius Caear honour'd with the right of Incorporation into the City. Whereunto add the certainty of this Art (which is the true note of the excellence of a Dicipline) being founded upon natural Agents, whoe effects are infallible; whereas Law hath no other foundation but the will and phanie of Men, which changes with Times, Places, and Perons.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXVIII. Of Sea-icknes.
div.p:
NAture hath furnih'd Things with two ways of preerving the Being he hath given them, namely, to eek their good and flee their evil. Both which, Animals do by attracting what is proper to their nature by right fibers, and rejecting what is otherwie by tranvere fibers, of which the Expulive Faculty makes ue. So when the Stomack is urcharg'd with too great a quantity of matter, or goaded by its acrimony, the expulive Faculty of this part being irritated by what is contrary to it, cats it forth by yexing, belching, and vomiting. Yexing is a deprav'd motion of the upper Orifice of the Stomach which dilates and opens it elf to expell ome thing adhering to its Tunicles or orbicular Mucles; which being commonly a harp and pungent vapour, we ee this Hickcock is remov'd by a cup of cold water, or ele by holding the breath; for the coldnes of the water reprees the acrimony of the vapour'd, and the retrain'd Spirits by heat caue it to reolve and evaporate. Vomiting is alo a deprav'd motion of the Stomack, which contracts it elf at the bottom to drive out ome troubleome matter; which, if it adhere too fat, or Nature be not trong enough, caueth Naueounes or a vain deire to vomit. Belching is caus'd when the aid matter is flatuous and meets no obtacle. Thee motions are either through the proper vice of the Stomack, or through ympathy with ome other part. The former proceeds ometimes from a cold and moit intemperies. Whence man, the moitet of all Animals, is alone ubject to Vomiting, except Dogs and Cats; but he only has the Hickcock; and Children, as being very humid vomit frequently. Sometimes 'tis from a faulty conformation of the Stomack, as when 'tis too traight, or from ome troubleome matter, either internal or external. The internal is a pungent humour, and ometimes Worms. In hort, every thing that any way irritates the Expulive and weakens the Retentive Faculty: So, oyly, fat, and weet things
floating upon the Stomack, provoke to vomit by relaxing the fibres which erve for retention. External caues are all uch, as either irritate or relax the Stomack; as, tinking Smells, and the ole imagination of dipleaing things, violent winds; exercie, epecially uch wherein the Body is mov'd by omthing ele, and contributes not it elf to the motion, as going in a Coach or a Ship; for here the Body rets and alo the parts are relax'd, only the Spirits agitated by this motion act more trongly upon the humours, and thee are here more eaily evacuated by reaon of the relaxation of the fibres then in other exercies, wherein the Body tirs it elf; as riding-pot, or a troat, in which the Nerves are bent, and conequently, all the parts more vigorous, and hence vomiting is not o eaie. 'Tis alo the equality of the motion which makes perons, unus'd to go in a Coach, vomit ooner when the Coach goes in a mooth and even field then upon rough ways. The ame hapning upon the Sea, 'tis no wonder if people be o apt to vomit there.

The Second aid, That neither the agitation of the Air, nor the motion of the Body can be the ole caue of Vomiting, and other Sea-maladies; ince the like and more violent at Land, as Swings, Charets, and Pots, produce not the ame effects. For we conider the agitation of the Stomack as the caue of vomiting, that of the Feet and Legs being but accidental; and experience tetifies, that 'tis not the lifting up but the falling down of the Ship that caues the riing of the Stomack. Wherefore I hould rather pitch upon the alt-air of the Sea, abounding with harp and mordicant Vapours: which being attracted by repiration trouble the Stomack, epecially its uperior orifice, the eat of the enitive Appetite by reaon of the Nerves of the ixth Conjugation: thus the door being open, the matter contain'd in the Stomack, which is alo infected with the malignity of thee vapours, is voided by the ordinary ways: as happens ometimes to uch who only come near the Sea. Indeed the bitternes and altnes of the humour in the Mouth, which is the forerunner of Vomiting, together with the quivering of the nether Lip, proceeding from the continuity of the inward membrane of the Stomack with that of the Gullet and Mouth, manifets the vapours which excite it to be alt and nitrous. Whence alo plain water drunk with a little alt, caues Vomit. Now if this malady happens ooner in a Tempet, 'tis becaue thoe nitrous pirits are more tirr'd in the toing of the Sea than in a Calm: as they ay, 'tis more frequent in the Torrid Zone, becaue there is a greater attraction of the aid Spirits by the heat of the Climate, which on the other is an enemy to the Stomack, extreamly weakning it, as cold much helps its functions. Such as go into deep Mines, are eis'd with the like diturbance to this of the Sea, by repiration of the nitrous Spirits which iue out of the entrails of the Earth and are the caue of its fecundity.

The Third aid, That Cato (who repented of three things, (1.) Of having told a Secret to his Wife, (2.) Of having pent a day without doing omthing, And (3.) of having gone by Sea when he might have gone by Land) had no doubt experienc'd the michiefs of that unfaithful Element: the cruellet whereof is the Scurvy, a Dieae complicated with everal others, and whoe chief ymptoms, are the ulceration and welling of the Gums and Legs, with pains over all the Body, caus'd by the impurity and malignity of the Air. But the mot frequent is vomiting, caus'd by the ole agitation and violence of the Air. For our aerious Spirits not only receive the qualities of the air we breathe, but alo follow its temper and motion, as is een by the Head-ach, eiing thoe that are beaten by winds in the Country; and by the eeming turning of their heads who attentively behold the circumgyration of a Wheel or ome other Body. So the Air at Sea being much agitated puts in motion the Spirits which are of the ame nature, and thee being tirr'd et the humours on work, which incommoding the parts are by them driven out by vomits and other ejections, according to every one's temper and propenity. For the cholerick and broad-breated, vomit more eaily and uccesfully then the phlegmatick and narrow-breated, whoe Organs of repiration are not ufficiently free. Whereunto alo the eaon of the year contributes; for Summer provokes vomit more then Winter, when the humours being more heavy, rather tend downwards. But epecially Cutom is coniderable herein, which renders thoe that go frequently to Sea not obnoxious to its inconveniences.

The Fourth aid, That the Earth conits of three ubtances; one Unctuous, which is the inflammable moiture, call'd by the Chymits Sulphur; another Cinereou • , which they call the Faeces or Caput mortuum; the third humid and incombutible, which they divide into Mercury and Salt; this latter again into Salt-nitre and Vitriol, of which the Sea being full, the ame is communicated to the firt Region of the Air contiguous to the Waters; and, ininuating it elf into our Bodies by inpiration; produces the ame effects therein, that it doth taken in ubtance; four Grains of which is a ufficient Vomit. Whereto alo helps the gentle agitation of the waves, which makes it penetrate; the examples of others vomiting, and epecially the fear commonly incident to uch as were never upon the Sea before, who are mot obnoxious to this trouble. For that Paion o contringes the whole Body, epecially the inward parts, that it weakens and relaxes the Nerves, epecially the Fibres which keep the parts in a jut tenor; and o the oblique Fibres and orbicular Mucles (which erve to retain them) being languid, uffer the juices and humours to pas out. The ame fear which caues relaxation of the Sphincter Ani & Veicae, relaxing the Mucles which erve to open and cloe the upper Orifice of the Ventricle:
Hence fear is commonly accompani'd with the pain of this part; whoe ene being very exquiite is the caue that the Vulgar call it, The pain of the Heart; which alo for the ame reaon happens to uch as look down upon low places.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXIX. Of Love by Inclination, or Sympathy.
div.p:
'TIs not only amongt the Poets that Love is blind, the obcurity of this caues evidencing him no les o amongt the Philoophers, who aign two orts of it; one of Knowledge, which tends to a good known; the other of Inclination, whereby we love without knowing why. Indeed there is no love without ground, and ome ort of knowledge; but yet, when the caue obliging us to love is manifet, it makes the former kind of love; when obcure, the latter: whereof we have many examples in nature, not only in the Symbolical qualities of the Elements, Electrical and Magnetical attractions of Stones, particular alliances of Metals, and all the amities of Plants and Trees, as of the female Palm which is aid to lean towards the male, and thoe which are found amongt Animals; but epecially in the particular inclinations of ome Perons to others unknown and void of all recommendations to qualifie them for the ame, and the emotions ome have felt both in Soul and Body at the firt ight of their unknown Parents: as alo of a contrary effect, when a dead body bleeds upon the preence of its Murderer; which is a tetimony of an antipathetical hatred contrary to the aboveaid Love, which we find in our elves almot upon all occurrences; as when two equally trangers play at Tennis, we wih that one may win and the other loe. For the firt motions of Love, as well as of all other Paions, are not in our power, and afford not the Mind time to deliberate and make reflexion upon them. Hence oftentimes, Anger, Sadnes, Panick fright, and uch other Paions eie upon us without caue; and Love doth the like frequently, without any apparent reaon. Yea, we may ay, there is no Love of Knowledg but what took its firt rie from that of Inclination, which preently makes us enamor'd of the proportions of a Face, which dipleaes another that undertands the ame as well as we, but without being any way affected therewith, becaue he finds not in it that correpondence and ympathetical reemblance that produces a Love of Inclination, which may alo arie without any knowledge, as in that blind man who lov'd a Las whom he had never een; as alo in Petrarch who made o many Veres upon his Lawra, whom he could never behold; The caue
whereof I hould attribute to the power of the Imagination, which fancies omthing of lovelines where there is none; or ele to the ole action of the Will, which not able to remain neuter between love and hatred (ince its action is to will, and to will is to love) when it meets no caue of hatred in an object, loves it; and hates it, when it finds nothing amiable therein. For if you aign the reaon of this love to the tranpiration of Spirits iuing out of the lov'd peron's body, their ubtance is too volatile to act o far off; and their iuing being never alike, (becaue the pores of the kin are more topt at one time then at another) this love would be remarkably alter'd every moment. Beides, we many times love by an inclination an abent peron for his merit; and many have been enamour'd of Beauties at the firt ight of their Pictures; but love was never produc'd between two blind perons, notwithtanding any emiion of ympathetical Spirits. Moreover, 'tis the Species and not the Spirits that are receiv'd by our Senes; and o none hould ever love thoe they had not een, but by a Propective-glas.

The Second aid, That it imports not much to the cauing of love, whether the object be really or only imaginarily good; and indeed our minds eem to interes themelves more in the purute and preervation of the latter then the former, which maintains it elf by its proper worth. Wherefore if Love of Inclination preuppoe goodnes in the object, the ame mut be apprehended either by the Imagination or by ome other Faculty, to which it mut therefore be approximated either immediately by it elf, or by it elf. So the weetnes of Honey makes it elf perceptible to the Tongue by it elf: but the proportion of a fair countenance cannot make it elf known but by its pecies, which is the picture and repreentation of it. This way, is produc'd the Love of Inclination as well as that of Knowledge; only with this difference, that the Species which produce the former, act imperceptibly, and more uddenly then thoe that produce the latter, which is more deliberate and rational.

The Third aid, There are but two orts of Love; one, improper and Metaphorical; the other, proper and formal. That precedes Knowledg, and is an Intinct inclining natural things to their proper good: This follows Knowledg as its guide, and is the firt Expanion of the Heart, pleaing it elf with the good it likes. And as that is diffus'd over all Creatures, o this is retrain'd only to the enible and rational. The Appetite, whence the former proceeds, is immers'd and incorporated in the nature of every thing, and not ditinguih'd from the faculties and powers they have to act. But the latter, arieth from the Appetite properly o call'd, whoe functions or motions are the eleven Paions, to which as many acts correpond in the Rational Appetite. The Quetion cannot be concerning that improper
Appetite; for then Stones hould have Love, as well as Intinct, towards their Centre; but of the true and proper Love ubequent to Knowledg, which gives Amability to good, as Light doth Viibility to colours. Wherefore they who talk of certain Spirits iuing out of the lov'd peron's body into the eyes of the Lover, and eiing upon the heart, without falling under knowledge, eem ignorant of the nature of Love. For hould uch pirits arrive at the heart without being oberv'd; yet they mut come out thence again to be known before they can caue Love; as we cannot know any thing that is in the oul, unles it come firt out thence and become enible; ince nothing is in the Undertanding but what pas'd through the Sene. So a man cannot know his own face but by reflection from a Looking-glas without him. For the Soul at our Nativity is like a mooth table or white-heet of Paper, and thence its primitive notions during this preent tate is by Phantams upplied to us by our Senes. Now the eential reaon of this dependance which keeps Love ubject to Knowledg, is, that the Appetite, which is the Principle of Love, is only a Paion or Propriety of the thing wherein it is; but the Principle of Knowledge is an eential degree of Nature. Hence, Souls are ditinguih'd by Cognition, not by Appetite: we call the Senitive Soul, o, from the knowledg of Sene, which contitutes its eential difference; and the Rational Soul o, becaue Reaon, the principle of Knowledg is a degree of Nature: but Appetite is a propriety which follows it. And being there is the ame reaon of Actions and their Principles; as the Appetite uppoes a principle of Knowledg, o Love, which is the action of the Appetite, uppoes actual and clear Knowledg. Hence, there is no love without knowledg. For that we have more phanie to the one of two perons playing then to the other, 'tis becaue we dicern omthing in his face, getures, or motion that pleaes us better. Sympathy (pretended the caue of this love) may indeed be the foundation of it; inamuch as we naturally love thoe like our elves; but it can never make us love till we have found in the thing ome Je-ne-cay-quoy of lovely. It cannot be the ole caue of our love, ince 'tis of it elf imperceptible to our knowledg, and conequently cannot produce love till the effects of uch ympathy, to wit, uch an Air, uch a Motion, and uch a Deportment have pleas'd us. And whereas 'tis aid that from eyes which behold us attentively we perceive omething come forth that animates us; I anwer, that oftentimes quick fix'd and weet intuitions are tokens of love, from which 'tis no wonder if ours take rie and growth, as from its proper caue; ince Love begets Love.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXX. How the ndertanding moves the Will.
div.p: 'TIs proper to the Undertanding not only to conjoyn things wholly different, but oftentimes to abtract and eparate uch as are perfectly united in one and the ame ubtance, and differ only in accidents, which it evers from their ubjects. Hence reflecting upon it elf, it ditinguihes in its operation two Faculties, to wit, its Cognition and the Reaonable Appetite or Will, although they are one and the ame thing, not only in the Soul, whoe eence is imple, but alo in the Intellect; nor are their objects different, Truth, the object of the Undertanding, being convertible and all one with Good, the object of the Will. Hence Civilians acknowledg no Will in thoe that want Undertanding, as Ideots and Children. And as the ame Sun-beam that produces light, caues heat too by the continuation of its action, or by its re-union in a Burning-glas: o an object long conider'd or trongly apprehended by the Undertanding as good, immediately incites and inflames the ame to eek and deire it. So that the cognition of a thing in the Undertanding is only Theory, which the Will, applying it elf thereunto by deire, reduces into Practice. As the Theorical habit of an Art differs not from the Practical, and the concluion of a Syllogim is only a dependance upon its two Premies. Wherefore the Will, which is the practice of the Undertandings peculation, and a reult of its ratiocination, is not ditinguih'd from the Undertanding; and to know good, to deire and eek means to poes it, are operations continu'd by one ole motion. Beides, to eparate the actions of the Souls faculties, and make them independent one of another, would infer a kind of diviibility in the Soul: but the Will being only a deire, every deire a pecies of motion, and motion an accident; it is eparable from its ubject, the Undertanding, whereof 'tis only an affection and propiety. So that the Intellect and the Will being the ame thing, when the former is carried towards an apprehended good, we ay it moves the Will, as it doth the other powers which it employs in quet of that good, when the ame is external and it cannot attain to it by it elf.

The Second aid, That to know, to will, and to be able, although of the ame extent in things purely natural (as in a Stone, whoe knowledge, deire, and power to tend to its centre are the ame thing) yet are different actions in rational agents. For oftentimes we know without willing, and will what we cannot do; and ometimes we know not that which we would: Oftentimes we will things not only without, but even againt Reaon; witnes the irregular Appetite of breeding Women
and Green-icknes Maids. Wherefore thee actions being different, the Faculties from which they proceed, the Intellect, Will and Motive Faculty, mut be wholly ditinct; eeing their two adequate Objects, which pecifie Faculties, are conider'd under divers formal Reaons, which are the ole Caues of the ditinction of Faculties. For Entity immaterial and piritual, is, as true and intelligible, the object of the Undertanding; but, as good and deirable, 'tis the object of the Will: which are two wholly different formal Reaons. Now though the Intellect and the Will are two different Faculties, yet there is uch a dependance between them that the one can do nothing without the other, and they communicate mutual aitance: the Undertanding upplies Reaons and Counels, which the Will caues the Powers under its dominion to execute: for 'tis a blind Queen, having no knowledg of her own but only what light he receives from the Intellect. But how can it ee the ame, if blind, as 'tis fancied? We anwer, that as all things have a bent and natural inclination to their proper good, though they know it not (as even the Intellect aents to a truth known by ratiocination, but knows not why it aents to a firt Principle, as, That the whole is greater then its part, and that 2 and 1 make 3; thee being connate Notions) o the Will is carried to the Good propos'd to it by the Undertanding, becaue the goodnes and utablenes thereof engage it to endeavours of enjoying it, wherein its upream Felicity lyes.

The Third aid, Since the Will is a deire, every deire a motion, and every motion from ome other (nothing moving it elf); the Will cannot deire unles mov'd by ome uperior power and knowledg: For as there is no deire without knowledg, o, to the end this may not be idle and unprofitable, Nature hath joyn'd an Appetite to it; to wit, a Senitive Appetite to the knowledg of a Senible Good apprehended uch by the Imagination, which is common to Men and Brutes; and a Rational Appetite (the Will) to the knowledg of an honet Good apprehended uch by the Undertanding. And whereas immaterial things cannot be known by themelves but by uch as are enible and corporeal, we cannot better judge of the manner whereby the Intellect moves the Will, then by that whereby the Imagination moves the Senitive Appetite; which is the weetnes of the Object, whoe Species being receiv'd by ome one of the outward Senes, and carried from the Common ene to the Phanie which relihes the ame to the full, is then propos'd to the Senitive Appetite, which preently flyes to it, oftentimes o impetuouly as that it hurries the Reaon and the Will along with it elf, and contrains them to yield to the violence of thoe Paions which it excites to joyn with it in puruit of that good, and which itre doubles upon the occurrence of any obtacle to its deigns. In like ort the Will is carried of it elf to a vertuous action, when the Undertanding repreents the honety
of the ame to it; provided it be not otherwie prepoes'd, and the aid action be not accompani'd with difficulties and thorns, as commonly happens; for then that Senitive Appetite oftentimes gets the better of Reaon; the Fleh, of the Spirit. There is this difference between the motions of the Will and the Appetite, that the latter necearily follows the duct of the Imagination, by which 'tis inclin'd inpite of it elf towards a Delectable Good; but the Will (common to us with Angels) is o mov'd by the Intellect, that nevertheles it always remains mitres of its own actions, and can do either good or evil by vertue of its liberty, which alone dicriminates Man from Beat, and gives him right of empire and command, (which the Civilians define, a power of making ue of any thing at one's pleaure;) and without which not only Judgments, Vertues, Vices, Rewards and Punihments, Praies and Dipraies, Conultations and Deliberations would be ueles; but alo all Laws would be to no purpoe, Man would be in wore condition then Brutes, over whom he hath no other advantage but that of Reaon; which would erve for nothing if he acted things necearily, as other Agents do, and not freely and voluntarily.

The Fourth aid, He had always accounted it a vain enquiry, how the Undertanding moves the Will; and the Senes, the Senitive Appetite towards their Objects; becaue the Cognocitive Faculty, and thee Appetites being really ditinct and having nothing common, there cannot intervene any commerce between them. They are Officers that have evered charges, without having any thing to hare or dipatch together. Nevertheles it being true that we love nothing but what is firt apprehended and judg'd amiable, we mut eek this dependance omwhat higher. Now all actions are of the whole Compoitum; and conequently Man, who is the whole, is he who by his knowledg either of Sene or of the Intellect, judges what both the one and the other Appetite ought to embrace or reject. Then after he hath pas'd his judgment by his Cognocitive Faculty, he determines himelf to follow by his Appetite what he hath judg'd fit to be done; in conequence whereof he applies his Motive Faculty to the execution of his Reolution. So that 'tis Man that moves himelf by his Will towards Good or Evil, to purue or avoid, after he hath conider'd what he ought to will, how, and in what ort to comport himelf. By this means we obviate a world of difficulties ariing from this Quetion, and reolve many; as, amongt others, How the Undertanding comes to illuminate corporeal phantams, without etablihing an Intellectus Agens for that purpoe, whoe office is pretended to ublime thoe phantams by denudating them of their ingularity and materiality, that o they may become actually intelligible and proportionate to the Intellect. For, beides that 'tis impoible to conceive how any piritual light can fall from the Intellect upon a corporeal phantam; (that which is corporeal
being incapable of receiving any thing piritual, and the Intellect of producing any thing out of it elf, ince all its actions are immanent:) we are deliver'd from all this trouble by aying, that in the tate of this preent life Man by his outward and inward Senes takes in as much knowledg of things as they can give him, and afterwards by his Undertanding deduces and infers things which the phantams alone could not acquaint him with. Thus when a phantam repreents to him a thing which his eye beholds afar off, he by his Undertanding judges the ame a Subtance, becaue the phantam hews him that it ubits of it elf; if he ee it walk, he judges it alive; So that 'tis ufficient to the drawing of all his Conequences that he infer from the phantams what they are capable to repreent to him, without need of piritualizing them, or of commerce between them and the Intellect. In like manner, 'tis not needful that the Intellect hew the Will its Object; but the man's eeing it, is ufficient to caue him to move himelf by his Will towards the Good which he apprehends. For as a King hath his Scouts to dicover the tate of his Enemies, upon whoe report he holds a Council of War, wherein he reolves what is to be done. So Man by his Senes dicovers the nature of Objects, as by o many Spies, which make their report to the Imagination; after which the Undertanding judges of the ame; and latly, the Man reolves and determines by his Will. Thus 'tis the Man that makes all this progres, employing all his Faculties diverly for that purpoe. And as 'twere impertinent to ak how the Scouts and Council of War acted and mov'd the Troops which execute the General's reolution to make them fight; but it uffices to ay, That 'tis his Order: So 'tis aburd to inquire how the Senes or Undertanding move the Appetite or the Will; 'tis ufficient to ay, That a Man reolves to will after cogniance of the matter.

The Fifth aid, That that which moves the Will, is omething divine and more excellent then Reaon, namely, that part of the Intellect, which is the knowledg of Firt Principles, and is to the Soul what he is to the Body which he informs. This appears in all the Will's actions; whereof thoe that tend to the End are, to Will, to Deire, to Enjoy, when the aid End is a Good, and is either abent or preent; not to Will, to Flee, to be Sad, when the aid End is an Evil, and that conider'd too either as abent or preent: thoe which repect the means leading to uch End are, To Chue, to Conent, and to Employ ome rather then others. All which actions it cannot exert of it elf, but being mov'd by that divine power of the Intellect which repreents to it the goodnes of the End, and the utablenes of the Means for attaining the ame: in like manner as the End moves the efficient Caue, attracting it to its proecution by an improper and metaphorical Motion.

The Sixth aid, As the Will is mov'd by the Intellect, o is the Intellect mov'd reciprocally by the Will, which commands
it to divide, define, abtract and perform its operations in uch and uch manner. Yea, there is no Faculty but is ubject to its empire. It commands the Imagination to frame Idea's and Species; the Memory, to recall and repreent them; the Motive Faculty, to peak, walk, and the like other actions; the Senitive Appetite, to love, hate, be angry, to raie and appeae its paions; though many times thee are deaf to its dictats.

The Seventh aid, Since the Rational Soul is a imple Form, and every Form a perfection of the ubject wherein it reides; that of Man being to know Truth, to love Good, and to be united to both by Fruition: the ame Soul when it knows, is call'd the Intellect; when it deires or loves the thing known, the Will. So that there is no need for the one to be mov'd by the other; for 'tis the Soul that moves it elf, which therefore Aritotle calls Entelechia, and the Principle of motion; the Pythagoreans, a Self-moving number.

The Eighth aid, That the Will depends not any way on the Intellect, and conequently is not mov'd by it. Which is prov'd, firt, becaue the Will is mutable and oftimes contrary, upon the ame ratiocination; as it would not be, if it were mov'd by the Undertanding. For if the Will were, according to Aritotles definition, a deire of good with reaon, the one ought always to follow the other. But it not doing o, 'tis an argument, that the Will hath another principle then the ratiocination. In the econd place, as it was lately argu'd, there are amities of Inclination, properly o call'd, becaue not grounded upon any Reaon; and therefore the Will, which never exercies its dominion more freely then in Love, follows not the Intellect in that kind of amities, and conequently is not mov'd by it. Thirdly, whatever the Civilians ay, Fools and Children have their Wills, as well as the Wier and Elder; yea both the former Will, as reolvedly as the latter: and Women, who we ay have les judgment then Men, are yet more elf-will'd and obtinate then they. On the contrary, the mot judicious are commonly the leat reolute, and find mot difficulties in willing. An Emperick and ignorant Phyician will be bolder and reolve things more pertinaciouly then an old experienc'd Methodit. A young and giddy Captain will ooner tell his opinion, which is the iue of his Will, then an old beaten Souldier who doubts of every thing, and labours much to bring himelf to a reolution. But the contrary would happen, if the Will follow'd the Duct of the Judgment. Wherefore I conceive rather that the Will moves the Undertanding as well as all the other Faculties; ince no body can reaon inpite of himelf, but he mut will to et his Mind upon a thing before the Intellect can make its reviews.

The Ninth aid, The bet coure was, rather to alve the Opinions of the School by ome Expedient, then wholly to
depart from them, as a way too difficult to keep; and that he conceiv'd it better to untye the Gordian knot then to cut it; which belongs only to Alexander. 'Tis acknowledg'd that the Intellect and the Will are two Faculties of the Rational Soul; that we will nothing unles the judgment believe it good, whether it be really or only apparently uch. But the difficulty is concerning the means that the Intellect employs to carry the Will to uch good. Take it thus: The Will is carri'd of it elf to good, as a Stone to the Centre; but as this Stone is ometimes hinder'd from arriving thereunto by obtacles which tay it; o Ignorance puts a bar to the Will. Hereupon the Undertanding falls to work till it have remov'd that obtacle by its reaoning: Which done, as there is nothing between the end of a hadow, and the beginning of light; o there is nothing between the end of our ignorance, and the beginning of our volition: where the operation of the Undertanding ends, there begins that of the Will, no more induc'd, mov'd, and as little forc'd as the weight that tends downwards, which cannot be aid carri'd towards the Centre, unles improperly, by him that takes away the piece of wood or other obtacle that top'd it in the Air. Moreover, it were no longer a Will, if mov'd by any other principle but it elf. As is een in thoe who having a will to do omthing, when the ame is once commanded them, change their reolution, or do only with regret what before they deir'd with paion: as the ame motion which was natural to the Stone, becomes violent to it when it is impell'd, intead of being uffer'd to decend downwards.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXI. Whence come the Marks or Spots wherewith Children are born?
div.p:
AS the Degrees of Life have dominion over the Firt Qualities, o they have authority one over another, each in his order. The Vegetative life in Man makes ue of the Elementary Qualities at pleaure, even to the prejudice of their own Nature. So, Heat congregates things of the ame, and eparates thoe of different Nature; but our Vegetative Soul makes it do the contrary, namely, Unite the Four Humours in the Veins though different in nature, intead of egregating them: for in this Cae, Heat acts not with full authority but as the Soul's Officer, following her intentions. And the reaon is, becaue thee four Humours being ingredients into the Nativity of Man, they mut necearily pas into his nourihment; which they cannot do without being mingled together. But when the
Blood is out of the Veins; then the Heat, diengag'd from the Soul's juridiction, digregates and eparates all four, making the Choler float uppermot, the Phlegm next, then the Blood, and lowet of all, Melancholy, as the dregs. Amongt Souls there is the ame order of Superiority. The Senitive makes the Vegetative obey it; as appears by this, that if after meat the Imagination attend much to an object, the Concoction of the Food is retarded, becaue all the Faculties of the Soul being united in their Root and Eence of the Soul, when he ets her elf much upon one object, he leaves the other inferiour powers idle; they not being able to work but as the Soul, (their principle) employs them. Now this premis'd, I ay, when a breeding Woman hath a longing for any thing, this deir'd thing is imprinted trongly in the Phancy; and this imprinting being made in the Brain, the Spirits which flow from thence, carry a copy thereof with them. For as an intire Looking-glas repreents but one Image, but every piece of a broaken one hath its whole Pourtrait: becaue the Intentional Species or Images of things, though diviible by reaon of their ubject, are yet in themelves formally indiviible, being Forms without Matter, and conequently indiviible; Diviion proceeding from Quantity, a concomitant of Matter: So thoe Spirits which tream from the Brain, though they leave there the image of the deir'd thing, yet withall they carry the ame image with them, as being portions of the ubtance wherein it is engraven; and running to the place where the Foetus is form'd, by reaon of the union of its Umbilical Veels with thoe of the Mother, they arrive at the Infant and imprint the Characters, they bring, upon it: the Vegetative and Platick or Formative Vertue uffering it elf to be over-rul'd by the Senitive, as this is by the Imaginative, and this again by the other uperiour powers. When the teeming Woman touching her elf in any part, the Spirits run thither from the Brain, either by reaon of the touch or the motion (both depending upon the Animal Spirits) but finding the Mother's fleh too hard and diproportinate to their effect, and miing their blow, they go to give it upon the tenderer fleh of the Child. And as in Generation, the Spirits of all the parts of the Body accur to the place where the Seed is receiv'd, there to engrave the Characters of the parts whence they flow, which afterwards erve for the Formative Vertue, every one having his tak to make the part from which it iu'd: o the Mother's Spirits keep the ame coure and rule towards the Embryo, o that thoe which erv'd to the Mother's touch, go to find that ame place in the Child's Body, there to mark the Image which they brought from the Brain; Nature finding ways for her Intention where none appear.

The Second aid, The impotence of that Sex and their weaknes of Mind, (evidenc'd by the violence of all their Paions, which know no mediocrity) is one of the principal caues of
the impetuoity of their deires. Now the Species of the thing deir'd being in the Imagination, it excites the Appetite which deir'd it; this the motive Faculty, which employs the Animal Spirits to execute the commands of the Faculties by whom it is et on work. And as the Vertues and Images of things generated here below by the heat and influence of the Stars, are receiv'd in the Air which conigns them to the Earth; o thoe Spirits receive the Species and Images whereof the brain is full; and being directed by the Imagination to the Womb (which hath great communication with the Brain by means of the nerves of the ixt Pair, as appears by the effects of Odors upon that part) there they retrace and imprint upon the Child the Images wherewith they are laden. For, if it be true that the Imagination can act beyond its Subject, as Etriches and Tortoies are aid to hatch their Eggs with their Eyes, and that Hens hatch Chickens of the colour of uch cloths as are laid before them whilet they are itting; much more may the Imagination of a Woman repreent upon the tender Fruit in her womb the Images of things which he paionately deires: and this is no more trange than the common obervation, of People falling ick, and recovering again, meerly by Fancy.

The Third aid, That the images of things deired are, in the Spirits, jut as thoe of enible objects are in the Air, which is full of them. But as thee, that they may be een, mut be terminated by a mooth and opake body; o, that thoe which are in the pirits may be expre'd, they mut be terminated by a oft, tender, and capable body, as a child's is in the firt months of his conformation, during which alone he is uceptible of thee impreions, which are only of things edible and potable; being the Child, then endu'd only with enitive Life, cannot be affected but by things erving to the Animal Life, as aliments are, which (beides) are ordinarily and mot ardently deir'd by breeding Women; thoe that long for chalk, coals, and other impurities being unhealthy and ditemper'd. Now to give account why the Grapes, Mulberries, Strawberries, Gooe-berries, and other Fruits delineated upon our bodies, ripen and change colour at the ame time as the true fruits upon the earth do, I hall not recurr to the Stars, or Talimanical Figures, but more probably to that Univeral Spirit which caueth the ame fermentation in the pirits of our bodies as in Wine and the Vine when it is in its ap and flower; and in Pork or Venion when Hogs and Deer are alt, mezled, or go to rut.

The fourth aid, That ome of thee Marks adhere to particular Families. So the family of Seleucus had an Anchor upon the thigh; in Greece ome were ditinguih'd by a Lance, a Crevih, a Star, &c. which marks, as Warts and Moles, proceed from the Formative Vertue in the eed, which containing the Idea of all the parts, exprees them to the life in the child. Other orts of Marks are not ordinary but fortuitous, and depend
upon the Imagination alone, which employs the pirits which are common both to the Mother and Child by the Umbilical Veels, and have the ame motions: o that when the Woman cratches her elf in any part of her body, the pirits having a like motion are carri'd towards that part, and at the ame time towards that correpondent part in the child's body, whoe tendernes is alone uceptible of the image wherewith they are impregnated, and which is never to be removed, as being from the firt conformation.

The Fifth aid, That not only the deire of eating and drinking, which is pacifi'd by enjoyment, but any vehement paion, even a udden fright againt which there is no remedy, ometimes leads the variable Fancy of Women to interrupt the work of the Formative Vertue, otherwie always very regular. As a certain Woman having een a Criminal broken upon the Wheel, brought forth a child that all the bones were broken. Hereunto alo contribute the exces or defect of the Matter, its evil quality, and the deprav'd conformation of the Womb. But to attribute the communication requir'd for this effect between the Imaginative and Formative Faculties to the Umbilical Veels, cannot hold; there being but one Vein, two Arteries, and the rachus, without any nerves, by which alone the animal pirits are tranmitted from the Brain. Nor can thoe Species without diipation and confuion, eparate themelves from the mas of Blood, and pas by the circuit of the Mother's Veins into the Umbilical Vein of the Foetus; wherefore 'tis more rational to acribe this effect to the correpondence of the Faculties, whereof the Superior indeed move the Inferior, but by a imple and pure irradiation, without tranmitting any thing to them: There needing no other communication then that of a Lutinit's finger, or a Dancing-mater's foot with their Imagination, which yet follow one the other, although it tranmits not to the ends of their hands and feet, the notes and cadences which they repreent. Thus, for the imprinting of a Mark, the Formative Faculty being mov'd by the Imagination, hath no need to receive any Species, as the Cognocitive Faculties have, of which number the Formative is not. Nor is it more trange, that the Foetus, indu'd with a particular oul, yet feels the effects of its Mothers Imagination, than that Fruits receive the changes and alterations of the Trees to which they adhere.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXII. Of the Original of Forms.
div.p: A Form is that which gives either Being or Motion. When it gives only Motion, 'tis call'd an Aitent Form, as that which moves the Heavens: When Being, an Informant Form, tyl'd alo an Act, Perfection, Eence, Vertue, Beauty. For what ever is excellent in a Subject, proceeds from the Form; which determining the Indifferency of the matter (of it elf imperfect) makes it to be one, that is to ay, not divided in it elf, and divided from every thing ele. Created Forms are either piritual or material; and both thee again either ubtantial or accidental. Spiritual accidental Forms are, Vertue, Science, and all Habits of the Soul. Subtantial piritual forms are Intelligences and Rational ouls. Material accidental forms are either imple, as Heat and Whitenes; or compounded, as Beauty and Health. Under Material ubtantial Forms are comprehended Vegetative and enitive Souls, which are the Forms of Plants and Brutes, and the Subject now in hand; although I will not grant them to be Subtances, but only Accidents. All agree that there are Forms, becaue there are Actions; which preuppoe Powers. Thee Powers are properties flowing from ome active principle which ets them on work; which the Matter, becaue purely pasive, cannot do; and therefore it mut be the Form. But the doubt is, whether this Form be ubtantial or accidental; as, whether it be only a certain degree of Heat, which makes Plants and Animals be nouriht, grow, generate, and move, or ele ome Subtance and Form more excellent that employs Heat as its Intrument for producing thoe Actions. And this is mot probable. For otherwie, A Subtance compounded of Matter and Form hould, contrary to the Maxim, be made of that which is not Subtance, if Forms were only accidental. They are introduc'd into a capable Subject by an Univocal Agent, which by generation communicates a oul of the ame Nature with its own, which is material, and conequently diviible; yet o diviible as that it is not diminihed in the traduction, no more than the Species of a Looking-glas which produces it elf wholly and entirely in all bodies capable of it, or then the flame of a candle wherewith a thouand others may be lighted, without any diminution of its ubtance.

The econd aid, That Forms are primogenial Principles, no more generable than the Matter which they always accompany, and according to whoe dipoitions they only change appearance. For 'tis not credible that Forms, the principal pieces of the world (without which it would be depriv'd of that from
which it bears its name, to wit, Ornament and Beauty) are ubject to continual corruption; otherwie the world and the natures therein contain'd would have been chang'd in o long a time, and yet they remain till the ame. Beides, if Forms perih, they mut either be annihilated (but nothing is o in nature) or ele reolv'd into that whereof they are compos'd, ince they are uppos'd material; and nevertheles we ee no remainder of them. 'Tis therefore always the ame form but diverly dres'd, and aid to be generated when it changes from an imperfect to a perfect tate; and to be corrupted when it returns into a wore condition then what is had before; both, according to the everal dipoitions of its Subject.

The third aid, That all natural Forms are nothing but Accidents, ince they are in matter as in a ubject, from which they are ineparable; and not as parts; for they are parts of the whole, but not of the Matter. The Forms of the Elements are the firt Qualities. And as all Mixts are compounded of the four Elements, o they derive their form (as well as their matter) from them, which follows the nature of the Element predominant in the Compound. Thus Drines is the Form of a tone, which hath more of earth than of any other Element; Oyl is humid, becaue aerial; all Living Creatures are Hot, by reaon of Heat, the noblet and mot active quality, which, attaining to the proportion requiite for performing the offices of life, is call'd a Soul; and according as it is more or les refin'd, and meets with different ubjects, 'tis called a Vegetative Soul in Plants, and a Senitive oul in Brutes. I ay further, that thee Forms are nothing but Modes and Fahions of Being. For as Water turn'd into Air, and this into Fire by rarefaction, or into Water by condenation, are till the ame, not differing but according as their parts are more or les cloe; o as well Forms purely natural as other living Forms, are nothing but Modes and Fahions of Being of the Elements, their Qualities, and the everal Mixtures from which thoe Forms reult.

The fourth aid, according to Anaxagoras's opinion, That all things are in all, and conequently Forms in the Matter, out of whoe boom they are educ'd by Agents conjoyning things of the ame Nature, and eparating others. As Art (which imitates Nature) makes not Wine, but only prees out that vegetal juice which was before in the Grape; and out of Marble forms a Statue only by paring off what was uperfluous: o out of the Earth, Nature forms Plants, which are turn'd into the ubtance of Animals, whoe bodies are again reduc'd into Earth.

The fifth maintain'd the opinion of Albert the Great, who is for the Generation of things, which the preceding opinion over throws, holding nothing to be new generated; He aid, that Forms are indeed in the Matter, yet not entire and perfect, but only by halves and begun; according to their eence, not according to their exitence, which they acquire by the Agents which educe things out of their caues.

The Sixth aid, If it were o, then there would be no ubtantial Generation, becaue Exitence is nothing but a Manner of Being, adding nothing to Eence, nor really ditinguih'd from it. Wherefore I embrace Aritotle's opinion, that Forms are in the Matter, but only potentially, and as the Matter is capable of them; jut as Wax is potentially Caear's Statue, becaue capable of receiving that form. This he calls, to be drawn and educ'd out of the power or boom of the Matter: which is not to be receiv'd in it, or to depend of its dipoitions, ince this belongs alo to the Rational oul, which is not receiv'd in the body till the previous dipoitions, neceary for its reception, be introduc'd therein; but the Matter it elf concurrs, though in a paive way, not only to dipoe it elf, but alo to produce the Form, and conequently to preerve it. Which is not applicable to the Rational oul, whoe Being depends not anywie upon the Matter.

The Seventh aid, Matter, being a Principle purely paive and incapable of all action, cannot produce any thing, much les Forms, the noblet Entities in the world. 'Tis the principle of impotence and imperfection, and conequently the uglines, deformity, contrary to the Form whereof it hould partake, if it contain'd the ame in power, as Wine and Pepper do Heat, which becomes actual and enible when reduc'd into act by our Natural Heat which looens it from the parts which confin'd it. Wherefore Forms come from without, namely, from Heaven and its noblet part the Sun, the Father of Forms, which are nothing but Beams of light deriv'd from him as their Fountain, whoe heat and influences give motion and life; which is the abode of Heat in Humidity: not Elementary Heat; for then Arenic, Sulphur, and other Mixts, abounding with this Heat, hould have life; but Serpents, Salamanders, Fihes, Hemlock, Poppies, and other excesively cold Plants and Animals, hould not. Moreover in whatever manner the Elements and their Qualities be mix'd, they are till Elements, and can produce nothing above their own Nature, which is, to calefie, refrigerate, attenuate, rarefie, condene; but not the internal and external enes, the various motions and other actions of life, which can proceed only from a Celetial Heat, uch as that is which preerves a Plant amidt the rigours of Winter; whoe coldnes would oon detroy the Plant's heat, if it were of the ame nature. Hence Vegetative and Senitive Souls having no Contraries, becaue Contraries are plac'd under the ame Genus, (but the Celetial matter whereof thee ouls are contituted, and the Elements are not) therefore they are not corruptible after the manner of other Mixts; but like light, ceae to exit upon the ceation of the dipoitions which maintain'd them. For, uch is the order of Nature, that when a Subject is poet of all the dipoitions requiite for introduction of a Form, the Author of Nature, or (according to Plato) the Idea, or that
Soul of the World (which Avicenna held to be an Intelligence detinated to the generation of ubtantial Forms) concurrs to the production of the Form, as alo this concoure ceaes when thoe dipoitions are aboliht.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXIII. Whether Lean people are more healthy, and long-liv'd then Fat.
div.p:
THe Immortality of our ouls having an abolute dipoition to length of Life, it depends only upon that of the Body, that we do not live Ages as our firt Fathers did. For 'tis from ome defect in thee bodies that the differences of life even in Animals and Plants proceed; whence ome les perfect ouls, (as thoe of Oaks) are yet more long-liv'd then thoe of Beats. The igns of long and hort life, are either imply uch, or alo caues and effects. Such is the conformation of the parts of our body. A great number of Teeth is held a ign of longaevity, as well becaue 'tis an effect of the trength of the Formative Faculty and Natural Heat, as that thereby the food is better maticated and prepar'd; and the other concoctions and functions more perfectly perform'd, whence comes health and long life. So alo the Habit of the body is not imply a ign, but likewie an effect of health and caue of long life; namely when the ame is moderate, that is, neither fat nor lean; which two, though compriable within the latitude of health, which admits a a great latitude, are yet o much les perfect as they decline from that laudable dipoition which is the rule and quare of all others. Now to make a jut comparion, we mut conider the Fat and the Lean in the ame degree of exces or defect from this Mediocrity, and compare Philetas the Poet (who was o dry and lean that he was fain to faten leaden oles to his hoos for fear the wind hould carry him away) with Dionyius of Heraclea who was choakt with fat, unles his body were continually beet with Leeches. Or ele we mut oberve in both an equality of Vigour in the Principles of Life, to wit, the Radical Heat and Moiture in the ame proportion, the ame age, under the ame climate, regiment, and exercies; otherwie the comparion will be unequal: and latly, we mut ditinguih the flehy, great-limb'd, and muculous from the fat. This premis'd, I am of Hippocrates's Opinion, Aph. 44. Sect. 2. that uch as are gros and fat naturally, die ooner then the lean and lender; becaue the Veels of the latter, epecially the Veins, are larger, and conequently fuller of Blood and Spirits, which are the Architects and principal Organs of Life: on the contrary, the Fat have maller Veels by reaon of their coldnes which contringes
them; as is een in Women, Eunuchs, and Children, whoe voices are therefore more hrill, and who have alo les health and life.

The Second aid, Nature hath furniht Animals with Fat, to the end to preerve them from external injuries, and therefore the Lean, who are unprovided thereof, mut be of horter life: for not many, beides decrepit old people, die of a natural death; that is, proceeding from caues within, whereas mot dieaes arie from external caues, wherewith the Fat are les incommoded, epecially with cold, the worn enemy of life; the mallnes of their pores, and the fat which environs them, excluding all qualities contrary to life, and withall hindring the diipation of the Natural Heat, which becomes more vigorous by the confinement; jut as the Bowels are hotter in Winter, becaue the cold air hinders the efflux of the heat and pirits, caus'd in Summer, and in lean bodies, whoe pores being more open, cannot retain thoe volatile ubtances. So that, had the Fat les heat, as they have not (for plenty of fat argues plenty of blood, the purer and more aiery part whereof ditilling like dew through the coats of the Veels, and paing through the Mucles, when it comes to the Membranes, is by them condens'd into that whitih ubtance rather by their denity and natural property then by their coldnes) yet this Heat being better dipens'd, and les alter'd in the Fat then in the Lean, mut conequently caue fewer dieaes, and lat longer.

The Third aid, Life is the continuance of Heat in Humidity, not aqueous and excrementitious as that of fat people is, but oleaginous and aerial; and the longer this Heat ubits therein, the longer doth life lat. Now it continues longer in the Fat, whoe more open pores let out the fuliginous excrements rais'd by Heat; which in fat bodies, whoe paages are topt by the coldnes or clammines of pituitous humors, tagnate and choke the heat, like fire that wants free tranpiration, o neceary to life that it cannot ubit a moment without this action, whereby the oul attracts air in at all parts of the body, epecially the mouth, for refrehing and ventilating the heat, and recruiting the pirits, and by the ame paages emits the fuliginoities necearily following all conumption of humidity by Heat. Which caues of Death being internal and conequently neceary and inevitable; are much more coniderable then the external, whereto lean people are ubject, and which may be more eaily avoided and remedied.

The fourth aid, That Fat perons have a more moderate and les conuming heat, its activity being allay'd by the humidity of their Contitution; and therefore 'tis more durable than that of lean people, whoe heat already violent of it elf is render'd more active by iccity, which is a pur to it. Hence they indure fating with more trouble than the Fat, whoe moit ubtance both moderates and feeds their heat, which appears to
the touch very gentle and temperate, as that of lean perons is harp and pungent. Moreover, Dieaes of Inanition, to which the lean are ubject, are more difficult to cure, than thoe of Repletion incident to the Fat. And old age which continually dries us up, is the tendency to Death, which is iccity it elf.

The Fifth aid, Health being a Dipoition according to Nature, which renders a man capable of performing the offices of life aright, and this dipoition coniting in a due proportion of the firt qualities, which makes a harmony and laudable temper of the four humors; the principal evidence thereof is a good tate and habit of the body call'd by the Phyicians Euexia; and that Extreme which comes nearet this, is the mot healthy and fittet for long life. The functions of life are Natural, Vital, and Animal; all which are better perform'd by the lean than the fat. Firt, the Natural, which are Nutrition, Growth, and Generation; becaue the hotter fleh of the lean attracts more than that of the fat, which may indeed imbibe the nutritive juices, but cannot perfectly concoct and aimilate the ame for want of ufficient heat; whence they produce abundance of crude flegmatick excrements, which render them pale and bloated. For their more fatnes proceeds from want of heat to conume uperfluities. Secondly, growth being an effect of heat, the Fat grow les, becaue they are les hot than the Lean. For heat rarefies, ubtilies, dilates, and make the parts mount upwards, as its defect makes the humors ettle downwards; hence women are never o tall as men, and their lower parts are groer; whereas the upper parts of men, as the head and breat, are more large. Thirdly, the lean are more apt for generation, becaue their pirits are more refin'd, and their eed more concoct and plentiful than that of the fat; the puret portion of whoe blood is turn'd into fat intead of eed; whence all guelded Animals become fat; and, according to Aritotle, fat women are for the mot part barren, bear eldom; who alo, as well as men of the ame habit, are more inclin'd to love; but we are commonly mot led to that which we perform bet. Then the Vital Functions too, are more perfectly perform'd in the lean; as appears by their large repiration, their trong and great pule, the nimblenes in their motions and paions. Latly, o alo are the Animal, to wit, outward and inward enation, by reaon of the purenes and ubtlety of their pirits, (which likewie caues goodnes of wit) and of the dipoition of their Organs, more purifi'd, and les burden'd with clouds and excrementitious humidities, which render the fat more heavy both of mind and body.

div.head: CONFEERNCE CXXIV. Whether we may better trut one whom we have oblig'd, or one that hath oblig'd us.
div.p: COnfidence being the fruit of Friendhip, yea, the weet bond wherewith this Virtue unites Hearts; it may eem we ought to have mot in him that loves mot perfectly, namely, he that hath oblig'd us. For as 'tis harder to give then to receive, becaue we cannot give without depriving our elves of what we enjoy, (which is contrary to our natural inclination) o it is a more virtuous action, and argues a greater kindnes: the receiver of a benefit finding no difficulty in this action of receiving it. Moreover, we cannot doubt of his good will, who obliges us by his benefits; but we may of his, that receives. For it frequently happens to thoe that do good, as it did to the Sower in the Gopel, part of whoe eed fell in tony places, part amongt thorns, part in the high-way, and was devoured by birds; and the leat part upon good ground, and brings not forth fruit but in its own time. Yea, there are many that hate nothing o much as the remembrance of thoe that have done them good, as if their preence were an Univeral Reproach, notwithtanding that a econd benefit revives the firt, and a third or fourth cannot but mind them of the preceeding. But when you have obtain'd of them to remember it, yet many regret nothing more then to pay a debt, becaue contrain'd thereto, either by Law or Duty; and Man being of his own Nature free, hates nothing o much as to do any thing by contraint.
