Hence, if he requites an Obligation, 'tis not with that freenes and cheerfulnes which is requiite to good Offices, and becomes a Benefactor; in whom therefore we have more reaon to confide then in another.

The Second aid, The little fidelity now in the world, even amongt nearet Relatives, makes it reaonable to enquire, Who may be truted. And if the fear of Ingratitude, (the mot vulgar crime, though in hew much deteted by all the world) is the caue why he who hath done good to another, yet dares not trut him; the receiver thereof hath oftentimes no les doubt of his Benefactor's intention. For though he hath receiv'd a eeming tetimony of his kindnes, yet the motives of benefits proceeding ometimes from an other caue beides true Friendhip, upicion may as well arie in the Receivers, as in the givers Mind. Many give onely that they may receive with Uury; others, out of vanity, and to make Creatures and Clients: which they regarding no longer but as their inferiors and dependents, 'tis as dangerous for thee to confide in their Benefactors, as for a lave to ue confidence towards his Mater, or a Vaal towards his Lord; not often allow'd by the repect
and timerounes of the les towards the great, as commonly thoe are that give: Whereas we ordinarily find in him whom we have oblig'd nothing but Subjection and Humility, Virtues much dipoing the mind to Gratitude, which cannot but aure their Benefactors of their fidelity. Nor can they eaily be ungrateful if they would, your confidence in them obliging them continually to fidelity, and, withall, giving them occaion to requite your kindnees by their aiduity and ervices. Which was the recompence wherewith the poor amongt the Jews pay'd their Creditors, by erving them for ome years. So that he is carce les blameable who ditruts him whom he hath oblig'd, and by this diffidence deprives him of the means of requital, then he who having receiv'd a benefit betrayes his Benefactor; the Injutice being almot alike in both. If the firt complains of having been deceiv'd by him whom he finds ungrateful; the econd, in whom his Benefactor puts not the confidence which he ought, will have no les caue of complaint that on the contrary he hath ditruted him, and oil'd the lutre of the firt Obligation by his diffidence and bad opinion of him; which is to tax himelf of impudence for having done good to one unworthy of it.

The Third aid, That if Men were perfect, Communicative Jutice would require of them that the receiver of a benefit hould repay the like, or at leat ome acknowledgment by his endeavours: Which the Poets intimated by the Graces, holding Hand in Hand. But the perverity of Man is uch, that the more he is oblig'd to this Duty, the wore he acquits himelf thereof, not doing any thing handomely but what he does freely; and becaue being a vain-glorious Creature, he hates nothing o much as to be ubject, and to pay homage to him that hath done him good; whoe preence eems to upbraid him with his own meanes. If he loves his Benefactor, 'tis with an interes'd and mercenary affection; whereas that of the former is free from all elf-repect, and proceeds meerly from a principle of Virtue, and conequently, is with more reaon to be rely'd upon. Moreover, a Work-man loves his Production more then he is lov'd by it: as alo God doth his Creatures; and Fathers, their Children. Now a Benefactor, who is a kind of Work-man and Artificer of our good Fortune, cherihes and loves us as his work and creatures, becaue he eems concern'd for our preervation; jut as Caues are for that of their Effects, in which themelves revive, and eem to be reproduc'd.

The Fourth aid, That our Natural Sentiments incline us more to rely upon thoe whom we have oblig'd, then upon thoe who have oblig'd us; not o much by way of challenging a requital, (for Obligations are not to be done in hope of recompence; which would be exchange rather than kindnes) as becaue we are apt to trut thoe mot, whom we love mot. But we love thoe mot, to whom we
have given greatet Tetimony of our Affections. A Man may be deceiv'd in reckoning his benefits as caues of Amity in the receiver; but, they are certain Effects and Signs of Affection in the betower: So that in repect of us, 'tis manifetly better to trut him whom we have oblig'd, than him who hath oblig'd us. The ame is prov'd alo in repect of him that is oblig'd; even the wild beats are tam'd, and, intead of hurting, obey thoe that feed them; and therefore 'twere injurious to humanity, not to judge It capable of acknowledging a benefit which it knows how to conferr without provocation. For upon examination, the Caues of Ingratitude will be found to arie from thoe who boat of the title of Benefactors; the imprudence whereof is o great in ome, that they dipleae more than oblige, by Preents uneaonably given, of no value, and (contrary to Seneca's advice) of little duration, intermixt with ill Offices, intead of being fenc'd with new to keep out the rain of the diguts and coldnees which detroy Friendhip; with regret, and not with a chearful Countenance; after denials and delayes, o that the thing eemes rather natch'd then receiv'd; diminih'd by burthenome conditions; and latly, nullifi'd by reproaches, if not requited as oon as was expected. Whence uch pretended benefits deerve rather the name of Out-rages: And nevertheles, being there are many that are grateful, even for uch benefits, we may jutly conclude that Courteies done with their due circumtances, are far more capable to oblige the receivers to Gratitude, which cannot conit with Unfaithfulnes.

The Fifth aid, That the Deciion of this, as of all other Moral Quetions, depends upon perons, times, places, and other circumtances whereupon Prudence is founded, which teaches when, how, and whom we are to trut. Yet, uppoing circumtances alike, and two perons equally virtuous, one of which hath done me good, and the other receiv'd good from me; the contrary Reaon of the Law, which preumes him alwayes bad who hath been once bad, makes me judge, That he who hath once done me good, will ooner do me good again then another; and therefore that I ought rather to trut him.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXV. Of the Caues of Freezing and Thawing.
div.p:
AS Heat and Cold are the Efficient Caues of all Meteors, o Drines and Moiture upply Matter for them, ublim'd and made volatil by extraneous Heat. Vapours which make Aqueous Meteors, are of two orts; ome acend to the Middle Region of the Air, whoe coldnes condenes them into a Cloud,
which afterwards turnes into Rain, Snow, or Hail: Others, through the weaknes of Heat, or tenuity of their Matter unable to acend, turn into Mits and Dew, and the Serene which preceedes it, and Frot. For the Matter both of Frot and Dew, is a ubtil thin Vapour, which when pread equally and uniformly about the Earth, hinders not the Air's tranparency, which therefore in time of Frot is alwayes clear and erene. But their Efficient is ditinct; that of Dew is the moderate Coldnes of the Night, whence 'tis mot frequent in temperate Seaons; that of a Frot is Vehement Cold, whereby being firt condens'd, it falls down in form of Crytal: Yet Cold alone uffices not to produce Frot; for then Water, which is cold in an eminent degree, hould be alwayes frozen. But ome terrene and gros parts mut erve for an uniting medium to compact the moit parts of the Water or Vapour, which being naturally fluid, cannot be link'd together but by means of ome dry parts fixing and retraining their fluidity. Hence the impuret and mot compounded Liquors are oonet frozen; ditill'd Waters, difficultly, by reaon of their implicity; Vinegar (though cold) never, by reaon of the tenuity of its parts. But the urface of waters being full of earthy and gros parts, which could not accompany the Vapours or Exhalations, drawn up by the Sun's heat, is therefore firt frozen; even that of running waters, though not o eaily, by reaon of their motion makes a divulion of their parts; as neither Oyle very eaily, (by reaon of its aërious and unctuous humidity) the Sea, and Hot Spirits; which yet Experience hews are ometimes frozen by Vehement Cold; the Poet in his decription of the harpnes of Winter, in his Georgicks, aying, that they cleav'd Wine with hatchets; and the Northern Navigations of the Hollanders, relating that they were detain'd three moneths under the eventy fourth Degree, where their Ships were frozen in the main ea.

The Second aid, That Heat and Cold are the immediate Caues of Freezing and Thawing, but 'tis hard to know, Whence that Heat and Cold comes? Now becaue Cold is onely the Privation of Heat, as Darknes is of Light; we hall ufficiently undertand the Caues of Cold and of Freezing, if we know thoe of Heat which caues Thawing. The truth is, the Sun, whoe approach and remotenes makes the diverities of Seaons according to the different mutations which he caues in the qualities of the Air, contribute thereunto, but the Earth helps too; he cannot do it alone; for we ee that the Snow on the Mountains which approach nearet Heaven, is lat melted. But the Sun's Rays piercing into the boome of the Earth, draw out that Fire which is inclos'd in its entralls; and becaue the Sun removes but a very little from the Aequinoctial Line, therefore that part of the Earth which anwers to that of Heaven where the Sun continually reides, is alwayes Hot; and by a contrary Reaon, that under the Poles is alwayes extreamly cold: And
even Country-people oberve winds to be the Caue of thee Effects; for thoe that blow from the North quarter, bring with them an extream cold Air, which is the caue of Freezing; and thoe from the South bring on us an Air extreamly heated by the continuall action of the Sun, and o are the caue of Thawing.

The Third aid, That Winds being continual, becaue their matter never fails, it happens that the tronget gets the better of the weaket, and they chae one another; whence Virgil calls them Wretlers. When the South Winds blow, (which are more frequent, and more gros then the Northern or Eatern, by reaon of the Sun's trength in the South, which opens the Pores of the Earth more:) the copious Exhalations which iue out of it, are hotter than thoe which come out of the Pores of the Northern Earth, which are cloed up by Cold, whence the Winds blowing from thence are colder and thinner; jut as our breath is cold when we contract our Mouthes, and hot when we dilate them. In like manner, the Exhalations iuing out of the Earth's Pores, are hotter or colder, according as the paages out of which they proceed are more or les dilated, and conequently, caue Freezing or Thawing.

The Fourth aid, That the Sun or other Stars are onely remote Caues of Freezing and Thawing; namely, by their Heat which erves to raie the Vapors, which are the next caues thereof, according as they partake more or les of that external Heat; or, (as the Chymits ay) as they are full either of certain nitrous and diolving Spirits which caue Thawing, or of coagulating ones which caue Freezing; uch as thoe are, harden Plants into Stones, which o preently congeal drops of water in Caves and Water-droppings, and form the Crytals of the Rock. Moreover, jut before it freezes, Sinks, and other tinking places mell more trong, by reaon that the Spirits and Vapors of the Earth are complicated with thoe tinks as they iue forth.

The Fifth aid, That the Caue of Thawing is to be attributed to the Heat of the Earth, which exhaling warm Vapors, fi • t heats the bottome of the Water, (for which reaon Fih retire thither) then they mollifie and moiten the urface of the Water, or the Earth hardned by Cold. Moreover, that Heat which is found in the deepet Mines where the Labourers work naked, and mot ordinarily in the Water without enduring any Cold; the veins of Sulphur, Bitumen, Vitriol, and Arenick, which are found in the entralls of the Earth; the Hot Springs, and the Volcanoes in its urface, ufficiently argue, That if there be not a Central Fire, (as the Pythagoreans held) yet there is a great Heat there, like that of Living Bodies, which concocts Metals, and makes Plants grow. Hence the changes of Air are firt dicover'd in Mines by the Vapors ariing from beneath, which hinder Repiration, and make the Lamps burn dim, or go quite out. Whereby 'tis evident that they are exhaled by the Heat
of the earth, and not attracted by that of the Sun and Stars, which penetrate but a very little way into the earth. Now as our bodies are inwardly hotter in Winter; o this heat of the earth being concentred in it elf, (as appears by Springs which moke in that eaon, and by the heat of ubterraneous places) raies greater plenty of warm Vapors, which in Winte render the Weather moit and rainy: but when rain or the coldnes of the air tops thoe pores, then thoe Exhalations being hut up, the Air remains cold, and it freezes; which frot is again diolv'd by their eruption. For the natural heat of the Earth, being contring'd and render'd tronger by the ambient Cold, drives out hotter and more copious exhalations, which conit either of the rain-water wherewith it is moitned, or of other humidities; and which arriving at the urface of the Earth which is frozen, often it and fill the air with clouds, which always accompany a Thaw, as Serenity do's a Frot.

The Sixth aid, That as Hail is nothing but Rain congeal'd, o Frot is nothing but Dew condens'd by the vehemence of Cold, and in the Water 'tis call'd Ice: which coldnes condening the Water, (which is a diaphanous body, and conequently hath an internal and radical light) is the caue of its whitenes, which is the beginning of light, as the Stars are the condens'd parts of their Orbs. Unles you had rather acribe that whitenes to the Air included in the Ice, which alo makes the ame wim upon the water. An Evidence that Cold alone is not the caue of Freezing; (for Cold alone render bodies more ponderous by condening their parts, whence Ice hould be heavier then Water) but there is requir'd, beides, ome hot and dry exhalation, which ininuating into the Water, gives it levity.

The Seventh aid, That uch bodies as are frozen, are o far from receiving augmentation of parts, that they loe the thinnet of their own; hence a bottle o cloe topped that the air cannot get in to upply the place of the thinner parts which tranpire and perih upon freezing, breaks in pieces for avoiding of vacuity. And Wine and Fruits loe their tat upon the los of their pirits, when they are frozen: which pirits not being able to tranpire in Cabbages and other Vicous Plants diget their crudities, and by that means render the ame Plants more tender.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXVI. Of the Caues of the Small Pox.
div.p: THe variety wherewith this Malady afflicts, or that which it caues in the body, hath given it the name of Variolae (Variolles or Vairolles) as its reemblance to the bliters, and to the manner wherewith the Venereous Dieae invades the Indians (to whom the ame is Epidemical, being caued by the corruption of the air) caues it to be called the Small Pox. Thee are efflorecences or putules appearing upon the body, epecially thoe of Children by reaon of the oftnes of their kin, with a Feaver, pain, cabbines, and purulent matter. This malady comprizes three orts of Dieaes; Namely, Intemperature, in its feaver and inflammation; Bad conformation, in the little Eminencies; and olution of continuity, in the Ulcers. Its precedent igns are commonly, hoarnes of the voice, pain of the head, inflammation of the whole face, yawnings, ditentions, trembling of the whole body, neezings, and titches. Its concomitant, eential, and pathognomonical igns are, Deliration, frightful Dreams, pains of the Breat and Throat, difficulty of Repiration, and a Continual Feaver, which is ometimes putrid, ometimes not. All which igns proceed from the violent ebulition and agitation of the humours, the conjunct caue of this Malady an effect of the natural heat; which being irritated by their Malignity, drives them outwards to the urface where they raie thoe little Tumours; which, if red and les high, make the Meazles; and when more eminent, the Small Pox: the Pimples whereof at firt appear very mall, afterwards in time wax red, and grow bigger from day to day till they become white; then they uppurate and dry, and latly, falling off commonly leave marks behind them, not to be got away, becaue they have conumed the kin which is never generated anew.

The econd aid, A common effect mut have a common caue. Now the Small Pox and Meazles (which differ only, in that the former is produc'd of thinner, and the latter of thicker blood) are dieaes not only common to many; but o few ecape them that a general rule here carce admits any exceptions. Two Caues there are, the Material, or the Efficient. The former is the impurity of the Mentrual blood which erves for nourihing the foetus in the womb; where at firt it attracts the puret and weetet blood, but when grown bigger the gros together with the thin. So that as Hores once in their lives cat the Strangles, o men mut alo once purge and void that mentrual impurity, which being equally dipers'd over all the body and in mall quantity, hinders not its functions. The efficient Caue, common likewie to all men, is the Natural Heat, which drives thee impurities outwards, and o they come to appear upon the
kin, (which is the Univeral Emunctory of the whole body) but epecially upon the face by reaon of its tendernes, and becaue being the place where all the Organs of Sene terminate, 'tis fuller of pirits then any other, and conequently there is a greater attraction thither of thoe malignant Vapors. Now that it eizes ome in their childhood, others in their youth, ome very few in old age, and all after a different manner; this depends upon our particular Contitutions, either natural or acquiititious by cutom, and a long ue of the things not natural. For, according as the humours reign in the body, they give occaion to the eruption of that Venemous quality which before lay hid; as Madnes and Leproie ometimes appear not till after divers years. Our diet alo contributes thereunto; for when it ymbolieth with that malignant humour, it encreaes the quantity thereof; as on the contrary, it corrects the ame, and retards its motion, if it be of a laudable temper, or exceed in contrary qualities.

The Third aid, What Original Sin is to the tate of the Soul, that the Small Pox eems to be to the tate of the Body; for this Dieae commonly invades children, who never committed any fault in their coure of living, and whoe nature hould be o much healthier by how much 'tis more vigorous and nearer the principles of their Nativity; wherefore it eems rather to proceed from the vitioity of the Parents. And as many hereditary dieaes come from the bad dipoition of the eed; o from the impurity of the blood (the material principle of our bodies) ome may alo arie; as Tettars, Kibes, Corns, and other deformities of the kin, which happen to children, very like this. Moreover, this dieae uually breaks forth in the eventh and ninth, which are the firt climacterical years; when Nature endeavours the perfection of her work by purging and cleaning it of all impurities. And as New Wine, when it comes to work, cats forth all the heterogeneous impurities in it's body; o doth the natural heat attempt the like by cauing an ebullition of the blood and pirits: whether this Fermentation happens by the univeral pirit of the world, as thoe in other natural bodies; or whether (as 'tis mot probable) it proceeds from the very trength of nature, whoe motions, although regular and certain, are yet unknown to any other beides it elf, which produces them according to the dipoitions of the Subject wherein it reides.

The Fourth aid, That being our bodies were always form'd of the maternal blood, and indu'd with one and the ame natural heat, (which two are held the material and efficient caues of the Small Pox) this Dieae hould have been in all times and places; and yet it was unknown before the Arabians, in whoe time it began to appear. For the little red round putules, and thoe other like flea-bitings, mention'd by Hippocrates, Aetius, and ome other Ancients, are nothing les then the Small Pox;
to which not only Women during their Suppreions, but even brute Beats, which have alo their purgations, (as among others, the Bitch, the Mare, and the Shee-As) ought to be ubject. On the contrary, uch as have burning Feavers hould be free from it; if it be true, that the eed and leven of this malady is diipated by the ebullition of the blood, which is vehement in a Feaver. But 'tis impoible to conceive, how a venemous and pernicious matter, (as that impure part of the blood is aid to be) can be preerv'd for many years in its Mas; for being the blood erves for continual aliment to all the parts, thee ought to reent omething of that malignity; yet thoe that are taken with this dieae are uually the mot healthy, and of a anguine contitution, which is the mot laudable. For this were to accue Nature either of Imprudence or Weaknes; but he is good, wie, powerful, and olicitous for nothing o much as to purifie the body, which he doth not only while the child is in the Womb, where he wraps it up in two membranes, which receive the Urine, Sweat, and other Excrements of anguification (as the Intetines do the groer excrements) but aoon as it is born, he expells its immundicities by bliters, curfs, cabs, tumors of the head and other purgations, which Hippocrates aith, preerve from dieaes, epecially from the falling icknes. Nor can the Malignity of the Air be the Caue, as Fernelius holds, alledging that the difficulty of repiration, heavines of the head, inflammation of the face, and uch other concomitant ymptoms, eem to be caus'd by the viciounes of the air, which infects the heart, and by that means hurts the other Functions. For then the Small Pox would be as Epidemical as the Petilence, or any other contagious maladies, and eize upon all men indifferently, not excepting uch as have once had them. Wherefore the matter of this dieae is a eroity accompanied with the humours, which make the Pox appear of everal colours, ometimes Red, Yellow, Black, or White, according as the Blood, Choler, Melancholy, or Flegm flow thither; Wind or Water only caue bladders or bliters. Nevertheles it mut be confeed that this eroity acquires ome particular malignity; as appears by the deformity caued by the putules, which not only pit the kin and fleh, but ometimes even corrode and rot the bones.

The Fifth aid, That the Small Pox is a new and hereditary dieae, and that as all other new maladies of thee lat ages, have always had their caues, but only wanted fitting dipoitions (without which nothing is produced) o the caues of the Small Pox have always been exitent, but the particular dipoitions of bodies not lighting upon the point requiite for its production, it hath not appeared till thee late times; whether through the influence of Heaven, or through the Malignity of the Air, or the intemperance of men (the mot apparent caue of mot dieaes formerly unknown) or ele through contagion
and contact, by which way the great Pox is communicated. For the Small is likewie contagious, and (which is remarkable) more amongt Kindred than Strangers; becaue they, being iued of the ame blood, have greater affinity of dipoitions than Strangers.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXVII. Whether we profit bet by Precepts or Examples.
div.p:
AS there is nothing o hard as to judg of the worth of things, o it is the highet point of prudence to undertand the goodnes of the means that may conduce to ome end. Precepts and Examples are the two Means to attain Vertue; 'tis demanded which is the bet and mot proper. At firt view, Example eems to have the ame advantage over Precept that the Whole hath over the Part; for a Good Example, beides being of its own nature a vertuous action holds the place of a Moral Rule; but a Precept is only a General Maxim, not necearily follow'd by a particular Action: whence it follows, that Precept regards only the Undertanding, whereto it affords ome light; but Example makes impreion upon both Faculties together, the Undertanding and the Will, by an order neceary in civil life, which is regulated by the example of others. Therefore Great Perons are oblig'd to good Example, which derives its dignity from that of the giver. Moreover, Moral Propoitions are o reaonable and conformable to the intinct we have of good, that all the World aents to them as conider'd in the General. There is no body but acknowledges, that, what belongs to each man ought to be render'd to him; that, we ought not to do that to another which we would not have done to our elves: yet in the circumtances and particular caes we do not always apply thoe precepts, becaue then they appear clog'd with difficulties, to which our paion or interet give birth. Wherefore Example, beng Particular, is more coniderable in Morality, wherein people are govern'd more by opinion then reaon; but Precept is Univeral, and affects the mind only at a ditance, our actions being oftentimes contrary to the ecret dictates of the Undertanding. In Example we feel the force and application of a precept in a particular ubject, and know not only that which ought to be done but how it ought to be done by eeing it practis'd. Experience it elf hew us, that Doctrine alone is weak and little perwaive, unles it be animated by the examples of a good life, whoe ilence is more eloquent than all precepts. Moreover, we are like thoe with whom we live, and the maladies of the body are not o contagious as thoe of the mind: which notwithtanding may as well profit by bad examples; as good, the
Undertanding being able to turn bad food into good nourihment: And as a brave Action excites good Motions in us by its beauty, reulting from its conformity to Reaon; o a bad Action, by its deformity and contrariety to Reaon, gives us averion againt it, and an inclination to its oppoite. Socrates judg'd no Leon o fit to moderate Anger, as for a Man to behold himelf in a glas when he is agitated with that Paion. Which cannot be aid of a bad Precept; for this being a bad eed, can never produce any fruit but of the ame Nature. On the other ide, Men are uch Lovers of Pleaures, that Virtue eparated from Delight, tumbles them, and eemes too evere: But Precept is a pure Rule of Duty, without any attractive; whereas Example, which appears to our Eyes, and is an Action cloth'd with circumtances, perwades us more weetly, becaue we are naturally prone to Imitation; whence it comes to pas that Comedies are o charming: And Example is the ubject: of Imitation, but Precept cannot be o; for it is general of it elf, and all Moral Actions are ingular.

The Second aid. That if it be true, as the Stoicks ay, that Virtue is nothing ele but a Science, then Precepts mut be the foundations, as of Science, o alo of Virtute; which indeed being a habit of a reaonable Faculty, mut be more promoted by Precepts, (which are infallible verities, and upply light to that Power) than Examples which have no force to convince a trong Mind. They who follow Virtue by Example, and not by Reaon, have more of the Ape than of the Man; and all the power Example hath, is onely to move the Will to admire and deire Virtue, but not to teach the way of attaining it, as Precept doth; which, beides being invariable, and always alike to its elf, is more eaie to be applyed than Example, which puts on a new face, according to the circumtances of times, places, and perons; there being no Actions, how, contrary oever, but have Examples to countenance their goodnes. Moreover, they are either of the time pat, and o move us not much; or of the preent, in which there are few of Virtue; beides that, they are of les duration than Precepts, which are eternal. If vicious Examples attract more powerfully to Vice than vicious Precepts, the ame cannot be aid of the practice of Virtues; ince thee have not all the External Sene of their party, as Vices have.

The Third aid, That enible and palpable things, as examples are, have more power upon us than bare words, which cannot o well perwade a Truth, but that they alwayes leave ome doubting in us; whereas Examples being enible, give us a more entire and perfect Knowledge: yea, they have influence even upon brute beats, who learn not by Precepts but by Examples, which is an evidence of their certainty; for a thing is the more certain, the more common it is to us with more. Hence Plato affirmes, That Examples are neceary to perwade high and lofty matters. Precepts, indeed, dipoe, but Examples
animate the Soul to Virtue; thoe admonih, thee timulate and guide, as in the reolution of doing well: Intructions hew the way, but Examples drive us with the point of Honour, and the force of Emulation. Nor do Precepts include Examples, but the contrary; and every Example comprehends a Document. When we ee a Good Man quare his Life out to his Duty, we find I know not what atisfaction and contentment in the admimiration of his Virtue, and this pleaure makes us conceive, yea, trongly perwades us, that all Virtues are amiable. Even Vicious Examples ometimes make Vice appear to us o deform'd, that we detet intead of puruing it. Hence the Lacedemonians etting aide the Precepts of Temperature, were wont to make their Slaves drunk, that the ill-favour'd pectacle might make their Children abhor that Vice. Latly, Our Saviour, whoe Life was a continued Example of Virtue, did more Works to teach us, then he gave Words and Precepts, mot of which are comprehended under Examples and Parables: Yea, the Devil, well knowing that Adam's mind was too trong to be prevail'd upon by Reaons, firt gain'd that of his Wife, which was more weak, that he might allure him to in by her Example.

The Fourth aid, The end is not onely more noble, but alo more effectual than the means; for 'tis to that alone that they aim and terminate. Now the end of all Examples, is to deduce Precepts from them; which Precepts, are general Notions grounded upon many Experiences or Examples, either of others, or our own; but thee being wholly particular, can have no power upon the Undertanding, which frames its concluions onely upon things univerally true, as Maximes and Precepts are, and that more than Examples; for thee are never perfect, but full of a thouand defects, thoe ure and infallible. Moreover, Precepts move the Undertanding, which is the noblet of all the Faculties; whereas Examples make impreion onely upon the outward enes and dull wits.

The Fifth aid, That as the Sight and the Hearing know how to put a difference between Colours and Sounds, without Learning; and all the Faculties can naturally dicern their own Objects: So the Undertanding knows naturally the firt Principles, and clearly beholds thoe firt Verities: The Will hath alo in it elf the Principles and Seeds of Virtues, (as the Syntereis, and remore of Concience in the mot wicked, ufficiently prove) and is of it elf carryed to Virtuous Actions, without needing either Preecepts or Examples, equally unprofitable to the bad, who amend not thereby; and to the good, who want them not.

The Sixth aid, That the Quetion is to be decided by ditinguihing of the Minds of Men. Thoe that excel in Judgement attribute more to Reaon than to Examples, which being more enible, affect the Imagination of duller heads, who are not capable
of Reaons. So that though Precepts and Arguments be without comparion more perfect than Examples; yet becaue very few are capable of them, (becaue the generality of the World is tupid and dull) therefore they are not generally o proper to teach as Examples; which nevertheles being of no power, but erving onely to clear an obcure Truth, ought not to have any acendant over a Mind that is reaonable and furnih'd with Knowledge.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXVIII. Of Incubi and Succubae; and whether Devils can generate.
div.p:
TWo orts of people err in this matter; the upertitious, and ignorant vulgar, who attribute every thing to Miracles, and account the ame done either by Saints or Devils; and the Atheits and Libertines, who believe neither the one nor the other. Phyitians take the middle way, ditinguihing what is fit to be attributed to Nature, and her ordinary motions, from what is upernatural; to which lat Head, 'tis not reaonable to referr dieaes and indipoitions, as the Incubus is, call'd by the Greeks, Ephialtes, and by the vulgar, the Night-mare. 'Tis defin'd, An impediment of Repiration, Speech, and Motion, with oppreion of the Body, whereby we feel in our leep as 'twere ome weight upon the Stomack. The Caue of it is a gros Vapor, obtructing principally the hinder part of the Brain, and hindring the egres of the Animal Spirits detinated to the motion of the parts; which Vapor is more eaily diipable than the humor which caueth the Lethargy, Apoplexy, and other Symptoms, which are therefore of longer duration than this, which ceaes as oon as the aid Vapor is diipated. Now whereas the Paions of the Mind and Body commonly upply the matter of Dreams; (as thoe that are hungry or amorous, will think they eat or ee what, they love; thoe that have pain in ome part, dream that ome body hurts the ame) hence when Repiration, (the mot neceary of all the animal functions) is impeded, we preently imagine we have a load lying on our Breats, and hindring the dilatation of the ame. And becaue the Brain is employ'd in the Incubus therefore all the animal functions are hurt; the Imagination deprav'd, the Senation obtunded, Motion impeded. Hence thoe whom this evil eizes, endeavor to awake, but can neither move nor peak, till after a good while. And though the Caue of this diorder be within our elves, nevertheles the ditemper'd peron believes that ome body is going about to trangle him by outward violence, which the depraved Imagination rather thinks upon than Internal Caues;
that being more enible and common. This has given occaion to the error of the Vulgar, who charge thee Effects upon Evil Spirits, intead of imputing them to the Malignity of a Vapor, or ome phlegmatick and gros humor oppreing the Stomack; the coldnes and weaknes whereof, ariing from want of Spirits and Heat, which keeps all the parts in due order, are the mot manifet Caues. Much unlikely it is to be caued by Generation, which being an Effect of the Natural Faculty, as this of the Vegetative Soul, cannot belong to the Devil, who is a pure Spirit.

The Second aid, As 'tis too gros to recurr to upernatural Caues, when Natural are evident; o 'tis too enual to eek the Reaon of every thing in Nature, and to acribe to meer Phlegm and the ditempered Phant'ie, the Coitions of Daemons with Men; which we cannot deny without giving the lye to infinite of perons of all Ages, Sexes, and Conditions, to whom the ame have happened; nor without accuing the Sentences of Judicial Courts which have condemned them. For to omit the Births of Hercules, Aemas, Alexander, Servius Tullus, and many other Heroes begotten by the fale gods of Antiquity, who were no other than Devils, as were alo the Fauni, Satyrs, and the chief of them Pan, the prime of the Incubi, called by the Hebrews Haza, as the chief of the Succubae was termed Libith: And to ay nothing of the Giants mentioned in Geneis, who according to ome Fathers were begotten by Angels; England hath had its Merlin a great Magician begotten by an Incubus; Poitou, Counts begotten of a Succuba, half Woman and half Serpent, called Melluine; Poland, Princes of the Race of the Jagelloes, iued from another in form of a Bear; Hungary, intire Nations called Huns, born of the Arlunes, Gothick Witches, and Fauni. Even at this day, in the Iland Hipaniola, by the Relation of Chieza, in his Hitory of Peru, a Daemon, call'd by the Inhabitants Corocota, hath to do with the Women, and the Children proceeding from uch Conjunction have horns; as alo among the Turks, thoe people whom they call Nepheolians, are believed to be generated by the operation of Daemons; whether they borrow ome humane eed which they tranport almot in an intant, and o preerve its Spirits from evaporation; or whether it be by their proper Virtue; ince whatever is naturally producible, as eed is, may be produced by Devils. For in the order of things natural, the uperior and more noble contain eminently, and in a more perfect, degree, the powers of the inferior and les perfect. Yea, though they were not able to make true eed, it follows not that they cannot produce a perfect Creature; for Nature, of which the Devils have compleat Knowledge, may have divers wayes to compas the ame end. But as the Devil performs the natural actions of Animals by means upernatural; as he ees without Eyes, moves Bodies without Contact, tranports himelf from one place to another, without commenuration of the
intermediate pace, becaue he hath no quantity; o he may make a perfect Animal without oberving the conditions of ordinary Agents. Moreover, Nature her elf hews us trange transformations, as of a Womans hair buried in a dung-hill into Serpents; and of leavs falling into the water, into Ducks; wherefore there is no doubt, but he who hath perfect Knowledge of all thee ecrets, can by Application of Agents to Patients produce perfect Animals.

The Third aid, That the Devil being a Spirit of uncleannes delights not only to combat the Purity of Mankind by his illuions, but will have a hand in the in too. When he hath to do with a Woman, he is called Incubus; when with a Man, Succuba. As for this latter, 'tis certain it cannot generate in its elf, for want of place fit to receive the Seed and to reduce it from power into act, as alo of Blood wherewith to nourih the Foetus during nine moneths. 'Tis harder to reolve, whether an Incubus can generate in another. All agree that the Devil by Gods permiion (without which he can do nothing) hath power to move all Bodies from one place to another; and can by that means form a Body of Air, or ome other gros matter; or for want thereof, take a Body lately dead, animate it with an adventitious heat, and give uch motions as he pleaes to all its parts. But becaue Generation requires three things; Ditinction of Sex, Copulation of Male and Female, and emiion of ome prolifick matter containing in its elf a vertue to form all the parts from whence it iued; the Devil may indeed make the two firt conditions meet, but never the latter, namely a fit and convenient eed, indued with pirits and vital heat, without which it is unfruitful and barren. For he hath no uch eed of his own, becaue it is the reult of the lat concoction, which cannot be made but in a body actually alive, as that which he hath is uppoed not to be; nor can he borrow uch eed elewhere, becaue it becomes unfruitful when once hed out of the Veels of Nature by reaon of the evaporation of its pirits.

The Fourth aid, There is nothing upernatural in the Incubus; for 'tis only a ymptom of the Animal Faculty accompanied with three circumtances, namely, Repiration hindred, Motion hurt, and a fanie depraved. The firt proceeds from a phlegmatick, raw, and cold matter, which coming to lye heavy in the bottom of the Stomack, pulls down the Diaphragm (whereto the Ventricle is annex'd by its upper part) which being loaden and wanting its free Motion; Repiration, whereof it is the principal Organ, is conequently hindred. As alo it is by gros fumes elevated from the Hypochondres and Mearaical Veins; (which being the firt ways of Food, abound with impurities and gros vapours) which coming to the hinder part of the Brain, obtruct the commerce of the Spirits, dedicated to the motion of all the parts; but particularly that of the Diaphragm, by obtructing the two couple of Nerves which iue
out of the fourth and fifth Vertebrae, and communicate motion to it; jut as, in leep, Senation is top'd by more tenuious vapours poeing the forepart of the Brain, which is more oft. Hence uch as leep upon the back part of head are more ubject to this Dieae then thoe that leep on one ide. Latly, the voluptuous phanie, which accompanies this accident, though very rarely, proceeds either from the abundance, or quality of the Seed; which ending its Species into the phanie, this Faculty frames to its elf a delightful object and tirs up the Motive Power, as this doth the Expulive Faculty of the Spermatick Veels, which dicharge that excrementitious matter, whilt the lacivious Imagination fancies to it elf the conjunction of unclean Spirits.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXIX. Which Animal is happiet, according to Nature.
div.p: WHereas a man cannot o well peak of others as of himelf, it were to be wihed that every thing, which is naturally capable of felicity, came hither to give its uffrage. I believe the Birds would not be the lat to tetifie to us by their inging and agreeable warbling, the mot certain indication of joy and contentment; as cries are of the contrary, grief and adnes. Indeed, if there be any pleaure in the World, I think Birds have it; for they go not only to eek their food in the bottom of the water, as Water-fowl do (to whom that Element is common with Fihes); they have not only the ame hare in the benefits of the land with four-footed Animals, and both together with amphibious creatures; but moreover they fly in the Air, approaching Heaven nearer then we can, and cleaving that Element with an innocent pleaure not to be undertood but by the action it elf; whence Angels are painted with wings. And as of all Animals the mot imperfect and leat capable of felicity are the Reptile, uch as Earth-worms, little differing from this very Element; o thoe are the happiet which remove themelves furthet from it, as Birds do. Amongt which I hall leave it to the Voluptuous to ay, whether it be the Cock, the Sparrow, or the amorous Dove; thoe that love Muick, to determine whether 'tis the Nightingal, and to thoe that eteem the ight the mot ravihing of all the Senes, whether it be the Eagle, whoe eye dicovers the remotet objects and turns not aide even from the beams of the Sun.

The Second aid, That ince nothing is intirely happy in the World, the Quetion hould rather be put, Which is the leat unhappy of all Animals. Man, the only competent judge, acknowledges 'tis not himelf, for he eems to be the Butt of all
the mieries in the World; of which alo he is o much more enible then Beats by how much he hath a mind more qualified to apprehend and reent them. For whereas they ay, he alone is capable of felicity; 'tis true indeed in reference to the future not the preent life, no age whereof is capable of relihing an intire contentment: and if one drop of Gall mingled with a good quantity of Milk denominates the ame bitter, certainly we cannot term mans life pleaant whilt it hath abundantly more pain then delight. He comes into the World weeping, and naked without any Arms or defence; wherein he is more unhappy then Beats whom nature hath guarded with covertures againt the injuries of the air. His firt Child-hood is not yet capable of any ort of pleaure. Adolecence would tate thereof indeed, but is denied liberty by its Pedagogues. Youth precipitates it elf into more kind of evils then it tates of good: beides that, it ees mot pleaures forbidden by Divines, Phyicians, and Civilians, who eem to have endeavoured to take from us all contentment in this World; which if old age makes us the les loth to part with, yet there is no o great reignation of pirit but is thwarted by temptations of the fleh, nor ecurity o carnal but is tartled with the records of concience. Moreover, the true mark of felicity being the atisfaction and contentment of him that poees it, no peron can be happy in this world ince none is contented. For man being deign'd to a more perfect life then this, naturally deires the Supream Good, and all that is below it dipleaes him, as uncapable to atisfie him; and becaue he cannot find it here, therefore neither can he find contentment, which conits in atisfying the Appetite. Beats, on the contrary, having no other knowledg but that of Senual and Delectable Good, deire no other, but are fully atisfi'd and contented therewith, and conequently more happy in this World then men.

The Third aid, If Felicity conit in action, that Animal mut be mot happy which acts mot perfectly. So doth man, whether you conider him as to the Body or the Soul. For to ay nothing of the divine functions of his Undertanding and Will; the ole tructure of his Body, which was made erect that he might behold Heaven (whereof he is capable) and which alone is indu'd with beauty, one of the effects of Health, ufficiently proves it: For though ome Animals poibly urpas him in ome one ene, yet he alone excells equally in all, and knows the differences of colours, ounds, odours, apours, and tactile qualities, in the participation of which he finds pleaure whereof beats are incapable.

The Fourth aid, That to believe Man can be happy here, is to contradict the opinion of all the Sages of Antiquity, who have acknowledg'd Man the weaket and pitifullet of all Creatures; and the Scripture it elf, which terms his life full of orrows, and this World his banihment. And indeed if we place
Felicity in the knowledg of poeing it, Miery mut alo conit in the knowledg or opinion we have of being mierable; of which reflection Man alone being capable, he mut be alo more too of unhappines then felicity; and the more, inamuch as there are more things that can afflict then content him; ome always bringing preent inconvenience with them, others leaving omewhat to be deir'd after them, and never atiating our Appetite. For the Reaonable Soul, which is held the ubject of Mans happines, is the principal obtacle to attaining it: ince having for its object a more perfect and abolute Good then it can poes in this life, it cannot etablih a true Felicity (which of its own nature mut be as lating as the Exitence of him who enjoys it) upon things acknowledg'd frail and perihing, as Natural and Senible goods are; which being utable to the duration and appetite of other Animals, their enjoyment thereof fills them with perfect happines. But amongt thee, Fihes eem to me mot happy; whether you meaure their happines by the largenes of their habitation which is the vat Ocean, of far greater extent then the Earth, from which being more evered then Birds, who are forced to decend thither for their food and ret, they are alo les ubject to the ambuhes of men, and in this regard more happy; or whether you conider corporal health (the foundation of all felicity) of which Fihes are o well provided that it hath occaion'd the Proverb, As ound as a Fih; or latly, whether you place felicity in the privation of pain, which reides chiefly in the ene of Touching; which being more dull in them then in other Animals, they are alo les enible of inconveniences; and for this reaon were made mute by nature which hath given a voice to Animals chiefly to tetifie thereby the grief which they reent.

The Fifth aid, If there be o great a number of opinions wherein the felicity of one ingle Animal, Man, conits; there may jutly be great variety of judgments, concerning which is the happiet of all Animals. To determine which, we mut imitate Painters, who before they couch their Colours propoe a perfect Idea of their work; which the nearer it approaches, the more excellent it is reputed. In like manner, we mut firt form an Idea of this felicity, and then ee which Animal comes nearet it; whether the Servant or the Mater, the brute Beat or Man; whoe mind, whereby he infinitely urpaes all the ret of the Creatures, eems to be ingenious to its own los; not imploying it elf, but to find out reaons to prove him unhappy: ince in favour of other Animals we lay aide that ambition which is o natural to us, and are willing to yield to the vilet of them, what we would dipute with the mot perfect of men. Now that which makes mot people mitaken in their judgment, is, that being no peron injoys an intire felicity, they imagine that all happines lyes in that thing which is wanting, and o eteem him alone happy that poees it. Thus a poor pirit
perwaded that all happines conits in trength and courage, will ay that the Lyon is the happiet of all Animals, ince his courage gives him empire over all thoe of his condition. The ick peron accounting health (the mot deirable of all goods, prefers Beats before Man, whom his exact tempers renders more obnoxious to external caues which produce dieaes. On the other ide, if Animals are happy, 'tis as Fools are, whoe minds are quiet, by reaon of their ignorance and inenibility. But as it is better to be enible then inenible even upon the condition of enduring pain ometimes; o it is more happy to have a rational mind, though it caues troubles to us ometimes, then to have none. Moreover we cannot avoid the troaks of fortune, otherwie then thoe of Thunder, namely by being very high or very low; but 'tis better to be above tempets then below them, and to be incapable of them by reaon as a wie man, then by tupidity as a beat.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXX. Whether is better, that Men have many Wives, or Women many Husbands.
div.p:
THough plurality of Wives or Husbands be diallowed by the Chritian Law, yet not being contrary to the Law of Nations (for many admit it), nor of nature (during which it was in ue); we may be permitted to doubt whether, uppoing Polygamy, it were better one Husband hould have many Wives, or one Wife many Husbands. There are examples of both. Plurality of Wives was practied by Lamech, who firt had two; by Abraham, Jacob, and the Patriarchs, for multiplying of their Lineage; afterwards by David and Solomon who had 700 Wives and 300 Concubins; and at preent 'tis in ue among the Turks who are permitted to have as many Wives as they can keep. As for plurality of Husbands, though it be not now in ue, yet it was ometimes amongt the Amazons who made ue of Men only as Stallions; as alo amongt the Medes and Perians, where it was a hame for a Woman to have les then five Husbands. And by the report of Caear in his Commentaries, the Women of great Britain had no les then ten or twelve Husbands a piece. Nevertheles this plurality of Hubands is omthing againt the Law of Nature, according to which the Male as the mot perfect is the head and mater of the Woman: and as 'tis a montrous thing for a body to have many heads, o 'tis for a Woman to have many Husbands; beides that they hinder production of Children; (for we ee publick Women are barren) and on the contrary, plurality of Wives is the
caue of much iue. Wherefore 'tis more expedient in a State, whoe chief trength conits in the number of men, that one Husband have many Wives, then one Wife many Husbands.

The econd aid, Though men, abuing the power and authority of Laws to their own advantage, have oftner married more Wives then they have permitted them to have more Hubands; yet the women have as much reaon of complaint in this point, as in any other etablih'd to their prejudice, without their being heard or ummon'd. Their vehement and irregular appetite after man (of which the irregular motions of that Animal in Animali are mot certain evidences) eems to conclude in their favour. For Woman alone of all Animals deires the Male at all times, even after conception; She, the Fire, the Sea, and Death, never ay 'tis enough; as the matter hath a continual appetite of Forms, o hath he of the Male: which deire being natural, ought to be atisfi'd; otherwie it were in vain: but nothing is o in Nature, and therefore he ought to be permitted more Husbands; ince one alone is more apt to irritate then atiate her. She is able and hath wherewith to atisfie them; but if one man cannot uffice one woman, how can he acquit himelf towards a dozen; Epecially in this age, wherein, no doubt, women would appeal from the contitution of Solon, who would have men live with their wives only thrice a moneth; as well as from that foolih cutom of Cato, who never viited his but when it rain'd. Lycurgus was much better advis'd, when he permitted old or otherwie impotent perons to chue out the handomet young men to lye with their wives. This Sage Legilator well judging that they would of themelves take this liberty; and therefore 'twas better to grant it them, that o they might be quit of the vice and blame attending this action when prohibited.

The Third aid, That the deciion of this Quetion (the very report of which ometimes put the Roman Dames into an aproar) being of very great conequence to both parties, 'tis requiite to oberve o much equity therein, that the Women have no ground of exception; though, to peak truth, I know not which would be mot to their advantage, whether to have more Husbands (who would be o many Maters and Tyrants) or to hare with other Women the Carees of one alone; the firt being contrary to their haughty humour. and the econd to their jealouie. Beides, the plurality of Hubands would hinder not only the propagation, but alo the education of Children; for none would take care of the Children which were not his own; and though they were, he would not believe they belong'd to him. It would be impoible for a Father to know his own Child; the term of Child-bearing being no more certain tetimony, then the reemblance of Phyiognomy. Moreover, whether the Wife were hated or loved by her Husbands, he
would be dipleas'd to ee all her Rivals in bad intelligence, or the effects of their common hatred: However, being unable to pleae all, by reaon of the diverity of their humours, he could not avoid the digut of ome of them. As for that impure pleaure, 'tis too hameful to be brought into the account; beides that the frequency of it would take away its weetnes; no pleaures of life being uch, but upon the core of their rarity.

The Fourth aid, They that fear the multitude of Husbands would hinder conception, and conequently generation, by the confuion of everal Seeds, know not how either is effected; ince Phyitians affirm with Hippocrates, That the Womb no ooner receives the fruitful Seed, but it huts it elf up to embrace the ame traitly (as the Stomach does the Meat) and that o exactly as not to admit a needles point; o that it cannot open again to receive new Seed in a econd Coition. And though uperfoetation happen ometimes, yet 'tis very rare, and is incident to a Woman that lies with the ame Man everal times, as well as to one that lies with many. The other Inconvenience, of the incertainty of Iues, and conequently of Succeions, is as little coniderable; for Man being not born for himelf, but for the State whereof he is a Member; and Children les belonging to their Parents then to the Commonwealth, whereof they are the Nurery; 'twere more expedient that they were bred and intructed like thoe brave Lacedemonians, at the publick charge, than of their Parents, whoe tendernes and too great indulgence is oft-times the caue of their evil education. Moreover, this was the deign of that Divine Commonwealth of Plato, who would have not only other Goods, but Wives and Children alo common; that o thoe ungrateful words of Mine and Thine, which are the caue of all Michiefs, might be taken away. For by this means that importunate olicitude of Appropriation and Jealouie, which oftentimes afflicts both parties, would be no longer any thing but a phantam: Women would find their atisfaction in the plurality of Husbands; thee, how many oever to one woman, having always enough and more then they needed; and the woman being cunning enough to divide her favours o that all her Hubands might be contented; who, beides dividing the burden of dometick cares, would have an eaier tak by having the more Aociates. But epecially 'twould be much for the womans interet; for if he be belov'd by all her Husbands, 'twill be unpeakable happines to her; if hated by any, the carees of ome will make her amends for the bad uage of others: whereas finding no remedy in that Gordian knot which tyes her to one peron, he abandons her elf to depair: inomuch that in the time of Spurius Carvilius, eventy women accus'd one another to the Senate of having poyon'd their Husbands. But if he be contrain'd to hare the carees of one Husband with a douzen rivals, there will be nothing but perpetual feuds, envies, and jealouies. Witnes Leah and Rachel;
who, though holy women, yet daily conteted for the poeion of their common Husband Jacob. And the Scripture oberves that Leah, who was blear-ey'd, was contrain'd to purchae of the fair Rachel with mandrakes the liberty of lying one night with Jacob.

The 5th aid, That eeing a Woman is a hagger'd and indocible animal, (Experience hewing us, that one ingle man is not capable to reduce her to reaon) 'twere more expedient to allow her many Husbands; the reverence and aw of whom (and in defect thereof, their force) might tame her pride and inolence; which is rien to the highet pitch, ince the time that Jutinian's Wife got the Law of Divorce repeal'd, which ever before had been a Bridle upon them.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXI. Of the manner of Accretion.
div.p:
MOtion, which is the mutation from one tate to another, is either imple or compound: Simple is either of Quality, & is term'd Alteration; or of Place, and is call'd Lation or Motion Local Compound is either to Subtance, and is nam'd Generation, which includes alteration and formation; or to a greater Quantity, which comprehends Local Motion with Accretion or Augmentation, which cannot be made unles the parts extended change place. This Accretion is an effect of one of the Faculties ubervient to the Vegetative or Natural, which are three, the Generative, the Auctive or Accretive and the Nutritive; according to the three operations oberv'd in living bodies which have parts generated, nourihing, and increaing; for a thing mut be generated before it can grow and acquire the perfection wherein it is maintain'd by Nutrition. The Generative Faculty, which is compounded of the Alterative and Formative, regards the foetus in the womb. The Auctive governs it from its birth till the twentieth or one and twentieth year, which is the term of Accretion. The Nutritive continues all the time of life, which cannot ubit without nourihment; becaue this repairs the continual diipation of our ubtance caus'd by the action of heat upon humidity; in which action, Life it elf conits. Now though the body may be nouriht without growing, yet it cannot grow unles it be nouriht. For Accretion being an Extenion of the parts in length and breadth, new ubtance mut be upply'd to fill up the place of that which is extended: otherwie, a living body hould grow no more then a bladder doth when it is blown, or a piece of leather when it is tretcht; in the former, what is gotten in capacity, is lot in thicknes; and in the latter, what is gotten in length is impair'd in breadth: o that the augmentation of parts would be rather imaginary than
real, without upply of new matter to ucceed that which is equally extended in all its dimenions: amongt which, nevertheles that of tature, and of the olid parts, (as the bones) is call'd Growth, and not that which is made in thicknes and the flehy parts, which are enlarged manytimes after the time of full growth.

The econd aid, That all things being finite, mut have bounds of magnitude utable to the ue whereunto they are appointed; which bounds are not determinate in inanimate bodies, as Stones, Metals, Hair, and Nails; whoe accretion being made by the bare appoition of matter, they are augmented continually, o long as there is acceion of new matter to the former. But in living bodies the ame are regular; for the accretion of thee being internal, and the work of the oul, continues till the body hath attain'd the proportion and tature requiite to its functions. To compas which, Nature employs Heat as the Efficient Caue, and Humidity as the Material. Hence children grow mot in their infancy, becaue they are then mot moit; and men to a larger ize then women, becaue they have more heat. Young men indeed have a more pungent and vigorous heat then Children, but thee are better tor'd; (as being nearer the principles of their generation); and though it be not o active, yet 'tis more proper for the growth of the olid parts, which being deiccated by a violent heat are not o extenible as when they are full of a fat and unctuous humidity. But as for the manner of Accretion, 'tis almot the ame with that of Nutrition: The Aliment having been prepar'd in the Stomach and Liver, and by this latter tranmitted by the veins into all the parts of the body, the purer particles of it, weat through the coats of the Veels, and fall like a gentle dew upon the parts, which firt imbibe, then agglutinate, and latly, aimilate the ame. So that Nutrition is nothing but Aimilation of the ubtance of the food to that of the living body; and as Aliments nourih by reemblance of their Subtance, and by vertue of their Form, o they caue augmentation by their Quantity, and Matter, which arriving at the olid parts, as the Bones, Cartilages, and Ligaments, caues the ame to extend and grow in all dimenions; but epecially in height, by reaon that 'tis proper to Heat to drive Humidity upwards. And as when the Nutrition is equal to the Diipation, the body is only nouriht (as in the Age of Conitence) o when the Income of matter is greater than the Expence, the urpluage meeting with a due heat caueth augmentation; if it be les, there follows wating or diminution, as is een Old-Age.

The Third aid, As Animals are indu'd with a nobler degree of life than Plants, o they vegetate after a more ublime manner, and not only by bare heat and moiture. For amongt Animals, the Elephant a melancholy, and conequently, cold and dry beat, is yet the greatet of the field; the Crocodile, though cold,
grows all its life; and ome Serpents have by long age attained to the length of ixty foot. So amongt Trees, Oaks, though the dryet, are the larget. Of Bones, the Malleus, Incus, and Stapes in the Ear, which erve to reproduce ounds, grow not at all, though they be full of mucoity and humidity: on the contrary, the Teeth, the dryet of all parts (as is manifeted by their rotting lat) yet grow all the life long. But if Heat and Moiture were the caues of Accretion, then the Sanguine, who are hot and moit, hould be of the larget ize, as they are not, but commonly grow as well as the Flegmatick more in thicknes than height, augmenting their fleh and fat more then their olid parts. On the contrary, the tallet men are commonly cold, dry, and lean, the lowet, generally hotter; and people grow upon recovery after fevers which dry the body. Wherefore 'tis more probable that the Growth of Animals is an effect of the Spirits, which ininuating into the Veels extend the ame, and withall the membranes, mucles, and other parts encompaing them proportionably.

The Fourth aid, That the Spirits are indeed the Soul's Organs and Intruments whereby he performs her functions; but being of o volatile and fluid a nature, as not to be reckon'd in the number of the parts of Man's Body, they cannot of themelves caue Accretion, which requires Appoition of new matter, which ininuates it elf equally into all the parts jut as the nourihment doth; both without penetration of dimenions, or admiion of vacuity. This matter mut be humid, becaue, of all Bodies; the moit are mot pliant and extenible: Whence the Sea by reaon of its humidity, produces Monters of trange bulk. Yet this humidity, as well as the heat mut be in due degree; for a great heat conumes intead of increaing; whence the Males of Birds of prey are leer than the Females, becaue they are hotter; but if it be too weak, then the moiture, intead of acending, falls downward by its proper gravity; which is the caue that Women, who have les heat, are alo of leer tature than Men, and larger downwards as Men are upwards. According to the various marriage of this heat with moiture, bodies grow variouly; ome more lowly; others, more peedily; ome are little and dwarfih; others, Giants; according to the defect or abundance of the matter erving to their firt Formation. But as for the ret of Man-kind, Wie Nature hath et her elf uch bounds as he hath judg'd convenient, beyond which the mot part grow not; which are between ix and even foot: Not the Accretive Faculty is then lot or corrupted, (for 'tis that power of the Soul, and conequently, incorruptible and ineparable, from her) but it cannot act longer for want of fitting dipoitions, to wit, the oftnes and moitnes of the olid parts. As a Mule hath a Senitive Soul, but not the virtue of generating, which is one of the Faculties of that Soul; and a Load-tone rub'd with Garlick, hath till the virtue of attracting Iron, but
cannot employ the ame, by reaon that its Pores are topt, no more then the Eye can ee in a Suffuion.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXII. Whether the Dinner or Supper ought to be larget.
div.p: DIet, or the Regiment of Living, (which is the firt and mot general part of Phyick, becaue it concerns both the healthy and the ick) conits in regulating the quantity and quality of Aliments, and the order and time wherein they are to be taken. The Quantity mut be proportional to the nature of the Peron, o that his trength may be repair'd and not oppres'd thereby. As for the Quality, they mut be of good juice, and as pleaing and agreeable as may be. The Order of taking them is to be this; uch as are moit, oft, laxative, and of oonet Digetion or Corruption, mut precede uch as are dry, hard, atringent, and of more difficult Concoction. The Time, in general, ought to be o regulated that the interval of Meals be ufficient for digeting the nourihment lat fore-going. The Cutom of mot Nations hath made two, Dinner, and Supper; Break-fat, and Afternoon-collations, being but Diminutives, or parts of them two, and the over-plus of notorious excees. Now if we compare Dinner and Supper together, it eemes requiite that the latter be more plentiful, becaue the Time enuing, it is mot proper for Digetion, in regard of the intro-receion of the natural heat during leep, which becoming by that means more united and vigorous, performes the natural functions, to wit, Concoction, Ditribution, Appoition, and Aimilation, more perfectly then after Dinner, when it is diverted otherwie, to the Senes and Operations both of Body and Mind: Beides that, the coldnes and darknes of the night, contributes not a little to the ame effect upon the account of Antiperitais. Unles we had rather, with ome, etablih a new power of the Soul, governing and dipoing the Spirits according to neceity; ometimes giving them the bridle, and cauing them to move outwards, as in Anger, Shame, and Indignation; ometimes ummoning them inwards, as in Fear, Sadnes, and Sleep, which for this reaon renders the Countenance pale, and all the extream parts cold; whereas in the time of waking, the external parts being hotter, leave the Internal more cold.

The Second aid, That he agreed with the Church, which enjoynes Fating in the Evening but allows Dinners; which it doth not without mature conideration, drawn as well from Nature as from Grace. For it thereby deignes the echewing thoe Illuions and Temptations attending good Cheer taken before going to bed; and conceives, a light Supper fittet for meditation
and erenity of Mind. The reparation of our diipated Spirits by Food, caueth the ame diorder in the Body that happens in a Town or Village upon the entrance of trangers to people it, after its deolation by ome accident; and therefore 'tis better that this trouble arrive in the day, when our waking enes are able to ecure themelves from the Commotions caued by this change, than in the night, whoe darknes helps to multiply the Phantams which are in the Imagination, peter'd with the vapors and gros fumes of Meats, the Digetion whereof is then but begun. Whereas in the day time, uch vapors tranpire more freely by the Pores which are opened by the heat of the Sun, and by the Exercies which are ued in the Afternoon. Beides, Meats being onely to fill emptines, the time of the greatet inanition is the fittet for repletion; which certainly Noon mut be, after the Evacuations of the fore-going Night and Morning.

The Third aid, There are four manners of taking Repats: Firt, Some eat often, and very much at each time; o did the Athletae of old, and o do thoe Gourmandizers who are alwayes hungry, and whoe Stomacks have been found after their death of unuual capacity: This way is altogether oppoite to Health. Secondly, Some eat little and eldom: which coure befits acute Dieaes; thoe that are judg'd the fourth day, requiring ometimes a total abtinence, in cae the Patient's trength can bear it; thoe that reach to the eventh or fourteenth, very little Food and eldom. Thirdly, Such as mut eat little but often; as little Children and Old people, whoe heat being weak and eaily diipated, they mut be often nourih'd; but by a little at a time, for fear of overcharging their too weak Stomacks. The lat and commonet way, is, to eat plentifully but eldom, which is the manner of middle-ag'd people, who uually eat twice a day, and more at one Meal than at the other: it being hard for a Man to atiate himelf both at Dinner and Supper without indammaging his Health. Which made Plato wonder when he heard that the Sicilians fill'd themelves with Meat twice a day, and oblig'd the Romans to make a light repat about Noon, and a plendid Supper; which I am for. Upon this account the Church hath, to macerate us, forbidden Suppers on Fating dayes; which is an Argument that they are more agreeable and more conducing to Health than Dinners. For uch quantity of Food is to be taken as anwers to the natural heat; which being not onely more vigorous, but alo of longer duration between Supper and Dinner, than between Dinner and Supper, (the interval whereof is eldom above ix or even hours, whereas that between Supper and Dinner is about eventeen) 'tis more reaonable to up more largely than dine. For if the Dinner be larget, we hall eat either as much as the heat is able to diget by Supper-time, or more. If we eat more, and go to Supper before the digetion of the Dinner is wholly finih'd, we hall beget crudities, which are the eed
of mot dieaes. If we eat as much as the heat can diget, and the Supper be les then the Dinner; then the heat which follows the Supper being tronger and more active, will oon concoct the meat taken at Supper; and (becaue 'tis a natural agent, not acting from a principle of liberty but of neceity, and cannot remain idle) having no extraventitious matter to work upon, it will necearily conume the laudable juices of the body, drying up the ame during leep. For whereas leep is aid to moiten, whence aroe the Proverb, Qui dort mange; He that leeps, eats; 'tis true, when the tomach and entrals being fill'd with ufficient nourihment, the Heat raies and diperes to all the parts the puret of the juices and vapours like gentle dews; which it cannot do when the Stomach is empty.

The fourth aid, Nature having given us an Appetite to advertie us of the need of all parts, there is no certainer rule of the time of Repat than this Appetite, which for this reaon is eated in the upper Orifice of the Stomach, render'd enible by the Nerves of the ixth Pair terminating therein. For there is a continual diipation of our ubtance in all the parts, which being exhauted attract from their neighbours wherewith to fill their own emptines: thee olicit the Liver, for upply; that, the Guts by the Mearaick Veins: thee the Stomack, at the top whereof this uction terminates, the ene or perception whereof is call'd Appetite; which, if of hot and dry, is call'd Hunger; if of cold and moit, Thirt. So that Nutrition being onely to recruit and repair the los of our Subtance, there is no more aured ign of the fitting time to eat, then when the aid Appetite is mot eager, at what hour oever it be.

The fifth aid, That this might have place in well temper'd bodies which deire onely o much as they are able to diget, but not in thoe whoe Appetite is greater than their Digetion, as cold and melancholy Stomacks; or who deire les, as the hot and bilious, whoe heat melting the juices, abates the Appetite; as on the contrary, Coldnes contracting the membranes of the Stomack, augments it: So that 'tis mot expedient for every one to conult his own Temper, Age, Nature, and Cutom of living; Old people, little Children, uch as are ubject to Defluxions, or have weak Stomacks, mut up paringly; on the other ide, the Cholerick, and uch as are ubject to the Head-ach, mut eat a larger Supper than Dinner: But above all, the Cutom of every particular peron is mot coniderable herein.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXIII. Which of the Humane Pasions is mot excuable.
div.p:
MAn being compos'd of two Pieces, Body and Soul, and upon that account tyl'd by Trimegitus, The Horizon of the Univere, becaue he unites in himelf the piritual nature with the Corporeal, the Inclinations whereof are different; he hath alo need of two guides to conduct thoe two Parts (the Rational and the Animal) and make them know the Good towards which they are carried of their own Nature. The Intellect makes him ee the Honet and Spiritual Good; the Imagination enables him to conceive a enible and corporeal Good. And as the Rational Appetite (which is the Will) follows the light afforded to it by the Intellect in puruit of Honet Good, whence Vertue arieth; o the enitive Appetite is carri'd to the enjoyment of enible Good which the Imagination makes it conceive as profitable and pleaant, and that by motions commonly o diorderly and violent that they make impreion not only upon the Mind, but upon the Body, whoe Oeconomy they dicompoe; and for this reaon they are call'd Pasions or Perturbations, and Affections of the Mind. Thee Pasions either are carri'd towards Good and Evil imply, as Love and Hatred; the firt inclining us to Good which is the Parent of Beauty, the latter averting us from Evil: or ele they conider both Good and Evil Abent, as Deire and Flight: or Latly, they conider them being preent, and caue Pleaure and Grief; which, if of longer duration, produce Joy and Sadnes. Now becaue difficulties frequently occurr in the puruit of Cood and flight of Evil, therefore Nature not contented to have indu'd Animals with a Concupicible Appetite, which by means of the ix above-mention'd Pasions might be carri'd towards Good, and avoid Evil; hath alo given them another Appetite call'd Iracible, to urmount the Obtacles occurring in the puruit of Good or flight of Evil; whence arie five other Pasions, Hope, Depair, Boldnes, Fear, and Anger. Hope excites the oul to the proecution of a difficult but obtainable good. Depair checks the motions of the oul towards the puruit of a Good no longer obtainable. Boldnes regards an abent Evil, which aures it elf able to urmount. Fear coniders the ame abent Evil without any means of being able to avoid it. Latly, the violence of Anger is bent againt a preent Evil, whereof it believes a posibility to be reveng'd. And becaue a preent and enjoyed Good cannot be accompani'd with difficulty; hence there is no Pasion in the Iracible Appetite anwering to Anger, as there is in the other Pasions: which again are divided according to the everal objects about which they are exercis'd.
The deire of Honours is call'd Ambition; that of Riches, Covetounes; that of flehly Pleaures, Concupicence; that of Meats, Gourmandie or Gluttony. The Hatred of Vice caues Zeal; that of a Rival, Jealouie. The orrow ariing upon the ight of Evil uffer'd by an undeerving peron, caues Compasion; Indignation proceeds from the happening of Good to one that merits it not. Now, among all thee Paions, Ambition, which aims at a general uperiority, eems to me the firt; and ince it hath erv'd to excue Parricides and Violators of the publick faith, whom it hath caus'd to ay, that for the ake of command nothing is unjut, it may very well be excus'd every where ele; beides that, it hath been the intigator to the mot glorious Actions, the ource whereof is that laudable Ambition which every one hath to out-vie his companion.

The econd aid, If the Paions are Dieaes of the Soul, as the Stoicks held, and the Quetion eems to preuppoe; I conceive none more agreeable and excuable than Love; whoe weet violence ininuating into the everet brets, finds nothing capable to reit it. Hence thoe that are taken with it, wih nothing les than a cure, which cannot proceed but from oblivion of the thing belov'd, wherein they live more than in themelves: the oul being more where it loves than in the body wherein it lives. Moreover, this Pasion is the mot natural and common of all, and conequently, the mot excuable; being found not only in all men, but alo in all Animals, who feel the aaults of Love, which makes them naturally tend towards Good. And as Love is the mot common, o it is likewie the ource and principle of all the Paions: for we neither hate nor fear any thing, we have neither joy, adnes, deire, fear, nor anger, but becaue we love omething: the true coure to become exempt from thee Paions, being, To love Nothing.

The third aid, That the mot violent Paions being the mot excuable becaue the hardet to ubdue, thoe of the Iracible Appetite (particularly Anger) being more vehement than thoe of the Concupicible Appetite, are alo the mot worthy of excue. The former poes the noblet part of Man, the Heart, which is the ource of Anger; the latter, the Liver which is the eat of Love; whoe weaknes the Poets have ufficiently demontrated by repreenting it to us under the form of a Child, which hath no power over us but what we uffer it to take. But Anger which is proper to the Generous, as Love is to the weak and effeminate, makes it elf mater of the Soul; and by its udden and impetuous motions obcuring the light of reaon, makes us the more excuable in that we are no longer maters of our own actions. And as Madnes excues the Frantick from blame and punihment, o Anger which is a hort Madnes, as the Poet aith, deerves the ame excue; its violence being o much above that of all other Paions, that it is
the mot quick and paes like Lightning: for when it takes root in the oul, it loes its name, and degenerates into Hatred.

The Fourth aid, That he was for Joy, becaue all the other Paions acknowledg its power uch, that they are contented to be its ervants; Love and Deire are only in order to ome hoped Joy; Hatred and Flight, only to remove all objects that may trouble it. Depair then only eizes us, when we can no longer hope for Joy; Hope is for it alone; Fear is only of what is contrary to it; Boldnes, to break through all Obtacles oppoing our contentment; and Anger erves to expres the dipleaure we reent for its delay or interruption. If a man injure us in his anger, or in his adnes, yea, or in his depair; we will not excue him: but be we never o dipleas'd, we not only excue the joy of others, but take pleaure in it. And whereas Contraries are known by their Contraries, ince nothing dipleaes us o much as Sadnes, nothing pleaes us o much as Joy; whoe violence is manifeted by ome that have dy'd of it, as none ever did of Anger. In fine, we cannot better prove and approve the power and empire of any one than by becoming his ubjects, as we all are of Joy; to which the greatet part not only give part of their time, but alo quit the mot important affairs to eek it in places detinated to the god of Laughter; whoe Fetivals are now more frequen then in in the days of Apuleius. And what makes us in youth bear and endure all the pains of tudy; Apprentices of each Trade, the hardhips which they undergo; Soldiers, the danger of Death, but a pre-conceived hope of Joy? which he that poees, becomes o mater'd by it, that he forgets all his pat evils: The Mariner no longer remembers the perils of the ea, nor the ick peron his pains; In hort, every one uffers himelf to be poe'd and govern'd by this Paion, which is therefore the mot excuable.
