The fifth aid, That Grief brings greater Evil than Joy doth Good; becaue Evil wholly detroys the Nature of a thing, which Good only renders more complete; whence it follows that the former is much more jut and excuable than the latter which gives only Well-being, but Evil detroys Being it elf; to the preervation whereof all Creatures being naturally enclin'd, more carefully echew uch things as may hurt them, then they purue thoe that may procure joy and contentment. Moreover the accents of the Voice which tetifie Grief or Sadnes are much more violent than thoe of Joy; which being nothing ele but a bare complacency receiv'd in the enjoyment of Good, conits rather in ret then in motion, whereof Grief partakes more largely by the endeavours which it caueth the oul to put forth for removing of what torments it.

The ixth aid, That the Paions being Appurtenances of our Nature, and part of our Selves, are all excuable in themelves, becaue
natural and inevitable; but epecially thoe whereto we are particularly mot inclin'd by Temper: o Love and Joy are mot excuable in the anguine; Choler and Depair in the Bilious; Hatred and Sadnes in the Melancholick; Hope and Boldnes in Youth; and Bahfulnes is excuable in a Child, but culpable in an old man. Yet Hope, which accompanies Man not only while breath lats, but extends even beyond death, eems by that duration to plead, that as it is the leat eparable, o it is the mot excuable.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXIV. Which is the mot laudable Temperament.
div.p:
TEmperament is the Harmony and Proportion of the four firt Qualities, reulting from the mixture of the Elements, whereof all ublunary Bodies are compounded; which being detinated to everal ends, requir'd therefore different Tempers and Qualifications. Now although the diverity herein be almot infinite, yet it may be reduc'd to three Supream Heads. For either the four Qualities are o mix'd that they remain in an equal proportion; or one of them excels the ret; or ele two together have the advantage. The firt makes the Temperament equal; the two latter make it unequal. The equal Temperament is two-fold; one call'd Temperament by Weight (ad Pondus, as they peak) when the qualities are o perfectly proportionate, that, could they be weigh'd in a balance, not one would preponderate above another: (Undertand this Equalnes, only of Qualities, not of Elements; for were there as much Fire as Water, as much Air as Earth, the more active fire would conume the ret and reduce into ahes all living things; whoe diolution hews us that they conit more of Earth and Water then of the other Elements. The other, call'd Temperament according to Jutice, is found in every ort of compound-ubtances; amongt which there is one that erves for the rule or tandard to all individuals compris'd under it, and poees in perfection the temper require requiite to the functions of its nature. Thus amongt Animals the Lyon is hot, the Swine moit, the Salamander cold, the Bee dry: but Man is temperate, and amongt his parts the Bones, Cartilages, and Ligaments are cold and dry; the Blood, Spirits, Mucles, Heart and Liver are hot and moit; the Brain, Phlegm and Fat are cold and moit; each of them being temper'd according to Jutice. The Skin alone, epecially that in the Palm of a well-temper'd mans hand, being moderate in all the Qualities and eeming a texture of the Fleh and Nerves, is equally cold and hot, oft and hard, and conequently the prime Organ of Touch, and
the judge of all other Temperaments. The unequal Temperament, (which nevertheles lyes within the latitude of Health) is either imple or compound. The former (wherein one of the four Qualities prevails over its contrary, while the other two remain in a mediocrity) is of four orts, Hot, Cold, Dry, and Moit. The econd, (wherein two excell) is likewie of four orts according to the four combinations which the qualities admit; viz. Hot and Moit, Hot and Dry, Cold and Moit, Cold and Dry: for Hot and Cold, Dry and Moit, cannot ubit in one and the ame ubject. And though the heat inceantly conuming the moiture, and the cold collecting plenty of humid excrements, hinder the hot and moit, and cold and dry tempers from ubiting long in the ame tate; yet they may continue therein for ome time, though they become chang'd by ucceion of ages. Now of the nine orts of Tempers, to wit, the four imple, four compound, and one perfectly temperate, this lat eems to me the mot laudable and perfect; a body thus temper'd being neither fat nor lean, hot nor cold, dry nor moit, but of a quare and indifferently flehy contitution, not inclining to one extream more then another, being in an exquiite mediocrity, and conequently more laudable then any of thoe which approach nearer the (always vicious) extreams.

The Second aid, If there be uch an exquiite Temperament as reaon eems to demontrate, then ince there is no paing from one extream to another but by the middle; when a Child changes the heat and moiture of his infancy into the cold and drynes of old-age, that middle equal Temper mut pas away as wift as lightning, and it's duration will be almot inenible. Wherefore though it be the mot perfect and deirable, yet ince 'tis only the tandard and rule of all others, I am for Hot and Moit, as mot utable to life, which conits in thoe two qualities; as Death, and its forerunner Old-age, are cold and dry. This is the Temperament of Child-hood, allotted to us by Nature at the beginning of our life; and therefore the mot perfect, anwering to the Spring (the mot temperate of Seaons) and to Blood (the mot temperate humour) whence 'tis call'd Sanguine; as the cold and dry, is Melancholick; the hot and dry, Bilious; the cold and moit, Phlegmatick. Which is not to be undertood of the excrementitious but of the natural humours contain'd in the mas of Blood, which follow the principles of our Generation. Moreover, 'tis proper not only for the functions of life, whereof health is the foundation, and joy the mot weet upport, which the Blood produces, (as Melancholy doth adnes, Phlegm lothfulnes; Bile, fury and anger) but alo for thoe of the Mind, which depending upon the purenes of the Animal Spirits, (as thee do upon that of the Vital and Natural) which are more benigne in the Sanguine, their conceptions mut be likewie more clear and refin'd.

The Third aid, If Heat and Moiture are utable to the actions
of the Vegetative Soul, (Generation, Accretion, and Nutrition) they are no les prejudicial to thoe of the Rational, the eat whereof is therefore remote from the two Organs of Concoction, the Ventricle and the Liver; let the fumes of the Food coming to be mix'd with the Animal Spirits might offucate and cloud the phantams and ideas wherewith thoe Spirits are charged, and conequently hinder the operations of the Undertanding, which depend upon thoe phantams o long as it is linked to the Body. For all Souls being alike, their operations differ only according to the divere temper of the Brain, which caues that of the Animal Spirits, which mut be ubtle and luminous, but not o far as to be igneous (like thoe of the cholerick and frantick, whoe motions are precipitate and impetuous) but in the jut proportion oberv'd in the Melancholick temper, which being cold and dry (that is to ay, les hot and moit) is mot proper for Prudence and Widom, which require a etled compos'd Spirit, like that of old men, who owe not their Widom o much to the experience of many years, as to the coldnes and drynes of their Brains, which makes men grave and edate. All brave men have been of this temper, which gives patience and contancy, without which nothing grand and coniderable can ever be perform'd. And as the hot and moit temper is mot ubject to corruption, o by the reaon of contraries the cold and moit mut be leat obnoxious to dieaes (as amongt Trees and Animals, the dryet and hardet are leat offended by external injuries) upon which account the Melancholy is not only mot deirable, but alo becaue it mot contents the mind of him that poees it, who being at his eae makes more reflection upon the benefit he injoys, unles otherwie diverted by contemplation.

The Fourth aid, That that is the mot laudable temper which is mot adapted to the functions both of body and mind; between which there is o great a diproportion, that what agrees well with the one, eems prejudicial to the other. The Sanguine is the mot excellent for the operations of life and good habit of Body, but incommodious for thoe of the Mind; partly through the oftnes and mildnes of that humour which cannot uffer trong attention, and partly through its exceive humidity, which filling the Imagination with vapours cannot upply fit matter to the Animal Spirits, whoe temper mut be dry for producing Widom, whereunto Melancholy is by ome judg'd conducible; but were it o, 'tis too contrary to the health and good contitution of the body to be deirable. The phlegmatick temper is proper neither for the health of the Body nor the goodnes of Wit. But the Bilious is for both; being les repleat then the Sanguine, and les attenuated and dry'd then the melancholick, beides very nimble and dextrous through the plenty of pirits; and as 'tis eaily diorder'd, o likewie 'tis retor'd in a little time; its maladies being the hortet.
Moreover, its vivacity is much more deirable then the heavines and lumpihnes attending the Melancholy and making the Vulgar think them Sage and prudent though they are only o in appearance: whereas the Cholerick are Indutrious and Courageous, accomplihing whatever they attempt; and as amongt Beats and Birds the noble Lyon and Eagle are of this complexion, and according to ome our firt Parent Adam (which ignifies Red) was in hair and temper bilious; whence perhaps alo Man is call'd in the ame language Ih, which ignifies Fire, whereof choler partakes.

The Fifth aid, That indeed his readines to obey his Wife was an effect of that Temper, of which he eems rather to have been then of that laudable and perfectly temperate one which our Saviour enjoy'd. But indeed, Tempers being the principles of all our functions, which mut be different in every individual, are deirable according to the Places, Seaons, Employments, Age, Sex, and Inclinations of every one in particular.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXV. Of Happines and nhappines; and whether men are Happy or nhappy, becaue they really are o, or becaue they think themelves o.
div.p:
THree orts of effects are oberv'd in Nature. Some arie always necearily, as the viciitudes of Days, Nights and Seaons, which depend upon the motion of the Stars, no more alterable without a miracle then the other effects of Univeral Nature. Others come to pas often but not always; the particular nature which produces them being ometimes hindred by ome accident, which makes it bring forth Monters. The lat happen neither always nor often but eldom; as all thoe which depend upon contingent caues, which are of two orts. The firt act by a neceity of nature, without any election: The econd by a principle of liberty without choice or deliberation. Both, when they produce an effect contrary to their intention and primary deign, are called fortuitous caues. And as thoe which act by natural neceity produce a caualty, as when a Stone falls upon the head of any one; o when thoe which operate by election and deign, produce another thing then what they had propounded to themelves, they make fortune, or good and ill-luck, according to the good or evil ariing thence by ways and prings, by us unforeeen: for in cae the caue or motives be known, the effects are no longer fortuitous and contingent, becaue they have their manifet and certain caue. So when indutry, labour, favour or friendhip procure
Riches, the effect is not to be acrib'd to Fortune, no more then the loes which follow upon the luxury and profuions of a diorderly life: but Riches and Honours are fortuitous when they happen to perons altogether incapable thereof; as alo poverty, infamy, and contempt alo to brave men, whoe contancy and reolution in undergoing all thoe digraces hath made it be commonly aid, That a wie man is above fortune, becaue he lights her troaks by the trength of his reaon; which being alone capable to render us happy, ince Beats detitute thereof have neither any hare in good-luck or bad-luck, I conceive that both the one and the other depends intirely upon our fanie, and the reflection we make upon the condition of the thing poeed; which appearing ometimes good and ometimes bad, makes us accordingly judge our elves happy or unhappy.

The Second aid, Diverity is no where more apparent than in humane Actions, the incertainty and incontancy whereof is uch, that men rarely arrive at their propoed end, but oftentimes behold themelves either exalted to an unhoped degree of Felicity, or overwhelmed with the Miery which there was no ground to apprehend. Which diverity of accidents, induced Supertitious Antiquity, to et up a blind and flitting Deity, contant onely in her incontancy, whom they held the caue of all uch effects; thus betaking themelves to an imaginary cane, in regard they could not, or would not acknowledg the true; which I attribute to every ones temperament, by means of which is produced in the Soul a certain natural motion and impetuoity for obtaining ome particular thing, without Reaons contributing thereunto; and according as a Man follows or reits thee intincts and inclinations, o he proves either happy or unhappy. Thus he who finds himelf dipoed to Arms, if he embrace them, thrives better than in a oft and edentary life, whereunto the Melaneholly peron is more addicted, and propers better herein. Now becaue dull pirits, fools, and thick-kull'd fellows, eaily uffer themelves to be guided by thoe motions; therefore they commonly prove more fortunate than the wie, whoe Prudence and Dicretion cauing them to make abundance of reflections upon what they undertake, caues them alo to loe opportunities which never return. For I am not of their Opinion, who hold, That as there are Spirits which make the Celetial Orbes move, and, according to Averroes, an Intelligence preiding over natural Generations; o there is a particular one for the various events of life, which it makes to happen according to the different intentions of the Firt Mover: Since without recurring to uch obcure and remote caues, we carry in our elves thoe of our Felicity and Infelicity, whereof we are the true Artificers; which to place in the Phanie alone, and not in reality, is to ay, good is not Good; ince goodnes being an eential affection of real entity, is ineparable from it, and conequently true, not barely imaginary.

The Third aid, That Good being uch onely upon account of its conveniency or utablenes to the Poeor, there is not in this world any Abolute Good or Happines, but onely Relative and by Comparion, eeing what utes well with one, doth not o with another. Riches, wherein mot Men place their Felicity, were cat into the Sea by a Philoopher, that he might the better attend Contemplation. Honors and Pleaures, (charms, which mot powerfully inveigle mot of Man-kind) are croes and torments to ome others. Imprionment, one of the hardet trials of Patience, is nevertheles ought by ome, who prefer Solitude and perpetual Retraint, before the vanities of the world. To have no Friends is the greatet of infelicities; yet Timon made it his prime Pleaure. Life, the foundation of all goods, hath been o tedious to ome, that to be deliver'd from it they have kill'd themelves; and the pains, afflictions, and dieaes leading to death, are, in the Stoicks account, but imaginary Evils, making no impreion upon the wie.

The Fourth aid, Since Happines and Unhappines eem to be the Elements, compoing the Political Life of Men, and the two Poles of that Globe upon which the Antients plac'd Fortune, their Conideration may be taken two ways, either in their Caue, or in their Effect. As for the firt, the Stoicks, who etabliht a Fate governing All by a Series of neceary and determinate Events, were as impious as Democritus and Leucippus, who, on the contrary, maintain'd that all things were done by Chance in the Univere, which, they aid, it elf was made by the caual occoure of their Atoms; thee denying the Providence of God, thoe his Power, by ubjecting and tying him to the immutable Laws of Fatality. But without conidering things in reference to God, to whom every thing is preent and certain, we may ditinguih them into two orts. Some acting necearily, have alwayes their neceary effects: others, which depend abolutely upon Man's Will, which is free and indifferent, have accordingly Effects incertain and contingent. Thus the accidents of the Sea, (where the vulgar believes is the chief Empire of Fortune), natural deaths, the births of poor and rich, have regular and neceary Caues. On the contrary, Goods freely given, or acquir'd with little indutry, or found, have contingent Caues; which being almot infinite, (for there is no Caue by it elf, but may be a Caue by accident, by producing another thing than what was intended) they cannot fall within the knowledge of Humane Wit, which knows onely what is finite and terminate. Other Events have Caues mixt of Chance and Neceity, as the death of the Poet Aechylus, hapning by a Tortoie which an Eagle let fall upon his bald Head. As for the econd manner wherein Happines may be conider'd, namely, Whether it render us happy in Reality or in Imagination; 'tis an accuing all Men of folly, to ay that Felicity is imaginary and phantatical; ince Nature, which hath given no Deire in vain,
(as he hould have done, if he had caus'd us to deire a thing that exits not) makes all Men apire to the one, and fear the other. There mut be an Abolute Happines as well as an Abolute Good, namely, the poeion of this Good, as that of Exitence is, which being the foundation of all Goods, mut be a Real and Abolute Good. Virtue and, the Honor attending it, being likewie true and olid Goods, their poeion mut adferr a emblable Felicity; the verity and reality is no more chang'd by not being equally guted by all, than the avour of Meat, or the Beauty of Light, would be by not being perceiv'd by a ick or a blind peron: Yea, as he that ha's a rough Diamond is not les the poeor, or les rich for not knowing the value of it; o he that poees ome Good ought not to be accounted les happy, though he think not himelf o. Moreover, 'twould be as aburd to call a Man happy or unhappy becaue he thinks himelf o; as to believe a fool is a King, or Rich, becaue he phanies himelf to have Empires and Riches.

The Fifth aid, That Happines, which is rather an Effect of our Genius, (as the examples of Socrates and Simonides prove) than of our Temperament, much les of the Stars and their influences, depends not onely upon the poeion of ome Good, or the belief a Man hath that he poees it, but upon both together; namely, upon the reflexion he makes upon the Good which he really poees; for want of which, Children, Fools, Drunkards, and even the Wie themelves, whilt they are a leep cannot be call'd Happy.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXVI. Of the Original of Precious Stones.
div.p: A Stone, which is defin'd a Foile, hard, dry, and frangible body, is either common or precious. Both are compounded of the Four Elements, chiefly of Water and Earth, but diverly proportion'd and elaborated. Coare Stones are made with les preparation, their proximate matter being onely much Earth and little Water, whereof is made a ort of Clay, which being dry'd by Nature, is hardned into a Stone. Precious Stones have more of Water, and les of Earth, both very pure and imple, (whence proceeds their Lutre, which attends the implicity of the Elements) and exactly mixt by Heat, which concocting the aqueous humidity, purifies and ublimes the ame to a mot perfect degree by help of that Univeral Spirit, where-with the Earth and whole world is fill'd, on which account the Pythagoreans eteemed it a great Animal.

The Second aid, Three things are to be conider'd in reference to the original of Stones; their matter, their efficient caue, and the place of their generation. Their remote matter is Earth and Water, which two Elements alone give bulk
and conitence: but their next matter, (concern'd in the Quetion) is a certain lapidifick juice, upplying the place of Seed, and often oberv'd dropping down from rocks; which, if thick and vicous, makes common tones; if ubtil and pure, the precious. Now this juice not only is turn'd it elf into tone, but likewie turns almot all other Bodies, as Wood, Fruits, Fihes, the Fleh of Animals, and uch other things, which are petrifi'd in certain Waters and Caves. Their remote efficient caue is Heat, which evering heterogeneous bodies unites thoe of the ame nature, whereof it makes the aid homogeneous juice, which is condens'd by cold; which giving the lat form and perfection to the tone is its proximate efficient caue. Latly, their place is every where; in the middle region of the Air, which produces Thunder-bolts; in the Sea, which affords Coral, (of a middle nature between Stone and Plant) and Pearls in their hells which are their wombs, by means of the Dew of Heaven; in Animals, in Plants and above all in the Earth and its Mines or Matrices which are cloe paces exempt from the injuries of Air, Water, or other external Agents, which might hinder their production either by intermixtion of ome extraneous body, or by uffering the Mineral Spirits erving to the elaboration of the Stones to tranpire.

The Third aid, Precious Stones, produc'd for Ornament, (as Metals are for Ue of life), are of three orts; namely, either bright and replendent, as the Diamond, Ruby, Crytal, Amethyt; or a little obcure, as the Turquois, Japer, and other middle ones without perfect lutre, as the Opal and all Pearls. And as the matter of common Stones is Earth the principle of Darknes; o that of the precious is an aqueous diaphanous humour, congeal'd by the coldnes of water or earth, or by the vicinity of Ice and Snow which inviron Mountains and Rocks, where commonly their Mines are found; and amongt others, Crytal which is (as 'twere) the firt matter of other precious Stones, and the firt eay of Nature (when he deigns to incloe her Majety in the lutre of the mot glittering Jewels) is nothing ele but humidity condens'd by cold. Whence a violent heat, uch as that of Furnaces, reolves and melts it. Moreover, the effects attributed to thee Stones, as to top blood, allay the fumes of wine, and reit hot poyons, argue them caus'd only by cold, which alo gives them weight by condenation of their parts.

The Fourth aid, If Crytals and Stones were produc'd only by cold, they could not be generated in the Iles of Cyprus, the red Sea and other Southern parts, but only in the Northern, where nevertheles they are mot rare, there being Mountains where cold hath preerv'd Ice for divers Ages without ever being converted into Crytal; which (beides) hould wim upon the water as well as Ice doth, and not be more heavy and tranparent: which cannot be attributed to their greater denity, caus'd by
a more vehement cold; ince water inpiated into Ice becomes les tranparent, and Crytals are not o cold to the touch as Ice. But above all, their Calcination evidently hews that there is omething ele in them beides Water; for finding out of which, we mut examine the principles of Bodies nearet akin to them; as Alom and Glas, which by their plendor and conitence, much reemble precious Stones, being (like them) Mineral Juices hardned and mixt by a proportionate quantity of Salts and violent Spirits, which joyned together, loe their Acrimony to embrace one another more cloely: Thee Principles are very vicous, capable of great olidity, and being of themelves tranparent, are proper to preerve all the brightnes and light, which their pecifick forms can add to them. This reemblance being uppoed, we are obliged to dicover the ame Principles of Compoition in Jewels; ince things agreeing generically, and having reemblance of qualities, agree alo as to matters, and have nothing to ditinguih them but that unknown Form which determines the Species. But the truth is, little brightnes and hardnes proceed not from their Form alone, which is uncapable of o cloe connexion, but from much dark Earth, and a very impure Phlegm; which is not found in precious Stones, or in the Glas where-with in the Indies they make Emeralds. Moreover, 'tis this body that mot reembles thoe Stones, which hath no other Principles but a Spirit mingled amongt much Salt, and ome little of Earth; which are united by the activity of heat, and condened by their natural inclination to inpiation, (cold contributing but very little thereunto, ince they acquire their olidity and conitence whilt yet very hot.) The Artifice of counterfeiting Rubies and Diamonds, with the ame Principles of Glas, greatly confirms this Opinion; onely for avoiding brittlenes, they mix les terretreity, and conume not the moiture, (which caues Concretion) with o much violence. The Calcination of Crytals, whereby much Salt is extracted from them, and the eaines of making Glas there-with, in like manner hews what are the Material Principles of thee Stones. Which Principles being contained, or generated in the boome of the Earth, certain Juices are formed of their everal mixtures, which unite to the firt body which happens to impres its Virtues upon them; then the puret part of thee Salts and Earths, is volatilized by the Spirit mixt there-with, and circulated by Heat, which alwayes perfects it by further Concoction, till it have rendered it Homogeneous. Thee Juices commonly tick in uperficial parts of the Earth, where a moderate heat finihes their Concoction, evaporating, the too great humidity which hinder'd the induration natural to uch ubtances; Divers pecies are made according to the different impreions of Heaven, or the place of their Generation, or other dipoitions; to which I alo refer the diverity of their Colours, and not (as mot Chymits do) to Sulphur, which is never found in thee
Stones; which Colours, they ought to attribute rather to Salt, their principal matter, ince by everal degrees of Coction or Calcination, it acquires almot all the Colours of thee Stones; being firt white, then blew, and latly, reddih.

The Fifth aid, 'Tis mot probable that in the beginning there were Species of Stones of all orts, dipos'd in places mot proper for their Conervation, which have continually generated the like, determining fit matter by the Emiion of a certain Vapor or Spirit, impregnated with the Character of their Species during its union with their ubtance, before a perfect, induration pres'd it forth; which Spirit lighting upon, and uniting to fit Matter, fixes and determines the ame to be of the ame Species, with the Mas from which it iu'd. For the common Opinion, That thee Stones are produc'd of a certain lime, compounded of Earth and Water, concocted and hardned by the action of Heat, is groundles; ince how temperate oever that Heat were, it would at length diipate all the moiture, and leave nothing but the Earth, the darket and mot friable of all the Elements; beides that, Water and Earth, having no vicoity, are incapable of any continuity and hardnes, which aries from Salt, which indu'd with a Principle of Coagulation, perfectly unites the Water with the Earth, o as not to be afterwards diolvable by any Water, but uch as is mix'd with much Salt. Latly, the Cement they make with Lime, Water, and Sand, petrifying in time, hews the neceity of the fix'd Salt of Lime, (which gives the coherence of all) in the generation of Stones. Wherefore I conclude, that as in common and opake Stones, there is a little Salt amongt much Earth; o in thoe which are precious, there is much Salt amongt a very mall quantity of Earth.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXVII. Of the Generation of Metals.
div.p:
MEtal, which is a Mineral, olid, opake, heavy, malleable, ductile, and ounding body, is compounded either by Nature, Art, or Chance, as, Latin, Electrum, and Corinthian Bras; or ele it is imple, and divided into even Species, according to the number of Planets, whereunto each of them is referr'd, as precious Stones are to the Fixed Starrs; namely, Gold, Silver, Lead, Copper, Iron, Tinn; and Quick-ilver, which others reject, from the number of Metals, becaue not malleable; as alo Tinn, becaue compounded of Lead and Silver. Their remote Matter is much Water with little Earth; their next, according to Aritotle, a vaporous exhalation. Their general Efficient Caue is Heaven, by its Motion and Influencess producing Heat, which attenuates and concocts the aid Exhalation, which is afterwards
condens'd by Cold: Hence all Metals are melted by violent Fire, which evaporates Quick-ilver, and oftens that ort of Iron which is not fuible. The place where they are generated is the boome of the Earth; the Metals found in Waters, as Gold in Tagus and Pactolus, having been carry'd from the Earth by the Waters; which wahing and purifying them, render them more perfect than thoe of the Mines.

The Second aid, Although Metals were generated at the beginning of the world in their Mines, whence they were firt extracted and wrought by Tubalcain, who is the fabulous Vulcan of Paganim; yet they ceae not to be generated anew by the afflux of utable Matter, which is a metallick Juice form'd of humidity, not imply aqueous, (for then Heat hould evaporate intead of concocting it) but vicous, unctuous, and omewhat terretrial, which for a long time holds out againt whatever violent Heat, as appears by the Fires of Volcanoes, which are maintain'd by Bitumen alone, and other ulphureous Earths. This alo is the Opinion of the Chymits, when they compound them of Sulphur and Mercury; Sulphur holding the place of the Male Seed, and Mercury, which is more crude and aqueous, that of the maternal blood. And as the Salt or Earth predominating in Stones is the caue of their friability; o Sulphur and Mercury, which is unctuous moiture, renders them malleable and capable of extenion; which is an Argument of their perfection, as well as colour, ound, and fixation, or enduring Fire without alteration, but not weight; for then as Gold, the perfectet Metal, is the heaviet, o Silver hould be next to it in weight, which is not; Quick-ilver being much more ponderous; next, Lead; after which follow Silver, Copper, Tinn, Iron, and Stones, whoe weight is very different. Whence it appears, that Gravity is not an Effect of the condenation of Matter; otherwie the Starrs being the dener parts of their Orbs hould be heavy, as they are not; but it proceeds from the Form, whereunto alo the many wonderful Effects oberv'd in Metals mut be referr'd; as that Gold dicovers Poyons, attracts Quick-ilver, and is attracted by the Foot of a Spar-hawk, and lov'd by Gryphons, as Iron is by Etriches, who diget it; that Tinn makes all Metals brittle where-with it is mixt, Copper inks not in the water of the Iland Demoneus, near Carthage; and that Quick-ilver, though humid, and alwayes fluid, moitens not; which ome attribute to the equal mixture of iccity and humidity.

The Third aid, If ever the Opinion of Anaxagoras (who held, Omnia in omnibus) was well grounded, it was chiefly in reference to Metals, whoe Etymology, together with the Chymits operations, peak the eaie tranmutation of one into another; imperfect Metals differing onely in certain accidental degrees from Gold and Silver, which they may be turn'd into after purifying from their Leproie, and refining by Nature or
Art. And thus according to the opinion of ome Moderns, it may be aid, that, uppoing the earth a great Magnet, it hath alo in it elf a commencement towards uch metallick mutation, ince the Loadtone is in a manner the principle of Iron, the mot terretrial of all Metals; whence it is that they attract one another, as do Mercury and Gold, which is compos'd thereof. And thus by the power of heat in the bowels of the Earth, Iron the mot imperfect and lightet of all Metals is turned into Steel and Copper, afterwards into Tin, and latly, being more depurated into Silver and Gold. And ince Art imitates Nature as in the fabricating of Artificial Gold you mut firt reolve a olid matter, then volatilize, and again fix and return into a olid ubtance; o the generation of Metals may be conceiv'd to be effected by evaporation of the thinner parts of Earth and Water, which being volatilized by the ubterranean heat, and lighting upon Rocks and hard Stones, are there fixed and condened into Metals differing according to the purity and concoction of their matter, and the places it lights upon, which are ordinarily Mountains.

The Fourth aid, That the different properties of Metals plainly argue the diverity of their Species; ince Properties preuppoe pecificating Forms. Beides, the World would have been very defective, if Nature had made only Gold, which may be better pared than Iron and Steel, and is les hard for ues of Life. Nor is it likely that Nature ever intended to reduce all Metals to Gold; which then hould be more plentiful than Iron and Lead; ince wie and potent Nature eldom fails of her intentions: As for the alledged tranmutation of Metals, were it poible, yet it proves them not all of the ame Species, change of Species being very ordinary, and as eaie to be made in Crucibles as in Mines; nothing ele being neceary thereunto but to open the bodies of the Metals, and et at liberty what in ome is mot active, and in others more uceptible of the Forms you would introduce. Nature indeed always intends what is mot perfect, but not to reduce every thing to one mot perfect Species, as all Metals to Gold; but to make a mot perfect individual in every Species; labouring with no les atisfaction for production of Iron and Flints then of Gold and precious Stones. As for the principles of Metals, all compound them of Mercury and Sulphur, joyning Vitriols thereunto intead of alt to give Body to the aid Ingredients; but ome will have Mercury to be the ole matter, and undertand by ulphur an internal and central heat in the Mercury concocting its crudity, and by Mercury the cruder portion of its elf; their Salt being only the conitence whereof the Mercury is capable after Coction. Others ditinguih what is metallick in metals (as only Mercury is) from the impurities mixt therewith, as earths, ulphurs, and Vitriols; and make the perfect metals o homogeneous that 'tis impoible to eparate any
thing from them; which is a proof (they ay) of the unity of their matter and conformity with Mercury, which always retains its own nature, though preparations make it appear in everal hapes. Moreover, they inferr from the great ponderoity of Gold, that it is only Mercury; otherwie the les heavy bodies pretended to be mixt therewith, hould diminih its weight; and Fuion, which eems to reduce all metals into their mot natural tate, makes them perfectly reemble Mercury, in which alone the Chymits for that reaon eek their Great Work. Nevertheles eeing Experience teaches us, that Mercurie's ulphurs and vitriols are found in all metals except Gold, it mut be confes'd that thee three bodies are their immediate principles. Nor doth it follow that they are not in Gold too, though the Chymits have not yet been able to find them, but o cloely united as to be ineparable; Coction having uch power upon matters that have affinity, as to unite them beyond poibility of eparation; as appears in Glas, of which nothing ele can be made but Glas, though it be compos'd of different principles, and in Mercury it elf, which is a Mixt, but reduc'd to uch homogeneity that nothing can be extracted out of it but Mercury. Indeed Gold could not be o malleable us it is, if it were all Mercury; and they that know Mercury, and the impoibility of depriving it of the pronenes to revive, will not eaily believe it can, without mixture of ome other body, acquire the form of Gold; whoe gravity proceeds from its proper Form, and not from Mercury which can give it no more weight then it elf hath; Gold by being more dene, not acquiring more gravity, any more then Ice doth which wims upon the water.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXVIII. Whether there be an Elementary Fire, other than the Sun.
div.p:
AS there are three imple bodies in the world, poeing, by right of Soveraignty, Drines, Cold, and Moiture; o there mut be one primely Hot, which they call Fire. The diverities of Motion, the four firt Qualities, and their poible Combinations, the Humours, Temperaments, Ages, and Seaons, the Compoition and Reolution of all Mixts, are powerful inductions for that quaternary number of Elements. Amongt which there is none controverted but Fire; the variety of fires found in the world rendring it dubious which of them ought to be acknowledg'd the Element, that is, the natural, imple, firt hot and dry body, wherewith, together with the other, three all Mixts are compounded. The Sun indeed is the Efficient Caue of all productions here below; but being a celetial and incorruptible body cannot enter into the compoition of any thing as
a Material Caue. Much les can our common Fire which devours every thing, and continually detroyes its Subject. But it mut be that Elementary Fire, which is every where potentially and actually in its own Sphere, which is above that of the Air, and below that of the Moon. Moreover, being the lightet or leat heavy of all the Elements, the Harmony of the Univere which conits chiefly in their ituation; requires that it be in the highet place, towards which therefore all other Fires which are of the ame Nature, acend in a point with the ame violence that a tone decends towards its Centre; thoe remaining here below, being detain'd by ome Matter whereof they have need, by reaon of the contraries environing them; from which that Sublunary Fire being exempt, hath nothing to do with Matter or nourihment; and by reaon of its great rarity and tenuity, can neither burn nor heat, any more then it can be perceiv'd by us.

The Second aid, That ubtlety, one of the principal conditions requiite to the converion of Matter into Fire, is o far from hindring, that it encreaes the violence and activity of Fire, making it penetrate even the olidet bodies; whence that pretended Fire, not being mixt with extraneous things to allay its heat, as that of Aqua Vitae is temper'd by its Phlegm or aqueous humidity, but being all Fire in its own Sphere and natural (place, which heightens the Virtue and qualities of all Agents) mut there alo heat, hine, burn, and produce all its Actions, which depend not upon denity or rarity, or uch other accidents of Matter purely paive, but upon its whole Form; which contituting it what it is, mut alo make it produce Effects utable to its Nature. Wherefore as Water condens'd into Ice or Crytal, is no longer Water, becaue it hath ceas'd to refrigerate and moiten; o the Fire pretended to be above the Air, inviible and inenible, by reaon of its rarity, is not Fire but ubtile Air. They who ay its natural inclination to heat and burn, is retrain'd by the Influences of the Heavens, particularly, of the cold Starrs, as Saturn and the Moon, peak with as little ground; ince the circular motion of the Heavens, whereby this Fire is turn'd about, hould rather increae than diminih its heat; And beides, Fire being a neceary Agent, its action can no more be hindred by uch Influences, than the decent of a tone downwards. Whereunto add, that the beams of all Stars have heat; and were any cold, yet thoe of Saturn are too remote, and thoe of the Moon too weak in comparion of this Fire, the extent whereof is about 90000. Leagues, for the ditance between the Earth and the Moon is almot as much, namely, 56. Semidiameters of the Earth, from which ubtracting between 25. and 30. Leagues, which they allot to the three Regions of the Air, the ret mut be occupy'd by the Fire, which they make to extend from the Concave urface of the Moon, to the convex urface of the Air; which it would conume in les than a moment, conidering the
great diproportion between them. Moreover, were there uch a Fire, it could not be own'd an Element, becaue its levity would keep it from decending and entring into the Compoition of mixts; and, were it not leight, yet it would be hindred from decending by the extream coldnes of the Middle Region of the Air, accounted by ome, a barrier to the violence of that Chymerical Fire, which ought rather to be reckon'd amongt their Entia Rationis, than the Natural Elements, whereunto Corporeity and Palpability are requiite. For thee Reaons, I conceive, with Pythagoras, that the Sun is the true Elementary Fire, plac'd for that purpoe in the middle of the World, whoe Light and Heat enter into the Compoition not onely of all living things, but alo of Stones and Metals; all other Heat beides that of the Sun, being detructive, and conequently, no-wie fit for Generation.

The Third aid, He confounds Heaven with Earth, and detroyes the Nature of the Sun, who takes it for an Element, that is to ay, a thing alterable and corruptible by its contraries, which it mut have if it be an Element. The Heat of his beams proves it not the Elementary Fire, eeing commonly the nearer we are to Fire, the more we feel the Heat of it; but the Supream and Middle Regions of the Air, are colder than ours. Beides, were our common fire deriv'd from the Sun, it would not languih, as it doth, when the Sun hines upon it; nor would the heat of dunghils and caves be greater in Winter than in Summer. Wherefore I rather embrace the common Opinion, which holds, That the heaviet Element is in the lowet place, and the leightet in the highet, whoe Action is hindred by the proportion requiite to the quantity of each Element.

The Fourth aid, That the qualities of Fire, viz. Heat, Drynes, and Light, concurring in the Sun in a upream degree, argue it the Elementary Fire; for Light being the Caue of Heat, the Sun (which is the prime Luminous Body) mut alo be the prime Hot, that is to ay, Fire. For as the pretended one above the Air, was never yet dicover'd; o 'tis repugnant to the Order of the Univere, for the leightet of Elements to be hut up in the Centre of the Earth, where ome place it. We have but two wayes to know things, Sene, and Reaon; the latter of which, is founded either upon Caues or Effects: Now we know nothing of the Sun, or any other Celetial Bodies, otherwie then by its Effects and enible qualities, which being united in Spherical Burning-glaes, (as they are in the body of the Sun) notifie to us by their Effects the Nature of their Caue.

The Fifth aid. That Fire being to the World what the Soul is to the Body, as Life is in all the parts of the Body; o alo is Fire equally diffued throughout the whole World. In the Air it makes Comets, and other Igneous Meteors: In the Earth it concocts Metals, and appears plentifully in Volcanoes, whoe
Fires would not continue alwayes, if they were violently detained in thoe Concavities; yea, 'tis in the Waters too, whoe altnes and production of Monters, cannot be without Heat. Yet being the mot active of all Elements, it is therefore ditributed in much les quantity than the ret; Nature having oberved the ame proportion both in the greater and leer World, Man's Body; in which there is les of Fire than of the other Elements: Otherwie, had the Fire been equal to the ret, it would conume all living things to ahes. Nevertheles as the fixed Heat of Animals requires reparation by the Influent Heat from the Heart, the Soul's principal eat; in like manner the Elementary Fire, dipered in all part of this great body of the World, needs the Influence of the Sun's Rayes, which produce and conerve it.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXXXIX. Which is mot deirable, long or hort Life.
div.p: NAture, not contented to produce all things, hath given them a deire of Self-preervation. Even Inanimate Bodies redouble their activity at the approach of their detructive contraries; whence proceeds Antiperitais. But this deire appears chiefly in Animals, and above all in Man, being grounded upon the Love he bears to himelf: Which extream Love, intigating him to eek all good things contributary to his contentment, makes him likewie deire long Life, whereby he may continue his other enjoyments, and, conequently, avoid all occaions of Death, as that which interrupts the coure of this Life, and makes him ceae to be. Hence, as by general conent Death is the mot terrible of terribles; o, by the reaon of Contraries, Life is the mot agreable, and conequently, mot deirable and bet thing in the World; and not deirable only by all Men who are endued with Knowledg, but alo by all living things, each after its mode, and according as they are capable of deiring; Plants attracting their nourihment, and Animals eeking their Food with difficulty, and carefully avoiding all dangers that lead to Death. For though Nature loves change, (whereof he is the Principle) yet 'tis onely that of Generation, or of a les into a more noble ubtance; that of Corruption and Death he abhorrs, being not further pleaed in the viciitudes of mutations, than he gains by the change; but he is a loer by Death, which eparates the Body from the Soul, in the union whereof, he hath all that he can wih. She may diguie her elf, and changing of hape and countenance, but can never light upon any more agreable, than that which he makes appear in the Marriage of a Body with a Soul; which are o perfectly united, that, after their diolution, our Souls alwayes retain an Inclination toward their ancient Mates which they once animated.

The Second aid, If the entiment of Nature makes us conceive long Life deirable; Reaon, which evinceth it full of Mieries and Calamities, teaches us that the hortet is bet, and that we may jutly wih, either never to have been, or to have dy'd as oon as we came into the World. This was the Judgement not onely of the greatet Sages of Pagan Antiquity, many of whom cheerfully quitted Life to ecape its Mieries; but the ometimes famous Republick of Mareilles, gave Licence to the mierable to take Poyon, which was kept in a publick Store. Yea, even the holiet Peronages have been of the ame Advice; as Job amongt others, who calls Man's Life a warfare upon Earth, and cures the day of his Birth; Moes and Elias, who pray'd to God they might dye; and Saint Paul, who deires nothing o much as to be loos'd from this mierable Body; in which, as in a dark prion, the Reaonable Soul is enclos'd, and remains againt, its will; ince being of a Celetial Nature, and o continually longing after the place of its extraction, Death, which delivers it from its fetters, mut be as deirable to it as contrary to the Body, which having nought to hope for after this Life, but to be the food of worms and corruption, hath all reaon to dread it, and avoid the occaions of it; as accordingly all uch do who live onely for the Body, reenting no other motions in themelves but of deire to live long. Whereas Reaon intructs us, that here we never poes the Good whereof the Immortal Soul is capable by its two Powers, the Undertanding and the Will, which never find any Truth or Goodnes in the things of this World but what is ophiticate; it makes us alo conceive Life as a violent tate, and contrary to the Felicity of our better part.

The Third aid, Since Life is the duration of Being, which undoubtedly is the greatet of all Goods, (Entity and Good being convertible) that mut be the mot deirable which is of greatet continuance, becaue it comes nearet infinity and eternity, under which all Perfection is compris'd, and which being therefore paionately deir'd by all Men, but not attainable by any, they endeavor to partake as much of it as they can by prolongation of Life, which is the foundation not onely of the Goods of the Body and Fortune, (whoe weetnes makes amends for ome Evils of Life) but alo of the Mind, in which Natural Felicity conits; whereunto amongt other conditions, long Life is requiite both for attaining of Knowledge and Virtue, not to be gotten without long time, (which renders Men knowing and prudent) as for making others tate the fruits of an exemplary Life.

The Fourth aid, That Beats and even Stones having the good of Exitence as well as we, that alone is not ufficient to render Life deirable, in regard Non-exitence is much rather to be wiht than a Being alwayes mierable, what ever ome ay to the contrary; ince even our Saviour aith, It had been better for
Judas never to have been born, then to have fallen into the crime of Treaon. Moreover, Seneca aith, No peron would accept of Life, if he knew how dear it mut cot him. Hence we enter into the World weeping, as if it were againt our conent; and as our Lives begin with tears, o they are continu'd with labor, and ended with pain. Nor have we more reaon to deire long Life for the Goods of the Mind, which conit in Virtue alone. For if we be vicious, 'tis expedient both for our elves and the Publick, that we live but little, for fear of corrupting others by our evil Examples, If virtuous, 'tis much to be fear'd let we be corrupted by the convere of the wicked, who are very numerous; which was the caue why God by a pecial favour took away Enoch in the midt of the coure of his Life, and tranported him into the Terretrial Paradie.

The fifth aid, If a long Life were les deirable than a hort, God hould have deceiv'd thoe that honour their Parents, by promiing them a bad alary in recompence of a good Action: Nor ought Phyick to trouble it elf and thoe that ue it, by o many Rules and Receipts, were a hort Life (that is to ay, a peedy death) o deirable; nor would the Laws punih Criminals with Death, if what they give them were better than what they take from them. Moreover, as the long-liv'd Oak and Palm-Tree are more excellent than the Muhrome, Hyop, and the Roe; Stags, Elephants, Eagles, Ravens, and the Phoenix more perfect than Butterflies, and thoe Inects which they call Ephemera, becaue they live but one day; o amongt Men, thoe that live long, eem to have ome advantage above thoe that are of a hort Life, having the Principles of their Generation more vigorous: wherein nevertheles the Sex, Temperament, Climate, Habitation, and manner of living, make a notable difference; Sanguine Men, and the Inhabitants of Temperate Regions, commonly living longer than Women, cholerick Perons, and uch as live under intemperate Climates.

The Sixth aid, Reaon having been given Man to correct the Inclinations of the Senitive Appetite, 'tis that alone mut judge whether it be expedient for him to live long; not Sene, which makes us judge like beats, That nothing is dearer than Life. But Reaon, illuminated either by Faith or by Philoophy, teaches us that this World is the place of our banihment, the Body the Soul's Prion which he alwayes carryes about with her, Life a continual uffering and War; and therefore he fights againt Natural Light who maintaines it expedient to prolong o mierable a State. For, beides the incommodities attending a long Life, which after 70. years, as David tetifies, is onely labour and orrow, long Life is equally unprofitable towards attaining Knowlege and Virtue. He that lives long can learn nothing new in the World, which is but a Revolution and Repetition of the ame Effects produc'd alwayes by the ame Caues; not onely in Nature, whoe coure and changes may be
een in the Revolution of the Four Seaons of the Year, but even in Affairs of State and Private Matters, wherein nothing is aid or done, but what hath been practis'd before. And as for Virtue, the further we are from Childhod, the les Innocence and Sanctity we have, and Vices ordinarily increae with years. The long Life of the firt Men having according to ome been the probable Caue of the depravation of thoe Ages.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXL. Of the Lethargy.
div.p:
AS the Brain is the mot eminent and noble of all the parts, being the Seat of the Undertanding, and the Throne of the Reaonable Soul, o its dieaes are very coniderable; and the more, in that they do not attaque that alone, but are communicated to all the other parts, which have a notable interet in the offence of their Chief, ceaing to diffue its Animal Spirits detinated to Motion, Sene, and the Function of the Inferior Members. Which Functions are hurt by the Lethargy, which deprives a Man of every other Inclination but that to leep, and renders him o forgetful and lothful, (whence it took its Greek name, which ignifies luggih oblivion) that he remembers nothing at all, being poes'd with uch contumacious leepines that he huts his Eyes as oon as he ha's open'd them; beides that, his Phanie and Reaoning is hurt with a continual gentle Fever. Which differences this Symptom from both the leeping and waking Coma, call'd, Typhomania: the former of which commonly begins in the Fits of Fevers, and ends or diminihes at their declination, but the Lethargick leeps oundly, and being wak'd by force, preently falls a leep again: The latter makes the Patient inclin'd to leep, but he cannot, by reaon of the variety of Species repreented to him in his Phanie. The ignes of this Malady are deliration, heavines of the Head, and pain of the Neck after waking, (the Matter taking its coure along the pine of the back), frequent ocitation, trembling of the Hands and Head, a palih Complexion, Eyes and Face pufft up, weatings, troubled Urine, like that of Cattle, a great Pule, languihing and fluctuating, Repiration rare with ighing, and o great forgetfulnes, as ometimes not to remember to hut their Mouths after they have open'd, nor even to take breath, were they not forc'd to it by the danger of uffocation. The Conjunct and next Caue of this Malady is a putrid Phlegm, whoe natural coldnes moitens and refrigerates the Brain, whilt its put refactive heat kindles a Fever by the vapors carry'd from the Brain to the Heart, and from thence about the whole. Now this Phlegmatick Humor is not detained in the Ventricles of the
Brain; for then it would caue an Apoplexy if the obtruction were total, and if partial an Epilepie, wherein the Nerves contract themelves towards their original for dicharging of that Matter: But 'tis onely in the inuoities and folds of the Brain, which imbibing that exceive humidity, acquires a cold and moit intemperature; from whence proceeds dulnes and litelenes to all Actions. For as Heat is the Principle of Motion, epecially when quickned by Drynes; o is Cold the Caue of tupidity and luggihnes, epecially when accompanied with humidity, which relaxes the parts, and chills their Action. In like manner, Heat or Drynes inflaming our Spirits the Tunicles of the Brain, produce the irregular Motions of Frenzy, which is quite contrary to the Lethargy; although it produce the ame ometimes, namely, when the Brain after great evacuations acquires a cold and moit intemperature; in which cae the Lethargy is incurable, becaue it tetifies Leion of the Faculty, and abolition of trength: But on the contrary, a Frenie after a Lethargy is a good ign, reolving by its Heat, and diipating the cold humors which produce the ame.

The Second aid, That coldnes being contrary to put refaction, Phlegm the coldet of all humors, cannot eaily putrifie in the Brain, (which is cold too of its own nature) much les acquire a Heat ufficient to communicate it elf to the Heart, and there excite a Fever; it being more likely for uch adventitious Heat to caue in the Brain rather the impetuous motions of a Frenzy, than the dulnes and languor of a Lethargy. Nor is it les then aburd, to place two enemy-qualities in the ame Subject, to wit, Cold and Heat, whereof the one caues leep, the other a Fever; which, I conceive, to precede not to follow the Lethargy, and which having raied from the Hypochondres to the Brain, a Phlegmatick blood mixt with gros vapors, there caueth that obcuration of Reaon, and luggihnes of the whole Body, but epecially the abolition of the Memory, the utable temperament for which is totally detroyed by exceive humidity. Indeed the troubled Urine, liquid Digetions, Tumors and pains of the Neck, bloated Fleh, and other uch igns accompanying this dieae, argue that its matter is more in the ret of the Body than in the Brain, which uffers onely by Sympathie.

The Third aid, If it be true that leep is the Brother of Death, then the Lethargy, which is a continual drowines, with a Fever and Delirium, eemes to be a middle Etate between Life and Death which is known by the ceation of Actions, mot of which fail in thoe afflicted with this Evil, which nevertheles is les then the Carus, wherein the leep is o profound, that the Patient feels not when he is prickt, or call'd by name; but is depriv'd of all Sene and Motion, aving that of Repiration, which carce appears in the Catoche, or Catalepie, (a tranger ymptom than any of the former) wherein the Eyes remain wide open, the
whole Body tiff, and in the ame tate and poture wherein it hapned to be when it firt eiz'd the ame. The Caue whereof, mot ay, is a cold and moit humor, obtructing the hinder part of the Brain; but I rather acribe it to a udden Congelation of the Animal Spirits, as I do the Lethargy to narcotick and omniferous vapors, which are the ole Caues of Inclination to leep; which cannot be produced by imple, cold, and aqueous humidity, (for then Water hould do it ooner than Wine, whoe very mell in Prees and Cellars caues leep, and oftentimes inebriates) but by a fat and oleaginous humidity, uch as is found in all Hypnoticks; ome whereof are hot, as Anie and Opium; others Cold, as Lettice, Poppy, and Henbane.

The Fourth aid, That the Brain being the Principal of Sene and Arbitrary Motion, which it derives into all the parts, both the one and the other are offended by the maladies of that part; ome whereof are without, others, are necearily accompanyed with a Fever: which is either Acute or Gentle, according to the diverity of the humor producing it, the former commonly proceeding from Choler or Blood, the latter from Phlegm or Melancholy. Amongt thee Dieaes, thoe which invade uddenly, as the Apoplexy and Convulions, are caued by the obtruction of the Ventricles, Contriction, or Diviion of the Nerves, which hinders the Flux of the Animal Spirits: but thoe which arruire in ome pace of time, as the Coma, Lethargy, and Carus, proceed either from a imple intempeires, ordinarily Cold and Moit, or ele joyn'd with ome Matter, which is oftentimes a Cold Phlegm, whereof the Brain is fruitful: Which coming to be inflamed, by reaon of its putrefaction caued by defect of Tranpiration, and the Heat of the Brain (which though Cold by its firt Temper, is yet hot, inamuch as animated, and more burning than the Air of Sommer) that Extraneous Heat begets a Fever, which yet is but little violent, and o hinders not the Natural Coldnes of the humor from producing the leep and luggihnes apparent in the Lethargy; which nevertheles by is, Hippocrates, plac'd amongt Acute Dieaes terminated on the eventh day; which time if it exceeds, the Patient recovers, epecially if the Matter happen to be dicharged into the Bret, and caue an Empyema there, or, in ome others, the Parotides.

The Fifth aid, That the Internal Maladies of the Head are of three forts: Some attaque the Membranes, and caue the Cephallagy, Megrim, and other pains of the Head, being very dolorous, by reaon of the exquiite enibility of thoe Membranes, which are either prickt, pres'd, or too much extended by vapors, wind, or humors, for the mot part acrimonious and erous. Others are in the Cavities and Paages of the Animal Spirits, whoe Influence being topt by ome Matter that obtruct the Paages, they caue the ymptoms of the Leion of Motion and Sene in the Vertigo, Palie, Apoplexy, Epilepie,
Incubus, Convulions, Trembling, and Catarrhs or Defluxions, to which Man alone of all Animals is ubject, by reaon of the quantity of excrements where-with his larger and more elevated Brain abounds: The third ort which poes the whole ubtance of the Brain, and either onely deprave the functions of the three Prime Faculties, Reaon, Imagination and Memory, are the imple Delirium, the Frenzy, Melancholy, Madnes, and Lycanthropy; or ele wholly abolih them, as in Folly, Stupidity, Forgetfulnes, the Catoche, Carus, and Lethargy, which is caus'd not onely by a Cold Aqueous Phlegm, where-with the Brain is oak'd, but alo by uch as is render'd vicous, thick, and tough, by the ubtance of the trange and ome extraneous heat, which caueth the Putrefaction and Fever.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLI. Whether it be better to marry, or not to marry.
div.p:
IF Nature made the Crytalline humor of the Eye without colour, the Tongue without avour, the Ear without ound, to the end they might impartially judge of all Objects offer'd to thoe Senes; I know not to whoe judgement we mut referr the Deciion of this Quetion: Virgins, marry'd people, and thoe that are not marry'd, being equally intereed, and conequently, lyable to exception. The firt, profeing Hatred of Marriage; The econd, unwilling to blame it, for fear of affronting their pas'd Judgement; And the Third, being unfit to judge thereof for want of Experience. If we will credit Cato, who had try'd it, and who being one day ollicited by his Friends to econd Nuptials, told them, He had once been deliver'd from Shipwrack, and therefore car'd not for venturing to Sea again; thoe that never embarque in Marriage will gain the Caue, it being the highet point of Humane Prudence to be wie at the expene of others, whoe example makes them jutly fear the inconvenienes of a Contract, o diadvantageous to the freedom of Man, as that of Marriage is, wherein there is this peculiarity, that in all other Contracts, ever one party is a gainer; but here both are oftentimes cheated, almot alwayes dicontented with the bargain, and willing to retract, if they had liberty, which hath been retrencht everince the Law of Divorce was abrogated by that of Grace, for the greater mortifying of Men, and teaching them to uffer and igh, in atisfaction for their ins, under the heavy yoke of Marriage. Beides that, the Friendhip o much boated therein, is o rare, as to be almot impoble; partly, becaue the Will is never carry'd to love an Object but by its full Liberty, and loves les upon never o little contraint; and partly, becaue Convere hews the Marry'd Couple
one another's defects, which being alwayes more then their Virtues, 'tis no wonder if Hatred arie thereupon more frequently than Amity, whatever artifice be us'd to make hew of the contrary.

The Second aid, He mut be a Mianthropus, and have wholly renounc'd all Humane Sentiments that can blame Marriage, the mot honourable and ancient Society of the World, founded not onely upon the Divine Law, (which makes it a Sacrament, and a very great Mytery) and upon that of Nations, by whoe univeral Conent, it hath been honor'd with great Priviledges and Immunities; as on the contrary, Celibacy hath been publickly dicountenanc'd and punih'd: but alo upon that of Nature, who hath inpir'd into all Animals a deire of joyning and coupling together for Generation of their like; which deire is greater in Men, inamuch as he apires to Immortality, no otherwie attainable in this World but by Marriage, which revives him in his Children. And the pleaure of them too is o great, that he mut firt be a Father that would conceive what it is; nor is the yoke of Marriage inupportable, except to uch as deire to live diolutely. The Amity ariing thereupon, if founded upon Virtue and Honor, not upon Beauty, or uch other profitable or delightful Good, differs as much from Love, as the continual temperate heat of the Blood and Spirits doth from its ebullition and ditemper; being alwayes augmented by mutual Offices of either party, rendred with a franknes and confidence not found in any other condition whatoever, where there is nothing ele but Diimulation and Hypocriie. 'Tis in Marriage alone that there is any treating with Liberty and Ingenuity; and therefore that State is to be deir'd, not onely by the mierable for Conolation of their Afflictions, but alo by thoe who are happy for communicating their Felicity, which is tedious when it hath no partakers.

The Third aid, Our Life is full enough of mieries, without needing addition of thoe that commonly attend Marriage; which a Philoopher, who had triy'd it, aid, hath but two good dayes; the firt, when there is nothing but laughing; and the lat, which delivers us from that ad lavery; perfectly contrary both to liberty and quiet, (the two greatet Goods a wie Man can enjoy in this Life) which are inconitent with the turmoil of Houwifrie, and the Cares of Marriage, from which therefore the Brachmans, Gymnoophits, Galli, and Vetals, and at this day, uch as are devoted to God's Service, have been exempted, to the end the better to mind Contemplation and Virtuous Exercies; both hard to be done in Marriage, wherein carce any other Virtue is practis'd but Patience, (whereof 'tis the true School) which Socrates aid, He had learnt better by the colding of his Wife, than by all the Precepts of the Philoophers.

The Fourth aid, Men would be Vagrants and Stragglers like
wild Beats, were it not for Marriage, which is the foundation of the State; for it makes Families, and Families make Common-wealths; which, conequently, owe their Nativity and increae to marry'd people, who have a much greater interet in the Conervation of the State, than thoe that have neither Houe nor Home, as unmarry'd Men eldom have. But as there is no compleat Good in this World; o Marriage, though a mot holy and good thing in it elf, intituted by God in Paradie, and during the tate of Innocence, hath nevertheles its incommodities, not o much from it elf, as from the fault of the perons who know not how to ue it as they ought.

The Fifth aid, 'Tis peculiar to Marriage to have nothing mall or moderate; every thing in it is extream. 'Tis either full of weetnes and Affection, or of Hatred and bitternes; 'tis either a Paradie, or a Hell. When 'tis uted with all Conditions requiite, there's no tate happier; but when any is wanting, no Infelicity equals it. And becaue Good requires the integrity of all its contituent parts, but Evil comes from the leat defect; 'tis no wonder that few or no Marriages are happy, ince there is none wherein there is not omething to be wiht for, epecially when the match is made, (as mot commonly 'tis) by another's Hand; though 'tis trange, that Men who are o circumpect and wary in other bargains, earching, examining, and taking Eay of what they buy, hould have o little Prudence in an Affair of uch Conequence and Danger. There is nothing but a Wife that a Man is oblig'd to keep as long as he lives; but they have been taken at a venture, ince, at the intance of the Roman Dames, the Law of Ancus Martius was aboliht, who had purpoely built a Temple to Male-Fortune near the Tyber, where Women were carefully examin'd. And as tis an intolerable madnes to engage voluntarily into fetters and a perpetual Prion, by ubjecting one's elf to the Caprichio of a Woman; o 'tis great implicity in a Man to entrut his Honor, the chiefet of all Goods, to her incontant humor, who may render us infamous when the Phanie takes her. I think therefore, every one ought to conult himelf, Whether it be fit for him to marry or not, that is, Whether he believes he ha's Virtue and Contancy enough to uffer the defects of a Woman, who may be commendable in ome Point, but at the bottom is alwayes a Woman.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLII. At what time the Rational Soul is infus'd.
div.p: AS Religion obliges us to believe, that the Soul, which is of an Immortal Nature, comes immediately from God, who drawing it out of the Abye of Nothing, at the ame time creates it in the Infuing, and infues it in the Creating; o nothing is determin'd abolutely touching the time in which that infuion is made. For knowing which, we mut oberve that the whole time of the Child's reiding in the Womb, is divided into four parts; namely, the Conception, Conformation, Motion, and Parturition; o ditinguihed between themelves, that the time of Motion, is about treble to that of Conformation; and the time of Parturition, double to that of Motion. The whole work of Conformation is divided again into four times, according to which the Matter contained is diverly fahioned and wrought, and is called Geniture, or Coagulated Milk, Foetus, Embryo; and an Infant when the Conformation of the parts is finihed, which is at the thirtieth day for Boyes, and at the forty econd for Girles; whoe les Heat and more waterih materials, require a longer time for Conformation of their Spermatick parts: After which the Blood arriving, fills the void paces of the Mucles, Fibres, and other carnous parts, which are not perfectly haped till towards the time of Motion, which is the third month for Males, and the fourth for Females; at which time the Second Conformation ends, and the whole organization is compleated. At firt, the Infant hath onely a Vegetative Life, by means of which, his parts are generated by the Alteration and Conformation of the Matter, and are nourihed, and take their growth not onely by their Attraction from all parts of the Matrix, but alo by an Internal Vital Principle, which is the Vegetative Soul, reiding in all fruitful eed, and being the ame with the Formative Faculty. Now becaue the Vegetative or Senitive Soul is but an accident, namely a certain Harmony of the Four Qualities, therefore they eaily give place upon the arrival of the reaonable oul, which I think happens when the organization of the parts is perfected, to wit, about the third or fourth month; before which time, the Body not being organized, cannot receive the Soul, (which is the act of an Organical Body) which alo he forakes, when, upon any notable olution of continuity, the Organs are detroyed and abolihed oftentimes, though the Temper of the imilary parts be not hurt; which conequently, is not the ole requiite for the Infuion of the Soul, but alo the convenient Fabrick of the Organs.

The Second aid, That the opinion, which introduces the Rational Soul in the firt days of Conception as oon as the matter
neceary for receiving it, begins to put on the diverity of Organs, is the mot probable; ince by this means this oul differs from others in that it proceeds and makes the dipoitions, whereas others follow the ame and abolutely depend thereupon. And the ame reaon which obliges us to acknowledg the Reaonable Soul after motion, contrains us to admit it before; which nothing hinders us from attributing to ome other caue, (as to the Senitive Soul introduc'd before the Rational) aving that caues are not to be multiplied without neceity, and one Soul alone may uffice for Sene, whilt yet the defect of Organs allow not the exercie of Reaon. The ame reaon hews how aburd it is to aign any other caue, in the firt days, of the Vegetative Actions; it being as eaie to infer the preence of the Reaonable Soul by this ort of actions as by the Senitive Actions, which may alo have another caue. For the infuion of the Reaonable Soul after forty days cannot be proved by actions proper to it (for it reaons not till long after) nor by the actions of a Soul imply; for then you mut grant that it is there before Organization, which is an action proper to animated things. Moreover, the Soul mut be admitted in the Body as oon as it may be there, which is at the beginning of conception; becaue even then there wants no fit dipoition to this Soul, which needs not any different Organs for the barely Vegetative Actions which he then performs, no more then Plants do; nor are different Organs neceary to her abolute exiting, ince God hath created her immaterial and without any dependance: and we ee the imilary parts of the Body are animated; o that the dipoitions wherewith the Soul can ubit, and which uffice to retain her in the Body, are alo ufficient to introduce her thereinto. Now thee dipoitions are no other then the ame which are requiite for the actions of the Vegetative Soul. For whatever indipoition happen to the Organs of Sene and Motion, the Soul abides in the Body till the heat be diipated or extinguihed; the Organs of Sene and Motion being not neceary to retain the Soul in the Body aving in as much as they contribute to repiration. Even the Apoplexie which abolihes all the noble dipoitions which the Philoophers hold neceary to the Soul, never drives her away unles it be by accident; ince a Child in his Mothers belly may have that dieae without incommodity, aving when it comes to need repiration. Now though Organization be not a dipoition requiite to the introduction of the Soul, yet he requires certain others, ome whereof we know not, as that unexplicable character imprinted in the Seed, beides the temperament which uffices perfectly to determine the matter for introdudion of this form and excluion of all other. The conformation of Organs being not a dipoition which determines necearily (eeing amongt humane bodies ome differ more from the generality of men in repect of the principal parts then they do from
certain other Animals) but 'tis the temperament alone, which ariing in the firt days after the mixture of the two eeds, and according to Hippocrates, the foetus having in the firt even days all that he ought to have, this opinion is more pious and expedient for repreing the criminal licene of thoe who without cruple procure abortion within the firt forty days.

The Third aid, Though the Reaonable Soul be of a much ublimer nature then the ouls of other Creatures; yet being created with reference to the Body 'tis not introduced thereinto till the ame be fitted for its reception; as no other natural form is ever received into a ubject not previously fitted with all due dipoitions. And ince the Soul is the principle of all actions, hence he needs Organs and Intruments for performing them; and the more ublime he is, the greater preparation doth he require then the Senitive Soul, as this alo doth then the Vegetative, which demands only a certain mixture of the firt qualities, beides which the enitive requires a more exquiite temperament of the two Principles of Generation, Seed and Blood, endued with a vital Spirit, capable of producing Sene and Motion. So that the Reaonable Soul ought not to be infued, till after the conformation is in all points completed.

The Fourth aid, Since there is no proportion but between things of the ame nature, the Immortal Reaonable Soul cannot have any with the corruptible Body, and o not depend more on the matter in its infuion then in its creation, which is probably the third day after conception; at which time the actions of life appear in nutrition, growth, alteration, and configuration of the parts. Which actions mut proceed from ome internal and animated principle; which cannot be the Soul either of Father or Mother, ince they act not where they are not inherently; nor yet the pirit of the Seed which is not a principal agent but only the intrument of a Soul; nor the formative vertue, which is only an accident or temper of qualities, and in like manner the intrument of ome more noble agent. 'Tis therefore the Soul contained in the boom of the matter, which produces all thee actions therein. They who hold the Reaonable Soul not introduced till after the two others, conider not that Forms receiving no degrees of more or les cannot be perfected or changed one into another, much les annihilated; eeing corruption is caued only by contraries, and Forms have none. It follows therefore that the Reaonable Soul is the principle of all thee functions; which he performs according to the dipoitions he meets with; and that he is the architect of her own habitation.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLIII. Of Metempychois, or Tranmigration of Souls.
div.p: THough Metemphychois, or the Tranmigration of Souls, be rather imaginary then true; yet becaue there is nothing which more inriches the Field of Philoophy then liberty of reaoning, we hall here inquire whether the Heathen, guided only by the light of Nature had any reaon to maintain this extravagance; which was firt taught in Greece by Pythagoras who had learn'd it of the Egyptians; by whom and mot other Nations of antiquity it was believ'd not only that ouls departed out of ome bodies re-entered and animated others, but alo that all things after a certain revolution of Ages hould reume the ame tate wherein they had formerly been. This was alo the opinion of Plato, aving that he was more rational then Pythagoras, who making three Souls of the ame quality, aid that thoe of men after death went to animate the bodies of Men, Beats, or Plants; for which reaon he abtained from the fleh of Animals, and could hardly reolve to eat Beans for fear of biting his Fathers head. But Plato held the Tranmigration of Rational Souls only into humane Bodies. Which opinion though les aburd then the former (which detroys it elf by the confuion it introduces amongt all natural beings) yet it hath its inconveniences too; ince the Soul being an incompleat form, making one whole with its other half the Body, it can never meet with one in all points like the firt; beides that, were it in another, it would have an inclination towards the firt, and o would not be in uch body in quality of a form, but in a tate of contraint and violence.

The Second aid, That the Pythagorical Metemphychois is not more aburd (in regard that being the form gives a determinate and pecifical being to every thing, if humane ouls pat into the bodies of Beats or Plants, thee Creatures would be Men;) then that of Plato eems probable: nothing hindring but that a humane oul may enter into another humane body after the diolution and ruine of the former. For if there be any thing to hinder it, it mut be becaue there is no return from privation to habit, That which hath ometimes been, can no more be uch as it was, and 'tis impoible for a oul which hath once informed a body to re-enter it again and there exercie the functions of life after having been once totally thence expelled. But thee Reaons hinder not, eeing the oul may be introduced anew into ome body wherein it is not now, but hath been formerly; as Gangraenous and wholly mortified members may be again vivified by a powerful effect of the oul and the goodnes of temperament. Moreover, it is not les poible for that
which never was to begin to be, then for that which hath formerly been to exit again in nature; eeing both being equally pure nothing, they are objects ufficient to be created by God; as the firt matter (which is almot nothing) is the object of Nature, his inferior; and natural bodies are the objects of Art which is below Nature. So that not only ouls, after having informed one body, may pas into an another by Metempychois, but (which eems more difficult) the ame oul may again inform the ame body.

The Third aid, 'Tis impoible for one and the ame thing which hath been to be a new; for then it hould be twice and have two durations, and conequently two exitences, and o not be one and the ame thing; eeing ingularity depends upon exitence. So neither can the ame oul return into the totally deerted body, although it may re-animate ome parcels of it, nor yet into other bodies. For in the firt place, as for the ouls of Plants and Beats, there is no more reaon to believe that thee forms diappearing upon detruction of the Organs whereby they exercie their functions, go to animate other bodies of the ame pecies, then that, when my wood is burnt, the ame form of fire goes to eek another faggot and kindle the ame as oon as fit dipoitions thereunto arie; if it were o, the Woodmongers hould have a very dangerous Trade.
