Moreover this tranmigration of ouls is either abolutely neceary (that is, bodies are animated no other way but this) and o there will be no other new generation, but the upernumerary ouls mut wait till their turn come, (according as the Platonick poet Virgil repreents them in the ixth Book of his Aeneis) for if there be more bodies then ouls, there will be no production, whatever dipoition be found in the matter; and then though we ow the Ground never o much with Corn, nothing will come of it, in cae more be own then there are Vegetative Souls to animate it; whence we hould be in great danger of Famine. As for the Reaonable Soul, ince there is no animated body whoe outward figure is not an Index of its inward form, were there uch a thing as Metempychois, the oul of a Hore hould be under the outward form of a Man, and o all knowledg from external hape hould be deceit and deluions, far from erving for Phyiogmony. Moreover the Ancients introduced this Opinion, partly to frighten the wicked, by making them believe that after death their ouls hould do penance in the bodies of Beats whoe manners they had imitated (Cowards becoming Hares, and cruel perons Wolves,) till after repurgation by the River Lethe they hould again become men; and partly to excite the good with hopes that their ouls hould be received into the bodies of Heroes and Demi-gods; uch fabulous tories erving to keep the more ignorant ort within their duty.

The Fourth aid, That the eparated oul carries along with
her, only three powers, the Undertanding, Will, and the Motive Faculty; by means whereof he is carried towards what he deires by a real local-motion, whereof he is as well capable without as within the body. Now he deires nothing o much as to be united to the body with whom he hath formerly been conjoyned. And conequently he cannot but return thither of her own accord; eeing when the deire and power meet the effect mut necearily follow, epecially when the deiring is in a violent tate, contrary to its own Nature, as that of the eparated Soul is; and therefore ince nothing violent is of long duration, the Soul's eparation from her Body cannot be perpetual.

The Fifth aid, If it be true that nothing is made which hath not already been, and that, according to Origen, there was a certain number of Souls produced in the beginning of the Creation, after which it is aid, That God reted from all his Works, and that he creates nothing ince he put the lat hand to the perfection of the World, (which it borrows from the forms or beauties which it contains) it may eem conentaneous to the ornament of the Univere, to ay that it was at firt tor'd with all the forms, where-with the Matter is informed, according as it comes to have fit dipoitions thereunto. And that thee forms having no contraries, and conequently being incorruptible, upon foraking their firt Subject, (through default of fit dipoitions to maintain them) are received into other Subjects, like the firt, and conequently, as capable of receiving uch form, which of it elf is indifferent to one Subject as well as to another; but ince the Rational Soul cannot have any particular Inclination towards the Body it formerly animated, which after Death being no longer Organical, nor capable of being o, but onely Dut and Ahes; 'tis more probable, that when eparated, it reents motions (if it have any) towards ome Body duly organized, and not yet furnihed with a form; there being (beides) les incovenience in aying that one and the ame Soul, can animate divers Bodies one after another, than that it can animate divers at the ame time, and in divers places, which nevertheles is the Opinion of mot Philoophers. For when it is eparated, it remains till an Act and a Form, capable of informing any ort of well dipoed Body, without affecting any in particular; into which it enters not ignorant, ince Knowledge follows Immaterality, and the Species and Notions being to the Soul, what accidents are to their Subjects from which they are ineparable, they mut accompany her where-ever he goes; although by reaon of the Clouds, and humidities of the Body which he informes, he is not actually knowing in Infancy, but onely proportionably, as in time the Body comes to be dried, and the humidities abumed, the Species which were ingraven in the Soul begin to appear, and as it were to be produced a new by Reminicence, which necearily follows Metempychois.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLIV. Whether there were braver Men in any preceding Age, than in the preent.
div.p: ALthough this Quetion, being rather of Fact than of Right, might bet be dicus'd, by comparing all the great Men of every Age between themelves, or thoe of each Age with ours; yet that way would be too long, by reaon of the great number of Illutrious Men who have flourih'd downwards to our Age, which is the fifty eventh ince the Creation of the World, (the duration whereof amounts to 5920. years, according to the mot probable Opinion, which reckons 3683. years and three months to the Nativity of our Lord) the Matter may alo be decided by Reaon, provided we lay aide two powerful Paions; the one proper to young Men, who alwayes value themelves above their Predeceors, and, like Rehoboam, think their own little finger tronger than the whole Body of their Fathers; the other ordinary to old Men, who alwayes extoll the time pat above the preent, becaue the infirmities of their Bodies and Minds, no longer allowing them the contentment they formerly enjoyed, they know not where to charge the fault but upon Time, though, in truth, it lyes upon Themelves. For Nature being till as Wie and Powerful as heretofore, and the Univeral Caues the ame, their Operations mut be likewie as perfect, and their Effects as excellent in thee dayes, as they have been in any. Then, as for our Minds, they are o far from being impair'd, that they improve more and more in acutenes; and being of the ame Nature with thoe of the Ancients, have uch an advantage beyond them, as a Pigmy hath upon the houlders of a Gyant; from whence he beholds not onely as much, but more than his upporter doth.

The Second aid, As a Stone hath more force by how much 'tis les from the hand that flings it; and generally all Caues act more powerful upon their next, than upon their ditant Effects: o alo Men are les perfect proportionally to their remotenes from their Source and Original, from whence they derive all their perfection. This decay is chiefly oberv'd in our bodies, which are not o ound and well-contituted, as thoe of our Ancetors; and therefore 'tis no wonder if the Souls where-with they are inform'd, have les Vigor though the ame Nature. For although, in order to judge aright of the Excellence of the Souls of one Age compar'd with another, we ought to wave that advantage which the later have over the preceding, by enjoying the benefit of their inventions; whereunto 'tis as eaie to add, as 'tis to build upon a good foundation, whereof others have firmly lay'd the firt tones and Pillars. Yet, for all thoe great advantages, there hath
not in thee lat Ages, appear'd any one equal to thoe grand Peronages of Antiquity, who have had the vogue in each Art and Science. Moreover, want of things made them more ingenious, and the Experience of many years render'd them capable of every thing; whereas now we ceae to live, when we but begin to know our elves. Indeed they had the true Diciplines and Sciences, whereof we have no more but the hadows; and intead of real and olid Philoophy, uch as that of the Firt Ages was, nothing remains to us but an ueles Scholatick Gibberih, which having been baniht the Company of all dicreet people, is hamefully confin'd to the incloure of Colledges, where I am confident the Profeors will readily yield to Socrates, Plato, Lycurgus, Solon, and the Seven Sages of Greece, to whoe Age, which was the year of the World, 3400. I clearly give the prize; there being no indowment of the Mind preferrable to that of Widom.

The Third aid, If Widom mut carry it, there is no Age to be compar'd to that of Solomon: but becaue one Swallow makes not a Spring, I hould prefer before it that of Augutus and Tiberius, when the Roman Empire was in its greatet Glory; the rather becaue our Saviour, the Paragon of all great Men liv'd in it, and Virgil, Ovid, Cicero, Cato, beides many others, flouriht at the ame time. Not to peak of the rare Inventions which alo then appear'd; as Malleable Glas, and Perpetual Lights, both now unknown.

The Fourth aid, If the complaint of the decay of Witts were true and new, the World mut be very old, ince Seneca, who liv'd 1500. years ago, made the ame in his time: But if the preent Wits are not inferior to thoe of Seneca's time, it will follow, either that the world grows not wore, as is commonly aid, or that long Series of years, which makes above a quarter of the whole Age the world, is taken but for one and the ame time: In which Cae, the world mut be older than religion and truth teach us, before it fell into that decay, wherein we ee it continue for o many Ages. But indeed, 'tis a weaknes to imagine that Witts diminih; our Natural Inclination to depie what we poes, and to regret what is pas'd, making us judge to our own diadvantage, that we are les perfect than our Ancetors, and that our Nephews mut be wore than our elves; whence aroe that Fiction of Four Ages, differing according to o many Metals; the Golden one, by reaon of its excellence; that of Silver, Bras and Iron, proportionably, as Men fell from the former Perfection of Soul, and Innocence of Manners. But all this while, 'tis in the beginning of the World that the weaknes of Man appear'd by uffering himelf to be govern'd by his Wife, and the damnable Reolution of a Fratricide. Moreover, the Mind of Man being a Power of well Conceiving, Reaoning, Inventing, and doing other Functions, whereof he is capable, he may arrive to a Supream Degree of Excellence, either by the
pure and liberal Will of his Maker, or by the dipoition and concurrence of Natural Caues, or by Humane Indutry. So that God, Nature, and Art, the three ole Agents of this World, being the ame as heretofore, they mut produce the ame Effects. For God creates not Souls now with les advantages and grace than formerly; he is as liberal of his favours as ever, epecially in the Ages of Grace. Nor doth Nature and other Second Caues contribute les to the perfection of Souls than heretofore. And the Humane Soul, however independent of Matter as to its Eence, yet is o link'd to the Organs of the Body, that it operates well or ill according as thoe are diverly affected, which is, what we call Good or Bad Wit, whilt we judge thereof by the Actions, and not by the Eence. For thoe Organs and Dipoitions depend of the Elements and Superior Bodies, which are alwayes the ame, and conequently, mut produce the ame Effects; and hence, the equal Dipoitions of Bodies, will inferr equal perfection of Minds. But as for the difference of Souls ariing from Art and Intruction, undoubtedly, thoe of our Age are better cultivated than any ever have been in times pas'd.

The Fifth aid, When I conider the high pitch whereunto o many great Men have carry'd the Glory of thee lat Ages, I find more wonders than in the preceding; but it pertains onely to the Ages enuing to make their Elogiums; Great Men, whilt living, being kept down by Envy or Contempt. One Age mut be let pas, before we begin to judge of the worth of it; then the following begins to regret what it leighted, it being natural to us to eek onely what is wanting, and to be diguted with plenty. And truly, I think 'tis the multitude of perons excelling in all ort of Arts, and epecially in the Sciences, (whereof never were o many Doctors, Regents, and Profeors, een in one ingle Age as in this) that makes us les eteem the ingenious that are now living; for 'tis onely rarity that gives price to things, and that made him pas for a great Clerk a few Ages ago, who could but write and read; he that poke Latine was a Prodigy, though now 'tis a Tongue almot as univeral, and common as the Native. Now Admiration being the Daughter of Ignorance, the eteem had of mot of the admired in former Ages, is rather an Argument of the Rudenes and Ignorance of the Times, than of the excellence of their Witts. Nor were they better than we in their Manners, but onely more imple, and yet culpable of as many Crimes. But were we the more wicked, this were no Argument of want of Witt, which is the matter in quetion. And if there have been ometimes a Ceres, a Bacchus, a Pallas, a Vulcan, and others, advanc'd to Deities for finding out the way to ow Wheat, plant Vine-yards, pin Wool, and forge Iron; we have had in thee lat Ages the Inventors of the Compas, the Gun, Printing, the Tubes of Galileo, and a thouand other Inventions both more difficult and excellent; the
eaiet having been firt dicover'd. The Modety of thoe that govern us, (who no les hate the vanity of praie, than they know how to exercie Actions deerving it) permits me not to hew you, that all pas'd Ages have nothing that comes near the grandeur of their Souls, and that their conduct is the more to be admir'd, in that their buines is both to keep themelves up with Friends, and give reaon to Enemies, who alo help to verifie, that there are greater State-men and Captains in this Age, than in any of the preceding.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLV. Of the Serene, which is a hurtful Dew falling in Summer Evenings.
div.p: AS Painters find it harder to repreent a calm mooth Sea, than the rampant foaming billows of a torm, which require more variety of Colours, and afford the Pencil more liberty; and as a Hitory of Peace is harder to write, and les pleaant to read, than the Troubles and Commotions of Warr: So I think it les difficult to decribe the everal impreions of Tempets, than thoe of a calm Air, which nevertheles at certain times, produces pernicious Effects; o much more remarkable, in that they proceed from a very imple Caue, no-wie malignant of it elf, to wit, from a clear and erene Air, free from Clouds and Vapours, which in the Evening being cool'd by the reaon of the Sun's Elongation, acquires a certain Refrigerating and Catarrhous quality, call'd by the vulgar, The Serene: becaue it happens either in the Evening, or more commonly in fair weather, when the Air is erene, than when it is pluvious and full of Vapours. Which quality, ome acribe to the Influence of the Stars, epecially to the Moon, term'd for that reaon by the Palmit, Infrigidans; which hath indeed a notable dominion over all Humid Bodies, particularly, thoe of Men, who find enible alterations in themelves, according to the everal faces of that Planet. But becaue the Heavens diffue their Influences upon thoe that are under covert, as well as upon thoe that are in the open Air, where onely the Serene is felt; I hould rather pitch upon the alterations of the refrigerated Air, which acts but o far as it is near us; and 'tis always more proper to attribute Effects here below to proximate Caues, than to recur to the Heaven, which is but an equivocal Caue thereof.

The Second aid. If Cold were the Caue of the Serene, the ame hould happen where-ever it were cold, and be more hurtful according to the vehemency of that quality, as towards Midnight or Morning, and likewie in Winter: Yet the Serene is never poken of but in the temperate Seaons of Spring and Autumn,
and ome little portion of the Seaons bordering upon them. Beides, in Summer the air of our cold Caves hould be capable of producing it at mid-noon. Wherefore I cannot think the Serene an effect of bare cold, but of the vapors wherewith the air, howoever apparently pure, is always charg'd (whence proceeds the diverity of refractions In the Planets, epecially at Sun-rie and Sun-et, which is never without ome clouds) which vapours being detitute of the diurnal heat and o coming to be condens'd, fall down upon our heads jut as Dew doth, which is produc'd after the ame manner but of a matter omwhat thicker and more copious. And as there is no Dew o there is no Serene but in temperate Seaons, and Regions; never in Winter or the midt of Summer: for violent cold congeals thee vapours into Frot and Ice, and vehement heat diipates and conumes them. The practice of our Ladies (who ue to remain in the Serene, thereby to whiten their complexion and often their fleh) hows that this evening-air having a cleaning and levigating vertue mut be impregnated with a quality like Dew, which is deterive by reaon of the alt which it drew from the earth; by means whereof it not only whitens Linen and Wax but alo purgeth Animals, as appears by the fluxes hapning to Sheep driven out to gras before the Sun has conum'd the Dew; and by Manna, which is nothing but a condens'd dew, and hath a purgative vertue.

The Third aid, Mans body being ubject to the injuries of all external Agents, receives o much greater from the impreions of the Air, as the ame is more neceary to life; capable of ubiting for ome time without other things, but not a moment without Air, which is continually attracted into our Bodies not only by repiration, but alo by inenible tranpiration through the Pores of the Body, which is pierc'd with holes like a Sieve for admiion of air which is taken in by the Arteries in their motion of Diatole or Dilatation. And being mot agile and ubtle, it eaily penetrates our Bodies, altering them by the four firt qualities wherewith it is variouly impregnated according to the vicinity of the Bodies environing it, which make the four Seaons of the Year, wherein it variouly dipoes the bodies upon which it acts, changing even their natural temperament. And becaue the parts of a natural day have ome proportion with thoe of a year, upon account of the everal changes caus'd by the common and proper revolutions of the Sun; hence the Morning is like the Spring hot and moit, or rather temperate, and the Blood then predominates: Noon reembles Summer, hot and dry, at which time Choler is in motion: the following part is cold and dry, Melancholy and correpondent to Autumn: the Evening and whole Night, by its coldnes and humidity which puts Phlegm in motion, is a little Winter, the coldnes whereof proceeds not from the vapors (which are always accompani'd with ome extraneous heat,
whereby they are retain'd in the Air and kept from falling) but from the bare privation of the heat of the Sun, who, as by his preence he actually caues heat in the Air, o by his abence he caues coldnes in the ame; which penetrating our Bodies calefi'd by the diurnal heat, eaily therein condenes the vapors which are not yet etled or laid, and queeing them out of the Brain and all the parts (jut as we do water out of a wet punge) they fall upon the weaket parts, where they caue a fluxion and pain.

The Fourth aid, That the Air being of it elf very temperate, can never do any michief, unles it be mix'd with ome extraneous ubtances, as Vapors and Exhalations which continually infect the firt Region wherein we reide. And becaue thoe ubtle parts of Earth and Water exhal'd into it are imperceptible, 'tis not trange if they produce uch udden and unexpected effects, as we ee the Serene doth; which is caus'd by vapors rais'd after Sun-et by the force of the heat remaining upon the urface of the Earth, like thoe ariing from heated water after it is taken off the fire: So that the Serene is that vapour whilt it mounts upwards, not when it falls downwards; for it cannot decend till it be render'd heavier by condenation into Water, Clouds or Mits, which make the Air nubilous and not erene, as in this effect it ues to be. But at their firt elevation, they are more volatile, rare, ubtle, and inviible.

The Fifth aid, That the chief caue of this hurtful accident, is the change of one contrary into another without medium, which is always incommodious to Nature; who for that reaon conjoyns all extreams by ome mediums, which erve for dipoitions to pas from the one to the other without difficulty. And as the alteration of the body from cold to hot is painful, (witnes thoe who hold their cold hands to the fire after handling of Ice) in like ort that from hot to cold is very incommodious; whence the hotter the preceding day hath been, the more dangerous is the erene; becaue the pores of the Body being open'd, and all the humors diorder'd and mov'd, by the diurnal heat, the cold ininuates into and works upon the ame with more liberty; jut as heated water is oonet frozen by reaon its parts are more open'd by the heat, and conequently more capable of receiving the impreions of Agents. Which is alo the reaon why the firt cold hurts us rather then the greatet frots, namely, becaue it finds the body more open, then enuing hard weather doth. So though in Winter the air be colder, yet becaue 'tis almot continually the ame, it makes les impreion in the evening upon our bodies already accutomed to its rigor: and though the air is colder at midnight then at Sun-et, yet the erene is only at the beginning of the night, when our bodies more enibly receive alteration from the ame. Wherefore 'tis only the udden change of the air which makes the erene, whereof our bodies are the more enible according
to the opennes of the pores and of the futures of the head, and the oftnes of the fleh, which renders the body obnoxious to external caues, as hardnes (which ecures it from them) makes it ubject to internal caues, through want of tranpiration. Hence Peaants, Souldiers and all uch as are hardned by labour and are of a firm and contant contitution, feel no inconvenience from the Serene, although they breathe an air more ubtle, and conequently more capable of being impregnated in the evening with qualities noxious to the body.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLVI. Whether the French are Light and Incontant; and why?
div.p:
THere is no more perfect Mirror of Incontancy, then Man; as appears by the pleaure his body takes in the change of Pature, his mind in that of Objects, and both in that of Condition. Hence men look not upon preent honours but as o many teps whereby to acend to new; the poeion of preent goods bringing no other atisfaction then that of their Stomack, that is, till a econd Appetite be excited by new Meats. Whereunto the nimblenes of their volatile Spirits, the fluidity and mobility, of their humours which contitute the temperament, too notoriouly furnih the efficient and material caue to inquire elewhere for them; for which reaon the melancholick are les ubject to this defect; this earthy humour being les uceptible of change, whence they prove more wie. But amongt all Nations there is none to whom the vice of Levity is more imputed then to the French. Caear who had long convers'd with them, frequently objects the ame to them, and experience ufficiently hews by what is pas'd that they are very far from the contancy of other Nations, as not only their Statutes and Edicts which they cannot long oberve, but all their Modes and Cutoms, and their deire of novelty abundantly tetifie. The caues whereof are either from the Climate or the Soil. For 'tis oberv'd that where the Heaven is always in the ame poture, as toward the Poles; or where the Sun heats almot in the ame degree as near the Equator (which makes the days and nights equal), the Manners and Inclinations of the People are alo equal: on the contrary, thoe that by the everal remotions and approaches of the Sun have different contitutions of Air, receive utable impreions from the ame, which are afterwards manifeted in their actions. And becaue what is below is the ame with what is on high, the Earth conequently partakes of the ame alterations which the Heaven produces in the Air, and
retains them longer: Thus our Soul being heated and cooled, moitned and dry'd in one and the ame day, uffering contrary changes in a very little time; 'tis no wonder if the Aliments it affords make the parts, humors, and pirits, like it elf, that is to ay, flitting, incontant, and mutable; which parts being communicated from Father to Son, can no more be chang'd by us, even by Travels and Alteration of Soil, than the Moor can change his kin which the temper of his native climate hath in like manner given him. Add hereunto, that the French Courteie, receiving all trangers more civilly than any Nation of the World, is alo more eaily lead by their perwaions and examples: And whereas the roughnes and ruticity of many other people thinks hame and corn to change, (as implying preceding Ignorance) the incerity and franknes of the French is uch, that he eaily alters his Mind and way as oon as another eems better to him than his own: other Nations, (what-ever Pride they take in being always contant and equal to themelves, and epecially more patient than we in our Adverities) urpaing us onely in this particular, that they better know how to diemble their dicontents.

The Second aid, Lightnes of Minds is, like that of Bodies, repective onely, not abolute. And as Air is term'd Light, in repect of Water and Earth; o dull people, thoe of the North, and uch others as would have gravity alone in words, getures, and actions, pas for Widom, call the French light, becaue they are more nimble and active then themelves; and being really what others are onely in appearance, affect not that fale mak of Widom, whereof they poes the olidity and Body, whilt thee content themelves with enjoying its hadow and ghot. For 'tis not the change of habits or modes that argues that of the Mind, but in great Matters, as Religion and State, in maintaining whereof, the French may be affirm'd more contant than any Nation. 'Tis not an Age yet, ince France bad reaon to glory, (as well as in Saint Jerom's time) of never having produc'd Monters, but of planting the Faith well amongt all its Neighbors, whoe rigorous Inquiition is les a tetimony of the Contancy, than of the lightnes or baenes of their Spirits, ince they are kept in their Religion by fear of the Wheel and the Gallows. Then as for the State, the French Monarchy is the ancientet in the world, and hath been always maintain'd amidt the ruines and downfalls of other States, by the exact obervation of its fundamental Laws; which is an eminent Argument of the Contancy of the French; the Nations who have mot charg'd them with this Vice, hewing themelves the mot incontant, whilt this puiant body of France remains always like it elf; which it could not do, if the members which compoe it were light and incontant, the greatet Vice where-with they can apere us. For ince, according to Seneca, Widom is always to will and not-will the ame things; Incontance and
Irreolution, in willing ometimes one thing, ometimes another, is a certain tetimony of Folly, Imprudence, and weaknes of Mind; which coming to change, intimates either that it took not its meaures aright, nor apprehended the fit means of attaining to the propoed end, or that it had not Courage and Reolution enough to go through with its deignes. And not onely he who hath an incontant and flitting Spirit is incapable of Widom, which requires a ettled Mind, not mutable like that of the Fool, (who, as the Scripture aith, changes like the Moon) but alo of all ort of Virtue, which coniting in a mediocrity, is not attainable but by Prudence which precribes its Bounds and Rules, and by Stability and Contance which arms the Mind againt all difficulties occurring in the way of Virtue; in which, as well as in the Sciences and Arts, the French having more hare than any other Nation, 'tis injurious to accue them of Incontancy.

The Third aid, 'Tis not more vanity to believe one's elf perfect in all things, than temerity in going about (upon blind paion for his Country) to exempt it from a Vice, whereof all trangers, who know us better than we do our elves, are univerally agreed. Let us confes therefore that we are incontant, ince, in comparion of the Vices of other Neighbouring Nations, this will not onely appear light, but make it doubtful, whether it be a Vice, ince 'tis grounded upon Nature, which is in perpetual change; whereby he appears more beautiful and agreeable than in identity and ret, which, is not found even in the prime Bodies and univeral Caues, which as well as others, are in a continual mobility and change, which is no-wie contrary to Widom, which requires that we accommodate our elves to the circumtances of places, perons, and times, which alter inceantly, and that we conequently alter our Concluions according thereunto; beides that, change of Opinion is a tetimony of a free and ingenuous Spirit, as that of the French is; and it may be attributed to the power of example, in a people environ'd with undry Nations extreamly different, and coniting of Spirits which are imbu'd with the qualities of them all. For this Country lying under the forty third degree, and the forty eighth, the mixture of thee people, which partake a little of the Southern, and a little of the Northern Neighbours; ometimes conforms to the modes of one, ometimes to thoe of the other: And as in the change of Colours, the difference is not een but in the two extreamities, thoe of the middle appearing changeable and diverifi'd; o France ituated between the Germans, Italians, and Spaniards, mixing and tempering in it elf the qualities of thoe Nations which are in its extreamities, appears to them changeable and uncertain.

The Fourth aid, Though the French are not more incontant than others, yet their boyling and impetuous humor, and the quicknes of all their Actions having made them be eteemed
uch by all their Neighbors, I hall rather refer the Caue thereof to their abundance of Spirits, which are the ole Motors and Principles of all Actions, (produc'd by the purity of their Air, and the variety of their Aliments) than to the Apects of Heaven, or uch other Caues; ince Nations under the ame parallel, with France, as Podolia, Hungary, Tartary, and many others, hould be ubject to the ame Vice, which was ometimes imputed to the Grecians, the mot fickle and incontant of all people; without referring the Caue to the Winds, as Cardan held, that uch as are mot expos'd thereunto, to have volatile Spirits; otherwie the French, and other Nations, ubject to Winds, hould quit their levity when they came into Climates les windy.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLVII. Of the undry Motions of the Sea and Rivers.
div.p:
NOthing ravihes us more than the Motion of Inanimate Bodies; Automata, or Bodies moving by Artifice, having in the beginning made Idolaters, who were undeceived when they came to know the Springs of them. But above all, the Motions of the Sea eem the more marvellous, in that they are very different and contrary. And they are of two orts; One Internal, and common to all heavy Bodies, whereby the Water decends downwards, the agitated Sea becomes calm by returning to its level, and Rivers follow the declivity of the Lands through which they pas: The other, violent, which is either irregular, (render'd o by the irregularity of the Winds) or regular; which again is of two orts, namely, that of reciprocation in the flux and reflux of the Sea, and that which depends upon the everal parts of the World, being either from Eat to Wet, or from North to South. 'Tis true, Water being naturally fluid and moveable, and not to be contain'd within its own bounds, it were more trange if this great Body were immoveable, than to ee it move, as it was neceary it hould for Navigation, and to avoid corruption. The wonder onely is, to ee in one ole Body o great a diverity of Motions, whereof onely the firt is natural to it; the others arie from ome extrinick Caues; amongt which, none acting more enibly upon the Elements than the Celetial Bodies, 'tis to the diverity of their Motions, that thoe of the Sea mut be imputed, but particularly, that of its flux and reflux, which being regular, and always alike in one and the ame Sea, cannot proceed but from as regular a Caue, uch as the Heaven is, and chiefly the Moon, which manifetly exercies its empire over all Humid Bodies, the flux and reflux
following the Lunar Periods and Motions, not onely every ix months, to wit, during the two Aequinoxes when their Tides are very high, but alo every month in the Conjunction and Oppoition of the Moon, and alo every ix hours of the day, almot all Seas have their flux and reflux, except ome which make the ame in more or les time, and are longer in their reflux than their flux; or on the contrary, according to the declivity and various winding of the Lands, the greatnes or mallnes of Creeks, the Streights of the Seas, narrownes of banks, and other differences of ituation.

The Second aid, That the Sea, being a imple body, can have but one natural Motion, viz. that of its own weight, which makes it flow into places lower than its ource, which it can never urmount. Amongt the other three Motions proceeding from without, that from Eat to Wet is dicern'd by the time pent in Voyages at Sea, which is much longer from Wet to Eat, than from Eat to Wet: becaue in the firt, they move contrary to the Motion of the Sea, and in the econd with it. Now the caue hereof is the impreion of the Firt Mover upon all the Orbes and Inferior Bodies, which follow the rapidity of its daily Motion from Eat to Wet upon the Poles of the World. That from North to South, is likewie een in mot Seas, and chiefly in the Euxine, which being fill'd by the Palus Maeotis, and the Tanais, dicharges it elf by the Aegaean, into the Mediterranean Sea; which, were it not for the high luces of Africa, would continue the ame Motion Southwards: Which ometimes hindred Darius and Seotris from digging that pace of Land which is between the Red-Sea and the Mediterranean, for fear let this latter hould overflow thoe Southern Countries. The Caue of this Motion, is the multitude of Waters towards that Pole, whoe coldnes not raiing o great a quantity of Vapors and Rains as towards the South, the Waters come to be greater there, and o are forc'd to fall towards the lower places. Or rather, (ince there is the ame cold under the Antarctick Pole, and conequently, the ame quantity of Waters and Rains) this decent of the Waters Southwards, mut be attributed to the Elevation of the Earth in the North, or to the narrow mouths or gulphs of thoe Seas which make the waters decend out of them more eaily than they enter into them. As to the flux and reflux, which is a Compounded, but regular Motion, it cannot proceed from Vapors, or from incontant and irregular Winds, but from the Motion, Light, and particular Influence of the Moon; which attracting the Sea in the ame manner that the Load-tone doth the Iron, is the Caue of its accumulation, or welling and increae, which makes the flux: And then her Virtue abating by her elongation, the Waters by their proper weight reume their level, and o make the reflux. And becaue all Seas are continuous, the Moon when under our Horizon, ceaes not to caue the ame Motions in our Seas, as when he is above it; the Waters necearily following
the motion of thoe which are next them, which would be alike in all did not ome variation arie from the different ituations of Lands, which is the caue that the flux and reflux of the Ocean is more enible then the Mediterranean, and in this the Adriatick, then the Tucan, by reaon that Sicily and the point of Italy makes the Sea enter impetuouly into the Gulph of Venice; wherein is oberv'd another particular motion call'd Circulation, whereby the Mediterranean flowing by its proper motion from Eat to Wet, and meeting immediately at the entrance of that Gulph the Coat of Macedonia, dicharges it elf impetuouly thereinto and continues its motion to the bottom of the Gulph, whence being repercus'd it returns by the oppoite Coat of Calabria to the other point of the Gulph by which it enters into the Tucan Sea. Hence, to go from Venice to Otranto they take the Coat of Galabria; and to return back, that of Macedonia.

The Third aid, Nothing o trongly argues the mobility of the Earth as the motions of the Sea and Rivers: for what ele were it but a miracle if water contain'd in an immoveable veel hould agitate and move it elf. That of Rivers proceeds not from their weight, which makes them fall into a place nearer their Centre; eeing that in a declivity requiite to the coure of a River for 200 leagues, there mut then be a depreion more enible then the altitude of the highet Mountains of the Earth, nor could the Sea remit the waters to their Springs (as the holy Scripture aith it doth) if thoe Springs were higher then it. But uppoing the motion of the Earth, 'tis eaie to render a reaon of that of the Water. As for Rivers, (almot all which run wetward) the Earth having its Diurnal Motion from Wet to Eat (according to the Hypotheis of Copernicus) may caue this their contrary motion by ubtracting it elf from the fluidity of the waters (liquid bodies not exactly following the motion of olid) as the water in a Tub ries in the ide oppoite to that towards which you way the Veel. By the ame reaon alo the Sea hall have its coure from Eat to Wet, which is therefore very enible between the two Tropicks where the rapidity of the Earths motion is greater then under the Poles. Hence upon this account Navigation is very eaie Wetward, the Currents very violent, the Tides great towards the Coat of America: as is oberv'd chiefly in Magellan's Streight, where the refluxes of the Northern and Eatern Sea are advanc'd above 70 leagues; and the Mar del Sur carce goes to 25, and that weakly: but about the Poles the Sea hath no other motion but that which is caus'd by Winds and Tempets. As for the flux and reflux of the Sea, according to the ame uppoition, of its motion compounded of the annual in the Ecliptick (where others make the Sun circulate) and the Diurnal upon its own Axis and proper Centre there aries a certain irregular motion, ometimes lower and ometimes wifter, which is the caue of that flux
and reflux: for as in a Boat mov'd at firt wiftly and then caus'd to move omwhat lower, the water contain'd therein wells in its extremities till by continuation of that motion it recover its level; and the Boat being again driven with the ame velocity, the water wells again upon the change of the motion: the ame comes to pas upon the unequal motion of the Earth mixt of the annual and diurnal. But becaue the Moon being annex'd to the Earth exactly follows its motions; therefore mot Philoophers have taken the Moon for the caue of the flux and reflux, although he be only the ign of it.

The Fourth aid, That according to this Hypotheis 'tis eaie to render a reaon of two things very remarkable in Danubius and Nilus. The firt which runs from Wet to Eat, is oberv'd in Hungary to move lower about Noon then at other hours of the day, as appears by the Water-mills which grinde les at that time: becaue the motion of the Earth being then contrary to that of the Ecliptick, it conequently appears more low. And as for the other effect, namely, the increae and inundation of Nilus, which begins at the Summer Soltice, this River running directly from South to North from, one Tropick to another, which is jut the middle part of the Earth, when it comes to incline its Axis and return the Antarctick part to the Sun, the tream of this River, which is contrary to that motion, waxes lower; and being beides augmented by the continual Rains of Summer, wells and overflows the Plains of Egypt. Which made ome Ancients imagine that the North Winds blew again the tream at that time and forc'd the water back upon themelves.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLVIII. Whether is better, to Love, or to be Lov'd.
div.p:
THe ame Nature, which by an intinct common to us withall things in the world, caues us to eek our own good, obliges us likewie to Love, when we meet Goodnes or Beauty in an object capable to render us happy by its poeion; which coniting in being united to the thing lov'd, 'tis in this union that the Lover places his greatet felicity, and accordingly goes out of himelf to joyn himelf to what he loves; the motions of the will (of whoe number Love is) differing in this point from the actions of the Undertanding, that thee are perform'd by the Species receiv'd by mediation of the Senes into the Intellect, which cannot know any thing but what comes home to it; but the Will when it Loves, mut go out of it elf and become united to the thing it Loves, to the end to beget omthing for Eternity. And becaue things are not known by the Undertanding
till they have been firt purifi'd from the grosnes of their matter by the illutration and abctraction which the Agent Intellect makes of their Phantams or Species, hence the notions of the foulet and mot dihonet things are always fair and laudable, being piritualis'd and made like the Faculty which knows them. On the contrary, the Will in loving renders it elf like the object which it Loves, is turn'd into its nature, and receives its qualities; if the object be unlawful and dihonet, it becomes vicious and its love is criminal. Which eems to argue that the Lover is les perfect then the Loved, into which he is transform'd; as food is les perfect then the body, into which it is converted. And as that which attracts is more excellent then what is attracted, becaue the tronger draws the weaker; o the thing Loved mut be more excellent and noble then the Lover, whom it attracts to it elf. Moreover, Love, according to Plato, is a deire of Pulchritude, which deire implies want; and therefore he that Loves hews thereby that he wants ome perfection, which renders the thing Lov'd amiable: ince the Will is never carri'd to any object but what hath ome goodnes either apparent or real. Only God loves not his Creatures for their goodnes, ince they have none of themelves; but his will being the caue of all things, he renders them good by loving them and willing good to them.

The Second aid, Since friendhip conits in the union of two, or at mot, of three Wills, whoe mutual correpondence makes that agreeable harmony and thoe weet accords, which make ravihing Lovers dye in themelves to live in what they love; there is no true love but what is reciprocal; which is the reaon why none can be contracted with inanimate things, no more then with Beats or Fools. And Jutice commanding us to render as much as is given us; 'tis a great injutice not to love thoe that love us; yea, if we may believe the Platonits, 'tis a kind of homicide of the Soul; ince he that loves, being dead in himelf and having no more life but in the thing lov'd, if that refues his love, by means whereof it hould live alo in him as he in it, he is contrain'd either to dye or languih mierably. And whereas he that loves is no longer his own but belongs to the thing lov'd to whom he hath given himelf, this thing is oblig'd to love him by the ame reaon that obliges it to love it's elf and all that pertains thereunto. But though perfect love be compos'd of thee two pieces, to love and to be lov'd; yet the one is often found without the other, there being many Lovers wounded with the Poets leaden Arrows, who intead of eeing their love requited with love, have for all recompene nothing but contempts and, refuals. 'Tis true, that it being harder to love without being lov'd, then to be lov'd without loving, there is no body but would chue rather to be lov'd then to love upon thoe terms, becaue nothing flatters our ambition o much as to ee our elves ought unto. Yet loving is a
nobler thing then to be lov'd; ince honor being more in the honorer then the honored, the honor receiv'd by the lov'd thing reflects upon him that loves; who for that reaon being commended by every one that eteems a good friend as a good treaure, and not he that is lov'd, is alo more excellent and hath more vertue, inamuch as he hath more honor and praie which are the attendants of vertue. Moreover, the Lover acts freely, and therefore more to be valu'd then the lov'd peron, who is forc'd to uffer himelf to be lov'd. For though deire commonly follow Senual Love, yet Love is not a deire, nor conequently a ign of Indigence; otherwie, it hould ceae with the deire, and expire after enjoyment; which is fale: for Mothers love their dead Children, and even before they came into the world, not by a deire but by a motion of Nature, which caues us to love what appertains to us, and the more if it cot much pain; which is the reaon why Mothers, who contribute more to the birth of their Children, and have better aurance that they are their own, love them alo more tenderly then Fathers do.

The Third aid, That to compare the lov'd peron with the Lover, is to equal the Mater with the Servant; for the amorous auming to themelves the quality of Servants of the Ladies whom they call their Mitrees, manifet ufficiently thereby that they yield them the pre-eminence. And although they be the mot intereed in this caue; yet they will never have the vanity to prize themelves above what they love; which would be to condemn their own choice and their love of defect of judgment, which making them igh after the enjoyment of the object they adore, argues their want and indigence, not to be upply'd by poeion of the good they expect from it; which herein like the Intelligences which move without being mov'd themelves, excites paions and motions in the Lover's breat, it elf oftentimes remaining immovable. And as he acts in a more noble way that moves without being mov'd, becaue he reembles the end, which is the noblet of all the Caues; o he that loves reembles Matter which Deires all Forms, expecting its perfection from them; and conequently is inferior to the peron that is lov'd, as from whom he expects his felicity. Even in Mutual Love, he that begins is les perfect, as confeing by that addres ome inviting accomplihments in the other, who finds not any obligation to love him again but the conideration of gratitude: For inferring the advantage of thoe that love from the noblenes of their ubject, as in Gods love to his Creatures, and that of Parents to their Children; I anwer, that 'tis rather an effect of paion then of true love.

The Fourth aid, That Love is according to the variety of its Object, (Good), three-fold; conidering either Profit, or Pleaure, or Vertue. In the two former, 'tis better to be lov'd then to love, but they are of no long duration; thoe friends
being wont to break as oon as they ceae to find their market or the contentments which they receive from thoe to whom they pretended kindnes. In honet friendhip (which alone deerves that name, being founded only upon vertue, which makes it durable) though 'tis not poible to love without being lov'd, becaue vertuous perons being alike mutually love and agree well together; yet ince this Amity, before it can become uch mut be cemented by frequentation, without which they cannot undertand, nor conequently love one another, becaue love aries from knowledg, it may be demanded whether the active love of him that loves firt be better then the paive of the other who is lov'd. Which Quetion I determine for the former, becaue he contributes mot to the enuing friendhip, by laying the foundations of it. For friendhip, as well as other things, is preerv'd by the ame means that produce it, namely, by loving. And as the Agent is nobler then the Patient, as concurring more coniderably to the perfection of the work; o he that loves being the Agent is more perfect then the Peron lov'd, who is the Patient. Alo to love is to wih and do good; to be lov'd, is to receive it: But 'tis more honorable and vertuous to give then to receive; which is a hameful action: and therefore he that receives never deires witnees. Hence, as he that do's a benefit loves more then he that receives it, as the Artificer loves his work more then his work loves him, and a Creditor deires his Debtor's afety more then on the contrary; in like manner he that loves is more excellent then he that is lov'd, Love being not o much a tetimony of indigence as abundance, becaue 'tis a deire of communicating; and the more goodnes a Being hath, the more it is communicative and diffuive.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXLIX. Of Hair.
div.p:
OF the different parts of Man's Body ome are abolutely neceary, others only for convenience or ornament, as the Hair, wherewith wie Nature hath adorn'd the Head (his noblet part) whoe nudity would have been indecorous; whence people are aham'd of baldnes, which is alo threatned by God as a cure to the Daughters of Sion. The good man Eliha had ufficient patience to endure Jezabel's perecutions for a long time, but not to upport the affront of the little Children of Bethel who call'd him bald-pate; and upon his cure forty two of them were torn in pieces by two Bears which came out of the neighbouring Woods; God by that means avenging the injury done to the noblet part of this Prophet, namely the
Head; upon which 'tis alo the cutom to place Crowns: and becaue 'tis the Manion of the Rational Soul, our Lord forbids wearing by it The Superincumbent Hair receives by that vicinity ome particular and myterious dignity, which hath made it o eteem'd, that not onely the Ancients offer'd it in acrifice to their Deities, epecially when they were tos'd by Tempets of Sea, and burnt it upon the death of Friends; but alo the Nazarens who were the Religious, or Monaticks among the Jews, were particularly prohibited by God to cut it; wherein likewie Sampon's trength, Abolom's Beauty, and, according to the Poets, Nius's happines conited. But above all, there is a certain Majety in the Beard, which is reerv'd onely to Man, as bet uting with the gravity of his manners. A large Beard was ever counted the character of Widom, and as uch choen by Philoophers as a badge of their profeion. Hence Diogenes to one that ak'd him, Why he wore o long a Beard, anwerd, To the end, that beholding it, I may remember that I am a Man, not a Woman. For though Widom and Folly be found in all Ages, and there be as many old fools as young hair-brains, yet the Beard is a ign of Experience, which principally renders Men wie. Natural Reaon eems alo to prove, that thoe that have Beards are wier, and les impetuous than thoe that have not yet put them forth; inamuch as the fumes and fuliginoities, which are the matter of Hair, being till inclos'd in the latter, make them more inconiderate and rah. Yea, were it onely for hew, I hould conclude in favor of great Beards, which at leat have this good that they make Men appear wie, though they be not o. And as Lycurgus aid of long Hair, that it adds handomnes to them that are handome, and covers the deformities of them that are not, whom alo it renders terrible to their Enemies; o large Beards erve for Ornament to thoe that are already wie, and make them coniderable that are not o overmuch.

The Second aid, Hair is the Symbol of Thought, deriv'd from the ame Brain, and as various in conceit and fahion; Nations having chang'd modes for Hair and Clothes accordingly, as they have fancy'd more becommingnes and utablenes in one fahion than in another. Four hundred years together there was no Barber at Rome, the firt being carry'd thither from Sicily by Ticinius Menas, Anno V. C. 454; and after that time 'twas accounted with them a note of barbarity and extream deolation to let their Hair and Beards grow, as Augutus did after the defeat of Varus. The French have been as mutable in this matter as in any other; Their Kings of the two firt Races, wearing long buhes of Hair, in token of liberty. And ince Francis the Firt, who hav'd his Hair upon occaion of a wound in his Head, and let his Beard grow to hide the deformity of carrs remaining in his Face after other wounds; hort Hair and long Beards began to be in requet, and continued o till our Age, wherein Periwigs
are more the mode than ever; which being to be grounded upon convenience or eemlines, I ee nothing that can jutifie the great buh but Caprichio and Example. For Hair being a uperfluous Excrement, its exorbitant greatnes cannot but be incommodious and prejudicial to Health, and the good Contitution of the Brain; the fuliginous vapors whereof, being repercus'd by the abundance of Hair, caue Vertigoes and pains of the Head, not more certainly cur'd than by having the Head. As for eemlines, much Hair is rather frightful than handome, and our Ancetors were no les comely perons than we, though they wore hort Hair; as at this day alo do many warlike Nations Enemies of oftnes and delicacy, whereof great Hair is a mot certain token, being proper to Women, as on the contrary, the long Beard is a note of Virility. For inamuch as he that loves, conformes as much as poible to what he loves, we may judge of the oftnes and diolutenes of the manners of this time, by the deire Men have to render themelves as like Women as they can, by wearing (like them) much Hair and little Beard: For when Men wore horter Hair, long Beards were in requet; and when the Hair ha's been long, the Beards have almot ever been hort; the length of the one recompencing the brevity of the other, which would otherwie render Men hideous.

The Third aid. If ever 'twas true that Cutom is a Tyrant, 'tis in this Cae, no variation having been o much as in matter of Hair. The Scythians and Parthians wore both Hair and Beard long, thereby to terrifie their Enemies. The Greeks, whoe Hair is much commended by Homer, kept it long, to ditinguih themelves from their laves, who were horn, as at preent are Galley-laves, Artizans, and Monaticks for Humility; whom alo Peter Lombard, Bihop of Paris, caus'd to have their Hair and Beard in the year 1160, according to the 44th Canon of the Fourth Council of Carthage, which forbids Clerks to wear either Locks or Beards. The Aegyptians wear their Hair long, and have off their Beards. The Maxii, a people of Africa, are horn on one ide of the Head, and let the Hair grow on the other. The Abaudi, had the fore-part onely haven, the Antii contrary. The Arabians have even their Daughters round about, leaving a Lock on the top. The Armenians have their Hair into the form of a Cros; but there is omething more majetical in the Beard than in the Hair, and even Animals furniht there-with, eem to have ome ort of gravity more than others. Hence uch as have affected the title of Wie, have likewie uffer'd their Beards to grow; but the Ephori made the Lacedemonians cut theirs, as alo Alexander and many Captains did their Souldiers, let their Enemies might catch hold of them. But as the caprichio of perons of authority, epecially Courtiers, gives the firt model of fahions, particularly, as to Hair and Beard; o to wear hort Hair now every one's reaches to his wate; or a magiterial pade Beard, now all are cloe haven,
(except uch whoe Age and Condition exempts them from this Rule) were for a Man to make himelf taken notice of, for things which bring no commendation: which hath no place in dicreet Minds, but argues a phantatical and humorome peron, who is commonly appointed contrary to the Modes; whereof the preent continually out-vie the Antient.

The Fourth aid, Hair, which is rather the leavs and boughs, than (as Plato held) the roots of Man's Body, (which he terms a Tree revers'd) having been chiefly deign'd for preervation of the Brain from External Injuries; they who would have care of their Health, mut conult the Contitution of their Brain before they determine either for long or hort Hair. Cold and Moit Brains, need tore of Hair to fence off the cold Air; Hot and Dry, the contrary. As for the Hair of the Chin, it was deign'd onely for Ornament, and a Tetimony of the Authority which the Male hath above the Female; whence that part eemeth omewhat acred, it being an Injury to touch one's Beard, of which the Emperor Otho made uch account, that according to Cupinian, he was wont to wear by his own. The proportion of it ought to follow the model of others of like condition; Wie Men following the advice of the greatet number in matters indifferent, provided they be not contrary to Honety and Health.

div.head: CONFERENCE CL. VVhether Alterations of States have natural Caues.
div.p:
STates being compos'd of Realms or Provinces, thee of Cities and Towns, thee of Families, thee of particular Perons, and each Peron having Natural Caues; 'tis clear that the Alteration of the Whole is to be attributed to the ame Caues which make the change of its parts. Thus when all the Houes of a Town are afflicted with Petilence, or conum'd by Fire, (which Accidents are capable of producing great Mutations in a Common-wealth) it cannot be otherwie expres'd, but by aying, that the Town is burnt or wated by the Plague. And as when the particular uffrages of each Counellor tend to the abolution or condemnation of a Criminal, 'twere eneles to ay, that the Sentence of the Court were other than that of the Preident and Counellors; o alo it is ridiculous to ay, that the Caues of peronal mutations are Natural, but not thoe of Political. As therefore 'tis almot the ole demontration we have in Phyicks, that our Bodies are chang'd and corrupted, becaue they are compos'd of the four Elements; in like ort, I conceive, the Caue of alteration befalling the body of a State, is to be ought in the Collection of the everal members that compoe it; which
coming to loe the harmony, proportion, and repect which made them ubit, they are diolv'd and corrupted; which is a mutation, purely natural, and of abolute neceity.

The Second aid, If God hath reerv'd any thing to his own dipoal, 'tis that of Crowns and the preervation of States, which are the firt and univeral Caues of the afety of every particular peron. Whence the transferring of thoe Crowns, from one State to another, which is a greater mytery, is a mutation purely upernatural; as not onely God himelf hath manifeted, when he ubjected the State of the Iraelites firt to Judges and Captains, which was a kind of Aritocracy, and afterwards to Kings reducing them to a Monarchy; but alo all uch as have wrought great changes in States of the World: And Legilators knowing this belief imprinted in all Men's Minds, have affected the Reputation of being decended from, or favor'd by ome Deity, as did Alexander the Great, and Numa Pompilius. Moreover, the Holy Scripture attributes to God the changing of Scepters, and frequently tyles him the God of Battels, the winning and loing whereof, are the mot common and manifet Caues of the change of States. And 'tis a pure effect of the Divine Will, that Men born free, ubject themelves to the Will of one ole or few perons; o the changing of that Inclination, cannot proceed but from Him who is the earcher of Hearts, and gives us both to will and to do. If Natural Caues had their effects, as certain in Politicks as in Phyicks, States hould have their limited durations, as Plants and Animals have: and yet there is uch a diproportion in the duration of all States, pat and preent, that one hath lated above 1200. years, (as the French Monarchy, whoe flourihing State promies as many more Ages, if the World continue o long) and another hath chang'd its Form everal times in one yeat, as Florence. Upon which conideration, the greatet Politicians have put their States under the Divine Protection, and caus'd all their Subjects to venerate ome particular Angel or tutelar Saint. Thus France acknowledges Saint Michael for its Protector; Spain, Saint James; Venice, Saint Mark; and even the Ethnicks thought that a City, (much les a State) could not be detroy'd till the Deity preiding over it were remov'd. Whence Homer makes the Palladium of Troy, carry'd away by lyes, before the Greeks could become Maters of it.

The Third aid, The Supream Caue exercies its Omnipotence in the Rie, Conervation, and Detruction of States, as well as every where ele; yet hinders not ubordinate Caues from producing their certain Effects, natural in things natural, (as in the Life and Death of Men, which though one of the mot notorious Effects of God's Power, and attributed to him by the Scripture and all the World, yet ceaeth not to have its infallible and natural demontrations.) Inlike manner, ubordinate Moral Caues, produce their Moral and contingent Effects in Moral Things, uch as that in Quetion is which Caues, depending
upon Humane Actions which arie from our Will, no-wie neceitated but free, cannot be term'd natural and contrain'd, unles either by thoe that ubject all things here below to Detiny, which ubverts the liberty of the Will (that is, makes it no longer a Will) or thoe who will have not only the manners of the Soul, but alo the actions always to follow the temperament of the Body; which were hard to conceive, and yet would not infer a neceity in the alteration of States, ince the effects of Love and Hatred, and other paions which give inclination or averion are oftentimes prevented by thwarting caues. When the Lacedemonians chang'd the popular State of Athens into an Aritocracy of thirty Lords, whom they call'd afterwards the thirty Tyrants, no other caue can be aign'd thereof but the chance of War, which ubjected the will of the Athenians to that of the Lacedemonians: And the ame may be aid of all other ancient and modern Revolutions. Indeed, if the caues in Policy had regular effects, or States were ubject to natural declinations. Prudence, which is converant about contingent things to manage them freely and alter its coure according to occaion, hould ignifie nothing. 'Tis more credible that as in the tate of Grace God hath left our actions to the dipoal of Free-will, that we may work out our Salvation our elves; o in the adminitration of Republicks he hath left mot things to chance, for imploying men's indutry according to their will, whoe motions being free and contingent, are diametrically oppoite to the neceity of natural caues.

The Fourth aid, That thee alterations may be, though voluntary, yet natural, yea neceary too; our Will being as inclin'd to apprehended good, as our Intellect is to Truth. As therefore knowing this truth that 2 and 2 are 4, 'tis impoible but I mut believe it; o, knowing that uch an action will bring me good, I hall do it: o that the caues of humane actions have omthing of neceity, and (beides) having their foundation in nature may in ome ort be term'd natural. Moreover, ince things are preerv'd by their like and detroy'd by their contraries (which contraries are under the ame genus) it follows that all ublunary things having had a natural beginning mut alo have a like end. Deire of elf-preervation, which is natural, gave birth to States; but if, intead of this deire which renders Servants obedient to their Maters, thee to the Magitrate, and him to the Sovereign, Rebellion and Treaon deprive their Chiefs of the uccour they expect from them, and by this means expoes the State in prey to the Enemies, it cannot but fall to ruine; unles that ome other natural caue, Perwaion (as that of Menenius Agrippa taken from the humane body, upon a Seceion of the Mechanicks of Rome from the Senate) or an exemplary punihment reduce the Subjects to their foraken duty. Whereby it appears that the State reumes its firt vigor by as enible and natural caues, as 'tis to be perwaded,
or become wie by others harm. Amongt many examples, the ruines of Troy and Thebes were caus'd by the rape of Helene whom the injutice of the Trojans deny'd to retore to her Huband, and the feud of two. Brothers apiring to the ame Royalty: then which no caues can be aign'd more natural and more necearily inferring the los of a State.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLI. Which is more healthful, to become warm by the Fire or by Exercie.
div.p: THey who quetion the neceity of Fire for recalefying our Bodies chill'd by cold the enemy of our natural heat, deerve the rude treatment of the ancient Romans to their banih'd perons, whom they expell'd no otherwie from their City but by interdicting them the ue of Fire and Water; knowing that to want either was equally impoible. Without Fire our Bodies would be oon depriv'd of life which reides in heat, as cold is the effect and ign of death. And as Aritotle aith, thoe that deny Vertue would not be otherwie diputed with but by cating them into the fire; o would not I otherwie punih thoe that decry it, but by expoing them to freez in midwinter, intead of burning a faggot for them. What could little Children and old people do without it? For though the natural heat be of another kind then that of our material fire, yet this ometimes aits that in uch ort that thoe who diget ill are much comforted by it, not to mention weak perons and thoe that are ubject to woonings. Moreover, the external cold mut be remov'd by an external heat, as Fire is, which heats only what part and to what degree you pleae; but motion heats all alike. As the Sun (which ome Philoophers take to be the Elemental-fire) contributes to the Generation, o doth Fire concur to the conervation of Man; not by immediate contact, but by the heat which it communicates to the Air and the Air to our Body, which by approaching or receding from it, tempers its exces in dicretion, and thereby renders it utable to our natural heat, not detroying Bodies but in its highet degree; as alo the Sun offends thoe at Noon whom it refrehes at riing and etting.

The Second aid, That the violent action of Fire which detroys all ublunary Bodies, argues its diproportion with our natural heat; which diproportion renders the Stoves and places heated artificially by Fire o noxious, and makes uch as love the Chimney-corner almot always tender, cabby, and impatient
of the leat inclemency of the Air; that heat againt nature not only detroying the natural but corrupting the humors and exiccating the parts. But the bodies of Plants and Animals inur'd onely to natural heat are far more vigorous, whilt the ame is ecured againt external cold by Bark, Hair and Skin, and thoe defenive Arms which Intinct taught our Fore-fathers o long as they were guided by Nature, in Caves of the Earth which moderate the injuries of the Air much better then humane Art can do; or ele by thick clothing which reflects the fumes inceantly iuing out of the pores of the Body; from which repercuion, proceeds the warmth of our Garments. If cold happen at any time to over-mater the natural heat in the external parts, the ame is preently reviv'd (but diipated by fire, before which infirm perons frequently fall into fainting fits) by motion and exercie which heats all Bodies, and much more uch as are animated, driving the Spirits and Blood (and with them heat) into the agitated part. Of the benefit of which motion we cannot judge more certainly then by its effects. For as Fire takes away the Appetite and dulls the Senes of thoe that it at it, o Exercie encreaes it and renders the Body and Mind much more lively. Wherefore I conclude for Exercie againt Fire, without which a late Phyician liv'd twenty years, eeing no other but that of his Candle, and without employing his Wood, as Sylvius did who run up and down Stairs laden with two or three Fagots, more or les according as he was cold, till he was warm, and then he laid them up till another time.

The Third aid, Exercie is not more profitable to uch as are accutom'd to it, then hurtful to others. Which Sedentary perons find true when they play at Tennis, or Hunt, or ue uch other violent motion. For every ort of motion is not Exercie, but only that which is perform'd with ome treining, whereby repiration is render'd more frequent, the Arteries dilated, the Spirits and blood chaf'd, whence oftentimes they break their veels, and beget Fevers, Pleuries, Fluxes, Head-aches and Catarrhs: which is a manifet proof that 'tis better to leave the Humors and Spirits in their natural temper. For Health conits in a jut proportion of the Humors, which are generated by the Concoction of temperate and moderate Food; which Concoction is perform'd better during ret then during motion, and in the leep of the night then in the labour of the day. So alo are excrements better expell'd when the Body is quiet then when 'tis in motion, which brings a confuion of pure with impure; Inenible tranpiration is ufficiently effected only by the internal motion of Nature without the help of external, which Nature hath not precrib'd Animals, although they have no need of Fire, being naturally Furr'd, Feather'd, and otherwie guarded againt the injuries of weather, and yet their age is almot as regular as that of immovable Plants. Man, on the
contrary, by reaon chiefly of his everal violent exercies hath no prefix'd time of life, which labour (ineparable from exercie) wears and conumes more then his years, and makes him old before his time, depriving him alo of that contentment and pleaure which makes us live. Moreover, ince things are preerv'd and acquir'd by the ame caues, lot health which is recover'd by ret and the bed, cannot be preerv'd by travel; which, beides conuming our radical moiture wifter then the natural heat doth alone, hath the ame effect that motion hath in a lighted Candle which is ooner pent when tirr'd then when at quiet.

The Fourth aid, That ince Fire introduces into us a foreign and contranatural heat, as beides the inconveniences already alledg'd, the weating of the head tetifies, 'tis more hurtful then Exercie, which only roues up the natural heat enfeebled by the apertion of the pores caus'd by the Fire in Winter and the Sun in Summer, when for that reaon Exercie ought to be les. The incommodity Exercie brings to unaccutom'd Bodies ought not to hinder their being form'd thereto by little and little, and by the degrees recommended by Hippocrates in all changes. For if Phyicians contribute all their kill to correct ditempers drawn from the birth, much rather may they endeavour to turn bad cutoms into good; as being an eaier tak. Thus Galen was not accutom'd to cleave wood, nor Pittacus King of the Mytelenians to grind corn, yet they exercis'd themelves in thee labours for their health. And indeed ome Maladies, as thoe which proceed from a cold and moit ditemper, are cur'd by exercie; epecially if they come from repletion. Thus Nicomachus of Smyrna was o montrouly fat that he could not put his hand behind him, yet was brought to a moderate bulk by Exercie. On the contrary, Germanicus whoe legs were omewhat too lender brought them to a competent proportion by Riding; the concuions whereof hake the Stone out of the Kidneys. Recovering perons need Exercie o much, according to their trength that 'tis the mot afe means of retoring it, and old men are chiefly preerv'd by it. Antiochus the Phyician and Spurnia, both of them 80 years old, preerv'd their Senes and trength, entire by walking a great way every day on foot. And yet Fire is les hurtful in that age by reaon of the coldnes and thicknes of the kin which gives not its heat o free entrance, nor o eaie an iue to that within.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLII. Whether Wine helps or hinders Digetion, and why?
div.p: THis Quetion will eem frivolous to the vulgar, who are no ooner debarr'd Wine by the Phyitian, but they complain of Indigetion and weaknes of Stomack. But our free Philoophy hall ue its own rights, and inquire, whether the common Opinion in this Point be the bet. Now if Wine, which is hot, and acknowledg'd uch by all Phyitians, be receiv'd into a temperate Stomack, it brings it into a ditemper, whence Saint Paul enjoyn'd it not to Timothy, but in regard of the coldnes or weaknes of his Stomack, in which cae a due temper reults from the one cold, and the other hot. But temperate perons mut avoid it's ue, which was a jut caue of Divorce to the Roman Dames, capital in the Camp of the Carthaginians, and till in divers parts of Aia; whereunto if you add, all thoe that are depriv'd of it, becaue they have none produc'd amongt them, Children and ick perons, it will appear that (to ay nothing of Beats, which drink onely water, and are more healthy than we) there are a hundred live without it for one that drinks it. Moreover, they who are troubled with Indigetions, find and make others ufficiently undertand, that Wine is lat digeted; otherwie it would not keep its firt colour, avor, and mell, after all other food, or at leat onely alter'd by the acidity into which 'tis eaily corrupted. Beides, Water-drinkers have a better Appetite than Wine-drinkers, which is an Argument that Wine helps Concoction les then Water; and no wonder, ince, as Galen aith, it increaes Thirt intead of quenching it as Water doth. For Thirt, which is the Appetite of Cold and Moit, cannot be extinguih'd by Wine, which is Hot, and o more apt to inflame it. The Life of the firt Patriarch, before the ue of Wine, namely, before the Deluge, was much longer than it hath been ince; and, no doubt, the principal defect in Man, and the Caue of mot Dieaes, is bad Digetion.

The Second aid, That Digetion being perform'd by the conflux of Spirits elaborated in the Spleen, and Wine which is more pirituous, and conequently, furnihes more matter for our Spirits than any other Aliment, cannot but powerfully promote the ame. Which clearly appears by old men, in whom Wine hath the ame Effect that Milk hath in Children, and preerves thee latter from Worms. Whence poibly Hippocates gave it not onely in Quotidian, but alo in Continual Fevers; the hurtfulnes to be fear'd from its heat, were it conjoyn'd with drynes, being ecur'd by its humidity, which makes it ymbolize with blood. Yet all Wines are not hot; mall green Wines, epecially the White and Sharp, have more of coldnes than of heat; and
other Wines drunk in mall quantity with much water, refreh more than water alone, becaue opening the Pores, they ininuate into the remote parts, which plain water preently cloes. Yea, Wine, as hot, is a friend to the Stomack and Bowels, whoe membranous ubtance being cold and dry, needs the contrary qualities of Wine; wherefore Wine helps Digetion, which water hinders, being indigetible it elf, and o unable to give what it hath not. God's dicovering Wine to Men after the Flood, as a remedy to the defect, left thereby in all Creatures erving for their food, being rather an evidence of its utility than hurtfulnes. And there is as little reaon to accue it of hortning our dayes, as Guaicum of cauing the Pox, upon pretence that the ue thereof was not known till that Malady appearing, needed it for its Cure.

The Third aid, That the ole reaon of the difficulty we find in digeting Wine, is the great reemblance of its qualities with thoe of Blood, both being Hot and Moit. But there can be no proper Phyical Action without contrariety. For ince every principal Agent induces Alteration in the ubject which receives its Action, this change cannot be effected, but by depriving it of its former State, and the qualities which maintain'd the ame. Which cannot be done, but by conteting with, and detroying them by contrary qualities; and o according to more or les contrariety, the Action is tronger or weaker. Hence in the Digetion of Aliment, which is a proper Phyical Action, wherein the Natural Heat detroyes the Food, in order to turn it into another Form, there mut be contrariety; and uch Food as ha's leat, gives the Heat leat hold to work againt it; it not being eaie for the Natural Heat and Moiture to act againt an Aliment Hot and Moit, by reaon of the reemblance between them; as a Friend hardly combats and detroyes his Friend. Wherefore Wine being of the ame quality, our Heat becoms idle in order to its Concoction. Poibly too, its abundance of Spirits make it hard to be digeted, tifling the Spirits employ'd for Concoction, by reaon of the too great reemblance between thoe of the one and the other.

The Fourth aid, That onely a diproportionate quantity of Wine is of difficult Digetion, a mall quantity promoting it. Which holds good in all repletions, but, particularly, of Wine; which relaxing the Fibres and Tunicles of the Stomack, weakens the Retentive Faculty, provokes the Expulive by its Acrimony, either in the Superior Orifice, whence arie Hick-cocks; or in the Inferior, whence proceed loathings and vomitings. Therefore the Apotle aith, Drink a little (not drink much) Wine. Nor would the inconvenience be les, if the bet Aliments in the World were taken in Exces. For when their mas is too great to be contring'd and embrac'd by the Stomack, the Natural Heat is it elf alter'd intead of over-matering that, in order to Aimilation.

The Fifth aid, That the Quetion is to be determin'd by the difference of Wines and Stomacks. Strong Wines, uch as are weet and piquant, are improper for Hot and Cholerick Stomacks which mut have only mall green Wines, or other beverages of neer quality to common water. On the contrary, Phlegmatick and Cold Stomacks, and Melancholy Tempers, are trengthened by Wine, but prejudic'd by water and other cold drinks; not that Heat is the caue of Digetion, (for the hotter a Fever is, the more it hinders the ame) but becaue 'tis a Medium, whereof our Natural Heat erves it elf.

The Sixth aid. That indeed the diverity of Subjects makes ome change in the Hypotheis, yet hinders not but we may pronounce upon the Theis; whether Wine helps or hurts Digetion. I believe the latter; becaue Digetion cannot be perform'd, unles all the Meats of one meal be digeted at the ame time; ele the Chyle will be, part well elaborated (namely, that made of the Food which hath had a convenient tay in the Stomack) and part too much concoct and adut, made of that which tay'd in the Stomack too long and after Digetion; and part alo too little, proceeding from Meats requiring more Concoction, and yet hurried away with the ret. Now 'tis certain, that Wine being ooner digeted than other Aliments, by the authority of Hippocrates and Galen, (who hold, that it awages Thirt, and is ditributed ooner than they) it will produce a confuion and hotch-potch in the nature of the Chyle, which hould be uniform. But Water erving only for a Vehicle, agrees better with variety of Meats, being like the Mentruum of the Chymits, and the Uniting Medium of the Lullits, which erves to re-unite all different Bodies into one alone, patiently attending their dipoition without corrupting, (as Wine and Vinegar doth) and without leaving behind in the Kidneys the tartar, or lee of Wine, which is the eed of the Stone, where-with Water-drinkers are not o commonly troubled; partly, for the aboveaid reaon, and partly, becaue that tartar is not dry'd in them, as having les Heat than others.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLIII. Why 'tis colder at Day-break than at any other time of the Night or Day.
div.p:
IF Cold be a real quality, then the greater ditance there happens to be between it and the Source of Heat and Light, (the Sun) the greater mut the Cold be. And if it be only a privation of Heat, then mid-night is darker then either the Evening or Morning, becaue oppos'd directly to the Light of the Sun, it may eem that the Cold ought be greater likewie at that time,
becaue the ame is oppoite to Noon, when the Sun's Heat is greatet; yet the cool of the Morning argues the contrary, being o ordinary that it fore-tells Day-break more certainly, than the crowing of the Cock. Unles you will attribute the caue to this, that at Morning before Sun-rie 'tis longer ince the Sun inlightned the Horizon, than at mid-night; at which time the Air and other Elements, till retain ome of the preceding Day's Heat, which tempering the Cold, occaion'd by the Sun's abence, renders the ame les perceptible during the thicknes of the Nocturnal Air, les ubtile than that of the Day; when the Light coming to diipate thoe Clouds, ubtilizes the Air by its ininuating beams; whence the Cold thereof more eaily ininuates into our Pores by the help of that weak Light, which is not trong enough to heat the Air. Jut as Vinegar, though hot and biting of its own Nature, yet mix'd with much water, cooles the part whereunto 'tis apply'd more than water alone doth.
