The Second aid, That poibly the comparion of the Heat of our beds, (out of which we arie in the Morning) with the cold of the outward Air, makes us guilty of a mitake; unles you had rather refer this Effect to the Oblique Apect where-with the other Celetial Bodies of our Hemiphere are regarded by the Sun at his riing. For at mid-night when he is directly under the Horizon, the little bulk of the Earth hinders not, but he directly darts his Rayes upon thoe Stars which are above us, the Pyramid of the Earth's hadow not paing beyond the Moon; o that then the vat and incredible magnitude of all thoe Celetial Bodies perpendicularly reflects upon us the Heat and Light of the Sun, which thus reflected may calefie the Air, as the Sun doth in the ame poture; but not at all at Sun-rie in their Oblique Apects: Whence though the Sun be nearer us in Winter, yet he warms us les. If it be excepted, that the Evening, when the ame Oblique Apects return, is not o cold as the Night; 'tis anwer'd, that this difference proceeds from the Heat of the foregoing Day, remaining in the Earth, Water, and Air, which conerve the ame, till by the abence of the Sun the upervening Night wholly diipate them.

The Third aid, That the Matutinal coolnes proceeded from the approaching Suns driving the Clouds before him, which agitation raieth a wind (as there is always one at day-break) whereby the ame coolnes is effected in the Air that a Fan caueth to a Lady. For all things here below having their motion from Eat to Wet, 'tis reaonable that the Air be o mov'd too, and acquire the conequent of its agitation, namely, coldnes. That all things come from the Eat, undry intances manifet; Mankind was from thence diffus'd into the other Quarters of the World; Rivers run generally Eatward; And the greater peed of Navigation from Eat to Wet, than contrarily, argnes the Sea to have the ame motion; as is chiefly oberv'd under the
Equinoctial, the greatnes of which Circle renders that motion more manifet. This rule the Winds keep, when not diverted to a contrary coure by Exhalations: And as for the Heavens, experience hews us, that their ordinary and bet-known coure is from Eat to Wet: So that 'tis no wonder if they hurry the neighbouring Air with them, and by a Mathematical contact and natural conecution, all the other Elements. I peak not of Sciences, Arts, Policy, and other things which the more curious may find to have been deriv'd from the Eat. It uffices that the Sun taking this road drives the Air befor him; the wind proceeding from which motion, caueth the coolnes we feel chiefly at day-break; when the vapours between us and the Sun being by his heat violently driven (as the water of the Aeolipila is turn'd into wind and driven forth by the ubjacent fire) the coolnes is more unacceptable, in that it ucceeds and multiplies (intead of diminihing) that of the night, as the diurnal heat in likelihood ought to do.

The Fourth aid, He attributed the increae of cold at day-break to the ordinary action of all natural Agents, which is tronget when they arrive at the period or utmot point of their declination. So a Candle jut upon extinguihing cats forth a marter flame; the violence of a Dieae is greatet at its criis, when 'tis towards ending; a Stone moves wiftet as it approacheth its Centre. And to compare the Year to the Day, the cold is commonly greater and more inupportable in February, the lat Moneth of Winter, than in the beginning thereof; though in reaon it might eem rather to be o at the end of December, when the Sun is further from us, and that the cutom of the two firt months cold hould render this lat more tolerable; as on the contrary, the heat is greater alo in the dog-days, and afterwards, than at the Summer Soltice, when the Sun is elevated highet above our heads. So alo in Summer 'tis hotter two hours after noon, than at noon it elf; not o much through any dipoition already received in the Air and Earth, as by reaon of that Rule, That Natural Actions are tronger at the end than the beginning; whereas violent actions, as the motion of a Stone upwards, is wifter in the beginning than the end.

The Fifth referr'd this effect to the Antiperitais of heat and cold. For as fire eems more corching upon the approach of a great frot, o by a contrary reaon cold mut become more vehement at the approach of the Sun's heat. Moreover, the like combat is oberv'd between the thicknes of the darknes of the night, and the rarity of the day, when the Sun's light rendring the illuminated Air more ubtle, what was gros in the dark Air cannot be expell'd in an intant without ome conflict and motion of the part condens'd by darknes with the rarefi'd by light; from which agitation arieth a wind commonly at day-break, which is probably the caue of the cold at that time. Now of that tenebrous part condens'd is made the Dew and Frot in our
Climate, and the Manna in Southern Countries; as the cold which we feel redoubled in Winter in the pace between a neighbouring fire (but out of its Sphere of Activity) and the ret of the Air, is a familiar example of this Antiperitais of heat and cold redoubled upon the approach one of the other. For as 'tis much colder then elewhere, between that fire which is too ditant to warm us, and the Air left in its natural frigidity; o at day-break our Air being too far off from the Sun to be heated by it, augments its coldnes upon his approach.

The Sixth aid, Air hath no natural quality but upream humidity, whereby 'tis upple, movable, and pliant; heat and cold being impres'd upon it by outward agents: Otherwie being the general medium and mediator of motions local, natural, vital and animal (for the Spirits are of an aerious nature) and the Factor of all Agents by whoe intervention they communicate their influences, it would act againt the qualities impres'd upon it, ometimes hot and ometimes cold, and detroy them by its own. Which indeed its humidity doth, but to the profit of animated bodies; drynes being their enemy. Hence cold and dry Saturn hath under him, hot and moit Jupiter, who tempers his hurtfulnes and utes him to living things. Now the Sun having at the declining of the day rais'd many aqueous, and conequently upreamly cold, and the heat whereby they were rais'd abandoning them upon his abence, the natural cold of thoe vapours becomes predominant, and returns them by degrees into their firt tate. Which refrigerating the Air makes the night the colder, the further the vapours are from their extraneous heat, that is to ay, the nearer day approacheth.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLIV. Whence the whitenes of Snow proceeds.
div.p:
THe firt attributed the caue thereof to the deiccation of water; for experience hews in all ublunary Bodies that drynes whitens, as Sea-water becomes white when dry'd to Salt, the talks of Corn, Pule and the leaves of all other Plants wax white as they wither and dry. The ame happens to the Bones of Animals, and grey Hairs, on no other caue but iccity, ince the extremity expos'd to the Air is white, but not the root. Hence water by its tranparence already partaking much of light (but which its rarity reflects not to our view) is no ooner deiccated into Ice, Hail, or Snow, but it acquires this pure whitenes, which humidity again detroys. So the high ways white with dut grow black upon rain; a wet cloth appears darker then a dry; and that ome things become black by drying (as
Coal) is becaue there was heat enough to draw the humidity, which was at its Centre, to the Circumference, but not enough wholly to dry it up, as appears in that the ame heat continu'd reduces the coal to white ahes which would be as perfectly white as Snow, did not the Tincture imprinted thereon by the Salts withtand it; for if you urge them further by fire, you will make them of a perfect whitenes; as appears in Chalks, which are made not only of grey and black tones, but even of Metals, as Cerue is made of Lead.

The Second aid, Whitenes is not a real Colour, ince it appears in all bodies depriv'd of preceding Colours, of all which 'tis indifferently uceptible. But 'tis otherwie with real Colours, a ubject imbu'd with one of which is not apt to receive all others but ome only; as Nature hath fram'd the Organs of Sene naked of all enible objects, to the end they might be uceptible of the ame. Wooll dy'd into a adder colour cannot receive a lighter, and black Wooll admits none at all; but white, being natural to every ubject that hath no colour, is capable of receiving all: So when you wah off the blew or dirty colour of a Band, it becomes white. Whereby it appears, that Whitenes hath the ame reference to Colours that Unity hath to Numbers whereof 'tis the beginning, but is none it elf. And as 'tis the Emblem of Innocence and Purity, o alo it proceeds from them. The Air, which is the puret of our Elements (for Fire is only in Mixts) and water refin'd into vapours, which follows the Air in purity, hapning to acquire viibility by condenation into Snow, cannot repreent the ame under any other out-ide but Whitenes. Now that Whitenes is an effect of purity, is manifet by the Stars, which are repreented to us only under the pecies of Whitenes, and cannot be painted but with white in their light, which de-albating what it irradiates, and leaving the ame elewhere black, hews that 'tis as the puret, o alo the whitet thing in the world. Likewie Metals are whiter according to their purity; Lead is wore then Tin, and this then Silver only upon account of their impurity; the ole perfect mixture of the yellow incombutible Sulphur of Gold not permitting it to be alter'd and poil'd of its yellow colour which nearet approacheth whitenes. Wherefore Snow being a mot pure Body, compounded only of two colour-les elements, namely, Air and Water, 'twas neceary either that it hould have no colour, or if any (whereby to become viible) the principle and origin of all Colours, namely White, in the perfection with which Nature makes all her Works.

The Third aid, That the ame difference which appears between the Stars and their Orbs, is found between Water and Snow, ariing only from Denity and Rarity. As the Star appears white, and the ret of the Heaven darker by reaon of its rarity; o likewie Water eems obcure upon account of its rarity, and Snow white upon that of its denity.

The Fourth aid, If that reaon were good, then Ice hould be whiter then Snow, becaue 'tis more olid; and yet the contrary appears. Beides Snow is o far from being more dene and olid then Water, that on the contrary, there is les Air in Water then in Ice, which is more cloe and compact then Snow; the wimming of Ice upon the Water arguing ome aerious parts included in it at the time of its congelation, which is not and cannot be made without air, Wherefore Snow differs from Water only by its figure or accidental form, which reduceth it into flocks congealed by cold in a cloud (not as it is reolv'd into Rain, for then 'twould prove Hail) but whilt yet a vapour in the region of the Air. So then in this figure alone is the reaon of the whitenes of Snow to be ought; which is not found in water, partly by reaon of its tranparence, and partly becaue its mooth urface gives no hold to the viual ray. Which is the reaon why Water is pictur'd with a blew and darkih colour. Thus burnih'd Silver as that of Looking-glaes eems dark if compar'd to rough Silver, which doth not diipate our viual Spirits as that former doth. Hence Ice is much whiter then water, as being les mooth.

The Fifth aid, That 'tis proper to cold to whiten, as 'tis to heat to blacken. Thus Southern People are either black, or tawney; Northern, white: and the Hair of both grows white with old age by reaon of the coldnes thereof. All the cold parts of our Body are white; as the Brain, Bones, Cartilages, Membranes, Fat and Skin. Linen and Wax are whitened by the coldnes of the night. For the ame reaon, not only Snow but Hail, Frot, Ice, Rime, and all other cold Meteors are of the ame colour.

The Sixth aid, That though the whitenes of Snow was diputed by Anaxagoras, and Armenia produces red by mixture of the exhalations of Vermillion with the ordinary vapors which the Sun raies from the water; yet this whitenes is as manifet as the caues are hid, no les then thoe of light, which is the colour of Celetial Bodies, as colours are the light of Terretrial. However, this whitenes eems to proceed from a mixture of Air and Water, as appears in froth, whoe conitence is like that of Snow, the whitenes whereof, poibly, is increas'd by the Spirits wherewith Snow abounds, which are luminous Bodies, whereof the fertility caus'd by Snow is an Argument; to which Spirits, (which Frot hath not) may be acrib'd what Galen affirms, namely, that Fih cover'd with Snow become more delicious; for to the Moon it can with no more reaon be referr'd than to the Sun.

The Seventh aid, That an univocal and certain caue of whitenes cannot be found in the firt or econd Qualities: Not in Heat or Cold; ince Snow, Sugar, and Salt are equally white, though the firt is cold, the econd temperate, and the third hot: Nor in Siccity or Humidity; ince humid Milk is no les white
than dry Chalk and Plater. The denity and weight of Silver, the rarity and levity of Snow, the weetnes of Sugar, and the acrimony of Salt; in hort, the examen of all other Second Qualities of white things, hews that it depends not on them. Nor yet on the third: for white Agarick is purgative; white Starch, and flowr of Beans, atringent. Latly, what ome call Fourth Qualities, or Properties of the whole Subtance, depend as little upon Colours, ince the ame whitenes which is in the Meal that nourihes us, is alo in the Sublimate that kills us. It remains to inquire the reaon of Colours, and conequently, of Whitenes in the proportion between the Sight and the Surface of the colour'd body. When therefore it happens that the Viual Ray, which iues forth pure and white, that is to ay, colour-les, finds no Colour in a Surface; if the ame be Diaphanous, it takes it for a Medium not an Object; (as is een in Glas, Crytal, Air, and Water); if opake, it tops at the aid Surface; and finding no Colour thereon, returns with the Species of the Object to make its report to the Common Sene that it aw nothing; and this is what they call Whitenes. Hence, White o little delights the Sight, that it digregates and wearies it; as a fale troke doth that brings nothing. Now to apply this to Snow, the Viual Ray is indeed topt by its condens'd Surface; but whence hould it have Colour, ince 'tis compos'd of Air and Water, both colourles? The Truth is, utably to its Principles, it mut necearily remain without Colour, that is, White, whereby it o digregates the Viual Rayes that ometimes it blinded a whole Army.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLV. Whether Courage be natural or acquir'd.
div.p:
COurage being the Contempt of Danger, which we naturally fear, we cannot be naturally courageous; for then two contrary Effects hould proceed from the ame Caue. But the Truth is, our Nature is indifferent to every thing whereunto it is lead and fahion'd. Thus, kittih Hores are made ober by inuring to the noie of Mukets, which before they could not endure. On the contrary, brave Courers kept in a dark Stable and unemploy'd, become rety and jadih. Moreover, ince there is no true Courage without Knowledge of the Danger, (whence Fools and Drunkards cannot be tyl'd courageous) this argues that this Virtue hath need of Rules and Precepts, as without which, our Knowledge cannot but be very imperfect. Nor did any thing render the Romans more valiant than the Nations they ubdu'd, but Military Dicipline; wherein the Roman Legionary
under-went his Apprentiage, as other Artificers do in their Trades: Which Intruction, ome of their Decendents depiing, have hewn thereby what difference there is between themelves and their Ancetours, and determin'd this Quetion to the advantage of Indutry. At this day our Souldiers are not more trong and courageous than Town-people; and the Officers whom alone we ee perform all the brave Actions, urpas not in Courage ordinary Souldiers, aving that thee have not been o well intructed as they, and reflect not o much upon the hame and los which they incurr by Cowardize. And becaue that Courage is greatet, which makes us contemne the greatet dangers; hence that which leads us to the Contempt of Death, the mot terrible of all things, is, undoubtedly, the greatet. But the Hitory of the Mileian Virgins is remarkable, who, upon the perwaions of a certain Orator, were, contrary to the natural timidity of their Sex, carry'd to o great a Contempt of Death, that nothing could retrain them from killing themelves, but the example of their Self-murder'd Companions drawn forth-with naked about the treets. Whereby it may be judg'd, how powerful Perwaion is to encourage us: Which Captains and Generals of Armies are not ignorant of, who employ all their Rhetorick to impres Audacity in their Souldiers breats, upon an aault or a battel; and thoe that have been in uch encounters, affirm, that nothing conduces more either to inflame the Courage of Brave Men, or infue it into uch as have none, than an Exhortation well apply'd and uted to the Minds of thoe that are to be encourag'd; ometimes by the Memory of their former Gallant Actions; ometimes by thoe of their Enemies Cowardice; ometimes by the greatnes of the Danger, and the inevitable ruine they incurr in cae of turning their backs; but commonly, by the alvation of their Souls, and the good of their Country; and always by the fair pur of Honour and Glory: Coniderations directly oppoite to thoe dictated to us by Nature, which tend onely to preervation of the Individuall.

The Second aid, If Intruction made Men valiant and courageous, than all that receive the ame Education, learn in the ame Academy, and fight under the ame Captain, hould be equally courageous. Yet there is o notable a difference between them, that it cannot be imputed to any but Natural Caues; uch as are the tructure of the parts of the Body, the temper of the humors, the nimblenes or heavines of the Spirits, and epecially the diverity of Souls which inform our Bodies; which diverity is apparent even in Infancy, before the Corporeal Organs can be upected to be the Caue thereof. One Child is more timorous than another, and no ooner begins to go, but he beats his Companions, who uffer themelves to be beaten by one weaker than themelves; the firt, not quitting his hold for the rod, for which another will do more than you would have him.
The truth is, if the Soul be the Architect of her habitation, to her mut be imputed the Principal Caue of the variety found therein, upon that of our Actions viibly depends. For as every one readily addicts himelf to thoe employments and exercies of body and mind whereunto he is mot fit, and which he performs with mot eae; o he is more eaily lead to Actions of Courage, whoe Organs are bet dipos'd for the ame. And becaue Children commonly have ome-what of the Habit of Body, and Temper of their Parents, hence Courage eems to come by Decent; which poibly renders our Gentry o jealous of the Antiquity of their Families, in which they had rather find a Man beheaded for an Action that peaks Courage, than a Burges who had not liv'd in a noble way. Moreover, to judge well of Courage, we mut not conider it olely in Man, ince 'tis found o replendent in Animals incapable of Dicipline and Intruction, that the certainet Phyiognomical Rule whereby to judge of a Valiant Man, is taken from the imilitude or reemblance he hath with the Lyon, Bear, or other Beats of Courage. Which hews that the true and original Valour being in Animals, Precepts rather alter and pervert, than produce it in us. Hence the mot learned are oftimes the greatet Pultrons. For which reaons the Romans caus'd the warlike people whom they had ubdu'd, to decend from the Mountains into the Valleys, that by that means they might change their Nature. Indeed, thee Romans were better diciplin'd than the Nations whom they call'd barbarous, and by that means more eaily overcame them; but they were not the more courageous for that, he who is vanquih'd abating nothing of his Courage thereby: witnes King Porus, whoe Courage Alexander more admir'd for his refuing to eat, that o he might by dying avoid the hame of being overcome, than for the ingle fight to which he had challeng'd him. Officers out-do common Souldiers, becaue they have more to loe than they, and their Puillanimity would be more taken notice of. And the Speeches of Generals in a day of battel are not for the truly courageous, who need them not, but for the Cowards, who are encourag'd againt the fear of Death, by fale uggetions of the Enemies paucity, and their own number. Whereas true Courage, as Socrates aith in Xenophon, is not in thoe that fear not, becaue they ignore the danger, but in thoe who beholding it great, yet judge their own trength greater and thereupon preume of urmounting it; which Reolution is never learnt by Books or Precepts, but is inherent in the Mind.

The Third aid, That he was of the Opinion of Socrates, in the ame Xenophon, namely, that as ome Bodies are more robut, o alo ome Souls are better to undergo dangers. That nevertheles Intruction erves greatly to perfect Nature: Whence certain Nations cannot utain the aaults of others better train'd and accutom'd to manage ome ort of Arms. All the kinds whereof, both offenive and defenive, proceeding from
Humane Indutry, Nature alone mut not arrogate the advantage we have over other Animals; whoe Courage being by the help of Art urmounted by that of Man, as Art can do nothing without Nature; o the Courage which leads us to attaque and vanquih them, mut be acrib'd to Art, without which, Man durt not attaque them.

The Fourth aid, We mut ditinguih Courages according to the diverities of Subjects whereon they are employ'd. The highet Clas is that of perons, who freely offer themelves to certain death for their Religion, whether true or fale. So did amongt the Romans, Q. Curtius, who threw himelf into a Gulph to appeae the anger of the Gods; Metellus, who ran into the fire to fetch out the Statue of Minerva; and of Hereticks a great number, of whom Books are full. But this Martyrology hews us a greater number in the true Church; yet the Courage of o many Martyrs cannot be acrib'd to Nature alone, but to Perwaion, and to Faith. Next comes the Courage of thoe great Heroes, and illutrious Men of Antiquity, as David and his nine Worthies, Alexander the Great, the three Horatii and Curiatii, Caear, Cato, and many others, whom none can ay would have done thoe brave Actions, unles they had been lead thereunto by a noble deire of Glory, to which our Minds are carryed onely by Reaons, Precepts, and Examples; and conequently, their Courage may be judg'd rather acquir'd than natural. Latly, Courage is found in all Callings and Employments. A Miniter, or Counellor of State, a Divine, and a Judge, acquire the Title of Courageous, when they reolutely perform the Office whereto they are call'd. This is not taught any peron by Nature, and therefore I find more effects of acquir'd than of Natural Courage, which (beides) how great oever, is perfected by Indutry.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLVI. Whether Men, not having learn' d of others, would would frame Language to themelves.
div.p:
NAture having given Animals a Voice for mutual communication at ditance, and that ditinguih'd into as many everall Tones and Accents as they have different Paions and neceities; 'tis not credible that he hath provided wore for Man, as to what was more neceary to him, as being ubject to more paions and neceities than any other Animal, which oblige to a Society, no-wie imaginable without Speech; which conequently, two Children would frame to themelves, as oon as the moiture of their Brain and Organs erving to Speech, being dry'd by Age, permitted free motion to their Tongue; beginning
by imitation of voices or ounds which they hear, and giving names to things utable to the voices or ounds they render'd. In defect whereof they would frame other articulate words, firt Monoyllables and Simple, as thoe of the Chinees are, and afterwards compounded: by which they would expres all their other conceptions, if not with uch facility as other Languages, which time hath enrich'd, yet at leat after their own Mode, uing the mot conformity they could to the nature and property of each thing. And where reaon fail'd them, they would be help'd by hazard; our Nature being o trongly carri'd to imitation, that he of the two, who firt apply'd a word to ome thing, would be follow'd by the other without contradiction. For the mind of Man being an Act, inceantly conceives; his greatet pleaure is in communicating thoe conceptions; and as a Torrent or River without hore, take their coure every way, o Man's conception being detitute of terms to imitate, would frame new according to his phanie, which coming to be receiv'd by others, would acquire the ame perfection whereunto other Languages arrive in time. Yea when the Organs of Speech fail, dumb perons move their members a thouand ways to make themelves undertood; and that o happily, that when Monieur de Sancy was Embaadour in Turkie, he hapned to ee two Mutes, the one a Turk and the other a Perian, who not undertanding one another becaue they had different igns, there was found a third Mute who erv'd them for an Interpreter. Which being harder then to articulate a voice, argues, that Nature would much ooner teach Speech then expreion by getures. For no body is ignorant that it is eaier to peak then to do.

The Second aid, That Speech being only an imitation, he that hould never hear another peak could never peak himelf. Hence perons born deaf are always dumb, though they have all the Organs fit for formation of Speech: and yet none will imagine that they have not all the ame faculties and neceities of expreing themelves that other men have, yea and greater too, being depriv'd of all intructions which are aquir'd by the ear, and other benefits proceeding from the ame. Which is further verifi'd by the examples of all avage Men that have been found; even by that of the Satyre, who by the report of S. Jerome in his Epitles appear'd to S. Anthony in the Deart; all which intead of words pronounc'd only inarticulate voices, liker ounds and bellowings then words; thee men being like one ignorant of playing on the Lute, who though he hath fingers yet cannot make it peak as he can who is kill'd in that Intrument.

The Third aid, That the Reaon why perons born deaf are alo mute, is, that he who peaks mut firt hear himelf peak before he be heard by others; otherwie he knows not whether himelf hath poken or no, much les can others know: and as little
doth he remember the voice which he made ue of to expres this thing or another: which is abolutely neceary to being able to employ the ame voice when he would ignifie the ame thing. But the cae is not the ame with him that having a good ear and intending to caue himelf to be undertood endeavours to expres his conceptions of things by his voice which he articulates by the judgment of his ear, as a Lutinit doth the trings of his Intrument, which indeed is more artificially touch'd by a killful then by an ignorant peron, yet ceaeth not to trike the Ear, as the Language invented by uch men without Precepts will not be les audible though more diagreeable then another. Moreover, Speech being as proper to man as Reaon (whereof 'tis the Image, whence poibly the Greeks denote both by the ame word) it may eem, that one remote from all commerce would not ceae as to reaon o neither to peak; but might as well do the one as the other. If there be any obtacle, it mut proceed from ome caue: not from the material, to wit, the pecies of things, which it imports not whether they be introduc'd by one ene or another; Nor from the efficient, the Organs of Speech being uppos'd intire; nor from the Formal, which cannot fail, ince 'tis neceary for Speech to follow as often as the breath is trongly driven out of the Lungs through the harp Artery into the Mouth, organiz'd by the Epiglottis, modifi'd by the Tongue, minc'd by the Teeth, and form'd by the Lips. As for the final, which is Communication, 'tis not les beneficial to one then to another. Wherefore all the caues of Speech concurring and being upply'd to man by nature, the effect mut necearily follow. And if Beggars, particularly thoe call'd Gipies, make to themelves a particular jargon, which they call Bleche or Narquois, it will not be harder for thoe we peak of to do as much. Yea they will not find more difficulty therein, then occurs in the inventing of new Characters by uch as write in Cyphers: which is alo confirm'd by the judgment of the Fathers who hold that the alteration of Tongues at the building of Babel, was nothing but the total abolition in each man's memory of the pecies of his maternal Language; which Memory being thereupon become a ras'd table and like a white paper, it concern'd men to agree together about new terms ignificative of their conceptions. Otherwie (they ay) if God had then infus'd an actual knowledg and habit of everal Languages in all thoe Workmen, this had not been a punihment but a reward of their arrogance, and in ome ort parallel to that famous gift of Tongues by the Holy Ghot at Pentecot.

The Fourth aid, That ince nothing can be in the Intellect which was not before in the Sene, the Species of Voice cannot be introduced into the Undertanding but by ome outward ene: Not by the Hearing, which is the right ene of Dicipline, ince none peaks to the Children of whom the quetion is: Nor by the Eyes, whoe ole object is the viible Species: nor
by the other Senes, whoe objects are alo different from thoe of the Hearing. Moreover, a Language being comprehended under Grammar, which is a Science, it cannot be undertood much les practis'd without either Precepts or Examples. For want of which the memory of Children (of whom, we now peak) not being furnih'd with any Idea, can dictate nothing to the Mucles and Nerves, the intruments of voluntary motion, which therefore can form no Speech; jut as he that is not accutom'd to other exercies of the body no more then to thoe of the mind, produces them not. That God created Adam and Eve with Speech, and that (as 'tis reported) ome Children have poken at their birth, yea ome in their Mothers bellies; thee are things purely upernatural, and from which nothing can be inferr'd.

The Fifth aid, That Women have uch a facility of peaking, that if two Children epecially of different exes were bred up together, 'tis likely the female would peak firt, not only as the more forward but as the greater tatler. Which was the reaon of the micarriage of the King of Egypts trial, which he made only with Boys. And yet this habit of Speech is uch in men that in our age the Contable of Catile's Brother being born deaf crot the Rule, that perons deaf by birth are always dumb; (as alo hapned to many of the ame Family of Velaco). For he was taught to Speak, Write, Read and Undertand Authors, by putting a cord about his neck and traitning or looning the ame to advertie him, when to open or hut his mouth by the example of his Teacher, that o he might • xpres the things which were repreented to him at the ame time: nor was there other difference found between his peech and that of other men, but only that he did not regulate his voice, peaking commonly too high: which hath alo ometimes been done by making the deaf man bite the Intrument upon which the ound they would have him hear was form'd, becaue the impreion which the Brain receives thereby anwers in ome ort to the Sene of Hearing.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLVII. Whether is better, to guard the Frontier, or carry the War into the Enemies Country.
div.p:
PEace being the end of War, he manages War bet that oonet attains that end. Now Peace is attain'd two ways; either by quelling the Enemies force; which eldom happens and is of long dicuion between parties almot equal (as thoe that go to war commonly are, too great inequality preently
ubduing the weak to the trong) or ele by rendring all his attempts ineffectual; and this is more eaily done by expecting him firmly and reolutely, then by aaulting him at his own home, withall the inconveniences and incertainties that occur in remote expeditions. Moreover, every deign ought to be render'd as infallible as is poible; yet o many unexpected difficulties arie in things which appear mot eaie, that we find by daily experience the Theory much different from the Practice. Which being preum'd certain, as indeed it is, none doubts but a Miniter of State may better lay the plat-form of a deign in a Country which is acceible to him and at his dipoal; as alo that both the Leaders and Souldiers may better give and execute Orders in a place where the Inhabitants are obedient and ready to contribute their care, pains, and money for promoting the projects which erve to the advancement of their party; then in places where they mut depend upon the honety of Guides, who are frequently deceivers or apt to be deceiv'd, and where all things are contrary. Beides, every one is more ardent and zealous for the preervation of his own Land, Wife and Children, yea and his own Life too, then for making deigns upon the Life and Goods of others; in which cae, beides the dubiounes of the event, the Souldiers are not ure that what they hall conquer hall remain their own; but they are certain that what they defend well will remain o, ince it belongs to them already. Moreover, Hitories inform us that of ten Enterpries made in an Enemies Country carce one hath happily ucceed •• , nor one of ten Conquets been kept. Witnes the late Invaions of the Englih and Spaniards in the Iles of Rhee, S. Honorat, and S. Marguerite, and more lately at Leucate. Add hereunto, that 'tis les chargeable to keep at home; and what is oberv'd in private Duels is appliable to publick Wars: for oftentimes the more unkillful Combatant keeping his ground and expecting his Enemy, kills him. Beides, Defence carrying more jutice with it then Invaion doth, it mut alo beget more confidence and boldnes in the Defenders, and more diffidence and fear in the Invaders, who cannot fight with o good a Concience for what is poet by, and therefore jutly preum'd to belong to others, whatever ubtilty may be us'd to et up and colour a fale title.

The Second compar'd him that invades an Enemies Country, and him that expects him in his own, to two Gameters, one whereof having begun to win will no longer venture any thing of his own, and the other begins the Game with his own money. For the Aailant hazards nothing of his own, ince he makes his Enemies Country the eat of the War and of the hazard which follows it. And whether you place the benefit and end of this War in the conquet of the Enemies Country, or in a jut defence only, 'tis always more commodious, profitable, and glorious to attaque him at home, then to expect him at your
own doors. For, if you deign to conquer, you mut necearily enter into his country to get poeion; if only to defend your elf, then (as wie men chue rather to divert and prevent dieaes then to repel them already form'd, and as a Fire is more eaily quencht in its firt flame than when it hath eiz'd the roof and walls, o) 'tis eaier to defend your own country by making a diverion upon that of the enemy than to expel in your own all the deolations that attend war, which you mut uffer at home unles you remove it further. Beides, in forreign Counties the war almot pays its elf, the Soldier lives as he lit, enriches himelf with the pillage of taken Towns, and o is les charge to his Prince. Yea, he becomes more valorous there too. For, as Antiperitais redoubles the force of Natural Agents, o the approach of an enemie's country gives heart to the mot cowardly, and renders others more diciplinable, as well knowing that they mut look for help only from themelves. Hence Armies have proper'd better in a trange Country than in their own. The Romans were always victorious out of Italy, but often beaten at home, and reduc'd to great extremities by the Gauls and Carthaginians; who likewie were always overcome in their own Country. Hence Alexander conquer'd more Kingdoms and Provinces by carrying his Arms into Aia, then his Father and all his Lieutenants won Towns in Greece; the Englih have been more fortunate in France then at home; and the Turks almot ever gain upon the Chritians by aaulting Chritendom. Yea Reputation, by which Kings reign, and Terror which half gets a victory, are always on the Aggreor's ide, whereas on the contrary nothing abates the courage more then to uffer the invaders to come to our houes, becaue the alacrity and promptitude of Soldiers is uually greatet when acccompani'd with great hopes.

The third aid, 'Tis impoible to determine any thing in this or any other political Quetions, which are variable accordding to diverity of Circumtances; The frontier of one State may be o afe that there is nothing to be fear'd at home from the enemy, againt whom therefore all the editious and turbulent perons may be afely ent: Forreign War erving as a Sanctuary to bad Citizens, who fear the punihment of their crimes; in which repect it erves for a purgation and bleeding to the body Politick. Other States, there are which (like Recovering Perons, whoe bodies are trong enough to upport themelves, but not to aail other) no ooner take the field but dicord and diviion aries at home, and o they incurr the reproach of the Atrologer who fell into a ditch whilt he was gazing on the sky. Wherefore 'tis not more eaie to reolve whether 'tis bet to make war, neer-hand or afar off, without aying in what time, in what place, with what means and againt what enemies, than to counel a Trademan whether he hould keep or get, without knowing why and whether he hath money in
his pure or no. The Examples alledg'd on either ide reemble the ound of thoe bells which accord with all Notes. Thoe that have proper'd in conquering would poibly have got more if they had put themelves only upon the Defenive; and thoe that have been worted in defending their own, perhaps did it too late, and (as it mot frequently happens) when their forces were impair'd. But it may be aid of the French and all other warlike Nations that they are much fitter to attaque their enemy afar off then to upport his irruptions in their own country; becaue the firt requires uch an ardor and impetuoity as is natural to them; and the econd hath need of much patience, in which we have always been urmounted by Strangers, till that grand Genius of the State which animates it at this day manifeted that Conduct doth all both in war and peace.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLVIII. Whence diverity of Opinion proceeds.
div.p:
TIs no wonder if every caue produces a different effect, and that there is diverity not only between things of different kind and pecies, but alo between each individual, o that two eyes are not perfectly alike. Which variety, had we ways of ditinguihing, would appear to us everywhere ele, as it doth (for example) to the Dog, who, of two Hares which we judg alike, knows which he tarted firt. But that one and the ame thing appears divers according to the diverity of thoe that judg of it, this eems as trange in the inquiition of its caue as 'tis common in practice. For ince that the Intellect judges of things according to the report of the outward enes, without whoe minitry nothing is introduc'd into it; and that thee enes and their mediums being well-dipos'd agree all in their reports, the whitenes of this paper, the blacknes of this ink, and the truth of all other objects being faithfully repreented to us; Why hould not all men, that hear one and the ame propoition, and the reaons whereby it is backt and oppos'd, make the ame judgment for, or againt it, without being divided, as they are, into everal opinions. The caue hereof I acribe to the everal dipoition and habitude of the Organs which render the oul's operations different. A ucking child being at a Sermon, undertands nothing at all of it; one ix or even years old carries away a confus'd knowledg of it, and thinks it enough to ay that the Preacher poke of God; the young man and the old man judg thereof according to their inclination, the cholerick hatily, the melancholy with more circumpection, and almot all everally. Again, if the matter be cholatical, the Peaant who undertands it not, judges thereof with
admiration, the Scholar eteems it, the illiterate Trademan blames it, and preferrs a point of morality in brief every one judges of it after his own way. In the mean time 'tis one and the ame Sermon, as one and the ame liquor pour'd into different veels, which give it the tat wherewith they are already imbru'd.

The econd aid, 'Tis true, Nothing is in the Intellect but what was before in the Senes, yet many times the Intellect is o prepoes'd with prejudice that all upervening reaons ignifie nothing; and when ome Paion, as Love or Hatred, biaeth it, there is no room for equal conideration. Hence condemned perons commonly accue their Judges unjutly; though indeed a friend's recommendation makes them look upon caues with other eyes then they hould do.

The third aid, This variety of judgments proceeds not only from the diverity of the pecies introduc'd by the common ene into the Intellect, but from the different conjunction which the Intellect makes of thoe pecies; jut as the ame alphabet is written and read variously by everal Writers, and though many peak the ame language, yet both their pronunciation and phrae is different. Whence their expreions being o different, 'tis no wonder if the concluions of their reaonings prove not the ame.

The fourth aid, He conceiv'd that there are ome qualities in the oul which he derives not from the body. Otherwie we hould not ee ome people extremely opinionative and obtinate, whoe temper hath nothing of melancholy; nor others o light and mutable, though their contitution be not cholerick; and yet thee two humors are commonly reputed the caues of tubbornnes and incontancy. But to what hall we acribe it except to the oul alone that ome men are naturally o given to devotion, that in an affair wherein religion is never o little concern'd they account nothing equitable againt Eccleiats; and in the mean time there are others to whom what ever this ort of people propoe is upected. And who can think that the reolution of thoe that have been burnt for Hereie proceeded from the temperament of the body.

The fifth aid, That Opinions are to be ditinguiht into Practical and Speculative. The firt whereof, wherein we find our elves intereed, and which we promote upon that account, 'tis probable follow the temper and conformation of the Organs. Thus the melancholy man, who fears even imaginary dangers, cannot be perwaded to prefer trading at ea before that at land, but is alwavs fixt to hazard nothing. If he mut chooe a profeion, he takes the Gown before the Sword, and then too he had rather be ilent then advance any new propoition lyable to rejection. But if his birth or fortune command him to the war; he is rather for corrupting the enemies forces then fighting them, and in cae of the latter he chooes an ambucade before a pitcht battel. On the contrary, the hot cholerick peron preferrs a
coure, whereby he may oonet compas his deign, though with the hazard of his Life, (which he will not believe, or at leat not fear) before the tedious progrees of other Employments, which afford not their proecutor meat till his teeth be out. And the Sanguine eaily agrees to this Advice, provided it requires no pains, or be weetned with ome patime; but the Phlegmatick cares neither for one nor the other. On the other ide, in things coniting onely in Contemplation, I ee not why I hould be rather of the Opinion, that the flux and reflux of the Sea is caus'd by the Moon than by the Sun. And hence it is that perons of different Tempers, Sexes, Climats, and Ages, agree more readily in a point of Philoophy, than in their particular Inclinations and kind of Life. Indeed the main Source of this Diverity of Opinion, is, the Vanity and Ambition of the Humane Mind, which judging it elf as well tock'd with Capacity and ufficiency as any other, and above all things, loving Liberty, which eems diparag'd by conenting to an Opinion advanc'd by another; this Conceit, together with the dubiounes of all things not demontrable, carries us to eek ome new Light, which cannot be o mall, but we love it more than that of another; as people commonly do their own Children. Hence arie the o different Opinions of the Ancients, about all matters of Philoophy and other Sciences, not excepting Divinity it elf even amongt Catholicks; amongt whom we ee Scotus, diagreeing with Saint Thomas, as Paracelus doth in Phyick with Galen, Copernicus with Ptolomy in Mathematicks, Raymond Lully and Ramus in Scholatick Philoophy with Aritotle, and in Civil Law Caius, with Labeo, and the Sabinians with the Proculeians.

The Sixth aid, 'Twere a greater wonder if all Men were of one Opinion, than that they imitate in this diverity all other things of the world: At leat 'tis harder to aign the caue why one and the ame Man is to day of one judgement, and to morrow of another, then to ee as many everal Sentences as Heads. But to me this variety eems to arie from the various conception of things. As appears by the example of Julius Caear, who being purpos'd to detroy King Deiotarus, no ooner heard Cicero peak in his defence but he pardon'd him; not to peak of many other Effects, both of his and Demothenes's Eloquence. Whence it comes to pas, that though the ame Fact be related with the ame Reaons, yet the Diverities found in the manner, and in all the enes, imprint in us different pecies; upon the report whereof we alo make a different judgement.

The Seventh aid, This Variety proceeds from the Principles of Knowledge, as appears in thoe of Mathematicks., which being certain and known to all, caue every one to aent to their infallible Conequences. And o in a peron een at a ditance, of whom having a confus'd Knowledge, one aith, 'Tis a Tree, another, a Beat or a Man; but when his nearer
approach makes him better known, all agree that 'tis Peter or James.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLIX. Why there is more Wind at Sea than at Land.
div.p: THe experience of les Wind and more Rain on Land than at Sea, makes their Opinion quetionable, who hold, Exhalations to be the matter of the former, and Vapours of the latter: unles we will ay, that Winds, to whom the Poets rightly attribute the Empire of the Sea, drive the Clouds over the Land, where being les agitated, they reolve into Rain. But to continue my reaoning with the ame Poets, I hall ay, that having plac'd Aeolus's Palace in the caverns near the ea, they have ufficiently proved, why the Sea is more troubled with them than the Land. For thee Winds viibly iue from deep Caverns frequent on the Coats of the Sea, whoe continually agitated waves inceantly tir them up. 'Tis no wonder then if they diplay their violences on that ide which is freet to them: Which is experienc'd in great Lakes adjacent to high Mountains; as in that of Comum, and de la Garde in Italy, whoe waves and roarings reemble thoe of the Sea; and alo in that of Geneva, which is troubled extraordinarily. Not but that Winds are generated in other Subterraneous places too, none of which is exempt from them; as appears in Wells and the mouths of Caves. But the openings of uch places being commonly trait upwards, the Wind that come out of them is not o perceptible as that which iues out laterally from high Caverns upon the Sea-hore; and they differ, in that the Sea Wind is dryer and les corrupting, poibly by reaon of the altnes of the water, upon which it paes.

The Second aid. That the difference in Quetion proceeds from the vat extent of the Sea, which gives the Air once agitated, more liberty to continue its motion; which, on the contrary, is traitned and repres'd on Land by the occure of Mountains, Trees, Houes, and other obtacles: By the ame reaon that the waves of a Pool or little Lake, are much les than thoe of the Ocean, beides, that one and the ame Wind hath much greater effect in a mooth and liquid plain, which yields to it, than upon a rough olid Body, upon which burdens are not mov'd but with more force than there needs upon the water; as they experience who endeavour to draw a tranded Ship on the Land, which they aw move almot of it elf whilt it was upon the water. The Mechanical Reaon whereof is, that the water breaking into infinite points, carce makes any reitance to its Agent; but the Earth pres'd with the ame load, reits it in infinite points.

The Third aid. He that defin'd Wind to be Agitated Air, rather poke its Effect than Caue, which is ome middle thing between a Vapor and an Exhalation, driven violently according to all the differences of place. For an Exhalation, which always mounts upwards, and the Vapor which refrigerated decends downwards, cannot eparately be the matter of Wind. Hence as oon as the Vapor of a Cloud is reolv'd into Rain, the Wind ceaeth; the Exhalations not being ufficient to produce it alone, as neither the Vapor is. Otherwie, Winds hould be greatet in hot weather, when Exhalations are mot plentiful. Wherefore the Sea having in its Four Qualities the materials of thee two Meteors, and being otherwie more capable of emitting them through its liquid ubtance, than the Earth is through its hard and olid urface, though both be equally heated as well by the Sun, as by Subterraneous Fires, Evaporations and Exhalations, are ooner and oftner made at Sea than at Land.

The Fourth aid, That the thicket Air being oftimes the calmet, and the clearet the mot windy, 'tis doubtful whether Vapors and Exhalations produce Winds; which, beides, preuppoeth actual heat in the Sea, which yet is never felt there, but onely on Land. It eems therefore that the Element of Air being very ymbolical to that of the Air by their agreement and moiture, they follow the motions one of the other. Hence the Air contiguous to the Sea, is agitated by it; whence arieth a Wind, which again agitates the Sea; it being well known, that when there are no Waves there is no Wind. On the contrary, when the Wind is to change, the billows turn firt. And ordinarily, the Winds change with the Tides.

The Fifth aid. There are two orts of Winds upon the Sea; Particular, which reign in our Seas, blowing indifferently from all Coats; and General, which blow continually from the ame quarter, without giving place to their Contraries. Such is the Oriental Wind in the Torrid Zone, which was call'd by the Latins, Subolanus, and by Mariners at this day, South-Eat. For it conducts Ships o contantly over the whole extent of Mer du Nord, & du Sud, that without dicontinuing Day or Night, it exempts the Sea-men from touching their ails, epecially when they are near the Aequinoctial. Indeed in the Eat Indies, this Rule alters, for this Wind holds there but ix moneths, leaving the other ix free to its Antagonit. The Caue whereof, is acrib'd to the repercuion of the capes and coats of thoe Seas, as that firt Wind is to the motion of the Primum Mobile, which, together with the inferior Spheres, draws the Air along with it in this place, where the circumference of its motion is larget. There is another general Wind, which blows between the Tropick, or twenty fourth Degree on this ide the Line, and the thirty fifth becoming Occidental with the like contancy that the aboveaid Oriental doth. This ome attribute to a contrary motion, which all things have when thoe nearet them are hurri'd
violently; as the tream of water running impetuouly in the midt, makes that near the hores recoil backwards.

The Sixth aid, That as Vapours make Mits and Fogs, and Sulphureous Exhalations make igneous Meteors; o the Nitrous make Wind, which keeps the air from corruption as the Earth is kept from it by Nitre, and the Sea by Salt. Moreover, both the Wind and Nitre dry, and are the caues of fecundity; as is prov'd (on the behalf of Nitre) by the Nitrous and of Nilus, whoe greater or leer overflow promies to the Egyptians a year proportionably fruitful; which is alo aid of the Rhone abounding with Nitre. And as for the Wind, beides that all flatuous Meats provoke lut, 'tis aid that the Mares of Andaluia conceive by the Wet-wind alone which alo is tyl'd the Father of Flowers. In Brief, if Wind be impetuous, the effects of Nitre in Gun-powder and Aurum fulminans, manifet that Nitre is no les. Now Nitre being mix'd with the Air, where it is volatile; with the Earth, where it is fix'd; and with the Sea, where it is barely diolv'd; no wonder if it exhale more eaily from the Sea then from the Land, and conequently if more winds be there. Whence the reaon may be drawn not only of the Sea-winds but alo of the tempets and commotions of that vat Element; a Tempet being nothing but the rarefaction of the Sea; Nitre, and the inflation of the Waters at Full Moon in March and September, only the fermentation of the ame Nitre in the eaon proper for generation. As for that inflation hapning at the time of the Dog-tar, when the Eteian winds reign, it proceeds from the heat of the Air then inflam'd by the rays of the Sun, like the ebullition of Honey and Syrups impregnated with much Salt, as appears by their diolution and the bitternes they acquire over the Fire.

The Seventh aid, That the coldnes of Vapors ariing from waters giving more body and conitence to winds, makes them trike a more enible blow then when they are detitute thereof; whence they are greater in Winter then in Summer, and in the Morning then at Noon. Thus the ame quantity of water will caue more alteration in the body being drunk cold then warm, becaue the impreion of the latter is much les upon our bodies. And the Providence of the Author of Winds is remarkable too, in that they are michievous at Land but ueful at Sea; hurtful things being by a ecret of his power as much diminih'd, as profitable are augmented.

The Eighth aid, That not only Wind-mills but alo the Wind-wagons invented lately in Holland, hew that wind well manag'd is no les profitable at Land then at Sea. Therefore I hould refer the caue to the poroities, overtures, and caverns of the Earth, into which the wind entring is by that means les at Land; whereas the urface of the Sea giving it no uch admiion, 'tis left to its freer coure upon the ame; whence when thoe pores of the Earth are hut up by frot, the wind
becomes more impetuous then it is in Summer when they are open.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLIX. Whether it be eaier to procure obedience by Gentlenes then by Terrour.
div.p: THe mot plauible vertues are not always the noblet: as they depend upon external things which encreae or diminih their value, o oftentimes they yield to thoe obcure and private vertues, whoe beauty being only internal, without borrowing any recommendation from abroad, they are therefore the more to be eteem'd. Gentlenes or Manuetude is of this nature, though it make not o great a noie as Fortitude, which is irreitible by the terror it imprees upon the oppoers of its deigns, yet oft-times it accomplihes its enterpries with the more facility in that it makes not ue of any extraneous help, but only of what this vertue it elf affords; which ininuating weetly into their minds whom it would lead by the conideration of their own good, more eaily procures obedience then fear doth; which indeed may contrain them to do what they would not voluntarily aent to, but is a violent motion, and o harder to be impres'd then that which is voluntary. For when once the reaon is perwaded of the jutice of the things enjoyned, there is no more obtacle in the Will, which then reigns it elf to be lead by that light of the Undertanding; much les in the inferior Powers, which move only by the orders of thoe upon which they totally depend.

The Second aid, Did men leave themelves to the guidance of Reaon more then of their Paions, it would be eaier to procure obedience by Gentlenes then by Terror, which then would be ueles; eeing 'tis not neceary to oblige uch men by denunciation of penalties to their duty, who addict themelves to it voluntarily upon the knowledg they have of right Reaon. But ince very few follow this Rule, in comparion of thoe that have none but that of their diorderly Appetites, therefore everity is more expedient then mildnes for reducing them at any rate whatever to their duty. For their obedience though contrain'd is nevertheles exemplary, and draws others to do the like, and o maintains that mutual correpondence which gives ubitence not only to States but alo to all other civil Societies, and which conits chiefly in a certain dependance between the parties detinated to obey and to command. So that as the latter ought to tudy to maintain the Authority and Superiority which they have, whether by Nature (as Fathers
over their Children) or by Love (as Kings and Magitrates over their Subjects, and Maters over their Dometicks) o when thoe under them fail of what they are oblig'd to render to them, there is no urer nor eaier way to bring them to it then Terror, which propoing a enible penalty to them in cae of micarriage is incomparably more powerful to make them obey, then weetnes; which indeed hath ome charms to win more rational pirits, but being accompany'ed with oftnes and indulgence, becomes at length odious and contemptible by the diorder and confuion which follow impunity of crimes. Moreover, 'tis certain that as States are maintain'd by the exact obervance of Laws, o their detruction ordinarily happens only by the relaxation which Superiors uffer of the punihments due to uch as trangres them.

The Third aid, That the Poets who feign men formerly dipers'd in divers parts of the Earth without Religion, Laws or Dicipline, to have been gather'd together by the melodious conort of muical Intruments, with which Orpheus, (as they relate) attracted even Beats and Rocks, eem to conclude rather for Gentlenes then Terror, this latter cauing thoe that ue it to be hated as much as the former doth to be lov'd. But etting aide fabulous authorities, the mot edulous inquirers into the caues of the foundation of States attribute the ame to the charms of their Eloquence of thee men, who being found fittet to ininuate to them the advantages of living in ociety, reduc'd them thereunto by impoing Laws upon them, the dipening wherewith they reerv'd themelves as well as the conduct of thoe that voluntarily ubmitted to their Government; which having taken its rie from Gentlenes cannot better be preerv'd then by the ame, if the Philoophers Maxime be true, That things are preerv'd by the ame principles which erv'd to their etablihment. And o 'tis eaier to procure obedience by Gentlenes then by Terror.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLX. Whether Trading derogate from Gentility.
div.p:
'TIs the part of the lothful and uch as live by the weat of others to blame Indutry. 'Twere tolerable indeed to reject out of the rank of liberal Arts uch as have any thing of baenes or ordidnes, but to do the like by an Employment capable alone to enrich States, furnih them with all necearies, and maintain them in Amity and good Intelligence with their Neighbours, is too great a piece of Nicenes, the reult whereof is that then the Gentry mut either remain poor or ele live by robberies and other unlawful coures. For notwithtanding
the precaution of mot places in adjudging almot the whole etate to the eldet ons of Gentlemen, (which would not be neceary if they were left in a condition of getting, as all other orts of perons are) yet the cadets of either Sex cannot have o mall a portion, but the ucceion which before was able to upport the dignity of the name, at length either comes to nothing or o mall that the principal Heirs are forc'd either to dye of hunger, or to utain their lives by ome exercie, the choice whereof is not o freely left to them as to their Predeceors. For the benefit alliances bring them is oftentimes not very coniderable; the Daughters being by the ame cutoms very ill provided, and that benefit commonly accompani'd with new expences. Indeed ome Legilators have abolutely forbidden Trafick, as Lycurgus; others have only permitted it to the inferior people, as Romulus, which induc'd Plato to found his Commonwealth far from the Sea-ports, for fear it hould be corrupted by the delights ordinarily introduc'd by trangers, and his Citizens getting their livelihood by Merchandize hould learn to lye and deceive, the common vices of Merchants, which Cicero aith likewie of the Carthaginians, that being good of their own nature, they learn'd by the convere of Merchants to addict themelves to frauds and lyes, out of their great deire of getting. But as Trading begets diimulation, o it makes men more prudent by the knowledge of everal perons manners. Whence Homer in the beginning of his Odyeus makes this remark of lyes, that he had een many Cities, which is proper to Merchants: but every body knows that one may lye, diemble, and deceive without being a Merchant, nor ought the abue of ome hinder all from the ue.

The Second aid, That the reaon why Trading is interdicted to Gentry, is, let the weetnes of gain hould retard them from the Wars for the ervice of the King and defence of the State, whereof they are the upport and the right hand. And Gentlemen having no other exercie but Arms mut needs be better kill'd therein then if their Minds and Bodies were har'd amongt everal Occupations, and upon occaion they are more ready and free from other employment to execute the orders they receive, then if they were in ome long Voyage, or buied about examining an Account-Book; an errour wherein, ometimes imports their whole etate. Beides, Souldiers more cheerfully obey him who they ee leads a life far from all Trading. This was the practie of the Romans, among whom 'twas not lawful for a Citizen to exercie Merchandize; but only for freed Servants, or others of the low vulgar. Much more was it forbidden to the Senators, who for that reaon had the Port of their Ship limited, let they hould Trafick under pretext of tranporting their Fruits and Rents; all profit eeming to them dihonet. And the Thebans admitted no man to any Magitracy, unles he had dicontinu'd Trading at leat ten years before.
The reaon is given by Aritotle; becaue Merchandize is an enemy to Vertue. Hence all acces to Honours hath been by the Laws interdicted to Merchants, or o much as to bear Arms; o that Gentility and Merchandize eem inconitent. Add hereunto, that God forbids his people to have any Merchant amongt them; becaue, aith the Wie man, the Merchant can hardly have his hands clean from in: And o Chryotome adventures to ay, that a Merchant cannot pleae God, by reaon of his perjuries and frauds; qualities directly contrary to true Gentility.

The Third aid, That eeing this life needs Action more then Contemplation; therefore good Polititians invite, by all orts of Honors and Priviledges, thoe that are able to contribute mot to the benefit, quiet, and increae of the State. But, o are Merchants; who bring plenty of all kinds of Goods to the mot deolate places, and enrich the more fruitful by ditributing their commodities, which otherwie would be poor amidt their abundance. Nor are they oblig'd to Trade in Peron, o that they are not hindred from paying the peronal Service they owe to their King and Countrey; for whoe good they are oft-times bet advertis'd by their Forreign Correpondences, and give the certainet Intelligence of an Enemies Deigns: beides that, having travell'd into his Countrey in time of Peace, they the better know what way to mannage a War againt him; and the money wherewith they abound more then Gentlemen, gives them large Credit amongt the Souldiers. The Roman Law that forbad Senators to Traffick, was extinct in the dayes of Hortenius, as he complains: whereby it appears to have been lawful not only for them, but alo for the Equites, or Knights to negotiate either by themelves or by others; as at this day the Nobles of Spain, England, Venice, and epecially thoe of Florence do. Thus Cicero peaks of Lucius Pretius an illutrious Roman Knight that Traffickt at Panormus, and of Q. Mutius of the ame quality at Syracue. That God forbad his people Traffick, 'twas probably to keep them from being corrupted by the Idolatry of other Nations; and 'tis no more to be drawn into conequence for us then abtinence from Swines Fleh and their other Ceremonies: But hould all that hath been aid againt Merchants be admitted for good, it mut be onely againt Merchants by Retail, not againt thoe that Trade in Gros, who have alwayes been excepted from the rank of others.

The Fourth aid, That Utility is not more incompatible with Honety then Trade is with Nobility, which nevertheles is different, according to the everal entiments of Nations, being rated by extraction amongt Chritians by warlike exercies amongt the Turks, by learning amongt the Chinees; as alo the Nobles live in the Countrey in France and England, but in Cities in Spain and Italy; from which circumtances Nobility receives everal Etimations, according to the everal opinions of Nations.
But in general, Commerce, as 'tis the exercie of the people, o it hath been more honor'd in popular States then in Monarchies, where the power of Sovereigns hines brightet in War (which is oppoite to Merchandize) and the fear of Monopolies (which would eaily prevail here) renders odious the trading of Grandees, who incurre the peoples envy as oon as they undertake the employments belonging to them. Moreover, the gain of Merchants is contrary to the liberality of a Gentleman, whoe donations are interpreted in Law more extenively, when there is quetion about them, then thoe of Yeomen. And our Saviour, o gentle towards other inners, whipt the Trademen out of the Temple, calling them Robbers, and their Shops Dens of Thieves. As accordingly, Pagan Antiquity aign'd them for their Patron Mercury, the Patron of Thieves, and the mot infamous of the Gods. And the Emperours forbad Merchandize, not only to Senators by the Lex Clodia, but alo to Nobles by extraction, L. Nobiliores. C. De Comerciis & Mercat. to Officers Leg. Ne quis C. de dignit. and even to Souldiers, L. Milites C. Loca, & L. eos C. ne milites negotientur. And if ome Nations, confounding Utility with Honety, have authorized the Trading of Nobles, 'tis but as bae Money is, upon ome neceity, allow'd current in one Countrey, and rejected in all others. And their own Doctors agree, that the Splendor of uch Nobility is much diminiht by negotiation; the ditinction of Gros and Retail, not changing the Species of the Quetion, any more then more and les do in all others. Nor is it material whether they negotiate by the intervention of others, ince 'tis not lawful to do by another what we may not do our elves; beides, that uch intervention draws in the Honor of a Gentleman to vouch anothers Fact. Latly, the poverty intended to be avoided thereby, is oftentimes met with intead of Riches; and were it otherwie, yet Poverty commonly erves for a pur to Virtue. Hence ordinarily Cadets are more courageous then Elder Brothers; and the poor Epaminondas and Phocion were the more Warlike; but Craus the Rich was overcome and lain by the Parthians.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXI. Why the French are o much incened with the Lye.
div.p:
TRue and Good being reciprocal; hence to call a man Lyar, is as much as to ay, that he is of no Value; and becaue the paltery Fellow is unworthy of Honour, whereof the French is more covetous then any other Nation (as appears by the courage wherewith he runs upon hazard to the danger of his Life, tetifying thereby that he pries Life les then Honour, to which mot other Nations need to be incited by infinite Artifices)
hence it comes to pas that the French are more enible of the Lye than they.

The econd aid, That all Mankind make eteem of Piety towards God, and Courage towards men: the former having been a means us'd by the greatet Princes and Legilators to gain the minds of their people; o powerful, that ome even with the apparence of it alone have produced trange effects, (witnes the dotages of Mahomet in the Eat, and many others elewhere.) The other, namely Courage, being the vertue mot rever'd amongt men, and eteem'd by women, who commonly favour the mot valiant. Now Lying is a Vice oppoite to both thee Vertues, implying Impiety towards God, and Cowardize towards men. For he that lyes cannot be ignorant, that God the Father of Truth knows, and will ooner or later punih his Crime, if he have power to do it, (as cannot be denied without manifet irreligion.) And ince Truth comes of it elf to the Tongues end, unles it be detained Captive by Fear, or ome other ervile conideration; hence a Lye preuppoes Cowardize and Fear of him before whom it is poken. So that it is no wonder if the reproach of thee two crimes trouble us o much, the French Nation being the mot glorious of the World.

The third aid, That the Lye cannot but have omething in it more hainous then the reproach of Coward and Impious, ince thee are repayed only with the Lye, but the Lye it elf with blows; probably becaue Lying is a ervile Vice, and the French are very jealous of preerving their Liberty. But we mut ditinguih between lying and telling a Lye; for in this latter cae people are not readily offended, as in the former. Thus an Advocate pleading upon a Breviate, the matter whereof is fictitious, takes it not for an injury if the Adveraries Advocate is fale; but replies only, that he will jutifie it. The Philoopher maintaining an erronious opinion, which he believes good, will not be angry at its being impugned of falhood. But when one is urpried in a Lye, which eems invented purpoely to impoe upon the Company, the dicoverer of the falhood eems to reproach him not only of knavery but alo of ottihnes, in that he could not utter it dexterouly enough to make it believ'd. As therefore Theft was not punihed, but eteemed among the Lacedemonians, when it was well concealed, and received not chatiement except the Thief were taken in the fact; o a Lye eems to offend only when it is dicovered; but if handomly told, intead of being blamed, is authorized by Rhetorick and Poetry, (which are arts of handomly feigning things that are not) by Complements, which are fair Diguiements; by diimulations, common enough everywhere; by tratagems of War. Hence when we give the Lye to any one, we add, aving the repect of the Company; intimating thereby, that we intend not to reproach them of little judgment in letting pas o gros a
falhood for a truth. For I ee not that the French are greater Lyars then other Nations, unles you will bring under Lying their reervednes and modety in not telling their deigns to all the world.

The Fourth aid, That the French being the mot civilized of the world, have reaon to take for the greatet affront the Vice which mot detroyes civil Life and Converation; which being founded upon Communication, whereof Speech is the Interpreter: if there be no aurance in this, then Humane Society is detroyed. All other things are known for what they are by the pecies which they end to our enes (as the pecies of a Dog and a Hore never fail to repreent them to us uch as they are) our intentions and thoughts alone are committed to peech; which, if it ill repreent them, is no more to be eteem'd then a fale Looking-glas which repreents objects quite other then what they are; or then a copy not at all reembling its original; or latly, then a thing which is nothing les then what it is taken to be. Hence a Lyar eeing himelf di-believed, and every one upon their guard when he peaks or negotiates; he hath reaon to be harply offended with him that gives him uch a repute: and becaue being accounted a Lyar, he that accues him would not believe his bare affirming the contrary; therefore he gives him a box on the ear, as the mot uitable reply that can be made to the Lye; which being the highet affront, the blow is the firt revenge of it, which the uncover'd parts of the body (namely the hand and face) preent to the offended peron; which blow is eteem'd the greater out-rage, in that it tetifies the highet contempt of the receiver, and is onely meant to provoke him to reentment: Therefore a thrut with a Sword at an enemy purpoely to deliver ones elf from the fear of him by killing him, is accounted much les injurious then an affront done purpoely for the affronts ake. But, beides the foregoing reaons, cutome (which oftentimes hath none) in France authorizes the greatnes of the injury of the Lye.

The Fifth aid, That the refiners of Honor are like thoe that harpen the points of Needles o much till they break. The French, intead of intereing their Honour (as mot other Nations do) onely in things of importance, and of fairly maintaining that they peak true when they are told that they Lye, are as much incens'd upon the ole pronunciation of thee words, as if they were o many magical terms forcing the hand to give a blow, or draw the word; and, which is trange, 'tis not enquir'd whether the thing be true or fale, the Lye being judg'd alike offenive in both: yea, ordinarily they are the greatet Lyars that are mot offended with the Lye: the reaon whereof may be, That the reproach of true Vices offends us more then that of fale and uppoitious, and thoe of the minde more then thoe of the body, as being more reprehenible in us, in that 'tis our own fault that they are not amended: for a reproach made to one
for a Vice he cannot remedy, erves more to hew the malice of the Reproacher than the fault of him that is blam'd But 'tis not o with a Lye, which preuppoes either ignorance or malice. Whence the terms of Sot and Ignorant are alo mot cutting even to thoe that are not o. Beides, a Lyar (unles he repel the injury; a vowing himelf the Diciple of the Father of Lyes, this Reproach is very odious to good men, epecially to the French, who o affect that Title from all Antiquity, that our Ancetors have transferr'd it to Valour, (which they eteem'd the chief of the Vertues) aying, that uch as have defended themelves well, have done en gens de bien, like good men.

The Sixth aid, That the Lye is offenive only upon account of the intention; ince mot of our Dicoures, Anwers, and Replies (wherein conits one of the greatet pleaures of life, & without which our Convere would have no agreeablenes, as appears by thoe that peak not to one another, or agree in every thing) are no other but fair givings of the Lye; yet are o far from being offenive, that they caue us to deire the company of uch as know how to make handom Reparties. Thus many of our Generals, whoe venturounes upon the greatet hazards ufficiently tetifies their deire of Praie, yet hew dipleaure at the hearing of their own Commendations; a Diimulation, which carries them ometimes o far, that when any Hitory of thee times publihes ome brave Action perform'd by them, they cruple not to blame the Hitorian, who by concealing the like another time, may ecure himelf from uch Complements, if he take them not in the right ene.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXII. Why every one thinks himelf well enough provided with Wit; and ome, better than others.
div.p: AS the Eye eeth it not it elf, o the Intellect, undertandeth not it elf; but judging only of the parts of all others finds omething in them to dicommend; and having a better conceit of its elf, arrogates the preeminence in the comparion. For the reflexion of the Intellect upon it elf is never incere, but disguis'd and falifi'd by the fale reports and prejudices of Self-love, which makes us think our elves better then our Neighbours. Hence thoe that take not pains to conider their own Wit, care not to make a jut comparion of it with that of others; ince a right Comparion is between two things known; and thoe that can do it, do it through the clouds of Interet, which like Optical Glaes magnifie Objects, and make an Elephant of a Fly.

The econd aid, 'Tis not univerally true that every one is contented with his own wit; for there are many no les diffident then others are confident of themelves. Hence ome eloquent Tongues, fit either for the Chair, or the Bar, are kept from both by timidity and ditrut of their own abilities, and (as ome great animals uffer themelves to be lead and govern'd by a Childe) o their good wits, not undertanding their own trength, permit themelves to be rul'd by thoe that have wore. Thus we ee there are Apprentices in all Trades and Profeions more knowing then their Maters; and many times in that of War, a brave experienc'd Souldier obeyes a cowardly and ignorant Captain: And in Religious Houes, ome excellent Spirits glorying not to repute themelves uch, uffer themelves to be guided and ruled by thoe of an inferiour Degree. Yea, the mot preumptuous are eldom atisfi'd with their own firt conceptions, as appears by the frequent connexions and expunctions in the originals of their Writings, to which even after publihing they never ceae to adde or diminih. Of which number are many, who making a review of their precedent actions, alwayes finde omething therein to dilike. But as for others who have a better opinion of their own wit then that of others, this defect eems to proceed from the want of knowledge of themelves, o much recommended by the Delphian Oracle; uch people reembling the old Hag who put her eyes up in a Box when he came home, and took them out onely when he went abroad; or thoe that have a Wallet upon their necks, whereof they never ee but the forepart into which they put the affairs of their Neighbours; the other being behinde, into which they put all that concerns themelves. Which our Saviour alo reprov'd in Hypocrites, who ee not the beam in their own eyes, yet py a mote in that of their Neighbour.

The Third aid, That there being three orts of Goods, namely, of the Minde, the Body, and Fortune; the two latter are o expos'd to the eyes of every one, 'tis impoible to deceive the Spectators in the judgement thereof. But 'tis not o with thoe of the minde, which not appearing to all are like ecret Records of a Law Suit, the extract or coppy whereof depends upon the honety or dihonety of the reporter; who being both Judge and Party, 'tis no wonder if he award the Caue to himelf; as thoe that give their Voices to themelves excue it by aying, That having worn to chooe the mot capable, they judg'd themelves uch: Whereunto the evil cutom of commending one's elf much contributes, by turning into Nature, and o perwading us of what we would make others believe. So alo do flatterers, whom all the world delights to hear (whatever is pretended to the contrary) and who may peak more boldly of the gifts of the minde, becaue they are not perceptible of themelves, and o les ubject to contradiction.

The Fourth aid, That 'tis o far from being true, that every
one eteems his own genius becaue he ees it not; that on the contrary he eteems it more then others, becaue commonly he ees none but it; not in its ubtance, but in its effects. For if we value a Friend whoe preents we frequently behold before our eyes, how great reaon mut every one finde to prize his own pirit, whereof all the actions are in a manner preent to him? He beholds himelf in himelf morning and evening, leeping and waking; and finding not external objects enough to compare with the multitude of internal pecies which his pas'd actions furnih to him, he makes the concluion to his own advantage. If he be a Poet, all his Senes are fill'd with his Rhimes; or with his quare Periods, if an Orator.
