The memory of his exploits inceantly returns to him, if he be a Souldier; and perhaps being reviv'd by ome Sore or old Hurt, makes him eaily preume that he is as good as a Captain; or if he be a Captain that he could better perform the office of Field-Marhal then he that hath it. In brief, there is no profeion wherein the minde findes not wherewith to content, yea, to admire it elf, and withal to abate the value of others; comparion being like a balance, one cale whereof cannot be rais'd without depreing the other.

The Fifth aid, That the reaon why every one is contented with his own Wit, is becaue we are never brought to acknowledge our own errours, unles by contraint or conviction. And the minde never fails of a ubterfuge and a pretene to lay the fault other-where then upon it elf. If haply ome one acknowledges that he wanted fore-ight, judgment, and good mannagement in his affairs; yet he will alwayes turn the fault from himelf, and rather recurre to caues that are not, aying, That he was bewitch'd, or at leat deceiv'd, even o far as to accue the truth of the mot general Maxims, when they prove not to agree with his own fale Principles. Whereas we are forward enough to condemn others magiterially both in preence and abence.

The Sixth aid, That what is receiv'd, being according to the form and capacity of the recipient, 'tis impoible for the mind to conceive any thing greater then it elf: if it do, 'tis by negation, as the Eye ees night when it ees nothing, and as the mot perfect Souls conceive the Deity, namely by conceiving that they cannot conceive it, which is no knowledge at all. Hence the Sky, Houes, Trees, and other great viible Objects enter into the Eye onely by a viual pecies proportional to the bignes of the pupil which diminihes them. So likewie the undertanding or minde of Man, being to judge of that of another, abtracts uch intentional pecies thereof as are correpondent to its own capacity, and uch alone as it is able to comprehend. And as the continent is bigger then the thing contained; o this intentional Species, which repreents the image of anothers minde, being les then the minde which conceives it; 'tis no wonder if that which is conceived appears les then that which conceives it.
For otherwie, ince the undertanding is conform'd to the thing which it undertands, if it hould conceive an Idea of a minde greater then it elf is, it hould become greater then it elf, which is aburd. Beides, as things nearet us appear greatet, and nothing is nearer us then our elves, 'tis not to be marvell'd at if we pas judgement to our own advantage.

The Seventh aid, That the reaon of this difference is becaue the pecies which concern others are not o deeply ingraven as thoe which the undertanding inceantly traces in it elf; whence it is that the dipoitions of that firt rank are not o well imprinted as the habits of the econd. Now that the Species relating to others are more lightly engraven than thoe that concern our elves, appears by the example of the Graver, which paing but lightly over the Copper makes a little troke almot imperceptible; whereas by its repaing everal times upon the ame place, (as is done by the frequent repetition of the ame thoughts upon what regards our elves) it makes more remarkable lines. Perhaps alo this pleaing Error is left to Man, to comfort him for the unequal hare of all other Goods; which otherwie would bring him into Depair, or at leat very much increae the unhappines of his Life.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXIII. How Animals are bred of Putrefaction.
div.p: THe Viciitude of finite things requiring their being in perpetual motion, the ame is four-fold; namely, (1.) To Quantity, which is term'd Augmentation and Diminution; (2.) To Quality, which is call'd Alteration; (3.) To Place, which is tyl'd Local Motion; (4.) To Subtance, which is nam'd Generation and Corruption. This lat is the drawing forth of the Natural by ome Extraneous Heat, as that of the moit Ambient Air, which ininuating into the corrupting body, plays the part of an Agent therein; and not onely alters its qualities, but alo either increaes or diminihes its quantity; as is een in the Fermentation of Medicaments, and in Leven which makes pate rie, in which motion the Local is likewie oberv'd. Thus the matter being wrought and agitated by all orts of motions, is dipos'd in a manner uitable for receiving ome form, which necearily enues upon uch dipoition.

The Second aid, That in Equivocal Generation; (which the Quetion relates to) Salt holds the place of the Maculine Seed; and the Humidity, it corrects that of the Feminine; as appears by a pot fill'd with common earth, which moitned only with Rain produceth Stones, Plants, and Snails: But after you have depriv'd it of its Salt, by wahing it with hot water, (as the Saltpeter-men
do) it remains barren: Nature employing its fixt Salt for the Formation of Stones; the volatile with its Mercury, for Plants; and the ame with its Sulphur for Animals, whoe diverity, poibly, comes from that of thee Salts; amongt which, Nitre contributes marvellouly to Fecundity. Hence Excrements, being almot wholly nitrous, o oon produce Beetles, Flyes, Worms, and other Inects: Sweat, beings of the ame Nature, makes Lice; and Urine, Fleas; the lime of Marhes, which is nitrous, (as the turfs we ue for fewel manifet) produces Frogs; Boats of Salt warm with Rats, who conceive others by licking the Salt: Wheat alo, being very nitrous, generates Field-mice, and other Inects: And all this in the unctuous moiture of its elf, or which it renders uch by its Heat, which reduces the ame to a vicounes fit for retaining the form to be introduc'd; and as the Ebullition of Syrrops and Mut, is a pontaneous Motion proceeding from their alts, o the ame being rais'd by the heat without to a more eminent degree caues the progreive Motion in an Animal. The outward formal Caue is the Dipoition of the Matter, which that double heat finding dipos'd for a certain Form, fahions and extends for that purpoe. Thus the marrow of the Back-bone being near the Reins, which are full of Salt, may become a Serpent; a Woman's Hair laid in a Dunghil produceth Worms or little Serpents; Caterpillars retain the colour of the ap of the Tree through which the Humour that produces them pas'd, and imitate the everal colours of the Flowers about which they are bred; as is een in the mothy colours of the ame Caterpillars epecially when they become Butter-flies. The internal, formal, or formative Caue is an inviible Character graven in the aid Salts, which determines every thing to its Species, anwerable to that which is found in the Seed of each Plant and Animal, and which the Chymits hold cannot be extinguiht in the alts of ome Plants, affirming, that the ahes of Sage or Roemary own bring forth Sage and Roemary. The Final Caue is the Perfection of the Compound; whereunto Nature always apires; it being certain, that an Animal is more noble than a Body inanimate, whence ome prefer a Fly above the Sun. Upon which account he changes Mixts into Plants, and thee into Animals.

The 3d aid, That the Univeral Spirit of the World acts in this cae like a General of an Army, who, eeeing an Enemy ready to fly, and none of his own party preent to eize upon him, though his Imployment be not to take Prioners, but only to give Orders, yet for this time he condecends to play the part of a common Soldier: o the aboveaid Univeral Spirit not eeing any Form dipos'd to keeps its rank in the Order of Nature, and finding the matter fit to receive the form of a Rat, Moue or Frog, preently upplies the ame to it by its own ole approach. Hence uch Inects as need fewet parts, are oonet and mot eaily generated of Putrefaction, perfecter Animals never.

The Fourth aid, That Nothing being made of Nothing, ome Matter is requir'd to every Generation, which being barely alter'd in Animals which produce their like, is corrupted in thoe which are generated of themelves; the internal Humidity which erv'd to conjoyn the dry parts together, being drawn out; whence Carcaes become dut. And becaue Nature is never idle, therefore when She finds part of that Humidity full of a eminal Vertue and a Vital Spirit, and cannot make a Plant or an Animal of it like what it was before, then he forms imperfect Creatures. Which effect is not to be attributed to the Elements being full of ouls, nor to that particular Intelligence which Avicenna aith is detinated to the introduction of Forms, nor to Heaven, call'd by ome, The Parent Forms; but to the etablih'd order of Nature, That when Matter is indu'd with all the Dipoitions requiite to uch or uch a Form, the ame mut be introduc'd into it; which contitutes not a different Species from the Animals generated of Seed; though the particular end of thoe bred of corruption eems to be the purgation of the Elements, all whoe impurities they attract, and are nouriht therewith.

The fifth aid, That thee Generations mut be attributed to the Sun, who tranmits not only his Influence upon the urface of our Elements, but alo his Influence and Vertue to the Center of the Earth, where it concocts, digets, prepares, and vivifies Metals, and makes mineral Waters boil. For, beides that uch Generations happen chiefly when he approaches or makes himelf mot fell upon our Horizon; ome have oberv • d, That Rats, begotten of Corruption without the help of Male and Female, are ditinguih'd from others; in that, being expos'd to the Sun after death, they have little or no bad mell, but are conum'd and become in a manner nothing; that Planet reuming what it had contributed to them: whereas the mell of other produc'd by ordinary generation is intolerable.

The Sixth aid, That both in Univocal Generation (which is compar'd to one fire kindling another) and in that by Corruption (which hath ome Analogy with fire excited by a Steel) the ame difficulty occurrs; namely, What imperceptible Chain and Link attracts Forms, and makes them necearily decend into the Compound, to give it Being o oon as fit Dipoitions concur therein; whether thee Dipoitions are awaken'd by the Seed, as when you ow a Plant in well-prepared ground, or whether they pring out of the earth without owing, as many Plants do, which are more vigorous, and les need cultivation than others: by the Gardener's reaon, that Mothers have more care of their own Children than Nures have of thoe of others. Hence Rats bred of Corruption, are more prightly, and long-liv'd, and multiply more than others. As for the manner of their Generation, it mut have ome proportion with that of
perfect Animals, which are as little undertood; there being no Philoophy that can tell why a Hore begets rather a Colt than a Calf; nor why a Pear-tree rather produces a Pear than a Plum.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXIIII. Of Zoophytes or Plant-Animals.
div.p: THe comprehenivenes of this Univere appears in that in the diviion of Entity and Subtance, not onely each Member anwers to as many things as are in Nature, but there are as many others as there can be everal combinations made of the Members of this diviion. Thus in the diviion of Souls into vegetative, enitive, and rational, there are found middle ones not onely between ene and reaon, but alo between Vegetation and Sene: Examples whereof may be een in the Families of Animals and Vegetables. Some Plants have no Root as Mileto and Muhrooms; others nothing but Root, as Trubs and Truffles: ome have onely leaves, as Duckmeat; others neither flowers nor eed, as Ferne; ome want leaves, as Venus-Navil; others commonly put forth the Fruit before the Leaf, as the Fig-Tree; and latly, ome Flower without bearing Fruit, as the Flower-Cherry-Tree: Of Animals, ome are bred of putrefaction, and of others, ome remain a while without motion or life (to appearance) as the Silk-Worm in its bag, and Snails in Winter; others remain alwayes immoveable, as Oyters: And becaue this manner of being nourih'd and growing without any progreive motion is proper to Plants, and yet by opening and hutting their Shells they tetifie ome ene; therefore they are call'd Plant-animals, in which the Soul eems to be compounded, and to reemble changeable colours, which conit of two extreams, as Gray doth of White and Black, being wholly neither, but both together. So alo a Zoöphyte is omething les then an Animal, and more then a Plant.

The Second aid, That Forms and particularly Souls are indiviible. Indeed one may be comprehended in another, as the Vegetative is in the Senitive, and this in the Rational (which comprehends all eminently) but it cannot enter into the compoition of another, much les be divided, informing a body that is half Plant and half Animal; otherwie by the ame reaon there might be others half Men and half Beats, which is not imaginable, but under the form of a Monter. Moreover, uch diviion would proceed to infinity, there being a Latitude and Degrees without end between one extream and another; of one whereof that which partakes mot, would contitute a new Species, or rather a new genius, which is aburd, and contrary to
Philoophy; which admits not multiplication of things without nec • ity.

The Third aid, That by the ame reaon Plants and Animals being of the ame pecies there can be no doubt but thee two attributes might be found in the ame Subject. For Vegetation and Sene being onely everal operations of the ame Soul, which acts differently, according as it findes the Organs of its Subject dipos'd; hence the multiplication of Souls is unneceary, eeing they are all but one. And as in Brutes the enitive faculty upervening to the vegetative in their generation, adds no new form to the former; o the vegetation of Plants is nothing les then the enitive: the dipoitions of the matter being the ole caues of this diverity. An Animal depriv'd of the ue of ome enes, is no les an Animal then another that hath all: why then is a Tree les an Animal, becaue it exercies fewer operations of its oul then Animals do? Nor is it a concluive reaon that Plants are wholly detitute of the faculties of ene, becaue the ame are not perceptible to our Senes, which yet finde omething to atisfie themelves in the enitive Plant, growing (as Scaliger and others relate in Zanolha, a part of Tartary, where the Inhabitants owe a Grain like that of our Melons, but omewhat longer; from which grows an Herb which they call Borrametz, that is, a Lamb, whereof it hath the whole figure, epecially the Feet, Hoofs, and Ears, yea, all the Head excepting the Horns; intead whereof it hath a tuft of Hair upon the Forehead. 'Tis cover'd with very oft Hair, employ'd by the Natives to make Caps of. Its Fleh reembles that of Crevices, and being wounded, ends forth blood, being alo of a very weet tate: It adheres to the earth by its root, which ends forth a Stem or Stalk which is inerted into its Navil. To all which wonders they adde, That it lives as long as there is any green Gras about it, and dyes when the ame is wither'd either by time or purpoely. And to make the comparion full, they ay that of all devouring Animals Wolves alone deire to feed of it, We finde alo ome example of this double Life in the Wood of Scotland, which being humected in water is turn'd into Ducks: as alo in the Leaves of another Tree like that of the Mulberry, which Anthony Pigafet reports to have two little feet, on which they run away as oon as one touches them, and live onely of Aire. Such likewie are the Mandrakes of upper Hungary, which grow in the axact hapes of Men and Women; The Baraas mention'd by Joephus, which hines in the night, and whoe flight cannot be topt but by the mentrual blood of a woman. The Balam-Tree which Pliny affirms to tremble at the approach of the Iron that is to make inciion in it; and that other Tree which Scaliger aith grows about eight foot high in the Province Pudiferam, and upon the approach of a man or other Animal contracts its boughs, and extends the ame again upon their departure, whence it took the name of Arbor Pudica: which contriction
and dilatation is alo attributed to the Spunge. In all which effects we oberve powers and faculties near of kin to thoe of Animals. The ame uniformity of nature between Plants and Animals is prov'd alo, in that, both the one and the other live and dye, have their nutrition, augmentation, and generation. If Animals have their time of being alacious, Plants have theirs of being in Sap. They have dictinction of Sex, as appears particularly in the Cypres, Hemp, and the Palm, which beareth not fruit unles planted near the Male, or at leat ome branch thereof be fatned to it. They eem too to have ome kinde of repiration; for beides that they love the free Aire, towards which they encline when planted near a high Wall, or under great Trees; their Root, which is their mouth, hath ome dicernment of tate, echewing hurtful oils, and preading freely into good ground, and not imbibing all orts of liquors indifferently, but onely uch as are convenient for them. Hence their parts have names common to thoe of Animals; as the Marrow, Fleh, Veins, Skin: In a word, they eem to want onely local-motion, which yet, beides the foregoing examples, is found in the Herba Viva of Acota which folds up it leaves and flowers when it is toucht; as likewie Tulips do in the evening, and open the ame again in the morning; Marigolds follow the Sun, and thence have gotten the Latin name Solequia; but more manifetly the Sun-flower, and the white Carline Thitle, call'd the Almanack of Peaants, who therefore hang it at their doors, becaue it folds up its flowers when a Tempet is at hand. 'Tis notorious that the Bon-Chretien Pear-Tree, and the Mulberry-Tree languih in places not frequented by men; and on the contrary, tetifie by their vigour and fertility that they delight in their converation. Hereunto might be added the experience of Wood-Cleavers who finde that a wedge enters further at the firt blow then for many following; as if the ubtance of the Tree clos'd it elf upon the firt feeling it hath of its enemy. But the bending of Hazle-rods towards Mines of Gold and Silver, eems to denote omething more in them then in Animals themelves. In brief, the motion of creeping Herbs may be call'd progreive: amongt others, that of the Gourd and Cucumber which follow the neighbouring water, and hape their fruit in length to reach it.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXV. Of Trubbs or Truffs, and Muhroms.
div.p: AS there is ome middle nature between a Plant and an Animal, partaking of both o; there is alo between a plain Mixt Body and a Plant, to wit, thoe Exuberances which grow ometimes on Trees, as Agarick; ometimes only out of the Earth, as Muhroms and other uch fungous Productions, which are driven forth by the inward heat of the earth helpt by that of the Sun. The matter of them is a lime, or unctuous or vicous moiture fit to receive a utable Form, which is various according to the trength of Nature, and the Dipoition of the places through which it is driven; as the Water of our Artificial Fountains puts on the hape of the pipe through which it paes. And as for Trubbs, 'tis Cardan's Opinion, That melted Snow inking into the urface of the Earth, and finding fit matter there, produceth this Plant. Which the plenty of Spirits found in Snow, makes me willing to aent to; becaue they may erve for Seed to its Production.

The econd aid, That he lik'd the common Opinion, that Trubbs proceed from Thunder; whoe agitation of the Air, and o of the Earth, awakens the hidden Seed of this Plant, as well of many others that grow of themelves; or ele perhaps the Rain that follows Thunder being full of Celetial Vertue, proper for this Production, is the Seed thereof. For the Providence of Nature ometimes upplies by an Univeral Efficient the Defect of particular Caues detinated to the production of other Plants, which in mot Trees and Herbs is the Seed, which this wants, as alo all the ordinary parts of other Plants; becaue 'tis of the Nature of thoe Animals who have not their parts ditinct one from another, having neither talk, nor leaves, nor flower, nor root, unles you will call it all root; becaue it hath more appearance of than of any other part of a Plant: which perhaps is the caue of its excellent tate, which is neither weet as mot roots are, nor owr as mot leaves are, nor of any other kind of tat oberv'd in the other parts of Plants, but mix'd of all tats together, being very pleaant, after coction hath matur'd what was terretrial and aqueous in it. As for Muhroms, both their Nature and Caue is different; but all proceed from an excrement which the Earth cats forth of it elf, and which was bred therein by the perpetual trancolation of the Humidities of the earth; whence they are more or les hurtfull according to the greater or les malignity of uch Humours, but always of bad juice utable to its Source and Material Caue.

The Third aid, 'Tis the Rain of Autumn that makes the Muhrom; the too great cold of Winter, and that which yet remains
in the Spring not permitting that Excrement to come forth, but hutting it up (as 'tis the property of Cold) and the heat and drought of Summer conuming the Matter that produces them as fat as it comes out of the Earth. But in Autumn, when the Earth is cleft and chopt in many places by the foregoing heat of Summer, the Showers and rainy Seaon upply excrementitious matter proper for this Production. The ame might be aid of Trubs, if we aw not their generation to be made as 'twere in the turning of a hand, immediately after Thunder: whereof the clefts of the upper crut of the Earth are a manifet evidence; not in all oils, but only in barren and les cultivated; in which, culture would diipate the matter before it could acquire the preparations requiite to this generation.

The Fourth aid, That the tory of Martius Licinius ometimes Praetor of Rome and Governour of Spain, who in Carthago Nova, biting a Trub or Tuber found in it a Roman peny of the value of even Englih, hews that this lump is made of earth hardned together, as Stones and other mixt Bodies are, which grow naturally by the ole appoition of matter without being either own or planted. For 'tis found in the earth without either root or fibres: yea it may be call'd an imperfection of the earth, becaue 'tis never found in good ground but only in gravelly places near woods and buhes, and hath no certain bignes; ome being very mall, and others of the bignes of the fit and of a pound weight; ome, full of and; others not, which are the bet. They are alo of divers colours, according to that of the Soil, namely Red, Black and White, of a very avory rellih, but hard of digetion, and windy. Their common hape is round, but Pliny mentions ome horned ones brought from Thrace, which therefore he calls Ceraunia; he alo addeth, that in ome places (as particularly at Mitylene) the torrents produce them, and carry them along with their treams; that they lat but a year, and are more tender in the Spring then at any other eaon. Some hold that they grow not at all, but are produc'd in an intant of their full bignes; and their reaon is, becaue they have no organs of Nutrition, without which they cannot grow; and indeed they do not generate. This opinion would be the more probable, if what Pliny aith were true, namely, that there is no ign of cleft or chink in the earth which covers them. But experience hews the contrary, Swine (who are greedy of them) being lead by the mell they exhale through thoe clefts, to find them and root them out of the ground.

The Fifth aid, That Muhroms are to Plants, as Inects are to Animals; for both are generated of corruption, and that uddenly; both want ditinct parts, and have omwhat of a hurtful or venemous quality (for the mot part). But Muhroms are either Medicinal, as Agarick; or Alimental; or abolutely
poyonous; which two latter pecies oftentimes differ only according to the oil. For uch as grow in Meadows are the afet, and the Orange-colour'd are as good and delicious in Provence and Languedoc, as they are poyonous in France, Germany and Hungary, where they are ordinarily employ'd to kill Flyes, and where they caue viions. Such were thoe which kill'd the Emperour Claudius Father-in-law to Nero, who therefore term'd them the food of the Gods, becaue the Roman Emperours were deifi'd after their death. They are alo ometimes dicernable by the colour and mell: The blackih or livid, whoe juice is yellowih and which mell like Copper, being deadly; but the white, the greyih, and thoe that are red underneath with a black juice and a pleaing mell, being alimental. The leat to be upected are thoe which grow by Art in dunged places, or Melon-beds enrich'd with Hogs-dung rotted for the pace of two years. 'Tis aid alo that the good have a thicker tem then the bad, and alo a circle or crown on the top. If any malignity remain in them, Cato advies to correct the ame by etting a Colewort near them, which (he aith) draws to it elf all the impurity of the earth; wherein, if oft, are bred Muhroms; if hard, Trubs; but both without eed: jut as Yellow-Gilly-flower and Pellitory grow pontaneouly upon walls made with Lime and Sand; Silver-weed, in Brooks; Crees, in Springs; the Earth containing in it elf the imperceptible eeds of many animated bodies. To the Production whereof Nitre alone (by its above mention'd fecundity) uffices; for finding no eed to determine it to any other production, it pends it elf in generating of Trubs. For beides their tate and mot uual inward colour, (which is white or greyih) their flatuoity and aptnes to provoke Lut (which two qualities are proper to Nitre) tetifie the ame; as alo doth their Nativity during the Thunder or Rain of Autumn, and of the end of the Spring; which eaons are full of Nitrous exhalations. The ame may be aid of Muhroms, which commonly pring out of Nitrous ubtances, as dung and earth where Salt-Peter grows.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXVI. Which is to be preferred, Company or Solitude?
div.p:
'TIs hence forward lawful to doubt of every thing, ince a Problem is made of an Axiom. For Man being a ociable Creature, renounces that quality when he eeks Solitude; in which not only Speech, Courteie, and Civility, but all Sciences and Arts, yea almot all Virtues become ueles to him, and leave him by little and little to put on Beat and beatial properties,
to wit Silence, Rudenes, Ignorance, and in one word Brutality it elf; (though there is ome ociety even amongt many irrational Creatures, as Cranes, Bees, Ants, and divers others.) Conider one of thoe olitary dumpih perons rightly tyl'd by the Vulgar Loups-garoux (or Men-wolves) enemies of mankind; they are commonly of extravagant minds, whoe dotages pas in their own weak judgment for divine thoughts beyond thoe of the ret of men; but when brought forth they erve for nothing but laughter, which is oftentimes the reaon why their Authors keep them o very ecret. Examples whereof are een in all thoe melancholy Doters who build Catles in the Air. If they make profeion of Arms, they are meer Don Quixots; if of Divinity, Hereiarchs; if of Phyick, Empericks and people void of other kill aving that they have ome incommunicable ecret. On the other ide, conider ociable humors, and you will find nothing in them but what is agreeable and pleaing. If they have any buines in hand, they advie with others about it, and knowing that two eyes ee not o many things at once as four may do, they pollih their reolutions by the mutual colliion of their own Opinions with thoe of others; and conidering that the way to do well is to be reprehended by many, they ubmit themelves to their judgment. Moreover, make an induction of all good things, and you will find them all in Society; without it the World would be depopulated in les then one Age, whereas 'tis perpetuated by propagation of the Species. There is nothing to be got in olitude, though one hould imitate the humor of an indefatigable Gameter of thee times, who finding no body to keep him company, plays at Cards and Dice all alone in his Cloet, which he aith is ome divertiement to him: but the Trades-men, Labourer and Merchant gain nothing without Commerce, which cannot be but between many perons. Pleaure is not o much as imaginable, whilt. a man is alone by himelf. Your Hypochondriacks and other fools cannot conceive any delight but by their fancying themelves convering with others. Then for Honour, it uppoes one peron honoured and another honoring; o it conits not with olitude, which conequently is an enemy to all orts of Good. But to purue the induction on the other ide; we ee that Balls, Comedies, Revels, Feats, and all Ceremonies both Civil and Eccleiatical are perform'd in company; which, the greater it is, adds the more plendor thereunto. Wherefore if you take away company, you at the ame time deprive men of all the means of employing the Goods which they have gotten by their labours, and alo of the honour they aim'd at in enjoying the ame, the hopes whereof was the onely thing that weetned their pains. Let a man be alone, and he needs no cloaths but to cover his nakednes, or keep off the cold; whereas the magnificence of Courts is the mot glorious token of the plendor of a State.

The Second aid, Though it be hard to praie olitude in o good company, yet it hath three orts of goods in it, which are endeavour'd to be acrib'd to Society: For, in cae it had no other benefit but ilence, of the oberving whereof none ever repented (but of peaking often) the perfection of a Chritian is found in it. For of the three manners of inning, Solitude hath none to avoid but thoughts; and thoughts themelves arie only from the former frequentation of company: upon which account, thoe that have mot ought Innocence, have retir'd from Companies and Towns. Thus did the Prophets in the old Law, and afterwards Hermites inhabited the Dearts of Thebes, and alwayes the trictet Religions have liv'd the mot olitary. Then for the delight it affords, there is no pleaure like that of Reading, Meditation, and Contemplation, which are not conitent with Company: and man being more eentially reaonable than ociable, who doubts but a man reaons better in olitude then in the turmoil of company? Nay, not only the peculative Sciences are bet poliht by it, but alo the civil and popular, as Eloquence and Poetry; the one was learnt by Demothenes in his Cloet, and on the Sea hores; the other is a great friend of olitude, and makes its followers eek it. On this account the Greeks built the Temples of the Mues in Woods and places remote from Towns; and night, the mother and companion of olitude, was by them tyl'd Eufrone, Wie. This was alo the reaon why the Pythagoreans enjoyn'd five years ilence before the hearing of their Philoophy: yea, thoe that have received mot honour and contentment in converation have mot lov'd Retirement; witnes Augutus, who long'd to diengage himelf one day from publick affairs; Diocleian and Maximian who went to eek it in Slavonia; and in the lat age Charles the Fifth in Portugal. 'Twas not therefore without reaon that the Roman people cry'd that onely Vatias alone knew how to live, becaue he retir'd from the City into a olitary and deart place. For though the Procriptions and publick Calamities had occaion'd his retreat at that time; yet the contagion of company, the common depravation of manners, and the contentments attending peaceful olitude, are charms trong enough to attract any conidering man; beides, that honour too follows it, being compar'd to the hadow, which flyes its puruers, and follows thoe that avoid it. Accordingly, all thoe that have affected olitude, as amongt the Pagans Empedocles, Apollonius, Num, the Gymnoophits, and our Druydes, have been mot eteem'd by men for o doing. And they are weak mindes which cannot upport themelves, but want the converation of others; herein reembling Ivy and other climing Plants, which onely creep upon the ground, if they be not propt up by ome other; whereas great Oakes and Elmes maintain themelves alone againt the outrages of the windes. So alo the mot generous Beats are olitary, as the Lion and Elephant in Dearts; the Eagle in Rocks and high Mountains; contrary
to Pullen and other timid Animals, which are call'd Gregarious. Hence it may be inferr'd, that Fear caus'd men to build Towns; and that (as Aritotle aith) onely the multitude of everal faces deerves not the name of a company, which made Diogenes go about at noon in the Market with a Lanthorne to finde a man; and makes me conclude, that as the wie Man hould take contentment only in himelf, o he ought to eek onely his own company. For being never les alone then when he is o, olitude indeed hath its ociety, but ociety is in • onitent with olitude.

The Third aid, That indifferent things are ditinguiht from good and bad, in that they are ometimes good and profitable, ometimes not; but the two latter are alwayes determin'd to one end. Now no body will maintain that company is either alwayes good or alwayes bad. It mut therefore be indifferent, and like the water of rivulets in Gardens, which is converted into the nature of the Plants it irrigates. For, is there any Society more authorized by God then Marriage? and yet 'twere a bold propoition to prefer it before the contentment of a Religious life, but becaue this is not alwayes olitary, after the mode of Carthuians and Hermites, company is to be preferr'd or potpon'd to olitude, according to the everal circumtances of the one and the other.

The Fourth aid, That according to Aritotles aying, There are two orts of olitary perons; the firt, above the ret of mankinde, as the Heroes and Demigods of Antiquity, who frequented not men becaue they found them unworthy of their converation: the other ort are below men, and avoid convere, as uncapable thereof, like thoe Peaants whom their ruticity keeps from appearing or peaking in company. But becaue the former are fewer then the latter, hence olitude is more commonly a ign of a mans defect then excellency, and conequently company is to be preferr'd before it.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXVII. Whether Birds, or four-footed Animals, or Fihes be mot Intelligent.
div.p:
THe Aire, having mot affinity with the Spirits whereby all the functions of the oul and body are exercis'd, and both are conjoyn'd; it may eem ufficient to give the advantage to its Inhabitants the Birds, though they had not the tetimonies upon which men value themelves above their fellows, to wit, more advantages of nature, and a greater apitude to diciplines then others. For they have the ame priviledges of walking upon the earth that other Land-Animals have; yea, ome of them, as the Plongeon or Ducker go upon the waters; and beides,
they have this particular Gift of Nature, that they cleave the Air with a motion o wift, that the Holy Scripture hath expres'd the peed of Angels by aigning them wings. Nor can you imagine any action, without excepting even virtuous ones, which is not found in a Bird. The Swallow is kill'd in Architecture; the Halcyon is able to divine how far the Nile will overflow, and knows that out of Nature's repect to her, there will be no Tempet at Sea while he is building her Net; the Gooe is o afe a Guard, that it ometimes av'd the Capitol to the hame of the Sentinels; the Wren erves for a guide and a cout to the Crocodile; the Crow and the Turtle are patterns of conjugal amity; o are the Storks of piety; and even the warms of Bees, are models of Common-wealths; and the Pimires, when Age and Experience has render'd them more advied, acquire wings. The Silk-worm is nothing but a Caterpiller till its wings appear; and then fluttering about it, perpetuates its pecies with uch prudence, that it doth not lay its Eggs in heaps, which would hinder their hatching, but diperes them in everal places, in order to being more commodiouly animated by the heat of the Sun. Then, as for Art, we ee no Animals beides Men capable of peech (the firt of Diciplines) but Birds. And the particular Examples of the Elephant, and a few other Beats that have hewn ome hadow of Judgement, are outdone by the Eagle which flew into the fire, wherein her Mitrees Body was burning, and many other Intances too numerous to be mention'd.

The Second aid, That the little head of Birds, in comparion of the ret of their Body, their drines and abounding Choler permit them not to be o intelligent as other Animals; their chattering jargon as little deerving the name of a Language, as their other actions do that of Virtue. Moreover, their leep being not o ound and deep, as that of Terretrial Animals, which by ucking their Dams are more humid; and leep being the retorer of Spirits, Birds cannot have uch plenty as other Creatures. Whence they uffer themelves to be more eaily taken than Land-Animals, whoe Bodies being more ymbolical with ours, they mut alo have greater aptitude for exerciing ome functions correpondent to thoe of our Mind. For the cavities of their head and brains more reemble ours, than thoe either of Birds or Fihes; particularly, that of the Ape, which conequently is the mot intelligent of all Animals next Man; with whom all will agree, that no other Animal can dipute the preeminence of Judgement with the leat hew of Reaon; if any hould, it would never gain the Caue, in regard Man mut be the Judge.

The Third aid, Man hath no more reaon to award this Caue to himelf, than to pretend to the advantage of flying better than Birds, or wimming better than Fihes, who exceed all Creatures in point of Health, even to a Proverb, which is a thing
altogether neceary to the functions of the Soul. Moreover, they are of a very long Life, which begets Experience, as that doth Undertanding. Their Health is manifeted by their Fecundity; and ince coldnes is the Complexion of the wife, and Salt is reckon'd the Symbol of Widom, Fihes, the inhabitants of the Sea, and the coldet of all Creatures, mut have a hare thereof. Beides, if oftnes of Fleh be a ign of goodnes of Witt every where ele as 'tis in Man, (and Phyiognomy teaches us to draw conequence from other Creatures to him) Fihes have this advantage above all the Inhabitants either of the Air or Earth; both which, were indeed made for Man, but the Sea was primarily made for Fihes; its other conveniences being only accidental. Silence, the common ditinction between the wie and the foolih, is natural to them; whereas the voices and chantings of Birds and other Animals, is oftentimes the occaion of their ruine. Yea, they are o ubtle, that Fiher-men cannot take them but with a white line, of the colour of the water; otherwie, if it be gros and viible, they will not come near it. Diffidence, the Parent of afety, is more common to them than to all other Animals, and their vigilance is greater. Land-Animals have no leight equall to that imperceptible charm, whereby the Torpedo chills the arm of the Fiher-man; or to that of the Cuttle-fih, which when he is in danger of being taken, moils the water with her Ink to keep her elf from being een; or to that of the Polypus, who becomes of the Colour of the Rock upon which it holds, to void being perceiv'd. And though the Element of Water o eparates us from the commerce of its Inhabitants, that the hundreth part of what concerns them is unknown to us; yet there is none but oberves, that Fihes need more leights to ecure themelves from the ambuhes and hotilities of others, than the beats of the field have, which are alo more eaily taken. The Fih call'd the Mullet, trikes off the bait of the hook with her tail, intead of being taken by it; and if he cannot do o, he is contented to bite it round about; and the Sea-wolf finding her elf taken, hakes her head this way and that way with much pain, till he have cat out the hook again; and for the ame purpoe, the Sea-fox turnes her inide outwards. The Loubine and Sea-dog finding themelves urrounded with the Net, make a hole in the ground and culk therein, till the Net be drawn over them; but the Dolphin rejoyces in the Net, becaue he may with eae fill himelf with his fellow-prioners; yet when he perceives he is drawing near the hore, he bites the Net; which if he cannot do quick enough, the Fiher-men knowing him a Friend to Man, pardon him the firt time, and only thruting a bul-ruh through his kin let him go; if he be taken again (which eldom happens, as Plutarch aith, out of whom mot of thee Relations are taken) he is beaten. Yea, they are ingenious not only for themelves, but for others; for when the Gilt-head hath wallow'd the
hook, his companions bite the line, and if one of them fall into one of the Mehes, they lend him their tails to bite and draw him through; and when the Barbles ee one of their companions caught they get upon him and with the indented pine they have upon their backs cut it aunder. Craus's Lamprey would take bread out of his hand, and was bewail'd by him when it dy'd: The tory of Arion, and that of the Fih call'd Manaro in the Iland of Hipaniola, which was delighted with praies and Muick carry'd nine or ten perons upon his back, and having been wounded by a Spaniard diappear'd; the Raye which Olaus writes defended a man from Dogs upon the hore of Denmark; and the Sea-Eele which the Indians carry behind their Boats to let him play about the Tortoies and other Fihes which they take; are abundant intances that Fihes are both ociable and docible. This alo is jutifi'd by the Pinatere, which pricks the Oyter to advertie it when its prey is within; by the Spongothere, which performs the ame office for the Spunge; and by the Whale's guide whom he uffers to leep in her throat, and without whom he would dah againt the hore; by the Pike, which keeps company with the Tench, whoe limines erves to cloe his wounds; by the Tunnies, who always et their good eye toward the hore, and move well order'd in a cubick quadron; by the Sea-Urchins, which preaging a tempet, lade themelves with tones for fear of being carry'd away by the waves; and by all Fihes in general, which wim againt the wind, let it hould open their cales, excepting one whoe cales are et the contrary way.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXVIII. What is the caue of the Criis of Dieaes.
div.p:
CRiis (if you conider its derivation from a word which ignifies either to judge or to eparate or to encounter) agrees in ome ort to every of thoe ignifications; for a Dieae is judg'd by it, it eparates the good humors from the bad, and that after a combat between Nature and the Dieae. But 'tis commonly defin'd a mutation of a Dieae either to Health or Death, for better or for wore. We mut firt conider in it, the term of its commencement, which is the Augmentation of the Malady, whence acute ones have their Criis ooner then Chronical; the very acute being ometimes judg'd in four days, in which time very malignant Fevers weep men away, but commonly within even days; acute Dieaes are judg'd by the 14th or 20th day, and ometimes not before the 40th. Chronical Dieaes extend to the 120th; after which term they count no longer by days but by moneths and years. The term it ends at,
is either Health or Death, or the change of one Dieae into another. The term through which it paes is the pace of time employ'd by Nature in the coction, eparation and excretion of the peccant Humours. The Agent or Motor is Nature, which mut be aited in imperfect Cries, not in uch as are perfectly made. Latly, we mut conider what is mov'd, namely the Humors; for Criis hath place only in humoral Dieaes. A perfect Criis judges the Malady perfect either to Health or Death, and hath had its indices of coction the fourth day for the Criis on the eventh, the eleventh for that on the fourteenth, and the eventeenth for that on the twentieth; it mut alo be manifet either by evacuation or abces (for thoe that mend without apparent caue relape) and fall upon critical days, without any dangerous ymptom: and after uch evacuation the Patient mut be manifetly better, epecially if it be univeral and utable to his Nature, Age, and Malady. Long Dieaes are judg'd by Abcees; acute, by Evacuation. In young perons Fevers are judg'd commonly by Haemorrhage or ome flux of blood; in old men, by that of the belly. Now beides thoe Critical and Indicative days there are others call'd Intercidents which judge imperfectly, and others alo Medicinal, becaue in them purgatives may be adminihed; which days are ometimes Critical, but always unfaithful, and commonly michievous; which will better appear by this general application. The firt day is reckon'd from the hour of the firt invaion felt by the Patient in acute Dieaes, and from the time of his decumbiture in Chronical. Yet in women newly deliver'd we begin not to reckon from the time of parturition, unles it were precipitated, but from the time of the Fever; and this firt day judges no other Dieae but a Febris Ephemera, or one-day Fever. The econd day is vacant and without effect. The third is Intercident, call'd by ome Provocant, becaue it irritates and provokes Nature to make excretions before the time; for being odd, it caues ome motion in the morbifick matter, but imperfectly, as not following the order of Nature mention'd hereafter; neverthes tis Critical in very acute Maladies, and uch as diorder the Laws of Nature. The fourth is an index of the eventh, and hews what is to be expected that day by either the Concoction or Crudity of the Urin and other excrements; no laudable Criis hapning without Concoction precedent. Which holds good not only in continual Fevers, but alo in the fits or acceions of Intermitting ones: for the fourth day being the middlemot between the firt and the eventh, it forehews the deign and trength or weaknes of Nature, and what he is able to do on the eventh. The fifth reembles the third, being likewie provocatory in Dieaes wherein Nature hath made an unprofitable attempt on the third, which he then endeavours to repair; but unuccesfully too, this Criis being mot commonly imperfect. The
ixth is alo Intercident but ordinarily very badly critical: Whence Galen compares it to a cruel and faithles tyrant, which precipitates the Patient into evident danger of life, if it do not kill him. It hath place chiefly in cholerick Dieaes, for in anguine ones alutiferous Cries happen on this day, which is even; the Blood being oberv'd to move on even days. On the contrary, the eventh reembles a jut and gentle King or Magitrate; for neither precipitating nor deferring too long the judgment of the Patient, it gives him time of conideration, judging him after its Indices fully and perfectly, afely, manifetly and without danger. 'Tis call'd Radical, as being the root and foundation of all the other Critical Days, and the end of the firt week. The eighth is of kin to the ixth, but not quite o dangerous. The ninth is the greatet Intercident and comes nearet to the nature of the Critical, though it be not of their number. The caue whereof is, its being compos'd of odd numbers, wherein we have aid that morbifick humors are commonly mov'd; or ele becaue 'tis equally ditant from 7 and 11. The tenth reembles the eighth in danger and other circumtances. The eleventh is an index of the fourteenth, to which it hath the ame reference that the fourth hath to the eventh; aving that the econd week is les active then the firt, and the third then the econd. The twelfth is not of any conideration: and Galen aith, he never oberv'd any Criis, good or bad, on it. The like of the thirteenth. The fourteenth follows the eventh in dignity, and judges thoe Dieaes which the eventh did not, being the end of the econd week, and in this conideration, odd. The fifteenth and ixteenth are not anywie remarkable. The eventeenth is an index of the twentieth, till which the intervening are inignificant, and this twentieth is taken by Phyicians for the end of the third week, becaue they make the ame begin from the fourteenth incluively. From the 20th to the 40th, (which is the end of Criis in acute dieaes) every eventh day is critical. But after the 40th, Dieaes are call'd Chronical, and have their Criis every 20th day to 120, o much the more obcure as they are ditant from the beginning. Of all which changes the Moon eems rather to be the caue then the other Planets, or the vertue of Numbers, as being more active by reaon of her proximity and various apparitions.

The Second aid, That the reaon upon which Atrologers attribute Criis to the Moon, viz. her moving by quaternaries and eptenaries, (her notablet changes hapning every eventh day) is too general. For though he rules over Moitures or Humidities, and a Criis is only in Humoral Dieaes; yet he cannot introduce any change in the above-mentioned Critical Days rather then in others; becaue then he mut have this power either from her elf or from ome other, and the everal Apects of the Sun. Not from her elf; for then no change would
happen in the Moon her elf, nor conequently in us by her means, ince things which are of themelves in ome ubject continue always the ame. Not from the Sun; for then thee alterations in Dieaes hould happen onely at certain potures of the Moon and not in all. Now, uppoe Alexander fall ick to day, and Aritotle to morrow, yet neither of them hall have a Criis but on the eventh day. Beides, the oppoition of the Moon being les at the eventh then at the thirteenth day; the Criis hould be rather on the latter then on the former. And the ame effect of the Septenary in the Conception, Life, Nutrition, and Actions of Animals, which is not oberv'd hitherto; the tomach digeting not better on the eventh day, and the eed not being tronger that day in the matrix then on any other: and the eighth day wherein the Moon is further from the firt then he was on the eventh, hould caue the Criis, and not the eventh. In brief, the eptenaries of dieaes rarely agree with the Septenaries of the Quarters of the Moon; whoe motions being unequal according to the different elevation of her Epicicle, would render Criis uncertain. Wherefore Galen not finding his reckoning hit with the Lunar Motion, feign'd a Medicinal Moneth coniting of ix and twenty days and ome hours; but he hath had no followers therein. Fracatorius went a better way, attributing the caue of Cries to the motion of Melancholly, which is on the fourth day: but as the bilious humor moving alone on the third day without melancholly, doth nothing, o melancholly alone produceth not any Criis on the fourth day. The fifth hath alo the motion of Bile alone, and conequently is without effect. The ixth is quiet in reference to thee humors, being the day of neithers motion: but on the eventh, thee two Biles concurring together make a great critical agitation. But if the matter be not then ufficiently fermented and concocted, the Criis will not come till the fourteenth, when the ame motion of thoe two humors is again repeated.

The Third aid, That this opinion of Fracatorius makes Cries fall upon dayes not critical, as the tenth, thirteenth, ixteenth, ninteenth, and two and twentieth, contrary to all antiquity and daily experience: and is founded in an errour, namely, that one humor cannot putrifie in the body whilt the ret remain pure; eeing Quotidian Fevers are caus'd by Phlegm alone, Tertians by Choler alone, and Quartans by Melancholly alone; and that no other reaon can be given of the regular motion of Criis, but that of the motion of the Heavens.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXIX. What Bodily Exercie is the mot healthful.
div.p: WHat motion is to the Aire and Water, yea, and to Fire too (which it maintains) that is it to our Bodies; Eae makes them heavy, and of the nature of the Earth, which of all the Elements alone delights therein: For the Body coniting of the Elements, it necearily without motion falls into the corruption which Ret introduces into them: and the excrements remaining after nutrition, either recoile back into the mae of Blood, or ele reting in that part of the body which is atiated with them, overcharge the ame, and caue that plenitude which is o much upected by Hippocrates. On the contrary, Motion awakens the natural heat, drives out the excrements collected by eae, trengthens the Members, and renders all the Faculties more vigorous; provided onely that it be us'd after evacuation of the groer Excrements, and before meat, becaue then ret is neceary; otherwie the food in the Stomach will be ubverted, and the motion of the outward parts will too oon attract from the inward the food undigeted; whence many dieaes arie. And this right ue of Exercie is o neceary to health, that the Athenians purpoely dedicated a place for exercies, call'd Gymnaiun, to Apollo the God of Phyick; for which word the Art which treats of exercies is call'd Gymnatica; and the Sorceries of Medea may be better undertood of Exercies, which make young, and trengthen bodies formerly oft and effeminate, than of Herbs wherewith he tuffed the bodies of old men whom he had jugulated; an Art, without which Plato and Aritotle thought a Commonwealth could not be good, and to which chiefly is to be attributed the difference found between our modern Souldiers, and the Roman Legionaries; yea, between the good habitude of their bodies, and the weaknes of ours, who have o intermitted their exercies that onely the names of many are left. Now, ince motion, which to deerve the name of exercie mut alter the repiration of the Animal, is violent to it, and of violent things we cannot take too little; I conceive that uch exercie as holds the mean between ret and extream motions, is the bet. As Riding, or going on Horeback, which giving us motion, diminihes the labour thereof, and tirs all the parts of the body; which happens not when only one part of the ame body is exercis'd, and the ret remain unmov'd.

The Second aid, That Exercie, which is a voluntary motion and agitation of the Body with repiration increas'd (whereby 'tis ditinguiht from the labour of Artians and Labourers, and from Actions accompany'd with no triving, as playing on
Intruments) was transferr'd to the ue of Phyick by one Herodicus according to Plato in the third Book of his Republick, and 'tis taken two wayes, either for that which is made by the proper motion of the Body, or for uch motion as is external to it, as Swinging (the Petaurum of the Latins) Navigation; going in a Coach, or Litter: As for thoe made by the Body alone, they are of three orts; Athletical, Military, and Ludicrous or Pastimes. The Athletick, though the ancientet, yet to me eem the mot unprofitable, erving onely to harden the urface of the body and the extream parts, as the Armes and Legs: uch were Wratling, (which is till in ue among our Britains, and at Contantinople before the Grand Seignior's Gate amongt ome Tartars whom they call Pluyanders) Acrochirim, which conited onely in keeping the fingers interlac'd one within the other; Fifty-cuffs, call'd anciently Pugilatus, and imitated at this day by the Gondoliers at Venice; Cae'tus, wherein the hands were arm'd with plates of Copper; and Pancratia, which was compounded of Wratling and Pugilate. Of this ort were alo, Running, commended by Seneca in his fifteenth Epitle for the Chief of Exercies, and by Plato in the eighth Book of his Republick; Leaping on high and in length, either on both Feet, or on one (as that of the Aleman) the hand and body being void, or ele laden with counterpoies of Lead which they call'd Halteres (as our Morrice Dancers oftentimes wear leaden Pumps, that they may be the more nimble when the ame are lay'd off) or with a Pole to balance themelves in leaping: whereunto may be added the Art of Vaulting. Military exercies belonging either to the ancient or modern way of Militating, and are perform'd either on foot or on hore-back. To the former belongs Fencing, anciently the Art of the Gladiators, and at this day much practis'd with Sword and Dagger: to which may be added managing the Pike, Halbard, and Quarter-taff, cating of Bullets, the Spanih port of running at Bulls, and the hurling of the Zagaye or Lance in Turkey, and hooting with a Bowe or a Gun at a Mark. Military Exercies on Hore-back are fighting at Barriers, running at the Ring and Quintin: to which may be referr'd all orts of hunting. The lat kinde of Exercies which relate to port are Dancing, the dangerous Tricks of Tumblers, who eems to practie the Cubitick Art of the Ancients; the Dik or Coiting, which eems common to them with us; and the Ball, of which among the Greeks there were four orts, differing according to the greatnes or mallnes of the Ball and the Intruments wherewith they truck. Adde to thee our modern patimes of Pail-Mail, Tennis, &c. Next to which you may reckon Shouting, or the exercie of the Voice, which opens the Breat, excites Heat, and cur'd the infirmity of Demothenes's tongue; whence Aritotle allows Children to cry, becaue it purges the Humidities of their Brains. But of all Exercies I think none equal to Walking; as that which comes nearet natural
motions, is eaie, conumes uperfluities, helps repiration, trengthens the tomach, recreates the Senes and Spirits, and appeaes the commotions of the Soul: upon which the Peripatetick Philoophers choe it as an exercie erviceable to the minde and body both together.

The Third aid, That he was of Galens opinion, who compos'd a Book concerning the Exercie of the little Ball, which he preferrs before all other for ix principal reaons. Firt, Becaue it exercies and delights the minde as well as the body; which pleaure is the greater in that it is not dihonet; this kinde of play being of the rank of the honorable. Secondly, Becaue Hunting, which may be alledg'd to be of that rank, needs a great train of nets or hays, hores, dogs, birds, and other uch equipage; whereas the Game of Ball, even as it was practis'd in Galen's time, when they play'd with the palm of the Hand without tick or racket, may be exercis'd by all orts of perons; and this every one knows, that a Good is the better for being the more common. Thirdly, Becaue Hunting requires much leiure, of which only rich and idle perons are capable; whereas a Scholar or Trademan may, without much prejudice to their ordinary Employment, divert themelves at this play: Which (in the Fourth place) exercies all the parts of the Body almot equally; which mot other motions do not, ome exerciing only the upper, ome only the lower parts, and that to exces: Which (in the Fifth place) happens not o commonly in this, wherein you may play as fat or as low as you pleae; the exces which ome commit therein, proceeding only from the irregularity of their Mind, from which the more dicreet are free, retiring upon the firt weat, if they have no other intention. In the Sixth place, it hath no danger as Hunting hath, where the Boar's tooth, the Stag's horn, and the caualties of falling from the Hore, at leat exceive toil and wearines, are more certain oftentimes than the pleaure expected from it; as Running alo caueth breaking of the Veins; and Wratling. dilocation of Members. Whereto it may be added, that the Body acquires dexterity by the Game of Ball.

The Fourth aid, That that Exercie eems mot healthful, which is uitable to every one's Nature. Walking is not for the lame, nor running for the Phthiical. Above all, every one's Cutom is coniderable, in which regard the Exercie of our profeion leaves us les Exercie than thoe of others. Wherefore I conclude, for Exercies which beides the motion of the Body, and the divertiement of the Mind, leave ome profit behind them; as when a Man of Affairs gives his dipatches and reolutions as, he is walking, and the Vine-dreer by exerciing himelf in digging his Vineyard, finds in the Evening, beides the good Stomack he hath gotten, the end of the tak which he had propos'd to himelf.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXX. Whether Vertue conit in Mediocrity.
div.p: 'TIs the property of every thing detitute of Reaon, to be carried to Extremities; the Stone to the Centre; Fire to the Circumference; the Earth imbibes as much water, and an Animal eats as much food as it can; the Spider weaves as long as it hath where-withall, the Nightingale ings oftentimes till he burts; every Paion guided by it elf alone, is carry'd to the utmot point. 'Tis reaon alone that precribes bounds to thee Extremities, which are every where found vicious. On this account, Daedalus in the Fable enjoyn'd his Son Icarus not to take his flight neither too high, for fear let the wax of his wings hould melt at the approach of the fire, which he conceiv'd was in the Sphere of the Sun; nor yet too near the Sea, for fear of wetting them: But to take the middle way in the Air, which coure all have held that have been happy. And as that Man is inupportable, whoe Avarice pares his Wine at the firt pint; o Thrift is too late, when you are come to the bottom of the veel. The Prodigal by doing good to others, does hurt to himelf; the Mier does no good to others, and much les to himelf; he alone that keeps a meaure in his Gifts, deerves the name of Vertuous, and makes his Liberality eteem'd. Rahnes does oftentimes as much, and more michief as Cowardie; but Valour, holding a mean between both, prevents it. The ame may be hewn by Induction in all the Vertues, which have therefore been conceiv'd to conit in the middle. In conideration whereof, the Wie-man prayes for neither plenty nor want, that he may echew the inconveniences of both; but for a Mediocrity, to which the Ancients, to hew their eteem thereof, gave the attribute of Golden.

The Second aid, That Mediocrity is an Invention of mean and irreolute Souls, who in expectation what ide to take, would keep themelves indifferent to any choice; and o long as they do o, they hew their want of Maculine Virtue, which alone accomplihes great deignes, though with great pains, which are the rate for which in old time the Gods old every thing; nor is there a clearer market now-a-dayes, wherein we ee none thrive that are neither Fih nor Fleh, and are alwayes to eek for a Mater, but only uch as have found a good one. Ak thoe who o much extoll Mediocrity, Whether they would make choice of an indifferent Friend, and do not eteem a zealous one above a luke-warm one; o hated both by God and Men, that the Scripture aith, God will pew the luke-warm out of his month, they being, in truth, no better than Hypocrites. Moreover, Charity, the ublimet Vertue, and which mut urvive Faith and Hope,
(perfect Fruition admitting only Love) ought to be o extream, that it can never be too much; ince we are oblig'd to endanger our elves for others, and to love God more than our elves, and our neighbours as much as our elves, whom we always love too much. Let us ee now, whether Jutice loves Extremities bet; concerning which matter, we find it aid, that the highet Jutice is the highet Injutice. Then for Chatity, Is it fit for a Woman (think you) to lend one port of her honor to a Friend, and to keep the other? In brief, Do we not ee that a too circumpect Captain deerves not the Name of valiant, but quits it for that of prudent? And in the practice of Prudence, he who balances too long, and takes not a peedy Reolution to purue the ame yet more courageouly, is abandon'd by all the World. Moreover, the Laws of the Athenians punih'd thoe that would wim between two waters, taking no ide in a publick Sedition; as judging it better to fail in the choice of the one or the other of uch parties, than to take none at all. If you have to do with a Priet about a Cae of Concience, is any thing more inupportable than to find an unreolv'd Mind? The ame may be aid of an Ambiguous Lawyer and Phyitian, who end back their Clients and Patients more diatisfi'd than they came. He that eeks Employment under Grandees, mut not boat of Mediocrity in his abilities to erve; Diligence will not admit diviion, much les fidelity; nothing pleaes but what is extream: Which poibly hath brought Hyperboles into uch credit at Court, and made nothing more uual in commendations, than the word Extreamly.

The Third aid. That ince a Defect and an Exces is incident to all Humane Actions, Reaon requires that we aign the middle place to Virtue, which is defin'd by Aritotle, An Elective Habit coniting in a Rational Mediocrity: And if any be found that eem to be only in Exces, as Humidity in an extream Abaing of of our elves; Magnanimity in Courage rais'd above the greatet things; yet their everal circumtances, epecially thoe of their End, erve to qualifie and determine them. This Chatity which eems uncapable in exces (ince a Virgin cannot be too chate) yet was vicious in the Vetals, becaue they had an Evil End in Paganim, as it is virtuous in our Nunns.

The Fourth aid. That Virtue being high and ublime, this argues that it conits in extremity; as alo do all the Theological Virtues; Charity, as is above declar'd; Faith, the leat doubtings wherein are criminal; and Hope, which never wavers. So likewie do the Cardinal Virtues, amongt which the inflexible Jutice of Cato and Aritides, far urpaeth in dignity the accommodements and wayes of Accord of Arbitrators, which alwayes need a upream Authority to be authoriz'd and executed. Hence a evere Judge of thee times having remitted a little of his ordinary everity, to comply with the Humors of the Age, was aid, To have become a Man; as if he had been Divine before.
As for Temperance, Chatity which is a Species thereof, is more laudable and better merits the name of Vertue in a Virgin then in a Wife; and the abtinence of S. Nicholas, who is aid to have fated from the Nure's Breat, or that of S. Simon Stylites was much more vertuous than ordinary Fatings. In brief, Prudence, though it teach us to keep the middle every where, yet is depis'd when accounted indifferent. Moreover, by the Reaon of Contraries, Vertue mut conit in extremities, becaue Vice does o; and if Vertue hould conit in the middle (which partakes of the nature of the extreams) it hould be compoed of two extream Vices; which is aburd. So the Earth, the vilet part of the World, is in the midt; and Heaven, the noblet, at the extremities, which are the circumferences. Otherwie we might with ome probability render the ame reaon that a Satyre of thee times did, why there are o few vertuous perons now-a-days; Becaue, aith he, Envious Antiquity plac'd Vertue in the middle which is a point, and a point is impoible to be found.

The Fifth aid; That we mut ditinguih Moral vertues from Theological. The former conit in mediocrity, but not the later; and are therefore call'd upernatural as not only attaining but urpaing the bounds of Nature; yet every moderate moral action is not vertuous, nor every extream vicious. For ome are always Vice how little over you take of them; as Adultery, Homicide, and Theft; others, always Vertue in whatever extremity they be found; as Temperance and Fortitude. And becaue Action, wherein Vertue conits, is of particular things, this is bet verifi'd by examples. Thus Liberality is a mean between Avarice and Prodigality; the Avarous being exceive in receiving and defective in giving; the Prodigal, on the contrary, exceive in giving and defective in receiving. Magnificence hath the ame repet to great expences that Liberality hath to les. The regular deire of moderate Honors hath for its extreams. Contempt of Honor and Ambition; Magnificence hath the like, in reference to great honors. Manuetude or Clemency is between Choler which is offended with every thing, and Stupidity which is offended with nothing: Veracity, between Boating and Diimulation; Facetiounes, between Bouffonry and Ruticity; Amity, between Flattery, Moroity and Pratling; Modety between Fear and Impudence. Indignation to ee the wicked abue Fortune, between Envy which is troubled at the properity both of good and bad, and Malevolence which rejoyces at the harm of both; Sufferance, between Softnes and Inenibility; Prudence, between Stupidity and Craft. In hort, all Vertues will be found thus, and have their extreams, although their names are not always eaie to expres.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXI. Whether the Imagination be able to produce and cure Dieaes.
div.p:
AS Health is a natural Dipoition fit for performing the everal operations of the Bodie's Organs, and coniting in the due temper of the Similar parts, the Symmetry of the Organical, and the union of both together; o a Dieae is a dipoition contrary to nature, hindering the ame Functions by detroying the Temperament of the firt Qualities, the proportion and laudable conformation of the Organs; and the Union of both; whence arie three orts of Dieaes, viz. Intemperies, ill Conformation, and Solution of Continuity. Now the Quetion is, Whether the Imagination can of it elf hinder the ordinary Functions of the Similar parts, by detroying the harmony and temper of the four firt Qualities, which is the principle of their actions; as alo thoe of the Organical parts, by changing the natural Figure, Magnitude, Number and Situation of thee Parts, and the action of both by the diolution and divorce of them aunder. Dieaes of bare Intemperature, which is either imple or with matter, the Imagination may produce by moving the Spirits and Humors; which it hath power to do. For the Spirits being aerious and naturally very hot, when they are ent by a trong Imagination into ome part, they may o heat it as by the exces of their heat to detroy the temper of uch part; as Anger ometimes heats the Body into a Fever. And as the too great concoure of thee Spirits makes hot intemperatures, o their abence from other parts caues cold Dieaes; as crudities and indigetions, familiar to uch as addict themelves to Study and Meditation after Meat; the Spirits which hould erve for Concoction being carry'd from the Stomack to the Brain. In like manner, the Imagination having dominion over the Humors, which it moves by mediation of the Spirits; as Joy, Shame, and Anger bring blood and heat into the Face and outward parts; and Fear and Sadnes give them a contrary motion; it appears that it hath power to produce Maladies of Intemperies with matter by the fluxion or congetion of the Humors into ome part, and out of their natural eat. But if the Phanie can diorder the work of Conformation in another body then its own (as that of an Infant, whoe marks and defects wherewith he is born, are effects of his Mothers Phanie) much more may it caue the ame diorder in its own Body, whereunto it is more nearly conjoyn'd. Wherefore, ince it can detroy the temper of the Similar parts and the harmony of the Organs, it may alo caue Dieaes, and by the ame means
cure them too: for if contraries be cur'd by their contraries, then it may cure a cold ditemper by producing a hot one; and if it hath power to caue by motion of the humors an obtruction in ome part, it may by the ame means return them to their natural place, and cure uch obtruction. 'Twas to the Phanie that the cure of thoe Splenetick perons is to be attributed, who were cur'd by the touch of the great Toe of Pyrrhus's left Foot; and we ee many Cures wrought by Amulets, Periapts, and other like Remedies; which having no vertue in themelves to produce uch an effect, the ame mut be referr'd to ome other caue. Now none hath more empire then the Imagination over the Spirits and other Humours, wherein almot all Dieaes conit.

The Second aid, That the Imagination being a imple Cognocitive Power cannot of it elf produce the effects that are acrib'd to it. For all Cognition is Paion, and to know is to uffer and receive the Species of the thing that is to be known, whoe impreion made upon the Organs of Sene is by them carry'd to the Imagination, which judges thereof upon their report. Moreover, there is this notable difference between the Senitive or Cognocitive Powers, and the Vegetative or Motive which are detitute of all Cognition, that the latter are active out of themelves and operate upon the Members, which the Motive Faculty moves with full power, and upon the aliments which the Vegetative Faculties (as the Nutritive and Auctive) alter and turn into the nature of the parts. But the Senitive Faculties and all other Cognicitive Powers have no real enible action. They are active indeed o far as they are powers iuing from very perfect Forms, but their actions are immanent and produce nothing beyond themelves, and conequently can have no influence abroad. So that the Imagination cannot immediately and of its own nature produce either a Dieae or Health in the Body, but only by means of the Motive Power or Senitive Appetite, the Paions whereof are acknowledg'd by Phyitians to be the external caues of Dieaes. If the Phanie could produce any thing, it hould be by help of the Species it is impregnated withall; which being extracted from things, ome think that they eminently contain the vertues of the objects from whence they iue and whereof they are Pictures, and that hence it is that the Teeth are et on edge upon the hearing of grating ounds, that the ight of a Potion purges many, and that of alt things makes the Stomack rie in others, and that the thought of the Plague oftentimes propagates it more then the corruption of the Air. Nevertheles thee effects proceed only from the various motion of Heat and the Spirits caus'd by the Appetite and the Motive Power, which are ditinct from the Imagination. For if the Species had the ame power with the objects from which they iue, they would not be perfective but detructive of their Organs; the Species of Heat would burn
the Brain, that of Cold would cool it, both would detroy it, which is contrary to experience. For though Heat and Cold are contraries in Nature, yet they are not o in the Undertanding, but rather friendly; the one contributing to the knowledg of the other; and the end of Intentional Species is not to alter, but onely to repreent the objects whereof they are copies.

The Third aid, That Aritotle hath built his Phyiognomy upon the great connection and ympathy of the Soul with the Body, which is uch, that the one caueth coniderable changes in the other: To which purpoe the Soul employes no other more effectual intrument then the Imagination. Which power of the Soul upon the Body is evinc'd by the mighty effects of the Paions, epecially of Fear, Love, and Anger; Fear having kill'd many, as particularly St. Valier before the troke of the Executioner: On which account it is alo that Mirth is commended for one of the bet preervatives from the Plague. And we ee that Fear and Sadnes are no les the caues then the infallible igns of the Dieae call'd Melancholy. The ame is further verified by the trange Hitories of thoe, who being become ick by Fancy, could not be cur'd but by curing the Fancy firt; the Remedy being to be of the ame kinde with the Dieae. Thus he who fancy'd he had no head, could not be retor'd to his right ene till the Phyician clapping a leaden Cap upon him, left him to complain a while of the Head-ache. And another, who having tudy'd Phyick a little, and took up a conceit that he had a prodigious excrecence in his Intetinum Rectum, could not be cur'd till the Chirurgeon had made emblance of cauterizing it. Another Gentleman who durt not pis for fear of cauing an univeral Deluge, was cur'd of his conceit by the Countrey peoples crying out, Fire, and deiring him to quench it. In like manner another believing himelf dead would not eat, and had dy'd in good earnet, had not his Nephew (who was reported dead) come into his Chamber in a winding Sheet, and fallen to eat before his Uncle, who thereupon did the like. And to go no further, the tying of the Codpiece-point is accounted an effect of the Fancy, and is cur'd by curing the Fancy alone. So likewie a Lord of Quality falling ick accidentally in a poor Village, and complaining les of his Malady then that he hould dye without a Phyician: no other expedient was found but to cloath his Cook in the Curates Gown; upon which he preently became half cur'd: but cauing the Curtains to be undrawn that he might the better ee to thank his Doctor, he dicover'd the deceit, and fell ick again more dangerouly then before: his imagination thus producing the effects both of icknes and recovery.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXII. Of Facination, or Bewitching.
div.p:
FAcination or Bewitching is the doing of hurt to one by ight, without Contact mediate or immediate; to deny which, is to deny common experience, the verdict of all Antiquity, of the Learned, and of the Holy Scripture it elf. The manner of it is vulgarly thought to be this, namely, when one, maliciouly, and with a dangerous eye beholding ome fair Child, (whoe tendernes of body makes it more ubject to hurt then a tronger peron) hurts it by commending it; which Sorcery is thought to be render'd ineffectual by making Children wear about their Necks ome preervatives, ridiculous indeed, yet much in ue, particularly amongt the Spaniards; uch as the figure of a thumb between the two fore-fingers in the form oberv'd in making a fig for one; 'tis alo a practice to make uch a fig when they rie in the morning, and to pit three times in the boom. Now this kinde of Facination the Poet extends even to Beats, in the common Vere, Necio quis teneros oculus mihi facinat agnos. Some refer it to Antipathy, as they do the Bailisk's killing at a ditance, and the hoarenes caus'd by ight of a Wolf. Plutarch in the fifth Book of his Sympoiacks aith, That ome hurt their Parents and Friends with their Eyes alone; and he relates a tory of one Entelidas, who (like a econd Narcius) perceiving himelf handome in a Fountain, thereupon lot both his health and his beauty: whence he concludes, that uch Facination proceeds not alwayes from Envy, but he refers the caue to the pervere cutom ome get of doing michief, which being turn'd into nature, becomes as neceary to them as 'tis to a bowl to roll. Others think it an effect purely natural; as a Blear Eye infects the beholder with the ame evil; and Plutarch aith, He aw certain ancient people call'd Thibii, who by their apect hurt not onely Children, but perfect men: the viual rayes being render'd more active by the evil habit of thoe that have intention to hurt out of envy, which is dicern'd commonly by frequent beholding the properity of a hated peron; whence comes the word Invidere. An example whereof is een in the little Bird call'd a Witwal, which becomes ick by the ight of one that hath the Jaundies; whereof the Bird being preently concious huts its eyes upon uch a perons approach. For the poion is communicated onely to uch as are fit to receive it, even at further ditance then fire reacheth Babylonian Naptha. And they hold that Envy, or ome other paion, increaes its activity, the
oul promoting the operations of the body; as the imagination excites love, and eager Dogs ometimes become blinde through the violence wherewith they purue their Game. This opinion is backt by the obervation of mentrous women, whoe apect alone taints a Looking-glas; and alo by the effects proceeding from the paion of Love, the caue whereof is attributed to the Eyes, which are ometimes o diorder'd by erotical Folly, that they ee not the objects before them, which cannot be attributed to beauty alone, conidering that the fairet women have oftentimes leat power to attract Lovers by their looks; whence ome are found more dangerous to behold then others. Beides, Plutarch, Aritotle, and Heliodorus, who confirm this Facination, (which is deriv'd from the word < in non-Latin alphabet >
to Envy) in Deut. 28.56. This word is us'd and tranlated by St. Autin, Facination; and the Chaldeans call'd it an evil-Eye, as elewhere that Eye of the envious Hireling is o term'd. But St. Paul peaks plainly of it, Gal. 3.1. aking the Galatians, Who hath bewitched or facinated you not to obey the Truth? Which St. Anelm interprets thus, Who hath hurt you by a livid and envious beholding of your perfection, or (like Enchanters) hath deluded you and made you ee one thing for another?
