And Tertullian aith, That Facination, which o followeth Praie, that the one is taken for the other, is a work of the Devil, and ometimes alo a punihment of God upon uch as forget themelves through vanity.

The Second aid, That Facination in the vulgar ene, is not onely poible but natural, though the caue be occult; as alo are magnetical and electrical attractions. Thus maleficiated perons infect by inenible tranpiration what they wear about themelves: whereunto the eye's tructure and temper renders it the fittet part of the body; whence, beides Dieaes of the eyes, we ee Tears eaily draw others from thoe that behold them hed. Pliny relates that the Tribalians and Illyrians when angry, kill'd people by their apect alone. And Olaus, That the ame is done at this day in ome Northern Nations. 'Tis read of Tiberius that his eyes parkled in the night, inomuch that a Souldier dy'd by beholding him. And Pyrrhus o terrifi'd another, who came to dipatch him, that onely by looking upon him, he render'd him unable to touch him: For, whether viion be by Emiion (as the Platonits hold) the Rayes will carry with them the qualities of the Eye that emits them; or by Reception (as Aritotle will have it) the colours reulting from the impreion of the qualities of a viible object will not be detitute of the ame qualities; or partly by emiion, and partly by reception (according to Galen) the rencontre of both orts of Rayes cannot but be of great efficacy, epecially when animated by the Paions of Choler, which enflames them, or of Envy, which envenoms them.

The Third aid, That there are two orts of Facination, the one natural, performed by natural means, as venomous and malignant
qualities, which are ent from one body to another, and infect the ame by their malignity; the other upernatural and diabolical, perform'd by ecret means, whereby the vulgar believe that Witches can make ick whom they pleae by touching, beholding, and peaking to them; which three wayes they employ to bewitch thoe to whom they deire michief. The firt ort of Facination is poible, and is founded upon the Antipapathy and Contrariety which is found between almot all Bodies; o that even the hadows of ome Trees are noxious to ome Animals, as that of the Yew to Man, and that of the Ah to Serpents. The Fig-Tree appeaes the madnes of the Bull when he is ty'd to it, by emiion of certain vaporous pirits, which entring into him temper and reduce him to moderation: and from the ame reaon meat hang'd on a Fig-Tree becomes more tender and delicate, to wit, by attenuating its groer parts. For the heat of every living body inceantly raiing, and ending forth vapors and pirits, when thee pirits meet others like themelves, they erve them intead of a recruit, and increae the good dipoition of the body wherein they are. And 'tis this way that old women prejudice the health of Children, whilt their vapid pirits are imbib'd by the tender kin of the Infants, and o corrupting the humors, diorder their natural functions. Hence alo conumptive perons give their dieae to uch as breathe near them; and o likewie all contagious and occult maladies are communicated by one morbid ubject, to another dipos'd to receive the ame affection. But the latter ort of Facination, whereby common people think that not onely men and Animals may be kill'd, but alo plants dry'd up, treams topt, tones broken in pieces, and the like; is no-wie in the power of nature, whatever the Arabians ay, who acribe all thee effects to imagination, whoe power they equal to that of Intelligences, who are able to move the whole Univere. For if it doth nothing of it elf in its proper body, where it imply receives the pecies of things, it mut do les without its precinct. Moreover, 'tis impoible for a ound man to make another ick, becaue he cannot give what himelf hath not; they, in whom by an extraordinary corruption the blood, eed, or other humors have acquir'd a venomous quality, being necearily ick. So that 'tis a pure work of Devils; who knowing the properties of things, apply the ame really to the parts of the body without our privity, whilt they amuze our enes with other objects, as the apect of another peron, or ome uch inignificant thing. Beides that, children being apt to loe their fleh upon unapparent caues, uch a change may be purely natural, whilt it is by mitake charg'd upon a trangers praies of the Infant, who mut necearily grow wore, becaue it cannot become better.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXIII. Of Amulets; and whether Dieaes are curable by Words, Tickets, or other things hang'd at the Neck, or applyed to the body of the Dieaed.
div.p:
THis Quetion depends upon the Precedent; for if 'tis poible to make a peron ick by the Apect alone, it may eem alo poible to cure him by Contact alone. In the examining of the matter, we mut ditinguih, as elewhere alo, upernatural cures from thoe which come to pas according to the coure of nature. Of the former ort are all the Miracles of the Holy Scripture, and Eccleiatical Hitory, thoe which Gods power manifets in all times by his Saints, and the cure which he hath reerv'd to our Kings by their ole Touch. Some cure may likewie happen naturally by the pronouncing of words, when the Patients Fancy is o trong that it hath power enough over his body to introduce ome notable change therein; whence that Phyician cures mot, in whom mot confide. Thus I have een ome perons eas'd of the Tooth-ache, upon ticking a knife in a Tree, and pronouncing ome barbarous words. But it falls out oftentimes, that the effect of one caue is attributed to another. Such was the cure of a Gentleman of the Ligue, whom the late King Henry the IV. urprized in the Town of Loges as he was hivering with a Quartain Ague, and the King in Railery ent him a Receipt againt his Ague; the ight whereof preently cur'd him, through the fear he had of that unexpected approach. So alo many remedies act by ome occult property, as Paeony hung about Childrens necks againt the Epilepy; and Quick-ilver apply'd upon the Breat, or hung in a Quill, is believ'd a preervative againt the Petilence: all precious tones are thought to have ome vertue againt ome indipoition of the body or minde: The Eagle-tone apply'd to the Arm retains the child in the Womb; and to the knee, facilitates Delivery: Coral and the Japer top Blood: the Nephitick Stone is conceiv'd to void the Gravel of the Kidneyes; the hinder foot of a Hare carry'd in the Pocket cures the Sciatica of the ame ide from which it was taken. For, Remedies whoe ole application cures by their penetrating and enible vertue are not of this rank. Thus, if Quick-ilver apply'd cures the Pox by cauing a Flux at the mouth, it mut not be term'd an Amulet; nor Cantharides, when apply'd, as a veicatory, they caue Urine; nor Epithemes apply'd to the Heart or Liver: but herbs and other things laid to the Patients writ may be o tyl'd, when they have no manifet qualities proper againt an Ague. The Quetion therefore is, Whether uch Applications, Supenions, and Wearings, have any Natural Effect; I conceive, they
have not. For a Natural Action requires not only ome Mathematical or Phyical Contact, but alo a proportion between the Caue and its Effect. Now what proportion can there be between a Prayer or other Speech (mot commonly inignificative) and the Cure of a Dieae, much les between a little Ticket, or other upended Body; and an Ague? what is aid of the weaponalve, being either fabulous or diabolical, and alwayes upertitious; as the Phylacteries of the Jews were. Although this Error is o ancient that the Greek Athletae were wont to arm themelves with uch things againt luggihnes, of which trifles, their Adveraries alo made ue to overcome them in Wratling; and at this day, ome wear certain Chracters about them, that they may win at play. In like manner, the Romans hung Amulets about their Children's necks, which they call'd Praefifcini, and Facini, and made of Jet; as the Spaniards make them at preent. To which, to attribute any power upon the account of their Form, Number, or other regard beide their Matter, is an Error as great in Philoophy, as it would be impiety and contempt of the Church to extend his concluion to Agnus Dei's, Reliques, and other acred things, whoe o continual Effect cannot be quetion'd but by the prophane and heretical.

The Second aid, That by the Doctrine lately publih'd in the Treatie of Talimans, it appears, that not only Matter, but alo Figure, Number, and other correpondences with the Celetial Bodies have ome efficacy; which to quetion, becaue we know not the manifet Caue, would be too great preumption. Yea, I would not call all uch Effects Supernatural, ince there are o many things feaible, whereof we know not the Caue. And as to the Supernatural Effects of Amulets, they are of two orts: For either they are perform'd by the favour and bleing of God, who redoubles, yea, heightens to a eemingly unpoible degree, the Effects of Natural Caues, or ele changes them: Or they are effected by help of the Evil Spirit, who is the Ape of Divine Actions. As then, in conequence of the Sacraments, God's Graces are conferr'd upon Chritians, o the Devil agrees with the Sorcerer or Magician, that as often as he hall make uch a ign, or peak uch a word, uch an Effect hall follow; whence 'tis no wonder if the Devil, though inclin'd olely to Evil, ometimes does good, as healing a Dieae by applying true Natural Agents to Patients, thereby to accutom the Sorcerer to give credit to his words. Thus an Italian having old a familiar Spirit, bethought himelf to put a great Spider in a box, and yet he that bought it found the ame ue and benefit of it which he deir'd.

The Third aid, That without recurring to good or bad Angels, whoe powerful Effects cannot be quetion'd but by Micreants, we find omething in the ordinary coure of natural things that makes for Amulets, the Antiquity whereof is tetifi'd by that aying of a Roman, who being ick, and ak'd
how he did, anwer'd his Friend, thus: You may ee how ill I am by this Ticket, which I have uffer'd to be put about my Neck: intimating that he mut needs be very ick to uffer it, ince he gave no credit to it. And yet Confidence is a neceary condition for the making Amulets efficacious. For as the belief of icknes oftentimes makes people ick indeed; o an Opinion that they hall be cur'd by uch an Action, Writing, or Word, is capable to work a Cure in thoe whoe Minds have great power over their Bodies: Which Opinion, being founded only upon the Word, Writing, or the applying of an Herb to the Patient's Writ, or other uch Conceipt, the ame cannot be term'd other than an Amulet. Beides, 'twere a great rahnes to conclude, that there is no Connexion or neceary Conequence between Words and Effects; ince the ame is found by Experience: And Words are the ignes and images of things, and conequently, have ome proportion between them. Whence poibly, they that hunt the Hyaena cry continually, I do not ee her, till he be enter'd into the toil, which he doth boldly upon Confidence of that Speech; and when they cry, I do ee her, he endeavors to fly and get out of the Net, but intangles her elf further therein: And in old time Gardners curs'd Parley as they ow'd it, to make it pring up the ooner. Hence alo the very naming of filthy things, epecially when we are eating, turns our Stomacks; and the mention of heinous Crimes makes us frown. And let this hould be attributed to Phanie alone, which is prov'd before not to be active, but only cognocitive, we find that Serpents are charmed by words; and Heiod hath a Vere to drive away Cantharides; and Shepherds affirm, that according to the diverity of certain Words, breeding Mares bring forth either Males or Females.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXIV. Whether Fruition diminihes Love.
div.p:
THe Ignorance of the Definition of Love, eems to have occaion'd this Quetion. For ince the Paions are ditinguih'd only by the various apprehenion of Good and Evil; Hope, repecting good abent; Love, that which is preent; (whence 'tis eldom without ome inward joy, and Lovers would not be freed from their Paion, though they complain of it) to quetion, Whether we love what we poes, is to quetion, Whether Love be Love. Beides, Love being not of things unknown, it follows that the more we know, the more we love that which is amiable (as we do by poeing it) for we cannot judge of that which we poes not, but by the report of others, which is commonly lyable to fallacy, according to the everal interets of the Reporters: Which will appear better by the
comparion of one that prefers a Picture before what it repreents. For what proportion there is between the Picture of a Mitres, and the Mitres her elf; the ame is found between uch Mitres whilt he permits her Servant no privacy, and her elf when he is married to him; the Actions of the one being but the hadow and Picture of thoe of the other, which are dicover'd in their implicity by fruition. We may ay therefore, that the Paion before Enjoyment, is Deire; but Poeion alone is capable to produce true Love. Beides, the perfection of each thing compleats it, and places it in its highet point, intead of detroying it; o likewie Enjoyment, which is the perfection of Love, and the ole Butt it aims at, doth not extinguih it. As one delightful meal may appeae preent hunger, but with-all it incites us rather to deire another than to digut it.

The Second aid, Did we not convere with things altogether imperfect, Poeion would encreae Love, becaue it would ee new perfections in the thing belov'd: But on the contrary, common Experience teaches us the imperfection of what, before Enjoyment, we accounted highly of; and o our Love of it comes to be diminih'd. Beides, difficult things being the fairet, and contrarily brave things, whoe acquiition is eaie, contemn'd, (witnes the Orders of Knight-hood and other Honors, which have been made rare, only that they might be the more amiable) it follows that we les love what we have in our power, than what we have not; Humane weaknes being oon weary of every thing, and naturally carry'd to change: But we cannot be weary of things not in our power, and, conequently, we mut eteem them more than what we poes, the familiarnes whereof, is apt to breed Contempt of it in us: Beides that, the Mind is prone to eek what it wants, and to eteem the condition of another above its own. Thus the Ox would fain gallop like the Hore, who on the other ide envies his labour at the Plough; and every one takes more pleaure in peaking of what he leat undertands, and about the profeion of others, than about his own. Yea, Experience hews us, that Lovers relinquih both the thing and name of Servants, as oon as they are marry'd. Whence a late Poet peaking of his Mitres, aid, He knew no way to moderate the exceive Love he had for her, but by marrying her.

The Third aid, That true Love mut be ditinguih'd from fale; this latter decreing by fruition, whereas the former is encreas'd by it; as alo we mut ditinguih of Subjects that are lov'd. Thoe that deerve not to be o, are like coare Pictures which require to be beheld at a ditance and in a certain tation, becaue neernes dicovers their defects; whereas the nearer an excellent and well drawn piece is beheld, the more it is eteem'd. Beides, a difference mut be made between what is practis'd and what ought to be practis'd. The defects of the peron loving
are not to be imputed to the thing loved; and therefore the Quetion hould not be whether Enjoyment diminihes, but whether it ought to diminih Love; as indeed it neither ought nor doth in things truly amiable; for the more they are known, the more they endear themelves. As therefore the more the Sun ripens a Grape, the weeter it is: and yet one in a Fever thinks it bitter and prefers Verjuice before it; which nevertheles, makes us not conclude Verjuice the weeter of the two: So the digut of a Lover is not to be imputed to the thing lov'd, but is indeed an argument of his own imperfection.

The Fourth aid, If the diminution of Love upon enjoyment were a ign of weaknes of judgment, Women would not be (as they are) more contant then Men after the ame: as we ee, more Men deert the Love of Women, then on the contrary. Witnes the tory of Demophoon after enjoyment of the King of Thrace's Daughter, who fell into depair upon his departure, as Medea did upon that of Jaon, and Dido upon that of her Aeneas. The caue whereof eems not imputable to feminine Pudor, as if having yielded themelves to one man they could not keep their honour unles they keep their affection: but the reaon is, becaue Men are more perfect then Women and find more caues in them for change. Yet I conceive that the augmentation or diminution of Love arieth not from enjoyment; as appears by Friendhip, which is contracted only after long convere, and the eating of many buhels of Salt together (as the Proverb peaks) o far is a thorough knowledg, uch as Enjoyment gives us, from diminihing it. Not to mention the examples of many married couples, who if occaion were offer'd, would not tick to imitate the noble contention of Gracchus and Cornelia, and chue to dye one for the other.

The Fifth aid, That if Fruition diminihes Love, it mut be the fault either of the Lover, or the thing lov'd. Not the firt; for he is always the ame peron, and fruition renders his object more enible, and conequently more amiable to him. Nor the latter; ince the very imperfections of the thing lov'd eem o many perfections to him that loves it, Balbinumque uae delectat polypus Agnae. Thus alo the imperfections of Children diminih not their Parents love, but by the help of compaion augment the ame; Grandfathers commonly love their Childrens Children more tenderly then their own; and amongt their own, the younget. Which holds not only in this kind of work, but in all others; bad Painters having no les kindnes for their own pieces then Apelles could have for his.

The Sixth aid, That the Quetion may be determin'd by ditinguihing the orts of Love. Impetuous Love, uch as is found in Youth and the Poets decribe, wells (like Torrents)
by reitance, and languihes by liberty. Regular and ober Love, uch as is found in ripe years, towards deerving ubjects, and epecially divine things, encreaes (like Rivers) by the acceion of new Notions, as o many new Springs, till it end in a boundles Ocean. Either ort receives augmentation or diminution according to the diverity of the minds affected therewith; the weak, as les capable of undertanding the inconveniences of this impetuous paion, (which matering all the ret, deprives them of the ue of Reaon, and renders them unprofitable to other actions of life) continue longer before they come to themelves and quit this trouble. Hence Women, and of them the leat judicious, are conceiv'd to retain this paion longet, even after poeion of what they lov'd. The contrary happens in the other love, wherein the more we enjoy, the more we are enflam'd to further purutes of knowledg.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXV. Whether 'twere better to know all that men now know, or all that they ignore.
div.p:
NOne doubts but there are till things to be known, and conequently Sciences to be attained. But if we will tand to the wieman's entence, That all known Sciences are vanity (that is to ay, Nothing), the Quetion will oon be voided, there being no comparion between Nothing and Something. Moreover, there being no Science without Demontration, and very few or no Demontrations in any Dicipline, which themelves are founded upon Principles not demontrable, which nevertheles ought to be known; it follows that there is no Science, and that we know but one thing with Pythagoras, to wit, That we know nothing. And Pyrrho went further; not allowing that men know themelves ignorant, but that they mut be contented to doubt of it, yea and to doubt of their very doubting. Accordingly we ee that no reaon is ever o trong but ome other may be found that thwarts it; and in all Diciplines the mot killful are the mot unreolv'd and furthet from that Scholatick temerity; which boats of knowing every thing, and never doubts of any thing; like thoe young Captains that make head upon every occaion, whereas your veterans are more ober. So likewie the mot killful Phyicians are always leat haty in their Judgments and Precriptions; and Lawyers the more practie and experience they have, the more contrary preidents they find in the ame cae. If you acend to Divinity there you will find more ignorance than any where ele; yea Ignorance is the firt degree, and one of the conditions requir'd
to it, which was the reaon why S. Paul o much blames Philoophy, and our Lord choe the implet and mot ignorant, uch as poor Fihers, not Doctors of the Law nor Scribes and Phariees, who were the mot learned of his Country. And at this day when matters of Religion eem mot refin'd, there's none o rah but acknowledges that one ingle moment of the Viion of God gives more knowledg then the whole Sorbonne hath, and that there is no more comparion between what all the men of the world together know of God, and what Beatitude will teach of him, then there is between finite and infinite, that is, none at all. Whereby it appears that the knowledg of men is infinitely exceeded by what they ignore. I hall intance further in the Mechanick Arts, wherein if you compare the things our Artificers are ignorant of with thoe they know, the mot excellent amongt them will confes himelf very unkilful and ignorant; whereof the ole ancient Inventions now lot may erve for a proof. For in ome Roman Monuments lately dicover'd there have been found Lamps which burnt twelve or fifteen hundred years, and were not extinguih'd but upon letting in of the Air; particularly in the Tomb of Tullia Cicero's Daughter at Padua. The invention of a perpetual Motion which animated Archimedes Sphear, dy'd with him; that of malleable Glas, with its Inventor, who was wretchedly lain by Tiberius; that of melting Stones or making artificial ones, or at leat of tranporting and managing them, whereby the Romans built thoe great Piles of Amphitheaters, and other Works inimitable by us, is not known at this day; yea, to go no further, the goodnes of building with mot of the materials of the Ancients is perih'd with them. So that 'tis no wonder that at this day many of their Hitories are accounted Fables; uch as the teaching of an Elephant to Dance upon the Rope, which Suetonius affirms was een in a Spectacle given to the Roman People; the care and indutry of Men being much diminih'd in this lee of times, wherein they deire to obtain every thing without pains. For the new Inventions of later Ages, as the Compas, Guns, Printing, Telecopes, and ome others, were before Chance produc'd them, or at leat gave ome hints to their Inventors, in repect of us in the ame Nothing wherein are all other poible things not yet effected. So that 'tis eaie to conceive that there are infinite uch ecrets, or more excellent (as the Philoopher's Stone, the Quadrature of the Circle, the Fountain without end, and many other things whereof we have only confus'd notions) which he that hould know would be as much higher then all other men, as the Intelligences are above them. For Daemons, whether good or bad produce none of their Marvels but by this Science of things to us unknown; whence we oft-times term that miraculous which is purely natural. As may appear by the few Secrets found in the hands of men, which make them admir'd by all others, and anciently advanc'd them to the rank of Gods.

The Second aid, This Opinion (that what we ignore is better then what we know) is founded upon the maligne envious nature of ome who light what is their own, and eteem only what is anothers, meerly becaue they want it: as thoe that acend up a Ladder, trample on the tep that upholds them, till apiring to that which is above them, but only to trample on it alo next. So he that knows not ome new thing, depies all he knows already, to learn it; and having learn'd it, depies it alo. For 'tis likely our firt Parents who had knowledge of all things, preerv'd the memory of what deerv'd it bet; yea, that for o many Ages as the World hath lated, men have retain'd the mot profitable Sciences and Inventions that Art or Chance hath taught them. If they have let ome be lot, 'tis becaue they found them unprofitable. And as Solomon aith, we hall ee nothing in the future but what hath been already: Should the World lat as long again as it hath done, it would be but a continual repetition of the ame things. Nothing is poken, but it hath been poken formerly. The terms of all Sciences have been o often mixt, that as few or no new words are produc'd in any Language, o there cannot be many productions of Wit but what are repetitions of old ones, cloth'd in a new mode. For, to intance in the Liberal Sciences; is it poible to Read, Write, and Speak either in Proe or Vere better then men do at preent? Can the Demontrations of the Mathematicks become more certain by time then they are now? Will it be more true to morrow then 'tis to day, that the whole is bigger then its part? Have the Chymits and other pretended reformers of Phyick, ucceeded better then others? Can the Laws be better undertood then they are? And for Divinity; is it poible to know more of it in this world then is known at preent? whilt experience teaches us that the multitude of Books doth not les perplex then profit us, both in this and all other Sciences? But, uppoe this old Errour had ome likelihood, to examine the certainty of it we mut compare what we know with what we ignore; becaue both the terms of the Proportion ought, ought to be known. Now we are concious indeed of what we know, but it implies a contradiction that we hould know what we know not. Wherefore if we hould quit the Sciences and Arts known and practis'd by men for what we know not, we hould have the ame fortune with Aeop's Dog, who let go his morel of fleh for the hadow of it which appear'd greater in the water, where indeed there was nothing at all. The truth is, thoe that have employ'd mot time, labour, and money in the earch of Secrets, confes that they have met with nothing but moak. Whence if there be any curious Artificer, he is always unproperous, becaue he never attains his purpoe.

The Third aid, That from what hath been aid of the difference of the knowledge of Daemons and ours, the reolution
of the quetion is apparent. For ince our knowledge is much hort of theirs, it follows that we have more things to learn then we know; the having a habit, not being neceary for knowing its privation. Thus one born deaf and blinde, yet knows that he wants more knowledge through his defect of Hearing and Sight, then he hath by his remaining enes: and though I ee not Night becaue it is not viible, nevertheles I conider by it the beauty of the abent day. Yea, he that hath no Science, commonly values it higher then the Learned themelves do.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXVI. Whether Muick doth more hurt or good.
div.p:
OUr Soul being a proportion, loves what partakes thereof; whence the Rules of Architecture ill-oberv'd, and the Getures of Clowns dipleae the Eye, and diorderly ounds hurt the Ear. For though there is proportion in the Senes of Touching, Smelling, and Tating (which is the reaon why cold hands are o pained upon immediately approaching a hot Fire; and moderate mells and rellihes pleae us better then exceive) yet onely two enes are well capable of judging of this proportion; namely, the ight, and the hearing. And the ame repect that there is between Beauty and Deformity, in reference to the Sight, is found alo between Harmony and Dicord in regard of the Hearing. Wherefore Muick being the Art of Harmony, they who love it not, are as extravagant as they that make no difference between a fair and an ugly face, proportion being the chief difference of both. Hence ome are not contented to account this Art as a Rule and Touchtone whereby to dicern well temper'd pirits from others, but have ventur'd to aert the hatred thereof a mark of reprobation. Moreover, the mot ancient Contets, were about the prerogative of Muick, every one pretending to be mater thereof. Witnes that of the Mues with the Syrens, of thee with Thamyris, of Apollo with Maryas, Linus, and Pan, (who puniht Midas's in judiciounes with Aes Ears) and that of Nero with all the Muicians of his time. Yea, it cures ome Dieaes, (as the biting of the Tarantula and Melancholly) and awages the raving of Daemoniacks, (as we read in the tory of Saul.) The crying of new-born Children is quieted by the jingling of Keyes or a Bain, and when they are become bigger they are diverted with the inging of their Nures. Youth particularly delights in Muick; whence the Cretians made their Laws to be more eaily learnt by their young people by cauing them to ing them; and we ee the Rules of Grammar are for the ame reaon contriv'd into Vere. Caius Gracchus,
when a man made ue thereof to regulate the tone of his voice, never making an Oration but with his Servant behinde him; who twanging a Muical Intrument, took him down when he was too high, and rais'd him when he was too low. And Achilles in Homer diverted himelf with his Harp when he was at leaure from his Military Employments. Artificers weeten the tediounes of their labour with Songs. Shepheards chear themelves with it, and it makes Maids pin more nimbly. Theodulphus the Bihop redeemed himelf out of prion with a Hymne which he compos'd, beginning Gloria, laus, & honor. The tory is known of Arion cat into the Sea by Pyrats, and carry'd afely to hore by a Dolphin, whom he ravih'd with his Voice and Harp, which was firt intituted to honour the Gods. The Indians perform'd their Worhip by Dancing to Songs, Cybele's Priets with Cymbals, the Curetes with Drums and Trumpets; the Romans ung Spondaick Veres, whilt they offer'd their Sacrifices; and David danc'd before the Ark, all his Palms being fitted to the Harp, and other harmonious Intruments of that time. And in this, ee what power Organs have to enflame the zeal of the devout, and how melodious voices are with it; o that the chief difference of Divine Service is in the Singing. And as for publick or private Feats and Ceremonies, nothing renders them more compleat then Muick; whence the Vere, Convivii citharam quam Dii fecêre odalem. 'Twas the cutom to preent a Lute to the Guets; and to him that could not play, a branch of Bayes, which oblig'd him to a Song. But above all, the ue of Muick is effectual in War, whence the Spartans march'd to the ound of Flutes in a kinde of Dance, to the end that by the motion of their Souldiers they might dicern the valiant from the poltrons. The Pythagoreans themelves were lull'd aleep with the Harp, to appeae the troubles of their minde. In hort, Muick accompanies us to the Graves, where people ing Elegies for the deceaed. Thus the Phoenicians added Flutes to their mournings, and the Romans had their Siticines who ung at their Funerals. For Muick excites both adnes and mirth. And jut as Phyick either quiets or purges the humors of our bodies, o doth Muick the Paions of the minde. Plato conceiving that it was given to man not only to tickle his ears, but alo to maintain the Harmony of the Soul with the Body, and to awake our leeping vertues. Thus of divers modes, the Dorick makes prudent and chate, the Phrygian excites to War and Religion, the Lydian abates pride and turns it into lamentations, the Ionick excites to honet pleaures and recreations. Hence Aegythus could never corrupt the chatity of Clytemnetra, Agamemnons Wife, till he us'd the help of the Poet and Muician Demodocus; and the Emperour Theodoius being ready to detroy the City of Antioch was diverted
and wrought to mercy by the melodious Sonnets of little Children, intructed thereunto by Flavianus their Bihop. Yea, the Prophet Eliha recommended this Art, when he commanded a Harp to be played on before him, and then Prophei'd to Joram the overthrow of the Moabites. And Michaia did the like in the preence of Ahab King of Samaria, refuing to propheie till one had played before him upon a Muical Intrument. The relation of Saxo Grammaticus in the 12th. Book of his Danih Hitory, concerning Henry the 2d. King of Denmark, who being told of the excellent Muick of the Violin, deir'd to ee the effects of it; which were uch, that at firt it put him into a deep melancholly, and afterwards chearing him up again, rais'd his pirit to uch a degree of rage, that he lew four of his Guard, and at lat it return'd him to his firt temper; erving onely to hew the excellence of Muick when it is rightly us'd.

The Second aid, That Muick effeminates mens courage, whilt it weetens; like that of Wine taken to exces, intoxicates them, and tranports them out of themelves: which hurtful effect gave jut caue to the fable of the Syrenes, who allur'd Pilots by their melodious voices, to plit againt the Rocks. But above all, it excites to filthy pleaures, and blindes the eyes of the Undertanding, as Mercury did thoe of Argus. And its great delectation, through the diipation of the Animal pirits which the weetnes of the ound attracts by the ear, leaves us les refreht then wearied, and incapable of etting about any erious matter. Its eaing the Sciatica (as 'tis reported) is common to it with every thing that caues great attention, whereby the pirits, and with them the humors being upended, the fluxion mut conequently ceae; and the Rabbins attribute the driving away Saul's evil pirit, not to the Harmony alone of Davids Harp, but to the vertue of the Characters of the Divine Name written upon it. What did the Sybarites get by training their Hores to the Pipe, but this, that the Crotonians cauing Mintrels to play at the joyning of a Battel, render'd their Hores ueles to the Fight, becaue they did nothing but Dance. Moreover, Orpheus one of the mot ancient Muicians was torn to pieces by women, becaue he debauch'd their Husbands. Whence alo Antithenes aid that Imenias was either a Fool, or a bad Citizen, becaue he could play o well upon the Flute; and Philip was angry with Alexander for inging too well; and Antigonns his Governour broke his Harp. Therefore the Egyptians banih'd Muicians as corrupters of Youth, and the Lacedemonians were o afraid let they hould grow into credit amongt them that they expelled Timotheus out of their City for adding a tring to his Lute. Aritotle alo places this Art amongt the Ludicrous, and blames Painters for repreenting the gods inging and playing upon Intruments; whoe goodliet effect is to break ilence, and wate time, leaving no permanent action after it, more then the play of Cards, Dice, and Tennis doth; which lat is much
more profitable for health, and is accounted as honourable to be perfectly kill'd in by perons of quality, as 'tis hameful to be an excellent Muician. In fine, we read not that our Lord ever Sung, nor yet Adam in the tate of Original Righteounes; but one Jubal, the firt Bigamer and econd Murderer of the world, is aid to have been the inventer of it.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXVII. Whether Barrennes is mot commonly tht fault of Hubands or of Wives.
div.p:
AS Fruitfulnes is a power whereby every living thing is able to produce its like, o Barrennes is an impotence in it to re-produce is elf by the way of Generation; by means whereof mortal individuals acquire immortality in their Species: to which purpoe nature hath furnih'd every one with neceary Organs. The generation of perfect Animals requires three things; diverity of Sex; matter or eed, which flows from both Male and Female, and contains in it elf the Idea and Character of the parts from which it iues; and latly, conjunction of both together, without which nothing is produc'd. And though the defect of Generation may be ometimes on the mans part as well as on the womans; yet he is more ubject to terility, which is an impotence proper to a woman, who, after the knowledge of a man in an age and time convenient, cannot conceive. For thoe that conceive not after the 50th. year, or before the 12th. are not term'd barren: Conceptions beyond the former, or before the latter term, being upernatural or extraordinary; as thoe of the Manandri and Calingi, and that of one mention'd by Savonarola, whom he aw big with Childe at nine years of Age; as alo the miraculous conception of Elizabeth after he was eventy years old. The caue of Barrennes is acrib'd by ome to the diproportion between the eeds; whence he that is barren with her firt Husband, is fruitful with her econd. Thoe of the woman are either internal or external. The internal depend partly upon the eed and mentrual Blood, and partly upon the temper of the Womb, and the habit of the body. The eed of a woman, as well as that of man, mut be of a laudable temper, quantity, and conitence, and provided of pirits enough. If the maternal blood, which concurs likewie to generation, be too plentiful or too little, no effect follows, any more then if it were corrupted or wanted other requiite conditions, The Womb (which is like the oil to corn) may be hurt either in its temper, or its conformation, or in the olution of continuity; all which diorders hinder gravidation. As for the habit of body, we oberve that fat women are barren, either
becaue the matter of Seed, which is the purer portion of the Blood, is turn'd into fat; or becaue the Epiploon of fat Women preing upon the Orifice of the Womb, hinders the Seed from entring into the bottom of it. Nor are Women too lean fit for Children, by reaon of their drynes, and the tenuity of their Womb, although they are far more fit than fat Women; but this leannes is to be undertood of o great an extenuation, that it leavs the parts dedicated to Generation, detitute of their vigour and due temperature. Neither are the very tall, or very low much fitter; but thoe that are of a moderate Corpulency and Stature, whoe Breats are firm, and their lower parts larger than their upper. Now ince Conception is an Action proper to the Womb, which quickens the Genitures, the Woman ought rather to be aid the Caue thereof than the Man, and (by the reaon of contraries) the Defect thereof mut likewie be charg'd upon her.

The Second aid, That to blame Women for being more frequently barren than Men, is to deprive them of their chief Glory, which is Fruitfulnes. For Nature form'd them chiefly for propagation, as the Conformation of their Bodies eems to prove, in which the parts erving to that purpoe, as the Womb and Breats, have direct communications not only between themelves, but alo with the noblet parts of the Body. Whence the Civilians reckon not Praegnation amongt Dieaes, (notwithtanding all its inconveniences) but, with Phyitians, as a ign of health and good dipoition. Whereof lpian l. 14. ff. de aedilit. edicto, gives this Reaon, Becaue their greatet and peculiar Office is to receive and preerve the fruit. And therefore Woman, having been in Nature's firt intention deign'd for Generation, he mut be alo much more fit for it, (becaue Nature never fails of her end) than Man, who being born for Command, Labour, Contemplation, and other more ublime Employments, is deign'd for Generation, but in the more remote intention of Nature. For not to peak of the deire of Coition, which might renew the old quarrel that cot Tireias his Eyes, Women eem far more deirous to be Mothers, than Men do to be Fathers; and Nature gives no deires in vain. Beides, Man is naturally Hot and Dry; a Temper les proper for Generation; and he inoreaes the ame by Hunting, Warr, Exercies, and other violent Labours; not to peak of buines and tudy; On the contrary, Women living alwayes at eae, have a Contitution both of Body and Mind more calm, and, conequently, more fit for this Action, or rather Paion. As therefore 'tis more eaie to uffer than than to act; o Women mut find les difficulty in Generation; and, conequently, have les impediment to propagate than Men. I ay nothing of Excees in Dyet, wherein Men are alwayes more licentious; yet 'tis the Exces of Wine that ome alledge as the chief Caue, why ome Northern Countries are at this day almot deart,
whereas anciently they were o populous, that Hitorians call'd the North the Shop of Men, and the Magazine of Nations. Witnes the frequent Colonies iu'd from thence, and the great inundations they have upon other parts of the world. And poibly, the reaon why the Hebrew Law oblig'd a Man to marry the Relict of his iules Brother, was, becaue it uppos'd the defect to proceed from the Huband, and not from the Wife; otherwie, why hould the Siter of a Wife deceas'd with iue ucceed in her tead too? But this Sex is reckon'd alwayes fit for ingendring, and, indeed, is ever ready for it (as the other is not); which is the reaon (as a late Lady aid) why Men make ute to Women, rather than thee to them. Perhaps alo upon the ame account, barrennes under the Old Law was accounted by Women o great a reproach; becaue being very rare, 'tis a kind of a montrous thing in their Sex to be barren. Moreover, we hear many Women complain to the Judges, which is one of the principal Caues of unfruitfulnes. But Hitories afford carce above three or four Women, of whoe inability their Hubands complain'd. And to peak truth, as fertility is imputed to the field, and not to the grain, o it mut alo be to the Woman alone, who is the field of Nature, and not to the Man.

The Third aid, That beides the Internal Caues of fruitfulnes and barrennes, there are alo External ones which depend upon the Air, Dyet, Exercies, Paions, and the abue of the other things call'd Not-natural. The Air by the continual alteration it caueth in the Body, (which attracts the ame by Repiration and Tranpiration) ometimes occaioneth either fruitfulnes or terility, according to the variety of its Subtance, Temper, and Qualities; two whereof, viz. Exceive Heat, and Cold, are great Enemies to Generation; the one melting; the other congealing the Humors; but the exces of Heat leat hinders it, epecially in Women; the coldnes of whoe Temper, is corrected by the warmth, and increas'd by the coldnes of the Air; whence they are more amorous in Summer than in Winter: Whereas the greater heat of Men is weakned by that of Summer, and augmented by the coldnes of Winter; during which, therefore they are more prone to Love. So Dyet too, contributes much to render our Bodies fruitful or barren, not only altering, but making them of the ame Temper with it elf. Thus the waters of Nilus are o fertile, that they make the Egyptian Women bring forth three or four Children at once, by reaon of the Salt-Nitre wherewith that River is impregnated; and, wherein Chymits place the principle of Fecundity, becaue Ahes and Earth depriv'd of their Nitre, produce nothing. But cold waters, even uch as have the Virtue to petrifie, render Women (epecially) barren, as mot Women in Spain are, through their frequent ue of Ice and cold waters; though ome lay the fault upon the rarity and tenuity of their Bodies, and the exces of Heat; which alo is the reaon why the African and Southern
people are not o fruitful as thoe of the North. Dyet, hot and moit, eaie of digetion, nutritive and full of good juice, conduceth much to render Women fruitful. On the contrary, the frequent ue of food hot and dry, gros, and of bad juice, may render them barren, as Leeks and Garlick do; and amongt other Plants, Mint, which was therefore forbidden to be eaten, or planted in time of war; wherein 'tis needful to repair by Fecundity, the los of Men it caueth. In like manner, want of Exercie, by the heaping up of uperfluous Humors, and too violent and continual Exercies, by deiccating the parts, oftentimes occaion terility. Amongt the Paions, Sadnes is the greatet Enemy to Generation; whence Heiod forbids marry'd people to ee one another after a Funeral, but only at their coming from a Bath, or from places of Mirth. In fine, what ever is capable to impair the goodnes of the Temper, is contrary to Fruitfulnes and Generation, which above all other Natural Actions requires an exact harmony of the qualities, and a perfect dipoition of the noble parts, which upply Matter and Spirits fit for this Action. And although Men and Women are alike expos'd to External Caues, yet Women being les vigorous, are ooner wrought upon by them. For, to Internal Caues, which are the mot coniderable, Women are, undoubtedly, more ubject; ince beide Seed, which they upply as well as Man, (who to deerve the name of fruitful, ought only to upply the ame in requiite quantity, quality, and conitence, and place it in convenient Recepticles) the Woman mut alo afford Blood, and alo a place for receiving and preerving both the Seeds and Blood, namely, her Womb, the leat diorder whereof, is ufficient to marr the whole work of Generation. Wherefore ince he contributes mot to Generation, and there are more Caues in her concurring thereunto; if it take not Effect, he is more in fault than the Man, who hath not o many everal concurrences in the buines.

The Fourth aid, That the Caues of terility being either Natural or Adventitious, and equal in the Man and the Woman, nothing can be determin'd upon this Quetion. For in either Sex, there are both univeral and particular deficiences of right Temper, and as many Effeminate Men as Viragoes, (the one not les unfit for Generation than the other, as Aritotle aith) Catration is practis'd in both, and diorderly living is equal as well in Male as Female in thee dayes. For if Men exceed in drinking, Maids and Women are as bad in Gluttony and Lickerihnes. If there be any difference, 'tis from the diverity of Climate; Women being found more fruitful in hot Countries, and les in cold, but Men contrarily; the intemperies of either Sex being corrected by an oppoite contitution of Air. Hence uch Women as have been long barren, ometimes become fruitful by change of Air, Places, manner of Life, and epecially of Age, by which the temperament of the Body being enibly alter'd,
it acquires the Fruitfulnes it wanted, by acquiring the Qualities and Conditions neceary to Generation. Many likewie upon the ame reaon, become fuitful after the ue of Mineral Waters or Baths, and being thereby deliver'd from everal Dieaes, to which barren Women are more ubject than uch as have Children, whom Parturition rids of abundance of Excrements peculiar to that Sex, and occaioning many diorders in the barren.

The Fifth aid, That the obervation made by Bodin in his Republick, and everal other famous Authors, [that the number of Women much exceeds that of Men] eems to void the Quetion; Nature having thereby ufficiently given us to undertand, That fewer men are as fruitful as more women. Which obervation is verifi'd, not only in the Eat and other Countries, where plurality of Wives hath places; but alo in France, where there is no Province wherein Virgins remain not unmarry'd for want of Hubands. Moreover, one man may beget abundance of Children in the pace of nine moneths, during which a woman breeds but one or two; and therefore Man eems more fruitful then Woman, who beginning to be capable of Generation but two years before Man doth (viz. at 12 years old at the oonet) ends 23 years ooner then he; for men generate at 70 years of age and more, but women end at 50. During which time alo they are ubject to far more infirmities and maladies than men; who have not above four or five, whereof women are not capable; but women have fifty or threecore peculiar to themelves.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXVIII. Whether Complaiance proceeds from Magnanimity or Poornes of Spirit.
div.p:
COmplaiance is a habit oppoite to Roughnes; the firt being a Species of Civility, the latter of Ruticity. Now ince we are complaiant either in good or bad things, to be o mut be commendable or blameable according to the nature of the object. But becaue no body doubts that we ought to be complaiant in vertuous actions, and that they are as culpable who connive at vice as they that commit it; It remains to conider of Complaiance in indifferent things, as 'tis in common practie amongt men; and as Juvenal repreents it in a peron that falls a weeping as oon as he ees his friends tears, and when he miles laughs aloud; and if you ay, you are very hot, he weats; if cold, he runs to his Fur-gown. Now the Quetion is, whether uch a man hath more of courage or baenes, I conceive he hews himelf a very pitiful fellow. For this deportment
differs not from that ervile Vice, Flattery, which is near akin to Lying, and eaily turns from an indifferent to a vicious action. Thus Courtiers varnih vices with the name of uch vertues as have mot conformity therewith, calling Avarice, Frugality; Laciviounes, Love; Obtinacy, Contancy; and o in other caes, till they render themelves ridiculous even to thoe they praie; who how vain oever they may be, yet cannot hear their own praies without bluhing at them, being concious that they dipleae all the hearers. Indeed when I am complaiant to any one, 'tis for fear to offend him; and fear was never an effect of Magnanimity. To which all that can be excepted, is that it belongs alo to Prudence to fear formidable things. But Fortitude and Courage are never employ'd in the practie of this vertue, which therefore is very much upected, and oft-times erves for an excue of cowardice. Hence old men, whom their cold blood makes les courageous, are eteem'd the mot prudent; and if they be not the mot complaiant, 'tis to be imputed to the ullennes attending that age, as jollity doth youth. Moreover, as Courage leads us to act without fear of danger what we conceive good and jut; o it teaches us to call things by their proper names, as Philip's Souldiers did. On the contrary, Complaiance teaches people to admire beauty in a deformed woman, to commend a bad Poets Veres, and deire a copy of them from him; to give fair words to uch as we will not or cannot do any kindnes to; in brief, to diemble all things and to diguie our words, contrary to the frequent expres prohibition of God in holy Scripture, which calls it having a heart and a heart: o that no peron of ound judgment can think uch demeanor conitent with true Courage.

The Second aid, That there is as much difference between Ruticity and Complaiance or Civility, as between a Beat and a Man; the former leaving us to the guidance of our Appetites and Senes, and to ay and do whatever they dictate to us; the latter over-ruling them by that power of Reaon, which after the contet remains victorious over the body and enuality. A cholerick man uffering himelf to be tranported by his Paion, utters whatever the violence thereof uggets to him; whereas one of a more edate temper maters his anger, although he have as good reaon for it, and by this prudent action he reduces his friend tray'd out of the rode of reaon; as he that intead of retorting the ill language his friend gave him, ak'd him what the Diamond upon his finger cot him. Which put the other into uch confuion, that having anwer'd the quetion, he ran to embrace him and ak'd his pardon. Whereby it appears how much more courage is requiite to urmount ones elf thus, (which is an effect of Complaiance) then to obey the wing of choler, as vulgar people do: For Complaiance forces our nature and contrains us to peak, and do things contrary to our firt inclinations, and conequently is of more difficulty then
'tis to obey them. Plutarch relates how one Telerus anwer'd his brother, who ak'd him how it came pas that he was les belov'd then himelf, who had been made one of the Lacedemonian Ephori, whereas he was treated with great contempt? The reaon is (aid he) becaue you are not complaiant, and cannot bear any injury. As therefore it requires greater courage to bear then to revenge an injury (as 'tis oberv'd in the life of Socrates, who hindred his Scholars from revenging an affront which was done to him) o 'tis more difficult to be complaiant then rude. And as the ame Author aith, Complaiance coniteth in peaking pleaing things, and in doing good offices; both which require a good reolute Spirit, for our Gallants falely account it courage to run into the Field upon the leat lip of an ambiguous word: Which pervere phantatry hath cot many a brave mans life, who for want of not having attain'd to that high point of Magnanimity which teaches us not to place the point of Honor in every triflle, but only where it ought to be, have really lot the life both of body and oul for an imaginary folly which carry'd them away with the torrent of the popular errour of this Age.

The Third aid, That we may as well place Continence in infamous places, as reckon Complaiance an effect of Courage; the repect being alike of both. For all the actions of a complaiant peron are o many marks not only of repect, but alo of a ervile fear, uch as was that of Alexander's Courtiers, who held their necks awry and hung down their heads in imitation of their Mater, who was forc'd to do o by reaon of a wound; and thoe of Dionyius, who tumbled at every tep, becaue this Tyrant was pur-blind. So when ome peron begins a tedious old tory, I pray, who hews mot courage, he that tells the relator 'tis an old one, or he that uffers himelf to be tir'd with it? Beides, that there is nothing more dangerous then this Complaiance. Certainly a Confeor that is complaiant to his Penitents, and a Preacher that is o to his Auditory, will damn both; and o alo a General that yields to every advice, and reits not uch as deerve it, will infallibly ruine his Army. A Phyitian of this temper, that to comply with his Patient neither bleeds nor purges him becaue of his unwillingnes thereunto, will be the caue of his death; as the Apothecary diminihes the vertue of the Medicine whilt he trives to make it agreeable to the tate, and a pitiful Surgeon makes the ore. A Lawyer that ues the ame coure with his Client, thruts him into many needles and unhappy Sutes. In brief there is nothing o dangerous, nor which argues more weaknes then Complaiance, which like too weet Sauces makes us naueate it, and leaves us as far to eek for Counel as before: Whereas plain and vigorous Counel oftentimes aves the State from hipwreck.

The Fourth aid, If you conider all the kinds of Complaiance,
they have need of contraint, which employs more force and courage then is requiite for following ones inclination. Thus, he that is more thirty then his neighbour and yet tenders the firt glas to him, does this violence to himelf out of complaiance, which likewie obliges him to put his hand lat to the dih though his Stomack be never o harp; if he meet with an occaion of anger, he only miles to himelf, and with diimulation gives the upper hand to his inferior. On the contrary, a rough-hewn peron had rather go to the Gallies then commend Veres which to him eem not good, and (as Plato aid to Diogenes) eat nothing ever but Coleworts, than comply with the Ceremonies and Modes of great perons. Thus he that pares his diarmed enemy, hows greater courage then if, leaving himelf to be guided of his hatred, he hould lay him, which yet is no more then a tetimony of his having overcome him; whereas in paring him he overcomes himelf, which is the greatet victory a man can obtain. To conclude, Praie is the reward of Vertue, and becaue it follows complaience, as corn and contempt doth rutick opinionatry: this is an evident ign that the latter is les vertuous becaue les commendable then the other.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXIX. Touching the means of re-etabling Commerce.
div.p: MAn being born ociable, and ociety not poible without Commerce, the ame eemeth one of the main Concernments of mankind, who are generally troubled, when the ame is either interrupted by War with trangers, or extinguih'd by the negligence of Natives; whereby it appears to be of two orts in general, viz. between thoe of one State, and with Strangers. Now this difference is o eential, that each of them hath its contrary Maxims. Forreign Trade is exercis'd commonly by the truck or exchange of one Merchandize for another, (the tranportation of Gold and Silver being prohibited by the Laws of the State, as alo ome Merchandizes, call'd Contre-band are) or in cae the Forreign Merchants like not the permutation of commodities, they make their payment by Letters of Exchange, which was come to be taken up upon the prohibition of tranporting money. On the contrary, Natives of the ame Country commonly make all their Bargains for money, either ready or upon Credit till a et time. And as the Prince endeavours to promote and facilitate Trade amongt his Subjects for their accommodation, o he ought to be circumpect to hinder Strangers from carrying away the Materials, and (epecially unwrought) Commodities about which his own Subjects hould be employ'd.

The Second aid, That the dignity of Merchandize is prov'd from its Antiquity and Utility. As to the former, we read in Holy Writ of Imaelite Merchants, who bought Joeph as they were going from Galaad into Egypt to Trade; and in the Poets of Jaon, whom they feign to have voyag'd with his Ship Argos for conquet of the Golden Fleece, ininuating thereby that Travelling and Trading by Sea and Land is the way to grow rich. As to the latter, all Arts would be unprofitable to men without ditribution of their works, which is done by Merchandize, whereby that becomes ueful and known in one place, which was ueles and unknown elewhere; and the Proverb is confuted, that every Land beareth not all things; ince a Countrey of Trade abounds with every thing, and the four parts of the world are brought together by Commerce. 'Tis Merchandize that enricheth States, all which acknowledge Money; which arieth by it, the inew of War, and the key of all political Enterprizes. 'Tis that which upplyes Princes with Metals, Jewels, Marble, and other magnificences, whereby the plendor of their Perons, Courts, and Palaces is advanc'd; and both in Peace and War 'tis the uret foundation for Impoitions, which maintain the expence of either. 'Tis that which upports the neceities of Souldiers, and upplyes them with proviions both for war and utenance; whence among the Eatern Nations, the Pedlers and Victuallers are the mot coniderable Officers of their numerous Armies. In hort, Commerce affords Lawyers the ubjects of their Pleadings, Sentences, and Arrets; and not onely Sugar, Cinamon, Cloves, and other Spices for our Tables, but alo mot Drugs for Phyick, as Rhubarb, Agarick, Sena, Caia, Tamarinds, Guaiacum, Muk, Ambergreece, and whatever is rare; beides, Books to all thee Profeions; and to God himelf, Incene to perfume his Altars. Nor is this employment more profitable then delightful in reference to the variety of places, perons, and things; a divertiement which alone ufficeth to induce Travellers to adventure the dangers which accompany them. As for the dignity of it, I hall onely adde to what hath been aid in a former Conference concerning the ame, That they, who depie Merchandizing as if it had omething of bae and abject in it, are more worthy of pity for their groe error, then of an anwer. Do they know better wherein Dignity conits then thoe ancient Roman Senators, who fraighted and maintain'd Trading Ships; the gain whereof was their bet revenue? and are o many other States and Republick ever the les noble for Trading? Is there more honour in the idlenes of a half Gentleman, who for want of other employment ueth no other Trade in time of Peace but to ait one of his Neighbours againt another in a quarrel of his own making, then in the care and vigilance of a good Merchant which redounds to the benefit both of the publick and himelf. Beides, the diligent Merchant raies his Family, whereas the idle Gentleman detroyes
his; being driven at lat either to go in a pittiful garb, or ele to be cloath'd upon the credit the Merchant gives him. Since therefore 'tis the duty of good Legilators to countenance what is mot profitable to the State, and on the contrary to depres and expel whatever brings damage to the ame. Methinks 'twere fit ome new marks of eteem were added to the eential honour of Merchandizing; as either Titles of Honour or Priviledges, which would invite the mindes of our youth to that good employment, who are otherwie apt to be drawn aide by popular error to looenes and debauchery, and thereby commonly deviate from the way their predeceors trac'd out to them. Whence a Merchant that hath got a good etate, intead of leaving his Son to ucceed his Credit, lets it fall, and puts him to ome new profeion, to which he was not born, as to the former.

The Third alledg'd as an argument of the utility of Commerce, that Cities detitute of it can neither increae nor grow rich; whence the ub-diviion made of the etates of families oon impoverihes the Citizens, unles they upply that defect by their indutry, as many rich Nations do. Thus England was for a long time enrich'd by the free trade it enjoy'd with all the neighbouring States, who were at Wars one with another. Thus mot States of Italy, epecially Venice, Genua, and Florence have been augmented by Traffick. But no place more evidently ets forth the excellent profit of Commerce then Holland, where, as their bet Authors acknowledge, and experience hews the countrey, which almot their indutry alone hath made habitable, hath nothing but Trade and Commerce, whereby they have enricht it. For the Soil is not onely bad, as being almot all Sandy; or all Marhy, epecially at Amterdam; the water is unwholeome, and the Air thick and noxious; not to mention their Turffe firing, which fills the head with vapours. So that though they have all the elements contrary to them, yet they cruple not to dipute the Sovereignty with the King of Spain, having made War upon him for four and twenty years together with more gain then los: which they could not have done without the great treaures they draw from Commerce.

The Fourth aid, That ince Trade conits in Negotiations, things old or exchang'd, and their value, the perons mut be honet that exercie it, the Commodity undertood, and the price certain; otherwie 'tis not Trafficking, but meer cheating; whence of all forms of Jutice, none ought to be more compendious, and equitable, and concientious then that concerning Merchandizing, which would be no les ruin'd by fale judicatures, and long uits then by injury and open force. The way therefore to re-etablih Commerce is to re-etablih fair dealing, to remove frauds and ophitication of commodities, whereby he, that thinks he buyes one thing, buyes another of wore value; and above all, to fix and make immovable the tandard of current
money; for want whereof no man knows what he hath.

The Fifth aid, That the firt condition requiite to Traffick, is the afety of wayes. The econd, that of payment, which is remitted to a et term. The Third, The capacity of the Merchant, which keeps him both from being deceived in the worth of Commodities, and in the orts of ready payment, though this kinde of payment be les us'd amongt whole ale Merchants, which is the true way of Merchandizing, that of Retail deerving the name les, and being alwayes accounted more ordid. Moreover, 'tis the former that enricheth States, upplying what they want, and carrying abroad what they abound with. 'Tis the nure of Arts and Manufactures, as appears in the Cities of Lions, Tours, and divers others, where ome one Merchant employes three or four hundred Artificers in Silk, Wool, and other uch works. Amongt which Merchants thoe that bet know how to practie the Maxims of buying and elling cheaper then others, that is, who content themelves with leat profit both in buying and elling, drive the greatet trade, and conequently thrive mot: whereas they that endeavour to grow rich in a day, dicredit themelves for the ret of their lives. I think alo 'twere fit to remedy the evil cutom of ome who et o high a rate upon their Commodities, that they frighten thoe that otherwie reolv'd to buy, or ele affront them with half the jut price. And if after the manner of ome Countreys, the prices of all wares were regulated, much more would be vented, and the time taken up in bargaining would be employ'd in other parts of Traffick, beides that, by this means we might end even any childe for any commodity whatever; in the conideration of the et price and the aurance of not overbuying would make make cutomers buy the ooner, their firt conultation being concerning what money the thing will cot them: whereas now many forbear meerly out of hame to higgle and beat the bargain.

The Sixth aid, That indeed the ole wealth of a State is Traffick, there being onely two orts of goods, moveable and immoveable. The latter increae and diminih onely by War, which is troubleome means and a kinde of game, wherein he that wins one time loes another: whereas moveables are us'd and conum'd though they be of Iron: whence onely Traffick remains for increae: but 'tis not ufficient to know the dignity and profit a thing brings; to put it well in practice, all its obtacles mut be remov'd; as in the firt place the idlenes of the Inhabitants, which is natural to uch as live in a good Soil; whence the Proverb, Bona terra, Mala Gens. Yea, in ome people, as in the Irih, 'tis contradicted by ill cutom; for that people being nouriht in loathfulnes, choe rather to cover their whole Bodies with a Mantle, then take the pains to cut it into Cloathes. Secondly, the want of Materials and Intruments proper for Trade, as Merchandizes, Ships, and other means: beides the
defect of afe Ports. Thirdly, The danger of tranportation by reaon of Thieves at Land, and Pirates at Sea. Fourthly, the want of Companies, both for undertaking great negotiations, and for aurances, as 'tis in Holland and elewhere, where they have found wayes to aure even the lives of perons under good cautions. Fifthly, the fale dealing of this age, directly oppoite to the fair dealing of Merchants, which is incompatible with brangling. Latly, that great proces not yet ended between the King of Poland and the Dantickers, about the impot he would lay upon the Baltick Sea, hows apparently that impoitions alo are a notable hinderance of Trade: All which obtacles and inconveniences may be thus remedy'd in France. The firt needs not much to be poken of, more French living by their indutry in Forreign Countries then Forreigners here, which is a certain evidence that our Nation is none of the loathfullet. But 'twere to be wiht that the Youth deign'd to the honet exercie of Merchandize were not les careful to learn the Map and the Countrey, then our Gentry is o for the war. Nor do I think the Tongues, epecially the Latin, les neceary for them then for Lawyers and Phyicians; ince thee may in cae of neceity learn their Art in their own mother Tongue: But Merchants cannot make themelves undertood in trange Countreys but by the Latin Tongue, which erves to interpret all others; and for want of which 'tis in the power of an Interpreter to deceive them. Neither do we want wares that are both as common and as good as elewhere, as Wheat, Wool, Hemp, and what ever is made thereof, as Cordage and Linen; Salt, Wood, and other uch things; much les materials to build and equippe Ships: and we have the bet Havens of the world. The inconvenience of Robbers and Pyrates is much more coniderable; but the former may be remedied in Cities, by an exact knowledg of all the Houes in each Street; by many clear lights et together, which will cot les then Lanthorns, whereof there is eldom any benefit; by a Night-Watch plac'd in each Street, and by other means to be mention'd in due place. In the Countrey it may be redres'd, if Merchants Travel together in Caravans, and get the aitance of the Provots or Sheriffs, who are bound to ecure the High-Wayes, and as well by Land as by Sea, by the erection of Companies.

The eventh aid, That the only way indeed of improving Commerce, is to etablih Companies. For both Nature and Art teach us, that as heavy burthens cannot be mov'd by little trength; o Affairs of great importance, which need a great tock and attendance in everal places, cannot be manag'd by one ingle peron; who alo ufficeth not alone to remedy oon enough the inconveniences foreeen and unforeeen, which necearily happen in all enterpries. Whence the firt los that befalls a olitary Merchant, dejects, and almot breaks him, becaue he hath not where-with to recover himelf; whereas in Companies, a los is
equally ditributed, and more eaily upported by all the Aociates; amongt whom, if the timorounes of one propoes the afet means, the Courage and Experience brings a Temperament thereunto; and eeing every one contributes his counel no les than his endeavors in the common caue, it is in the les danger by reaon of the many that mind it. Moreover, Companies are bet able to olicite and procure the recovery of prizes unjutly taken at Sea, obtain Letters of Mart, and put them in execution. But as thee Companies are abolutely neceary, and neighbouring States furnih us Examples thereof; o care mut be taken that they do not degenerate into Monopolies, and et exceive prizes upon Commodities.

The Eighth aid, That beide what hath been remark'd, the conjunction of Rivers o frequently propos'd and not yet executed, (through want of Spirits contant enough to accomplih their deigns) would much facilitate Commerce; the tranporting of Commodities ucking up the main of the profit, by reaon of the Exactions of Inns, which laugh at the regulated Rates of Proviions, for want of an Eye to keep them up. All which might be remedied by an able Company, by appointing places of baiting and lodging for their Factors, to be kept by ome of the Aociates, who being thereby intereed in ome portion of the profit, would look more narrowly to the ecurity of the Highways; for want of which care, the mot famous Meengers are often rob'd. It would be of great ue alo to have good and certain Intelligence of the Affairs of the world in general, epecially of the inclining to ruine, delays and failings of Bankrupts, who oftentimes break in one place whilt their Factors are taking up Commodities in others; as alo of the beieging and taking of Cities by an Enemy, or their danger of being o; in which Cae the Merchant will haten to with-draw his tock from thence, and hinder others from ending thither to trade; there being no Sympathy between War and Merchandize. But above all, in this Occurrence 'tis neceary for him to know the certain prizes of the Commodity he intends to deal in: Which hath gain'd great Credit to this Aembly, by the printed Bills it hath ometimes ent abroad, containing the currant prizes of all Wares for every week, in imitation of the City of Amterdam. For by this means, the Merchant needs only dicount the charges of tranportation, and make a Reduction of Weights and Meaures, to ee his evident profit; yet alwayes carefully oberving to draw a line with ome imaginary umm for hazards and contingences which may happen unexpectedly; it being impoible, what-ever care be us'd, to regulate exactly the gain of Merchandize, as depending, partly, on Chance, and, partly, on the Will and Phanie of Men; o that a Commodity, which, for being to day in fahion, or otherwie in credit, would yield twenty in the hundred profit to the Owner, ometimes leaves him a loer, or he is forc'd to keep it long in his Ware-houe.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXIX. What are the mot common Caues of Law-uits; and why they are more now than heretofore.
div.p: PLato deigning a Common-wealth, whoe Citizens might live in good intelligence, jutly excludes out of it the words of Mine and Thine; conceiving, that o long as there was any thing to be divided, there would ever be Male-contents; becaue Self-love (the root from whence the too great deire of keeping and acquiring aries) acts variouly in Men; by main force and trong hand in time of War, and in Peace by Law-uits. Now the deire of Getting, having never been o great as at this day, nor o much countenanc'd and rewarded, (ince in conideration of wealth mot Offices are dipos'd of) 'tis no wonder if Law-uits be more numerous at this day than in times pat.

The Second aid, That Community of Goods, feign'd by the Poets, and exemplifi'd in the Primitive Church, (bating the Charity which produc'd it) would caue as many michiefs, and, conequently, Law-uits, as there are at preent. For every one would endeavour to appropriate what hould be common, and depie it if not able to compas it; as we ee common Caues are neglected, and commonly lot, for private interet. Whence appears the impertinence of ome Legilators, and of the Nicolaitans, who, that the Children might be lov'd the more, would have Wives common; for common Wives and Children would be own'd by no Body; and if uch Women as belong but to two or three, keep them alwayes in jealouie, and many times ingage them in a Law-uit, what would thoe do that belong'd to all the world? Wherefore, I conceive, that if contrary Effects have contrary Caues, 'tis Plenty, and its Daughter, Pride, that caueth Law-uits; and Poverty and Humility makes Peace and Agreements. Which the French Democritus intimates, where he introduces an old man reconciling two Adveraries, but 'tis after they are both undone. Thus alo the Circle of Humane Life repreents Labour holding Wealth by the Hand, Wealth holding Pride, Pride holding Contention, which caueth Poverty; this, Humility; which again produces Labour; that, Wealth; and o round again. For of fifty Law-uits, not one would begin between the parties, (or at leat it would oon be determin'd) if either would humble themelves as much one to the other, as they do to their Judges; yea, oftentimes to their Council. Wherefore Vanity being greater in this Age than ever it was, (although with les reaon in mot) 'tis no wonder if our times abound more with Law-uits than the former.

The Third aid, That uch as are at their eae have no mind to Law-uits; and therefore 'tis not Plenty that begets them, but Neceity, yet not an abolute one; for he that hath nothing cannot go to Law; but uch, that the one cannot pay what he owes, and the other cannot be without it: In every other Cae, Accommodements are poible. 'Tis from this Source that o many Seiures and Sentences proceed, which the indebted would never uffer, had they wherewithall to pay, conidering that the whole charges mut fall upon themelves. Now as there were never o many rich, o there were never o many poor, as there are at this day in France; becaue every body labours out of the vanity above-mention'd, to diable themelves every day more and more, laughing at the Contitutions which are made to reduce us to frugality, and acribing all inconveniences both publick and private to any other Caue but themelves.

The Fourth aid, That though the Ages pat having had the ame viciitudes of Peace and War, and of Poverty and Riches, yet had they not o many Law-uits as there are at preent; and therefore ome other Caue thereof mut be ought, which poibly is this; That the Spirits of Men are become more refin'd and ubtle in the everal Ages of the world, and conequently, advanc'd to a higher pitch of maliciounes, whence many difficulties and contet arie in uch matters, wherein the goodnes and implicity of our Ancetors found none at all. Nor hath the multitude and diverity of Laws been a mall occaion of this bad event. For (beides the Roman Laws which lay long in oblivion, and were retor'd to light by Veruher, in the year 1127. and the Canons compil'd by Gratian, (whence came the judicial formalities) our Cutoms and our Ordinances; and amongt others, thoe made ince Charls VIII. with long preambles and reaonings in imitation of Jutinian, have tirr'd up more Law-uits, than there were in a thouand years before. So that hath been good work for uch as were minded to draw profit thereby, to make o confus'd and intricate an Art of the Law, that there is almot no Cae wherein they cannot find ome trick to multiply a Suit, and render it immortal) Moral Reaon (the foundation of the Law) admits a thouand different faces, not only in circumtances of Fact, but alo in matter of Law; whence there are few Laws but have their contraries.

The Fifth aid, That the multiplicity of our Law-uits is to be attributed to the humor of the French Nation, which is deirous of change, and naturally ubtle and eloquent. Whence a Latine Poet tills France the Nure of Lawyers. Likewie the improvement of Learning in this lat Age, hath contributed much thereunto: And the ight of great Etates gotten by the Law, hath induc'd many Parents to put their Children to that profeion, as the readiet way to advancement. Such as could not be Counellors, have been made Attornies, Solliciters, Sergeants, and this great number of people employ their inventions to get a
livelyhood, which they cannot do without Law-uits. And therefore 'tis no wonder if they advie, continue, multiply, and eternie them as much as they can; egging on the Plaintiff by the motive of Profit, and the Defendant by that of Self-preervation; and refuing to the more imple their writings and other uch helps as might bring them to accord.

The Sixth aid, That Law-uits increae or diminih according to the diverities of proportions kept in the Adminitration of Jutice. For ome meaure them by the Law of Nature, (whereby all Men are born equal) and proceed by Arithmetical Proportion. Thus the Medes turn'd Jutice into Equality; whereas (as Xenophon told Cyrus, reproving him for awarding the coats to his Companions, according to their tature, and not according to the right and propriety) the Perians made Jutice equal. This Arithmetical Proportion was oberv'd by Draco, Solon, Lycurgus, and all popular States; where every thing was put to the balance. Such alo was the Law of Retaliation among the Jews; Eye for Eye, and Tooth for Tooth. But this equality having o many inconveniences, that many times the highet Jutice is the highet Injutice; Plato made Jutice arbitrary without any other Laws but thoe drawn from the proportion of the great to the mall, and other circumtances, which he call'd Equity, or Geometrical Proportion. Yet this Jutice being alo too vagous, and left to the dicretion of Magitrates, who are ubject to corruption; therefore Aritotle choe a middle way between thoe two Extreams, regulating Commutative Jutice, which judgeth of the right of private Men by Arithmetical Proportion; and Ditributive, which is for publick Affairs, by Geometrical Proportion. And our uage hath approv'd an Harmonical proportion; the Supream Magitrate uing both Law and Equity, and tempering the too great trictnes of the former, and the much liberty of the other; which coure is oberv'd in good Monarchies, where the Chief Courts being above the Law, and yet having Equity in their Power, make an agreeable Temperament of Jutice with Reaon, being impower'd to revere the Sentences of Subordinate Judges, who are ty'd to the Letter of the Law; as the Royal Authority is above both. Whence it reults, that there are few Law-uits where Arithmetical Jutice, that is, the inflexible rigor of the Law is exercis'd; omewhat more, where Geometrical Proportion hath place, becaue 'tis requiite to ue Reaons; which being alwayes the ame, cannot be alter'd, as it happens in Harmonical Proportion, in which the point of right (which is indiviible in it elf) being variouly balanc'd between Law and Equity, and drawn from each ide according to the interet of the parties, the Deciions of ome Caes cannot be wholly uted to others, by reaon of the diverity of circumtances. But as Diametrical Proportions having no connexion of their quantities together, though they quiet private Contets, yet they caue a dangerous reflux into the body
