of the State, by the indignation of the Nobles againt the Commonalty, and the People's Envy againt the Nobility; o Harmonical Proportion, uch as ours, is much more prejudicial to private perons, which it entertains in Suits, than to the State, wherein it employes turbulent Spirits to dicharge their Choler upon paper againt their Adveraries. But in Anwer to the Quetion, Why we have more Law-uits now-a-days than formerly, I believe the Reaon is, becaue the common-people have got too much Knowledg of the Laws and Statutes, and Legal Pleadings; for whilt thee remain'd in Latin and were not undertood, Men were not o apt to commence Litigious Suits one againt another.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXX. Whether more hurt or good hath proceeded from haring the parts of Phyick between Phyitians, Apothecaries, and Chirurgions.
div.p:
THis Quetion being of the greatet moment of any that hath been dicus'd in this Company, requireth alo mot caution; becaue there is none of us knows how oon he may come to be at the Mercy of ome one of that Profeion which his Sentence hall dioblige. Now all the parts of Phyick were practis'd of old by one peron; yea, in Aegypt it was no et Profeion, but the Priets of Memphis were bound to write in the Temples of Vulcan and Iis uch Remedies as any Man came and declar'd to them, that himelf had found benefit by; to the end others might ue the ame. So likewie the Greeks writ in Parchment, and hung at the Porch of the Temples of Apollo and Aeculapius, thoe Receipts that had cur'd them; which the Priets took from thence to pronounce to others, as if they had been Oracles; authorizing Medicine by Religion. Afterwards, this Science augmenting by degrees, (as all things do) ome were found that reduc'd thoe Experiences to an Art; the ancientet of whom was Aeculapius the Son of Apollo and Ariadne, to whom in time uceeded another Aeculapius, the third of that name; who (as Cicero, Lib. 3. de Natur. Deor.) was the firt Tooth-drawer, and undertook firt to looen the belly, leaving for his Succeors his Children, Podalirius and Machaon, who were at the iege of Troy, the former of whom profes'd the curing of Inward Dieaes, the other of Outward by manual operation; from which time, the Art of Phyick began to be divided into Pharmacy and Chirurgery, which were practis'd joyntly by Chiron, who took his Name from the dexterity of his hand in operations, and was feign'd a Centaure, becaue he was always on Hore-back to relieve remote Patients. And for that the operations of Chirurgery are more apparent than thoe of the
other parts of Phyick; Plato aith, that the ancient Phyick was only Chirurgery. Hippocrates, who firt poke worthily of Medicinal Matters, exercis'd the three parts of Phyick conjunctly; and o it was practis'd till Galen's time, to wit, 600. years after. Moreover, 'Tis an Argument, That Chirurgery was exercis'd by the Phyicians, That they were expell'd Rome, becaue one of them had cut off a Roman Citizen's leg with bad ucces. So alo Darius's foot dilocated by a fall from his Hore, and retor'd by Democedes a Crotonian Phyician, then his Prioner at Sardis, (after the vain attempts of his Aegyptian Phyician) and is an evidence that he was both a Chirurgion and a Phyician. But ince, Phyicians have done like the heirs of Merchants, they have thought fit to avoid the pains, and enjoy both the honor and the profit; they have reerv'd olely to themelves the authority and power of precribing, and left to the Apothecarie's honety and kill, the choice, dipenation, preparation, and compoition of medicaments; and to the Chirurgion, all manual operations: Nay, many of thee too, out of heedlenes, have left to Barbers and Stews-keepers the Art of triming the Hair; to others, the dexterity of drawing Teeth; and again, to others the Reduction of Luxations and Fractures; all Appendances of Phyick. Now to determine, Whether this Diviion hath done more good or hurt, eems to me to depend upon the capacity of thoe employ'd in this Art.. For if the Phyician hath not kill enough, or trength of Body to attend all thoe functions, he ought not to undertake them. But he that judges himelf able to dicharge them all, will be very heedfull, when he ees the whole honor or blame mut fall to himelf alone; whereas the diviion of ucces amongt many, makes each peron more negligent: Beides that, every one can anwer better for his own deed, than for another's; and agrees better with himelf, than with a econd or third; between whom 'tis eldom but ome Clah happens, and that to the detriment of the Patient. Latly, the Phyician repreents the Intellectual Faculty, the Chirurgion the Animal, and the Apothecary the tal; o that to divide them, is as much as to eparate the Liver, Heart, and Brain of one and the ame Man; and Theory being never well undertood without practice, 'tis no wonder if their di-union hath occaion'd the etting up many Ignorants and Empericks.

The Second aid, If Man's Life be hort, in repect of the Art of Phyick (according to the aying of Hippocrates the Prince thereof) then 'tis the way to horten it more, even by two thirds, to aign it three Arts and Exercies, each of which requires the whole Man. The Egyptians were of another Judgment, not only ditinguihing Phyicians from Operators and Preparers of Medicaments, but alo having particular Phyicians for each coniderable part of Man; as for the Eye, Ear, &c. which render them more expert; becaue we do nothing well, but what we
do often; and what difference there is between one that exercies more Arts, and him that is contented with one, appears by comparing Country-Apothecaries and Chirurgians, who practie all three parts of Phyick, and thoe of great Cities. Moreover the alliance between the Body and the Soul is uch, that while the one is employ'd about ome work, the other cannot intend its cogitations ele-where, as it ought to do in this Cae. And therefore to require a Phyician to let blood, et a bone, or prepare a medicine, is all one as to expect that a General hould both give Orders, and perform the Office of a common Souldier. For if the Mind that is at ret be eteem'd the more wie and capable of reaoning, (whence our Judges it, Phyicians conult, and the Greeks would have adoration perform'd in that poture) what good advice can be expected from a Phyician who is always out of breath with his preparations and operations? Beides, 'tis not eemly for a Phyician to viit his Patient with his Hands melling and dy'd with drugs, and the confidence of the Patient in him being much conducive to the Cure, it cannot but be better truting to three perons than to one. And indeed, uppoing a Phyician were o wicked as to have ill intentions againt his Patient's Life, (which yet is hard to imagine, and there are very few Examples of uch) it would be harder for him to execute them when others prepare his remedies, than when he prepares them himelf. As likewie the Apothecary may play the Villain more ecurely, when he hath not the inpection of the Phyician over him. Wherefore 'tis bet that Phyick remain ditributed into three Profeions, which, like an Harmonious Trade, ait and uphold each other; the Phyician being as the Head, and the other two as his two Hands. All the buines, is, that this Harmony and Proportion be o well oberv'd, that the Hands think not themelves to be the Head; which happens but too frequently, to the great dihonor of Phyick, and damage of the ick.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXI. Whether there be any Real Evil beides Pain.
div.p:
THings have either an abolute Eence, or a Relative; the former are Real, as to be a Man; the latter which have no Being but from the Repect they have to our Phanie, depend upon the ame, as to be glad or troubled at certain News. Thee two Heads contain all Entities; but becaue the weaknes of Humane Judgement often confounds them, taking an imaginary thing for a real, hence the inquiition of their difference hath furnih'd the Schools with various Quetions. That of the Stoicks was o far from admitting any other Real Evil beides Pain, that
it allow'd not Pain it elf to be an Evil. On the contrary, Epicurus held, there was no other Evil but Pain; nor any other Good but Pleaure, its oppoite. Indeed by adjoyning Vertue to that Pleaure, and aigning the pre-eminence to the pleaure of the Mind, it will be eaie to make Good and Pleaure convertible: whence it will alo follow that Evil and Pain mut be reciprocal.

The Third aid, That Evil being the Privation of Good, and Privation no real Entity; to enquire whether there be any real Evil, is the ame as to ak whether a Privation be a Habit. But to comply with the terms of the Quetion, which eems to be, Whether there be any other ufferings of that kind which the Vulgar calls Evils, cauing enible dipleaure in us as necearily as bodily Pain doth? In anwer whereunto, I ay; Firt that there is both a piritual and a corporeal grief or pain; of either of which ome perons are more or les enible then others. Secondly, That all people deire pleaure as a good, and hun pain as an evil (for even the inflictions of ome Religious perons upon themelves, are done in hope of a future good) and latly, that both the one and the other are excited by everal and oft-times contrary ways and means. For as the bitternes of Succhory, hurts and dipleaes ome but is agreeable to others; o alo the ame accident may caue pleaure in ome minds and adnes in others; this variety proceeding from the different temper of Minds. Beides, corporeal and piritual pain differ, in that every one is a capable judge of the former, but not of the latter; whence, as Aritotle aith, all run after pleaures of the Body, becaue they ignore thoe of the Soul; and o likewie mot only reckon their bodily pains true Evils, becaue they have no experience of griefs of the Mind. But he that well weighs how infinitely the Intellect excels the Body, eaily finds that the evils that attaque the ame are alo far greater; ince 'tis that by which the Body is render'd uceptible both of pain and pleaure, and receives impreions of both upon the countenance; wherein particularly the Eye is term'd the Mirror of the Soul, for no other reaon but becaue it repreents her Paions and Affections. And to hew how much grief and dipleaure of Mind urpaeth that of the Body, we ee ome redeem the los of their Honour with that of their Lives, which cannot be without uffering the pain of death.

The Third aid, 'Tis not the Quetion, whether the griefs of the Body or the Mind be greatet ince every one judges variouly thereof according to his humor. As the Mier prefers his profit before the pains of Hunger and Thirt; and the Ambitious peron ventures his life in the Field rather than endure the Lye. But the Quetion is, Whether there be any reality in the Evils which the Mind of man undergoes beides Pain, of which alone we ee all other Animals are enible, Nature teaching Man thereby that he hath left it to his own conduct, how much
his natural condition is wore then theirs, whilt he is not only lyable to the ame bodily evils, but becomes ingenious to his own hurt, and an expert Artificer of his own bad fortune. An intance whereof we have in the Swine that was eating his food peaceably in a Tempet, whilt all the Paengers fearing every moment to plit againt the Rocks, dy'd as often of apprehenion as they thought of that ad fate. Which fear ended with the Swine's meat, and the Ship's arrival at a afe Port; where it appear'd that that vile Animal had felt none of that trouble which the Tempet had caus'd in the more unhappy men; and conequently that their Imagination was the ole caue of it. The like may be aid of all other afflictions which men give themelves, call'd therefore deervedly by the Wie-man, Vanity and vexations of pirit. For mot of the inductions and conequences which the Mind draws from events prove fale, and nevertheles they give us real orrows; we ee frequently that a great Etate left by a Father to his Children makes them debauch'd and worthles, and degenerate from the vertue of their Parent, who having receiv'd no inheritance from his own was contrain'd to labour, and by that means attain'd Riches and Honour: Whence it appears that the trouble of a Father leaving a mall Etate to his Children at his death hath no foundation in the thing but only in his abus'd Imagination, and conequently cannot be a real Evil, and yet this is the mot general Evil of all with the Vulgar. Thus two men, lodging under the ame roof lot both their Wives not long ago: one of them was o afflicted therewith that he dy'd of orrow; the other receiving the conolatory viits of his friends, could not o well diemble his joy but that it was perceiv'd; and yet their los was equal. So that the adnes of the one, and the joy of the other depended only upon the different reflection they made upon this accident. Thus alo the ame affront that made one of Socrates's Diciples draw his word, made the Philoopher himelf laugh at the ottihnes of his enemy: and every thing which the Vulgar calls Good or Evil, (Pain excepted) is a Medal, which hath its right ide and its revere.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXII. Whether Man be the mot dieas'd of all Creatures, and why?
div.p:
A Dieae being a preternatural dipoition hurting the Functions, every living Body capable of action may become ick by ome caue impeding its actions. Hence not only Men but alo Animals, and even Plants have their Dieaes, which
Theophratus diligently decribes. Amongt Beats, though ome are ubject to particular Dieaes, as the Dog to Madnes, the Swine to Leproie, the Goat and Lyon to Fevers; yet there is none o invaded with all orts of Maladies as Man, who is not exempt from any; the leat of his imilary parts that is nourih'd being ubject to twelve orts of Dieaes, namely, when they attract their aliment, either not at all, or but weakly, or otherwie then they hould, or when they are defective either in retaining or concocting it, or in voiding uperfluities. But if uch part have ene too, it may have fifteen; if motion alo, eighteen: And if it not only be nourih'd it elf but labours alo for the publick, 'tis lyable to twelve more, according to the three ways that its Functions may be offended, in attraction, retention, concoction and expulion. The Eye alone is ubject to almot 200 infirmities; and, as if there were not ancient Dieaes enough, we ee daily new ones unknown to former Ages. Now the reaon hereof lyes in the nature of Man, who being the mot perfectly temper'd and bet compounded of all Animals (becaue deign'd to the greatet actions) is therefore apt upon the leat occaion to loe that evennes of proportion, which as it requires a great train and concurrence of many things, o alo there needs but a little thing to ubvert it by defect of the leat of thoe requiites. Indeed, there are but two caues of Dieaes, to wit, Internal and External; and man is alike ubject to both; to the former, by reaon of his hot and moit temper which is prone to putrefaction, and the more upon account of his variety of Food; whereas other Animals never change their Diet; which is the mot probable caue of their health and good contitution: For diverity of aliments incommodes Nature, weakens the natural heat, produces Crudities, the Sources of mot Dieaes; which alo are frequently caus'd in Men by the internal Paions of Anger, Fear, and Joy. The mot ordinary external caues are the evil qualities of the Air, petilential vapours and malignant influences, whereof Man's body is the more uceptible, by reaon of the tendernes of his Fleh, and the poroity of his kin; which on the contrary, in other Animals, is hard and cover'd with Hair, Feathers and Scales, and renders them les ubject to the impreions of external bodies, as alo to Wounds, Contuions, Fractures, and other olutions of continuity.

The Second aid, That uch perfections or defects of things as we know mot exactly, eem to us the greatet; as the excellences and defects of Pictures are not well oberv'd but by thoe that are kill'd therein; and he that is unacquainted with ome certain Nation cannot know its Vices o as they that convere with it do. Now Beats being unable to ignifie to us the differences of their pains and the other circumtances of their dieaes, hence we judge them to have fewer, although the contrary appears in the Hore, in whom obervant Farriers remark
a great number of Dieaes, to which we are not ubject. So that other Animals may have as many, or more than Men, who being les concern'd therein, les undertand them. 'Tis true, the parts of Animals reemble ours, aving what erve to ditinguih their outward hape; as appears by the Diection of Apes, whereby Galen learnt Anatomy; and no difference is found between the Ventricles of a Man's and a Calfe's brain. If their blood and other humors differ, o do thoe of one Man from thoe of another. Moreover, Beats have the ame inward Caues, Fear, Anger, and the other Paions; in hort, all the other Non-natural things, and not at their dicretion as Man hath. If a Dog hath the harder kin, yet man is les lyable to blows, and the injury of the Air. In fine, who knows but it may be with thee Animals as 'tis with ruticks, who, though Men as well as we, and ubject to the ame inconveniences, yet all their Dieaes are reduc'd to a few Heads; ince the true and purious Pleuriie, the Athma, the Cough, the Palie, and other Maladies, whereof we make o many branches, are all reckon'd by them only for a hot or a cold Rheume.

The Third aid, The nearer Nature promotes Bodies to their utmot perfection, the more frail he renders them. And as in Mixts, Glas, which is her utmot atchievement, is weaker and brittler than Stones; o in Animals, Man the mot excellent and perfect, is the mot frail and weak, by reaon of the part wherein he abounds more than they, and which advances him, to wit, the Brain, the root of mot Dieaes. And as the mot noxious Meteors, are form'd in the coldet Region of the Air, o thoe that have a moit Brain are oft and les vigorous, as Women and Children; whence amongt the old Spartans, and at this day amongt the Aethiopians, (as Alvarez reports) 'tis a hame to blow the Noe or pit, becaue it ignifies Effeminacy; and the Thracians, (as Pliny records) freed themelves from many Dieaes, by cutting the Nerves behind the Ear, whereby all fluxions from the Brain were topt. On the contrary, Animals having a dry and les Brain, leep in the open Air without inconvenience.

The Fourth aid, That as Man exercies the greatet variety of Actions, o he is liable to mot Dieaes. Animals which reaon not, have no Delirium; thoe that peak not, are not ubject to be dumb. But the truth is, Men conider not remote things further than their interet reaches. Hence more Dieaes are oberv'd in the Bee and Silk-worm, than in the Elephant. Unles we had rather ay, that there being o great a variety of dipoitions and tempers requir'd to the Health of all the parts, humors, and faculties of a humane body, it happens very rarely that they are all as they hould be. As 'tis harder to make good Muick with a Lute, or other many tring'd Intruments, than with one that hath fewer trings and accords, as Animals have in repect of Man.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXIII. Of the Greennes of Plants.
div.p: COlours being the illuminated urface of Mixt Bodies, alter according to their various mixture; and becaue the les a body is ditant from its implicity, it partakes the more of light; hence as oon as water becomes conitent and olid, it puts on Whitenes, which is o near akin to Light, that the latter cannot be painted but with the former. For this reaon new-prung Plants, iuing out of the Womb of their Elements, retain a White Colour; till having thrut their tem out of the Earth, the nourihment they attract adding to their compoition, they aume a new Colour, which utably to the Temper of the Compound, (whoe upper part is heated by the Sun-beans, and lower part nourih'd with the juice and vapors of the Earth) becomes Green, upon the ame reaon that Blew and Yellow make a Green; the Blew proceeding from condens'd Moiture, (as appears in deep Seas) and the Yellow from the Sun-beams. Hence a Plant depriv'd of the Sun's apect, looeth its verdure, and remaining Colour-les by the privation, which is always Harbinger to ome enuing Generation, it appears white; as we ue to make Succhory and Thitles white by burying them, or covering them in a Veel whereinto no Air can enter. Greennes therefore is the firt mixture of the Sun-beams with corrupted humidity, (as putrid waters wax green) and the firt aay of the Vegetative Soul, and conequently, an evidence of their Life; as, on the contrary, Yellownes hews that the Sun hath dry'd up the humidity wherein the life reided, and left only the Colour of Feüille-morte. But when this humidity is o unctuous and adherent to the compact and olid body of a Plant that it cannot be exhal'd, (as Oyle is not evaporated by the Sun) than the outward Cold hutting the Pores, retains the Greennes longer and brighter, whilt other Herbs and Trees are depoil'd of their verdure. And therefore 'tis no wonder if the leavs of uch Plants, as the Laurel, Holly, Box, Ivy, and many others, feel no injury from great Cold and great Heat.

The Second aid, That the production of Vegetables proceeding from the reolution of Minerals, (as appears, not only in the order of Generations, which proceed from imple to organick bodies, but alo in the ympathy of the Oak with Copper, of the Beech with the Load-tone, of the Hazel with Gold and Silver) 'tis probable that Vitriol, (the commonet of Minerals, and found in mot grounds) gives Plants their Verdure; which many of them alo tetifie by their acidity. For I cannot attribute the Caue to Light, which is indifferent to all Colours, and hath none in it elf; the Gold Colour of the Sun not inhereing
in him, but proceeding from the reflexion of bodies he irradiates. But if we are to find ome mixture of Yellow and Blew to make this Green, I hould rather aign the Yellow to the Earth, which is mot commonly of that Colour; as the Air and Heaven are Blew. And perhaps too, this Greennes is but a ign of imperfect Generation, ince 'tis lot when Plants are mature; and we find it again in mouldy Bread, which is in a tendency to corruption.

The Third aid, That all Bodies mut have ome Colour or other, and a Plant being the firt living thing, ought to have the mot agreeable, as being equally temper'd of the two Extreams, Black and White; for at its firt iuing out of the Earth, whilt it is yet full of earthy humidity, it is of a dark Green, which becomes lighter as the Plant hoots higher; till at length the more volatile particles are excluded in a Flower which borrows its Colour from the various qualities of the ap; then comes out the fruit, which keeps its verdure till the Sun have fully concocted its juice.

The Fourth aid, That 'tis not poible to give the reaon of Colours, ince we ee Tulips change theirs almot every year; and there are Black, White, Red, and other colour'd grapes, equally weet, and good for Wine; as alo Apples, Pears, and other fruit. Nor is Greennes ineparable from the leavs of Plants; for we have not only red Coleworts, but alo Roots, and ome leavs of Rapes, Purple, Violet, and of other Colours. All that can be aid in this matter, is, That Colour is nothing but a reultance of the External Light from the Surface, whoe Particles are o, or o modifi'd and poited. Hence Blew appears Green by Candle-light; the necks of Doves eem of divers Colours by diverity of ituation; and Wool appears whiter when compacted together, than whilt it was in flocks; whereas Water, which hath no Colour, hews white when Particles are divided by Air, and reduc'd into Snow. So alo when Humidity is digeted by Heat, (which is ineparable from Light) it puts on the firt of Colours, which is Blew; (of which Colour thickned Air appears to us) and the prodominant earthines of Plants, makes that Blew incline to a darker degree, thence arieth Green; which is the general Colour of all Plants. The Temperament contributes leat to this Colour; for we ee Sempervivum, which is cold, of the ame Colour with Leeks and the Aloë-Plant, which are Hot. Jut as Sugar and Salt are both White, and yet differ much in Tate and other qualities; o are Chalk and Snow; Honey and Gall are Yellow, the juice of Aloes and that of Liquerice black. Yea, in Animals too, the diverity of their Colour, Hair, and Plumes is deceitful; whence came the Proverb, Of every Hair a good Grey-hound. And whereas Phyicians reckon the Colour of the Hair a ign of the Temper, 'tis not always true; ince we ee perons of the ame Hair totally different in Manners and Humors; and others of different Hair,
perfectly agreeing in temper; wherein conequently we mut not eek the reaon of colours.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXIV. Of the Cold of the middle Region of the Air.
div.p: THe common Opinion attributes the coldnes of the middle Region to the Antiperitais of the heat of the upper and lower Regions, which treightning the cold on either ide leave it no other place but the middle, whither the vapors rais'd by the Sun-beams acending, and no higher by reaon of their weight and the thinnes of the air there; it comes to pas that the neighbourhood of thee vapors returning to their natural cold, encreaes that of the middle Region. But many inconveniences invalidate this Opinion. Firt, if this Element were hot and moit, as is uppos'd, it would hew ome effects thereof; but 'tis quite contrary. For he were a fool that hould go into the Air to warm himelf; and the Air hath o little humidity, that it dries all Bodies. Secondly, many Mountains urpaing the middle Region of the Air, and retaining figures decrib'd in the ahes of a Sacrifice for a whole year, which hew that in all that time no Wind or Rain was rais'd there to deface them; it would follow that uch Mountains reflecting the Sunbeams by their olidity, hould caue heat in the middle Region of the Air, and yet they are commonly cover'd with Snow. Latly, this Antiperitais being only in Summer, not in Winter when the cold of the lower Region ymbolies with that of the middle, this reaon hould then ceae; and yet 'tis in Wintertime that cold Meteors manifet themelves. Wherefore we mut recur to ome other caue; which Cardan takes to be the natural coldnes of the Air, not regarding the combination of the four firt qualities. For if cold be natural to the Air, it will be eaie to conclude, that it mut be coldet in the middle, which is les alter'd by the contrary quality of heat; being mot ditant from the Element of Fire (if there be any) and from the heat which necearily follows the motion of the heavenly Sphears.

The Second aid, That Cold being no poitive Quality, but a bare negation, it follows that Bodies detitute of Heat are necearily cold. Now the Air cannot have heat or any other quality, becaue 'tis to erve for a medium not only to all ublunary Bodies, but alo to the heavenly influences, whoe nature would be perverted and alter'd by the qualities of the Air; as a colour'd medium imparts its colours to objects. It happens therefore that vapours cool not but are cooled by the Air, o that they become colder in the middle Region then whilt they
were in their natural eats. Yea they are o far from rendring the Air cold that they abate its harpnes, which is never greater then in clear weather; cloudy and mity weather being always more warm and accompany'd with les piercing cold. For being rais'd rather by the ubterraneous heat then by that of the Sun, they warm our air (which reaches not above a league from the Earth); then being gradually deerted by the heat which carry'd them up they meet in thoe higher paces which are void of all heat, and begin immediately to condene and congeal them. What people talk of the higher Region of the Air is very doubtful, becaue the Element of Fire being but an Opinion cannot counter-balance the report of Acota, who affirms that divers Spaniards were kill'd by the cold in their paage upon the Mountains of Peru which he judges the highet of the World and within the upper region.

The Third aid, That if we were to be try'd by experience alone, the Earth (which in Winter is hot at the Centre, and in Summer on its Surface) would not be judg'd cold and dry (as it is) no more then the Water always cold and moit, ince the Sun's heat warms it, and the altnes of the Sea renders it heating and drying. But accidental qualities mut be carefully ditinguih'd from eential; becaue thee latter are hard to be dicern'd when any impediment interpoes. As the ight cannot judge of the traitnes of the tick in the water but by having recoure to reaon; which teaches us that all light Elements are alo hot. Now the lightnes of the air is indiputable; and its heat is prov'd by its ubtlety, whereby it penetrates bodies unpaable by light it elf. Yet this heat is eaily turn'd into cold; becaue the air being a tenuious body and not compact, retains its qualities no longer then they are maintain'd therein by their ordinary caues. So that 'tis no wonder if not being hot in the highet degree (as Fire is) but in a remis and inferior degree, it eaily becomes uceptible of a more powerful contrary quality. For the Sun-beams, which ome hold to be the true Element of Fire, heat not unles they be united by reflection; and this reflection being limited cannot reach beyond our firt Region; the higher Regions mut necearily remain cold; unles upon further inquiry it be thought that the motion of the air carry'd about with the Sphear of the Moon and the Element of Fire plac'd under the ame, are capable to heat it.

The Fourth aid, That if we may judge of thoe higher Regions of the Air by thoe of the Earth and Water which we frequent, each of thee Elements hath three enible differences; its Surface, Middle and Centre. Thoe that frequent Mines, tell us that the heat which ucceeds the exterior cold of our earth penetrates not above a quarter of a league in depth; about the end of which pace, cold begins to be felt again, and encreaes more and more towards the Centre. In like manner 'tis probable that the Water follows the qualities as well as the declivity
of the Earth. That it is hot at the bottom (whither therefore the Fih retire in Winter) proceeds from the nearnes of that middle Region of the Earth. So that it being proper to thee Elements to have different qualities in their middle from thoe of their extremities, the ame may be true alo of the Air; poibly becaue a perfect identity of temperature would not have been convenient for the generation of Mixts, to which end all the Elements were detinated. And it being the property of cold to cloe and re-unite the looenes and diipation of the Air, it was therefore highly neceary to be predominant in the middle Region thereof.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXV. Of the Generation of Males and Females.
div.p:
DItinction of Sex is not eential, but conits only in the parts erving to Generation; Nevertheles Aritotle makes Male and Female differ, as Perfect and Imperfect; and aith, That Nature's intention is always to make a Male; and that only upon the default of ome requiite condition he produces a Female, whom therefore he calls a Mitake of Nature, or a Monter. Galen likewie acknowledging no other difference tyles Man a Woman turn'd outwards, becaue Woman hath the ame Organs with Man, only wants heat and trength to put them forth. Now indeed this heat and trength is manifetly greater in Males then Females even from the firt conception; for the former are compleatly form'd by the 30th day, the latter not before the 40th; the former move in the third moneth, the latter not till the fourth; thoe are born in the ninth moneth, thee ome days after; and beides live not if born in the eventh moneth, as Males do, whoe periods are therefore reckon'd by Septenaries, and thoe of Females by Novenaries. After birth, we ee the actions of Males are perform'd with more trength and vigor then thoe of Females, who are actually colder and uffer more inconveniences from cold. They are never ambidexters, becaue they have not heat enough to upply agility to both ides; and their right ide is peculiarly detinated to the Generation of Females, becaue the Spermatick Veel on that ide derives blood from the hollow Vein which is hottet by reaon of the proximity of that Vein to the Liver; whereas the left Spermatick draws from the Emulgent, which carrying Seroe humors together with the Blood, 'tis no wonder if the Seed of that ide be crude and cold, and conequently fitter for generating Femals then Males: Hence Hippocrates aith, that if as Peaants tye a Bull's left Teticle when they deire a Bull-calf, and the right when a Cow-calf,
the ame be practis'd by Man, the like effect will follow. Whereby 'tis manifet that whatever makes the Seed more hot and vigorous both in Male and Female, furthers the Generation of Males, and contrarily; and conequently that the Morning, when 'tis bet concocted, is more proper then the Evening, for begetting Boys; and the Winter then the Summer (at leat on the man's part.)

The Second aid, That as to the production of Males rather then Females, or on the contrary, no certain caue hath hitherto been aign'd thereof; ince we ee that the ame man, in all likelihood without alteration of his temper, hath only Girles by his firt Wife, and only Boys by the econd, and on the contrary; and ome that could get no Children at all in their youth have had only Boys in their old Age. Others have Males firt, others Females, and others have them alternatively. Whereof no other reaon can be aign'd by Chance, or rather the Divine Pleaure alone, in the impenetrable Secrets whereof to eek for a caue, were high temerity. If heat and trength caus'd the difference, young marry'd people would not have Girles firt, as it happens mot often; and decrepit old men hould never get Boys, as daily experience hews they do. Moreover, ome men depriv'd of one of their Teticles, have nevertheles begotten both Sons and Daughters; which could not be, if the faculty of begetting Children of one determinate Sex were affix'd to either of thoe parts. And as from a fale Principle nothing can be drawn but fale Conequences, o alo is it in the opinion of Aritotle, That Woman is but an occaional Creature. For then Nature hould produce far greater abundance of Males then of Females, or ele he would erre oftner then hit right (which is inconitent with her widom), and yet in all places more Girles and Women are found then Men; as appears in that we every where ee plenty of Maids that want Hubands, and in Countries wherein Polygamy is lawful, there are Women enough to upply ten or a dozen Wives to each Man. And indeed, Nature's deign is mainly for preerving the Species; as that of every individual is to preerve it elf; and the bare degree of heat or cold in the Seed being but an accident of an accident cannot effect a formal change in the ubtance. Only defective heat may occaion an effeminate man, and abundant heat a Virago. Beides this Opinion detroys the common and true one, viz. That Generation is one of thoe actions which proceeds from a jut proportion and temperature of the humors; whence exceive or feverih heat detroys the Seed in tead of furthering Generation, and is an enemy to all the other functions. Wherefore 'tis bet to ay that the ame difference which is oberv'd between the Seeds of Plants, is alo found in that of Animals, though not dicernable therein but by the effects: and as the exactet prying cannot oberve in the kernel of an Almond or Pine any difference of the Trunk, Leaves and Fruit
of thoe Trees, although thee parts be potentially contain'd therein, o alo the Seed of an Animal contains in it elf even the leat differences of Sex, albeit imperceptibly to the eye. Which the Rabbins being unable otherwie to comprehend, conceiv'd that our firt Parent was created an Hermaphrodite, becaue both Sexes came from him, his own and that of Eve.

The Third aid, That the ole ignorance of things occaions the acribing of them to Chance, which hath no power over the wie, becaue they undertand the reaons thereof. As for univeral caues, as the Divine is, they concur indeed with particular ones; but as they are becoming in the mouths of Divines and of the Vulgar, o Naturalits mut not top there, ince by the right ue of external caues the internal may be corrected; by which correction not only Seeds formerly barren, or which fell in an ingrateful oil, are reduc'd to a better temper and render'd prolifick, but uch as were detinated to a female production through defect of heat, are render'd more vigorous and fit to generate Males. Now that young married people hit not ometimes upon this latter Sex, 'tis becaue of their frequent debauchery, which cools the Brain, and conequently the whole habit of the Body. Which happens not o frequently to men of more advanc'd age, who ue all things more moderately.
The Fourth attributed the caue to the Contellations and Influences of the Stars which reign at the time of Conception; Males being generated under Maculine, and Females under Feminine Signs.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXVI. Whether the French Tongue be ufficient for learning all the Sciences.
div.p:
A Language is a Multitude or Mas of Nouns and Verbs which are igns of Things and Times, detinated to the explication of our thoughts. There are two orts; the one perfect, call'd Mother-Languages, the other imperfect. The Mother-Languages are the Hebrew, Greek, and Latine; the imperfect thoe which depend upon them. Now the French being of this latter ort, we cannot learn the Sciences by it alone, becaue being particular, and the Sciences general, the les is not capable to comprehend the greater. Moreover, our Language being not certain in its Phraes, nor yet in its Words (not only Ages, but alo a few Years changing both) whereas the Sciences are certain and immutable, it will follow that they cannot be taught by it. Beides, there may be Inventions for which our
Language hath no expreion, or at leat not o good as others; and to buie our minds in the earch of words is more likely to retard the mind in the acquiition of Sciences then to further it. The truth is, 'twere well if things were generally expres'd by the mot proper and ignificant words, but they are not o in any Language much les in the French, which is o far from being rich enough of its elf that it borrows from the Greek and Latine to expres the mot common things, and conequently is not ufficient to teach all the Sciences.

The Second aid, The French Tongue is deriv'd from the Greek, Latine, and Gothick, which are Languages much more copious then it; and therefore they that will recur to originals will find thoe Tongues more adapted for teaching the Sciences then the French, and yet not any ingle one of them ufficient for it; ince the Romans, to become and deerve the name of Learned, were oblig'd to learn Greek. Moreover, ince Books are the chief intruments for attaining the Sciences, the ancient Latine and Greek ones (which yet were not ufficient for it) are much more numerous than the French, and by conequence the French Tongue is not capable to teach every Science: and had it more Tranlations then it hath, yet thee are but mall Rivulets deriv'd from that grand Source of Sciences which is found in the original Languages.

The Third aid, If we regard the order of times and particularly that of the Creation when all things were in their perfection and purity; 'tis mot likely that, that Language which took birth with Adam, and all the Sciences, is more fit to teach them then the much more Novel French, and ince there mut be a proportion between Intruments and the Matters upon which they act; and this proportion is not found between the French Tongue lately invented and the Sciences which are as ancient as the World, who can think it ufficient to teach them? and the Cabalits hold that the Language fit to teach the Sciences perfectly, mut have words adapted to ignifie the Vertues and Properties of things, which ours hath not.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXVII. Of diverity of Colours in one and the ame ubject.
div.p:
THe diverity of Colours is commonly deduc'd from the mixtion and proportion of the Elements; but more truly from the everal degrees of Sulphur, which produces them, as Salt doth Sapors, the mot certain indications what degree the quality of a Plant is of: For if Colours had relation to the Elements, then all red things hould be hot, and white things cold; which is not true in Poppy, and Roes, on the one ide, nor Orange-flowers and Jamin on the other. So alo green things hould be always moit, becaue this colour proceeds from an indigeted humidity mixt with a part of putrifi'd earth; as appears in tanding waters; and yet the greennes of Lawrel and Mint hinders them not from being hot and dry, nor that of Ranunculus from burning. But Colours are either natural, or artificial;
which latter as we find it in Stuffs and Silks, is neither the caue nor the effect of their temperament. But natural colour, uch as that in the parts of living Animals, is an effect of their Life, and alterable after their death. Wherefore I conclude, that colour and its varieties proceeds from the different degrees of Sulphur in the ubject; but that one and the ame ubject is of everal colours, the caues may be: Firt, for that ome of its parts are more compact; others, more looe, and o differently receive the impreion of the Sulphur and the Internal Fire. Secondly, the Sun hining more upon one part than another, draws the internal colour from the Centre to the Circumference; as Apples are colour'd on the ide next the Sun. Thirdly, the ame difference which is found between the Root, Trunk, Leavs, Flower, Fruit, and other parts of Plants and Animals, is alo found in each portion of thoe parts; as the lower part of the Roe is green, the middle part whitih, and the top red; and the Tulip variegated, is compounded of as many everal particles; which variety of places and matrices, erves to determine the colour which Sulphur paints thereon, being guided by the pencil of Nature.

The Second aid, That this diverity of colours proceeds only from the divers apect of light which varies the colours of certain Bodies to our Eye, as in the Rain-bow, the Camelion, and the necks of Pigeons, in things expos'd to the Sun, which eem far brighter than before: To which you mut add the ditance and tation of the beholders; o water eems black or blew afar off, but near hand colourles; Turpentine, Crytal, and the whites of Eggs in everal ituations do the like.

The Third aid, That there are four colours anwering to the Elements, viz. Black to Earth, White to Water, Yellow to Air, and Red to Fire. For dicovering the Caues of whoe diverities, the ancient Philoophers prepar'd a Matter, which by the degrees of fire, they pas'd through all the colours of Nature, and perceiv'd ometimes in their veel what they call'd the Peacock's tail, repreenting all colours in one ingle Matter; whence they concluded the variety of colours to proceed from that of External Fire, moving the Matter les in one part than in another. Thus Antimony, which is at firt Black, is rais'd into White, Yellow, Red, and mixt Flowers, according as they are ublim'd more or les. But you can draw no conequence from hence to the Colours of Plants, ince rednes, which, in works of Art, argues perfect Digetion, and Fire predominant, doth not o in Simples.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXVIII. Whether we are more perpicacious in the Affairs of others, or our own, and why?
div.p:
IT may eem uperfluous to make this a Quetion, ince by the enumeration of all orts of Affairs, it appears that we are Moles, yea, perfectly blind in the Judgement we make of our elves, and more clear-ighted than the Lynx in thoe we make of others. Which alo the Gopel tetifies, by the comparion of a mote which we epy in the Eye of a Neighbour, not eeing the beam which is in our own; for, (according to the direction of the Lawyers, who are to be believed in point of affairs) in the firt place in reference to perons, every one undertands himelf much les either in Mind or Body than he doth another; mot eteeming themelves more capable and worthy of praie for Witt than they are; and (as the Eye ees not it elf, but every other viible thing o,) he that hath any perfection or imperfection, cannot conider the ame in its true Latitude, but eaily adds omething to the firt, or diminihes from the econd; whilt the various bent of our Paions always exalts and deprees the balance, and keeps it from that aequilibrium which is neceary to a right Judgement. Hence Phyicians, although they ought to know themelves better than they can be known by others, yet, when ick, permit themelves to be treated by their Companions; and never ucceed o well in the Cure of themelves or their dometicks, as they do abroad elewhere. In the econd place, we are les quick-ighted in things that concern our elves, than in thoe of others: whence commonly the greatet Lawyers leave the affairs of their own Houes more imbroiled than others. Which was the caue that the Wife of Pacius, the famous Lawyer of our time, ent to him to ak his Advice concerning his own affairs under fancied names, making him pay a Solicitor with his own Money. In the third place, Actions are in a very evill hand when they are to be managed or defended by their Authors; either Modety on the one hand extenuating them, or Thraonical pride dilating them, and adding thereunto more than is fit. Latly, the Laws hew ufficiently what hath been the opinion of Legilators upon this matter, when they forbid Advocates and Procurators to plead and practie in their own Caue; and when they injoyn Judges to forbear, not only their own, but alo from all thoe wherein their kinred or alliances may have any interet. Thus much for the firt Head of the Quetion. The Reaon, which is the econd, arieth hence; That the Eye as well as all other Organs of External and Internal Senes (uch as the Judgement is) mut be erene, and not prepoeed by any tincture or Prejudice. Now to require
this erenity and indifferency in our own affairs, is to demand an impoibility. The Caue whereof may come from the purenes and ubtilty of the Humane Spirit, above that of other Animals, compared to the Elements of Earth and Water, which contracting themelves round about their own Centre, move not but in quet of their food; others more ayerious, rie a little higher, but yet have a bounded Region; uch are the pirits of Women, whoe Knowledg and Curioity is limited to the affairs of their houwifrie, or at mot to thoe of their neighbourhood. But the Mind of Man reembling Fire, which hath no other bound but Heaven, penetrates even to the Centre of the Earth, carries its point every where, and is like flame in a perpetual agitation, oftentimes reembling our natural heat in Summer, which abandons the Internal parts to carry it elf to the extremities.

The Second aid, There is as great diverity of Judgements and Witts, as there is of Eyes amongt Men. As there are ome blind; other Eyes from which the Objects mut be et at ditance to become viible; ome alo to which they mut be approached; and, latly, others which require a moderate ditance between the Viible Object and the Organ: Iin like manner, there are ome Judgements abolutely blind; others, which judge not things too near, but require to have them removed, or et at a middle ditance; there are others alo, which judge them better near hand than a far off; and this truly is the cutom of the bet Judgements, and of uch as leat uffer themelves to be prepoes'd. Indeed, what is more aburd than for us to remove far from Objects in order to judging of them, after the manner of old men, and of thoe that are hort-ighted; and if the aying of Aritotle be true, The Species of the thing to be known mut be not only introduced into, but alo made like the Mind; Is the diveting our elves of it away to know it well? By this reckoning we hall never ee clear in any affair: not in our own, becaue 'tis ours; nor in thoe others, in regard of the Envy Men bear to the properity of their Neighbours, which makes them think that their Vines are more fruitful, and their afflictions les evere. If ome Phyicians reign themelves to the cure of others of the ame profeion, 'tis becaue they believe them as able as themelves, or, perhaps, becaue their own Judgement is diturbed by the dieae; otherwie, ince the particular Knowledge of every one's Temper is the condition mot requiite to a good Phyician for curing his Patient, and every one knowing his own better than another can in along time, none can be a better Phyician of another than of himelf; and if dometick cures be effected with les notice, yet they are not les ure and remarkable to him that would conider them. That Lawyers are not admitted to plead in their own Cae, is rather from their too much, than too little Knowledge; the Court foreeeing that they would be too prolix and hot in the proecution thereof, beides
the greater temptation to dihonety in diguiing their own actions. Nor is exception againt Judges in the cae of their kinred allowed, becaue they ee not clear enough into the affair in quetion; but becaue interet, which is ineparably fixed in humane minds, might lead them to relieve their Relations to the prejudice of a third. Which yet hath not place in all, there being found good Judges who would condemn their own Child if he had a bad Caue. But to attribute to elf-love, the defect of clear-ightednes, is to peak too Poetically; ince the Prince of Poets believes it not poible to deceive a Lover; and the knowledge we have of others affairs, hath no other foundation but that which we have of our own, jut as elf-love is given us for a rule of that of our Neighbour.

The Third aid, That which happens mot frequently being the rule, and the ret the exception; and the greatet part of Men reembling that Lamia, who being blind at home, put on her Eyes when he went abroad; it mut be agreed, that we are les clear-ighted in our own than in others affairs: Which is the meaning of the Proverb of the wallet, in the forepart of which the bearer puts other Mens matters, cating his own into the part behind upon his back. Moreover, to ee clear, is to ee without clouds or mits, uch as are thoe of the Paions, Fear, Hope, Avarice, Revenge, Ambition, Anger, and all the ret which uffer not the Species to be calmly repreented to the Intellect, which receives the ame as untowardly as tirred water, or a Looking-glas ullied with inceant clouds, or vapors receive an Image objected to them; 'tis true, the Paions have ome effect upon it in affairs without; but as themelves, o their trouble is les, and he is the bet Judge who gives them no admittance at all; which cannot be in our own affairs, where, conequently, we are no les clear than in thoe of others.

div.head: CONFERENCE CLXXXIX. Of the Original of Mountains.
div.p:
GOD having created the world in perfection, it was requiite there hould be Plains, Mountains, and Vallies upon the Earth, without which agreeable variety, there would be no proportion in its parts, wherein nevertheles conits its principal ornament, which hath given it the name of world; no other beginning of Mountains eems aignable but that of the world. Nor is there any poibility in attributing another Caue to thoe great Mountains, which eparate not only Provinces and States, but the parts of the world; all the Caues that can be aigned thereof, being unequal to uch an Effect: Which the dicovery of the inequalities of the Celetial Bodies, oberved in our dayes
by Galileo's Tubes in ome ort confirmed; for by them Mountains are dicerned in ome Planets, epecially an eminent one in the Orbe of Mars; which Mountain cannot reaonably be attributed to any caue but his primary contruction. The ame may likewie be aid of the Mountains of the Earth, which beides having necearily its lopenees and declivities which are followed by Rivers and Torrents, there is no more difficulty to conceive a Mountain then an elevated place in the Earth; o that to ay, that from the beginning there was no place higher in one part of the earth then in another is to gain-ay Scripture which aith that there were four Rivers in Eden, each whereof had its current; which could not be, unles the place of their rie were higher then that whereunto they tended.

The Second aid, That the proportion from which the ornament of the World reults is ufficiently manifeted in the correpondence of the four Elements with the Heavens, and of the Heavens with themelves, yea in all compounds which reult from thoe Elements moved by heat and the Celetial influences, without fancying a craggy Earth from the beginning, to the prejudice of the perfection which is found in the Spherical Figure, which God hath alo pourtray'd in all his works, which oberve the ame exactly or come as near it as their ue will permit; as is een particularly in the fabrick of Man's Body, his mater-piece, whereof all the original parts have omewhat of the Spherical or Cylindrical Figure, which is the production of a Circle. And if the other Elements of Fire, Air, and Water, are abolutely round and cannot be otherwie conceived, though their conitence be fluid, and as uch more eaily mutable in figure; 'tis much more likely that the earth had that exactly round figure at the beginning; otherwie the Waters could not have covered it as they did, ince not being diminihed from the beginning of the World till this time, they are not at this day capable of covering it. 'Tis certain then that God gave the Earth that Spherical form, it being to erve for the bulk and Centre to all the other Elements, by means of which roundnes the Water covered it equally, but when it was time to render the Earth habitable to Animals, and for that end to dicover a part of it, it was to be rendered more hollow in ome places and more elevated in others, ince there is no Mountain without a Valley, nor on the contrary. Afterwards it came to pas that the Rain wahed away whatoever was fat, and unctuous in thoe higher places, and carrying it into Brooks and Rivers, and thence into the Sea, this Sea by the impetuoity of his waves makes great abyffes in ome places and banks of and in others; but the great and notable change happened in the univeral Deluge when the many Gulfs below and Windows on high, as the Scripture peaks, overflowed the whole Earth for forty days and forty nights together; the Earth being thus become a Sea was in a manner new haped by the torrents of the waters, and
the violence of the ame waves, which made Abyes in ome places and Mountains in others, according as the Earth happened to be more or les compact, and apt for reitance. Which is yet eaier to be conceived of Rocks which being unapt to be mollified by either that univeral rovage of waters, or torrents uperven'd in four thouand years ince, they remain intire and appear at this day as upercilious as ever over the more depreed parts round about.

The Third aid, That ome Mountains were produced at the Creation, others ince, partly by Rains and Torrents, partly by Winds and Earth-quakes, which have alo ometimes levell'd Hills and reduced them into Valleys; o that you cannot aign one certain or general caue of all. For there is no more reaon to believe that the ravages of waters have produced Mountains, then that they have levell'd and filled Valleys with their oil; as 'tis ordinarily een that the fattet portion of Mountainous places is wahed away by Rain into Valleys, and fertilizes the ame. And the mallnes of the Earth compared to the ret of the world permits not its inequalities to make any notable diproportion in it, or hinder it from being called Round; as appears in Eclipes caued by the hadow of the Earth, which he ends as regularly towards Heaven as if he were perfectly round.

The Fourth aid, That the waters of the Sea, from which, according to the Scripture, all waters iue and return thither, impetuouly entring into the caverns of the Earth go winding along there till they find reitance, whereby their violence redoubled makes the Earth rie in ome places and o forms Mountains; which therefore are more frequent on the Sea-coats then elewhere, and eldom further from the ame then a hundred and fifty Leagues. Now that the Sea is higher then the Earth the Scripture notes, and thoe that travel upon the Sea oberve the truth of Geneis which aith that the waters were gathered together on a heap. For being remote from a Port at uch ditance as would otherwie uffer the ame to be een, the riing of the interpoed waters intercepts the view thereof.

The Fifth aid, 'Tis eaie to conceive how waters running underground make breaches and abyes, uch as that at Rome, into which Q. Curtius cat himelf, and alo in many other places even in our time wherein a Town of the Grions was totally involved in the ruines of a neighbouring Mountain, whoe foundations the torrents had undermined. And what is found in digging up the ruines of Buildings, paved treets, and other footteps of mens habitations o deep that the caue thereof cannot be attributed to a bare raiing of the ground in building by ome humane artifice, hews that thee changes happen'd by the depreion and inking of the ground whereon uch Towns tood, and by the overturning of neighbouring Mountains, which in this cae turn Plains into Valleys and Valleys into Plains
or ele into Mountains, as alo thee Mountains into Levels: all thee changes which to us eem prodigious, being no more o to Nature, whoe agents are proportional to their effect, then when we cover an Ant-hill with a clod of Earth. But 'tis not likely that ubterranean waters, whoe violence is broken by their windings can raie Mountains, or o much as ordinarily Hills; much les can they raie higher the cavities of Rocks which are the ordinary Bais of uch Mountains; ince our Vaults are ruined by the ole defect of one cliff or tone which joyns and knits the ret together; the and Hills which the winds heap up in Lybia, as the waves do the banks in the Sea, pertaining as little to the Quetion as they deerve the name of Mountains. Wherefore 'tis probable that Mountains are as old as the Earth, which was formed uneven by Gods command, that o its declivities might erve for aembling the waters together; for to ay that the ituation of the Sea is higher then the Earth, is not only contrary to the experience of Dreiners who find the declivity of the Land by no more certain way then by the inclination of the waters, but alo to the belief and manner of peech of all the world, who ue the term of going downwards when people pas along with the tream of Rivers, which run all into the Sea whoe urface mut therefore necearily be lower then that of the earth. Whereas it is aid that all waters come from the Sea, this is meant of vapors exhaled from it and converted into Rain and Springs, from whence arie Rivulets, Brooks, and at length Rivers, which terminate again in the Sea.
The Sixth aid, In puruance of Copernicus's opinion which makes the earth turn about the Sun, that the everal concuions it receives from that motion may poibly elevate one place and debae another.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXC. Whence proceed good and bad Getures, Gracefulnes and ill Apects.
div.p:
THe Soul being the principle of all the actions, we need go no further to find the caue of Getures, and Potures. 'Tis true, that as this Soul is but a general caue, being according to the opinion of mot Divines, alike in all men, it mut like melted Metal borrow its form from the Mould whereinto it is infued; o the Soul follows the model of the Body and as he formed it, o in ome ort be modified by it exerciing her functions variouly according to the diverity of its Organs. Whereunto alo the humors and their mixture or temperament
contributes very much. Hence a man of mall tature and cholerick hath quick and haty motions; the tall and phlegmatick, more heavy and low; the Sanguine and middle-ized, between both. Nevertheles the principal reaon is drawn from the conformation of the parts; whence, the Lame halts; he who hath the Mucles and Ligaments of the hinder part of the Neck too hort, holds his Head too upright; He who hath a great Mouth and a large Breat is a great talker; and o of all the other parts, from the diverity whereof even that of Languages is aid to have come. Thee Getures are either univeral, as we ee ome geticulate with the whole body; or particular, one contracting his Forehead, another hrugging his Shoulders, beating of meaures with his Foot like a good Hore, rubbing his Hands as if they were cabby or to be wahed, not being able to peak to any one without touching him, pulling his Button, or puhing him upon the Arm or Breat. Where alo is but too obervable the troubleome way of ome, who never end their dicoure but by an Interrogatory, whether you hear them? or at leat by an hem! which they continue till you anwer them; yea, others interlard their peech with ome word o impertinent that it takes away the grace from all the ret: all Getures words and vicious accents, to which may be oppoed others not affected or repeated too often, becaue 'tis chiefly their frequent repetition which renders them tedious and as blamable as the aying over and over the ame word: as on the contrary, their eldomnes erves for an excue to thoe who have no other. Above all it mut be endeavoured that the Getures uit, or at leat be not wholly oppoite to that dicoure which they accompany; as that ignorant Comedian did who pronouncing thee words, O Heaven! O Earth! look'd downward at the firt, and cat up his Eyes at the lat. Whence one and the ame Geture may be good or bad in repect of the ubject whereunto it is applied, and according to its eldomnes or frequency. As for ill looks, they are always diagreeable, difiguring the proportion of the countenance and proceeding alo from the firt conformation of the parts, For as the Arm is bowed only at the Shoulder, Cubit and Writ, and the Leg at the Knee and Ancle, though the Soul which makes the flection be alike in all other parts, but the articulation is only in thoe parts: o the motion is carried alike to all the Mucles; but only thoe dipoed by their conformation to receive the figure of uch grimaces, are uceptible thereof. They likewie ometimes happen upon Convulion of the parts, which caue the trange bendings we oberve therein, though never without a precedent dipoition which may be called their antecedent caue.

The Second aid, That we ought to acribe to the Imagination all the Motions and Getures of the Body, which are agreeable or dipleaing according as they uit with that of the beholder.
Hence Fools and Children whoe judgment is irregular, are pleaed with eeing uch geticulations and the grimacies of Jack-puddings, which dipleae the more judicious. So that as there is one beauty abolutely uch and another repective and in comparion of thoe who judge differently thereof according as they find it in themelves (whence the Africans paint the Devil white becaue themelves are black, and the Northern people paint him black becaue themelves are white:) o there are Getures and Motions purely and imply becoming, honet and agreeable; others uch only by opinion of the beholders, as are the Modes of Salutation; and latly, others abolutely bad as Frowning, Winking, biting the Lip, putting out the Tongue, holding the Head too upright or crooked, beating of meaures with the Fingers; in hort, making any other diorderly Geture. All which defects (as they are oppoite to perfections which conit in a right ituation of all the parts without affectation) proceed from the Phanie either ound or depraved. Which happens either naturally or through imitation. The firt cae hath place in Children who from their birth are inclined to ome motions and ditortions of their Mucles; which being double, if one become weaker and its Antagonit too hort it draws the part whereto it gives motion out of its natural eat, as is een in thoe that quint. The econd is oberved in Children omewhat bigger, who beholding ome Geture repeated, render the ame o familiar to themelves, that at length it becomes natural to them. Hence the prohibition of Mothers give their Children not to counterfeit the vices their companions bodies, is not void even of natural reaon; becaue the Phanie is tronger in a weak Mind, and when the Memory is unfurnihed or other pecies; whence the Phanies of Women are more powerful then thoe of Men. The Minds of Children being weak, and reiding in oft pliant Bodies, more eaily admit any idea's once conceiv'd: And as a Language is more eaily learn'd by Ue then by Precepts, o example is Extreamly prevalent, and weetly ininuating into the Phanie by the Senes diffues its influence over the whole Body.

The Third aid, That if the Soul be an harmony as the pleaure it takes therein eems to intimate, we need eek no other caue of the everal motions and cadences of the Body which it animates. 'Tis the Soul which moves all the Nerves of the Body and carries to all the parts uch portion as he pleaes of Spirits proper to move them, whereby like a player upon a Lute or ome other Intrument he makes what tring ound he pleaes, tretching one and looening another. And as Muick is uch as the Quirreter pleaes to make it, delighting the Ear if it be proportionate thereunto and procuring the Muitian the repute of kilfulnes; if not, the contrary happens: o the Soul imprints upon the Body one figure or another which make a good or bad grace, inomuch that oftentimes gracefulnes is
more eteemed than Beauty, unles it may be better aid to be part thereof; for want of which, beautiful perons reemble inanimate Statues or Pictures. But as true Beauty is wholly natural, and an Enemy to Artifice, o the Soul ows to its original and firt temper, the good or poture which it gives its Body; and there is as much difference between natural gracefulnes and affected potures, as between the Life and the Picture, truth and appearance; yea, the ole upicion of affectation offends us. Moreover, a Clown eldom becomes Courtly, and whatever pains be betowed in teaching him good Carriage, yet till his defects appear through his contraint; as on the contrary, amongt Shepherds mot remote from the civilities of the Court, we ee gentilenes and dexterities; which manifet that good carriage, or Getures are purely natural.

The Fourth aid, That in the Getures and Motions of the Body, two principles mut be acknowledged, one natural and the other accidental. The former is founded in the tructure and compoition of every one's Body, the diverity whereof produceth, with that of the pirits, humors, and manners, all the Actions and Paions which depend thereon, the true motive caues of our Getures and Carriages. Hence he that uffers pain frowns, he that repents bites his Lip or Fingers; he that admires omething, and dares not expres it, hrugs his houlders; he that mues deeply turns his Eyes inward, and bites the end of his Pen or Nails. The accidental principle is imitation, which, next to Nature, is the mot efficacious caue, and acts mot in us; Man being born for imitation more than any other Creatures, as appears in that carce five or ix Species of Birds imitate our Language, the Ape alone our Getures; we, on the contrary, imitate not only the voices of all Animals, but alo all their Actions: And therefore as it cannot be denied that Nature contributes to our Getures, o neither can it be doubted that Imitation hath a power therein.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCI. Which is mot proper for Study, the Evening or the Morning.
div.p:
IF Antiquity had not had Errors, the caue of thoe who prefer the tudy of the Evening before that of the Morning, would be very deperate. But Reaons having more force here than the Authorities of Pedagogues, who hold Aurora the friend of the Mues, only to the end that their Scholars riing betimes in the Morning, themelves may have the more time left after their exercies; I conceive the Evening much more fit for any Employment
of the Mind, than any other part of the day; the Morning leaving not only the firt and more common wayes full of Excrements, but alo all the Ventricles of the Brain wherein the Spirits are elaborated, and alo the Arteries and Intertices of the Mucles full of vapors; whence proceed the frequent ocitations, contortions, and extenion of the members upon our awaking, to force out the vapors which incommode them. On the contrary, the Evening even after repat, finds thoe firt wayes full of good Aliments, which end up benigne and laudable vapors which allay and temper the acrimony of other more harp and biting, found by experience in Men fating, who for that reaon are more prone to Choler. Moreover, Study coniting in Meditation, and this in reflection upon the Species received into the Phanie, 'tis certain that the report of thee introduced all the day long, erves for an efficacious Leon to the Mind, when it comes to make review of the things offered to the Intellect, for it to draw conequences from the ame, and make a convenient choice: but in the Morning all the pecies of the preceding day, are either totally effaced, or greatly decayed. Moreover, the melancholy humor, which is mot proper for Study, requires contancy and aiduity, which ordinarily accompanies this humor; and it is predominant in the Evening as Bloud is in the Morning, according as Phyicians allot the four humors to the four parts of the natural day; as therefore the Sanguine are les proper for Study than the Melancholy, o is the Morning than the Evening. Hence the good Father Ennius never verified o well as after he had drunk, which eldom happens in the Morning; and the conceptions of fating perons are commonly more empty, and les agreeable than thoe of Authors well fed. For the Spirits repaired by Food are carried much further, as being more vigorous when their continual flux and deperdition finds matter proper for their retoration, as they do after Supper, having then the ame advantage that an Army hath, which ees at its back another Auxiliary one ready to recruit it. On the contrary, in the Morning nothing remains in the Body of all the Aliments of the foregoing day, but only a mas of liquid blood, which is preently ditributed into all the parts, having its elf need of retoration: Whence the other animal-functions are performed les vigorouly in the Morning than in the Evening, epecially after Supper; Which is jutifi'd alo by the experience of thoe who when they would learn any thing by heart, tudy it in the Evening and leep upon it, committing the ame to thoe vigorous Spirits newly produc'd by the food, to be more deeply engraven in the Memory. And your nightly Students leep commonly in the Morning, which is the fittet time for it, and bet refrehes the forces both of Body and Mind; whereas Evening leep is lyable to muings and tumults. Which alo is confirm'd by the practice of Courtiers, who bet of all Men undertand the delights of Life; epecially Ladies, who by long leeping in
the Morning, preerve themelves fair and in good plight; which is an infallible ign of health, without which, the functions of the Mind cannot be rightly perform'd.

The Second aid, That a veel which is to be fill'd, mut firt be empty'd, and the Organs of Sene mut be free from all Species, that they may be uceptible of thoe whereof we deire to inform them. For which purpoe, the Morning is far fitter than the Evening, when all the Idea's of the day pat, throng into the Phanie, and hut the door to new Objects. The Spirits likewie are then more pure from the vapors, which arie from meats while undigeted; which vapors are very prejudicial to the Spirits, as appears in thoe that have drunk too much, who reaon but very ill; and they that apply themelves to tudy after Supper, find a manifet difference in themelves from what they were before it; their Animal Spirits being clouded by multitude of vapors which fill their Heads, and leave no longer free paage to the Spirits: Beides that, Attention hurts Digetion, calling the Spirits to the Brain from the Stomack, where they hould be to concoct the food; whence follows imperfect anguification, tetified by palenes of Complexion of hard Students. Moreover, the Soul being Light, delights more to exercie its functions in the day than in the night, whoe darknes addens it, and reprees its beams; whence our conceptions are much more dull in the night, whoe coldnes is an Enemy to all Actions, as heat (which is greater in the day) is a friend to them. And the Cutom of the mot tudious is back'd with Reaon, which requires that the Soul, Man's chief part, begin to take its food of Knowledge at the chief and firt part of the day. And our ancient Laws eem to favor this Opinion, whilt they prohibit the judgement of Criminal Caues after dinner, as requiring more attention than Men are commonly capable of at that time; and certainly they mut be much les capable thereof after Supper.

The Third aid, That the Quetion cannot be determin'd but by ditinguihing of Complexions, Ages, Cutoms, and different Studies. The Cholerick commonly find themelves fittet for tudy in the Evening, when the Acrimony of their predominant humor is allay'd by the recent vapors of meat. On the contrary, the Phlegmatick mut not leep much, and to be early is both mot healthful for him, and the fittet time for his tudy; but the Sanguine requires more leep. And for Cutoms, though bad ought to be reform'd, yet if an Evening Student changes for the Morning, or on the contrary, it will be with les ucces. If it be asked, What Cutom then is bet to be contracted, we mut come to the conideration of Ages; wherein, Children after even years old, when they begin to be capable of regular dicipline, mut not be confin'd to les than eight or nine hours leep; after the Age of Puberty, Morning Studies are mot profitable for them. The Evening is fittet for the Studies of Youth and
Manhood, in whom Choler predominates, as les diturbing their Morning repoe, which is neceary to repres the boylings of their hot Blood; whence if they rie too early, they are commonly troubled with the Head-ach. Latly, Old-age being more phlegmatick, and its humors harper, 'tis good for them to go to bed betimes, to the end to temper that Acrimony by the gentlenes of the vapors riing from the lately taken Supper; and alo 'tis mot profitable for them to rie early, whereunto they are guided by Nature, awaking ooner than any other Age.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCII. Who are the mot Ingenious of the World.
div.p: BY Ingenious are meant inventive, ubtle or acute perons; He that undertands, dicoures and exercies the functions of the Soul more ubtly then another is tyl'd Ingenious. Thus Apelles when diguis'd was dicover'd by a third line which he drew upon two others, o mall, that none but he could have drawn it: And in a dipute, he that bet ditinguihes a term confounded by the Antagonit, paes for the mot ubtle and ingenious; o alo doth an Artificer that makes the mot ubtle pieces of work, as chains for Fleas, Nine-pins with a Bowl extreamly mall, Knives and other Intruments, not weighing above a grain of Wheat. For as they that can perceive the leat objects are the mot clear-ighted, o minds not contented to conceive common and gros things, are the mot ingenious. This being premis'd, I conceive that the Cholerick are uch; and for the ame reaon Southern people, whoe Climate produces that humor mot. Hence thoe that govern people in thoe parts trouble not themelves to reaon with them, becaue having to do with refined pirits, it were to no purpoe; there being no reaon o good but a contrary one might be invented amongt them: But they relye upon nothing more then Faith and Religion, whereby they accomplih their ends upon their people, who elewhere are govern'd by force of Reaon.

The Second aid, That if Ingenuity conited only in ubtlety, there would be none in making Colous's and great Piles of Buildings, wherein nevertheles there is far more then in little Trinkets, which like ome Iron mechanick-Intruments are ueles by being too fine. And as he that ditinguihes pertinently in a Dipute is reputed ingenious, o is he no les who entangles the repondent by confounding things which ought to be eparated. In the practie of Affairs, things too ubtle pas for Chimera's, and are never put in execution; nor is he accounted the bet Painter that draws the finet trokes. Moreover, the Eyes that dicern the leat object are not always the bet; but
'tis a ign of weaknes of ight to ee things out of their proportionate ditance. Much les probable is it that the Cholerick are more ingenious then the Melancholy, ince reflection is neceary to the making of a olid concluion, which the impatience of Choler cannot endure; and indeed, never was there een a man of great parts who was not penive. And accordingly, Northern people, being more cold and reerv'd, will carry it above other hotter Nations.

The Third aid, That as to Nations, he conceiv'd that as not only the Plants, but alo the Pearls and Jewels of the Eat, are more excellent and purer than thoe of other parts of the world, o alo are their Witts: The Reaon whereof, is, That the Sun coming from the Eat betows the Firt-fruits of his own and other Celetial Influences upon the Orientals; which Influences, like the impreion of Perfumes, are mot vigorous in their beginning. Moreover, we ee that God made ue of the excellence of the pirits of thoe people to make the firt and greatet Law-givers and Sages. If Authors of new and untrue Religions have been found there, this fortifies rather then detroyes this Opinion, more Witt being requiite to maintain a bad than a good caue. As for Temperaments, the Sanguine hath the advantage. Firt, becaue 'tis the mot healthful Complexion, and Health is the principal condition of a good Witt, which cannot diplay it elf perfectly in a ick body. Secondly, becaue Blood is the proximate matter of pirits, and he that hath good Blood mut have plenty of pirits. Thirdly, becaue this is the Complexion of the amorous, who are the mot ingenious people of the world. Whence the Poet aid, Quis fallere poit amantem? But if the Quetion be, What Exercie or Employment hath the mot ingenious people, 'tis harder to be detemin'd; o great Witts being found at this day of all orts of profeions, that 'tis difficult to judge, of which there are mot. Some will prefer the Scholatick Devines for their ubtle diputes and nice ditinctions; others, the Rational Phyicians, for their dicoures and conjectures upon the caues of hidden dieaes, others, the Mathematicians for their curious earches into Heaven it elf; or the Lawyers who manage their affairs o advantageously above others.

The Fourth aid, That, abolutely peaking, there is no quarter of the world more Oriental or Occidental than another; thee words having been invented only in repect to Men themelves, to ome of whom one and the ame people is Oriental, and yet Occidental to others; ince the world is round, and all the parts of a Sphere are of the ame Nature. What differences there are, mut be taken from omething ele than the four parts of the world, and, particularly, from Cold and Heat. Thus thoe that live under the Poles, are of a different Complexion both of Body and Mind, from thoe that are between the Tropicks. According to which difference, the Inhabitants of the temperate
Zones mut be the mot ingenious: Cold being too much an Enemy to Life, to advance the Wit; and exceive Heat burning the Humors no les within than without, as the woolly hair and black kin of the Nations expos'd to it, manifet. So that 'tis no preumption in the French and other Nations under the ame Climate, to award the preheminence to themelves in this matter. For the operations of the Mind, as well as the digetions and other natural operations of the Body, require a temperate, not an exceive Heat.
