And the levity imputed to our Nation is a proof of it, ince commonly the mot ingenious are leat tedfat in executing the things they have devis'd. But amongt the French, I account none more ingenious than the Lawyers, who confute the Philoophical Maxim, which aith, That whatever hath a beginning hath alo an end, ince they render Suits immortal. Intead of the four caues taught by Naturalits, they create others without number; and in pight of the Maxim, which aith, There is no Vacuum, they make one at length in the pures of their Clients.

The Fifth aid, That ince there are good and bad, ingenious and ots in all Lands, to be the one or the other, dependeth not upon the Climate; Heaven, from whence the Soul decends, being alike in all places. Nor is it likely that profeions render Men more or les ingenious, ince thoe to which people are lead by natural inclination, are rather Effects than Caues of good or bad parts. As for thoe to which we are perwaded or forc'd, nothing can be inferr'd from them, having no affinity with our Nature. Latly, nor doth Temper always contribute to render Men ingenious, ince there are ome o of all Tempers, Ages, and Sexes. The true Caue is the proportion which happens to be between the Soul and the Body at the firt conformation. Whence the uret igns of good parts, are taken from the figure of the Body, and chiefly of the Head, which if harp, never makes a wie man; as on the contrary, great Heads, and broad Fore-heads, are always ingenious, of whatever Country, Vocation, and Temper they be.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCIII. Of the Fraternity of the Roie-Cros.
div.p:
I Find that thee Brethren being aociated in Germany two or three hundred years ago, ware mutual Fidelity to oberve the Laws of their Fraternity; the chief of which was Secrecy, never to peak or write but in the Allegories of their Cabal, whoe pretenion is to re-etablih all Dicipilines and Sciences, epecially Phyick, which, they ay, is ignor'd and ill practis'd by all others; themelves alone having the Knowledge of o
many Secrets that they hold the Philoopers Stone for one of the leat, and profeing to imitate undry other Societies of ancient time; as firt, that of the Kings, Priets, and Philoophers of Aegypt, under the names of Iis, Oiris, Apis, Anubis, and Mercury, the myteries whereof they hid under their Hieroglyphical Letters, leaving the ue of the common way of writing to the vulgar: For proof whereof they alledge, that the firt Priet of this Fraternity being urg'd by Alexander to dicover to him the Secret of Iis and Oiris, told him for the whole Secret, that they were not gods but men whom they worhipt. With which Anwer, Alexander was o well atisfied, that he writ word thereof to his Mother Olympias, deiring her to burn his Letter as oon as he had read it, for fear of Scandal. The econd Society which they alledge, is, the College of the Eumolpides, o called from Eumolpus its Author, an Eleuinian Priet at Eleuis in Athens, in imitation of that intituted in Greece by Orpheus, to the honor of Baochus; of which Eumolpides, the upream Sacrificer carry'd a golden key in his mouth to mind him of keeping the Secret, which was not communicated to all the initiated in this Order, but only to uch as were of approv'd dicretion. The Third (they ay) was that of the Samothracians, who were never troubled with icknes or poverty, the two grand courges of Life; maintaining themelves in perpetual Health by repairing the radical humidity, and by Atrological Application of Specifical Remedies deriv'd to them from their Predeceors; and having by their great work ecret means of upplying the common neceities of their Confreres and Aociates. Then follow the Magi of Peria, where, Cicero aith, it was required as a Condition of admitting any to be King, that he were kill'd in natural Magick, that is, in the mot profound and admirable ecrets of Nature; to learn which, Empedocles and Plato, purpoely ail'd into Peria. Of this Magick they make Zoroater the Author, who liv'd ix hundred years before Moes, and pent twenty years in a Deart in tudying the works of Nature, trying the Effects enuing upon the Application of Actives to Paives; whence he got the name of Necromancer, as if he invok'd Devils. Next they quote the Chaldaeans in Babylon, and the Brachmans in India; both orts viited by Apollonius, to whom Hyarchas the Moderator of the Eat hew'd a Well four paces broad, by which they wore, having near it a Cup full of fire, which perpetually burning, never urmounted the brims of the Veel, and two Hogheads, the one of wind, the other of rain, both which infallibly follow'd upon opening the ame. They bring in likewie the Gymnoophits of Aethiopia, who aembled under an Elm, and aluted the ame Apollonius by his name, without having ever known him. Pythagoras alo, they ay, profes'd the Secret, trying his Diciples taciturnity by five years ilence, and hiding his myteries under Numbers. They tell further of one Aucarus who did many wonders, appearing in everal places at the ame time, killing with one word a Serpent
that detroy'd a whole a Country; and latly, they mention a Colledge of Arabians in the City of Damcar, where the Author of this Brotherhood of the Roie-Cros had his Academy, after the etablihment whereof he went to Fez to intruct the Moors, where his progres was uch, that the Society came to be diffus'd into Germany, Poland, and Hungary.

The Second aid, That the rie of this Fraternity is by Mayerus referr'd to the year 1378, when a German Gentleman (the initial Letters of whoe name were A.C.) of the Age of fifteen years, was hut up in a monatery, where having learnt Latine and Greek, in his eventh year he began to journey to the Holy Land; but falling ick at Damas, he heard o much talk of the Sages of Arabia, that recovering, he went to Damcar the City of thee Sages, who aluted him by his proper name, and telling him that they waited for him a long time, dicover'd to him many Secrets; after he had learnt their Language and the Mathematicks, he travell'd into Aegypt and Spain; then return'd into Germany, defraying his expences by the invention he had of making Gold, with which he built and liv'd magnificently for five years; afterwards be thinking himelf of reforming the Sciences, which he had deign'd from the beginning, he aociated to himelf three Brothers to whom he communicated his Secrets. Thee four not ufficing for the great number of Patients which flockt to them from all parts to be cur'd, they took four more who enacted among themelves thee Rules of their Society. I. None hall make other Profeion but of curing the ick gratis. II. None hall be ty'd to any particular Habit, but left to conform therein to place and time. III. Every Brother hall aemble once a year on a et day, in their Houe call'd the Houe of the H. Ghot, or ignifie the caue of his abence. IV. He hall chooe a worthy and fit peron to ucceed him after his death. V. Thee two Letters R. C. hall be their Symbole, Signet, and Character. VI. The Fraternity hall be kept ecret for a 100. years. Thee Articles being worne to, he retain'd two of the Brothers with him, and ent the ret about the world. This founder, they ay, liv'd 106. years, was buryed ecretly by his Confreres in the year 1484; after which time, thee Brothers ucceeded one another, every one of them living no les than a 100. years; and in the year 1604. one of them finding a tone in a wall pierc'd through with a nail, which denoted omething more than ordinary, pull'd it out with great difficulty, and dicover'd a Vault; wherein, amongt other trange things, he found the Sepulchre of this Founder with this incription in Latine, I hall be manifeted after ix core years: And at the bottome, A, C, R, C, In my life time I made this Abridgment of the Univere for my Sepulchre, with many devies, one a ide, and four in circles. The Body held in its Hand a parchment-book written with Golden Letters, at the end of which was his Elogium, containing among other things, that after having heap'd up more riches than a King or Emperor,
of which he judg'd his own Age unworthy, he left them to be ought for by poterity, and built a little world anwering to the great one in all its motions, by which he had compendiouly acquir'd the Knowledge of all things pat, preent, and to come; and after he had liv'd above a 100. years, he render'd his Soul to his Creator amidt the embraces and lat kies of his Brethren, not by reaon of any dieae, (which his own Body never felt, and he permitted not others to uffer) but God with-drew from his Body the illuminated Soul of this mot beloved Father, mot agreeable Brother, mot faithful Mater, and intire Friend. The ame Mayerus aith, that the place of thee Roie-Crucians Colledge is till unknown, but yet they repair to it from all the parts of the world. In the year 1613. News came that one of thee Brethren nam'd Mulley om Hamet, having aaulted Mulley Sidan King of Fez, and Marocco trongly arm'd, defeated him with a handful of unarm'd men, and eiz'd his throne; from whence thee Conquerors were to go into Spain, where at the ame time ome Spaniards taking upon them the title of Illuminati, fell into the hands of the Inquiition. This report oblig'd the Society to publih two Books, intitul'd, Fama & Confeio, wherein, after refutation of wrongful reputations, they et down their Maxims, and ay, That the great Knowledge of their Founder is not to be wonder'd at, ince he was intructed in the Book M, which ome interpret the Book of the World; others, the Book of Natural Magick, which he tranlated out of Arabick into Latine: out of which, they affirm, that Paracelus afterwards learnt all his Knowledge; which being new, 'tis no wonder, they ay, that both he and they be derided and hated by the ret of men. And that the above-aid Founder caus'd to be collected into another Book for his Diciples all that man can deire or hope, to wit, both Celetial and Earthly Goods; thee lat coniting chiefly in Health, Widom, Riches, to acquire all which, they hew the means. In brief, that their main end is, by Travells and Conferences with the Learned, to obtain the Knowledge of all the Secrets in the World, and relate them to their Society, and to none ele.

The Third aid, That there have ever been pirits extravagant, irregular, and incapable of all Dicipline both Political and Eccleiatical. Hence have rien in the Church Hereiarchs and Schimaticks; in the State, Rebels and Mutineers; in the Sciences, Innovators and preumptuous perons, who wanting Ability and Contancy to undergo the pains of Study neceary for obtaining the kill requiite to the right exercie of the leat Diciplines and Profeions, take upon them to blame what they undertand not; and as the vulgar eaily cloe with Calumnies, to which the faults of the Profeors, not the Profeions, give but too much occaion; o they readily prepoes the Undertanding of their Hearers. For which there is more matter in Phyick than there is in any other Profeion, becaue the vulgar, who
judge thereof, conider only events, which are not in our power but only the application of caues; the ret being the work of Nature. Hence Paracelus, and others of that gang, tarted up in the world, etablihing new Principles, and vaunting themelves upon the authority of imaginary antiquity. And as no Opinion is o erroneous but hath its followers; o there have been found people enough of that ort to make a Colledge, who forgetting that one of the faults they charg'd upon the Rational Phyicians, was, that in their precriptions they made ue of a trange Language and Cyphers unknown to the vulgar, have imitated thoe above-mention'd Priets of Aegypt, who made an outide hew of brave Ornaments, which being lifted up, you ee nothing but a Cat, or an Ox at the tall. Thus all their dicoure is only of Aurum Potabile, Mercurius Vitae, Magitery of Pearls, Quinteences, Spirits, Extracts, which they denote by Cyphers invented at pleaure, and apply (as they ay) only according to the mind of Heaven, all the cadences whereof they oberve and meaure for that purpoe: But if you look to the bottome of all, you will ee their Hands foul'd with coals or dung, their Faces dicolour'd by the Arenical Exhalations of the Minerals they prepare in their furnaces; and yet the mot pitiful wretch of them all will wear that he knows the great work. Indeed, this were no great matter, if the ucces of their Practie made amends for the defects of their Theory. But eing chief remedies conit in vomiting or purging violently, whereof few Bodies are capable; no wonder if people ue them only in deperate caes. Nor is their impertinence ufferable, whilt, to credit themelves, they pretend to be decended from the Gymnoophits, from whom, 'tis to be fear'd, they inherit at lat nothing ele but their nakednes. For what better title have they for their ucceeding to all thoe ancient Societies, (I mean uch as were commendable and worthy of imitation) than our Faculties have, which are authoriz'd by the Laws of the Prince, by poeion immemorial, and a conformity of all Nations, which renders their right as trong as that of Nations. Wherefore I advie thee Brethren, if they will not betake themelves to tudy as as others do, to render themelves altogether Inviible, (as they pretend to be) withdrawing from the Commerce of the ret of Mankind.

The Fourth aid, Who openly profes'd himelf one of this Fraternity, aid that Doctor Flud of England had ingeniouly interpreted thee three Letters; F. fide, R. religione, C. charitate, though the common opinion prevails, which will have them ignifie, Fratres Roeae Crucis. But neither of thee interpretations can pas for a great Secret; wherefore it appears upon further earch, that the Cros is truly ignificative there, but in another ene, which is, that in this † the word LX is included, whence ome think that thee Brothers took in Spain the title of Illuminati: I hall venture further, and add that Ros (Dew) which is the mot powerful diolver of Gold amongt natural and
not corroive Bodies, is nothing ele but Light condens'd and render'd corporeal, which being concocted and digeted artificially in convenient time in its proper veel, is the true Mentruum of the Red Dragon, i. e. of Gold, the true matter of Philophers. Of which Secret, this Society deiring to leave Poterity intimation in their Name, tyll'd themelves Brethren of the Roie Cros. Thus Jacob's bleing upon Eau, contain'd only thee two matters, De Rore Coeli, & pinguedine Terrae det tibi Deus. Whereas this Society is charg'd with pretences of being inviible, they mean only that it hath no viible marks to ditinguih it from others, as other Societies have, namely, everal colours and fahions of habits, but 'tis known and viible only to thoe of the Society it elf.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCIV. What Paracelus meant by the Book M.
div.p:
I Shall not tand to conider whether it be true, as ome ay, that more perons beides Theophratus ab Ohenheim bore the name of Paracelus; my preent purpoe is only to conider a paage lately recited here out of his Archidoxa; At
que haec omnia (aith he there) parùm vulgaria de Medicina upernaturali & Magica, ex libro ecreto ex Arabico idiomate in Latinum vero qui pro titulo habet Literam M. In which words we may oberve how remote this Author's manner of Writing is from that of the Doctors of thee times; yea, and of former too, (if you except the Chymits) who mainly aim to peak clearly, and to render themelves intelligible, many of them profeing to wih that things themelves could peak. From which practie this Author is o far, that he conceals even the Book's name wherein he tudied, by a kind of Plagium, hiding his Theft, let others hould trap him; and the ame Jealouie runs through all his Works. However, for Curioitie's ake, let us conider what Titles will ute to this Letter. Me-thinks the fittet is Mundus, that great Book, open to all that are minded to read in it; that to which Job, David, and many other Authors acred and profane o frequently refer us; each Element whereof is a Tome, every Compound a Book, and every part thereof a Letter. All other Books are only Copies of this Original, to which if they happen to have conformity, they pas for good; if not, they are meer Chimera's, having no foundation in the thing. Hence arieth that o remarkable difference between the Theory and the Practie of Arts; for almot all Books being fale Copies of this of the World, no wonder if Book-doctors are mot commonly ignorant of Things, whoe olid Contemplation produces other atisfaction in the informed Intellect, than do the empty Phanies
of thoe who either never undertood what they writ, or had not the gift of right expreing it. And certainly we may have more exact and natural information from the pecies of things themelves, than either the Writing or Speech of another peron can give us.

The Second aid, That this Book M. is the Book of Magick; whence many have believ'd Paracelus a Magician, and the rather in that they find him teaching in many places of his Books to cure dieaes by words, and to produce men by inchantment in a great bottle, with other uch abominable propoals, not to be accomplih'd but by Diabolical aitance. Moreover, we eldom ee any perons o bold as to attempt to overthrow o ancient an Intitution as Phyick, both in Theory and Practie, but who are led to that enterprie either by God or the Devil: And the continual calumnies and detractions, whereof this evil pirit is the Author, and for which Paracelus and his followers o ignalize themelves, give farr more probability of the latter than of the former. Whence, poibly, to diguie the matter, mot Magicians pretend to have learnt their Characters out of ome Book, as, particularly, that which they call Clavicula Solomonis.

The Third aid, That it may be Magick, and yet lawful, to wit, true and Natural Magick, uch as was profes'd by the Indian Magi, three of whom having dicover'd our Saviour's Birth, came to worhip him; the other black and infamous Magick, no more deerving that name, than Empiricks and Mountebanks do that of Phyicians. Now Natural Magick is the knowledge of the nature and properties of all things hidden to the vulgar, who take notice only of manifet qualities, and reduce all to generalities, to avoid the pains of eeking the particular virtues of each thing; and therefore 'tis no wonder if they ee only common effects and uccees from them. Thus Plants bearing the ignature or reemblance of a dieae, or the part dieaed, as Lungwort, Liverwort, Pepperwort, cure by a property independent on the firt qualities, though few undertand o much. Of this kind are many excellent Secrets, whoe effects eem miraculous, and as much urpas thoe of ordinary remedies, whoe virtues are collected only from their appearing qualities, as the Soul doth the Body, and Heaven Earth.

The Fourth aid, That by the Book M. cannot be meant Mundus, ince the World cannot be turn'd into Arabick and Latine; and 'tis not a Secret but a Figure and Metaphor to call the World a Book. If it be lawful to admit a Figure in it, I think 'tis more likely that this Book is nothing ele but a Talimanical Figure, or Character engraven in a Seal, and employ'd by the Roie-Crucians to undertand one another; and call'd the Book M, becaue it repreents an M cros'd by ome other Letters, from whoe combination reults the mytery of the Great Work, deigning its matter, veel, fire, and other Circumtances; the firt
whereof is Dew, the true Mentruum or Diolver of the Red Dragon or Gold. In brief, o many things are compriz'd in this figure, by the various combination of the Letters repreented therein, that it deerves well to be term'd a Book.

The Fifth aid, If this be the Secret of the Brethren of the Roie-Cros, they are Inviible in all their proceedings; becaue no Secret is een in it, but only many aburdities. As, amongt others, to call that a Book, which is neither Paper, nor Parchment, nor Leaf, but a Figure; in which 'tis no wonder if they find what they pleae, ince in thee three Letters Sic, variouly interlac'd one with another, you may find not only all the Letters, but alo by their combination all the Books and all the things which are in the World; and it requires no more indutry than to found all orts of notes upon a Flageolet. Let us therefore rather ay, That Authors who puzzle their Readers minds with uch Figures, are as culpable as thoe are commendable, who feed them with true and olid demontrations; and whereas we thought that this M ignifi'd Mons, we now ee that it ignifies no more than Mus; according to the ancient Fable of the labouring Mountains, out of which upon the concoure of people to the pectacle, iu'd forth nothing but a Moue.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCV. Of the Art of Raimond Lully.
div.p: SOme Wits are fitter for Invention than Imitation, and o was that of Raimond Lully, who invented an Art how to find many Attributes, Propoitions, Quetions, and Means of peaking to any Subject propounded, to the end to be never urpriz'd, but to be and always appear ready. By this Art, which upon account of its ue, and becaue it pretends to horten vulgar tudies he tiles Great, he endeavors to out-do Aritotle, who having reduc'd all Logick to Definitio, Proprium. Genus, and Accidens; and in his Books of Topicks, et down ome few places out of which to draw Mediums for arguing; Lully hath propos'd others, not only drawn from all the preceding, but increas'd with many others invented by himelf. This Art he divides into two parts. The firt treats of imple terms, which he calls Principles, whereunto he hath joyn'd general Quetions; and this part he calls the Alphabet, becaue it comprizes each of thoe terms, reduc'd to nine by as many Letters of the Alphabet. The econd treats of the connexion of thee Principles, and makes Propoitions and Syllogims of them: this part he intitles De Figuris, either becaue, 'tis illutrated by Tables or Figures repreenting the combination of thoe Principles, or becaue Arguments are compos'd of them as the Celetial Figures are of Stars. His Alphabet is thus delineated by Pacius.

This Table, as you ee, contains three Columns, each of which hath Nine Squares, and every one of thee a word. The firt Column contains Abolute or Trancendent Principles; the econd, Relative Principles; the third, Quetions. On the ide of thee Squares are et the nine firt Letters of the Alphabet, namely, from b to k, becaue Lully reerv'd a to denote the firt Figure or Connexion of thee Squares; and he employ'd thee Letters alone intead of Words, which they denote, for brevitie's ake. Thus bb ignifies the goodnes of the difference, or the difference of good things; bc the goodnes of greatnes, or the
goodnes of Concord; bd, the goodnes of contrarieties, or things contrary, and o of the ret; for he ties not himelf olely to the word of each Square, but extends it to all its Conjugata, or Derivatives, Species, and Contraries. As the Conjugata of Goodnes are Well, Good, Bonificative, (or, that is able to make omething good) Bonificent, (that makes a thing actually good) Bonificable (that may be made good) Bonified, (that hath been or is made good) to Bonifie, (to make good) and Bonification (the action whereby a thing is made good.) The Species of Goodnes are, 1, Permanent Good, as To be; Tranient Good, as To act. 2. Honet, Profitable, and Delightful: the Contrary of Good is Evil; of Honet, Bae; of Profitable, Damageable; of Delightful, Troubleom.— Greatnes trancendent and not categorical is that, by reaon whereof it is term'd great, and acts very much; its Conjugates are Great, Grandifying, or Magnifying, Magnificative, Magnification, and to Magnifie, whoe definitions may be undertood by what is aid of Goodnes; its Species are Finitenes and Infinity, length, breadth, heighth, multitude, production, dilatation, multiplication, and their conjugates; its contraries, mallnes, hortnes, narrownes, and their Conjugates.—Duration is that, by reaon whereof a thing endures and is permanent. Its Conjugates, are enduring, durable, &c. its Species, Eternity, Time, and their Conjugates; its contraries, Change, Privation, &c. with their Conjugates.—Power is that whereby a thing can exit and act; its Conjugates are potent, poible, to be able; its Species, Omnipotence, (which is in God alone) imple power, (which is in Creatures) trength, materdom, authority, juridiction, empire; its contraries, impotence, imbecillity, impoibility, and their Conjugates.—Widom is that by reaon whereof any one is wie; its Species are Science, Intelligence, Prudence, Art, Prophecy, Concience, and their Conjugates; its contraries, Ignorance, Imprudence, Error.—Appetite, is that by reaon whereof a thing is deirable; its Species are Intinct, Cupidity, and Will; its contraries, Hatred, Malevolence, Horror, &c.— Virtue is here that which unites and contains a thing; its Species are, Perfect (in God) imperfect (in Man) its contrary. Vice, &c.—Truth, is that by reaon whereof things are true; its peech are verity of the thing, (o God is Truth it elf) Verity of the Intellect (as when we conceive that Man is an Animal) and Verity of Speech (as in this Propoition, Homo et Animal) its contrary is Fality; its Species, thoe oppoite to the former. Truth is again divided into Neceary and Contingent, Simple and Conjunct.—Glory is the upream and utmot perfection of a thing in the enjoyment whereof it acquieces, being unable to wih ought more; uch will be the Glory of the Bleed; its Species are Honour conider'd in it elf and call'd by the Latins, Decus; and Honor receiv'd from others, which they properly call Honor. Thus much for the firt Column.

The Second is of Relative Terms, which agree not to all things in general as the former do, but are three Ternaries, one of the three whereof necearily agrees; for every thing either differs, or agrees, or is contrary to another; is at its beginning, middle, or end; is greater, equal, or les; and is extended likewie to its Conjugates, and divided into its Species: but they have no other contrary but themelves conider'd one in repect of another.

The Third Column is of Quetions, whereof the firt is, Whether the thing imply exit, as, Whether there be a Phoenix; or, Whether it be ome other thing; as, Whether the Moon be greater than the Earth. The econd is, What the thing is? To which it is anwer'd by the Genus or Difference, and conequently, by a Definition or Decription; or ele, What the word ignifies? The third hath two branches; the former demands, Whence a thing took its Rie, as in this Quetion, Whence comes Original in? From that of our firt Parents. The latter asks, To whom the thing belongs, as, Whoe book is this? The fourth Quetion inquires the Caue; as, Why a tone always tends towards the Centre? The fifth concerns either continu'd Quantity; as, What magnitude the Sun is of? or disjoynted Quantity; as, How many everal magnitudes of tars there are in Heaven? The ixth is concerning Quality; as, Whether Opium be hot or cold? The eventh is of Time; as, When is there an Eclipe of the Moon? The eighth is of the means by which one thing is in an other? as, The Earth in its Centre, the Part in its Whole, the Accident in its Subject, Wine in its Cak. The ninth aks; How any thing is done? As, How do the Intellectual Species act upon the Intellect? How do the Senible Species act upon the Senes?

The Ue of this Art, (tyl'd alo by its Author Cabalitica, becaue 'tis learnt better by Cabal, or Tradition, than by Rules) conits in Terms, Quetions of the Alphabet, and Figures, which are Combinations or Conjunctions of two or three of thoe Terms; to the end it may be eaie for any one to examine the Quetion propos'd by all the wayes reulting from thee Combinations or Conjunctions of Terms. For Example, if you deire to prove that the Intellect is immortal, you mut run over the Terms by themelves, and examine the goodnes of the Intellect, its Greatnes, Duration, Power, and other following Terms; firt, each apart, and afterwards joyning two or three together. And if you would not forget any Medium of proving, carry the Quetion through all the quares reulting from the Combinations of thee Terms, which, indeed, are o numerous, that the mot judicious retrain themelves only to the principal and mot uitable to the Subject; it being not the multitude but the goodnes of proofs that perwades.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCVI. Why a Needle touch'd by a Loadtone turns toward the North?
div.p: TO omit Preface in this Quetion, There are two orts of Load-tones; the black, ditinguiht with little lines, which draws fleh; and that which is of the colour of Iron. This latter is call'd Lapis Herculeus, perhaps, upon account of its great virtue; and Sideritis, from Iron which it attracts. Cardan mentions a third ort, with which a Needle being rub'd, enters into the fleh without being felt. We here conider the econd ort, which turns it elf towards the tail of the leer Bear. And ince nothing is done in vain, the Loadtone mut be mov'd thither by ome Caue, which alo mut be either in Heaven or on Earth, the Poles of both which are fixt. I am of their opinion, who ay, that under the Northern Pole there is an Iland call'd Ilva, wherein there are high Mountains of Loadtone, towards which, (the tronger prevailing over the weaker) both our leer Loadtones and Needles toucht therewith turn; becaue thoe vat heaps of Loadtone diffue their virtue over the whole Earth, and o draw all Loadtones, and what-ever Iron is rub'd with them towards themelves.

The Second aid, That the Caue of this Motion ought rather to be acrib'd to ome thing in Heaven, becaue in Ships that approach that Iland of Loadtone, the Needle till tends towards the North, and not towards that Iland. The truth is, there is a Sympathy between ome parts and things of the world; the Female Palm bends towards the Male, Straw moves to Amber, all Flowers, and, particularly, the Marigold and Sun-flower incline towards the Sun, the Loadtone towards the Iron and the tail of the little Bear, which if we conceive to be of the Nature of Iron, there is no more inconvenience therein than in the other Properties attributed to the ret of the Starrs and Planets.

The Third aid, That (to wave what other Authors have aid) this inclination of the Loadtone proceeds from the great humidity of the North, which is the Centre of all waters, towards which they tend. For the Loadtone being extreamly dry, and oblig'd to tend ome way, when it is in aequilibrio it veers towards that quarter to eek the moiture which is wanting to it; as alo doth Steel heated red hot, and uffer'd to cool of it elf, if it be lay'd upon a piece of the wood floating gently in water.

The Fourth was of Cardan's Opinion, who conceives, that tones are animated, and, conequently, that the oul of the Loadtone carries it to the earch of its food and its good; as the the Eye affects Light, a Whelp is carry'd to his Dam's teat, and a
Sheep naturally echews a Wolf. For it matters not whether we hold, That the touch'd Load-tone moves towards the tail of the little Bear, which is ditant five degrees from the Arctick Pole; or, Whether it flie and recoil from the part of Heaven diametrically oppoite thereunto? Now that the Loadtone is animated, appears by its being nouriht with, and kept in the filings of Steel, by its growing old, and by the diminihing of its attractive virtue with age; jut as the virtues of other bodies do. Wherefore, 'tis probable, that the Loadtone's oul either with-draws it from that part which is contrary to it, or ele leads it towards its good. Indeed two different inclinations are oberv'd in this Stone, depending upon the ituation it had in the Mine; one Northwards, whither it turnes the part that once lay that way; the other Southwards, whither it turns its oppoite part. But the Experiment of Iron looing its attraction by being rub'd on the Loadtone the contrary way to which it was rub'd at firt, is an evident ign of uch a oul in it, which makes it thus vary its actions.

The Fifth aid, That all thee accounts leave many difficulties to be reolv'd; for if the Loadtone mov'd towards thoe great Adamantine Mountains of Ilva, then they would draw only that and not Iron; if Iron too, why not before 'tis rub'd with a Loadtone? Nor doth this inclination of the Loadtone proceed from its drynes, for then plain Iron, (which is as dry) Pumice, Lime, and Plater, (which are dryer) hould have the ame effect: Beides that, there is not uch want of humidity as that this tone hould eek it Northwards, the Mediterranean and the Main Ocean being nearer hand. As for Heaven, the Caue is no les obcure there, and the terms of Sympathy and Antipathy differ not much from thoe which profes naked Ignorance. The econd Opinion hath mot probability; for ince the two pieces of a Loadtone cut parallel to the Axis, have o great a community of inclinations, that a Needle touch'd with one piece, is mov'd at any ditance whatoever, according to the motion of another toucht with the other piece; why may we not admit that the tail of the little Bear, or its neighbouring parts, are of a Magnetical Nature; and have the ame community with our Terretrial Loadtone; according to that Maxim in Trimegitus's Smaragdine-Table, That which is above, is as that which is below.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCVII. What Sect of Philoophers is mot to be follow'd.
div.p: ALl the Sciences confes Obligations to Philoophy. Divinity draws Ratiocinations from it; Eloquence is diffue Logick; and Rhetorick is not to be learnt but after Philoophy. Civil Law, being wholly founded upon Morality, is nothing but an effect of it, whilt it teaches us to do voluntarily what the Laws makes us practie by force. Phyick uppoes excellent kill in Philoophy, ince the Phyician begins where the Naturalit ends. Now there are o many Sects of Philoophers, that to follow them all, is to fall into manifet contradictions; and to adhere to one alone, is to be in great danger of mitaking the wort. That which keeps us from being able to make a good choice, is the little knowledge we have of thee Sects, and the Probability each eems to have; and therefore 'tis requiite to examine them in general, in order to drawing a general concluion. And becaue Saint Augutine cites almot three hundred Opinions touching the Supream Good, and as many may be brought touching other points of the Sciences; I hall only take notice of the famouet Sects, as eeming the mot rational, and mot follow'd. And let us compare the always contentious Peripatericks, and the Stoicks together: The end of the former was to contemplate and undertand things; the latter, aim'd more to do good than to know it; their deign was Speculation, the cope of thee Practici. I ide with the former, becaue that Science which embelliheth Man's noblet part, his Undertanding, is the mot ublime, and conequently, the mot coniderable. And as the Undertanding is more excellent than the Will, o is Theory in matter Science than Exercie, Acts of Virtue depending on the Acts of Reaon, and thoe of Reaon not depending on thoe of Liberty. Beides, that is mot to be eteem'd, which mut render us bleed; and that is the knowledge of God, and of the Creatures in God and in themelves, which is to contitute the Beatifick Viion.

The Second aid, That Men ought not to get knowledge only to know, but to operate comformably to their knowledge. Truth would be either ueles or dangerous, if it lead us not to practie. And though the Will is one Sene ubordinate to the Undertanding, yet it commands the ame in another. To know how to do well, and yet to do ill, is a double crime. And if knowledge alone could make happy, the Devils would be oon in Heaven; ince Divines tell us, the leat of them, hath more natural knowledge than all Mankind together. Now the Opinion of the Stoicks regulating the Acts of our Wills, and compoing our Manners uitable to Reaon, eems to place the teps which
mut raie us to the highet pitch of Felicity. Wherefore I conclude, that the Curious may follow the firt Sect of thee, namely, the Peripateticks; but good men mut necearily adhere to that of the Stoicks.

The Third aid, That there are three other Sects which eem to comprize all the ret, and therefore not to be omitted in this important choice: Firt, the Pyrrhonians, who doubt of all things, and ay, There is no knowledge of any thing. Secondly, Thoe that doubt of nothing, but think they know every thing. Thirdly, Thoe who are neither in doubt, nor in perfect certainty, but in earch of Truth. The firt do found their Opinion upon this receiv'd Maxim, That there is nothing in the Undertanding but what pas'd through the Senes; and thee being fallacious, our Notions mut be o too; That being we perceive not the eence of things, we cannot ay that we know any thing. But thee people may be anwer'd, That ince they have not o much as a knowledge of their doubts, they cannot make the ame pas for a demontrative maxim; if they think they have uch a knowledge, they mut grant that there is knowledge of ome thing; and if of doubts, why not of certainties. Moreover, if the Senes be always fallacious, it will follow that there are Powers, which acting without impediment, never attain their end; and if our Undertanding be always abus'd, 'tis in wore cae than the faculties of Brutes, who acquiece in embracing their Objects. In brief, thee dreamers cannot be ignorant that themelves exit, becaue they act, and that exitence is the foundation of all action. Nor are thoe that think they know every thing much more intelligent; the former offend againt Truth, by denying it; thee, by thinking it their ole Mitres. They argue, that ince the Undertanding is the Subject of the Intelligible Species, which contain (they ay) either actually or potentially the impreions of all Objects, it follows that as oon as we frame a Notion, we know all things. But I ak thee Knowing Men, What Truths they know o eaily, which other Wits hold o difficult to be known, Whether created or uncreated Verity? The former is knowable only to it elf; we may demontrate, That it is, but not What it is in its own Nature. And how many errors have there been concerning the Nature of that Sole, Neceary, and true Being? And as for the latter, we know not the Truth of Eences, but by their Accidents; and thee by Species which are very often perverted, either in the Medium, or the Organ. But how can we know other things perfectly, whereas we know not our Selves? We know that we act, but we know not how; o that the Opinion of thoe that profes only to eek Truth, is the bet and uret, though it ingageth us to continual labour; and be the punihment aid by the Holy Scripture to be inflicted upon Men, both to atisfie and chatie their Curioity. Now Action is the Life of the Soul, and that Science which keeps the Mind always awake, is jutly preferrable before that which
renders o good an Agent idle, and impoverihes it by perwading it that it hath riches enough already. Beides, all Men are of this Opinion, either directly or indirectly: And Dienters themelves, eek Reaons every day to maintain it. Atrologers till endeavor to dicover new Stars, Chymits new Secrets, Phyicians new Remedies, and Philoophers new Opinions.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCVIII. Why Mules breed not.
div.p: THe Firt aid, That Mules are barren, becaue every perfect Animal can produce only its own like by univocal Generation, defin'd, The production of a Living Thing decending from another Living Thing by a conjoyn'd Principle, in order to imilitude of Species. But Mules cannot generate thus, becaue being produc'd by a Hore and an As, they are neither the one nor the other, nor yet both together; but a third Species retaining omething of both. So that after what-ever manner they joyn together, they cannot make their like, that is, produce an Animal part Hore, and part As; If a Mule could generate, it mut be by coupling with a Species different from its own, as with a Hore or an As; whence infinite everal Species, partaking more or les of the nature of Hore or As would arie, and o Forms being increas'd or diminih'd, Subtance hould receive degrees of More and Les, contrary to the Maxim of Philoophers. And in this matter, Nature's Widom and Providence is obervable, who rather upends her Action, than uffers any inconvenience to come by it.

The Second aid, That there are particular as well as general caues of the Sterility of Mules. As firt, they want ditinction of Sex, that between them being only imilitudinary, and the parts they have anwering to the genitals of other Animals, having only the outward figure, not the internal form and energy thereof: Jut as the Teats in Men, Dogs, Swine, &c. ignifie nothing as to any ue, but erve only for correpondence with the Female and Ornament.

The Third aid, That the Sterility of Mules cannot be deign'd by Nature only to avoid multiplication of Species in infinitum; ince this conideration hinders not but that Leopards and other Mixt Animals generate, and Plants ingrafted upon others of different Species bear fruit. But the caue hereof mut be ought in the divers Temperature and Complexion of the As and Hore; the former being very melancholy, that is, Cold and Dry, as appears by his lownes; the other Hot and Dry, as he tetifies by his nimblenes; their two eeds mingled together compoe a third, which indeed, hath Natural Heat and Radical Moiture
enough for making an Animal: but Nature having brought her work to this point, can go no further; becaue he pent all the Radical Moiture and Natural Heat he had in the firt production; whereby Mules have the Courage of the Hore, and the Laboriounes of the As. But the Mule having only Heat and Radical Moiture enough for it elf, and not enough for the production of another, the ame cannot be produc'd.

The Fourth aid, That the Number of Forms and Species of things being limitted, 'tis not in the power of Art and Nature to multiply them. And though it be eaie to multiply them in the family of Plants, which are but of one Sex, (though ome are ditinguiht into Male and Female, upon account of ome mall differences); Yet 'tis not in the Gardener's power to ingraft all orts of Fruits one upon another. For (excepting the Colewort, in whoe foot, when 'tis become hard and ligneous, one may ingraft ome hrubs) Plants of divers kinds mingle not one with another, as trees with herbs or hrubs, and herbs with trees. Nor will the Pepin admit inition into the Nut-tree, or on the contrary: Nature differs from Art in this chiefly, that he hath her work bounded and determin'd; but Art counterfeits what the Artit pleaes. Whence Painters oftentimes draw fine Pictures, and beget deform'd Children. Every mixture of Perfumes is not pleaant, nor of Medicaments effectual; nor do our Sawces admit of any ingredients, but only of ome that are uitable and proper. So alo two everal grains mixt together produce nothing, becaue Nature hath temper'd eeds in uch degree, that nothing can be added or diminiht from them, but deprives them of their efficacy. If uch unnatural Mixture make any productions, the ame is prodigious, and amongt Animals is call'd a Monter: But being an Error of Nature, he returns to her old way as oon as he can, and rather ceaes to generate, than produces econd Monters of thoe firt. And this in Mules rather than other Species, becaue the Equine and Ainine Natures are no les contrary than Fire and Water. So that if they happen to be conjoyn'd, and make one Compoitum, the Generative Virtues then exitent in their eeds make an Animal indeed; but, in producing the ame, they extinguih one another, as Fire doth Water; and o what is generated of them, hath no power of Generation.

The Fifth aid, That this Sterility being uppos'd, (although Aritotle relates, that in Syria-Mules commonly generate; and Theophratus, Varro, and others affirm the like of thoe in Cappadocia and Africa) Democritus in Aelian, attributes the caue thereof to the ill conformation of their genitals, particularly, of the womb, which is unapt to retain and quicken the eed, becaue through the exceive heat deriv'd from the Hore, the paages erving to thoe parts in either ex are too much dilated; beides that, the ame are very laxe in the Shee-As; whence Naturalits and Experience tells us, that he conceives not, unles
after covering he be well cudgel'd, that o the pain thereof may make her contringe her womb, and retain the eed which otherwie would lide out again. Now this over great dilatation of the genitals appears by diection; and 'tis found by Experience, that the Beats themelves are unwilling to uch an unnatural copulation; o that in ome Countries people are fain to feed Aes with Mare's milk, and cover the Mares ometimes with Cloaths of the colour of an As, to beguile them into the ame. Add hereunto that both the Species, of which Mules are generated, are very ubject to Sterility. For the As is of a cold temper, and particularly, its eed is o cold, that unles it begins to generate at the firt cating of its Teeth, it remains barren for ever. Yea, if an As couple with a pregnant Mare, the coldnes of his eed makes her cat her Foal. The Hore likewie, by Ar • totle's report, is very little fruitful; whence his eed being further refrigerated by that of the As, they produce an Animal indeed, but altogether improlifick.

div.head: CONFERENCE CXCIX. Of the Mandrake.
div.p:
SInce of the three Conditions of Curing, to wit, pleaantly, peedily, and afely, this latter pertains chiefly to Plants; it were good that a little more curious earch were made into the treaures hid in the Plantal Family of Remedies, whereof Nature hath provided above three thouand everal Species, which are many more than are in thoe of Animals and Minerals. And as Nature hath (intead of the Intinct betow'd on other Animals to guide them to their good) given Man Reaon, whereby he may proceed from things known to things unknown; o, beides the manifet and occult qualities of Plants, from whence their ues may be inferr'd, he hath markt thoe which are mot ueful to us with certain Signs and Characters: Amongt thee, Mandrake is the mot famous, repreenting not the Eye as Eye-bright doth; nor the Lungs, as Lungwort; nor the Liver, as Liverwort; nor the Rupture, as Solomon's Seal; nor the Hemorrhoids, or Orpment; nor an Ulcer as potted, as potted Armart; but the Figure of an entire Man: And as the eminent Virtues of Ancient Heroes being too great to be comprehended by the Wits of thee Ages, gave occaion to fabulous Romances; o the Wits of Botanits that have been capable to write the Virtues of other Simples, have not been ufficient to peak of thee of Mandrakes, leaving the vulgar the liberty to attribute Supernatural Virtues to them. Which made ome Rabbins ay, that the Teraphins of Laban, Jacob's Father-in-law, were the roots of Mandrake, which render'd him Anwers; and for the los of
which he fell into uch Paion; and Pliny acribes to the Mandrake the name of Oiris, which was that of an Aegyptian Idol. Our Hitories report, that in the year 1420. a certain Cordelier, nam'd Frier Richard, was o perwaive in his Serm • ns, that in two dayes the Pariians publickly burnt all the intruments of voluptuounes and debauchery, and, particularly, the Women their Images; and Mandrakes which they kept wrapt up in their attires, upon a belief that as long as they had Mandrakes, they hould never fail to become rich: which Mandrakes, gave them Anwers by haking the head, or ele by peech. And there are not only true, but alo counterfeit ones, uch as were made by an Italian Mountebank, (as Matthiolus relates) who carv'd the root of Pyony, or of a great Reed in the hape of a Man, and ticking Millet or Flax eed in the places where hair hould grow, bury'd the ame for twenty dayes; at the end whereof, fine mall threads appear'd in thoe places, and a kin over all the ret, which repreented and pas'd for a true Mandrake. Belleforet alo relates, that the Maid of Orleans was calumniated for having acquir'd the valour he tetifi'd againt the Englih by the Magical Virtue of a Mandrake. And Henry Bouquet, a modern Author, affirms, that Thieves teal the Goods out of Houes, and Children from their Mothers Breats by help of it; thoe that behold them being unable to defend themelves, becaue this Plant tupifies their Hands. So likewie Levinus Lemnius tell us, that 'tis employ'd with great effect in Philtres and Amorous Potions: Upon which account, Natalis Comes, thinks it was an ingredient in that which Circe gave Scylla, whereby he became o deperately in Love with Glaucus, that, being unable to enjoy him, he cat her elf headlong into the treight of Meina. Some think, 'tis the ame Plant that Joephus lib. 7. cap. 25. de bello Judaico, calls Baaras, from the valley wherein it grows; which, he aith, hines in the night like fire, and is pluckt up by a hungry Dog ty'd to the top of the root, after the ame hath been oftned with the Urine of a Woman; becaue upon its plucking up, 'tis aid to end forth a hreek which is mortal to the hearer, and o the Dog dyes after his work is done. Others conceive, that this root cannot be found except a little before the riing of the Pleiades, which is about the beginning of September. Which is no more incredible, than that the eed of Fearn prings but at a certain prefixt time, before and after which, it appears not. 'Tis likewie thought particular to Upper Hungary, and to be pluckt up only by certain Sorcerees, and that in the night; whence alo they ell the ame ecretly, for fear of being punih'd by Jutice; as it happen'd Anno 1630. at Hamburg, where the Senate caus'd three Women who exercis'd this trade to be whipt. Moreover, they hold that this Plant, (call'd Mandrake from a German word which ignifies to bear the figure of a Man; for Man hath the ame ene in that Language as in ours; and Dragen, is to bear or carry) comes from the eed of Men hanged on
Gibbets, or broken on the Wheel, which dropping upon the ground, already fat and unctuous by the multitude of hanged Bodies, produceth this Anthropomorphite-Plant, o term'd by Pythagoras, and alledg'd as an Intance to prove his Metempychois. Which Conceit is alo trengthened by the production of Beans, which the ame Pythagoras and many others hold, to be produc'd of dead Bodies; for which reaon he not only abtain'd from eating them, but had them in uch reverence that he uffer'd himelf to be kill'd in a field of Beans, through which he might, have ecap'd, but would not, for fear of hurting them. So likewie of the Urine of a Dog is produc'd the Herb Orrach; of an Elephant's Blood, uckt and vomited by a Dragon, Sanguis Draconis; of the Bodies of Serpents, Serpentana; and of the eed of Stags, the Muhroms, call'd Boleti Cervini. So that though this Plant be not een, it doth not follow that there is no uch thing; it being no more aburd to credit the voice of the vulgar in this matter, than in many others.

The Second aid, There are three orts of Plants that bear the name of Mandrake, the Etymologie whereof may be taken from the Latin word Mandra, which ignifies a Cave or a hady place; becaue this Plant loves to grow in the hadow, and cannot long endure the heat of the Sun. The firt ort is call'd Mandragoras mas, or white Mandrake; hath on the top of its Root great leavs, pread on the ground like thoe of broad-leav'd Lettice, but omewhat long, hining and mooth, in colour reembling thoe of Bete, to wit, of a pale green; the Flower is likewie pale, whereunto is annexed a round Apple of the bignes of a mall Lemon, of a pale Saffron colour, and full of a ucculent pulp, wherein are pale or blew kernels, like thoe of a Pear, aving that they are not pointed, but flat like a kidney. Its root is lating, and dyes not yearly as mot others do; long, and o thick, that it can carce be grap'd with one Hand. 'Tis uually divided into two; of colour outwardly, between white and red; within, white; carnoe, juicy, and of tate between weet and bitter. The whole Plant ends forth a trong mell, epecially the Apples, whoe juice is om what vinous, but bitterih; and burdens the Head both melt and tated. The econd ort call'd Mandragoras niger, or Female Mandrake, hath leavs like the Male, but les and traiter, like thoe of mall-leav'd Lettice, of a dark green, bearing Apples as big as our little Medlars: Its root is les, but otherwie in mell, tate, and figure, like the former; only 'tis black without, and white within, and ometimes divided into three. The third kind is call'd by ome Herbarits, Morion, or Mandrake of Theophratus; touching which, though all agree not, yet the opinion of Codrus, whom we follow here, is, that it hath great roots, a high talk, and leavs of a middle ize between Solanum and Female Mandrake; its Flower is black, and o alo is its Fruit; equal to a big Grape, and of a vinous juice: which Plant ome call Solanum Mortiferum, the Italians Bella
Donna, which grows likewie in hadowy places (as the former alo do) in many parts of Italy, epecially in Apulia, and ometimes is et in Gardens: the Apples are ripe in Augut. Galen accounts them cold in the third degree, and all Authors agree that they are very moit. All their parts are omniferous, and of great ue in Phyick, according to Diocorides. The mot active is the bark of the Root: The ancient way was to peel the root, pres out the juice, and thicken it in the Sun; or ele to boil the root in new Wine till a third part were conum'd, or to infue it without coction: of this liquor they adminitred one or two glaes to uch as could not leep, and three to uch as were to have a limb cut off. They us'd it likewie in inflammations of the eyes, ome feminine dieaes, and to uppurate Phlegmons; having uch a mollifying faculty, that in ix hours boiling the Root with Ivory, (they ay) the ame becomes plyable, and apt to take any impreion. At this day carce ought but the leaves and roots are in ue, (except that the apples are ometimes boil'd in oil) but all externally, not by the mouth. 'Tis alo thought alexipharmacal againt Serpents, and good to cure Tetters, being bruis'd and apply'd with vinegar. All which effects have made it admir'd; but (as humane Nature is prone to Supertition) though this Plant be indu'd only with Vertues common to other Plants, (the oporiferous Quality being found in Lettice, Poppy, Henbane, and more eminently in Opium; and that of being proper to Women, in the Aritoloches) yet becaue its root reembles a man's legs, and its trunk in ome ort his body without arms; hence Mountebanks have by their frauds and tricks brought people to believe their trange Stories of it, even that it eats like a man, and performs his other natural functions. Which impoture, though les prevalent upon trong minds, becomes les credible by the prodigious manner they relate it to be produc'd: for 'tis impoible to imagine that any generation can proceed from perm detitute of pirits, and out of the proper natural ubject detinated to its reception.

The Third aid, That indeed no Univocal Generation can be made after the los of the pirits of Sperm; but equivocal, uch as this is, may: whereunto Nitre contributes very much; which alt not being lot by death, nothing hinders but, a fertile oil being determin'd by ome form or other, a Plant may arie out of it; to which production fewer conditions are requiite than to that of an Animal. And 'tis the les incredible, if the Experiment deliver'd by ome Authors be true; That the alts of Roemary, Sage, Mint, and ome other trong-ented herbs, being extracted according to Art, and frozen in a Glas, exhibite the image of thoe Plants, therein; and, if own in well-prepared earth, produce the Plants of ame Species.

The Fourth aid, That not only the means of the production of this imaginary Plant are o too, but alo the upernatural vertues acribed to it are ridiculous; yea, thoe aid to be natural
to it are very hard to be jutifi'd: for to be oporiferous, and to promote Procreation in Men and Women of everal tempers is inconitent, becaue thee things require Simples of very different Qualities; and alo are the caues of Sterility. This error of its being prolifick,, proceeds from a fale uppoition taken out of Geneis, where 'tis aid, that Reuben, the Son of Leah, one of Jacob's Wives, having brought Mandrakes to his Mother, her Siter Rachel could not obtain them of her but upon condition that Jacob (who depis'd her for Rachel the fairer of the two but barren) hould lie with her that night: which bargain was made between them. Now becaue Rachel had Children afterwards, hence ome Interpreters infer, that he eat thoe Mandrakes, and that they render'd her fruitful: which is not at all in the Text; and her Fruitfulnes might proceed from the favour of God, or ome more fit means than that Herb. Nor is it an edible fruit, neither did all the Women in the Scripture, who of barren became fruitful, eat Mandrakes. 'Tis therefore probable, that this Plant hath neither the Form, nor the Properties which vulgar and vain Antiquity attributes to it.

The fifth aid, 'Tis eaier to overthrow, then to etablih a Truth, when the quetion is about things apparently repugnant to Reaon, which many times agrees not with our own experience, whereby we ee everal contrary effects of one and the ame Plant. As the pulp of an Orenge cools, the peel heats, and oil of the eeds is temperate: The like may be aid of Mandrake, which according to the diverity of its Species and Parts may produce the different effects, which are atteted by Antiquity; Apuleius, in his Metamorphois relating, That a Phyician deluded the malice of a Servant and a Stepmother, by giving them the juice of Mandrake intead of poyon (which they deir'd of him to kill a young man) which caus'd them to think him dead when he was only in a deep leep: and Columella peaking of the oil where it grows;
Quamvis emihominis veano gramine foeta,
Mandragorae pariat flores.
Moreover ince there are middle Natures compos'd of two extremes, as your Zöophytes between Plants and Animals, to wit, Spunges and Coral; between Brute and Man, the Ape; between the oul and body of Man, his Spirits: why may there not be omething of a middle Nature between Man and Plant, to wit, the Mandrake, a Man in external Shape, and a Plant in Effect and internal Form. In brief, we believe there is an Unicorn, though no man of this age hath een it; why therefore may we not believe, that there is uch a Mandrake as mot decribe, who affirm that they have een one, as I my elf have alo, though I cannot affirm whether it were a true or fale one.

div.head: CONFERENCE CC. Of Panick Fear.
div.p: THe Species conceiv'd in the Phantaie repreenting to the Intellect ome future Good, they beget Hope; when Evil, Fear. 'Tis not very hard to comprehend the way, nor how he, that ees himelf puru'd by a potent enemy, betakes himelf to flight, by the Intinct of Nature, which avoids what ever is detructive to her: But the Mind is puzled to find the caue it ees not, as of groundles Fear; which nevertheles ometimes befalls the mot reolute, yea whole Armies, which fly without any puruer. The Vulgar of the Ancients, (who made Deities of every thing, epecially of what they undertood not) thought Pan the God of Shepherds put this udden Paion into the minds of men; becaue oftentimes it happens to flocks of Sheep, over which he is aid to preide; though there be no appearance of any Wolf to fright them: whence they call'd it a Panick Terror. Unles you had rather interpret Pan to be the Univeral and Supreme Deity, who giving the ucces of Battels, ometimes immits uch a fear into the hearts of thoe men whom he intends to deliver into the power of their Enemies.

The econd aid, That Pan was an ancient Warrior, who invented the ranging of Soldiers in order of Battel, and ditinguih'd them into Wings, call'd by the Latins, Cornua; whence he was pictur'd with Horns. He alo firt devis'd Strategems; o that one day, having ent out his Scowts, and undertood that the Enemies were lodg'd in a deert place full of reounding caverns, he order'd his Soldiers, that as oon as they approach'd the Enemy, they hould make a great hout; which, multiply'd by the Echo of thoe neighbouring caverns, o frighted them, that before they could undertand what it was, they betook themelves to flight, conceiving they had to do with a far greater multitude of Enemies than there was: Whence the Fable of this God Pan adds, that the Goddes Echo was his Mitres. From this, Groundles Fear, as others of the like nature, came to be call'd Panick Terrors. Such was that which eiz'd the Soldiers of Marc Antony in the War againt Mithridates; that of the Gauls under Brennus, when they were ready to ack the Temple of Delphos; that of Hannibal, when he approacht the walls of Rome to beiege it; and that of Macedonians under their King Pereus, who o lot their courage upon ight of an Eclipe of the Moon, that it was eaie for the Romans to overcome them.

The Third aid, That Plutarch, in his Treatie of Iis and O ••
ris, relates another caue of this Appellation; namely, That when the latter of them reign'd in Aegypt, Typhon urpris'd him
by a wile, and cat him in a chet into Nilus; which News arriving amongt the Pans and Satyrs, it put them into an atonihment; from which all other udden frights took their name. But leaving apart conjectures of words, let us conider the thing, and examine, Whether it be not a mitake, to think that there can be terrors without any caue? I think, There cannot; becaue 'tis as true in Moral as in Natural Philoophy, That nothing produceth nothing. But as an even balance is way'd either way by the leat blat, and (the caue being imperceptible) eems to incline of it elf; o when Men are ready for a battel, and every one thinks of the doubtful event thereof to himelf, the leat external caue hapning to make never o little impreion upon their Spirits whilt they are in this balance, is enough to move them either way; the firt object that occurs, yea, the leat word, being of great efficacy. And becaue Fear is found more univerally imprinted in Mens minds than Courage; hence there needs les ubject to produce it, than to animate them. Thus at the battel of Montcontour, this ingle word, Save the Princes, poken either accidentally, or by deign, made them loe the day. Thitles being mitaken for Lances, gave a great terror to a whole Army; and an As or a Cow in the Trenches, hath ometimes given an Alarm to coniderable Garrions.

The Fourth aid, That Fear caus'd in an Enemy being one of the uret means to conquer him, Generals have not been more careful to animate their own Souldiers, than to terrifie their Enemies even by vain affrightments; as howts, extravagant arms, and habits. For this reaon the Germans were wont to paint their Faces with everal colours, that they might eem terrible; ome think our Poictevins had their name of Pictons from this cutom: So Gideon by Gods command employ'd Trumpets and earthen Pitchers with fire in them to terrifie the Amalekites. Yet none of thee Inventions, no more than that of Elephants, Chariots of fire, and other Machins, can caue a Panick Terror, becaue it ceaes to bear that name when 'tis found to have ome manifet caue. So that to ak, Whence Panick Fear proceeds? is to ak, What is the caue of that which hath none? If there be any, I think 'tis from ome hideous Phantams irregularly conceiv'd in the Brain as a Mola, or a Monter is in the womb; which Phantams ariing from a black humor, caue Sadnes and Fear; a Paion eaily communicable, becaue conformable to the Nature of Man; who coniting of a material and heavy Body, hath more affinity with the Paions that deject him, as Fear doth, than with thoe which elevate him, as Hope and Ambition do. The moral caue of Panick Terror is Ignorance, which clouds and darkens the light of the Soul; whence the mot ignorant, as Children and Women, are mot ubject to this Fear; and Souldiers, who are the more ignorant ort, being taken out of the Country, and from the dregs of the people, become eaily urpriz'd with it; and by the pronenes of Men to imitation, upon
the leat beginning it finds a great acceion and familiarity in Humane Nature.

The Fifth aid, That the caue of this Terror may be a natural precience our Souls have of the evil which is to befall us; which is more manifet in ome than in others; as appear'd in Socrates, who was advertis'd of what-ever important thing was to befall him by his familiar Spirit, or good Angel. Now if there be any time wherein thoe Spirits have liberty to do this, 'tis when we are near our End, our Souls being then half unloos'd from the Body, as it comes to pas alo at the commencement of a battel, through the tranport every one uffers when he ees himelf ready either to die or overcome.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCI. Of the Water-drinker of S. Germain's Fair.
div.p:
THis Peron is of a middle Stature; hath a large Breat, as alo a Face, epecially his Fore-head; very great Eyes, and is aid to be ixty years old, though he appears to be but about forty. He was born in the Town of Nota, in the Iland of Maltha, and is nam'd Blaie Manfrede, They that have oberv'd him in private Houes, and upon the Theatre, relate that he makes his experiment not only every day, but oftentimes twice in one afternoon. Moreover, vomiting o freely as he does, he is always hungry when he pleaes. His Practie is very diagreeing from his publih'd Tickets, wherein he promies to drink a hundred quarts of water; but he never drinks four, without returning it up again. His manner is thus: He caues a pail full of warm water, and fifteen or twenty little glaes, with very large mouths to be brought to him; then he drinks two or three of thee glaes full of water, having firt waht his mouth, to hew that there is nothing between his teeth: Afterwards, for about half a quarter of an hour, he talks in Italian; which time being pas'd, he drinks three or four and twenty more of the aid glaes, and thereupon pouts forth of his mouth with violence a red water, which eems to be wine, but hath only the colour of it. This water appears red as it comes out of his mouth, and yet when it is pouted into two of his glaes, it becomes of a deep red in one, and of a pale red in the other; and changing the ituation of his glaes, on the left ide of his mouth to the right, and of thoe on the right to the left, thee colours always appear different in the ame glas; namely, the one of a deep red, and the other yellow, or Citron-color. Some of the water is of the color of pall'd wine; and the more he vomits, the clearer, and les colour'd the water is. He hath often promis'd to bring up Oyl and
Milk; but I never aw nor heard that he did it. This done, he ets his glaes to the number of fifteen or ixteen upon a form or bench, to be een by every one. After which, he drinks more water in other glaes, and brings it up again either clear water, or Orenge flower water, or Roe-water; and latly, Aqua Vitae, (which are manifet by the mell, and by the burning of the Aqua Vitae) having been oberv'd to keep this order always in the ejection of his liquors, that red water comes up firt, and Aqua Vitae lat. He performs this Trick with thirty or forty half glaes of water, which cannot amount to above four quarts at mot; then having ignifi'd to the people that his Stomack, although no Mucle, (which is the intrument of voluntary motion) obeys him, he cats the ame water up into the Air with its natural colour o impetuouly, that it imitates the Cats of water in Gardens, to the great admiration of the Spectators, who for ix we • ks together, were eldom fewer than three hundred daily. For my part, I find much to admire in this action. For though men's Stomacks be of different capacities, and ome one peron can eat and drink as much as four others; yet I ee not, poibly, where this fellow hould lodge o much water. And again, he eems rather to powr water into a Tun than to wallow it, though the conformation of the Gullet doth not conit with uch deglutition. Beides, vomiting is a violent action, and yet mot facile in this Drinker. And as to the order of this Evacuation, 'tis certain, that all things put into the Stomack are confounded together therein, o that Concoction begins by Mixtion; and yet this fellow brings up what-ever he pleaes, as 'twere out of everal veels; o that he undertakes to eat a Sallad of everal orts of Herbs and Flowers, and to bring them up all again in order. Moreover, what can be more prodigious, than this mutation of Colours, Smells, and Subtances? And, indeed, they ay, he hath ometimes fear'd to be quetion'd for Sorcery. But the greatet wonder is that martnes and violence wherewith he pouts out water from his Stomack, not laterally, which is the ordinary manner of vomiting; but upwards, which is a motion contrary to heavie bodies, as water is. Some peculative peron that had read in Saint Augutin, that a Man's being turn'd into a Hore by the power of Imagination, might refer the caue of all thee wonders to that faculty; which daily producing new hapes upon the Bodies of Children in their Mothers womb, may with les trangenes, produce in this Man the above-mention'd alteration of one colour into another. And as for his facility of bringing up what-ever he hath wallow'd, I can find no better Reaon for it than Cutom, which in him is turn'd into Nature.

The Second aid, That Ignorance being the Mother of Admiration, we begin les to admire as we proceed to more Knowledg. Now if this Maltee were a Magician, he would do more marvellous things, and of more than one ort; whereas all his power is confin'd
only to the vomiting up of liquors which he drunk before; and the faculty of his Stomack being determin'd to this ingle kind of action, the ame mut be natural; becaue that is the definition of natural powers. Moreover, no action ought to be accus'd of Magick, till good Reaons have evinc'd it to urpas all the powers of Nature; which is very hard to prove, becaue we know not how far they may reach: And hould we accue of Magick every thing when we undertand not the Caues, almot all Natural Philoophy would be turn'd into upertition. Again, a Man that promies more than he can perform, drinking but the twentieth part of what he boats of, and who can make but one ort of colour iue out of his mouth, though he expoes everal others to the Spectator's Eyes, cannot pas for a great Sorcerer, or refin'd Magician. As for the eaines and violence where-with he cats water out of his Stomack at pleaure, it cannot be either from Artifice or Cutom alone, which cannot put free and voluntary motions into parts wherein there is none, nor procure new Organs neceary to this action; and no Man being able to accutom himelf to move his Ears at his pleaure, unles the ame be naturally dipos'd thereunto, as Manfrede's Stomack is. Now natural dipoitions are only of two orts; ome depend upon the Temperament, which is incapable of this effect; others, belong to the Stomack, as it is an Organical part; namely, a particular Conformation, which may be eaily conjectur'd from the example of ruminating Animals, who when they lit, bring up their food out of their Stomack into their mouth: An action not impoible to Men; ince Nature oftentimes by error gives one Species uch a Conformation in ome parts, as is of right peculiar to another; and accordingly the faculty of ruminating is found in divers Men. Aquapendens aw two to whom this action was more voluntary than that whereby we void our excrements, when they importunately olicite us; oberving exprely that they were not contrain'd to it, but by the pleaure which they took in it. And the ame Author likewie records, that opening the Body of one that ruminated, he found one Membrane of his Stomack more fibrous and trong than ordinary. And the ame is probably o in that of this Maltee, ince this voluntary motion can proceed only from uch a Conformation. In like manner thee perons that have been able to move their Ears, have been oberv'd to have the Mucles behind them more flehy than other Men. And our Conjecture is further confirm'd by the Intance of the Bladder, whoe Excretion is perform'd by the Pyramidal Mucles, which oftentimes are deficient; and in that cae their office is upply'd by the carnous Membrane of the Bladder which is valid, and performs the motions of a Mucle, according to the opinion of the greatet Anatomits of this Age. So that what is o ordinary in the Bladder, is not to be admir'd in the Stomack: Beides that, Cutom may have much increas'd the trength and dexterity of this faculty; and although it have not otherwie
conduc'd in the leat to the effect, but only as founded upon a natural Dipoition. That all ruminating have not been able to do the like, is, becaue they neglected to increae the natural Dipoition by ue and practie; and as to the diverity of colour and mells, there is nothing therein but artifice and fallacy.

The Third aid, That what is here thought mot admirable, the drinking of a great quantity of Water, is een every day at Pougues and Forges, where you hall have one Peron drink ixty glaes: and thoe that have een the Stomach, that hangs up in the Anatomical Theater of Leyden, and is capable of even quarts, will not think it trange, that this Maltee drinks much les: As for the diverity of Liquors, which he brings up, dicern'd by their everal colours, mells, and the inflammability of the Aqua vitae, I attribute it to the perfection of the reaonable oul, which, as well as all other forms, imprints Dipoitions in the matter; this being univeral, that, beides the Properties common to the whole Species, there is a particular one in every Individual which ditinguihes the ame from others, and comes from the lat Character of the form. That of the Maltee, is to turn common Water into Wine, Orenge-flower-water, Roe-water, and Aqua vitae. For the diverity of matter, and its dipoitions, ignifies nothing as to the mutations introduc'd therein by the Forms; though one may ay, that in common Water, epecially that of the Well, all the Elements, and the three Principles of Chymitry are found, having its Salt from the Earth, its Sulphur from the Bitumen and Naphtha, wherewith the Caverns of the Earth, and epecially Wells abound; and, as for Mercury, 'tis nothing but water it elf. No wonder then, if ince every thing may be made of every thing, by the Maxim of the mot ancient Philoophers, our Maltee fetches what he pleaes out of his Stomack.

The Fourth wonder'd, if this Maxim were true, That every thing is made of every thing in the Maltee's Belly, even without any ditinction or preparation of the matter, why this Water-drinker fetcht o great a circuit to get money, ince 'twould be a horter way for him to make it, and even Gold it elf by the ame reaon; or at leat he would make ale of his weet Waters, and not uffer the Perfumers to be at uch charge in fetching them from far. If he make it his excue, that he would not get vent for uch an abundance, why, if there be no cheat in the thing, hath he not taken occaion of the dearnes of Wine in France this year, to ell the Wine he makes in Paris? But Experience renders it manifet, that the Wine he promies is nothing but water, and conequently, he is les able to make Aqua vitae, into which water cannot be turn'd but by firt taking the nature of Wine; and indeed there needs more wine to yield the quantity of Aqua vitae he pretends to bring up, then he drinks water before he ejects it. Beides, Chymitry manifets, that Aqua vitae is
not made, but only eparated. Nor can this change be a Property in the Maltees Stomack, becaue all Properties are pecifical, and belong to all the Individuals of the ame Species, there being nothing peculiar in any man, but a certain degree of indiviible temperament, call'd Idio-yncraie. And, if his temper be o hot as to turn common water in an intant into Aqua vitae, 'tis impoible to be cold enough to make Roe-water at the ame time: if it have any tranmuting vertue, it ought to turn all into one ort of Liquor; becaue the ame Agent never makes but the ame Effect, unles the Subject be diverifi'd by diverity of matter; whereas here 'tis all water from the ame Spring. Neither could this Drinker drink Well-water without intoxication, becaue, being turn'd into Aqua vitae, the vapors thereof would mount up into his brain; and o to precribe him water in a Feaver, would be no more refrehment to him then if one gave him Aqua vitae.

The fifth aid, That the diverity of colours and odors of the Liquor he ejects, proceeds from the tincture of ome mas of Eence extracted from the ame materials, which thoe Liquors repreent; which Maes he holds between his teeth incorporated with ome gum which fatens them there; o that, as the Water he drinks, paes impetuouly between his teeth, it derives colours and odors from the ame: Which is the reaon why the water he firt cats forth, is mot colour'd; whereas, if the Dye proceeded from his Stomack, it would be deeper at lat of all, as having acquir'd more digetion by a longer infuion.

The Sixth aid, That Hitories are full of everal particular Contitutions of the Natural Parts; witnes the example of the Maid mention'd by Cardan, who drinking but two pints of water a day, pis'd twenty; and that of the Emperor Maximinus, who commonly eat forty pound weight of meat, with proportionable drink, and weat o abundantly, that he fill'd — 'Tis aid, That Theagenes the Thaian eat a Calf for his dinner; and Milo, the famous Wratler of Croton, devour'd a 100. pound of Fleh, a Hoghead of Wine, and Bread proportionable. Such was that Paraite, who one day at the Table of the Emperor Aurelius, eat a Boar, a Sheep, a Pig, and an hundred Loaves, and drunk half a tun of Wine. All which tories render les trange the quantity of this Maltee's Drink, whoe colour poibly afterwards he diguies with powders hid in his Handkerchief which he handles o often, or by the help of a double Glas, of which his Veels are made, or by ome other trick whereto he ha's inur'd himelf for many years.

The Seventh aid, That mineral waters are uually drunk with more eae in great quantity by half than common water can be, becaue their tenuity makes them pas immediately into the habit of the Body. And if you conider that this fellow drinks only out of mall veels, and thoe not always full; as alo with what nimblenes he dipatches his work, you will much abate
the opinion that he drinks o much as is generally believed. Beides, though his pail be of a middle ize, yet 'tis never quite full; and he pends much water in wahing his mouth and his glaes, and ome too is left behind. Nor is it aburd to think, that before his hewing himelf to drink, he wallows a bolus of Brazil, or of Alkanet, or Fearn Root, or of red Sanders, or Indian Wood, or ome uch other thing in powder; after which drinking two or three glaes of water, he interpoes ome interval, that the ame may be the better tinctur'd in his Stomack; which time being pas'd, he drinks about two quarts of water, which oon after he brings up red, appearing o both in the Air and in the glaes: Which colour being weak for want of time to be well imbib'd by the water, is wholly lot when the ame is powr'd into a veel, wherein there is a little Verjuice, Vinegar, juice of Citron, Spirit of Vitriol, or other uch acid liquor, which is proper to conume the aid color. And 'tis obervable, that the lat water he vomits, is continually paler than the firt, the tincture being diminiht by the quantity of water. Add hereunto, that 'tis likely his glaes are mear'd with ome eences, which eem tranparent to the Spectators; for though he makes hew of wahing them, he only paes the brims dextrouly over the water, and lets none of it enter into them. As for the violence wherewith he pouts forth the water, it mut be confes'd, that the fellow hath a great natural propenity to vomiting, which by frequent repetition, is become habitual to him: Cutom being capable to produce uch effects, that I have een a Beggar about fifty years old, by being exercis'd thereunto, pis as high as a pike.
