div.head: CONFERENCE CCII. Why dead Bodies bleed in the preence of their Murderers.
div.p:
HOnet Antiquity was o deirous of knowing the Truth, that when natural and ordinary proofs fail'd, they had recoure to upernatural and extraordinary. Such was the Jews water of Jealouie, which made the otherwie undicoverable Adulterer burt in under; the innocent Vetal's Sieve, in which being accus'd of Incet, he carry'd water without hedding. Such alo were the Oaths made upon Saint Anthonie's arm, of o great reverence, that 'twas believ'd the perjur'd would burn a year with the fire of that Saint; and in our time the excommunication of Saint Genevieue, which thoe that incurr, are commonly reckon'd not to out-live a year. In like ort the zeal of Men againt that horrid crime of Murder, hath made them cherih a perwaion, that a Carkae will bleed before its Murderers; (though mot lain Bodies bleed when they are tirr'd) that o the Concience of the Actors being diturb'd, they might either by word or geture
be brought to make dicovery of themelves. For, indeed, the Blood which was congeal'd in the Veins preently after death, becomes liquid again after two or three dayes, when it is in its tendency to corruption; which Liquefaction, and the Inquiition after the Murderer, hapning commonly at the ame time, 'tis no wonder if the Body bleed in the Murderer's preence, ince it doth o frequently when he is abent. Yet becaue this fale perwaion from the co-incidence of times, ceaes not ometimes to have its effect, and to dicover Truth; therefore Legilators have thought fit to authorize it, and to ue it as an Argument at leat to frighten the Murderer; though, indeed, 'tis no concluive one to condemn him.

The Second aid, That 'tis not credible that Courts of Jutice who often admit this proof to good purpoe, could o continue in ignorance of Natural Caues, as not to dicern the effuion of Blood enuing upon its putrefaction in the Veins, from that which happens upon confrontation of a Murderer. 'Tis better therefore to eek further for the caue, than to quetion the effect; which ome attribute to ome ecret Antipathy of the murder'd peron's blood to that of his Murderer; or ele to their mutual emiion of pirits, which till eeking the detruction of each other's peron, thoe of the Murderer being the tronget, becaue till living, caue a commotion in the Blood of the dead, which thereupon breaks forth at the out-let of the wound; Campanella attributes it to the ene where-with all things are indu'd, and which till remains in thee dead Bodies; o that having a ene of their Murderers, and perceiving them near hand, they uffer two very different motions, Trembling and Anger, which caue uch a commotion in the Blood, that it flows forth at the wound. For the pirits, which during life had uch perceptions as were neceary for their receiving and obeying the Soul's commands, retain omewhat thereof after death, and are capable of dicerning their friends and their enemies.

The Third aid, If this opinion concerning the emanation of pirits, whether by Sympathy or Antipathy, be true, it will follow, That one who hath done a Murder with gun-hot, cannot be dicover'd by this ign; and that one lain in his Wife's arms, and in a crowd of his friends that endeavor'd to defend his life, will bleed rather in the preence of his friends than of his Murderer, whoe pirits are more inwardly retir'd through fear of punihment; whereas thoe of his friends are ent outwards by Anger and deire of Revenge: Yea, if the Murderer had been wounded before, he hould rather bleed than the dead, becaue his Blood is more boyling, and capable of commotion by the pirits iuing out of the Carkae. And had they any Sympathy, they could not dicover the Murderer for want of ene, which they never had; for the pirits which are in the Blood carce deerve that name, being purely natural, and void of all ene even during life, and pecifically different from the animal pirits. The
vital pirits which are a degree above them, vanih together with life, whence the Arteries that us'd to contain them are empty. And thoe that erve for Senation cannot remain in a dead Body, becaue they are eaily diipable, and need continual reparation; whence we ee all the enes fail in a woon, becaue the Heart recruits them not by a continuity of their generation: Beides, hould they remain after death, they would be unactive for want of fit dipoitions in the Organs. Moreover, natural caues act necearily when their object is preent; but ometime tis known, that Murderers have thrut themelves more diligently into the crowd of Spectators than any other perons, for avoiding upition, and no uch bleeding hath hapned in their preence; and that Executioners take Criminals the next day from the Gallows or the Wheel, and not a drop of Blood iues from their wounds. And why hould not a dead Sheep as well fall a bleeding afreh in the preence of the Butcher that kill'd it? Or a Man mortally wounded, when he that did it is brought unknown into his Chamber? For 'tis hard to imagine that we have les ene and knowledge whilt life remains than after death, that a wounded peron mut die that he may become enible. In hort, tis eaie to ee that this effect is not like other wonders which have a caue in Nature; becaue though we cannot aign the particular caues of thee, yet they are prov'd by ome demontrative, or at leat ome probable reaons. And as for Antipathy, it hould rather concenter all the dead peron's Blood in his Murderer's preence, and make it retire to the inward parts. Wherefore, I conclude, that not only the caues of this miracle are not yet found, but alo that 'tis impoible there hould be any natural one of it at all.

The Fourth aid, That according to the opinion of Avicenna, who holds, That the Imagination acts even beyond, and out of its Subject, this faculty may caue the effluxion of Blood; the Criminal's Phanie working mightily when the peron lain by him is objected before his Eyes; And the nitrous vapors ariing out of the Earth upon digging up the Body, together with the heat of the Air greater than that of the Earth, and increas'd by the conflux of Spectators, may in ome meaure contribute to the new fermentation of the Blood. But the truth is, after all our inquiries, this extraordinary motion cannot be better acrib'd elewhere, than to God's Providence, who ometimes performs this miracle for the dicovery of Murder, which would otherwie be unpuniht, but not always. And 'tis no les impiety to deny, that Divine Jutice comes ometimes to the aid of that of Men, than 'tis ignorance and ruticity to be atisfi'd in all caes with univeral caues, without recurring to particular ones; which God employes mot ordinarily for the Production of Effects, yet does not o tye his power to the neceity of their operations, but that he interrupts the ame when he pleaes, even o far as to give clay power to open the Eyes of the blind.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCIII. Of the nicorn.
div.p:
THere are no greater impotures in the Art of Phyick than thoe which relate to Antidotes and Preervatives from Poyon, uch as the Unicorn's Horn is held to be: And I am mitaken, if it be not a popular error. Firt, becaue the opinions of all Authors are o contrary concerning it. Philotratus in the life of Apollonius aith, that the Animal of this name is an As, and is found in the fenns of Colchis, having one ingle horn in the fore-head, where-with he fights furiously againt the Elephant. Cardan, after Pliny, aith 'tis a Hore, as 'tis mot commonly painted; only it hath a Stag's head, a Martin's kin, a hort neck, hort mane, and a cloven hoof, and is bred only in the Dearts of Aethiopia amongt the Serpents, whoe Poyon its horn which is three cubits long reits. Garius ab Horto aith, 'tis an Amphibious Animal, bred on Land near the Cape of good Hope, but delighting in the Sea, having an Hores head and mane, a horn two cubits long, which he alone of all Authors affirms to be moveable every way. Mot agree that it cannot be tam'd; and yet Lewis Vartoman aith, that he aw two tame ones in Cages at Mecha, which had been ent to Sultan Solyman. Almot all confes it very rare, and yet Marcus Sherer, a Renegado German, afterwards call'd Idaith Aga, and Embaador from the ame Solyman to Maximilian the Emperor, affirms that he aw whole troops of them in the Dearts of Arabia; And Paulus Venetus the ame in the Kingdom of Baman; where they are almot as big as Elephants, having feet like theirs, a kin like Camels, the head of a Boar, and delighting in mire like wine. Nor are Authors les various concerning its manner of eating; ome alledging, that being unable to feed on the ground by reaon of his horn, he lives only on the boughs and fruits of Trees, or on what is given him by the hands of Men, epecially of fair Virgins, of whom, they ay, he is amorous; though others think it fabulous. Some believe that there was once uch an Animal, but not now; the whole race perihing in the Deluge; and that the horns we find now, for the mot part in the earth, have been kept there ever ince. And if there be uch variety in the decription of this Animal, there is no les in the horns, which they tell us are thoe of the Unicorn. That at Saint Dennis in France, is about even foot high, weighs thirty pound four ounces, being wreath'd and terminated in a point from a broad bae. Yet this is not comparable to that Aelian mentions, which was o thick that cups might be made of it. That at Strasburg hath ome conformity with this of Saint Denis, but thoe of Venice differ from both, as that decrib'd by Albertus Magnus doth from all. For
'tis, aith he, olid like a Hearts horn, ten foot high, and very large at the bae. The Swies have one, which was ometimes found on the bank of a River near Bruges, two cubits long, yellow without, white within, odorous, and apt to take fire. That at Rome is but one foot high, having been diminih'd by being frequently rap'd in order to be imploy'd againt Poyon; 'tis alo mooth and hining like Ivory. Aldrovandus who writ a Treatie of this Subject, aith, he aw one o big at Niclabourg, that it reembled the rib of a Whale rather than a Horn. Becanus the Queen of Hungarie's Phyician, peaks of one at Antwerp even foot high, o fatned to the kull of the Animal, that it was bow'd backwards along the back bone, and could not erve to trouble the water for repelling its venenoity, (as Authors ay it doth) nor yet be of any defence, which is the ue of horns, except by bowing down the head between the fore-legs, as Bulls do in their fights. It was alo white; and yet Aelian aith, it mut be black: And Cteias, Phyician to King Artaxerxes, repreents it but one cubit high, purple towards the point, and black at the bae. Which variety makes ome believe, that all thee are the horns of Fihes, or Sea-monters, there being no Element uceptible of more varieties: Whereunto that Fih is to be referr'd which Albertus Magnus calls Monoceros, from its having one horn in the Fore-head; the opinion of thoe that think the Unicorn was the Rhinoceros. Pliny, after Cteias, affirms, that ome Oxen in India, have but one horn, and are not cloven hoof'd. Aelian and Oppian report the like of others in Aonia; and Caear of others in the Hercinian Foret; and Lewis Barthema, that he aw uch Cows in Aethiopia. In brief, as 'tis agreed that there are Animals with one Horn, o 'tis impoible to know which is that whereunto Antiquity gave the Appellation of Unicorn by way of excellence; which incertainty, thoe Kings and States that have them tetifie, by keeping them in their treaures for hew only, not for ue, and not making them into drinking veels, which (according to Aelian) retun'd the hurtfulnes of all Poyons. Add hereunto, that 'tis not credible the Romans who ubdu'd mot of the acceible world, and were very careful to delight their people with pectacles of the raret beats, would not have forgot to hew them Unicorns, if there had been any. But were there a Unicorn, I hould not eteem its virtues uch as they are decrib'd, being countenanc'd by the authority neither of Galen nor Hippocrates. So that Charles the Ninth's Phyician aid, he would have taken away the cutom of putting a piece of this horn into the King's Cup, but that it was good to leave an opinion of its virtue in the minds of the vulgar. Moreover, the marks given of it are like all the ret, equivocal, incredible, and ridiculous. For they ay, a true is dicern'd from a fale by the ebullition the true one caueth in water when cat thereinto; which nevertheles all porous Bodies do, as burnt bones, lime, brick, and uch other things wherein there are many
cavities. Others dicover it by giving ome of it in powder after a doe of Arenick to a Cock, or a little Dog; whom it will not only ecure, but almot revive when dead, and yet all that can be gather'd upon trial, is, that we ee thoe Animals that have taken this antidote, die more lowly than others. Which is uppos'd to happen by the atriction that all horn caueth in the mouth of the Stomack, and the other Veels, whence the exhalation of the Spirits is retarded. The trial of ome Empericks is yet more ridiculous; they boat, that if a Circle be decrib'd with a piece of this horn upon a Table, and an Adder or Spider laid in the middle of it, they can never come out of it; and, that thee Animals die, if only held a quarter of an hour under the hadow of this Horn. Some add, that this horn weats in the preence of poyon, which eems aburd: becaue in this cae the counter-poion uffers from the poyon, which conequently, mut be tronget and mot active of the two. In brief, thee numerous Contradictions, Impoibilities, and Incertainties make me conclude this Story of the Unicorn a meer Fiction.

The Second aid. If the Verity of things were haken by the fale conceits others have of them, there would be no Phyitians, becaue there are oftentimes ignorant ones; no point of Right, becaue many know it not; no true Deluge, becaue the Poets feign'd that of Deucalion and Pyrrha; no true Religion, becaue the Pagans and others have had fale ones. On the contrary, as the Romances, concerning Charlemagne, were built upon the truth of his admirable exploits, o 'tis credible, that the marvellous effects of the Unicorn's Horn have given both great and mall occaion to peak of it, and out of ignorance of the Truth to feign much more then the Truth concerning it. The objection taken from the verity of decriptions of the Unicorn, and from that which is oberv'd in everal Horns, (of about twenty whereof found in the treaures of Princes and States of Europe there are not two altogether alike) is not concluding; ince the ame may be aid of mot other Animals, who according to the diverity of Climats change their colour, and oftentimes hape too, yea, in one and the ame place, they differ according to their Ages. Moreover, the Error is very excuable in Authors that have treated of the Unicorn, in taking (as Aritotle doth) the Greek name Monoceros, and the Latin
nicornis, for a Noun Adjective applicable to every ort of Animals that have but one Horn, as many have not. Some indeed have confounded Rhinoceros with Monoceros through the reemblance of their cadence, which Rhinoceros the Romans had in their Spectacles or Shows, and is decrib'd by Martial o furious, that he threw a Bear up into the Air, as one would do a Ball: But it follows not, that they had no Unicorns in their Amphitheaters, becaue there is no mention made of any; an Argument drawn from Negative Authority not being demontrative:
and, granting it was unknown to them, it follows not thence that there is no uch thing in Nature; not only becaue they knew not the greatet part of the World, but alo, becaue this Animal is repreented o furious, that it cannot be taken alive; epecially in its perfect Age, being fierce even to thoe of its own Species of either Sex, and only accotable at the time of their Copulation. Philo after Aelian aith, That the Brachmans call it Cartazonon, that 'tis of the bignes of a Hore, of a bay colour, very nimble of body, epecially of the legs, though without joints; that it hath the tail of a Boar, one horn between the eyes, black, treak'd like a Snail, and ending in a very harp point, two cubits long; that it hath a hoare voice, is les furious towards other Beats, than to thoe of its own Species, with whom it fights inceantly, unles when they are at rut. There are alo ancient Medals repreenting this Animal putting his horn into a Cup; which 'tis thought were Alexander's. Aeneas Sylvius, and Paulus Venetus affirm, That Unicorns are found in the Mountains of India and Cathay; though the marks this latter give them, agree better to the Rhinoceros: But thee Authorities are not coniderable in repect of that of the H. Scripture, wherein 'tis aid, Deut. 28. His horns hall be like that of the nicorn: and Pal. 22. Deliver me, O God, from the Lion's mouth, thou hat heard me alo from among the horns of the nicorns: and Pal. 29. He maketh Lebanon and Sirion to kip like a young nicorn; and Pal. 92. My horns halt thou exalt like the horn of an nicorn; and Iaiah 34. The nicorns hall come down with them, and the bullocks with the bulls. Job alo peaks of it, chap. 39. Add to thee Authorities the experience and example of o many Kings and States, who would not think their treaure well furnih'd, unles they had an Unicorn's horn. For, the matter that makes teeth, being transferr'd to the generation of horns, and o further ublim'd; 'tis certain, that all Horns have an Alexiterical Vertue, by which they reit Feavers, cure Fluxes of the belly, kill Worms, and erve for many other Remedies to Man: but when this already great Vertue comes to be united into one ingle Chanel, as it happens in the Unicorn, the ame is mightily augmented. And 'tis too much detraction from the power of Nature, to deny uch Vertue to be found in inanimate Bodies, as in the Serpentine Tongues found in the Caves of Malta, ealed Earths, and Minerals, uch as thoe they call for that reaon nicornu minerale, not becaue taken from Unicorn's bury'd under ground ever ince the time of the Deluge, but becaue of their Reemblance in Vertues, Properties, and outward Figure: and indeed there is o much of this Mineral Unicorn's horn, and Mineral Ivory found, that 'tis not credible it ever belong'd to any Animal. Nor is this truth prejudic'd by [the] tricks of Impotors, who make counterfeit Unicorn's horns of Ivory, or other horns, or the bones, of Elephants, and other Animals kept for ome time under ground, whereby they acquire more olidity,
and ome tranparency, by means of the alt of the Earth, which ininuates thereinto, as it doth to Porcellane, which for that reaon is bury'd a whole Age: nor by the ebullition that ome other natural and artificial bodies caue, or by the weating of ome Stones upon the approach of poyon, which proceeds from the poyon's inpiating the Air, which thereupon ticks to the next olid body. Nor is the colour material; ince proces of time may alter it; beides that, the Ancients attribute blacknes only to the horns of the Indian As, and the Rhinoceros: And, as for the mell found in the Unicorn's horn in Suizzerland, 'tis an argument, that the ame is either adulterate, or a Mineral one; the texture of the horns being too cloe to evaporate any thing; and thoe that have ditill'd them by fires, find, that they abound with an inodorous Salt, and a tinking Sulphur. In hort, 'tis not credible, Clement VII. Paul III. and divers others, would have taken this Animal for their Arms, if there were no uch; nor do Popes o much want undertanding men, that Julius III. would have bought a fragment of it for 12000. crowns; whereof his Phyitian made ue uccesfully in the cure of Dieaes that had any thing of venenoity. Marilius Ficinus, Braavola, Matthiolus, Aloiius, Mundela, and many other Phyicians, recommend it in uch dieaes, epecially in the Petilence, the Biting of a mad Dog, Worms, Falling-icknes, and other uch hideous Maladies. To conclude, I conceive, that effects which depend upon occult Properties, as this doth, ought not to be rahly condemn'd; being mindful that our knowledg is limited, and therefore, the Authorities, Reaons, and Experiences, which etablih the Unicorn's horn, and its wonderful Effects are to be yielded to; only with exception to Impoture.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCIV. Of Satyrs.
div.p:
NOvelty and extraordinary things have uch power upon our Minds, that they not only render us attentive when they are preent, but remain longer imprinted in the Memory; as thoe, that teach the Art of Memory truly oberve. This oblig'd many Poets and Hitorians to peak of Hydra's, Chimaera's, Bailiks, Satyrs, Centaurs, and other uch Fictions. For thoe that have mot exactly examin'd the power of Nature, find the mixture of thee Species impoible, not only on the part of the Matter which is to receive the Soul, to which it is determin'd by a certain proportion, but alo in repect of the Form, which is indiviible, epecially the Rational Soul. To which purpoe the Poet Lucretius peaks very learnedly, and maintains, that there can be no Centaurs; and the reaon he alledges, holds as well againt
the poibility of Satyrs: Becaue, aith he, if this mixture of the humane and equine Nature had place, Hores being in their full trength at three years old, at which time children carce leave ucking the breats of their Nure, how is it poible this montrous Animal hould be in its tender age and full growth both together? And again, a Hore growing, when the Man enters into the prime of his youth, how can the one dye, when the other is in the tate of its greatet vigour? Now Goats live les time than Hores, and o there is les probability for an Animal compounded of the Nature of a Goat and a Man. Hence Pliny, in the eventh book of his Natural Hitory, aith, That a Hippocentaur being bred in Thealy, it dy'd the ame day, and was afterwards preerv'd in honey, which is an excellent bawm. Virgil places them at the entrance of Hell, becaue things againt Nature cannot ubit. And S. Hierom in the life of S. Paul, the Hermit, relating how a Centaur appeard to S. Anthony, doubts whether it were a true Centaur, or the Devil under that hape; and indeed eems to infer it an Evil Spirit, becaue it was driven away by the ign of the Cros. So that Satyrs are to be attributed only to the liberty Poets have ever taken, as well as Painters of daring and attempting every thing, without oberving the Rule Horace precribes them not to conjoyn Natures totally diagreeing and oppoite; for, by thee mixtures they intended only to repreent very nimble, lacivious, rutick, and perhaps abuive men; (whence came their Satyrick Poems.)

The econd aid, That 'tis as dangerous to conclude all impoible that we have not een, as to be credulous to every thing. But when Reaon, and the authority Experience carries with it, are of a ide, our incredulity, hath no excue. Now the cae of Satyrs is uch; for they may be as well produc'd by the mixture of the Seeds of two Species, as Mules are. Beides, were not the Imagination of Mothers capable of imprinting this as well as any other change of Figure in a Child's body, whereof we have daily examples; yet the wild uckling and coure of life ome Children may have had amongt Goats (as Romulus and Remus had from a Wolf) may in proces of time have begot ome reemblance of hape in them. As for Lucretius's Reaon, we ee that Plants are ingrafted into others, not only of the ame, but alo of a different Species, as the Apple-Cyon on a Colewort; which Plants being of different durations, the graft becomes of a middle duration between them, namely longer-liv'd then a Colewort, and horter then another Apple-tree. And S. Hierom is not poitive, that the Centaur, which appear'd to S. Anthony, was an illuion, but doubts whether it were a true Centaur uch as Antiquity poke of, or whether 'twas not the Devil appearing in that hape to frighten that holy Peron. And, Plato, in convivio apientum, relates, That a Shepheard having preented to Periander a Foal born of a Mare of his, that had the head, neck, and hands of a Man, the ret of an Hore;
and the voice of a Child, Diocles affirm'd, that this Prodigy preag'd Seditions and Diviions of Minds: But Thales reply'd, 'Twas a natural thing, and, for preventing the like again, advis'd him to have no other Hor-keepers but what were married. Pliny, likewie in the eventh Book of his Natural Hitory, aith, That in the Country of the Cratadulones, amongt the Indian Mountains, Satyrs are found; very wift Creatures, running ometimes on two feet, ometimes on four, and having the hape of a Man. And Plutarch tells in Sylla's life, That, as he return'd into Italy, a Satyr was brought to him like thoe decrib'd by ancient Authors, half-man, and half-goat; and being akt what he was, anwer'd nothing that reembled a humane voice, but with a tone mixt of that of Goats, and the neighing of Hores. Whereupon, Sylla, having compaion on him, appointed guards to carry him back. S. Hierom in the above-mention'd place decribes another Satyr, which, he aith, was of a middle tature, having a crooked Noe, horned front, and Goats feet, and brought Dates yet hanging on a Palm-branch, to S. Paul the Hermit. The Saint askt him what he was, and he anwer'd, that he was a Mortal, one of the Inhabitants of that Hermitage, whom the abued Pagans adore, for Fauns, Satyrs, and Incubes; and I come (aith he) as deputed to you from our Company, to deire you to pray for us to your and our God, whom we know to be come into the World, for the common Salvation. After which words, this light Animal took its coure and fled away. And let this Relation might eem trange, I hall add, That under Contantine, a living one was brought to Alexandria, and hewn there to the People; afterwards, being dead, it was called and carried to Antioch to be een by the Emperor. Pauanias records alo, That he was inform'd by one Euphemius, who, (he aith) was a man worthy of credit, how that ailing into Spain, he was driven by torm into certain Ilands full of avage Men, having hairy bodies, long tails, like thoe of Hores, and red hair; whom they could not keep off from them, but by blows; and a Woman being expos'd on the hore by the Mariners, thee Satyrs abus'd her with all outrages imaginable. So that to doubt of the exitence of Satyrs after o many Tetimonies, is, to acribe too much to our own enes, and too little to the witnes of the Ancients.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCV. Of the Phoenix.
div.p:
IF ever there were caue to admire the implicity and credulity of the Ancients, 'tis the tory of the Phoenix, which is feign'd a Bird that lives many ages, after which repairing to the City Heliopolis in Aegypt, it builds its net, or rather funeral pile, there of aromatick wood, which, by reaon of its high ituation being fir'd by the Sun-beams, he dyes, and immediately another aries out of her ahes; it being as impoible for Nature to be without a Phoenix, as the Phoenix to have a Companion. In which Relation the Hitorians have imitated the Poets, and choen rather to tell trange things than true. For, firt, this Nativity of this imaginary Bird is a manifet impoibility; becaue nothing is more abhorr'd by Nature than voluntary death, and that orderly Governes would rather have given the Phoenix a Female, as well as to all other Creatures, than have put her elf thus upon the neceity of a miracle. Nor can any thing be more contrary to the generation of Animals than ahes, which, are dry; drynes being altogether oppoite to life, and to the corruption which is antecedent to every generation. Next, its progres is equally aburd. For, they ay, this little Bird no ooner attains its jut bignes, (which is equal to that of an Eagle, having its head crited with divers colours, the neck gold-colour, the ret of the feathers purple aving that the tail is mixt of carlet and ky-colour) but it prepares it elf to pay the lat duties to the bones of its deceaed parent. (But how conitent is this with the Bird's being reduc'd to ahes?) Which bones he lays upon her back, and flyes from Aegypt with them to Arabia, where he places them upon an Altar dedicated to the Sun; upon which the ame Bird before her death had made an offering of the Neat, which was to be her fatal pile. After thee funerals it flies towards Heaven, where 'tis fed with dew, and the fumes of Incene and Amomum; and intead of drink, makes ue of the vapors which arie from the Sea, abhorring all kind of grain and food common to other Birds. According to Aelian, it lives five hundred years, according to others ix hundred, and according to others more, in places apart from the commerce of Men; but o highly reverenc'd by all other Birds, that they follow it with great repect and admiration, inomuch that Birds of rapine forget their prey, and others the fear of being taken. As many fictions as words, even if Lucretius's opinion be true, who admits not, that any ingle Animal can generate. Wherefore 'tis not without reaon, that to avoid rendring account of the many aburdities ariing from thee fale uppoitions, the Hitorians make it to be hid from our ight o many Ages; foreeeing that if there was
but one Woman found that had danc'd twice at Rome in the ecular Playes, there will be no witnees found to attet the nativity, life, and death of this Animal.

The Second aid, That we ought not to condemn the abent under pretext that they are unknown; for the Nativity of this Bird is defended by that of Barnacle, which is bred of the putrefaction of a Ship; and of another call'd Ephemeron, which by Aritotle's report, is produc'd of the leaf of a Tree near the River Hippanis. If the duration of its life be uncertain, o likewie is that of all Animals with which we convere not. And were the authority of Betonius upected, who confounds it with the Manucodrata, yet that of Tacitus in the fourteenth Book of his Animals is authentick. P. Fabius, and L. Vitellus, (aith he) being Conuls. the Bird call'd a Phoenix after many Ages appear'd in Aegypt, and gave occaion to many Greeks and other peronages of the Country to dicoure of the miracle; concerning which they relate many doubtful things, but worthy to be known. They ay, this Animal is devoted to the Sun, and that its beak and variety of plumes, is wholly different from other Animals. Mot affirm, that it lives five hundred years; others, that it attains to one thouand four hundred ixty one: and that the firt were een under Seotris and Amais, Kings of Aegypt; next, under Ptolomy, who reign'd the third of the Macedonians. It came then into the City of Heliopolis, accompany'd with a great number of other Birds, who eem'd as well as Men amaz'd at the new pectacle. But becaue (aith he) there were but two thouand five hundred years from Ptolomy to Tiberius, under whom this appear'd; this made ome doubt it was not the true Phoenix, and came not from Arabia, whence it ought not to come till its life were near an end, to build its neat in Egypt; wherein he leavs a genital virtue whereby his Succeor is produc'd, who as oon as come to full vigor, prepares to pay the funeral duty to its parent; which it doth not, lightly, but after it hath try'd by carrying an equal weight of Myrrh, whether it be able to carry that of its parent's bones. However, aith he, 'tis a certain thing that this Bird is een ometimes in Aegypt. And, indeed, its exitence is prov'd by the Authority of Orus Apollo in his Hieroglyphicks; Manilius, Pliny, Ovid, Athenaeus, Albertus Magnus, yea, by the publick voice which ues this word, to ignifie a rare thing, and ingular in its Species: Which were not much indeed, if Lactantius, Tertullian, and many other Fathers had not often employ'd it to convince the Pagans who quetion'd the Reurrection. Moreover, Aelian in his Hitory of Animals, preuppoing this too well known to be particularly decrib'd, only blames the broking Miers of his time, who prefer their affairs before the wonder of this Bird, which is o well kill'd in calculation, that it fails not to repair to its fatal neat at the prefixt time. In hort, we may doubt of ome circumtances, but not of the truth of its exitence; its renovation is prov'd poible
from the re-animation of a drown'd fly by the Sun; and ince hard to give a atisfactory account of common generations, we may therefore forbear to reject this, which, though extraordinary, may yet be maintain'd by Chymits, who lay the foundation of generation in Salt, the ole permanent principle, and not volatile as the two other are.

The Third aid, That the Fathers in uing Comparions from this Bird, had regard to the common belief, as God accommodates himelf to the Language of Men, attributing Paions to himelf, though he hath none. And for the Authors that peak of it, 'tis always upon the credit of others. Even Herodotus and Pliny, the firt whereof, (if you will believe him) aw almot every thing however trange and unheard of; and the econd affirms almot every thing; (o far as to ay, that certain Birds lay their Eggs in a Hare's kin, which they afterwards hang upon a Tree; and that others carry theirs upon a tick lay'd over the houlders of two; beides infinite other things no les incredible and ridiculous) yet peak but doubtfully of this Bird. So that we have great reaon to do the like, yea, to eteem it a Fiction.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCVI. Of Senitive Plants.
div.p:
SEne and Motion are in ome ort oberv'd in all Plants, which incline towards the Sun and Light, and attract their aliment at ditance; particularly, the Vine, which eems to act with choice, twining about the next Tree that may upport it, not once, as might be by chance, but twice or thrice. But with much more reaon may we attribute Sene to the Helitropium and Marygold; as alo to Tulips, which hut up themelves at night, and open again in the day. Pliny attributes a yet more admirable property to the Lotus, aying, that it inks and hides it elf totally at night in the River Euphrates near which it grows, o that 'tis not to be reach'd by one's hand, then ries out of the water again at Sun-rie; and that, in places where it grows remote from water, in the Evening it wraps up its Flower and Fruit in its leavs, and dicovers them afreh next Morning. The Tree call'd Arbor Tritis, eems alo to have much Sene, its leavs reemble thoe of the Sloe-Tree; its Flowers open at night, and in the day are all languid, though of o good a mell, that the Inhabitants of Malaca, and Goa in the Eat-Indies, ditill an odoriferous water from them, and make ue of their red talks to colour meats, as the Europaeans do of Saffron. So likewie do thoe Trees of the Ilands Hebrides, the wood whereof being rotted in the Sea is
turn'd into Birds like our Ducks; and that mention'd by Ruellius, l. 12. ch. 38. of his Hitory of Plants, which bears Cockles, of which Birds are produc'd; and thoe aid by Munter in his Comography, to grow in Vomonia near Scotland towards the North, whoe Fruit falling into the water is turn'd into a Bird, call'd a Tree-Bird. Guadaguigna, an Italian Author, affirms the like of the leavs of another Tree. Add to thee thoe which Cardan aith, grow on the bank of a River in Ireland, of whoe leavs thoe that fall into the water become Fihes, and thoe that fall upon the land Birds; as alo thoe which Pigafetta aith, he aw in the Iland of Cimbubon, near Borneo in Oriental Aia, which falling to the Earth, walk'd upon four harp and hort feet, whereof he kept one eight dayes, which mov'd when it was touch'd, and liv'd, in his judgement, of Air alone. Of this ort are likewie all Sea Vegetables, uch as the Sea-Star, Sea-Nettle, Oyters, which have a very dull Sene, are immoveable, and oftentimes fatned to the Rocks, and from the midt of whoe hells ometimes prings a hrub call'd Sea-Oak, which grows alo upon tones and potheards, having no root but a thick purple leaf, as Pliny and Theophratus witnes. But all this is nothing in comparion of what Scaliger aith of the Scythian Lamb, nam'd Borrametz. They affirm, that in Zalvolha a part of Tartary, the Inhabitants ow a grain like Melon-eed, aving that 'tis not quite o long; from which iues a Plant about five pans high, having the feet, hoofs, ears, and whole head of a Lamb, (aving the Horns, which are repreented by one tuft of Hair) and being cover'd with a hairy thin kin; its fleh is very weet, and like that of Crevihes; and which is more trange, it bleeds when it is wounded, and is much deir'd by Wolves, but not by other Animals that live on fleh. It adheres to the Earth by the Navil, and cannot live unles gras be own about it; which withering, or being purpoely detroy'd, the Plant dyes: Which Plant-Animal, Sigimond Liber, a Pole, aith, is alo call'd Smarcandeos by the Muulmans, who wear the kin of it upon their breats and haven heads for warmth. And there are een at this day in the King of France's Garden in the Fauxbourg of S. Victor at Paris, three orts of Plants, to which cannot be deny'd the name of Senitive, ince being toucht, they flag their leavs, one ooner, another more lowly, and the third very leiurely; which leavs return to their place after the Sun hath warm'd them again with his rayes, Garias ab Horto peaks as much of certain anonymous Plants growing in the Province of Malabar, which as oon as they are toucht, hrink and contract their branches by a motion contrary to the former; and he adds, that their leavs reemble thoe of Polypody, and the Flowers are yellow. Theophratus in Book 4. Chap. 3. of his Hitory of Plants, attributes the ame faculty to a Spinous Plant like Fearn, (according to Gaza's Tranlation) or Feathers, (according to that of Pliny) the leavs or boughs of which Plant being toucht, become arid and languid,
cloe, and compres themelves, and after ome time turn green again, and reume their firt vigor: He aith, This Plant grows at Grand Cairo, and is o big that three men can carce fathom it. Apollodorus, the Diciple of Democritus, acribes the like virtue to an Herb which he calls Aechinomene, or Chat-Herb, becaue it huns the hand of any that offers to touch it, hrinking its leavs up into an heap. Pliny peaks of another in the Ilands of the Troglodites like Coral, call'd Charito-Blepharon, which eems to be enible of the approach of him that comes to cut it, becomming then as hard as horn; and, if he wait ome time, like a tone. The Portugals tell in their Navigations of an Herb that grows with mall roots in hot and moit places, putting forth eight little branches two fingers long, furniht with leavs on each ide, as green as Tamarisk, but reembling thoe of Polypody. From the middle of the roots arie four mall talks, each of which bears a yellow Flower like that of Cloves, but without mell; which being never o little toucht, languih and flag, but reume their firt vigor upon the removal of the hand. Of which Marvail, a Philoopher of Malabar being unable to find the caue, became a fool. Monardes a Phyician of Sevil, having decrib'd a ort of Barly in new Spain, call'd Gayatene, or Cevadilla, (wich falls flat as oon as it is toucht) makes mention of another Species of the ame Herb, which lying pread upon the ground, upon touching, folds it elf like criped Colewort. Latly, Nicolas Conti ays, that in the Eat-Indies between the Cities of Binagar and Malepur, there grows a Tree without Fruit three yards high, call'd Arbor Pudica, which retracts its branches when any Man or Beat approaches it. By all which Relations, it is manifet that there are Senitive Plants.

The Second aid, That ince 'tis not poible to imagine Senitive Life without Organs, thee motions mut not be attributed to Sene, but to other Caues; as to the attractive heat which is in all Plants, which makes them fold up themelves according to the figure of the Body near which they are. Some Animals, as Oyters, have indeed a more imperceptible degree of Sene, yet are not they therefore Plants; thoe whereof that have any local motion, have it, perhaps, from the concuion of the Earth caus'd by the approaching peron, or from the tirring of the Air; which though imperceptible, drives along the Ignis Fatuus: And, perhaps, thee Flowers and Herbs are of a very rare and ubtle texture. Unles you had rather recurr to the Antipathy which is found between thee Plants and Man, which caues the kin and fiddle-trings made of Sheeps guts, to break at the noie and ound made by thoe of a Wolf, with which they will never be brought to be harmonious. For this is a better way than to multiply Species without neceity, as they do who etablih a middle Nature between a Plant and an Animal. And as for thoe which remove from one place to another, they may, perhaps, find the ame account of them upon inquiry that Aeneas
Sylvius did, who (as he aith in his Decription of Europe, Chap. 46.) aking James VI. King of Scotland, touching thoe Tree-Birds reported to be bred there, learnt from the mouth of that learned King, that thoe famous Trees grew not there but in the Orcades. Whereupon Aeneas truly and handomely reply'd, Miracula fugiunt.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCVII. Of the Bezoar.
div.p:
THis word ome think is deriv'd from the Hebrew Bel, which ignifies King, and zaars Poyons, as if it were the King or Mater of Poyons, which are ubdu'd more powerfully by this than any other remedy. According to Scaliger, Bezohard is taken by the Arabians for that which preerves life, and o the Stone will have borrow'd its name from its effect. Cardan aith, there is a poyonous root of this name, which bears a fruit call'd Niraebri, which is an Antidote to it. This tone is divided into Natural and Artificial. The Natural is of two orts, viz. Animal and Mineral; yea, Plants and every thing good againt Poyons is commonly term'd Bezoardical, But the Name primarily belongs to a tone found in an Animal, called by the Perians Paan, or Paar; which Animal, Monardes aith, is of the bignes, and almot of the hape of a Stag, having two Horns large at the bae, pointed at the top, and bowed over the back like thoe of a Goat, which it reembles in the feet, and omething too in the form: Whence ome term it Trag-elaphos, i. e. a Goat-Deer, though this be a different Animal, having hort Hair, and a kin between grey and red, and ometimes of other colours. The Indians take them in nets for the tone's ake, which they ell to Merchants. For though the Beat is o furious that it breaks any other link but thoe of Iron, yet the price of this tone is o great that it makes the danger depicable. He adds, that it is o nimble that it cats it elf down from an high Rock, and lights upon its horns without any hurt; and that its pace is leaping and bounding like a football. All agree not in what part of the Animal the tone grows. The Arabians write, that this and all other orts of Deer finding themelves old and ick, by their breath draw Serpents out of their holes and devour them, that o thereby they become young and well again; after which finding themelves heated by this food, they run into the water, and tay there without drinking till their heat be over; during which tay in the water, this tone is bred in the corners of their Eyes, whence it is taken for the ues aboveaid. But Monardes more probably learnt from the Inhabitants of the Mountains of China, that in the Indies near the River Ganges, thee Goat-Deer after their eating of Serpents
go about the tops of the Mountains feeding on uch Herbs as Nature hath taught them reit Poyons; of the quinteence whereof mix'd with that of the Poyons, the Bezoar is by ome particular virtue produc'd in ome cavity of their Bodies; Garias ab Horto, and Acota ay, in their tomack; particularly in that reduplication by which they ruminate: others, as Fragous, in the kidneys, becaue ome tones have the figure of that part, which alo is the mot lapidifick of the whole Body; and others too, as Rabbi Moes the Aegyptian, in the Gall; which opinion Monardes himelf is of though he admits too that it is found in the Ventricle, Intetines, and other cavities of the Body: As, indeed, there is no place in the Bodies of Animals, but tones may be generated in them. However, 'tis univerally acknowledg'd o ueful, that the hunters are exprely commanded to carry them all to the King, who buyes them at a great rate, and they are not tranported elewhere but clandetinely. Amatus Luitanus aith, that one of the richet Preents which Cochain King of the place ent in his time to the King of Portugal, was one of thee tones, a little bigger than a Hazle-nut; of which having oberv'd the great effects, he procur'd others to be brought from that Country. Thee effects are the curing of Petilential Fevers, the Leproie, Small Pox, Epilepie, Worms in Children, bitings of venomous Beats, and generally againt all Poyon; particularly, 'tis very proper for faintings, — and other effects of Melancholy. Whence 'tis us'd in Quartan; Agues to appeae the Symptoms thereof, and Charles V. took it often; yea, 'tis oberv'd in ome Hopitals, that the bare powder of this tone temper'd in water, communicates its virtue thereunto, o that it hath cur'd the Purples and other Epidemical Maladies.

The Second aid, That uch as deign'd to get themelves Reputation in Phyick, finding many Dieaes unconquerable by common Remedies, that they might not remain idle, and uffer the defect of curing incurable, and rebellious Maladies to be imputed either to their Art or their Ignorance, have had recoure to the Foxe's kin, propoing the ue of Remedies o rare and hard to find, that their Impoture might not be dicover'd. Hence, ome have o highly extoll'd precious Stones and Gold, which not fifty years ago the poor were perwaded, cur'd them by being boil'd in Retoratives, though the rich, who made ue of the traud, found their gold Chains as heavy afterwards as before, (in cae they lookt well to them, in the boiling) and conequently, that no Vertue was deriv'd from them. Of this kind is the Bezoar-tone: touching the Original whereof we ee how Authors differ, and a few moneths ago an Animal was hewn in this City very different from that above-decrib'd, which they term'd Pucos, and affirmed to be that which bred the Bezoar. Beides, the difficulty of dicerning the true Stone from fale, which probably are the mot numerous, mut needs render the ue of it upicious; ince even in the time of Serap on it was
old falifi'd, which, he aith, was unprofitable, but I think rather michievous. And Cluius complains, That the Merchants of Lisbon would not uffer the uual trial to be made for ditinguihing the true from the adulterate. Neither do Authors agree about thoe trials; ome accounting it a ign of Goodnes, if the Stone hath nothing but a little dut in the Center; whereas the falifi'd (ay they) have ome Seed, or other olid body there, upon which the other Materials were uperinduc'd: others think, the right hath always a traw in the middle. Wherein we may oberve, that the everal cales or folds it hath one over another, like thoe of an Onion, or the Stone of a man's Bladder, which are made by new appoition of matter, agree not with the above-mentioned manner of its being made all at once. But in whatever manner and place it be produc'd, I think it can act only by its manifet Qualities which alone are active; the Effects of occult Qualities being as hidden as themelves. Beides, how could thee Treaures and Preents of Kings to be o common at this day, in all Shops, if they had uch great Vertues too as are attributed to them. Wherefore 'tis mot likely, that the Avarice of Men hath added this to other popular Errors.

The Third aid, That as no Sect is more eaie than the Pyrrhonian or Sceptick, which doubts of every thing; o 'tis a very obvious Invention for uch as are willing to decline inquiring into that vat treaure of Remedies, which are dipers'd from the Concave of the Moon to the Center of the Earth, and into the trials which may be made by their almot infinite preparations and mixtures, to reject all upon pretext of Incertainty in Philoophical accounts. But though the hortet, I doubt whether it be the bet way; ince Experience hews us many Effects which depend not upon Qualities; and, they that decry the Bezoar, becaue it acts not by manifet Qualities, admit others which do as little, viz. Elective Purgers, Splenetical, Hyterical, and other appropriate Remedies, though in ome caes even of a contrary temper to the parts they are apply'd to. Which error happens, from our always making Qualities Caues; whereas oftentimes they are Effects. Beides, 'tis great pride to deny whatever we undertand not; ince the mot knowing agree that they ee only through a cloud, and the chief effect of Beatitude will be, To be ignorant of nothing. And why hould the faculties of Antidotes depend more upon firt Qualities than thoe of poyons do? ince they ought to be contraries, and contraries are under the ame Genus. Wherefore it ufficeth to recur to Authority and Experiment. Indeed Hippocrates and Galen knew not Bezoar; yet neither do wee reject Sena which they knew not, and which is one of the commonet and bet Medicaments we have. But all the Arabian Phyicians concurr in this point, and Serapion particularly affirms, that this Stone is a potent Antidote againt all poyon in the bitings of venemous Beats; and o efficacious, that not only three or four grains of
it held in the mouth, enervate poyons; but the powder apply'd to a venemous Animal, tupefies it, and takes away its power of hurting; o that ome parts already begun to corrupt by their biting, have preently been retor'd to their firt etate by its ingle application. Avicenna, in the fourth Chapter of his econd Canon ranks it with Treacle, amongt Alexipharmacal Remedies which preerve health, and trengthen the Spirits. Rhais, in his Continent, affirms, That he found more admirable Faculties in Bezoar, than in all other Antidotes; and in his book to Almanor, he aith, That Remedies for reiting poyon, that aault the heart, and offend by their whole ubtance, are in vain prepar'd, if Bezoar be left out; which alone, he aith, reits the poyon of Napellus or Monks-hood the mot pernicious of all. Avenzoar, in his Theyer, writes, that a man given over for dead upon taking of poyon, was cur'd by three grains of Bezoar. Peter de Abano (call'd the Conciliator) affirms, That Edward I. King of England, being wounded with a poyon'd word in the war againt the Sultan, and ready to expire, was cur'd by ome of this tone given him by the General of the Templars: and that the bare wearing it reits poyon. Monardes affirms, That with this Stone in les than a quarter of an hour he cur'd a certain Licentiate, whoe body was already all well'd by having once drunk, and another time eaten poyon; and that a poyon'd Maid, after the ueles tryal of all other Counterpoyons, was preently cur'd by this. The ame Author produces a great number of Syncopes, Petilential Feavers, Vertigoes, Epilepies, and other Dieaes cur'd by this Remedy; which is the more excellent in that it is inipid and void of all the bad tate which accompanies mot other Remedies. Thee Examples are further authoris'd by the publick voice, which cannot be eaily outweigh'd by the few perons that undertake to bid defiance to Antiquity, and to accue it of ignorance or fraud, though it be not wholly detitute of Reaon. For ince 'tis granted, that Viper's fleh is neceary in Treacle to render the ame efficacious againt the bitings of that Animal, (it being neceary, that omething intervene of a middle nature between ours, and that of the Viper, as its fleh, is being void of venom, but uceptible of it) why hould it be deny'd, that Bezoar which is produc'd of omething that hath poyon, and omething that reits it, may erve for a medium to ubdue the ame in our bodies. The objections to the contrary are either general or particular. The former concern only Mountebanks, who are left to anwer them; it being incredible that a good man, much les a Chritian, would deceive in a matter o important as Life; which yet may be as often indanger'd by rejecting good remedies upon vain Argumentations, (to ay no wore) as by precribing thoe that are unprofitable. The Objection againt Gold and precious tones makes as much againt the Confection de Hyacinthis, and others, whereof they are ingredients; but they that
have well conider'd thoe rich Bodies, find virtues to iue from them which impair not their weight; as is oberv'd in Quickilver, the decoction whereof kills worms, though its weight remain the ame; and in the Regulus of Antimony, a cup whereof renders liquors purgative in infinitum, without any diminution of its ubtance. As for the diverity of Opinions touching the generation of this Stone, this difficulty is found almot in all forreign remedies; and though 'tis not known, Whence Amber comes? yet we find its perfume excellent, and its ue profitable in Phyick. Nor is Adulteration proper only to Bezoar tones, but common to Balm, Civet, Storax, Rhubarb, and, in a word, to all other remedies; and the abue ought not to prejudice the ue, ince the ame Authors that have oberv'd thee impotures, teach us alo to avoid them. Cluius makes tryal of them, by paing a poyon'd thread through a Dog's Leg, and when the Symptoms of the Poyon have made him fall down as dead, if upon taking a little of the powder of this Stone, he revives, 'tis right; if not, 'tis falifi'd. Monardes's tryal is by breaking the tone, which ought to appear made of everal films thicker or thinner according to its bignes, which is commonly equal to that of an Olive, and almot of the ame colour, though ome are found to weigh two ounces, and the bigget are the bet; but the Surfaces mut be all mooth, the inward more than the outward, in the middle of which is a powder of more efficacy than the outide, or a traw or little piece of dry'd Herb, not a eed as there is in the fictitious; thoe that are vers'd therein know how to avoid being abus'd, and adjudge the Oriental better than the Occidental, which are darker and weaker. It matters not as to the truth of the effect, in what manner this tone is generated; though 'tis not impoible for everal Tunicles to be produc'd together, as thoe of the Onyon are. In fine, uch may the rarity of Bezoar have ometimes been, that only great perons made ue of it; but its admirable effects have made men curious to procure tore of them, which they may the more eaily do even by their means who decry them, the Apothecaries thereby having always ome left in their hops.

The Fourth aid, That in order to know well the benefits of Bezoar, 'tis requiite firt to be agreed What it is; which point is not yet determin'd. Scribonius Largus conceives it the hardned tear of a Stag a hundred years old: Others, think it a Mineral; others, a tone bred in an Animal, o contrary to Nature that the Animal that breeds it is exceedingly tormented with it, epecially if be big; which the hunters gues by eeing them go with pain, as Men do that have the tone in the Bladder. Yea, 'tis not agreed in what part of the Body 'tis found, though this indication be neceary towards the dicovery of its virtue; ince tones found in the Gall are of another Nature and Properties, than thoe of the Reins or Bladder. Moreover, the colour of thee tones is extreamly various, not to mention the difference
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
which proceeds from that of Climates; the Occidental being almot without virtue in comparion of the Oriental. Whence it follows, that no certain unquetionable property can be aign'd to this tone as to other Remedies, which act always in the ame manner; otherwie there would be no Science. But hould the Bezoar have an Alexipharmacal Virtue, yet it could be but like that of other Bodies, which act proportionally to their bulk. Now what proportion is there between three grains of an inipid powder which caues no evacuation, or other enible action; and a mortal poyon, whoe cruel Symptoms dicover themelves as peedily as fire doth when put to matter uceptible of combution? And I appeal to the tetimony of all thoe that have made ue of it in our Age, whether they ever found the effects that are attributed to it. Whence it follows, that it is doubly to be rejected; Firt, becaue 'tis of great cot to the Patient; Secondly, it takes up the place of ome other good Remedy, cauing los of time which might otherwie be profitably employ'd in relieving the ick.

The Fifth aid, That Poyons and Epidemical Dieaes hurt not by their manifet qualities, nor by the quantity of their matter; as appears in the biting of a Scorpion, which cats forth an imperceptible quantity of venom. And therefore 'tis not to be expected that their Remedies hould act either by uch qualities, or by their quantity. Nor are we to doubt of the effect of Bezoar, under pretext that 'tis given in few grains, though ome have given twenty and thirty grains; and that the ordinary doe is about nine or ten grains. Neither is it material whether it be the tone of the kidneys of a Goat, Deer, or the tear of a Deer, provided it have the Virtues acrib'd to it, which is no more incredible than that which Scaliger affirms, himelf try'd in the Stag's tear, which, he aith, o melts Men's Bodies that are either poyon'd or infected with the Petilence, that they eem turn'd all into water, and thereby are cur'd. To which Experience, there are few well employ'd Phyicians but can add many more. Nor is any thing aid againt Bezoar, but what may be objected againt all other Antidotes, as Sealed Earth, Unicorn's Horn, and all Cordial Remedies, whoe Virtue may as well be quetion'd as that of Bezoar.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCVIII. Whence proceeds the udden Death of Men and Animals upon decending into certain Pits.
div.p:
ON the ixteenth of June lat, an Inhabitant of the Town of Tilliers, two Leagues from Virruel, perceiv'd a goodly Pigeon, which he took to be one of his own, fall down into a Well hard by his Houe; whereupon he call'd his Son, and, to draw it out, they let down a baket with a rope to the bottom of the Well, into which the Pigeon preently entred; but as oft as they lifted it up from the water, it fell back again thereunto: After their deign had fail'd, the Son tyes a cudgel to the rope, and being let down by his Father, endeavors to take the Pigeon. The Father ak'd him, Whether he had her? He anwer'd thrice, No; and after ome ighs falls, having lot both Speech and Life. The Father troubl'd at o trange an accident, reolves to go down himelf, and accordingly without any help decends into the Well, where he remain'd as his Son. The Neighborhood advertied of this dyater repair'd thither, and, amongt others, one who had not long before cat the Well; He acribing all to the weaknes of thoe who were dead, preently betakes himelf to go down; but he was carce come within two foot of the water but he fell down dead without making any complaint. A trong and vigorous young Man upon the belief that the company conceiv'd that thoe perons were not dead, but only needed help, undertakes to go down likewie; he did o, but uddenly fell backwards with a little Convulive Motion which made him cat up his head. Hereupon, notwithtanding the diwaions of the Curate of the place, who began to upect ome mortiferous caues of this effect, a fifth decended after he had caus'd the rope to be fatned to his middle; he was no ooner in the middle of the Well but he was pull'd up again upon the Getures which he made, with a livid Countenance, and other ignes fore-runners of Death, which he ecap'd by being preently uccoured with Wine and Aqua Vitae. Being recover'd, he affirm'd that he had perceiv'd no hurt but only a certain faintnes upon him. This lat attempt cool'd all aitance, o that there was no more talk of going down, but only of getting the Bodies up; which was done: and 'twas oberv'd that none of them had any ignes of Life aving the Son, in whom were een ome mall tokens which preently vanih'd. The wonderment of all this was greatly increas'd, when a Gentleman of the Country, curious of eeing what was reported, let down a Dog, who continu'd there a quarter of an hour, and was pull'd up again afe and ound. This Well twenty five foot deep, and of water but two, is inclos'd with a very ancient Wall at the foot of a good
high Hill, whereon tands the Catle of Tilliers: And which help'd not to diminih the wonder, it had been cleaned by two men who found no hurt, nor any thing extraordinary in it, aving an odour tronger than elewhere; the water being as clear as that of the Spring, and without any ediment. Now if it was mineral and malignant vapors that uffocated thoe that decended, the ame might have done the like upon thoe that firt gave them vent.

The Second aid, That this Effect cannot be attributed to vapors barely venomous, and of the nature of ordinary Poyons, which corrupt our humours, ometimes after Applications, as the Plague and other Epidemical Dieaes do; but this team is o oppoite to Life, that it detroyes the ame in an intant; which we cannot imagine to proceed from any other caue but a mineral, which is far more active. The ecape of thoe that cleans'd the Well, may be attributed to the mud which meared the ides of the Well, and o kept the vapor in; till growing tronger by that retraint, it made way for its elf through that remaning crut, and produc'd the above-mention'd dimal effects; emitting its Poyon in a trait line, according to the rectitude of the Well, which weakned the Pigeon in uch ort, that it was unable to rie again; as 'tis reported that Birds fall down as they fly over the Mare Mortuum, or Lake of Sodom, in Judea.

The Third aid, 'Tis not probable that any uch limy crut hindred this Effect at firt, ince the Dog let down afterwards found no hurt; unles you think a new crut aroe in that little time which pas'd between the death of the Men, and the decent of the Dog. This Effect therefore may probably be attributed to the Archaeus, or Central Fire, that Motor of Nature, which dries all the vapors of the Elements from the Centre to the Circumference, ubliming the principals of minerals, in order to make its Productions; and as the everal mixtures of thee elevated vapors are in ome places wholome, to wit, in Bathes and mineral waters; o there are others detructive of our Nature. But becaue uch elevation is not continual, but only at certain times, according to the motion of that grand Motor, and, particularly, of the Sun; hence Arenical vapors have produc'd uch Effects at one time, and tifled thoe that decended into a Well filled with them, which they have not done to thoe that clean'd it, nor to the Dog; in as much as thoe vapors were not rais'd at this time. And, perhaps, thee mineral vapors are not always ublim'd in uch a degree as to be mortiferous; otherwie it would follow that none could ever labor in mines with afety, by reaon of deadly fumes.

The Fourth aid, That uch expellations could not extinguih the Fire of Life in o hort a time, without ome fore-running ignes. But 'tis more probable, that this Effect proceeds from ome venomous Animal infecting the Air, which being confin'd in a place incapable of evaporation, and uckt by thoe that
decend down the Well, they can no more ave themelves from Death, than in a petilent Air. Nor are they Fables which Hitory records of certain Grottoes, in which Bailiks and Serpents reiding, infected not only the place, but alo the whole Country; as Philotratus relates in the Life of Apollonins, how a Dragon carry'd the Plague into all places where-ever he went. Now as to the particulars of the Story, what is difficult in them I thus reolve. Thoe that cleans'd the Well open'd the paage to the Bailik, who by degrees creeping forth out of his hole into the Well, there darted forth his mortal rays upon what-ever was preented to his Eyes; which done, he retir'd into his hole again; o that the Dog let down into the Well after the Bailik's retirement, could not be hurt: For that the pirits iuing out of the Eyes of this mortiferous creature, are harmles to dogs, and deadly to Men, is not warranted by any Example; Antiquity, whoe Judgement is venerable even in doubtful things, allowing this Beat capable of doing michief only in the place where he reides.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCIX. Whether a Dead Body can be preerv'd naturally many years.
div.p:
THis Quetion is divided in two points; Firt, Whether a dead Body can be kept without art; Secondly, Whether it can be o by art; Nature being here oppos'd not to Art, but to what is upernatural. The firt is hard, every Carkae having in it elf the principles of Coruption; becaue the harmony of qualities which caus'd to ubit being diolv'd, it advances of it elf to an annihillation: And Nature hould ceae her continual motion, if her ubject depriv'd of animal life hould always remain in one and the ame tate. Yea, if Nature hould top her coure in dead Bodies, and not be able to reolve them into other works, the Influences of the Heavens would be ueles in repect of them, as alo their motion, which is in order to generations, which would ceae if there were no more corruption; whence the detruction of the Univere in its parts would follow. Nor would the Elements act any more one againt another, remaining pure and imple, and incapable of any generation, ince iccity could no more act upon humidity, nor heat upon cold. It remains to enquire, Whether a dead Body may be preerv'd by art; which eems poible, becaue we may by art detroy the activity of the Elements, and reduce them to a jut and equal temperament capable of long preervation. For if impurities and uperfluities lead mixt Bodies to Corruption, 'tis eaie to eparate them by Chymitry; otherwie this art would be incapable of reducing them as it doth every day to a jut Temperament: Yea, if we conider
the Principles of Preervation, it will appear, that thoe of Art are more powerful than thoe of Nature, in regard of the means and Intruments it employs to eparate them which Nature cannot do, becaue She mixes things without choice and depu • ation: and conequently, ince Art hath o much power in o many Agen • s, 'tis poible to preerve a dead body for many years. Moreover, our own Experience and that of Antiquity teach us, that Balms are able to preerve bodies a long time; as appears in the Mummies of Aegypt, and in ome Embryo's, which • re preerv'd long in pirit of Salt, and other Liquors repugnant <…> .

The econd aid, That a dead body may be preerved long, not only by <> , but alo naturally as that of a Lady deceaed fifty ix years ago, which was found lately intire, and gave occaion • o this Conference; Whence it may be preum'd, That Women are not o eaily corruptible, becaue their bodies are made of fleh more elaborate then that of man, which was immediately taken from the dut, and conequently is more prone to return into its firt Original. Now the way to preerve dead bodies from corruption, is, to prevent the diolution of their parts; which is done by maintaining the connexion of humidity with drines; to which end all extrinical heat and moiture mut be kept from them as much as poible. Hence it is, that dead bodies are plac'd in ubterraneous places, and incloed in leaden Coffins, to the end, the cold and dry vapours ymbolizing with the qualities of Saturn, (which the Chymits make as jutly preervative as the Poets make it detructive) may withtand extrinecal heat and moiture, and maintain the marriage of <> with humidity; which is alo the cope of the Gums and Spices we employ to imbalm bodies; which having ome heat with a certain Unctuounes uck up the uperfluous moiture, and preerve the Natural. Moreover, the Sex, Age, and Temperament, are coniderable in this matter. A Habit of body moderately flehy, (which Galen accounts the mot laudable, and which denotes a good Contitution) is fittet for this purpoe; and 'tis probable, that the bodies of thoe that die of a udden death, reit putrefaction longer than thoe that have been extenuated by a longer Sicknes, or brought to the Grave by a Feaver; becaue in thee caes the body is in a great tendency to putrefaction even before Death.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCX. Of the Remora.
div.p: TIs a mall Fih, half a foot long, called by the Greeks, Echeneïs, and, by the Latins, Remora; becaue 'tis thought to top the motion of Ships, by means of two cales wherewith it cloely imbraces the keel. This common belief is founded upon many experiences reported by Authors, worthy of Credit. Pliny writes, That Periander, having ent a Ship to Gnidos, with orders to catrate all the principal Children of that Iland, it was topp'd in the main ea o long time as was requiite to end for other Orders contrary to the former by another Ship; and that in remembrance of this happy retardment, the two cales of this little fih were in his time een hanging up near the Altar of Gnidia and Venus. The like happen'd to a Pretorian Ship of Anthony at the battel of Actium, o that he could not advance to give Orders to his Naval Army. The Emperor Caligula, having et ail from Asturia, with a Gally of five banks, was likewie contrain'd to tay by the way with his Veel, the other Ships not uffering the ame obtruction; at which this Prince was o incens'd, that he preently commanded divers to eek out the caue, who at length found this Fih ticking to the helm of the Veel which they hew'd him about the bignes of a Snail; and he was more urpris'd when he aw that it had not the like effect within the Ship as without; as 'tis aid, the foot of a Tortoie being in a Veel, makes it move lowly. Plutarch, in the econd book of his Sympoiacks, affirms, That this Fih was found ticking to the Ship which he hired, to ail into Sicily; and Rondeletius aith. That the Cardinal of Tourain being imbarked for Rome, in a Veel of three banks was a long time topp'd in a place at Sea by this little Fih, which being taken was erv'd up to his table; though others write, that it is not fit to eat. But what they add, That its vertue of retarding is uch, that it is made ue of to hinder the Judgment of a Law-uit whereof the iue is fear'd; and alo in filtres to retain a Lover that depies his loving Mitris, is as hard to believe, as 'tis to find coniderable reaons for it, without having recoure to the ancient aylum of thoe who depair to find any, which is the pecifick form of this Fih, which hath the ame faculty of topping Ships, that a Diamond hath of retaining the Vertue of the Loadtone, and Garlick of hindering it to act: as the Ship appeaeth the fury of the Elephant; the Fig-tree, that of the Bull; and many other uch things, which though mall in bulk, are yet very great and virtuous; as they make appear in their Qualities, which are as enible in their Effects, as they are occult in their Caues.

The Second aid, That the Remora worketh the ame Effect upon the Ship, that the Torpedo doth upon the hand of the Fiher, which becomes tupid, when he toucheth the ame with a long pole. Now of this effect of Remora is not hard to be accounted for, if we follow the Principles of Campanella, and thoe who allow ene to all, even the mot gros corporeal things. But this opinion being little received, 'tis better to ay, that whereas all natural things ubit only by the viciitude of motion and ret; wie Nature, who is the principle of both, hath judiciouly dipenc'd them that they are found differently in ome things, and in others, and that for the good and ornament of the Univere, which requires, that as they are bodies immoveable by reaon of their cituation or ue, to wit, the Earth, and the Poles of the Heavens; others always in motion, to wit, the Heavens, Rivers, Air, and Fire; and others, endued with an attractive vertue, as the Loadtone and Amber; o She hath given others a Quality contrary to this. Namely, the Remora, that of topping the motion of a Ship: and becaue motion and ret are contrary one to the other, their principles are no les, as well thoe that are effective of motion, as thoe which caue ret; but 'tis better to explicate them by their enible and indubitable effects, than by reaons ordinarily frivolous and impertinent.

The Third aid, 'Tis no rare thing for Ships to be taid in the main Sea, whatever pains the Mariners take to make them go forward; and how favourable oever the Wind may be, the caue whereof is no other but the contrary motion of the waves of the Sea, epecially in treights and narrow places where there are trong Currents, which probably. topp'd Caligula's Ship, and thoe other mentioned in Hitory, rather than this little Fih which 'tis credible can end o trong a Vertue from its mall body, as to fix and check the far greater, and oftentimes irreitible force of the Winds and Sea. Unles you had rather attribute this retardment to the mucoity and other foulnees wherewith Ships are cruted in long Voyages, which hinder their advancing; and this Fih being ometimes found in thoe mucous humidities, people mitake it for the caue, though it no wie contributed thereunto.

The Fourth maintain'd, according to the opinion of Francatorius, That 'tis not poible for o mall a Fih as the Remora, to top a great Ship at full ail; but that this Effect is occaion'd by Rocks indu'd with a Quality like that of the Loadtone; upon which this Fih uing to reide, when a Ship paes near them, their Adamantine Vertue attracts the ame towards them; whence the ame thing happens by thee two violent motions, viz. that wherewith the Veel is driven along in the main Sea, and the attraction of thee Rocks, as when two equal forces draw a weight two everal ways, the thing remains unmov'd; o that this fih is not the caue, but only the ign of this retardment.

The fifth aid, That if there were any uch magnetical vertue, in this cae the nails and iron-works of the Ship o tay'd, would rather be taken away, than its coure topt, the latter being more hard to do than the former; ince a little force ufficeth to pull a nail out of a Ship, whoe impetuous motion, 'tis not poible to withhold; whence Archimedes's his drawing of a Ship out of the Port into the Market-place by his endles erue, pas'd for one of the goodliet ecrets of the Mechanicks, though indeed it be nothing to the preent enquiry. And the truth is, this trange effect may bet be attributed to a hidden property, and ingular quality of this Fih, which being always found ticking to the topped Ships, is more probably the caue of that impediment, than any unknown Rocks, which ought to do the like to all Veels that approach them, if there were any uch: For tis a vanity condemn'd by the mot intelligent in the ecrets of Nature, to preume to give valid reaons thereof, whilt we have none for the mot enible and ordinary effects, for want of knowing the lat and proximate differences which contitute every thing in its Eence, and ditinguih it from others; it being eaie to know, that the Remora, after the example of many other which act by a propriety of their form, produceth this effect, without being needful to trouble our elves to find out the means it imploys in order thereunto.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXI. Of Negroes.
div.p:
NAture loves variety o well that he is not contented with producing a great number of Species of all orts of Animals differing chiefly according to the Climates which produce them; but he hath alo pleas'd her elf in an innumerable diverity of individuals epecially as to colour, as cannot be call'd an Accident in Blackamores, but an ineparable property, which ditinguihes them from other men, and contitutes the nature of Negroes, in whom the Sun's heat produceth an effect contrary to that of his light; this brightning, the other obcuring the ubject upon which it acts. Yet it acteth not alike upon all Subjects, ince the ame Star (Aethiopian) whitens linnen and wax; but this blacknes happens to the Aethiopians becaue moiture exceeds, and in a manner extinguiheth heat; jut as we ee it come to pas in Charcoals, Gangreens, and the parts of man's body when truck with Lightning. For, if the firt Quality would take colours, no doubt cold would be white as we may judg by Water, Ice, Snow, Gray Hairs, and the Animals that live under the Artick Pole which are all white, though of the ame Species with ours of another colour; as Bears and
Hares. Which is further prov'd by Herbs which grow white under ground, and loe as much of their heat and bitternes, as they partake of uch whitenes, witnes the talks of Hartichoaks and Savoury. Hot things would be red, and of the colour of Fire, which we ee gives that colour to faces formerly pale, to hot Iron and burning Wood; but a uperfluous humidity upervening tifles, and extinguihes this heat, and leaves behind it the colour of corruption; as we ee the whitet kin grows black by heat upon travelling Southwards; the contrary happening to thoe that go Northwards.

The Second aid, That, if heat alone made Blackamoors, thoe that are mot expos'd to the Sun-beams hould be the blacket; but they are not o, there being many Nations of the New World, where it is o hot, that they go all naked, of an olive colour; whereas in Guiney, Aethiopia, and other places inhabited by Moors, they are cloth'd and feel more cold. And becaue this colour may be acrib'd to the reciprocation of heat and cold, which is more likely to alter men's bodies in all other qualities, than in a permanent one; there are found both black and white people under the ame parallels and elevation of the Pole; as in the Ile of Sumatra, where the Inhabitants are white. Wherefore this colour mut not be attributed to the Heaven but to the Earth, which produceth all other varieties of Animals, epecially of men, as is oberv'd in the Patagons, who are Gyants: To whom are oppos'd the Pigmies which their oil likewie produceth. And to hew that the tincture of the kin is not the only particularity obervable in Negroes, they have many other Properties whereby they are ditinguih'd from other Nations; as their thick lips, addle-noes, coare hort hair, the horny tunicle of the eye, and the teeth whiter than the ret of men. Beides, they are not only exempted from the Pox and other Venereous Maladies, but their Climate alone airs the ame. Not to mention the Qualities of their minds, which are o ignorant, that though they have plenty of Flax, yet they want Cloth, becaue they want kill how to work it; they abound with Sugar-canes, yet make no trade of them, and eteem Copper more than Gold, which they barter for the like weight of Salt; and are wholly ignorant of Laws and Phyick. Which ignorance renders their pirits more bae and ervile than thoe of other Nations; and they are o born to lavery, that even free men among the Abyins (the mot coniderable people of all Aethiopia) when they are employ'd by any one, take it not ill to be lah'd with a Bull's Pizzle, provided they be paid; and when their Priets exhort the people, they whip them till the blood comes, for the better inculcating of their Intructions, thoe being held in mot reverence, who whip them mot everely; though they were the firt Pagans who were converted to the Faith by Queen Candace's Eunuch, who was intructed by S. Philip. And as puillanimous perons are commonly the mot
treacherous, (thee two vices having both the ame principles) and preuppoing ignorance of the point wherein true Honour conits; o the Moors are ordinarily bae and unfaithful to their Maters, as is verifi'd by abundance of Hitories; which meannes and poornes of Courage, reaches from the econd next the King's peron to the mot inferior amongt them; all bowing down and touching the ground with their hand when they hear the name of their King Prete-Jun, before whoe Tent they make a Reverence though he be not there, and flatter him o exceively that if one of their Kings happen to loe an Eye or other member, they deprive themelves of the ame too. Moreover, they are o credulous that they perwade themelves that this King is decended in a direct line from Solomon and the Queen of Sheba, (who, they ay, was nam'd Maqueda) when he came to ee him, as they report, for ome other caue beides admiring his Widom.
