The Third aid, That the cae is the ame with the Negroes, in repect of the color of their kin, and the other above-mention'd particulars, as with the long heads of the Children of Paris, which Nature produceth at this day of herelf, ever ince the Midwives had form'd the firt after that manner, upon a belief that this figure was more becomming and uitable to the functions of the Soul than roundnes. So likewie the heat of the Sun firt blacken'd the kin of the Moors of either Sex by little and little; amongt whom, the blacket hides, the thicket lips, and mot evers'd being in eteem, every Mother endeavor'd to make her Childrens lips and noe of that figure; and Nature, helpt by their Imagination mov'd by the occurrence of like objects, hath produc'd uch ever ince. But 'tis no wonder if the people of ome Countries, under the ame parallels and latitude indeed, but defended from the heat of the Sun by oppoite Mountains, are exempt from the effect of that heat; as there are places in France, where upon the ame reaon fruits are a month or two later in ripening than thoe of their Neighbors. Moreover, the fril'd hort hair of Negroes is an effect of the ame heat, as alo their being exempted from the Pox, which being a phlegmatick cold poyon, as appears by its invading the permatick parts, and the encreaing of its pains in the night more than day, 'tis more reaonable that the Temperaments oppoite thereunto, uch as theirs whoe fleh is very dry and void of Phlegm, be free from the ame. Now that Negroes abound not in Phlegm and Moiture, appears in that they never pit in their Churches, not only out of cutom, but expres Law, which would never have been made if it had not been eaie to oberve. Moreover, the whitenes of their teeth is augmented by the blacknes of their faces: And as for their wits, Scaliger thinks them not really dull, but only out of deign and craft, which always argues wit. Whence Geographers, who reckon Southern people amongt the mot ingenious, ay, They could never be brought to their duty
by Reaon, but uffer themelves to be rul'd only by Religion: Becaue where Humane Reaon holds not, as in matters of Faith, there the greatet wits are oblig'd to become ubject to the les, when they peak to them as from God. Beides, their Characters are handomer and more agreeable than either the Arabick or Turkih. They are addicted to Navigation, and have a Military Order under the protection of Saint Anthony, to which every Gentleman is bound to deign one of his three Sons, except the eldet, which erves for their King's Guard, and amounts to 12000. Horemen. And if there be no other reaon to eteem them ignorant but their having no wrangling Lawyers, many other Nations would be happy if they had none neither. And though Phyick be not reduc'd to an Art, nor taught by a Method amongt them, (as neither was it of old amongt us) yet they want not Remedies ueful for health. Their want of Linnen proceeds from their abundance of Cotton; and the comparion of Gold and Copper depends upon Phanie: And, latly, the paucity of the people finding food enough at home, have les caue to be eager upon Trade abroad.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXII. Of Ectacies.
div.p:
THough the union between the Body and the Soul be o trict, as to erve for a model to all other unions obervable in Nature, yet is it not o trong but that ometimes it admits of a diolution, which the Philoophers conceiv'd poible, both thoe parts continuing entire. This eparation is call'd an Ectacy, wherein the Platonits, who firt brought it into Vogue, plac'd the Summum Bonum, or greatet Felicity, inamuch as they pretended, that mens minds were thereby diengag'd from all material things; nay, from their very Bodies, by the clouds and humidities whereof they imagin'd, that the mind was diturbed in its functions, which, being equally piritual, are the more compleatly perform'd, the more the Undertanding whereby they are produc'd, is diengag'd from this corporeal mas. Whence it comes, that old men, epecially uch as are near death, or in their leep, have clearer viions, and more certain predictions than young men, and thoe who are in perfect health, of a moit Temperament, who are waking, and perform all their other functions. And whereas there is no great road between the highet widom and the greatet extravagance, it may be further inferr'd, that thoe who are of a more dry Temperament, whereof it is as likely that fools as well as wie men, may be, frequently have uch viions, and fall into thoe Ectacies; and upon this account,
that they mind not their own thoughts, are eaily uceptible of external impreions, and the firt objects which preent themelves to them. So that we may make a ditinction of Ectacies into two kinds. The former is to be attributed only to great and contemplative perons, and may be aid to be only a diengagement of the mind, which is o taken up with the apprehenion of an object, that it quite forgets all its other functions. For the cae is the ame with the ndertanding, in reference to its object, which is Truth; as it is with the Will, in repect of its proper object, to wit, Good, which it o paionately affects, that it is not o much where it lives, as where it loves. In like manner, the Undertanding being forcibly engag'd to a taking object, whereof it makes a particular obervation of all the differences, is o transform'd into it, that it ceaes to act any where ele. Now the reaon of this, is, that knowledge or apprehenion, as well as all the other functions, is wrought by a concoure of pirits, which being by that means, in a manner all employ'd in that trancendent action, there are not enough remaining for the performance of other actions, the mall portion that is being wholly employ'd about repiration, nourihment, and the other actions neceary for the Conervation of Life. Accordingly, this kind of Ectacy, or ceation of the functions is not only oberv'd to happen in that conflict and contention of the mind, when it is wholly bent upon the examination of ome object, but alo in all the other actions which are perform'd with exces: uch as for example, the Paions are, the extraordinary violences whereof occaion Ectacies, an extream grief cating a man down o much, that he becomes as it were tupid and inenible. The ame thing happens alo through joy by a contrary effect, as well as in Anger, Fear, Audacity, and the other perturbations of the iracible and concupicible Appetites, by reaon of the great diffuion or concentration of the pirits. Whence it follows, that it is not more trange to ee a man ravih'd and fallen into an Ectacy as it were out of himelf, in the contemplation of ome object, than to ee ome perons o over-joy'd, as to die out of pure joy. For Knowledge being an action of the Undertanding, whereby it raies and elevates to a piritual and incorporeal Being things that are mot material, which are advanc'd in the Undertanding to a new and more perfect Being, than that which they had of their own Nature, the Undertanding renders them like it elf, and is o united to them, that there cannot be a greater conformity than what is between the object and the power whereby it is known. When therefore that object is of its own Nature piritual and immaterial, the Undertanding having diengag'd it elf from every other Subject, is o over-joy'd at its own knowledge, that it forgets all other actions of les conequence.

The other Ectacy is properly attributed to Lunaticks and ditracted perons, and is by Phyicians plac'd among the highet irregularities, caued by black Choler in the minds of uch as
are much inclin'd to Melancholy; in whom it caues an alienation of Spirit, which inclines them to imagine, peak, or do things that are ridiculous and extravagant; ometimes with fury and rage, when that humor is enflam'd, and converted into black Choler, and ometimes with a tupid adnes, when it continues cold and dry.

The Second aid, That the Greek word ignifying an Ectacy, is ordinarily taken for every change of condition whatever it may be; ometimes for a tranportation and elevation of mind, whereby a man comes to know things abent, as it was explicated in the precedent part of this dicoure. Such peradventure was the taking up of Saint Paul, even while he liv'd, into that blisful Seat of the Bleed, which he calls the Third Heaven, allowing the Air to be one, and the tarry-ky to be another: And that of Saint John the Evangelit, which he peaks of in the Revelation; Nay, before them, uch were thoe of the Prophets, and, after them, thoe of many other perons, if we may give any credit to Hitorians. Such was that of the Abbot Romuald, who, finding a great difficulty to read the Palms of David, became, in an Ectacy he had as he was aying Mas, o learned, that he was able to interpret the mot intricate paages of them. Such was that of Saint Francis, the Founder of the Order of Francicans, who, in a ravihment, receiv'd upon his body the marks of our Saviour's Paion. Such was Saint Thomas Aquinas, who frequently fell into uch an Ectacy, that he eem'd dead to all that were about him. Such was John Scot, commonly known by the name of the ubtle Doctor, to whom the ame thing happen'd o often, that his mot familiar friends eeing him as he ate reading or writing, found him many times immoveable and without entiment, inomuch that he was carry'd away from the place for dead; and yet thee two lat, were rais'd up o illuminated from that Philoophical Death, that they have left but few imitators of their great Learning. The ame thing is affirmed of a certain Virgin, nam'd Elizabeth, whoe Senes were ometimes o tupifi'd, that he continu'd a long time in a manner dead; from which kind of Trance being come to her elf, he fore-told ome things, which afterwards came to pas according to her predictions. To be hort, there are few Monateries of either Men or Women, but affirm as much of their Founders. And that it may not be imagin'd, that uch a eparation of Body and Soul happened during this Life only to Enthuiam, or a highly-contemplative meditation of divine things, which nevertheles mut be acknowledg'd the common caue of it; we read of Epimenides of Creet, and Ariteas the Proconneian, eminent Poets and Philoophers, that ometimes they left their Bodies without Souls; which, having taken their progres about the world, return'd after a certain time, and re-animated their Bodies. Nay, Pliny hath a pretty remarkable Story, how that the Soul of this Ariteas was many times perceiv'd to take her flight out of his Body,
under the form of a Crow; and that his Enemies having oberv'd it, and on a time met with his Body in that poture, burnt it, and by that means diappointed the Bird of her net. Apollonius relates a Story yet much more prodigious, of Hermotimus the Clazomenian, to wit, that his Soul made Voyages of everal years; having left his Body, during that time, without any entiment, while he went up and down into divers parts of the world, fore-telling Earth-quakes, great Droughts, Deluges, and uch other remarkable Accidents. And further, that this thing having everal times happen'd to him, he had given his wife a trict charge that no Body hould touch his Body during his Soul's being abroad upon the account aforeaid; but ome perons of his acquaintance bearing him a grudg, having with much importunity obtain'd of her the favour to ee his Body lying on the ground in that immoveable poture, they caus'd it to be burnt, to prevent the Soul's return into it; which yet it being not in their power to do, and the Clazomenians being inform'd of that injury done to Hermotimus, built him a Temple, into which Women were forbidden to enter. And Plutarch, in his Book of Socrates's Daemon or Genius, confirming this Relation, and allowing it to be true, affirms, that thoe who had committed that crime, were then tormented in Hell for it. Saint Augutine in his Book of the City of God, Lib. xiv. relates, that a certain Priet, named Retitutus, when-ever, and as often as, he was deir'd to do it, became o inenible at the mournful tone of ome lamenting voice, and lay tretch'd along as a dead Carkae, o as that he could not be awak'd by thoe who either pinch'd or prick'd him; nay, not by the application of fire to ome part of his Body, inamuch as he could not feel any thing while he continu'd in the Ectacy, only afterwards it was perceiv'd that he had been burnt, by the mark which remain'd upon his Body after he was come to himelf; before which time be had not any repiration, and yet he would ay, that he had heard the voices of thoe who had cry'd aloud in his Ears, calling to mind that he had heard them peaking at a great ditance. The ame Author in the xix. Book of the ame Work, affirms, that the Father of one Praetantius was apt to fall into uch Ectacies, that he believ'd himelf chang'd into a Pack-Hore, and that he carry'd Proviions upon his back into the fields with other Hores, when all the while his Body continu'd immoveable in the Houe. Among other Examples of this kind of Ectacy, Bodin in his econd Book of his Daemonomania, chap. 5. relates a tory of a certain Servant-maid living in the Danphine, having been found lying all along upon a dung-hill, in uch a dead leep that all the noie made could not awake her; nay, her Mater's banging her with a witch not prevailing any thing, he ordered fire to be et to the mot enible and tenderet parts of her Body, to try whether he were really dead or not. Which being upon tryal believ'd, they left her in the ame place till the morning; and then ending to look after
her, he was found very well in her bed. Whereupon the Mater aking her, What he had been doing all the night before? Ah, Mater, aid he, how unmercifully have you beaten me? Upon that dicovery he was accus'd for a Witch, and confes'd it. To be hort, Cardan in his eighth Book of the Variety of Things, affirms of himelf, that he fell into an Ectacy when he pleas'd; inomuch that he leightly heard the voices of thoe who poke to him, but undertood them not; Nay, what is more, was not enible of any pinching, nor yet feeling the exquiite pain of his Gout, whereto he was much ubject; as being not enible at that time of any thing but that he was out of himelf. He afterwards explicates the manner how that Ectacy is wrought, affirming, that he felt it begin at the Head, epecially in the hinder part of the Brain, and thence pread it elf all along the Back-bone. He affirmed further, that at the very beginning of it he was enible of a certain eparation about the Heart, as if the Soul with-drew at a kind of wicket, or ally-port, the whole Body concerning it elf therein; and adds, that then he ees what-ever he would with his Eyes, and not by the trength of the Undertanding, and that thoe Images which he ees are in a continual traniency and motion, in the reemblance of Forets, Animals, and uch other things: The Caue whereof he attributes to the trength of the Imagination, and harpnes of the Sight. He further relates of his Father uch things as are much more miraculous, and occaion'd the upicion of his being a Magician.

Now from all thee Sacred and Prophane Hitories, it may be inferr'd that of Ecstacies, ome are miraculous, and others natural. The former not ubmitting to ordinary Caues any more than all the other things do that concern Religion, which tands much upon the preheminence of being above Reaon. The latter proceeding from the great diproportion there is between the Body and the Mind, the one being extreamly vigorous, the other extreamly weak. Whence it follows, that there are two orts of perons ubject to Natural Ectacies, to wit, thoe trancendent Minds which are dipos'd into weak Bodies, and weak Minds in trong and robut Bodies; inamuch as there being not a perfect connexion and correpondence between them, the Soul finds it no great difficulty to diengage her elf from the Body, or the Body from the Soul, which by that means obtains a freedom in her operations, it being upposd that they do not all at depend one upon another, as may be een in the Formation of the Embryo, wherein. the Soul making her elf a place of aboad plainly hews, that he is able to act without it, as alo in woundings and faintings, during which, the Body continues o detitute of ene, that no active faculty, at leat no operation of the Soul, is obervable in it.

The Third aid, That the Vegetative Soul, which is without motion, being the firt whereby we live, it is not to be much admir'd,
if the other two Souls, to wit, the Senitive and the Rational do ometimes eparate themelves from it; and this is that which they call Ectacy: whereof we have a certain intance in all the faculties, wich are in like manner eparated one from another, without the los of their Organs. Accordingly, he who is mot harp-ighted as to the Undertanding, hath commonly but a weak corporeal ight; the mot robut Body is ordinarily joyn'd to the weaket Mind: Thoe perons who walk and talk in their leep, do alo hew that the Rational Soul does quit the Government of the Body, and leaves it to the direction and dipoal of the enitive; and the ame thing may be alo aid of the Vegetative excluively to the other two. To come to Intances: we have at this day the experience of ome, who continue a long time in Ectacies, and that not only in matters of great importance, but alo in ome things of little concernment, which they are not able to comprehend; nay, there are ome have the knack of falling into Trances and Ectacies when they pleae themelves. And this hath been affirm'd to me of a certain peron who was able to do it, without any other trouble than this: He caus'd to be painted on the wall a great Circle all white, in the Centre whereof he et a black mark, and after a long continu'd looking upon it, the Viual Spirits being by degrees diipated, brought his Soul into a Vertigo, or Dizzines, which occaion'd the Ectacy.

The Fourth aid, That the opinion of Bodin, which allows a eparation between the Souls and Bodies of Witches and Sorcerers, having been invented only to render a reaon of what they affirm they had een, during the time their Bodies had been immoveable, is not to be believ'd without ome further proof; ince it is impoible even by that to explicate the Relations which they make of thoe places, where they ay they had been, and the things they had there done; inamuch as they poitively affirm, that they had made thoe progrees with their Bodies and all their members, and that they had made ue of them in eating, drinking, and performing uch other actions as are purely corporeal, and cannot be imagin'd done in a tate of eparation, as being not compatible to eparated Spirits, which being immaterial, tand in need of Bodies to aume corporeal affections, and perform thoe beatly Actions whereof Sorcerers talk o much.

To this may be added, that this eparation cannot be wrought without death, and, that uppos'd, it were impoible the Souls hould re-enter into their Bodies otherwie than by a real reurrection, which is an act that God hath o reerv'd to himelf, that the Devil is not capable of doing it: Nay, though it were in his power, it is rather to be imagin'd that he would be far enough from taking ouls out of their bodies, and dirobing them of their enual inclinations, inamuch as he does all lies in his power, to involve the Souls of Men more and more into their Bodies, and
make them wallow in enuality, and render all their affections corporeal. Accordingly, great and generous Souls, uch as are mot diengag'd from the Body, are not fit for that purpoe; ince Agrippa, and all the other Maters of that detetable profeion, require Simplicity in thoe who would be Sorcerers, as a neceary and previous dipoition. So that if the Souls of Sorcerers, which are at firt engag'd, and afterwards continu'd in the Devil's ervice, only in proecution of the concerns of the Body, came to be deveted of that heavy mas whereby they are encompaed, and tripp'd of the inclinations of the Body, no doubt they would break off o diadvantagious a bargain, at leat they would not find any delight in the divertiements where-with the Devil does amue them. It is therefore more probable, that the Devil hould ometimes cat Sorcerers into a certain leep, and bind up their common ene, o as that they are rendred incapable of receiving external impreions, and that in the mean time, he hould joyn together the different pecies of Memory, and raie in the Imagination uch repreentations thereof as are conformable to the truths which are made ele-where. So that the Undertanding not receiving any thing from without, which might undeceive it, is wholly taken up with the pecies it hath within; the apprehenion of Sorcerers being much like thoe of ome perons, who having their brains either weakned by Dieaes, or naturally receive uch an impreion from their dreams, that when they awake, they are hardly able to ditinguih them from the things they have een. That therefore which is commonly called a Diabolical Ectacy, deerves not the name, ince it is only the cating of one into a dead leep. Thoe Dieaes which Phyicians call Ectacies, as Catalepies and Madnes, are only uch improperly; and the ame thing is to be aid of thoe kind of woundings, which have frequently been taken for Ectacies in ome perons, who having continu'd their Contemplations beyond the trength of their Bodies, and thereupon wounded out of pure weaknes, have upon the recovery of themelves, imagin'd, that their Minds had been tranported into real Ectacies, and yet can give no account of what had pas'd during the time of their Trance. The precedent tories, and thoe which may be thereto added, of Socrates, Archimedes, and ome others, do not prove that, naturally, there can be any Ectacy; for either thoe tories eem to be palpably fabulous, or only hew that the Souls of thoe Ectatical Perons had not broke off all correpondence with the Body, nor quitted the aitance of the enes and their Organs, that they might be wholly involv'd in themelves, and o reign themelves to Meditations purely Intellectual. For he who hall examine the example of Socrates, as it is related in Plato, will look upon that action rather as a tryal, which Socrates made of his own Patience, than as a real Ecstacy, epecially ince Socrates is imagin'd tanding; a poture requiring the motion of the Mucles, which preuppoes
entiment in the exterior parts. Accordingly, dead bodies, as alo thoe wherein the action of the Soul is check'd and hindred, are not found tanding, though the Athenians have huffled in, among their tories, a tale of one of their men who tood upright after he had been kill'd. The other Intances are of perons who meditated with uch earnetnes and attention on their own thoughts, and directed their minds with o much violence towards that ene, whereof they had mot occaion, that the other enes were detitute of Spirits and without action, not dicerning their own proper objects if they were not extreamly violent, which is no real Ectacy, inamuch as otherwie we mut call Sleep an Ectacy. And, indeed, the mot refin'd and ubtilet Meditations, which we derive from thoe Ectacies, mell o trong of the Body and Matter, that it is probable, they were not the pure productions of the Soul, no way diverted by the diturbances of the Body and the internal enes, on which he objectively depends, even in the inorganical actions he does; it being a thing impoible for her to meditate alone, ince that in her direct actions he tands in need of the Imagination, and mut be excited by Phantams; but above all, he cannot be without Memory, which always furnihes her with the matter of her peculations, and reerves the pecies of them. Beides, thoe who are of opinion, that all the faculties of the Soul while he is in the Body are organical, cannot imagine any Ectacy wherein the Soul meditates by her elf, without any commerce with the Body and its entiments; and thoe, who conceive, that the faculties of the Undertanding and Will borrow nothing of the Organs but the objects of their actions, do nevertheles inferr, that the Soul tands in need of the enes, in order to the doing of her actions, and is not over-earnet in the doing of them, but when he is excited by the Phantams, for the tirring whereof the Animal Spirits are abolutely neceary, which takes away all conceit of Ectacies. And thoe who imagine, that in Ectacies the Soul hath no correpondence with them, and makes no ue of them in her actions, do, by that means, intead of etablihing detroy the Ectacy; ince it mut be inferr'd, that the Soul during the time of thoe retir'd meditations, leaves the Spirits in the Organs, whoe function it is in the mean time to receive the impreions of the external objects, and convey them into the common Sene, and thence into the Imagination and Memory; whereas 'tis expected, that the Ectacy hould leave the Body without action. Whence therefore, I conclude, that there is not any at all, in regard that an Ectacy ignifying a tate of the Soul, beides that which is natural to her, and beides the natural conequence there is between the actions of the enes, and thoe that are proper to the Rational Soul; it may be affirm'd, that uch a tate never happens, and that the Soul hall not be abolutely freed from the incumbrances and ditractions of the Body till after Death. And this hath been ufficiently acknowledg'd by
Socrates in Phoedon, notwithtanding all the Ectacies attributed to him; and Aritotle, whoe thoughts were more abtracted, and trancended thoe of all others, would not by any means admit of Ectacies from a natural caue, but attributes them all to God. Which procedure of his hath been approved by Scaliger and many others.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXIII. Of the Cock, and whether the Lyon be frightned at his Crowing.
div.p:
THe Germans being engag'd upon an expedition of War had ome reaon to carry a Cock along with them, to erve them for an incitement and example of Vigilance. Thence haply proceeded the cutom, which ome Mule-drivers and Waggoners till oberve of having one faten'd to the leading Mule or Hore; and ometimes for want of that, adorning them with a plume of his or ome other feathers. 'Twas upon this account, that Phidias's Minerva had a Cock upon her head-piece, unles it be attributed to this, that the aid Goddes had alo the preidency and direction of War, where there is no les need of Vigilance than Indutry; though that Bird belongs to her ufficiently upon the core of his other qualities, as being o gallant and courageous, as many times rather to loe his Life upon the pot, than quit the deire of victory; and when he is engag'd, fighting with uch fury, that Caelius Aurelian relates that one who had been peck'd by a Cock in the heat of fighting, grew mad upon it. For the Paion of Anger being a hort fury, 'tis poible it may extreamly heighten the degree of heat, in a temperament already o highly cholerick, that in time the body of the Cock becomes nitrous; and upon that conideration, is precrib'd to ick perons for the looening the belly, and that after he hath been well beaten with a wand, and the feathers pluck'd while he is alive before he is boyl'd. It may be further urg'd, that this Courage of the Cock was the motive which inclin'd Artaxerxes King of Peria to grant him, who kill'd Prince Cyrus, the priviledge of carrying on his Javelin a little Cock of Gold, as a ingular acknowledgement of his Valour. Whereupon the Souldiers of the Province of Caria, whereof he who had the aforeaid priviledge of the Cock was a Native, in imitation of him, intead of Corlets wore Cocks upon their head-pieces; whence they had the name of Alectryons, or Cocks, in Latin Galli, which poibly is the reaon that gave the French that name: And whereas the Cock commonly crows after he hath beaten another, it came alo to be the Hieroglyphick of Victory, and that
haply gave the Lacedaemonians occaion to acrifice a Cock when they had overcome their Enemies.

This Creature was alo dedicated to Mars, and the Poets feign, that he had ometime been a young Souldier, whom that God of War order'd to tand entinel when he went in to Venus to give him notice of Vulcan's return; but he having lept till after the Sun was rien, and by that neglect of duty Mars being urpriz'd with her, he was o incens'd that he metamorphos'd him into a Cock; whence it comes, ay they, that being ever ince mindful of the occaion of his transformation, he ever crowes when the Sun approaches our Horizon. This fable, how ridiculous oever it may be thought, is as upportable as that of the Alcaron, which attributes the crowing of our Cocks to one which it aies there is in Heaven; a Cock of uch a vat bulk, that having his feet on the firt of the Heavens, the head reaches to the econd; and this Cock crowing above, awakens and incites all thoe upon Earth to do the like, as thee lat et one another a crowing, as if they all crow'd at the ame intant all over the world.

The Cock was alo dedicated to the Sun and Moon to the Goddes Latona, Ceres, and Proerpina; whence it came that the Novices, and uch as were initiated in their myteries, abtain'd from the eating of it. It was alo the ame to Mercury, in regard that vigilance and early riing are requiite in Merchants. And thence it came that he was painted under the form of a Man itting, having a Cret or Comb on his Head, Eagle's claws intead of Feet, and holding a Cock upon his fit. But there was a particular conecration made of him to Aeculapius, which oblig'd Socrates at his death to entreat his Friends to acrifice a Cock to him, ince the Hemlock where-with he was poyon'd had wrought well. The Inhabitants of Calecuth acrifice him to their divinity under the form of a he-goat: And Acota, after Lucian, affirms, that anciently the Cock was ador'd as a God; which Chritianity not enduring, hath order'd them to be plac'd upon Churches & on the tops of teeples, and other very high tructures, that by their turning about they might tell the beholders which way the Wind blew; unles haply ome would refer it to the repentance of Saint Peter, at the econd crowing of one of them. As concerning the crowing of this Creature, it is commonly attributed to his heat, and may be a certain dicovery of his joy at the approach of the Star of the ame temperament with him. And whereas he is more uceptible than any other of the impreions of the Air, (whence it comes that being moiten'd by the vapors, he crows with a hoarer voice, which Labourers look on as a prediction of Rain) it may be thence conequent, that he is the firt enible of the coming of the Sun. Moreover, whereas there is a Solar Animal, uch as is alo the Lyon, but in a lower degree than he, the pecies of Birds being hotter and dryer, as being lighter than that of four-footed Beats; it thence follows,
that the Cock hath an acendent over the Lyon, which no ooner hears his crowing, but it awakens in his Imagination thoe pecies which caue terror to him: Unles we would rather affirm, that the pirits of the Cock are communicated to the Lyon, by that more than material voice; and as uch more capable of acting, than the pirits iuing out of the Eyes of ick perons, which nevertheles infect thoe who are well, and look on them; nay, if we may believe the Poet, bewitch even innocent Lambs.

The Second aid, That this error of the Lyon's being terrifi'd at the crowing of the Cock, was to be added to the number of all thoe vulgar ones, which had occaion'd o much beating of the Air in the chools and pulpits about Maxims which are dicover'd to be abolutely fale in the Practick; it being a thing not impoible, that ome Lyon which had been tam'd, and by change of nourihment become cowardly and degenerate, had been a little tartled at that hrill crowing of the Cock, grating of a udden upon his ears. And this conjecture will not be thought trange by thoe, who, about the beginning of March lat, 1659. were preent at an engagement which had been appointed between uch a Lyon and a Bull in a Tennis-Court at Rochel: The Lyon was o frightned at the ight of the Bull, that he got up into the Lights precipitating the Spectators, who had planted themelves there in great numbers, as eteeming it the afet place of all; and thence he lunk away and hid himelf, and could never afterwards be gotten into the lits. It may alo be imagin'd, that the trangenes and novelty of that Crowing might urprize ome Lyon that had never heard it before, by reaon of his living at a great ditance from Cities and Villages, where thoe Creatures are commonly bred, and that thence it came the Lyon was tartled at that firt motion. Moreover, 'tis poible, nay, it may be more than probably affirm'd, that ome have taken that tartling out of indignation, obervable in the Lyon when any thing dipleaes him for an argument of his fear, whereas it was a dicovery of his being incens'd. For to imagine a real and general fear in that generous Creature, upon o leight an account as the crowing of a Cock, I cannot ee any probability for it, in regard that correpondence and conformity which is attributed to them, hould rather occaion a Sympathy in them, than any thing of averion, which being fully as great as that which the Sheep hath for the Wolf, hould no more frighten the Lyon, than the bleating of the Sheep does the Wolf. Nor is it o much out of an averion and Antipathy which the Wolf hath for the Sheep, that he devours and converts it into his ubtance, as out of kindnes and love to his own preervation; and there are commonly een about thoe houes, where Lyons are kept, everal Cocks and Hens, and yet the Lyons never make any dicovery of their being frighted at their crowing or crakling. Nay, for a further confirmation hereof, it comes into my mind, that I have een a young Lyon devour a
Cock, which, I mut confes, crow'd no more than thoe of Nibas, a Village of the Province of Thealonica in Macedon, where the Cocks do not crow at all. But if there were uch an Antipathy between them, as ome would have imagin'd, the Lyon would have thought it enough to tear him to pieces, and not eat him as he did. And therefore it is to be conceiv'd, that what hath given occaion to this error, is the moral ene, which ome would draw from it; to hew, that the tronget are not free from a certain fear, which they conceive of thoe things whence they hould leat expect it. So that, to put this Quetion, Why the Lyon is frightned at the crowing of the Cock, is, to enquire for the caue of what is not.

The Third aid, That we are not to make o leight an account of the authority of our Ancetors, as abolutely to deny what they have affirmed to us, and eems to be ufficiently prov'd by the ilent acquiecence of o many Ages, under pretence that we are not able to reolve it: Which were to imitate Alexander, in cutting the Gordian knot, becaue he could not unty it. It were much better to endeavor to find out in the nature of the Cock and in his crowing, the caue of the Lyon's being frightned thereat. Let it then be imagin'd, that the Lyon being an Animal always in a Fever through an exceive choler, whereof his hair and violence are certain marks; the ame thing happens to him as to ick and feverih perons, to whom noie is inupportable, epecially to thoe, in whom a cholerick humor enflam'd caueth pains in the Head: Nay, there are ome kinds of ounds which ome perons are not able to endure, yet o as that they cannot aign any caue thereof, and o as that we are forc'd to explain it by Specifick Properties and Antipathies; uch as we may imagine to be between the crowing of a Cock and the ear of a Lyon. And that is much more probable then the topping of a Ship by the Remora, when he is under all the ail he can make, and a thouand other effects imperceptible to reaon, and uch as whereof only Experience can judge; and therfore that terror which the Lyon is put into at the crowing of the Cock, is not o irrational; that Sovereign of Animals having jut caue to admire, how from o mall a Body there comes a voice o hrill and trong, as to be heard at o great a ditance, conidering with himelf what michief he does with o little noie; and this terror of the Lyon is increas'd if the Cock be all white, inamuch as that colour promotes the diffuion of his pirits already dipers'd by the firt motion of his apprehenion.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXIV. Of the Sibyls.
div.p: THough it be generally acknowledg'd that there were Sibyls, yet as to their Names, their Number, their Country, and their Works, nay, the whole tory of them, all is full of doubts and uncertainties. The Etymology of the Greek word ignifies as much as the Will or Counel of God; the Aeolick Dialect aying Siou intead of Theou. The Chaldeans call'd them Sambetes. They are cited, and conequently acknowledg'd by Jutin Martyr, Theophilus of Antioch, Athenagoras, Clemens Alexandrinus, Tatian, Lactantius, and other ancient Authors. Varro, and Diodorus Siculus, call them Women fill'd with divinity, fore-telling things to come, whence they came alo to be call'd Prophetees. Some conceive that they were before the War of Troy, and referr all their predictions only to one of them, imagining that the ame thing happen'd to them as had done to Homer, who, for his great reputation, gave occaion to everal Cities of Greece, to attribute his birth to them: in like manner as a great number of Cities and Countrys; as for intance, Erythrae, Cumae, Sardis, Troy, Rhodes, Libya, Phrygia, Samos, and Aegypt, deirous to attribute to themelves the Birth of that Sibyl, it came to be believ'd, that there were many of them. Amongt whom, Martianus Capella, grounding his aertion upon very probable conjectures, acknowledges but two, Erophila, the Trojan Sibyl, whom he affirms to be the ame that others call the Phrygian and Cumaean, and the others Symmagia, call'd alo Erythraea, at the place of her birth. Pliny affirms, that there were at Rome three Statues of the Sibyls, one erected by Pacuvius Taurus, Aedile of the people; the other two by Marcus Valerius Meala, the Augur. The firt of thee three, according to the relation of Solinus in his Polyhitor, was call'd Cumana, who prophesy'd at Cumae in the fiftieth Olympiad, and had till her Temple at Pouzols, about a hundred years ince, but was burnt in a general conflagration that happen'd there in the year MDXXXIX. under the ruins of which it was then buried; o that there remains now only ome ubterraneous places, into which a man cannot go upright, yet till expres a certain divinity, inamuch as thoe reliques of a vat and pacious tructure, eem to be all cut out of one tone. The econd was call'd the Delphick Sibyl, and liv'd before the Wars of Troy. The third is that Eriphyla of Erythrae, who prophesy'd at Lesbos. Aelian affirms, that there were four, to wit, the Erythraean, the Samian, the Aegyptian, and that of Sardis. To that number others add two, the Judaick and the Cumaean; but Varro, deirous to have yet more of them, adds four, and makes them up ten; of which opinion is alo Onuphrius. They are dipos'd into this order.

The firt and mot ancient is the Delphick, of whom Chryippus peaks in his Book of Divination, by the Ancients called Artemis, born at Delphi, and it is conceiv'd that Homer inerted many veres of this Sibyl in his Works. Diodorus Siculus calls her Daphne, and ayes he was the Daughter of Tireias, of whom he had not learnt the Art of Divination, when the Argians having taken the City of Thebes, ent her to Delphi to pay their vows, where having learnt to divine by the inpiration of Apollo, he poke Oracles to thoe who conulted her.

The econd is the Erythraean, as is affirm'd by Apollodorus, a Native of the ame Country: And yet Strabo ayes, that he was a Babylonian, and had only given her elf the name of the Erythraean, whom Euebius affirms to have liv'd in the time of Romulus.

The third is the Cumaean, or Cimmerian, o call'd from the Cimmerian Town near the City Cumae in Italy, whom ome call Deiphobe; to this Sibyl it was that Aeneas addres'd himelf when he made his ecape from Troy.

The fourth is the Samian, otherwie called Phyto, of whom Eratothenes ayes, that he was mention'd in the Annals of the Sam • ans. Euebius is of opinion, that he flourih'd in the time of Numa Pimpilius, and that he was called Heriphila.

The fifth is the Cumaean, otherwie Amalthaea, or Demophila, and called by Suidas, Hierophila. Of this Sibyl is related the tory of the nine Books, and according to others of the three, (not of the Cumaean, whom ome unadviedly confound with this, though they were different) which he preented to Tarquinius Superbus, as it is affirmed by Varro, Solinus, Lactantius, Servius, Suidas, and everal others. And Solinus gives this further account of her, that, in his time, her Sepulchre was hewn in Sicily.

The ixth is the Hellepontick, born in the Trojan Country, at the Town of Marmius, near the City of Gergithium, whom Heraclides of Pontus affirms to have liv'd in the time of Solon and Cyrus, that is, in the L X. Olympiad.
The eventh is the Lybian, of whom Euripides peaks in the Prologue before Lamia, which he writ in the LXXX. Olympiad.

The eighth is the Perian, of whom there is mention made by Nicanor, in the Hitory of Alexander the Great. Jutin Martyr calls her alo the Chaldaean, in his Admonition to the Gentiles; and he is conceiv'd to have been the Daughter of the Hitorian Berous, and Erimantha. She liv'd in the CXX. Olympiad.
The ninth is the Phrygian, who prophecy'd at Ancyra.
The tenth is the Tiburtine, called Albunea, who was worhipped as a Goddes on the hores of the River Anienus, in which her Statue was found.

All thee ten Sibyls are repreented by a Picture hanging up as it were in the Clouds, having their Heads encompas'd with
Light, as our Saints commonly have. But the firt holds a Hunter's Horn in his right Hand; the econd, a Sword; the third, a Torch; the fourth, a Cros; the fifth, a pair of Gloves in the left Hand; the ixth, a Cradle on her right Hand; the eventh, holds a Lanthorn; the eighth, a branch of a Roe-buh; the ninth, hath a loaf of Bread on one ide of her; the tenth, hath a mall Wand or Rod. The Painters have preum'd to add two others, to wit, the Europaean, holding a Crown of thorns; and the Agrippinean, who holds a banner faten'd to a Cros; but they do it not by any other Authority, than that They and the Poets aume to themelves to attempt any thing. According to which priviledge, there are yet divers others, to wit, one named Elia, who prophesy'd in vere: Whereto may be added Caandra, the Daughter of Priamus, the Epirotick Sibyl, the Thealian Manto, Carmenta the Mother of Evander, Fatua the Wife of King Faunus, Sappho; and, upon a better title than any of the precedent, Deborah, Miriam, the Siter of Moes, and the Prophetes Huldah.

The mot famous of all, and he to whom the Ancients gave greatet credit, was the Cumaean, who, under the form and habit of an old woman not known to any, came to Tarquinius Superbus, to whom he preented nine Volumes of Oracles, which he aid he hould have for three hundred philippus's; whereat the King took occaion to laugh, as if the old woman were grown a child again, to ak o great a umm for uch inconiderable Books: Which he perceiving, went away and burnt three of them; and coming again to make him a econd proffer of the ix remaining, demanded the ame price he had ak'd for all the nine; and the King having laugh'd at her as before, and being confirm'd in his conceit of her being ditracted, he burnt three more of them; but returning the third time, and aking of him the firt mention'd umm for the three that were left, Tarquin atonih'd at that pereverance, conulted the Augurs what he hould do; whereto their Anwer was, that, in all liklihood, they were ome Counells ent by the Gods to the City of Rome for the wellfare of it, which he hould not any longer refue. Accordingly he order'd her to have what he demanded; and having advis'd him to be very careful in the keeping of thoe Books, he vanih'd, and was never after een either in that King's Court, or any where ele, which much heightned the opinion already conceiv'd of her Divinity. Tarquin recommended thee Books to the keeping of two perons of good repute, which number was afterwards mutiply'd to ten, elected one half out of the people, the other out of the Senate: And afterwards it came to fifteen, and o increas'd till it roe to ixty, but till kept the name of the Quindecim viri, which receiv'd their period with all the other heathenih ceremonies in the time of Theodoius. Only thoe perons were permitted to read the Books of the Sibyls, and their upertition came to uch a pitch, that there was not any thing o
holy and acred in Rome, as thoe Books; inomuch that when any thing occurr'd, wherein the Roman State was highly concern'd, as the Petilence, civil War, or when their forreign Wars were not carry'd on with the ucces they had promis'd themelves; their recoure was to thoe books of the Sibylls, whence they pump'd out the remedies and advices which they had to give the Senate and People. This was oberv'd till the time of the Social War, when, Cains Norbanus and Publius Scipio being Conuls, the Capitol was burnt, and with it all the acred things, and among them the Books of the Sibylls. But oon after the reparation of the Capitol, Scribonius Curio and Cneus Octavius being Conuls, there came out an Edict from the Senate, that three Deputies hould go, as they did, to Erythrae, and other Citties of Italy, Greece, and Aia, whence they brought to Rome about a thouand Veres written by divers perons, with the names of the Sibylls to whom they were attributed. And it is from the ignorance of o many hands, as had been employ'd in the writing of thoe Veres, that the many faults found therein proceeded; as being uch as oblig'd Tiber, to correct thoe errours, and ditinguih the uppoititious veres from the true ones, to order that every one hould bring in to the Praetor, of Rome whatever he had of them, with a prohibition that any hould retain Copies thereof ave only the Quindecim viri, whoe Office and Name receiv'd its period at the lat conflagration of the Sibylline Books made by the command of Stilico, Father-in-law to the Emperor Honorius, thinking by that means to raie a edition againt his Son-in-law, and o to transfer the Empire to his own Son Eucherio.

And this is all we have of certainty concerning the Hitory of the Sibylls, who may be probably conjectur'd to have prophecy'd by a certain Enthuiam and divine inpiration, which was granted them according to the acknowledgment of the Fathers, as a reward of their Virginity; it being not imaginable, that the many noble things they have foretold, even to the highet myteries of our Salvation, hould proceed from the evil Spirit, much les from the motion of Nature, the trength whereof is not able to come up to Prediction.

The Second aid, That the vain deire, which men of all times have been inclin'd to, of knowing things to come, having put them upon an unprofitable conultation of Heaven, Earth, and Waters, to find out whatever might bring them any tidings thereof, they have not let lip any occaion which they conceiv'd might inform them; their upertition being come to that height as to draw conequences and preages from all things, and oblige them to earch into the very entrails of Beats, and the epulchres of the Dead: Nay, what is yet more, if they have deriv'd a certain divination from the very chirping of Birds, whence their Augurs receiv'd their name, it is not to be wondred, they hould give credit to the Dicoures and Songs of
young Maids and Women. For, among thoe who were called Sybills, there were ome married, epecially he who writ the firt book of the Oracles attributed to them; which Sibyll ays he had been in Noah's Ark, with her Husband, her Father-in-law, her Mother-in law, her Brothers-in-law, and her Siters-in law, who conequently had not the gift of Prophecy betow'd on them, upon the account of their Virginity: And though, according to the tetimony of Euebius, and mot of the other Eccleiatical Authors, there was not any Sibyll more ancient then Moes; yet does the Sibyll before-mentioned foretell the coming of Moes, and the Deluge, at which by that means he could not have been preent; for things preent are never fore-told. But what brings the credit of their Works into greater upicion, is, that thoe Veres do themelves dicover, that they were written fifteen hundred years after the beginning of the Grecian Empire, and conequently, whatever they tell us of Moes, the raign of Solomon, and the Empire of the Lacedaemonians, all which preceded that time, are Hitories, which they obtrude upon us for Prophecyes. And all the Myteries of our Salvation contain'd in the Sibylline Veres, are, in all probability of the ame Nature. And, in the fifth Book of the Sibylline Writings, the Sibyll ays, that he had een the econd conflagration of the Vetal's Temple; which, according to Euebius, happen'd in the year of our Lord CXCIX. under the Emperour Commodus. And then it was indeed, that thoe Veres firt appear'd in the World, nor were they een before, nor cited by any one, and the Prophecies contain'd in them, have not ought to ay of what hould come to pas after that time, inamuch as they could not have done it with any certainty. As to her aying, That there hould be three Emperours after Adrian, to wit, the two Antoninus's, Pius, and the Philoopher, and the Emperor Commodus, and then the times hould end, being found fale in repect of what was to happen afterwards, as being things abolute beides her knowledg, it was not to be imagin'd, he hould et down the names of the Emperors, or given the firt Letters thereof, as he had done thoe of the fifteen, who preceded, of whoe Hitory he gives as particular an account as thoe Authors who peak affirmatively thereof, and with all circumtances after their death. Add to this, the erroneous opinions of ome Chritians of that time, which are inerted into their Works; as for intance, that the damned hould be deliver'd after certain Ages; and that Nero hould remain conceal'd to be Antichrit in the lat times. Beides, the too exact obervance of order in thoe Writings, is an argument that they were not the productions of perons ubject to Fanaticim, uch as ome would have the Sibylls to be, who writ upon the leaves of Trees, the Veres which their Enthuiam dictated to them. And to conclude, there is no probability, that the Prophet Eay, who hath poken more clearly of the Incarnation than
any other, hould think it enough to ay, A Virgin hould bring forth a Son; and that the Sibyll hould ay, before the thing came to pas, The Virgin Mary hall bring forth a Son named Jeus in Bethleem: there is no probability, I ay, that God hould betow greater illuminations on thoe Women, whom Antiquity ranked among the Prietees of Bacchus, than on the mot inpir'd among his Prophets. Whence it is to be jutly imagin'd, that ome Chritians were the Authors of thoe Veres, who piouly thought to make ome advantages thereof againt the Pagans, who gave credit to other Writings which were then in vogue and repute under that name: as there are ome in our days who father on Notradamus uch things as he never thought of, and that after they are come to pas; under pretence that there is ome mention made thereof in that confuion of matters, whereof he treats. This will not be thought trange by thoe, who conidering the multitude of accidents, which that Author hath huffled into his Centuries, whereof the varieties are o great, that it is no hard matter to find therein mot occurrences of humane life; as we ee that in yllables diverly tranpos'd and put together, all things in the world may be found.

The Third aid, That the Ancients are not be thought o credulous, as to attribute uch authority to the Sibylls, if there had not been ome young Maids and Women, who had effectually fore-told things to them. True it is, chance may be fortunate in one or two caes, as a blind Archer may caually hit the mark; but it is very unlikely, that one who cannot hoot at all, hould have the reputation of a good Archer all the world over. And yet Authors are full in aerting the authority, wherein the anwers made by thoe women were. Virgil grounding his dicoure on that common perwaion ays,
ltima Cumaei venit jam carminis aetas: And the Satyrit confirms what he had aid, with another vere, to wit, Credite me vohis folium recitare Sibyllae. And it was ordinary to incribe on Monuments the names of thoe who were appointed for the keeping of thoe books of the Sibylls and took care for the Sacrifices, which the Romans offered up, to appeae the wrath of the Gods, according to the counel, which, as occaion requir'd, they took from their veres. Nay, there was uch a trict prohibition that any hould have them in their private Libraries, that one of thoe who were entruted with the cutody of the Sibylline Books, named Marcus Atilius, was own up in a bag, and cat into the Sea, for lending Petronius Sabinus one of thoe Books to be trancrib'd, or, as ome affirm, only their imple Commentary, containing the ecrets of
the Sacrifices which were made according to them. Upon the ame conideration that it pleas'd God to anctifie Job, though out of the Judaick Church, the only one wherein alvation was then to be found, I may ay, there is no inconvenience to imagine, that he might as well betow the Spirit of Prophecy, on thoe Virgins at leat commonly accounted uch. And conequently, what is aid to the contrary, deerving rather to pas for adulterate and uppoititious, then that there hould be any quetion made of what divers of the holy Fathers have affirmed of them: the gift of Prophecy having been communicated alo to Balaam, and God having miraculouly opened the eyes, and unloos'd the tongue of his As. What remains to this day imprinted in the minds of a great number of perons, concerning Merluzina, and other Fairies, contributes omewhat to the proof of what hath been aid; ome illutrious Families deriving their origin thence. For, as to the inerting of ome uppoititious veres into the body of their Works, it hould be no more prejudice to them, then it is to thoe of the mot excellent Authors, among which the purious productions of others are ometimes huffled in. And if it be true, that Homer's Veres were at firt confuedly pronounced by him, and that it hath been the employment of others, to reduce them into that noble order, wherein we read them, Why hould the ame obervance of order be cenur'd in the dipoal of the Sibylline Veres? Plato, in his Theagines, affirms, That Socrates acknowledged them to be Prophetees; and in his Phoedon, the ame Socrates hews, by their example, That extravagance or ditraction of mind does many times bring great advantages to Mankind. Aritotle, in the firt quetion of the thirtieth Section of his Problems, affirms, That Women become Sibylls, when the brain is over-heated, not by icknes, but through a natural ditemper. And elewhere he decribes the ubterraneous Palace of a Sibyll, whom he affirms, according to the common report of her, to have liv'd a long time, and continu'd a Virgin. Plutarch, in his Treatie, Why the Prophetes Pythia renders not her Anwers in vere, affirms, that, by a particular favour of God, a Sibyll had poken things during the pace of a thouand years; and elewhere, that he foretold the detruction of everal Cities that were afterwards wallow'd up, the fire of Mount Gibel, and divers other things, etting down near the time when what he had aid hould come to pas. Pauanias affirms, that the Sibyll Herophila, had certainly foretold the bringing up of Helen at Sparta, and that it hould occaion the detruction of Troy. Jutin, having related what account Plato made of perons who foretold things to come who he ays, deerve the name of Divine, though they do not themelves comprehend the great and certain things which they predict, ays, That that is to be undertood of the Sibylline Veres: the Writers whereof, aid he, had not the ame power as the Poets have, to wit, that of correcting and
polihing their works; inamuch as the inpiration ceaing, they do not o much as remember what they had aid, though ome have been of opinion, that the agitation of Mind, wherewith they have prophesy'd, eem'd to be the Effect of the evil Spirit; producing, as a confirmation of this opinion, one of the Sibyls, who ayes of her elf, that, for her enormous crimes, he was condemn'd to the fire. Yet allowing thee Veres to be ranked among the uppoititious, there is till a greater probability inclining us to judge otherwie of them, when we conider the good intructions given us, and the myteries of our Salvation contain'd therein; it being not the function of Devils and evil Spirits to encourage us to piety. But however it be, this is clearly evinc'd, that there have been Sibyls, and that they fore-told things to come.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXV. Whether of two Bodies of different weight, the one decends fater than the other, and why?
div.p:
OF Natural Bodies, ome move from the Centre to the Circumference, as Fire; others, from the Circumference to the Centre, as the Earth; others, are in the mean between both, as Air and Water, the latter whereof inclines downwards, but both of them are principally deign'd to fill the Vacuum. Whence it comes, that the Air decends as much, nay, fater to the bottom of a Well when it is dry'd up, than the Water had done before; which conideration, hath given occaion to ome to attribute a mean, or circular Motion to thoe two Elements, as they have done a direct Motion to the two firt. And whereas thee two kinds of Local Motion, to wit, the direct and the circular, are the Principles of the Mechanicks, the mot profitable parts of the Mathematicks, and that among the aid Motions, that which tends downwards, which proceeds from weight, is the mot ordinary Agent, and uch as is the mot commonly us'd in Machins or Engins, where it is the mot coniderable, either for the aitance it gives to fixt and etled intruments, or for the obtruction it gives thoe which are moveable; thence comes that famous dipute there is, concerning the caues of Motion from above to beneath. Which ince it mut needs proceed from one of thee three, to wit, the weight of the Body decending, and lightnes of the mean through which the decent is made; or from the impulion of the aid mean: Or, latly, from the attraction made by the Centre; the Quetion is, To which of thoe three Caues that Motion is to be referr'd? If it be attributed to the weight, it will follow, that
the heaviet Body hall decend oonet; if to the impulion, the celerity or lownes of the Agent hall accordingly render that Motion wift or low; but, if only the attraction made by the Centre be the Caue of it, the leer weight hall decend as fat, nay, fater than the greater, upon the ame account as that the ame piece of Loadtone more eaily draws a mall needle than it does a great key. Nor can Experience always ait us in this cae, in regard the different compoure and form of heavy Bodies, as alo the diverity of the means, and the variety of the Agents, whereby they are thrut forwards, will not permit us to make an allowable Comparion between them. Thus a ball of Cork, which decended as fat in the Air as one of Lead, hall not do the like in the water, to the bottom whereof the Lead hall fall, but not the Cork. And again, the ame Lead being put into the form of a Gondola, or other hollow veel, hall wim on the water, which it could not before: A Cloak, folded cloe together into a bundle, hall have a peedy decent in both Air and Water; but let a Man faten the ame Cloak under the arm-pit, o as that it may pread into a circle, it hall o utain him the Air, that he hall fall very gently, and receive no hurt by his fall. Hence it alo comes that many Women have been av'd, when, falling into the Water, their Clothes were pread all abroad. The ame thing may alo be oberv'd in thoe frames beet with Feathers, or cover'd with Paper, which Children call Kites, and utain in the Air, and uffer to be carryed away with the Wind, giving them ever and anon little checks or jerks by drawing the pack-thread to them whereby they are held, imitating in that action the beating of the wings in Birds. In fine, the different manner of giving the firt hock to weighty Bodies, does accordingly diverifie their Motion towards the Centre. For as the impulion made downwards hatens its bent towards the Centre; o when it is forc'd circularly, it is retarded. Whence it comes that a glas o cat down that it hath certain turns by the way, does ometimes fall to the ground without breaking. But to peak abolutely, all conditions being uppos'd equal, it hould eem that the more weighty a Body is, the ooner it falls to the Centre: And this is made good by daily Experiences, as may be een in the weighing of Gold and Silver in the balance, which hath a peedier and horter cat, when the piece is much weightier or lighter, than it hath when there is but half a grain difference between both the cales.

The Second aid, That the Nature of weight or heavines was to be number'd among the occult things. Aristotle defines it to be a Quality inclining Bodies downwards and towards the Centre. Others would have it to be an Effect of denity, which proceeds from the great quantity of Subtance and Matter, comprehended and contracted in a mall room. There are yet others, who would have it to be an impulion or fatning of one Body upon another, in order to Motion downwards: But, to come nearer
the buines, it is only the relation or report there is between a Body and its mean, and its comparion with another Body. According to this account of it, the ame piece of Gold is aid to be light in repect of one weight, and heavy in repect of another; Wood is heavy in the Air, and light in the Water; Tin is light in comparion of Gold, though very weighty in repect of Wood. Whence it follows, that weight hath only a repective being, and uch as depends on ome other thing, and not on it elf: The Caue of it therefore is not to be ought in it elf, but ele-where; as mut be that of the recoiling of a Tennis-ball, which is not in the Ball, nor in the arm of him that playes, nor yet in the walls of the Tennis-Court, but reulting from all thee three together. And whereas Experience eems to decide the Quetion propos'd, 'tis fit we hould refer our elves to it. Now it is certain, that of two Bodies of unequal weight, and of the ame Figure and Matter, equally forc'd, or uffer'd to fall, the one will as oon come to its Centre as the other; as thoe may ee who hall let fall at the ame time from the top of a Tower, two leaden bullets, one of two pounds, and the other of a quarter of a pound, both which will come to the ground at the ame intant; the reaon whereof is, That the tronger impulion in the bullet of two pounds, meets with a tronger reitance of the Air to break through as it falls, than that of quarter of a pound. Whence we are to make a ditinction between the greater impulion which the weightier Body makes upon another Body, and the celerity or lownes of the Motion wherewith it decends; a hundred weight being heavier on the houlders of a Porter, than one pound, but not coming ooner to the ground than it. In like manner, a tone decending o much the more wiftly the nearer it comes to its Centre, clearly hews, that it derives the force of its Motion from the Centre, as its principle; as we conclude, that the trength of a bullet is pent, and the Motion of it grows fainter, the further it is at a ditance from the arm and gun from which it came, and which we hold to have been the caue and principle of it.

The Third aid, That the weightiet Bodies make the more hate to their Centre, the nearer they approach it; for their weight is increas'd by their approaching of it; gravity, in the cent of weighty Bodies, increaing by the continuance of Motion, quite contrary to violent Motion, which admits of remiion thereby; artifice, it eems in this point giving place to Nature, o as that the latter never grows weary, nay, is infallible in all her Motions, and that uch a propenion of weight to the centre, is the only certain rule to draw direct lines to that centre; and which is yet the more certain, the greater the weight is. And whereas the Mind of Man judges the better of things when they are oppos'd one to the other, behold one of thoe little Atomes which dance up and down in the beams of the Sun triking in at a window, it is a Body utain'd in the Air only by its malnes,
and requires a long time to make an impreion in that part of the Air which is under it, which thing cannot be aid of a Muket-bullet: It is therefore deducible thence, that the heaviet Bodies decend fatet to the Centre.

The Fourth aid, That we are not to eek for any other reaon for the peedier decent of heavy Bodies, than there is in all the other Motions of Nature, which proceed from the intinct imprinted by her in all things, of loving their good, which is their ret and natural place, which till they have attain'd, they are in perpetual diquiet; and whereas the heavier a Body is, the more parts there are in it, concern'd in the puruance of that good, it is not to be wonder'd if it happens to them as to divers ollicitors in the ame caue, who pres it more earnetly than one alone would do. We may therefore ay, that the ame natural intinct that makes the Mulberry-tree expect till the cold weather be over before it buds; and the Halcyons till the tempets be pat, before they build their nets, and makes them to ecure their young ones before the Rain, may much rather caue the mot maie and weighty Bodies to make more hate. For thee, fore-eeing that the Centre is not able to lodge all the Bodies tending thereto, endeavour to get to it as oon as they can, adding to their hate the nearer they approach it. But the mot certain reaon of this peedier Motion, is the general rule, that the more the Caue is increas'd, the more is the Effect augmented; whence it follows, that if weight be the Caue of Motion downwards, the greater the weight is, the more intene ought to be the Motion.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXVI. Of the Silk-worm.
div.p:
THe ue of Silk was brought over from the Eat-Indies into Europe above a thouand years ince, and was particularly introduc'd into Italy by two Religous Men, who brought thither the grain of it omewhat above three hundred years ince; in which Country of Italy, that commodity hath been much cultivated, and that upon everal accounts; as, the preciounes of it, the eaie tranportation from one place to another, by reaon of its lightnes: And, latly, for that it is one of the principal intruments of Luxury, which never wanted Partizans and Abettors in any Age, not to mention the great advantages and wealth attending the manufacture of it. The Latine word Sericum, is receiv'd from that of Seres, an Oriental people, who were more edulous in the cultivation of it than any other: and the ame thing hath happen'd to this, as to many other excellent
productions deriv'd from mean and depicable Principles. For the Animal, from whoe labour we have the ilk, is an Inect, as are all thoe which pin, to wit, the Spider and the Caterpillar, and it differs in nothing from this latter, ave that the Caterpillar hath a little hairines, and the ilk of the Silk-worm is tronger than the web of the Caterpillar, and of another colour, but as to figure and bulk there is little difference between them. Whereto may be added, that their production is much at one, as being as it were hatch'd of certain eggs, living on leaves, encloing themelves in certain webs, out of which they make their way, after they are become a kind of Butterflies, by a trange Metamorphois, which forces them from one extremity to another, that is, from the nature of Reptiles to that of Volatiles: which transformation is uch, as, were it not for the frequency of it, might be plac'd among the greatet miracles of Nature, conidering the great difference there is between thoe two forms. And that indeed is uch as hath given ome occaion to doubt, whether the Silkworm becoming a Butterfly did not change its Species, as it would be true, were it not that every thing produces its like; and the Silkworm deriving its birth from the eed of the Butterfly, it is an argument that both are of the ame Species. Thus much as to their progres. The Kingdom of Spain commonly furnihes us with the bet grain or eed of thee worms, which are like heads of pins, but black, or reembling Rape-eed omewhat flatted on both ides: This grain, ometime in the Month of April, being put between two warm pillows, or expos'd to the Sun, enclos'd in the linings of ones cloaths, or otherwie chafed by a moderate heat, but without any moiture, there are produc'd of it little certain worms of the ame colour, that is, black at their firt coming forth, which by reaon of their malnes, as reembling the points of needles, pas through certain little holes made in a paper, wherewith they are cover'd, and faten themelves on the Mulbery-leaves, which are alo placed on the aid paper full of little holes, upon which leaves all the bet grain being hatch'd, within five or ix days, goes creeping after the firt worm that gets out of her hell; all that is hatch'd afterwards never coming to any good. Thee worms are thence tranported, with the leaves laid upon little boards or hurdles, into a temperate place, and dipos'd in a lightom and pacious room, where they are entertain'd with freh leaves twice a day, among which thoe of the white Mulbery makes finer ilk than thoe of the black; for want whereof the leaves of the Roe-buh, Lettice, and ome others may be ued: but though the Worm makes a hift to ubit by that nourihment, yet either it will not pin at all, or the Silk will be like the web or clue wrought by the Caterpillars. Thus it feeds for the pace of forty days, during which it becomes grey, and changes its colour four times, not eating for ome days before each change, by reaon of the fulnes it is then enible
of. The Worm is ubject to certain dieaes; and thoe oblige uch as have the care of them to remove them out of one room into another, and that even when they are dying in great quantities; Perfume, Incene, Benjamin, Vinegar, and Wine recovering and comforting them; as alo the mell of broyl'd Bacon. To prevent which Dieaes, and the aaults of Flies and Pimires, who will make havock among them, they are very carefully to be kept clean, the boards on which the leaves lie to be rubb'd with wormwood, or prinkled with Wine, which mut be well dry'd up before they come near them, all moiture being hurtful to them, as alo alt, or the hands that have handled it. All harh ounds, as thoe of the dicharging of Mukets, Bells, and Trumpets, detroys them; nay, the trong breaths of thoe who come near them, epecially uch as have eaten or handled Garlick or Onions, are very prejudicial to them. When their time of pinning draws nigh, which is about ix weeks after their being firt alive, at which time they are about the bignes of a man's little finger, more tranparent than they ue to be, and the little nowt o lengthen'd as that it repreents the form of a Noe, the Animal by an extraordinary motion, exprees the inconvenience it endures by reaon of its burden: Then is it cleans'd oftner, and there is o much the les given it to eat, and afterwards they et on the boards ome dry'd branches of Heath, Broom, or Vines, and above all of Birch, as being the mot delicate and leat prickly, leat it hould prick the Worm, or entangle the Silk. Then you hall ee them faten their firt threds, and cating out of their mouths a kind of coare leeve ilk, and afterwards that which is finer and more perfect, in one continu'd thread, accompany'd by a gum, which makes it tick one to another, o that the worm does encompas it elf with that ilk, which is commonly yellow, very eldom greenih or white, and being come to the end of the clue, hath only o much room as it takes up. Then, for the pace of fifteen days, it remains immoveable, and is cover'd with a kin or film like that which covers the fruit of the Pine-tree, under it • hell, and which appears not till after that is broken. But thee fifteen days being over (of which thoe will abate ome, who are deirous to make advantage of the Silk, and trouble themelves not what becomes of the grain) the Silkworm, though it eem'd to have been dead, breaks through its web, and comes out in the form of a white and horned Butterfly, bearing a certain image of the Reurrection; then coming together, the Male, which is maller coupling with the Female that is bigger, the latter heds her eed upon a clean paper, pread under her for the reception of it. The eed being carefully put into a box is either kept for the next year, or old by the ounce; they commonly keep as much as comes from a hundred Males, and o many Females; the grain or eed whereof before their copulation is barren. Now
if they be deirous to get ilk out of it, which is the principal advantage, in order to which the Worms are kept, about fifteen days after they are compleated, thee webs are cat into water, omewhat better than luke-warm, and the Women and Children employ'd about that work, tir the water with an handful of Birch, till they have faten'd on even or eight ends of ilk, which having done, they wind it up into kains, and that is the raw ilk.

The Second aid, That it is to be imagin'd the ue of Silk was abolutely unknown to the Jews, epecially when we conider, that in the works of that magnificent Temple of Solomon, wherein they par'd not any thing of what they thought mot precious, there is no mention made of Silk, intead whereof they made ue of Goats-hair, and other precious Fleeces. But it was no trange commodity to the Greeks and Romans; not to the former, ince that Pariatis, the Mother of Cyrus, was commonly wont to ay, that Kings were always to be poken to in ilken words; nor yet to the latter, inamuch as they had ome garments all of Silk, which they call'd Vestes holoericas. Which is the more creditable, in regard that the Inhabitants of China who made ue of it above a thouand years before us, have very ancient Books, whereof the paper is made of Silk. In the interim, through the revolution of times, which makes that unknown in one age, which was familiar in another, it hath happen'd, that Pliny, never having een any, relates trange tories of it, calling the Silkworm a Fly, though it be not transform'd into a Fly, as was aid before, till after it hath finih'd its working of Silk. He further affirms, that this worm makes its net in dirt, or clay, and that o hard, that intruments of iron cannot penetrate it; that in the aid net it makes more wax, then Bees do, and leavs in it a Worm, bigger than the other Flyes. Afterwards not being atisfi'd with himelf, he brings in a dicoure, which hews indeed that he had heard ome talk of our Silk-worm, but that he had never een any, nor met with any certain account thereof, when he ays, That Silk came from a Worm that had two horns, which worm brings forth certain Caterpillars, which engender that which is call'd Bombylius, out of which comes the Worm, which produces that, which makes the Silk, and all thee productions, and the making of the Silk perform'd in ix Months: the lat Worms, aith he, making a web of ilk like that of a Spider, and that the firt who ever found out the invention of unweaving and unravelling that web, that o ome ue might be made of the Silk, was Pamphila, the Daughter of Latona, of the Iland Coos. In fine, to make the tory yet more fabulous, he ays, that in the Iland of Lango, the Silkworms are engendred of the Flowers, which the Rain caues to fall from Turpentine-trees, Ahes, Oaks, and Cypres Trees, enliven'd by the vapours which exhale out of the earth; being at firt little naked Butterflies, which afterwards get a little hairines, to eecure
them from the cold, and their feet are o rough that they faten on all the Cotten they meet upon the leaves of Trees, and make their ilk of it; then they break it with their feet, card it with their claws, and having reduc'd it to ilk, hang it up between the boughs of Trees, where they comb it, to make it the finer, and that done, they wind themelves within it, as within a botom of ilk; and then are they dipos'd into earthen pots to be kept warm, and are nourih'd with noie, till they are renew'd again, and re-aume their wings, as they were before they had done their work. So pitiful a thing is a deviation from Truth, and o hard is it for a man to meet with her, when he is once got out of her own path.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXVII. Why Ice being harder than Water is yet lighter.
div.p:
IN this Quetion, there are everal others comprehended; the firt, Why Ice is harder than Water; the econd, Why it is lighter, inamuch as lightnes is an ineparable accident of oftnes, as this latter is an ineparable accident of lightnes. On the contrary, denity, hardnes, and compaction is a ign, or rather a caue of weightines, as it is obervable in Meal, Ahes, and other Bodies of the like Nature, which weigh heavier, when they are cloe thrut together in the Buhel. Nay further, this Quetion comprehends in it elf the Efficient Caues of Ice, which is the coldnes of the Earth, the Water, or the Air. It is not the firt, becaue, if it were, Rivers and Lakes would be frozen at the botom, which, on the contrary, is mot temperate, and erves for a retreat to the Fih, while the urface of the Water is frozen up, which freezing if it be o violent as to reach the Center, it is communicated by degrees from the urface. Now that Rivers begin to freez on the ides, does proceed hence, that the Water there moves more lowly; the channel, or current of the Water, which is rougher in the midt, being interrupted by the inequality of its coure. For motion prevents congelation; not upon the account that it warms, inamuch as that effect happens not to it, otherwie then by the colliion of two or more olid bodies, but becaue there is no change made, but upon ome olid foundation, which cannot be imagin'd in Water, as long as it is in motion. Nor is the Water congeal'd by that Cold, which is Nature to it elf; for that which is in Caves and places under ground, where it continues in its own nature, is not frozen. Nor yet that which lies expos'd to the influence of a cold air, epecially when it may eaily ininuate it elf into it. Whence it comes, that to caue water to freeze
in a hort time, it mut be warm'd before it be expos'd to the Air, which, finding its pores open by the heat, o much the more peedily ininuates it elf into it. For as to what is maintain'd by ome Phyicians, to wit, that the Air is hot and moit, eems to have been advanc'd by them, rather to make a correpondence of the four poible combinations of qualities to o many Elements, than for any convictive reaon; ince the Air is never hot if it be not warm'd by ome other heat then it hath in it elf, uch as is that of Fire or the Sun-beams, and thee too mut be reflected by the Earth. On the contrary, when it continues in its own nature, as it does in the night-time, during the abence of the Sun, it is actually cold: nay, even in the greatet heats of Summer, it keeps its coolnes, provided there be no application made to a hot body, as may be een in our Ladie's Fanns, who forcing away the Air from their hot faces, are refreh'd by its coolnes, which then cannot proceed from any other principle than the proper nature of Air, inamuch as motion would be more likely to imprint heat on them, then cold. And this is further confirm'd by the Air we breathe, the reciprocation whereof cools our Lungs, whereas it hould warm them, if it were hot, as the Peripateticks would have it. It happens therefore that the Air, for that reaon call'd by ome Philoophers primum frigidum, the firt cold, ininuating it elf into the Water, produces therein the effect which Aritotle attributes to it, to wit, that of congregating all things as well of the ame as of everal kinds.
