And whereas our common water, what implicity oever there may be in it, conits of all the Elements, epecially Earth and Air, the Air joyning it elf to what it meets withal of its own Nature, does in the firt place render that cold; and being by that means united to the other parts, viz. to the Earth unperceivably intermixt with the Water, and to the Water it elf, contracts and comprees them o as that they take up les pace then they did before; as may be een in a Bottle fill'd with water, and frozen up, which though it had been full, is nevertheles found to contain air in its upper part. And yet this compreion cannot be o well made, but that there remain everal particles of Air enclos'd in the Spaces of the Ice, which, were it not for that air, would be vacuous; and this, by reaon the urface, as was aid before, freezing up firt, it from thenceforward hinders from making their way out, thoe parts of air, which either were got in before, or caus'd by the avoiding of vacuity, when the Center and other parts of the Water are forc'd by the Cold to take up les place then they did before. We conclude therefore, and ay, that though the Ice be dene and hard, by reaon of that compreion of all its parts, yet is lighter than Water, becaue there is air enclos'd within it, which cannot return to its phere, as that does which gets into the Water, which by reaon of its liquidity makes way for it. So that it is no more to be wondred at, why Ice is lighter than Water, then
that cork, being harder, is lighter than the ame water. Otherwie, had the Ice no Air inclos'd within it, as it happens to that engendred in Mines, which in proces of time comes to be Crytall, it would fall to the bottom of the water as the other does. The ame thing may be intanc'd in porous wood, which wims upon the water; whereas Ebony, by reaon of its olidity and want of pores, will ink.

The Second aid, That whether the Air be granted to be light, or not, or that it pas only for a body les weighty than the water, as this latter is les heavy than the earth, certain it is, that the intermixt Air, not that comprehended within the concavities, but that diffus'd through the leat parts of the Ice, is that which makes it lighter; inamuch as it augments its innuoities, as may be oberv'd in a bottle fill'd with water, which breaks when the water is congeal'd, in regard that being converted into Ice, the bottle cannot contain it. So that, as Snow is lighter than Hail, o this latter is lighter than Ice; and this lat is lighter than water, in regard it contains les matter in an equal pace: Accordingly, it is the Air that freezes the water, yet dos it not follow thence, that it hould be the primum frigidum; as the Iron which is red hot burnes more vehemently than the elementary fire, yet is not that red hot Iron the primum calidum; that ditinction proceeding from the difference of matter, which as it mut be the more compact in order to a greater burning; o the cold, for its better ininuation into all the parts of the water, requires the conveyance of the Air. As to the lightnes of Ice, it eems to be the more trange upon this conideration, that Phyicians explicate lightnes by heat, as they do heavines by cold. But the fiery vapors which are in the water, as may be aid of that which hath been warm'd, contribute very much to that lightnes, it being not incompatible that thee contrary qualities hould be lodg'd in the ame Subject, conidering the inequality of the one in repect of the other; and it is not to be thought a thing more trange, that there hould be potentially hot Exhalations in the water, than that the Nile hould abound in Nitre, which is of an igneous nature. Now from what matter oever the cold proceeds, 'tis evident by its action that it is not a privation of heat, as ome Philoophers would have maintain'd; ince that which is not, as privation, cannot have any effect. But thoe who have referr'd freezing as well as thawing to the Contellations, eem to have come near the mark, in as much as thoe making certain impreions in the Air, which erves for a mean, to unite the Influences of the celetial bodies to the inferior, diverly affect them, one while contracting, another, dilating them, according to the diverity of matter; there being ome not uceptible of congelation, as the Spirit of Wine and Quinteences, either upon the account of their heat or implicity.

The Third aid, That if the firt qualities of cold and heat were the Caues of freezing and thawing, they would always
happen accordingly; the former, when it is mot cold; and the other, when the cold diminihes. Now many times we find the contrary, there being ome dayes without any frot, on which thaws, we are more enible of cold; and ometimes we perceive it yet without any perceivable remiion of the cold. Whence we may well take occaion to attribute both to the Influences, which, coming to meet with, and poibly to introduce alo into the water the conditions requiite, uch as is cold in repect of ice, do ininuate themelves into the water. And whereas there is in thee Influences omewhat of a celetial nature, and that they are rather piritual than material Quinteences, the ame thing happens to them as to Spirits, which make thoe Bodies which they animate, lighter, than they would be if they were inanimate.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXVIII. Of Masks, and whether it be lawful for any to diguie themelves.
div.p:
THat the wearing of Maks, and other ways for people to diguize themelves, is of great Antiquity, is apparent by the prohibition which God made to his own people, that the man hould not put on the habit of the woman, which is a diguie commonly made with the Mak, in regard that otherwie the hair and beard of the man would dicover his Sex. So that the Quetion eems to be already decided, and that it follows from this prohibition, that Maks are not to be allowed. But however, we may enquire, What repute they were in among other Nations. And we find, that they were frequently us'd among the Romans, who, about the beginning of the Spring, celebrated a Feat in Honor of the Mother of the gods; in the pomp of which olemnity, it was lawful for any one to mak and diguie himelf, and to repreent what peron or part he pleas'd, which was done bluntly enough, as the French Comedians were heretofore content to have only a certain powder or meal cat over their faces, as they till have in the Farce. To hew the viciounes of that poture, we need only urge the indecency of it, and alledge that the ue of it ought not to be allow'd, in regard that all Diimulation and Hypocriie is a great in in the ight of God and men: Now the Mak is o hypocritical, that the very word it elf is commonly taken for Hypocriie. Thence it comes that Seneca, defining the maked or hypocritical peron, gives him this Character, Cum prae e fert aliquis quod non et, When any one would eem, or appear to be what he is not. Beides, if Painting be forbidden, and be accounted a capricious humour o prejudicial to decency and good manners, that there
is no Maid nor Woman, but thinks it an injury to be reproach'd with painting her elf, what opinion ought we to conceive of thoe who diguie themelves? For it is imagin'd done out of no other end than to cloak their lewd actions, who make ue of it; as we frequently find in the informations for Murthers and Felonies, that they are committed by diguis'd perons, who thereby would prevent the dicovery of their crimes. Let therefore the ue of the Mak be utterly dicarded, as a thing which is contrary to that uprightnes of dipoition, the igns whereof are modety and hamefatnes, and by a prevention of bluhing, uhers in impudence, abuivenes, and a contempt and falification of God's Image imprinted on the face of man.

The Second aid, That in times of War, the Horemen, who are commanded out againt the Enemy, having cloe head-pieces over their faces, eem to be o mak'd and diguis'd that they are not to be known; not o much to prevent their being wounded in the face, as to elude their Enemies, o as that they may not dicover the Commanders and perons of quality, upon whoe afety the gaining or los of a battel depends. And this Diimulation hath ometimes been practis'd with great advantage, when ome private Souldier hath put on the armour, and rid the hore of the General of the Army, o to draw the Enemies Forces from that ide, while they unexpectedly charge him on the other. And whereas he is commonly the Mater of his deires, who can dicover the counels of his Enemy, and thoe cannot be known otherwie than by Spies, who would never be admitted either into Cities or the Enemy's Camp, if they did not in their habit and demeanour imitate him; what Quetion is to be made, but that it is lawful to put on diguies upon uch a deign, to get the more certain intelligence? To divert from Military Affairs to Merchandize, it is the afet way for him who would travel to diemble his condition; and whereas Poverty is that which is leat of any expo'd to dangers, unles a man will follow the example of lyes, who counterfeited himelf a Beggar or Pedlar, of which profeion all are not equally capable, it will not mibeeem a great Lord to demean himelf as an ordinary Gentleman, and ometimes to avoid urprizes, to act the part of his Servant, while the Servant acts that of a Prince. Let us divert thence, and make our appearance before the Courts of Jutice; and we hall there find, that Attorneys and Lawyers, when they peak, are ever mak'd & diguis'd in laying open the Caues of their Clients, who on their ide are alo apt enough to diemble & conceal whatever they think might prejudice them. So that the Painters had much more reaon to repreent the Lawyers, Attorneys, and their Clients, with a veil over their Eyes, then Jutice; ince that among them, he hath the reputation of the bravet man, who is the greatet Orator, and hath the bet Lungs; and according to their aying, who have bet defin'd the Art of Oratory; It is the Art of perwading people to what they pleae, by making great things
little, and little things great, which, in other Language, is for a man to diguie all things, and himelf into the bargain, inamuch as he eems to believe the contrary to what he ayes and knows, and that among the rules of Oratory, this is one, that the Orator is to peronate even to his voice and geture, and accommodate himelf to what he ayes, which is properly to mak himelf, and that not only the face, but alo the feet, the hands, the tongue, and all thoe parts of the body which are employ'd in pronunciation, elocution, and the getures uitable to the thing treated of. Nor is it to be expected that Divines and Phyicians are abolutely exempted from thee kinds of diguies, ince that, the better to ininuate into the affections of their Penitents and Patients, which is the way to gain their hearts, and by that means to Convert and Cure them, they ought to be very complaiant towards them, comply with their infirmities, and accommodate themelves to their humors in all things indifferent, that they, on the other ide, may ubmit to their advice in thoe things which are neceary. And not to decend to particular Intances which might be made in all other Profeions, this will be the reult, that thoe who will find fault with Maks and Diguies, mut, with the ame breath, cat an aperion on all humane ociety, which, as Augutus aid at his departure out of this world, is nothing but a Comedy, wherein every one acts his part under a diguie. The ame thing was aid by one of the Satyrits, but much more pleaantly; for being, as we ay here, upon the Save-all, that is, ready to give up the lat gap, he cry'd out to his friend, Draw up the Curtain, the Play is done. For the greatet part of our Complements being only o many fictions and flatteries, Traffick and negotiations being o many diguies, and humane life coniting in thoe actions, the conequence is, that all the world is under a Mak, and that the les dangerous, ince there are ome make it their Profeion to be mak'd, as do alo Ambaadors and other perons of quality in ome places of Italy when they have a deire not to be known. And as to what hath been aid againt Painting, it eems to be a little too evere to blame that pardonable curioity, which the women are only guilty of, to preerve and heighten their greatet Treaure, that is, their Beauty, upon the account whereof they are principally recommendable to men; who, were it not for that, would be apt to leight them much more than now they do. For what do the poor women do more in that than is daily done in Medicine, whereof one part treats of Cometicks, that is, of Painting, and is brought in for the reparation of the defects and deformities of Nature.

The Third aid, That the Mak or Vizzard, by the Latines called Perona, either upon this conideration that it changes the condition of the peron, cauing him to be taken for ome other; or haply à per-onando, by reaon of the new ound he gives the words pronounc'd through the Vizzard. This invention of Vizzards, as alo that of peaking Prologues before Playes,
is by ome attributed to one Thepis, an Athenian Poet, of whom it is aid,
—Et plautris vexie poemita Thepis
Quae canerent agerent
que peruncti foecibus ora.

By others, to Aechylus the Tragidian,
Pot hunc peronae pallae
que repertor honetae
Aechylus.—
At firt they painted with divers colours the faces of thoe Comedians, who were carry'd about the treets in Chariots; but that humour not taking o well, becaue the ame Actor by that means found it very troublome to act everal parts, they found out the convenience of Maks and Vizards, made as near as they could like thoe whom they were to repreent, till uch time as the Macedonians became formidable in Greece. For thee meeting with ome perons in Vizards who reembled them, the Actors were omewhat at a los how they hould handomely come off: whereupon the buines being taken into deliberation, it was reolv'd, that thoe made thence forward hould be for the repreentation of extravagant or ridiculous perons, or uch as might frighten the Spectators; uch as were thoe which the Greeks called Mormolycea, bug-bears, and Oxyodontas, and the Latines, Larvas, (wherewith the Mothers threatned their little Children) Gumias, Lamias, Sillos, &c. Thee lat repreented the countenances of ridiculous and abhominable women,
—Cum peronae pallentis hiatum
In gremio matris formidat ruticus infans.

She was alo —Magno manducus hiatu. They were at firt made of the leavs of the Fig-tree, then of a certain herb that had large leavs, and, from its being us'd upon that occaion, called peronata. Afterwards the aid Vizards were made of the bark of Trees; whence came this expreion, Ora
que corticibus umunt horrenda cavatis.

And at lat they came to be of wood, whence this other,
t tragicus cantor, ligno tegit ora cavato. Whence it may be inferr'd, that the deign of uing Maks and Vizards upon the Stage, where it is mot us'd, is in order to imitation, and to heighten the confidence of the Actors, who by that means are not known. And the convenience and decency of
that cutom is uch, that one of the greatet reproaches lying on the memory of Nero, is, that having brought ome perons nobly decended upon the Stage for to be Actors, he caus'd them to put off their Vizards while they play'd on the Flute, and forbad the Comedians to appear vizarded upon the Stage. To this may be added, that, according to the Counel of the Holy Fathers, women and young maids, when they walk abroad, nay, when they go to Church, ought to be not only mak'd, but alo veil'd, to prevent the temptations which the full ight of them might caue in men, and the detraction of their own and the others devotion. Now the female ex making up above one half of the world, we cannot, upon any rational grounds univerally find fault with that thing or cutom, the ue whereof is allow'd to the greater part.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXIX. Of Fables and Fictions, and whether their conveniences or inconviences be greater?
div.p:
OF all the flowers of Rhetorick, lying is one of the wort, and withal o much the more pernicious, the more full it is of artifice. For if the aying of Aritotle be true, That the lyar always deerves to be blamed, there is a certain reemblance between him who imply tells a lie, and him who imply takes away another man's life by poyon; inamuch as the latter infects the Heart, and the former viciates and corrupts the ource of our Ratiocination; the end whereof is only to come to the knowledge of Truth. As therefore the poyoning of a man is always a heinous and punihable crime; but that Steward who hould poyon his Mater, when he gave omewhat to eat or drink, when the other pretended to be exteamly hungry or dry, would be the greatet villany in the world, and deerve a far greater punihment: So he who imply tells a lie is not o much to be blamed, as he who covers and diguies his lie under the appearance of ome probable hitory, which is clearly receiv'd by our undertanding; and this thus drawn in by the liklyhood of the relation, grows les ditrutful of it, than of the other kinds of falhood, which are deliver'd without any artifice. So that lying, and conequently Fables, and all the pecies thereof, have the ame proportion to our Undertanding, as Monters have to Nature; our Undertanding cannot endure them, whereas Truth is its utenance. Thence it comes that thoe Fables which are detitute of the ornament of Truth, which is probability, are not heard with any patience, uch as are old Wives Tales, and the like aburd relations, which are o ridiculous, that only the ignorance of Children is capable of entertaining them with any pleaure; but with o much the greater danger to themelves, in regard
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
that thoe tender Tables receiving the impreion of ome fale perwaion, will not afterwards o eaily part with it; nay on the contrary, it commonly continues there to the end, at leat ome part of it, as if Time were not able o fully to eat it out, but there may be een ome lines of the firt draught. Whence it comes that ome eminent perons do account it a great overight in the education of Children, to entertain them with Tales and Stories: intead whereof, thoe weak minds, wherein, as in oft wax, a man may eaily imprint what he pleaes, hould rather be acquainted with Hitory, which, by reaon of its variety and truth, would be equally delightful, but much more advantageous. And indeed thoe who make ue of Fables, thinking by them to teach truth, take a very prepoterous way to do it. For all the advantage which may be deriv'd from Fables, is only to draw on mens minds with greater delight to the knowledge of true things: and it is eaily found to be a way as unlikely to prevail, as if a man hould make ue of ome place infamous and notorious for lewdnes, as a School wherein he hould read Lectures of Chatity to young Men and Maids; or lodge a Fuller or Whitener of Cloth with the Collier, one oyling all that the other had cleans'd.

The econd aid, that Man's undertanding h • ving its ditats and humouromnes, as well as his body, and Content being equally requiite for the utenance of both, in regard that a coarer dih of meat taken with a good tomack is preferr'd before better chear forc'd down againt Appetite; it is but neceary, that the ame remedies hould be ued to recreate our minds, when they are wearied, and out of humour with an over-earnetnes of tudy, as are us'd to retrive and harpen the languihing appetite. This latter is recover'd by feeding on ome dih excellently well-order'd, uch as by its haut-gouts, and picquancy will rather excite, then atisfie the Appetite. Such is the bitternes of the Olive, Vinegar in Sallets, and the like; which have the ame effect as the tepping back of uch as leap, or the appearance of a Fly on a face of an exquiitely fair complexion. Thee Fables are invented to reduce the wandring and wearied Undertanding to its former interrupted puruance of Truth. There are two kinds of them: One may be called a imple Fiction, uch as are old Wives Tales, which deerve not the name of fabulous Relations, unles it be upon the account of their aburdity; and yet it ought to be eaon'd with omething that is miraculous and delightful. The other is Mythological, which may be divided into four kinds. Firt, the Poëtical, in one continu'd Relation, uch as are the Metamorphoes of Ovid; or Drammatick, and accommodated to Perons, uch as as are Comedies and Tragedies. Secondly, the Emblem, or Device, which is a real explication of ome feigned thing, painted, or otherwie repreented. Thirdly, the Apologue, uch as are the Fables of Aeop; and thee are divided into three orts,
the Moral, the Rational, and the Mixt. The Moral, are thoe, wherein irrational things are introduc'd, uch as is the Fable of the two Pots, the earthen and the brazen; or that of the ditribution of the prey between the Lyon, the As, and the Fox. The Rational are only of Men, uch as is that of the Satyr and his Entertainer, whom he leaves, becaue he blew hot and cold out of the ame mouth. Of the Mixt, we have an example in the Fable of the Fowler, and the Stork, taken in the net with the Cranes. The fourth kind is the Romance: The benefit and advantage of all which kinds of Fable is notorious to all: For beides that they comprehend that common recreation, which is oppoite to the conflict of Mind, and erious occupation produc'd by the reading of Hitories, the Poetical kind of Fable, I mean that of the continu'd Relation, where the Poet peaks alone, does make extraordinary dicoveries of the old Pagan Antiquities, whereof a man cannot be ignorant without a great defect. The Dramatick, where Perons are introduc'd peaking, when it is repreented by good Actors, makes a prevalent impreion on the minds of the Spectators and Auditors, and hath nothing comparable to the other kinds of writing and expreing: o that it is the mot efficacious intrument to move and work upon the Paions. There may alo be very great advantages made of the other fore-mentioned kinds of Fable, epecially of the Romance, which hath the ame effect on our minds, in order to their intruction in goodnes and vertue, as well-proportion'd Pictures have to teach us the art of Drawing. For, as there are not to be een now any Pictures comparable, in point of body, to that of the o much celebrated Venus, which conited of whatever was handom in any Woman or Maid, and borrow'd the hair of one, the complexion of another, the neck of a third, and the breat and other members of others; o is it impoible that Hitory hould ever come up to the noble height and delight of the Romance. For, Hitory, though it be not abolutely true, yet being oblig'd to repreent things pat with as much likenes as a picture is taken according to the face of him who is to be drawn, the conequence of that obligation is, that however it may embellih things and actions, yet is it till engag'd to expoe them to the eye of the Reader as they are, or at leat as they are conceiv'd to be. Now the number of unjut things much exceeds that of the jut, and conequently the bad and ad examples will much horten the Reader's delight. Whence it follows, that Hitory wants thoe two principal ends, for which it ought to be ought after, to wit, content and advantage: whereas the Romance brings both along with it, as being commonly full of the rewards obtain'd by vertue, whereof one is, that a incere and contant Love hould at lat be crown'd with the greatet of worldly enjoyments; and on the contrary, there are not wanting the punihments and executions of lewd and vicious perons; whereto add the trange
variety of the accidents, repreented therein, which being carried on with nobler and more unexpected intrigues, extreamly heighten the atisfaction of the Reader.

The Third aid, That for any man to endeavour the dicovery of Truth by its contrary, to wit, Fables, is to look for light in the midt of darknes; and as a certain Muician among the Ancients demanded a double reward, for teaching thoe who had been intructed amis in that Art, for this reaon, as he aid, that there was a certain time requiite for the forgetting of what they already knew, and as much for learning how to play well: o that Child, who hall have heard of the univeral Deluge by the Fable of Deucalion and Pyrrha, will find more difficulty to diengage his mind of thoe tones, which, they having cat behind them, became men and women, then he will have to imprint in it the natural Story of Noah and his Ark. The ame thing may be aid of all the other Fables, out of which there is any truth to be deriv'd, to wit, that it is like the ordering of Crabs, where there is much more to be picked away, then there is to be eaten. Nay the Romans themelves, who eem to be more intructive, may be reproach'd with this, that they have not repreented to their Readers, the State of life and civil Converation, as it really is, but have entertain'd them with a Platonical Commonwealth. And that dicourages men very much, when they find the coure and cutoms of the World to be contrary to what they had taken o much pains to read: Whereas the young man will be the les tartled to find himelf his'd by his Auditors, when he peaks well; and lighted by Fortune, when he does well; while the ignorant and the wicked are her greatet Favourites, after he hath read in Hitory of many Perons of worth o treated; than he would be, if he thrut himelf into affairs, having never een any thing but examples of Vice punih'd, and Vertue rewarded.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXX. Whether it be better to go to bed late, and rie betimes in the Morning; or do the contrary.
div.p:
THough it be a kind of receion from the common opinion, to prefer going to bed and riing late, before the oppoite; yet is it to be noted by the way, that mot Perons of great affairs, and the more judicious ort, oberving that coure of life, are of that judgment; ince that to approve a thing is to do it. Now we ee that all the great Lords and Ladies about the Court, the mot refin'd pirits, and uch are bet able to judge of all things, nay mot men who have any thing more than an ordinary
burthen of affairs, for the mot part go to bed late, and rie late; whereof everal Reaons may be aign'd. The firt and mot ordinary, me-thinks, are the affairs themelves, which inenibly teal away the time from us; and that the more unperceivably, the more delightful that buines is, about which we are employ'd; the time liding away fater from him, who takes a pleaure in the doing of a thing, then it does from another who is in ome trouble of mind or body. Whence it comes, that a tedious Tale, and a bad Book, are ever thought too long. They therefore are to be thought the happiet, who, if they had their own wills, would go to bed latet; not only for that reaon which made a certain King of this part of the World ay, That he would be King as long as he could, inamuch as when he lept, there was no difference between him & the meanet of his Subjects: but alo for this, that night urprizing them before they had done all their buines, the Supper or Collation mut be the later, and conequently the going to bed. The econd reaon is deduc'd hence, that there ought to be a correpondence between the tranquillity of the mind and that of the body. It being therefore neceary, that he who would take a good leep hould not be ubject to any diturbance of mind, & that inditurbancy being procured only by that order which every one hath taken in his affairs, it is to be imagin'd, that the later a man goes to bed, the more buines he hath dipatch'd, and conequently there remains the les to be done. Upon this core is it, that Merchant's Suppers are accounted the mot quiet, for having pent the whole day in trudging up and down about their Trade, they then enjoy themelves with greater erenity. In the third place, a man hould not go to bed, till digetion be pretty well advanc'd; from the want or lownes whereof, hideous Dreams, Crudities, Ventoities, nay ometimes Apoplexies, do proceed. Now this digetion is o much the more advanc'd, the later a man goes to bed: which difference will be bet oberv'd by thoe, who go jut from the Table to their beds, and lie down as oon as the meat is out of their mouths. Fourthly, that Cutom is ever the bet, from which it is in a man's power mot eaily to wean himelf, and in the change whereof he will be ubject to leat inconvenience. Now he who hath contracted a habit of going to bed late, will find it a les inconvenience to go to bed betimes, that o he may rie betimes, or upon ome other Motive, then he hall, who hath accutomed himelf to go to bed betimes, for he will be leepy, and unfit for the doing of any thing, as oon as his bed-time is come. Fifthly, Hippocrates would not have a man enlave himelf to an over-trict coure of life, grounding his advice on this, that uch regular perons find it the greater difficulty to upport the micarriages which oftentimes cannot be avoided in the ordinary coure of life; as thoe who walk upon ropes are more apt to fall, at leat find it a harder matter to keep on, then thoe who walk on the plain ground. Now thoe who go to bed betimes are commonly more regular in the hours of Supper, and all the other actions of the day, upon the exact obervance whereof that of their bed-time does
depend. Now it is obvious to any one, who hall conider the difference of profeions, that there are but few that leave a man at liberty to oberve o exact a rule as this is. So that being ometimes neceitated to make a breach of it, the conequence will be, that thoe who have the more trictly engag'd themelves to the obervance of the rule of going to bed betimes, mut needs receive a far greater inconvenience from the neglect of it, than they ordinarily do who go to bed late. Sixthly, the ame reaon that obliges phlegmatick perons, and uch as are ubject to Catarrhs, to content themelves with little leep, which is this; that their humidity, joyn'd with that of leep it elf, augments their ditemper; beides, that Sleeping which moitens and cools, is not o well procur'd in that part of the day which is mot cold and moit, that is, from nine at Night till three in the Morning, but rather towards the Morning, at which time the Blood begins to be predominant, inamuch as in o doing he abates omewhat of its Heat, and being to dilate it elf till ten in the Morning, at which time Choler begins to be predominant, moderates its acrimony; as all thoe will acknowledge, which Sex oever they be of, who are ubject to the Megrim, who find very great eae by that Morning leep, which accordingly is found to be the mot delightful; and hath this further advantage attributed to it, that the Dreams thereof are prophetical, and will come to pas in a hort time; whereas the others are accounted uperfluous by thoe who have been Profeors in that Art. Moreover, thoe who rie too early in Morning are ubject to the Headach in the Afternoon, and more eaily tranported with Anger all the ret of the day; to effect which, the conideration of the Temperament does very much conduce. For, as leeping in the day time is born with in Old Men and Children, and that in both, by reaon of their weaknes, and for the recruit of their Spirits, and, particularly in Old Men, to take off omewhat of the acrimony of that erous phlegm which is predominant in them; o, the greater part of Men being ubject to Choler, (whence haply proceeded the error of ome Phyicians, who talk of nothing but refrigeration in all dieaes) and the coolnes and moiture of the Night correcting that hot and dry ditemper, it is the more convenient, that Sleep hould do as much in the Day time, by taking off then omewhat of their Choler.

The Second aid, That the retrival and retauration of the Spirits obliges the Animal to leep, which ought to continue at leat for uch a pace of time as amounts to the third part of that a man hath been waking, and hould never exceed the one half of it. Far is it therefore from being imaginable, that Nature hould be able to endure what is affirmed of the even Sleepers, or the long nap of Epimenides, which lated fifty years. Nor are we to give any more credit to what is related to us concerning a Plant in the Low-Countries, which will keep people waking many nights and dayes together, without any inconvenience; but the time when we hould begin or end our leep, being left to
our own dicretion, 'tis requiite we hould accommodate our elves to the order precrib'd by Nature, which hath appointed the day to labour, and the night to ret in: Nay, it is alo the advice of Hippocrates, Galen, and all Phyicians, who think it not enough to direct ret in the night, and waking in the day, but alo conceive very great hopes of thoe, who, in the time of their icknes, are o irregular therein. Add to this, that darknes, ilence, and the coldnes of the night being fit to recruit the Spirits, and promote their retirement within; whereas light, noie, and the heat of the day, are more proper to occaion their egres for the exercie of actions; which granted, he who oberves not this rule charges Nature with an erronious proceeding. And that this is her way, is apparent hence, that thoe Animals which are guided only by her motion, (which is as certain as our reaon is ordinarily irregular) go that way to work. Cocks and other Birds go to their ret, and awake with the Sun; if any of our Dometick Creatures do otherwie, our irregularity is the caue thereof and that perverion is of no les dangerous conequence than that of the Seaons, which is ever attended by dieaes. And who makes any doubt but that the greatet perfection of the Heavens conits in their regular motion, the principal caue of their duration? Which order ince we are not able to imitate, it is but requiite we hould come as near it as we can in our actions, among which leeping and waking, being the hindges on which all the others of our life do hang, if there be any irregularity in thee, confuion and diorder mut needs be expected in all the ret, as may be een in the lives of Courtiers of both Sexes, who turn night to day, and day to night, a coure of life much different from that which is oberv'd by the Superiours and Members of regulated companies. Beides, it is the Morning that not only holds a tricter correpondence with the Mues, but is alo the fittet time for the performance of all the functions of Body and Mind. Then is it that Phyicians precribe exercies, in regard that the Body being clear'd of the Excrements of the firt and econd concoction, is wholly dipos'd for the ditribution of Aliment, and evacuation of the Excrements of the third. So that he who pends that part of the day about his affairs, beides the expedition he meets with, does by that means maintain the vigour of his Body and Mind, which is commonly dull'd by leeping in the day time, which fills the Head with vapours, and when exercie comes to ucceed it in the warmet part of the day, the heat which is then commonly greatet makes it les upportable. Therefore Nature, who is a ure guide, inclines us to leepines in the Evening, there being not any thing but the multiplicity and ditraction of Civil Affairs, which, depriving us of that Function, as it does of divers others, makes the Life of Man o much the les certain, the more he is involv'd in Affairs; whereas the duration of that of Animals, and, next to them of Country-people, and
uch as comply with the conduct of Nature, is commonly of a greater length and more certain.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXI. Whether the Child derives more from the Father, or the Mother.
div.p:
IF our Fore-fathers may be conceiv'd wie enough to have known the nature of things, it is to be acknowledg'd, that the Child derives mot from the Father, ince that they thought fit to betow on him his name rather than that of the Mother; and that the name is the mark and character of the thing. Beides, the Male being more perfect, larger and tronger than the Female, which indeed is an imperfection and default of Nature, whoe contant deign it is to make a Male, and is not diappointed; but through want of heat, vigour, and temperament; it is but rational, that what proceeded from thee two, hould have the denomination from the more perfect of them. Thus a Regiment is known by the name of the Colonel; a City, by that of its Founder; a Law and Ordinance by that of the Law-giver; and a Receipt, the Compoition whereof conits of two imple medicaments, hath mot of the nature of the tronger, and that which is of greatet virtue. This is further confirm'd by the common Comparion, which is us'd to expres the difference there is between the Father and the Mother in the buines of generation. For the Mother, and particularly, the Matrix, is compar'd to a field, and the paternal eed to the grain which is own in that field, which erves well enough in order to its prouting and hooting forth, but upplies it only with matter, which is determinated by the form of the grain, from which the Plant produc'd of it receives its being. So that the preent Quetion amounts to no more, than if a Man hould ak, Whether an ear of Wheat deriv'd more from the ground, or from the eed that had been owne in it? A further proof hereof may be deduc'd from the intruments of generation, which being more apparent in the man than in the woman, are a ilent ininuation, that the former contribute more thereto than the latter. And the greatet and mot remarkable difference that there is between the Children being that of the Sex, the experiment alledg'd by Phyicians, that if the right Teticle be bound, Males will be produc'd, as Females will if the contrary, clearly hews that by the Father's part the Sex is determinated, and conequently, it is from him that there do alo proceed the leat individual differences and circumtances, wherein the likenes or unlikenes of Children to their Fathers and Mothers, either in Mind or Body doth conit.
For if the Males epecially hould retain more from the Mothers than they do from the Fathers, that proverbial aying would prove fale, which affirms, that Fortes creantur fortibus— in regard that mot women are chargeable with a want of Courage. And daily experience makes it apparent, that one of the greatet and mot common caues of Valour is deduc'd from the Fathers ide: Upon which principle is grounded the account we make of Nobility, which comes eldom but from the Father's ide, whereas the want of Nobility on the Mother's ide, does not make the Child les a Gentleman. Nay ome have made it a Quetion, whether the Mother did contribute any thing to the formation of the foetus, or only found it nourihment. But thoe who have treated more nicely of this matter unanimouly agree, that the Woman's Seed is much weaker, and more watery than that of the Man, erving only to qualifie it, as Water does Wine, yet o as that the Water is converted into the nature of the Wine, and is call'd Wine as oon as it is mixt with it. As to thoe Children who chance to be more like their Mothers than their Fathers, 'tis to be conceiv'd one of Nature's fagaries, who delighting in variety cannot produce many children, but there mut conequently be a great diverity of Lineaments in their faces, and figures in their members; among which the idea of a Woman imprinted in the imagination of the Father may be communicated to his Seed, which conequently exprees that figure.

The econd aid, That there were three kinds of reemblances, to wit, that of the Species, that of the Sex, and that of the Effigies, as to the Body, and that of manners, as to the Soul. or The reemblance of the Species is, when a Man begets a Man, a Woman proceeds from the material Principles of Generation which the Mother contributes more plentifully then the Father: the proof whereof may be een in the copulation of Animals of different Species. For if a Hee-goat couples with a Sheep, he hall beget a Sheep, which hall have nothing of the Goat in it, ave that the fleece will be a little rougher then it is wont to be. And if a Ram couples with a She-goat, the production will be a Goat, whoe hair will be omewhat ofter than otherwie. But as to what is related of Arito's, having had a Daughter by an As, who for that reaon was called Onocele; of Fulvius Stellius's, having another by a Mare, who was thence called Hippona; and of a Sheep, which brought forth a Lyon in the patures of Nicippus, to whom it preaged Tyranny; of Alcippa, who was deliver'd of an Elephant, having been impregnated by an Elephant, are to be look'd on as montrous, and poibly fabulous Productions.

The reemblance of the Sex depends on the temperature and
predominancy of the Seeds. For if the eed of both Male and Female be very hot, Males will be engendred; if cold, Females; and both of them will be either vigorous or weak, according to the predominancy of heat or cold. Whence it follows, that this reemblance does not proceed more from the one then the other, of thoe who are joyn'd together: but the reemblance of Effigie, and the other accidents of the Body, and of the manners is more hard to reolve, there being a ecret vertue in both the Seeds, which, as Aritotle affirms, is continu'd in it to the fourth Generation, as may be confirm'd by the tory of Helida, who having lain with a Negro, brought forth a white Child; but her Grandchild by that was black. Plutarch affirms the ame thing to have happen'd in the fourth Generation of a Negro. And yet this reemblance proceeds rather from the Mother's ide than the Father's; for if the caues, which communicate mot to their effects, imprint mot of their nature into them; by that greater communication, thoe effects accordingly retain o much the more of their Caues. Now the Mother communicates more to the Child then the Father does, for he upplies him with Seed, thoe who have maintain'd the contrary being perons not much skill'd in Anatomy, and after he hath contributed as much as the Father to that Generation, he alone nourihes the foetus with her mentrual blood, which then begins not to follow any longer the coure of the Moon, whereby it was regulated before. Beides, coming thus to furnih the aid foetus with nourihment, for the pace of nine Months, it is no wonder he hould abolutely tranform it into her own nature, which is thence accounted but one and the ame, in repect of both Mother and Child. Now there is not any thing liker, or can retain more of it then the thing it elf; which cannot be aid of the Father, who is not only different from the Embryo, whom he hath begotten, but alo hath not any thing common with it, after that firt action. So that there are many Children posthumi, and born long after the death of their Fathers, which thing never happens after the death of their Mothers; nay it is eldom een that a Child taken out of the body of a Mother ready to dy, ever thrives much afterwards. Though we hall not tick to acknowledge, that what is related of the firt peron of the race of the Caears, from whom that Section was called the Caearean, might poibly happen, according to the Relation; yet is it done with this retriction, that mot of the other Stories told of it, are fabulous. But if the Mother comes afterwards to uckle her Child, as Nature and the Example of all other Animals teaches her, which is haply the reaon of their being more vigorous, and of a continuance of life more regular than that of the man, that econd nourihment added to the former, being drawn from her milk, which derives the quality of the mas of blood, from which it is extracted, makes him abolutely conformable to the Mother. For if nourihment may, as we
find it to be true, change the Temperament of Perons well advanc'd in years, with much more reaon may it work a remarkable alteration in the Body and Mind of a Child newly come into the World, who is as it were a mooth Table uceptible of any impreion. Whence it is to be concluded, that they proceed very rationally, who are o careful of the well-fare of their little ones, (when the Mothers, either by reaon of icknes, of upon ome other account, are not able to bring them up) as to be very inquiitive about the Nures they put them to, and the quality of their Milk. Nay, what is more; are not the changes caus'd by Nures in the Body of the Infant as coniderable, as that which happens to the two eeds of Male and Female mixt at the Generation, which recover their increae by the irroration of the Maternal Blood which flows thereto; and, if it be impure, does communicate its impurity to it; as, on the contrary, being pure, it is many times able to purifie the corrupted eed of the Male. Whence Phyicians have oberv'd, that ound Children have decended from Fathers ubject to the Leproie and uch dieaes. Add to this, that the afety on the Mothers ide is greater than on the Father's. Moreover, they are the Mothers, from whom proceeds the Imagination, which acts upon their Embryo all the time they are with Child; and thence it comes, that they are much more fond of their Children than the Fathers; which fondnes is a ign that there may be more of the Mothers oberv'd in the Children, than of the Fathers. For the love we have for our elves is o great, that God would have it to be the meaure of that which we ought to bear unto our Neighbour; and that which we bear to God himelf hath ome reference to his affection towards us. Thoe therefore who would ininuate themelves into the favour of any one, have no urer way to do it, than by complying with his humor, and as much he can become conformable to him.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXII. Whether is harder, for a Vertuous Man to do that which is Evil; or for a Vicious to do that which is Good.
div.p:
BEfore we come to the Reolution of this Quetion, we are to conider two things; the former, that Man conits of two parts, the Superiour, which is the Soul; and the Inferiour, which is the Body; and whereas thee two parts have different objects, and uch as which contradict one the other, there happens to be a great Conflict; the body being trongly inclin'd to enuality, and the Soul endeavouring to raie her elf up to piritual things. But in regard the Organs he makes ue of are material,
uch as are alo the Senes, which ait her in her operations, it is not to be thought he can overcome without great pains; inamuch as the intruments which he tands in need of, for the exercie of Virtue, hold a greater correpondence with the Body; and as they derive their Being from matter, o they betray the Reolutions of the Soul, reducing her under a Tyrannical Subjection. Whence it follows, that the wicked or vicious peron finds it the greater difficulty to do well; inamuch as being enlav'd to vice and in, he cannot hake off that yoke, as having a contant inclination to evil.

The Second thing to be conider'd, is good and evil in it elf; for, according to Nature, there is no evil in Humane Actions, inamuch as in appearance they are all good; otherwie the Will, the object whereof is that which is Good and pleaing, would not be inclin'd thereto, ince good is that which all things deire. There are therefore two orts of good, and as many of evils, one Natural, and the other Moral; the Soul is eaily enclin'd to the Moral good, and the Body to the Natural; and, conequently, it is much more eaie for the Vicious peron to do a Moral good, than it is for the Virtuous Man to do a Moral Evil.

The Second aid, That it is harder for a good Man to do evil, in regard that to the virtuous man Virtue eems o fair and taking, that he finds it the greatet difficulty in the world to forake her, and o to embrace Vice, which he looks upon as a hideous Monter, inamuch as Beings and Subtances are more amiable than Privations are odious; in regard that as Love repects the things that are amiable, and averion is not extended to that which is not; in like manner, Vice is not o much hun'd, as Vertue is belov'd: Whence it follows, that it is a greater trouble for the good man to do that which is evil, in regard he knows the perfection of good, as much as the vicious peron is ignorant of it; and, from that ignorance, there mut needs proceed a difficulty and backwardnes of embracing it.

The Third aid, That the vicious peron finds it a harder tak to do well, in regard that Nature is trongly bent towards that which is evil; and, conequently, the virtuous peron, when he does that which is evil, eaily falls down into the bottom; according to the decent of humane inclinations; and the vicious peron, when he does that which is good, climes up a high Mountain full of Rocks and Precipices, and engages againt Nature her elf, being in open hotility againt the enual Appetite, and, according to the Scripture, We do not the good which we would do, but the evil we would not do, that we do: To hew that the difficulties men find in the puruance of good are o great, that Saint Paul himelf complains of his having a Law within him which rebelled againt the Law of God. This Nature of ours being full of the imperfections conceiv'd in Original Sin, hath o great a repugnance to good, that there was a neceity of a Law of Grace to regenerate it, in order to the puruit of good, a complyance
with the true entiments of Religion, and the knowledge of God; not to urge, that Pleaure hath o great attractions and charms, that it is almot impoible to over-mater them. Thence it came that lyes order'd himelf to be bound to the mat of his Ship, and caus'd his ears to be topp'd, that he might not hear the harmonious voices of the Syrens; otherwie his Reaon would not have been o trong as to over-mater his enual Appetites, which mut be either detroy'd, or o fetter'd, that the Soul may not be drawn away by pernicious temptations.

The Fourth aid, That Virtue was natural to Man before Adam's Trangreion, and, from the time of his rebellion againt God, Vice hath eated it elf in her place; o that when Innocence forook our firt Parent, all vices and imperfections poes'd themelves of his Mind, and are become o naturaliz'd there, that it begat a neceity of etablihing Divine and Humane Laws: whereof ome were for the eradication of Vices; others, for the punihment of Crimes; all which trouble might have been par'd, if there had not been o much difficulty in the doing of that which is good.

The Fifth aid, That it being uppos'd, (as indeed it is true) that Humane Nature is more inclin'd to Vice than to Virtue for the reaons before alledg'd, yet is there a certain means to frutrate and detroy that Inclination, and advance the Soul to a overeignty over the Body, by abolihing and detroying the Senes, and thoe intellectual powers whereby the Organs are govern'd. For if the Body have the Materhip, the Soul will be forc'd to obey; but if the Soul commands, he will bring the Body into ubjection to all the vertuous actions he pleaes her elf. And then the Vertues will be naturaliz'd in man, and the Quetion propos'd will meet with a contrary Solution; for in that Cae, it will be much more hard for the vertuous man to do that which is evil, than for the vicious to do well; inamuch as the virtuous peron by that mortification of the Senes, will be in a manner reduc'd to the tate of original innocence, and retor'd to the glorious condition Man was in before the Fall.

The Sixth aid, That uch a moral regeneration is a great Cabalitical Secret, unknown to all the learned; that uch a mortification and detruction of the Senes as was propos'd, is a work not yet well dicover'd to the Curious, as trancending all common rules. For, if the Soul acts not without the aitance of the Organs, and the interior and exterior Senes, the weakning or detroying of thee will contribute to the weakning of the Soul; and intead of making a Prophet, the transformation will be into ome Hypochondriack, or extravagant Phanatick, as it happens to thoe who macerate their Bodies by an indicreet zeal; inomuch that having not the perfect knowledg of that Science, it were more expedient that men had a recoure to the ordinary means of Morality, to regulate the Paions of the Soul, and bring her to the puruance of Virtue. Now according to the rules of Morality,
even thoe who are good, are much inclin'd to evil, and find it no eaie matter to oppoe it.

The Seventh aid, That it is as hard a matter for the vicious peron to do well, as it is for the virtuous to do ill, in regard that the inclination, which the good man hath to do good and echew evil, is equal to that of the wicked peron, which is always bent to do evil, it being very difficult for him to embrace Virtue by hunning Vice, by reaon of the averion which he hath to that which is good. And to make this the more clear, we commonly find ome perons o naturally addicted to the exercies of Virtues, that what they do eems to be without any tudy. Whence it may be deduc'd, that the firt eeds of Virtue and Good proceed from thoe natural Dipoitions, which are called Inclinations, and, conequently, the difficulties in both are concluded to be equal. And that may alo be oberv'd in Socrates, who himelf acknowledg'd, that his natural Inclinations were o bent to Vice, that if the dictates of Philoophy had not wrought things in him beeeming the peron, whom the Oracle had declar'd wie, he would have been carry'd away with enual Appetites, according to his natural Inclinations; there being ome Natures truly Heroick, and ever doing well; and others brutih, and always inclin'd to evil. To this we are to add the conideration of the perons, their qualities, and age; inamuch as there being omewhat particular in any of thee circumtances, it changes the reolution in the general propoition, which being univeral, and of a large extent, it were neceary, in order to the finding out of the Truth, that we confin'd our elves to thee circumtances, yet till following the forementioned opinion. For as fire finds no difficulty to acend, no more than the water does to flow downwards and make towards its centre; o every one complying with his own Inclinations, tands in an equal bent towards good and evil, without any trouble or difficulty; but to proceed contrary to that motion, the virtuous peron finds the trouble attending the doing of a evil action, equal to that of the vicious in doing a bad one.

The Eighth aid, That this bent of the Inclinations ceaes in thoe who are one while inclin'd to the doing of that which is good, another, to the doing of that which is evil, as may be oberv'd in Nero, who, during the firt five years of his Government, was the mildet of any of the Emperours, yet afterwards gave himelf over to all manner of Cruelty. For what can be aid of this alteration, and if a man be naturally inclin'd to good, Why is not the ame inclination continued in him? Does this incontancy proceed from the mind or from the body? If it proceeds from the mind, ince the powers thereof have a certain knowledge of the Good, Why does it not embrace that which is good, anwerably to its knowledge of the ame? If it proceeds from the body, ince this hath a dependance on the mind, why does it not follow the impreions which it derives
from the other? The Profeors of Atrology, who give o much credit to their Influences; affirm, that thee diverities proceed from thoe Contellations, whereby that change is caued, and by which the Will is moved, and receives a bent either to good or evil; but if Reaon have the overeignty, it ought to be conformable, and produce uch effects as are anwerable thereto. There is therefore a great probability, that the caues of good and bad actions are to be referr'd to the regeneration of the Elect, and the reprobation of the wicked, who are left to the puruance of their enuality; and thence it will follow, that it hall be as hard for a truly-devout peron to in, as for a reprobate to do well; and o the Quetion is to be referr'd to the deciion of Theology.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXIII. Whether a piece of Iron laid upon the Cask prevents Thunder from marring Wine contain'd within it, and why?
div.p:
SInce we are always to begin with that which is undenyable in matter of fact, whereby we are aur'd, that a piece of Iron laid upon a veel full of Wine, prevents its being corrupted by Thunder, which, without that precaution, would caue it ome prejudice; which precaution hath alo the ame effect in preerving the Eggs which the Hen its upon, and in keeping Milk from turning; all the difficulty of this Quetion is only in the latter part of it, and that is, to find out the reaon thereof, which mut either be referr'd to ome occult vertue in the Iron, or to ome of its manifet qualities. If it be aid that this is wrought by the manifet qualities of that metal; it eems requiite that the Iron hould be within the veel with the Wine, that o it may oppoe the poyon of the Air whereby it is infected. But on the other ide, to alledge thoe occult vertues, is an argument of humane ignorance, inamuch as they are to act by the interpoition of ome means: So that, all things conidered, it is more rationally affirm'd, to be an effect proceeding from the manifet qualities of the Iron, which prevent and hinder that bad impreion of the Air. But to give a more evident reaon hereof, we are to conult Atrology. That Science teaches us, that Mars, by which Planet Iron is deigned, hath its Houe in Aries, which is the ign of the Ram; and the Naturalits oberve, that the Sun entring into that Houe, caues the ap and moiture of the Vine to acend, an evident ign that there is a correpondence between Wine and Iron, and that the one preerves the other by the natural Sympathy there is between them. And to make it appear that the Influences exercie their vertues even upon things inanimate,
yet deriv'd from the root of what had been Vegetable or Animal, we find that Wine, though it be carried ever o far, is ubject to an obervable alteration, when the grapes of the ame Vine are near their maturity; that ditance of Places and Climates not obtructing the Union and Correpondence which there is between the whole and its part, which cannot be joyned together ave only by means of the Celetial Influences.

The Second aid, That the foremention'd reaon deduc'd from Atrology was not evident, and that there is more ubtilty in it than Truth, and, conequently, that it is to be ought with greater probability to find it out of Natural Philoophy, which treats of Meteors, where the greatet difficulty is to know whether that effect is produc'd by the expulive, or by the attractive and retentive vertue. That we hould affirm it proceeds from the expulive vertue, cannot with any probability be done, inamuch as expulion is to be wrought by omewhat that is more powerful and more ubtile. Now there is not any likelyhood, that Iron hould be more powerful and more ubtile than Air, inamuch as the Iron is of a more weighty matter, paive, earthy, and hath omewhat of the nature of that Paive Element. We may therefore rather affirm, that this effect is wrought by the attractive and retentive vertue; which opinion is prov'd, in regard there is but one humid matter, which the central fire forces from the deepet part of the Earth; and of the more unctuous and weighty part of this matter Metals are made; of the les weighty, Minerals and Salts; from the ubtiler part Vegetables and Animals derive their nourihment; of the mot ubtile are produc'd the Winds, Thunder, and all the Meteors, which participate of Heat and Drought, which make everal combinations in the Air. Now whereas it is from the mot imperfect part of this unctuous matter that Iron is made, of an earthy and impure Sulphur, it is deducible thence, that there is a Sympathy between Iron, and the gros vapours of Thunder and Lightning: To make which out a little more clearly, we find that the places through which Thunder hath pas'd, mell of Sulphur; nay, there is fram'd in the Air that which is commonly called the Thunderbolt, which omewhat reembles Steel, as it were to hew the correpondence there is between Iron and Thunder. So that the Air, being impregnate by thoe noiome terretrial vapours, which are of the ame nature with Iron, meeting with ome piece of it laid on a veel, is joyn'd to the Iron by Sympathy, makes a udden top there, and puts a period to its operation; and the Iron by its attractive vertue receives them, as by its retentive it retains them, and by that means prevents their effect.

The Third aid, That though that opinion were probable, yet doth it require a more ample dicuion, and we are to examine how this attractive vertue operates. Now there are four Natural Vertues which govern all the operations of Nature and Art; the Attractive, which is now under conideration, acts by heat
and a temperate drought; the Retentive, by drought and cold; the Expulive, by moiture and heat; the Digetive, by heat and a temperate moiture. The Iron then which is aid to attract thee vapours, hath indeed thoe qualities of heat and drought; yet can it not be eaily conceiv'd, that a little piece of that mettal can check the malice and infection of a great quantity of Air, pread all over a pacious place; beides that it is alo neceary, that the Iron hould end forth out of it elf the effects of its qualities, that o the attraction might be made, the marks whereof are neither een on the Iron, nor the effects of the qualities out of the Subject, inamuch as mettals being quench'd in cold Water, are not evaporated but by a violent fire. So that it may as well be aid, that the attraction is wrought by ome occult vertue, which draws; yet o as that neither the attraction nor the manner of it can be oberv'd.

The Fourth aid, That the operations of Nature are not like thoe of Art; her ways and contrivances are more obcure, and the caues of things are occult; as for example, the Load-tone draws Iron, yet o as that there cannot be any thing perceiv'd of any body of air and moak iuing out of the Loadtone. And the magnetical Balom, or Weapon-alve, cures a wounded peron, though at a great ditance; having only ome part of his Cloths, yet can there not any thing be oberv'd on the Subject which receives the Plaiter; o ecret and ilent is Nature in her Operations. On the contrary, the deigns and contrivances of Art may eaily be dicover'd, as thoe of a Clock or Watch. But the reaon of this diverity of operations between Art and Nature, is, that Art goes to work publickly and before the Senes, and Nature does her buines within doors and ecretly; the latter works in the Centre, the other in the Circumference; one produces the eed of the combination of the Elements, whereof he keeps an exact account of the weights and proportions; and the other can neither make nor produce any thing, as being only in a capacity of making ue of the ubtance and materials of Nature, in order to their joyning together, after he had prepar'd and purify'd them. But on the other ide, Art hath this advantage, that her works are much more perfect, inamuch as he makes ue of purify'd eences, and the other of accidents and uperfluities, having not intruments fit for the purifying of her Materials. So that there are ome who doubt of the reality of the effect now under conideration. And therefore, ere we proceed any further to the finding out of the caues and reaons thereof, it were requiite a trict enquiry hould be made, whether it be certain that Iron prevents the effects of thunder, by preerving Wine and Eggs under a Hen that its, from receiving in any prejudice.

The Fifth aid, That what was confirm'd by general experience was not any longer to be quetion'd, and that whoever tood upon the Negative betray'd his own ignorance; that for
us to think to find olutions for all the poibilities of nature, were an attempt omewhat like that of exhauting the Sea; That there are certain ecrets in Nature of things dreadful to humane Reaon, incredible, according to the principles of Art and of our Knowledge. That Nature is the great Circe, the grand Sorceres, That the Load-tone draws Iron to it; That there is a certain Stone called Pantarbe which draws gold to it; That dead Are-mart being laid under a Stone, cures the wound on which it hall be rubb'd, ooner or later according as the Herb putrifies; That the hair or wool of a mangy beat being thrut in, for a certain time, under the bark of an Apen-tree, cures the beat of vermine; That the Menstrua of Women trouble Springs, poyl Looking-glaes and Powdering-tubs; And if there be ome things that corrupt them, it is not to be imagin'd that Nature is o cruel a Step-mother, but that there may be others whereby they are preerv'd, and o the Remedies may come from the ame hand as caus'd the dieae; That the Hazel-tree dicovers hidden Treaures and Mines; That Talimans are made againt Serpents and Inects, nay againt ome Dieaes; That there is a mutual friendhip between the Olive-tree and the Myrtle, whereof it would be as hard a matter to give any reaon, as it would be to give any, of the enmity between the Vine and the Laurel, and the inclination which the Male-palm hath towards the Female; That the crowing of the Cock frightens Lyons, and that that Bird hould be o exact a Fore-teller of the Sun's approach; That the Fih called a Remora, tops Ships under ail; That the eye of a Dog prepar'd after a certain way keeps others from coming near the peron that hath it; That the powder of Crab-hells prepar'd, draws out Arrows and Bullets hot into the Body; That there is a certain Stone got out of the Snake, which cures uch as are ubject to the Dropie; That Serpents are not found within the hade of Ah-trees; That the Marygold follows the motion of the Sun; That the precious Stone called a Topaze put into eething water, immediately tayes the eething of it; That the Emerald, the Saphire, the Turqueis Stone, and Coral, change their colours, upon the happening of certain accidents to thoe who have them about them; That there are certain Herbs which chae away pirits, as well as Muick does; and that the dipoitions of a black and adut choler invite and entertain them. Now from all thee intances it may be deduc'd, that, as it is a great preumption to think to give reaons of all things, o does it argue a certain weaknes of mind to doubt of all that hath been alledged; o great are the abyes and inexhautible treaures of Nature, whoe operations trancend humane belief, in thouands of other things, as well as in the Quetion now under dipute.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXIV. Of Stage-Plays; and whether they be advantageous to a State, or not?
div.p:
HUmane Life is travers'd by uch a viciitude of ditractions and diturbances, that not only the Civil, but alo the Eccleiatical Magitrates have unanimouly concluded it neceary, that men hould have ome divertiements, whereby their minds and bodies, not able to undergo continual labour, might receive ome relaxation, for want whereof they would be cruh'd under the burthen of their affairs. Now among thoe relaxations, there is not any brings greater delight with it, then what is perform'd on the Theatre, that is, Plays; which repreent unto us things pat, heighten'd with all the circumtances they are capable of, which cannot be done by Hitory, as being a thing dead, and not animated by Voice, Getures, and Habits. But if we add thereto, that this innocent divertiement is attended by thoe advantages which may be deduc'd from excellent Sentences and Intructions, we mut conclude him who finds fault with it, to be of a more than Timonian humour, and a profes'd enemy to civil Society. The proof hereof is deriv'd from the Ue of it, the true Touch-tone, whereby good and profitable things are to be ditinguih'd from uch as are hurtful and unprofitable. For there have been an infinite number of things taught by Men, which have been mother'd as oon as brought forth; and there are others alo, which the Inventors of them have out-liv'd; but when an Invention finds a kind entertainment through many Ages, it is the bet argument that may be of its goodnes. And uch is that of Comedy, which (how weak or ridiculous oever it might be at the beginning, at which time Thepis got himelf drawn through the Streets in a Chariot, as he recited his Poems) preently met with thoe who made it their buines to cultivate and heighten it to that pitch of perfection, whereto it is now come, which is uch that it is no wonder the greatet minds hould yield to the charms of it. For as thoe things that are enible, are more apt to move and make impreions on the pirits of men, then uch as are purely intelligible; o Plays, expoing to our eyes all things with a greater circumpection, decorum, and order, then is obervable in the actions of men commonly diturbed by unexpected emergencies, and the uncontancy of their paions, accordingly raie in us a greater averion for crimes, and greater inclinations to vertue. Nay, thee caue more apprehenive emotions in our ouls, than they are apt to receive from any other repreentations whatoever, not excepting even the precepts of Philoophy it elf, which
are weak enough when they are detitute of their examples, imprinting in us uch Characters as can hardly be blotted out, in regard they force their paage into our Minds through everal of our enes; and as Hitory prevails more by its Examples than the reaon of its Precepts, o Playes have the advantage of Hitory in this regard, that in the former, things act upon us with greater efficacy. This Influences it hath on us in captivating our Senes and Undertanding, is the more remarkable, in that the greatet Witts are incapable of other reflections, while they behold what is repreented on the Stage. Beides, if the great buines of the world be truly conider'd, it is but a Stage-Play, wherein every one acts a part; he who would avoid Plays, and not ee the vanity of humane actions, mut find out ome way to get out of the world. Nor are all perons in a capacity to learn how they hould demean themelves by Books and Precepts, but all are uceptible of ome intruction by Playes; ince that in thee, there are uch enible Leons, that the mot ignorant may find in them certain encouragements to Vertue, which on the Stage appears to them in her lutre, and attended by thoe honourable rewards which the Poets betow on Heroick Actions. And as Geographical Maps cannot o well acquaint thoe who tudy them with the dipoitions of people, together with all the circumtances of places, as Travels and Relations may: In like manner, Philoophy mites not the Senes, as thoe paages do which are repreented on the Theatre, where uch as are in Love (the ordinary ubject thereof) may oberve their own Adventures peronated, and take notice of their vain puruits, and the unhappy events of thoe which are carried on by unjut wayes. In fine, if immortality flatters ours labours with promies to tranmit our Memory to Ages; yet at a great ditance from us, what greater atisfaction can there be, than to hope that our noble actions hall be repreented on Theaters before Princes and Magitrates?

The Second aid, That Humane Nature being more enclin'd to evil than to good, thoe confus'd repreentations which are made on the Stage, of all orts of good and bad things, are more likely to make impreions of evil in the minds of men, than to render them more inclinable to that which is good. Whence it is to be inferr'd, that the danger and inconveniences of Plays will outweigh their advantages. This conideration occaion'd the banihing of them out of everal States. And whereas the Subjects of them are commonly taken from the Loves of ome extravagant perons, and the crimes attending them, the end thereof mut be anwerable to the means, which are lewd Artifices, whereby it is compaed, and where-with mens minds are imbu'd, and o inclin'd to wicked actions, and uch as are mot likely to promote the execution of their pernicious deigns; which would not happen, were they ignorant of them. Nay, to go to the original of this kind of entertainments, the mot ancient of them, acted in the time of Romulus, was contriv'd for the urprizal and
carrying away of the Sabine Virgins; it being eaily inferr'd, that what produc'd o bad an effect mut of neceity have been a bad caue.

The Third aid, That Playes conider'd in themelves were indifferent, but that according to the diverity of their Minds who frequent them, they have a different operation; as Wine exceively taken beots and layes ome aleep, and enlivens others, according to the difference of their Temperaments. For if they meet with weak Minds, they imprint in them the Paions of the things that are repreented, much more eaily than Books uually do. But if they are perons of a trong Contitution of Intellectuals, they conider what they ee as a pure Fiction, and a draught of Painting, in the intrigues whereof they find a certain divertiement, much like that of excellent P • inters in their Perpectives; they are pleas'd to ee a mit cat before the eyes of the vulgar, while they themelves are ufficiently atisfi'd, that what others think repreented to the life, is only perform'd by the interpoition of Scenes: So that, from this diverity of operations, this only can be inferr'd, that Playes and Opera's are advantageous and innocent divertiements to uch as are well-vers'd in the affairs of the world, who, being over-pres'd with a continu'd earnetnes in the proecution of their more erious concerns, find a certain relaxation therein; not in a melancholy loath, uch as is inconitent with the activity which is natural to them, but in thoe les erious employments; as on the contrary, thoe perons who are already too much enclin'd to idlenes, vanity, and effeminacy, ought not to be admitted to Plays, in regard they can have no other effect on them, than to make them more effeminate.

The Fourth aid, That as Women are jutly forbidden the ue of the Sciences, o ought they alo to be forbidden the ight of Plays; inamuch as it is not expedient, in order to frugal Houe-keeping, that that Sex hould be allow'd an acquaintance with thoe curioities which might divert them from the care they ought to have of their dometick affairs. For, beides the los of time, idlenes is extreamly prejudicial to that Sex, whoe portion hould be aiduity in labour, frugality, and a contant keeping of the Houe, which is not conitent with the frequenting of Shews and Play-houes, and eeing the repreentations made there: Which, the more intructive they are, and the more likely to fill Womens heads with new things, the more ought they to be forbidden the ight of them; there being not any thing a Huband hould fear o much in his Wife, as an exces of Wit, upon the conceit whereof he aumes to her elf a certain authority over him, contrary to the Intitution of Matrimony, or at leat thinks her elf equal to him, which is not much les to be fear'd, inamuch as it is a great diturbance to the dometick tranquillity. This may be the better apprehended by the example of two Men equally learned, who diputing one againt the other,
eldom come to any agreement, as a knowing and an ignorant peron many times do; for if the latter chance to contradict himelf, he is eaily convinc'd, and acquieces. And though the Greeks ometimes admitted Women in their Academies, to execute the functions of Profeors and Regents, yet are not thoe examples to be introduc'd into this Age, whereof the corruption is uch, as is able to change Vertues into Vices. But, from this general Rule we are to except uch Heroina's, as are the great Exemplars of all Vertues, who urpaing the greatet part of Men in Wit and Intellectuals, it were injurious to think them uceptible of thoe bad impreions, which the Men are able to reit.

The Fifth aid, That the example of the Romans who gave extraordinary alaries to Comedians, as Cicero aures us they did to Rocius, ufficiently hews the advantages of publick repreentations. And indeed, if there be any thing to be blam'd in Plays, it is this, that they are too Pathetick, that is, too apt to raie and expres Humane Paions. For as an Oration meaur'd in Vere, is more elaborate than Proe; o Veres, dipos'd by a ound Judgement for the Stage, are extreamly beyond thoe of Exegematick Poems, wherein only the Poet peaks himelf. Moreover, the obervance of Time, whereto all the Acts are confin'd, and the other Laws of Dramatick Pieces, dicover their excellency above all others. So that to quetion, Whether they are advantageous, is to bring into doubt, Whether the Mater-pieces of Poets, Orators, and Hitorians, are advantageous to a State.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXV. Whether that Temperament of the Body which conduces mot to Health, be alo the mot convenient for the Mind.
div.p:
I Shall not here init on the diviion of the Temperaments, as for intance, into Simple, to wit, when one Quality is predominant over its oppoite, the other two remaining equal, as we affirm him to be of a hot Temperament, who hall be more hot than cold, humidity and drought remaining in an aequilibrium; and Compound, to wit, that which is the reult of the ame combination of qualities, which makes the four Elements: into the niveral, to wit, of the whole Body; and Particular, viz. that which is proper to each part: into that which is of Weight, wherein all thoe qualities are as it were in a balance, one not exceeding the other; and that of Jutice, wherein thoe qualities bear a certain proportion one to the other: Not initing, I ay, on thee Diviions, but preuppoing them as common doctrines; I hall here think it ufficient to examine, in the firt place, Which
of all thee Temperaments is mot convenient, in order to health, and in the econd, whether the ame will alo be mot convenient for the acquiition of a good mind, that is, for the better exercie of the functions of the rational Soul; in a word, whether the mot healthy peron hall always be the mot wie? Galen hath writ an expres Treatie, to prove that the Manners follow the Temperament of the body, and therefore ince thoe manners are the effects of the Will, the noblet of all the faculties of the Soul, in regard it hath a Soveraignty over all the others, it hould eem that the affirmative is to be maintain'd, epecially if we lay this for a ground, that thoe perons who are ubject to Melancholy are the mot ingenious, foramuch as they are the mot healthy; cold and drought making up a more olid and firm mas, then any other two qualities; and heat and moiture being too variable, and too much ubject to corruption. Upon which conideration, Galen, in his firt Book of the Temperaments, chap. 4. denies, That the Spring is hot and moit; on the contrary, aith he, it is the wort of all the Temperaments of the Air whereby we are encompas'd, and that is commonly the contitution obervable in ickly and contagious eaons. In his eighth Book of the Method of curing Dieaes, chap. 7. he adds, That a hot and moit ditemper makes our health incline to corruption. The hot and dry is alo too eaily inclinable to be enflam'd, as the cold and moit is too much ubject to defluxions; and withal to harp Dieaes, uch as are putrid Feavers, for the firt; Burning Feavers, for the econd; and Apoplexies, Palies, and Dropies, for the lat. On the other ide, cold and drought are enemies to corruption, and by thoe very qualities which are contrary thereto, they more powerfully oppoe external injuries, by reaon of the olidity of the kin, and the denity of its parts; as the dipoitions of melancholy perons are not ubject to the paionate diturbances of the Cholerick, the incontancy of the Sanguine, the lothfulnes of the Phlegmatick; and communicate the ame Stability which is in them to the Spirits, which act anwerably thereto. Of this Contitution were all thoe laborious and tudious people, and all the great Perons, whoe aiduous employments have made them famous in their own and ubequent Ages.

The Second aid, That if we may believe the ame Galen, in the ixth Book of the preervation of Health, the hot and moit Temperament is the mot healthy, as being the mot proper to man's nature; and he-further writes, That thoe who are very moit, are long-liv'd, and when their bodies are come to their full trength, they are more healthy then others, and are more robut and hardy then other men of the ame Age, and o continue till they grow old.
