And thence it is, aith he, That all the Phyicians and Philoophers, who have diligently examined the Elements of man's body have commended that Temperament. For, as Aritotle affirms in his Book of a long and hort life, Our life conits in heat and moiture, as cold and drought dipoe us towards death, and the ooner the animal
grows cold and dry, the ooner it grows old and dies. But thee two contrary entiments of Galen may be reconcil'd well enough, by affirming his meaning to be, that exrernal heat and moiture are enemies to health; whereas on the contrary, the natural heat and radical moiture are friends to it; inamuch as thee are never chargeable with exces, but always moderate, one erving for aliment to the other; and they are o far from being capable of receiving any ditemper, that, what reults from them, erves for a rule whereto all the other Temperaments are referred; which the Vulgar improperly calls by the name of the four Humours, that are predominant in them; but that abue being fortify'd by cutom, we mut follow it, though for no other reaon then that we may be the better undertood. Whence it follows, that the Sanguine Temperament is the mot healthy, as being the mot conformable to life. This Temperament is alo the likeliet to produce a good Wit, inamuch as it exercies better then any other the functions of the Rational Soul, which being ditributed between the natural, vital, and animal Faculties, and thee being better exercis'd when they mot abound with clear and purify'd pirits, it is certain, that the Sanguine Temperament, the only treaury of the Spirits, upplies more plentifully, and with uch as are more pure, thoe in whom it is predominant, then it can be imagin'd to do others, in whom that blood is either puffed up by an exceive froath of Choler, or drown'd in the waterihnes of Phlegm, or bury'd in the mud of Melancholy. And this may be oberv'd in the gentilenes, and the ingular leight, nay the eaines, wherewith perons of a anguine Contitution demean themelves in all things they undertake, betraying uch a miling chearfulnes in their eyes and countenance, as dicovers their interiour joy and atisfaction; and is no les delightful to thoe that are preent, then the impetuous allies of the Cholerick give ditate, the luggih delays of the Phlegmatick are tedious, and the profound reveries of the Melancholy hateful and importunate. But as for the incontancy, the only Objection, which the other Temperaments make againt the Sanguine, it is not to be accounted vicious in them, but look'd on as a divertiement, wherewith they are pleas'd, and which they put themelves upon, only that their labours may, by that ohange, be the more delightful to them. Which change is o much the more excuable in them, that they court it not, to the end they hould be idle, but they may apply themelves to ome other employment, which uits better with their humour, uch as the over-long contemplation thereof might not dry up that noble blood which runs in their veins, and, by converting it into dregs, turn the anguine into a melancholick Contitution, to which the obtinacy, wherewith it perits a long time in the proecution of one and the ame deign, is a greater dicommendation, than the incontancy imputed to the anguine is to that, inamuch as the latter makes advantage of it, to wit
that of attempting, and many times executing everal deigns together, epecially when it undertakes uch as it is ure to mater, uch as may be Dancing, Muick, Courthip, well-concontriv'd Stories, and uch other pleaant things. And indeed, it is impoible to exercie the functions of the mind well, when the body is indipos'd; as on the contrary, when the body is in perfect health, the mind acts its part o much the better.

The Third aid, That it were very unjut to deprive of the honour due to them, the Heroes and Worthies of the World, whoe temperament mut needs have been cholerick, by attributing to any of the others the great and noble actions of the mind, which belong to them. Now to demontrate that the temperament of the Heroes conited of heat and drought, we need bring in no further evidence, than the uddennes and expedition wherewith they undertake and execute all their deigns, as it were complying with the activity of Fire, which hath the upremacy among the Elements, as they have the preheminence amongt men. Nay it may be urged, that great enterprizes would never be executed without ome degree of choler, which erves as it were for alt to all humane actions. This premis'd, as out of all dipute, we now come to conider whether the hot and dry Temperament be the mot conitent with health. I affirm then, that it is more conitent with it, than the Phlegmatick, which abounds in excrements; then the Sanguine, which eaily admits of alterations; nay alo then the Melancholick, whoe gros humours are more ubject to obtruction, then Choler is, the vivacity whereof is to be een upon all occaions; thoe of the Cholerick Contitution having always their Veels large, and, as uch, much more unlikely to be topp'd up.

The Fourth aid, that o far as the oul and body are different, o far are alo their qualities uch. From which conideration Aritotle took occaion to affirm, That robut bodies are deign'd to obey, as the weak are to command, inamuch as commonly they are the receptacles of a tronger oul. This rais'd a peruaion in ome, that the mot imperfect bodies have commonly the mot perfect ouls, alledging to that purpoe, the example of the crooked and ill-hap'd Tree, which upplies us with the bet of Liquors, Wine; whereas the trait and fair-preading Oaks, bear nothing but acorns, for the feeding of Swine. Beides, as the word pirit or mind is ometimes taken for the Invention which principally conits in the Imagination; ometimes for the Judgment, or Undertanding; and might be alo taken for the Memory, among which this lat requires a hot and moit temperament, as the firt is pleas'd with a hot and dry; and the econd, to wit the judgment, conits in the dry and cold, which makes men taid and ettled: o is it accordingly requiite, that we hould ditinguih, of which of thee three faculties the quetion is to be undertood. But generally peaking, it is not eaily imaginable, that there hould be a well-fram'd mind in a much-indipos'd
body, inamuch as there is the ame proportion between them, as there is between the mold and the figure cat in it; a Palace, and him who dwells in it. The ame thing may much more rationally be aid of the humours, from which the pirits being drawn bring their quality along with them: o that the Temperament which is mot convenient in order to health, will alo be the mot convenient for the functions of the Soul.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXVI. Whether it be more expedient for a Man to have only one Friend or many.
div.p:
SInce Man is no further to be called o, then as he is ociable, and that there is no Society more delightful then that of Converation, which cannot be better maintain'd then by the relation and correpondence there is between uch as are of a like dipoition, which preuppoe a Friendhip; it hould eem, that it is not grounded only on Reaon, but alo on Nature her elf, which ubits altogether by that Union, as he is abolutely detroy'd by dicord. And this is principally made apparent in civil life, wherein Friendhip is o powerful, that, being religiouly oberv'd, there will be no need of Jutice, ince every one would voluntarily render that to another which is due to him, which is the proper Work of that Vertue: which being in like manner well adminitred, that of Fortitude would alo be unneceary; and it would be uperfluous to ue the rigour of the Laws, to oblige men to the doing of a thing which they exercied without any compulion. Hence it came that the wiet Law-givers, as Aristotle affirms in his Ethicks, took more pains in etablihing the Laws of Friendhip among their Citizens, then thoe of Jutice; inamuch as thee latter take place, only upon the non-obervance of the former, which are o much the more durable, in regard they are grounded upon the pure freedom of the Will, without any other obligation, then that which our own choice hath impos'd on it elf, of its own accord, in a legal friendhip. Its nature alo is as much conceal'd as its effects are manifet, which are o convincing, that thoe, who have poken mot advantageouly of them, affirm that to take away Friendhip were to deprive the World of the light of the Sun; and that humane Society may as well be without it, as want the ue of Fire and Water. Nor is it their meaning to peak of that irregular Paion, produc'd by the motion of the concupicible Appetite, which is inclin'd towards a delightful good, and which only flattering the Senes, thoe who are carry'd away with it are called amorous Perons, and not Friends; but, of that Queen
of Vertues, which is enthron'd in the rational Appetite, excited by a vertuous Good, which being conceiv'd as amiable, and proportion'd to the Will, he loves and trictly embraces it, cauing uch a perfect union between him who loves, and him who is belov'd, that they are but one heart and one oul, which, for that reaon is aid to be rather where it loves then where it lives. So that it being not to be imagin'd, that uch an union can be among many, neither can true friendhip be among many, but only between two, whoe mutual correpondence being the greater, their Friendhip is conequently more firm and durable. And it is more compleat between thee two Relatives, then it can be among many, whoe correpondence being more difficult, for want of the conditions requiite to Friendhip, which are not o eaily met with in a greater number, it is poible they may have a certain kindnes and good-will one towards another, but not a olid and incere Friendhip, which looks on a friend, as a econd Self, a relation that hath place only between two, whom Antiquity, for that reaon, order'd always to go by Couples.

The Second aid, That Friendhip could not continue long only between two friends, in regard that there being not any one but is chargeable with ome imperfection, it is impoible but that it hould produce ome coldnes and indifference, in his apprehenions who takes notice of it, and that in time will come to an alienation, as it commonly happens in Friendhip. And this is yet the farther from being wel-etled, upon this accompt, that continual familiarity coming to dicover the weaknees of one or the other, it can never be long without ome punctilio's and diputes, which are many times advanc'd to uch a height, that there is a neceity of a third peron to compoe their differences. Now this mut be done by one who is a common friend to both, and conequently, to etablih a permanent friendhip, it is requiite there hould be three, a number the more highly to be eteemed, in that the Graces conit of it; without which, Friendhip will be but of a hort continuance. Upon that accompt it was that the Tyrant Dionyius wih'd that he might make up the third, with thoe two intimate, friends Damon and Pythias. The Scythians alo, as Lucian affirms, to make up a perfect friendhip, requir'd that there hould be three perons, who drunk together out of a Veel, into which they had pilt ome drops of their blood, wherewith they dy'd the points of their words.

The Third aid, That Friendhip, in repect of our Will, was as Science in repect of our Undertanding. For as this latter hath a natural inclination to Knowledge, o the Will is endu'd with uch another to Love, inamuch as in it he finds her overaign good. Thence it comes, that as there are ome pirits o ublime, that, not content with one only knowledge, they embrace everal, whereas there are others o circumcrib'd and confin'd, that only one Science wholly takes them up o, as that they
are not able to make any progres into others; o are there ome Souls o limitted in their affection, that it can be dilated but to one object, which checks, and makes them incapable of loving any more, as thoe generous and heroick hearts do, which have o trong a bent to do well and to love; that, not atifi'd with one object, they diffue their affections to all thoe whom they think worthy thereof. And o the deciion of the quetion hould depend on the Capacities of thoe who love, ince that, conidering the amiable objects, whether they be uch, and, conequently, there be caue for the loving of them, or are not really uch, but only o conceiv'd by the apprehenive faculty, they are equally fit to move the Will to love them, and to gain its affections; and they ought to be the more agreeable to it, in that it finds in them its perfection and the accomplihment of its deires. And o the plurality of Friends is o far from being any prejudice to Friendhip, that it ets a greater eteem upon it, as alo on him who loves.

The Fourth aid, That Friendhip, taken generally, is a mutual Good-will between thoe who are deirous to do one another ome reciprocal kindnes; but taking it more preciely, it may be defin'd a Vertue, by means whereof vertuous perons are o united in Affection and Will, that they become abolutely like one another, through a hearty good Will, Concord, and good Turns mutually done and receiv'd. The former reides particularly in the interior motions of the mind; the econd, in words and dicoure; the third, in effects. Thee are the three eential marks of a vertuous Friendhip; which, not regarding its proper interet, as thoe do, who love upon the account of pleaure or profit, courts not the objects it loves, out of any other conideration than that of the Vertue or Science which render it recommendable. Now thee qualities being eldom found among many, who ought to be equally furnih'd therewith, that the Friendhip may be reciprocal, it is very hard to meet with o many Subjects capable of o ublime a Vertue as that; which, beides that combination of Vertues, requiring much experience, and a great proces of time that we might not be deceiv'd in the choice of Friends, (with each whereof a Man, according to the common aying, hould eat a buhel of Salt before he contracted a Friendhip) it will be found a much harder tak to make uch a trict examination of the qualities and dipoitions of many, than it will be to do it of one alone; with whom, conequently, it is more afe to enter into Friendhip, than it can be with many.

The Fifth aid, That Friendhip being grounded on converation, and there being not any more divertive and delightful than that between thoe who eat and drink together, the Cae is the ame with friends as it is with guets, which ought not to be under the number of three, nor exceed that of nine; whence came the ancient Proverb, that a well-ordered Feat hould not be under the number of the Graces, nor trancend that of the Mues. In a word, ince converation is the ground-work of
perfect Friendhip, as the former cannot be pleaant among les than three, and mut be confus'd and weariome among above nine; but is mot divertive, when five or ix perons well-qualifi'd, and perfectly undertanding one the other, fall into mutual dicoure; o Friendhip cannot be of long continuance between two, but there mut be a third to encourage it; yet with this further caution, that it is better maintain'd among a greater number of perons equally vertuous, provided nevertheles it exceed not that of nine, to prevent the confuion and inconvenices attending a greater.

The Sixth aid, That though there be an abolute neceity of Friendhip, in all he tranactions of humane life, in order to the more pleaant expence of it, yet are there principally two certain times, wherein its neceity is more apparent, to wit, thoe of Properity and Adverity. In the former, our friends participate of our happines, in the latter, of our misfortunes; and whereas thee lat are commonly more frequent than good uccees, the plurality of Friends, who are our econd-elves, making the burthen the more upportable by the part every one takes in our misfortunes; it is much more expedient that a Man hould have many, then content himelf with a mall number, which being not able to bear the brunt of o violent an aault, he would be in danger of being overcome thereby. Nay, though all things hould happen according to our wihes, yet were it convenient to have a coniderable number of Friends, the more to congratulate our good fortune, which will make the greater noie in the world, the greater their number is who approve and applaud it.

The Seventh aid, That the plurality of Friends was equally inconvenient, as well in good as bad fortune. For, in the latter, it mut needs trouble us very much to give occaion of grief to a great number of Friends, who though they bemoan us ever o much, yet are we till in the ame period of misfortune; nay, our unhappines is the greater, in that it is contagiouly communicated to o many perons at the ame time. In the former, there cannot be any thing more troubleom then that great number of people who love, or pretend to love us in our properity, it being then impoible for us equally to atisfie them all, as we might eaily do one ingle Friend, from whom we may alo derive greater comfort in Adverity, than from many addreing themelves to us at the ame time; to whoe humours to accommodate our elves well, we mut tudy an uncontancy equal to that of Proteus, and put on as many Countenances as they have different Inclinations.

The Eighth aid, That ince a good thing is o much the more excellent, the more it is communicated and diffus'd everal ways, Friendhip ought to derive its eteem from that communication, which the greater it hall be, the more recommendable hall it make the Friendhip, which, conequently, is the more perfect
among many, to whom it is always advantageous, ince it comprehends the three kinds of Goods, the profitable, the pleaant, and the vertuous. For, is there not much to be gain'd in a ociety, which the more numerous it is, the greater advantages and aitances may be deriv'd from it? There is not any thing o highly delightful as to love and to be belov'd of many. But whereas Friendhip is the Livery of Vertue, whoe ineparable attendant he is, Can there be any thing more vertuous and commendable then after that manner to love everal others who love us, and by that reflux of mutual kindnes give aurances of our Vertue, anwerable to the acknowledgements we had made of their merit; the multitude of Friends not abating any thing of the eteem of civil Friendhip, no more than the great number of charitable perons does prejudice Charity which is a conummate Love, and equally embraces all?

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXVII. Of Oracles.
div.p:
THere is not anything diquiets the Spirit of Man o much as the deire he hath to know things to come; and whereas he cannot of himelf attain thereto, by reaon of the weaknes of his knowledge, which he derives from, the Senes and other corporeal powers; he will needs try what he can do out of himelf, and there is no place into which his curioity hath not found a way to dicover what he o much deir'd. But in fine, after he had to no purpoe ought this knowledge in the Elements and all Natural Bodies coniting of them, upertitious Antiquity be thought it elf of another way to gain it, which was to addres it elf to thoe counterfeit Divinities, whom the Holy Scriptures aures us have been no other than Devils, whom it elewhere calls the Gods of the Gentiles. For thee, after they had, by in, lot the gift of Grace, having conerv'd that of a mot perfect Science, and o general, that there is not any thing in all Nature which they know not, and cannot foretell (excepting only uch effects as are purely free, which are known only to God) thoe ancient Idolaters have oftentimes been inform'd by them of things to come, conulting them to that purpoe, when they were upon the undertaking of ome Affair of great importance, the ucces whereof was doubtful, reolving upon the proecution thereof, according to the Anwers of thoe fale Gods called Oracles, in regard they were pronounc'd either by their mouths, or thoe of their Miniters. The manner of declaring them was two-fold; one, by Dreams, or Nocturnal-Viions; the other, by an expres Voice, which was ditinctly heard by thoe who came to conult them. The Oracles, which were deliver'd in
Dreams, though they were not o clear as thoe receiv'd by the Voice, were nevertheles coniderable proportionably to the eteem made of the perons who were the Interpreters of them, and the places where they were deliver'd. That of Amphiaraus was the mot remarkable of any; in which, after the accutomed expiations, thoe who came to conult him, laid themelves down on the ground upon the skins of uch Rams as had been acrific'd to the Gods, whoe names were written upon the Altar, and were in that poture intructed in what they deired to know. The ame Ceremonies were heretofore ued among the Aegyptians and the Greeks, in the Temples of Serapis and Aeculapius, where thoe mute Divinities return'd their Anwers only to uch as were aleep, who conulted them principally for the cure of their Dieaes.

The econd way, which was by expres voice, was either perform'd by the whipering-places of certain Grots; or by the mouths of uch Statues as were dedicated to the aid Divinities; which Statues, for that reaon, had their mouths always open, and ready to peak;, or by the mouths of the Priets and Sibylls, who being eiz'd by a acred fury pronounced the Oracles with a certain impetuounes of voice, and violent contorions of the countenance, not unlike thoe of ditracted people among us; or latly, by the mouths even of brute beats, which the tupidity of thoe poor blinded people alo made ue of to that end. Thus the Aegyptians worhipped and conulted an Ox, under which figure they repreented their God Apis, whoe Oracles were accounted favourable, when he chearfully receiv'd the fodder preented to him, but it ignify'd the contrary, when he refued to open his mouth to receive it; and this was interpreted a preignification of the death of Germanicus. The Tenedians oberved the ame Ceremonies towards a Cow, big with Calf; the Nubians, a people of Aethiopia, the ame towards a Dog, and the Perians towards a Cock, the different accents of whoe crowing ditinguih'd their Oracles. Among thee, the Oracles which ome went to hear in the vat deerts beyond the Country of the Garamantes, at the Temple of Jupiter Ammon, though they were the mot venerable of any, as being the mot ancient, were nevertheles as ridiculous as any of the ret, being grounded only on a imple motion of the body, a bowing of the head, a wink with the eye, which thoe that were preent imagin'd they had oberved in the Statue of that Controller of the Gods, ador'd in that deolate place, with the head and horns of a Hee-goat. He was a little more familiar in the City of Dodona in Epirus, where he had alo a very magnificent Temple, taking the pains to pronounce his Oracles ometimes with his own divine mouth, and ometimes uing thoe of two Virgins, whereof one, called Peritera, which ignifies a Dove, gave occaion to the Fable, wherein it was reported, that, in the Temple of Jupiter at Dodona, there were Doves that poke, as well as Oaks, which
anwer'd the quetions that had been put to them. The manner thus; thoe high Trees being haken by the ordinary Winds of thoe Countries made a great noie there, which was encreas'd by that of a great number of Bras-kettles faten'd to the branches of them, amidt the ound whereof thoe Oracles were deliver'd, that they might be receiv'd with greater reverence. But whereas the Art of Divination was by a pecial priviledge reerv'd to Apollo among all thoe Gods, his Oracles were accordingly look'd upon as the mot certain. Thence it alo came, that he was worhipped, upon that account, in everal parts of the World, epecially in the Iland of Delos, one of the Cyclades, the place of his Birth, where there was an Altar built of horns taken from the right ide of the heads of everal Animals, neatly laid one upon the other with incomparable dexterity; the horns of the left ide being not it eems o proper for Divination. He there return'd his Anwers under a humane hape, as in Lycia he did it under that of a Wolf: But in his Temple at Delphi, a place remarkable for its cituation, as being in the midt of the World, whence it was conceiv'd to be as it were the navel of it, he made his Anwers ometimes through the throat of a Dragon, under which form he was there honoured, ometimes by the mouths of his Prietees, who, after they had been haken for a certain time by a violent wind, which iu'd out of a deep and obcure cave, whereby they felt themelves animated and agitated into a more then natural motion, pronounc'd their Oracles, ometimes in Proe, ometimes in Vere, according to the impreions of that Divinity whereby they were inpir'd. But to render thee yet more Majetick, thoe Prietees affected certain precie days, as for example thoe of the Calends and Ides, and requir'd certain particular dipoitions, that they might the more inolently impoe upon the more credulous: And thee conited in certain expiations and preparations, in order to their being more worthily uceptible of that divine inpiration, which the Pythian Prietes pretended her elf fit to entertain, after he had drunk of the Water of the fountain of Delos; as another, who erv'd the ame God at Colophon, imagin'd her elf worthy of it, when he had drunk of a neighbouring Spring, the Water whereof put her into an immediate fury. At Argos there was a neceity of drinking the blood of a Lamb, and at Aegira, that of a Bull, ere the Oracles could be gotten out of them. But what mot dicovers their vanity, is, that even thoe who conulted them (which they did only to comply with the weaknes of the people, and gain reputation among the imple) if they found them not favourable, either went on nevertheles in the proecution of their deigns, or forc'd them to pronounce uch as hould be to their advantage. This coure was taken by Alexander the Great and Cleomenes; by the former, when he conulted the Pythian; by the other, when he conulted the Delphick Oracle, both which they forc'd to ay what they pleas'd themelves.
Thence it came, that mot of the ancient Philophers exclaim'd againt them, and the Platonits, who made a greater account of them then any of the other Sects, acknowledge, that they are no other then the mot depicable Devils, and thoe of the lowet rank, who engage themelves in that employment, which they mut needs practie in deert and dreadful places, to the end there might be fewer witnees of their weaknes and impotures. Thee are apparent in their very Anwers, which, if not fale, were o ambiguous, or at leat o obcure, that many times there needed another Oracle to explain them. Nor were they in vogue, but during the darknes of Paganim, which being dipell'd by the light of the Gopel, thoe Oracles never durt appear in that glorious day, which would have dicover'd their lying and falhood.

The Second aid, That the Art of Divination being conjectural, and grounded on experience, as well as everal others of that nature, it is not to be admir'd, that the Anwers of thoe who heretofore made profeion thereof were not always true: and therefore it is as irrational a procedure to draw any conequences thence to its prejudice, as to infer, that the Precepts of Medicine are fale, becaue the Phyician does not always make his Prognoticks aright. The General of an Army may ometimes proceed upon wrong grounds; and the expert Pilot may run upon thoe helves and rocks which he mot endeavours to avoid. True it is that the ubtilty of the Devil, and depravednes of Mankind have foited abundance of abues into the buines of Oracles, epecially in the erecting of thoe Statues to thoe fabulous Divinities, which they commonly made of Olive-tree, Lawrel, Vine, Cedar, or ome uch kind of wood, full of unctuous moiture, which they aid were the tears or weat of their fale Gods; as alo in the pompous Ceremonies, wherewith they amued the credulous Vulgar. Such were thoe of Trophonius among the Thebans, who anwer'd only thoe who being clad in white decended through a hole of the cave into his Temple, and there offered cakes to the Spirits which inhabited it; after which they were convey'd out at another place of the cave, where they drunk the Water of the Fountain of Memory, which caus'd them to remember whatever they had heard; as they had drunk that of Lethe before they had entred into it, which had caus'd them to forget all affairs of the World. But we are not hence to conclude, that all Oracles were fale, nor doubt of the validity of that ublime Art, upon its being diparag'd by thoe who have profes'd it, ince it hath its grounds, not only in the inclination of mens minds, who having an extraordinary earnetnes to know things to come, there mut needs be ome Science for the attaining of that Knowledge; otherwie Nature, who had imprinted that deire in him, hould, contrary to her cutom, have done omething in vain; but alo in the dipoitions of that Temperament which is ubject to Melancholy, or black
Choler. For, the former of thee is the Temperament of the more ingenious ort of people, according to the Philopher in his Problems; and the other, being more replendent, is that of perons enclin'd to Divination, occaion'd by the clear repreentation of the Species in that humour, which being bright and mooth as a Mirrour, cannot o well be dicover'd by thoe who are not of that Contitution; to which Plato in his Memnon attributes the caue of Apollo's Prietee's pronouncing the Oracles in Hexameter Vere, though he had never learnt Poeie; and Pompanatius in his Books of Enchantments, affirms, that it caus'd a Woman, who never was out of Mantua, where he was born, to peak everal trange Languages.

The Third aid, That Divination being above the reach of our Undertanding, as much as this latter is below the Divinity, which hath reerv'd to it elf the priviledge of a ditinct knowledge of things to come, it is to no purpoe to eek for the true caues of it in our elves, but we are to find them in the Heavens, whence, if we may believe the Profeors of Atrology, that quality of Divination or Prediction is communicated to Men by the interpoition of the Intelligences, whereby thoe vat Bodies are moved, and that Science taught, by making it appear how great a correpondence there is between the effects of the ublunary Bodies, and the uperior caues on which they depend, and wherein they are potentially comprehended, even before they are actually exitent. Whereto if you add the concoure of the Univeral Spirit, which equally animates the whole world, and the parts whereof it conits, and which meeting with convenient dipoitions in the minds of men, and the everal places where Oracles have been given, inpir'd thoe extraordinary motions, which have rais'd the Spirit of man, and open'd its way into effects the mot at a ditance from his knowledge: Admitting, I ay, uch a concoure, there may ome probable reaon be given of thee Predictions, not only of things, whoe caues being natural and neceary, their effects are infallible, uch as are Eclipes, the Riing, Setting, and Regular Motions of the Planets; or of thoe whoe caues are only probable, as it is reported that Pherecydes foretold a dreadful Earth-quake, by the boyling up of the water in his own Well; and Thales foreaw the carcity of Olives in the Territories of Athens: But alo of effects, which having only contingent or free caues, lie not o obvious to dicovery; and yet thee being denoted by the general caues, uch as are the Heavens and the Univeral Spirit, thoe perons who have clear-ighted and illuminated Souls may perceive them therein, even before they happen.

The Fourth aid, That there are three general caues of Oracles, one Supernatural; another, Artificial; and the third, Natural; and that, not to peak any thing of the Supernatural, whereof the Devils were the Authors, and made ue of it to continue till in their firt Rebellion, when they attempted to
acend into the Throne of God, and be like him; nor yet of their Artificial Caue, which was certain perons devoted to their worhip, who retiring into Caves and Subterraneous places, were incited by thoe evil Spirits to that ordid Minitry, that o by that means they might lay nares for the imple, who were eaily drawn away by thee fale Lights. The Natural Caue of thoe Oracles, epecially uch as were pronounc'd out of the celebrated Caves and Grots of Antiquity, was a ubtile Exhalation rais'd out of thoe places, which, fatening on the Spirits of the Prophet or Prophetes already dipos'd to receive that impreion, had the ame Influence on them as the fumes of Wine have on thoe who drink it to exces; whether that evaporation be caus'd by the quality of the Earth or Waters, or proceed from the Metals, Minerals, and other Foile Bodies, contained within their entrails. For if it be acknowledg'd, that the waters paing through them, derive certain particular qualities, Why may not as well thoe vapours do the like, nay, haply in a greater meaure, and, conequently, work thoe extraordinary effects? Nay, upon conideration, they will not be found more miraculous than what is related of an Exhalation which iues out of a Cave near Hieropolis, which, as it is affirm'd, is fatal only to Men, and not to thoe who have not lot their Virginity; nor yet than the water of a Fountain in Boeotia, which caues Mares to run mad, as that which was in the Temple of Bacchus at Andros, had the tate of Wine; that of Delphi lighted thoe Torches which were within a certain ditance of it, and extinguih'd thoe which were thrut into it. Now uch qualities as thee are, depending on the properties of the places; it may be as eaily conceiv'd, that thoe, where uch Anwers of the fale Gods were given, had the like: and thence it is to be imagin'd, that thoe having ceas'd by the ordinary viciitude of all things, the aid Oracles accordingly receiv'd alo their period.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXVIII. Of the Tingling of the Ears.
div.p:
AS the Ear is the Intrument of that Sene which is called the Sene of the Diciple, and is more erviceable to us in order to Intruction, than all the ret put together; o is it not to be wondred, the Ancients hould be of Opinion, that it contributed o highly thereto, that the mot inconiderable motions of it advertie us of things which eem to be farthet from our knowledge. Thence it came that they deduc'd certain conjectures of things to come from the tingling of the Ears, which they held to ignifie good luck when it was on the right ide; and the contrary, when it happen'd on the left Ear: which is to repreent
enemies, as the former does friends; yet with this proviion, that nothing contributed thereto from without, as for example, noie might do, or ome other agitation of the air, tirr'd by ome external caue, but the tingling mut proceed from within; onitu uopte tinniunt aures, without which condition it ignifies neither good nor bad luck, that is, nothing at all. And what eems omewhat to confirm this obervation, is, that it hath not been cat out among all the other rubbih of upertitious Antiquity, but reigns even in the preent Age, wherein not only many among the Vulgar commonly ay, that they are well or ill-poken of, when their ears glow or tingle, but alo ome of the better ort are alo of the ame perwaion. They ground this belief on the Sympathy or Antipathy there is between Friends and Enemies, which are uch, that not being confin'd by the ditance of places, which yet according to their opinion ought not to be too great, they force the pecies of voice and words towards the organs of Hearing, which are thereby excited, through the communication of thoe Magnetick Vertues, and thee are not les enible then thoe which the objects direct towards the ame intruments in ordinary enation; though they be more delicate and ubtile. As the Lynx, the Eagle, and other harp-ighted Animals ee the pecies of viible objects far beyond their reach who are horter-ighted; and the Birds of prey mell carcaes though they are very far from them.

The Second aid, That it was a little too far fetcht, to attribute thoe Effects to Sympathy, which being as abtrue as what ome pretend to deduce from it, amounts to as much, as if one would prove one obcure thing by another which is yet more obcure. As therefore there is no action done beyond the limits appointed to every Agent, which comprehend the phere of their activity, o can there not be any uch between the onorous Species, and the Hearing of him who feels this Tingling, unles it be within the reach of his ear; which ince it cannot be, when, for example, we are poken of in our abence, it is impoible the Hearing hould receive the impreion of the voice pronounc'd in a place at too great a ditance to be conveyd to it, inamuch as it is neceary in all enation, that, beides the good dipoition of the enitive Faculty and the Mean, there hould be a proportionate ditance between the enible object and the organ, ere it can judge well of it. So that thoe who imagine they hear what is aid of them afar off upon no other reaon then that their ears tingle, have not their Hearing more enibly, but, on the contrary, wore qualifi'd then others, through the diturbance caus'd therein by gros humours, which occaion the ame diorder in the Ear as uffuions do in the eye, when it ees the Objects in the ame colour and figure as the vapours or humours, whereby it is clouded, though they be not effectually o. In like manner, the ound or noie, heard by thoe whoe ears tingle, though it makes them conceive the pecies of uch a ound
proceeding from without, is only illuory, and caus'd by the diorder of the ill-affected organ, but it communicates its irregularity to the Imagination, when it frames to it elf favourable conequences from uch a humming in the right Ear, and ome misfortune from the like in the left, there being not any reaon, by which o fantatick and chimerical an opinion can be maintain'd.

The Third aid, That it is injuriouly done to deny Man that advantage which we find by experience, that ome, not only brute Beats, but alo Plants have, to wit that of having a previous feeling of the good or evil which are to happen to them by a property betow'd on them by Nature for their conervation. Thus we find Rats forake the houe which will oon after fall down; Lice take leave of one that is dying; Birds of prey come from far ditant places to their food; the Swallow comes to give us a viit in the Spring, and pends that delightful eaon with us; which once pat, he goes to find out other Springs in unknown Countries. The Ox gives us notice of an approaching hower, when, having lifted up his head very high, and breath'd withall, he immediately falls a licking his thighs; The Cat makes the ame Prognotication, when he combs her elf as it were, with her paws; The ame thing is done by the Water-fowl called the Ducker, and the ordinary, Drake, when they ettle their feathers with their beaks; The Frogs do the ame by their importunate croaking; The Ants, by the extraordinary earnetnes they expres in hoarding up their corn; and the Earth-worms, when they appear above ground; Nay, the poor Trefoyl will cloe it elf upon the approach of a Tempet, as do alo mot Plants in foul weather; which being over, they pread abroad their leaves and flowers, and eem newly blown, as it were to congratulate the return of the Sun, as is done, among others, by the Marigold, which for that reaon is called Heliotropium; for the great correpondence there is between it and that all-enlivening Star. Nay, that correpondence is alo o remarkably obvious in the other Plants, that thoe who have oberv'd them mot exactly, affirm, that there is not any herb o depicable, but it hath an interiour character, anwerable to that of ome Star, which communicates its vertues and qualities to it, and thence it comes to be called a terretrial Star. Why therefore hould it come into dipute, whether Man hath uch a Priviledge, as that he may be enible of what is prejudicial or advantageous to him, by that tingling of the Ear, which may well be the ign thereof though the caue be not abolutely manifet? For, experience it elf and the effects conequent to the obervation do very much confirm it, for thoe being commonly anwerable to what had been conceiv'd by thoe to whom that kind of Divination by the Ears had happened, there is as much ground to give it ome credit, as there is to deduce any thing from ome other les coniderable accidents, from which the like
conjectures are made; uch as are, for example, among others, the twinkling of the Eyes, neezing, the meeting of omething extraordinary, epecially a Negro, an Eunuch, or ome other defective peron; and the triking of ones feet againt the threhold of his own door, which prov'd fatal to C. Gracchus, who was murther'd the very day that uch an accident had happened to him; as alo to Craus, the day he was defeated by the Parthians. In all which igns there is much les likelihood of declaring the accidents, which ome would attribute thereto, than may be imagin'd in the Tingling of the Ear, as being the eat of the Memory, which the Ancients for that reaon were wont to tir up, by plucking the tip of it; and if it be true what Plato aith, that all our Knowledge is but Reminicence, and that we only remember the Species of things, which had been before in our Undertanding, it will be no hard matter to find out ome ground for this praeenion.

The Fourth aid, That there was no other conjecture to be drawn from this Tingling of the Ear, than that the Peron ubject thereto, hath a weak and ill-dipos'd Brain, which breeding abundance of ill humours, if they come to make any toppage in the paages of the Ear, its action is vitiated and obtructed by that Tingling, which is a ymptom of a deprav'd Hearing, and caues the party to hear an importunate ound or noie, though there be not any made without, and that there be not any application of the hollownes of the hand to the Ear, in which cae it hears ome uch noie. 'Twould therefore be ridiculous to look after any other caues thereof than what may be in the dipoition of the Brain, and the excrements it produceth, on the diverity whereof as alo on that of their Motion in the Ears, that Tingling depends; as do alo the Breathing, the Ringing, the Buzzing, and the Swimming of the Ear, which are Symptoms of a deprav'd Hearing; the breathing or blowing being done by a little blat which gets out gently; the Tingling by the interruption of its motion; the ringing proceeds from a more gros vapour, and uch as blows more trongly; as the reounding does from an impulion yet more vehement; and latly, the Swimming is caus'd by the agitation of thee as well vaporous as pirituous matters, which being different and differently moved, produce thoe different ounds. And therefore it is aburd, to derive any other marks of what hould happen to us, then thoe laid down in Medicine, which teaches us, that they who are ubject to thee frequent tinglings and ringings of the Ears are in their way to Deafnes, by reaon of the danger there is, that thee vaporous humours hould make o trong an obtruction in the organs of Hearing, that the auditory air cannot get into it, to make enation: and if this happen in a burning Feaver, together with dimnes of the eyes, it is a certain preage of the ditraction or madnes, which ordinarily follows that noie of the Ear.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXIX. Of Philtres, and whether there be any proper Remedies for the procuring of Love.
div.p:
THere is not any thing o pleaant and delightful as to be belov'd; To procure that, it is requiite there hould be ome perfection, which being conceiv'd uch by the peron whoe favour is courted, it prevails o far upon his Inclinations, that he cannot forbear being in Love with it. Thus is it that a known Truth doth o fully atisfie our Undertanding, that it cannot deny its conent thereto: Thus is the Will o trongly engag'd upon the puruance of a Good which eems delightful to her, that it is hardly in her power to gain-ay it; nay, he is of her elf inclin'd thereto, not needing any other Charms to induce her thereto, than thoe he meets with in the goodnes of the Object which he loves. Thee are real Philtres which never fail to raie Love in thoe that have them; there is no neceity of looking after other Remedies, all which are us'd either to a bad end, or to none at all. Deianira, deirous to make ue of them, in order to her being better belov'd by her Huband Hercules, prov'd the occaion of his death, by the means of a garment, which he ent him dy'd with the Blood of the Centaur Neus. Another Woman, as Aritotle affirms in his greater work of Ethicks, brought her Huband to the ame Fate, after he had made him take a Medicine of that kind. Lucilia adminitring uch a Philtre to the Poët Lucretius her Huband, put him into uch a ditraction that he kill'd himelf. The like was done by the Emperour Lucilius, after he had taken uch a one from the hands of Callithenes; as alo by Caligula, after he had drunk off one of thee potions into which there had been put a piece of that fleh which is found on the fore-heads of young Colts as oon as they are cat, called in Latine Hippomanes, an ingredient particularly recommended among thee Medicaments. In which Receipts, we find alo the brains of Cows when they would go to Bull, and thoe of young Aes, the bones of a green Frog, the little Fih called the Remora, the Matrix of the Hyaena, and the little Bird call'd Motacilla, the Wagtail, from its continual wagging of the tail, which it eems is o effectual a Remedy for the procuring of Love, that Pindar, in his fourth Ode of the Nemaea, acknowledges that his Heart was o trongly drawn away and charm'd by the means thereof, that he could not forbear Loving. But though it were granted, that thee Remedies had ome particular Vertues to excite Love in thoe to whom they had been adminitred, yet would it not follow thence, that they hould make that Love mutual, by obliging them to love thoe by whom
they are belov'd. For thoe to whom they are given commonly not knowing, nay, many times having an averion for the others, it is impoible that thee Philtres hould be able to force People's Wills and Inclinations, which are always free to love what they know not; or if they know it, have a horrour and averion for it. Otherwie it would amount to as much, as to give them a certain Sovereignty over a free power; uch as the Will is, which it cannot endure, as being above all Corporeal Agents, uch as thee Medicaments are. Among which, as there are ome have the vertue of extinguihing the flames of Concupicence and Carnal Love, by correcting the heat of the Blood, diminihing the quantity of the Seed, and dipering the Spirits whereby it is raied; o on the contrary, there are others, which as it were awake and excite that Paion, by the production they make of abundance of good and pirituous eed, and, conequently, may indeed invite thoe who ue them, to that bae and unbridled Love, but not to a mutual Love, uch as is particularly directed to him, who finding his affection leighted, is forc'd to give thee Remedies that he may be belov'd by the peron whom he courts.

The Second aid, That Love and the Graces, if we may credit thoe Authentick Authors the Poets, always kept company with Venus, whereby they would ignifie to us, that the mot effectual means which any one can ue to ininuate himelf into the Love of another, was, to become himelf amiable and agreeable; and that thoe who pretend to do it by other wayes, do many times come hort of their intentions; or if they at lat come to be lov'd, it is by uch a perverion of the party's imagination whom they court, that, intead of framing a rational and well-regulated Paion, they raie therein that fury and rage, which the Phyicians call Erotomania. Thence it comes that to accomplih their de • res, beides uch means as are natural, they alo make ue of all the diabolical Artifices and Inventions that Magick can furnih them withall, to compas that piece of Witchcraft. To that purpoe, they make ue of Mandrakes, wherewith the women prepare a certain Drink for the men, adminitring the female to procure themelves to be lov'd by them; and the men caue them to take the male, that they may belov'd by the women They aign the ame properties to the Herb Calamint, affirming, that it gains the Heart, and raies it into uch a heat, that it is inclin'd to love him who gives it, and the ame thing is aid of everal other odoriferous Herbs, which eem to have a tricter connexion with the effect they promie themelves from them, than an infinite number of other impious and aburd things, whereof they make an extraordinary account. As for intance, among others the Mentrua of Women; the Navel-tring of a Child newly born, reduc'd to powder, and taken in a potion; as alo the kin of uch a one where-with they make their Virgin-parchment, on which they write their Characters; Eggs dipp'd in the Blood of
a Toad; a certain bone taken out of the throat of a alt Bitch; the feathers of a Scrich-Owle; and epecially the parings of the Nails, together with the Hair of the Head, or of any other part of the Body; and for want of thoe, ome mall thread of the peron's garment whom they would engage to love, which thee impious Miniters of Sathan hide under her bolter; or if that cannot be done under the threhold of ome door through which he is to pas, adding thereto, according to their common practie, certain words and figures, forg'd by the old Spirit of Lying. Nor are they content with all thee palpable fooleries, but they mut add thereto ome enormous acriledges, by their abuing the mot acred Myteries of Chritian Religion, profaning not only the Olive-Branches and hallow'd Palms, the holy Oyls, the Habits and Ornaments of Priets, whereof they make ue of ome parcels, as they do alo of the crapings of the hallowed tones of our Altars, but alo the acred Hot it elf, on which they grave certain Marks and Characters with Blood; and having reduc'd it to powder, put it into the meats of uch as they would bewitch with thoe Love-Sorceries. There are alo others who pretend to do the ame things by Images of Wax, made like the perons whoe Love is deir'd, which they melt at a fire made of Cypres, or ome rotten pieces of wood taken out of Sepulchres, imagining that by vertue of the words which they pronounce during that Ceremony, the Heart of the peron belov'd will be oftned and grow more tender, the hardnes whereof if they cannot overcome by imple melting, they prick the waxen figure with the points of needles, preuming that the thing which it repreents, will be enible of the like treatment. There are others yet who content themelves with this Ceremony, that is, to burn the leavs of Lawrel, or the tones of Olives, ued anciently, according to the tetimony of the Prophet Baruch, by Women, to reproach their gallants with their neglect towards them. But the famous Sorceres Canidia, makes it her boat, in Horace, that he had wrought this effect with the marrow of the Bones and the Liver of a young Child, which he had taken out of his Belly, after he had tarv'd him to death buried in the ground up to the chin; promiing her elf, by means of this powerful Philtre, o far to recover the affections of her Gallant Var • s, who had been debauch'd from her, that he would enflame and make him burn more violently than pitch et on fire. So certain is it, that there is not any crime, how heinous oever, which this furious Paion will not inpire into thoe, who o earnetly endeavour the atisfaction of it, which for that reaon the Laws punih with o much everity. Nor do they les condemn the upertitious remedies which ome others propoe for the prevention of them, as being uch as are no les dangerous than the michief they would hinder, of which kind are thee, to carry about one the privy parts of a Wolf, a Secret recommended by Pliny and Pompanatius; to drink of the Urine of a Hee-goat; to cat
on himelf the dut of the place where a Mule had wallowed; and uch other unlawful and upitious means.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXX. Of Atoms.
div.p:
IT is a Truth not quetion'd by any of the Philoophers, what Sect oever they were of, that there mut be certain Principles, whereof Natural Bodies conit. Their Generation and Corruption confirm it; ince that according to the former, there being not any thing made of nothing; and according to the latter, it being not imaginable that any thing can be reduc'd to nothing, there mut be ome firt Principles, from which, primarily, and of themelves natural things do proceed, and whereto they are at lat reolv'd. But it hath not yet been fully decided, to what this prerogative is to be granted. Heraclitus would betow it on Fire; Anaximenes on the Air; Pherecydes, to the Earth; Thales, on the Water; Xenophanes, on the two latter, joyntly; Hippon, on Fire and Water; Parmenides on Fire and Earth; Empedocles, and mot of the other Naturalits, on thoe four Elements together; which yet, as ome affirmed, could not execute the function of Principles without the aitance of other Superiours, uch as Heiod maintains to be Chaos and Love; Antiphanes, Silence and Voice; the Chaldaeans, Light and Darknes; the Mathematicians, Numbers, and among others the Tetrad, which the Pythagoreans affirm to be the ource of all things; the Peripateticks Matter, Form, and Privation; Anaxagoras, the Similar Parts; and Democritus, his Atoms, o called by reaon of their malnes, which renders them inviible, and incapable of being ditinguih'd and divided into other leer Particles, though they have quantity, and are of o great a bulk as to be thereby ditinguih'd from a Mathematical Point, which hath not any; as being defin'd to be what hath not any part, and what is o imperceptible and mall, that it can hardly fall under our External Senes, but is only perceivable by reaon. The ame thing may alo be aid of the other qualities of thee Atoms, which Epicurus, who receiv'd them from Democritus, as he had the knowledge of them from Leucippus; and he again from one Mochus, Phoenician, who liv'd before the Trojan Warr, made it not o much his buines to lay them down for the firt Caues and general Principles of Natural Things, as to take away the four common Elements, ince he does not deny but that thee are contitutive parts of the world, and whatever is comprehended therein. But his main work is to maintain, that they not the firt eeds and immediate Principles thereof, as coniting themelves of Atoms or little Bodies o ubtile and mall, that they cannot be broken or made
les, and being the mot imple and next pieces, whereof mixt bodies are made up, and whereto they are afterwards reducible by diolution, there is ome reaon to give them the denomination of the firt material and enible principles of natural bodies.

The Second aid, That if thee Atoms be allow'd to be the principles of natural bodies, thee lat will be abolutely unknown to us, as being made, up of infinite principles, which being incapable of falling under our knowledge, it will be impoible for us to come to that of the mixt bodies which are to conit of them. Whence it will follow, that though the Atoms hould be uch as the Philoophers would perwade us they are, yet would not our Undertanding, which cannot comprehend any thing but what is finite, be ever the more atisfy'd, ince it would not be able to conceive them, nor conequently the things which hould be produc'd of them. Nor is it to be imagin'd that thoe things would differ among themelves, ince that, according to their entiment, thoe little chimerical bodies are not any way ditinguih'd, but all of the like nature, and of the ame ubtance.

The Third aid, That though there be not any eential difference in the Atoms, yet is it certain, That they make remarkable diverity in the production of things, by the properties and different qualities that are in each of them, whereof there are two kinds, Common and Proper. The proper are, Largenes of Bulk, Figure, Motion, and Reitance; the common are, Concoure, Connexion, Situation, and Order, which are generally competible to all Atoms, as the four others are proper and particular to them. Their bulk is not to be conider'd as if they had any coniderable quantity; there being no Atom, how great oever it may be, but is infinitely les then the leat body in the World, being for that reaon o imperceptible, that it is impoible for the ight to ditinguih it. Yet does not that hinder but that they are bodies, and conequently have quantity, which is a property ineparable from bodies; as Mites, Hand-worms, and uch other little Animals, which by their extreme litlenes elude our ight, do nevertheles conit of divere parts, miraculouly dicoverable by Magnifying-glaes, nay to the obervance of Veins, Arteries, Nerves, and uch like obcure parts, anwerable to thoe which reaon obliges us to admit, though our enes cannot attain thereto. It being the property of figure to follow quantity, which it determinates and qualifies, it is neceary, that if the atoms are different as to bulk, they hould be the ame alo as to figure: which being obervable when bodies are broken into great pieces, and thoe appearing with uperficies, angles, and points diverly figur'd, they mut till retain ome figure even after they are pounded in a mortar into mall parcels and particles, though our enes by reaon of their weaknes, are not able to comprehend it. To the ame
weaknes it is to be attributed, that we are not able to dicern the diverity of figures in grains of corn and other eeds, which eem to be in a manner alike, though they are not uch, no more than the leaves of Trees and Plants. Nay even in Drops of water and Eggs, though in appearance there is a likenes o great, that it is come into a Proverb; yet is there o remarkable a diverity, when it is trictly oberv'd, that there were heretofore in the Iland of Delos certain people o expert, that, among everal Eggs, they would tell which had been laid by uch or uch a Hen. The hair of our heads (a thing, to ome would eem incredible) have particular figures whereby they are ditinguih'd one from another. The figures of Atoms are of that rank, as are alo thoe of the Moats which are een playing and dancing up and down in the beams of the Sun, when darted in at a narrow paage: for though they eem to be all round, yet examin'd with that intrument which magnifies the pecies of things, we find in them an infinite number of other figures. In like manner is it requiite, that the Atoms hould have the ame difference of figures, that they may the more fitly concur to the mixture and generation of Bodies. To that end, the maintainers of this opinion affirm, that ome are round, ome oval, ome oblong, ome pointed, ome forked, ome concave, ome convex, ome mooth and even, ome rough and rugged, and of other uch like figures, as well regular as irregular, in order to the diverity of their motions. Of thee there are three kinds aigned; according to the firt, the Atom moves downwards by its own weight; according to the econd, it moves upwards; and according to the third, it moves indirectly and from one ide to another. Thee two lat are violent motions, but the firt is natural to the Atom; to which Epicurus attributes a perpetual motion, which cauing it to move inceantly towards the lowet place, it till makes that way of its own nature, till uch time as in its progres it hath met with other Atoms, which coming to trike againt it, if they are the tronger, they force it upwards, or of one ide, according to the part of it which had receiv'd the hock; and o clinging one to another, they make everal mixtures, as, when they come to eparate after their union, they are the caues of the corruption of mixt bodies. And thee bodies have o much the more Reitance, which is the lat property of thee Atoms, the more dene and olid thee lat are; as on the contrary, when they are les dene and olid, by reaon of the vacuity there is between their parts, the bodies coniting of them have o much the les vigour and force to oppoe external injuries.

The Fourth aid, That there is not any better intance, whereby the nature of Atoms can be explicated then thoe little Motes, which move up and down the air of a Chamber, when the Sunbeams come into it at ome little hole or cranny. For from this very intance, which is o enible, it may eaily be concluded, not only that they are bodies, which have a certain bulk and
quantity, how little and indiviible oever it may be, but alo that they are in continual motion, by means whereof, as thoe little corpucula, or Motes, inceantly move and trike one againt another, and are confuedly intermixt one among another; o the Atoms, by their perpetual agitation and concoure, caue the mixtures and generations of all natural things. So that, all conider'd, it is as ridiculous on the other ide to affirm, that they are only imaginary principles, becaue they are not een, as to maintain, that thoe little Motes are not in the air, becaue they are not perceiv'd to be there in the abence of the Sun-beams, which we mut confes renders them viible, but with this aurance, that they are nevertheles there, even when they are not dicern'd to be there.

The Fifth aid, That it is certain, there are abundance of bodies in Nature, which are in a manner imperceptible to our enes, and yet mut be granted to be real bodies, and conequently endow'd with length, breadth, profundity, olidity, and the other corporeal qualities. Such as thee are, among others, the enible Species, which continually iue out of the Objects, and are not perceiv'd by the enes, but only o far as they are corporeal and material, epecially the Odours, exhaling from certain bodies, which after their departure thence, in proces of time, decay and wither. Of this we have intance in Apples, and other Fruits, which grow wrinkled, proportionably to their being drain'd of thoe vaporous Atoms, (whereof they were at firt full) which evaporate in a leer or greater pace of time, the more cloely thoe little bodies tick one to another, or the more weakly they are joyned together. Nay, the intentional Species, how ublimated oever they be, by the defaecation made by the agent Intellect, are nevertheles bodies, as are alo the Animal Spirits, which are charged therewith, and the vital and natural, whereby the former are cherih'd. In like manner, Light, the beams of the Sun and of other Stars, their Influences, their Magnetick Vertues, and other uch Qualities, obervable in an infinite number of things, between which there is a mutual inclination and correpondence, or antipathy, cannot be imagin'd to act otherwie then by the emiion of certain little bodies; which being o mall and ubtile that they are incapable of further diviion, may with good reaon be called the Elements and material Principles of all Bodies, ince there is not any one but conits of them.

The Sixth aid, That the concoure of thee Atoms being accidental, if we may credit Epicurus, we cannot attribute thereto the caues of the generations happening in this World; inamuch as an accidental caue not being able to produce a regular effect, uch as is that of Nature in Generation, it is ridiculous to attribute it rather to thee Atoms, than to ome other caue, which is uch per e, and always regular in its operations, uch as
is Nature her elf. But what further dicovers the aburdity of that opinion is this, that it thinks it not enough to refer the diverity of the other effects, which are oberv'd in all natural bodies, to that of the Atoms, whereof they conit; but pretends alo by their means, to give an account of that of our Spirits, which thoe Philoophers would repreent unto us made of thoe orbicular atoms, and accordingly eaily mov'd by reaon of that round figure, and that thoe in whom it is mot exact, are the mot ingenious and inventive perons, as others are dull and blockih, becaue their Spirits have a leer portion of thoe circular Atoms. But this peculation may be ranked among pure chimaera's, ince that the functions of our Undertanding, being abolutely piritual and immaterial, have no dependence on the different contitutions of thoe little imaginary bodies; nay though there were any correpondence between them and the actions of our minds, their round figure would not be o much the caue of our vivacity, as might be the pointed or forked; as being more likely to penetrate into, and comprehend the mot difficult things than the circular, which would only pas over them, without any fixt fatning on them.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXI. Whether the King's Evil may be cur'd by the touching of a Seventh Son, and why?
div.p:
THough this noiom Dieae ometime fatens on everal parts of the body, yet is there not any more enible of its malice than the neck, which by reaon of its being full of glandules, is extreamly troubled therewith, which happens as well by reaon of their thin and pongy contitution, as their nearnes to the brain, from which they receive the phlegmatick and excrementitious humours, more conveniently, than any of the other parts can be imagin'd to do, which are at a greater ditance from it. And yet thee lat, notwithtanding that ditance, are extremely troubled therewith, nay ometimes to uch exces, that, if we may credit Johannes Langius in the firt Book of his Medicinal Epitles, a Woman at Florence had the Evil in one of her Thighs, which being got out weigh'd ixty pound; and a Goldmith of Amberg had another of the ame bignes in a manner, neer his Knee. And what is much to be oberv'd, is, that though the Evil eems to be only external, yet is it commonly preceded by the like wellings, which ly hid within, and whereof thoe without are only the marks: which obervation is confirm'd by the diections made of thoe who are troubled with it, in whoe bodies, after their death, there are
abundance of thee Evils, whereof the Glandules of the Meenterium and the Pancreas, which is the mot coniderable of any about Man's Body, are full, and which are commonly produc'd by Phlegm, the coldnes and vicoity whereof do indeed contribute to their rebellion; but it is very much augmented by the external and common Caues, uch as are Air, Aliment, and Waters infected with ome malignant qualities, which render it Endemious and peculiar to certain Nations; as for intance, the Inhabitants of the Alps, and the Pyrenean Mountains, epecially the Spaniards, who are more infected with this foul dieae than any others, which is alo communicated by ucceion, as mot of the other dieaes, which become hereditary by means of the Spirits, employ'd by the Formative Faculty in Generation, and carrying along with them the Character of the parts and humours of him who engenders, and imprinting them on the foetus. Hence it comes that for the curing of it, there is more requir'd than to adminiter the remedies commonly us'd in the cure of other tumours, which mut be diolv'd or oftened, that o they may be brought to uppuration, unles they can be conum'd and extirpated; but in this there mut be ome particular means ued. And, not to mention that which is generally known to all, to wit, the touching of thoe who have this Evil by the King of France, and his Majety of Great Britain, whom they heal by a miraculous vertue, and a pecial priviledge granted thoe two great Monarchs by God himelf; it is commonly affirmed, that the eventh Male-child, without any interruption of Females, hath the ame advantage of healing this dieae, by a favour which Theology calls gratia gratis data, and whereof many affirm, that they have een the effects. Thee are attributed to the vertue of the Number Seven, o highly eteem'd by the Platonits, as coniting of the firt odd Number, and the firt even and quare number, which are Three and Four, and are by them called the Male and Female, whereof they make uch account, that, according to the Opinion of thee Philoophers, the Soul of the world was made up of thoe two Numbers; and it is by their means that whatever is comprehended in it ubits. It is alo for this Reaon, that Children born in the eventh month, live as thoe born in the ninth; whereas uch as are born in the eighth die. To this may be added, That the mot coniderable Changes of Man's Life happen in thee everal Septenaries, which number does not only contribute to his Conception, which is not perfect till the eventh day, after the Matter hath receiv'd the Virile Sperme, and to his Birth in the eventh month; but alo to all the other accidents which happen to him in all the everal Septenaries. For the Child begins to have ome appearance of Teeth in the eventh month; at twice even months he makes a hift to tand alone; at three times even his Tongue is o far loos'd, that he peaks with ome Articulation; at four times even he goes teadily and confidently; at the age of even years he acquires
new forces, and renews his Teeth; at twice even he is of ripe age, and capable of engendring; at three times even he gives over growing, but becomes till more and more vigorous, till he hath attain'd to even times even, that is, to the forty and ninth year of his age, by ome called the little climacterical year, as being the mot compleat of any, in regard it conits of a perfect number multiply'd by it elf, and in which there always happens ome accident proceeding hence, that Nature being not able to forbear the doing of omething, when he hath attain'd that overeign degree of perfection, is forc'd to decline. It is therefore to be attributed to this compleat number, (which is called by the Greeks by a term which ignifies Venerable) that the eventh Son cures the Evil, the caue whereof being malignant, and, indeed, having omething in it that is obcure, which Hippocrates calls Divine; it is not to be admired, that the curing of it hould depend on a Caue equally obcure, and at o great a ditance from our knowledge.

The Second aid, That without having any recoure to o abtracted a Caue, as that of the vertue of the number Seven, which, being a dicrete quantity, is incapable of action, which is reerv'd to uch qualities only as are active; Nor yet to the Stars, which are at a greater ditance from us; Nor yet to the force of the Imagination, which many think may produce that effect: Waving all recoure to thee, I am of Opinion, that it is rather to be referr'd to the Formative Faculty, which producing a Male when the Seeds of the Parents are o dipos'd, as that what is more vigorous and trong hath a predominancy over the other which is les uch, that is, when it continues till in the getting of a Male without any interruption to the eventh time, the reaon of it is, that thee Seeds are till o trong and pirituous, that a Male is gotten intead of a Female, which is the production of thoe Seeds that are weaker and colder than the Maculine. Now the heat and pirits whereby Males are procreated, may communicate to them ome particular vertue, uch as may be the Gift of healing the Evil; which may be affirm'd with as good ground, as that the pittle of a Man fating being well-temper'd, kills Serpents; and that it is held, many have heretofore had uch a prerogative for the healing of certain dieaes, by ome particular qualities, depending either on thoe of their Temperaments, or of their whole ubtance. Thus Vepaian, as Tacitus affirms in the fourth Book of his Hitories, retor'd his ight to a blind Man. Adrian, as Aelius Spartianus relates, healed a Man born blind only by touching him. And Pyrrhus, King of the Epirotae, if we may believe Plutarch, in his Life, heal'd all that were troubled with the Spleen in his time, by touching their Spleen with the great Toe of his right Foot; of which Toe there was a far greater Opinion conceiv'd after his death, in that it was found intire, and not conum'd by the fire, as all the ret of his Body was. This vertue of healing thus after an extraordinary manner,
hath been deriv'd into ome whole Families. There are to this day many in France, who affirm themelves to be of the Family of Saint Hubert, and have the gift of healing uch as are bitten by mad Dogs. In Italy there are others, who make it their boat that they are of the Families of Saint Paul and Saint Catharine: whereof the former are not afraid of Serpents, which, for that reaon, they bear in their Coat; no more than thee latter are of burning coals, which they handle without burning themelves. In Spain alo, the Families of the Saludatores and the Enalmadores, have the gift of healing many incurable dieaes only by the Touch. Nay, if we may rely on common Tradition, we have this further to add, that it holds for certain, that thoe Children who come into the world on Good-Friday have the gift of healing everal orts of dieaes, epecially Tertian and Quartan Agues.

The Third aid, That if the gift of healing the Evil depended on the vigour of the Principles of Generation, which meet in the eventh Male-child, it would follow that the eighth or ninth coming into the world conecutively, hould more jutly pretend to that priviledge; inamuch as the generative faculty dicovers a greater vertue and vigour in that production of a ninth Male-child without interruption, then it might do in that of a eventh. Which being not found true, it were aburd to look for the Caues of it in Nature, whoe forces are not able to attain an Effect o trancendent, and o much above her reach. It mut therefore be a upernatural gift, which God betows on certain perons, out of a pure gratuitous favour, and more for the eae and comfort of others, than out of any advantage to thoe who receive it; as are alo the gifts of Prophecy and doing Miracles. For it is a demontration of God's Omnipotence, not to heal dieaes only by ordinary means, the dipenation whereof he hath left to Phyicians, who to that end make ue of natural remedies, but to do the ame thing without any aitance of Nature by extraordinary and upernatural means, in the application whereof, he ometimes ues the Minitery of Angels, as in the curing of Tobit, and thoe ick people who came to the Pool at Jerualem, after the water had been tirr'd by the Angel; ometimes by the Saints, of whom it is written, that the very hadow of their Bodies hath many times been effectual to that purpoe, as was that of Saint Peter; and oftentimes thoe of other perons, to whom he had communicated the gift for reaons unknown to us; as he granted that of Divination to the Sibyls, though they liv'd in Idolatry.

The Fourth aid, That Man was, potentially, all things; and that coniting of a Body exactly temperate, and of uch a Soul as is the mot perfect of forms, he comprehended in an eminent degree within himelf all the vertues of things as well corporeal as animate. Whence comes it then, that he hall not have the vertues and properties which are obervable not only in tones,
wherewith he participates Being, but alo in Plants which are capable of Vegetation as well as he; Animals, with whom he hath motion, ene, and life; and latly, in the eparated Spirits, as having, anwerably to them, certain powers that are piritual and remov'd from materiality? And o, ince the Vertue of healing Dieaes is found in mot Beings, which are of ome nature with Man, it is but reaonable he alo hould have the ame one, uch as is the gift of healing the Evil, which happens principally in the Seventh Male-child, by reaon of the perfection of his nature, which performs all the mot compleat functions in that number, which Hippocrates upon that occaion affirms to be the dipener of life. Nay if there have been ome who have had the Vertue of communicating everal Dieaes, by their ight and touching, as it is related of the Pylli, Tribales, Illyrians, and other Nations, who bewitch'd thoe whom they touch'd; and of him, whom Philotratus makes mention of in the life of Apollonius, who kill'd with his very apect, as the Bailik does; far greater reaon is there that there hould be ome to communicate health. For though this latter, requiring more preparations and conditions, is o much the more difficultly transferr'd from one Subject to another then icknes is, yet the reaon of contraries will have it o, that if the one is, the other may be communicated, and that with the greater jutice, inamuch as health, participating of the nature of good, ought to be more communicative from one ubject to another then icknes.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXII. Of Conjuration.
div.p:
THere is as much fault to be found with the exceive curioity of thoe, who would know all things, as there is with the unufferable tupidity of ome others, who are not any way touch'd with that natural deire of Knowledge: for as thee latter, by renouncing that accomplihment, deprive themelves of the greatet atisfaction of life; o the others, being tranported beyond the limits precrib'd to the mind of Man, wander they know not which way, and precipitate themelves into the abyes of errours and impieties. That of the Necromancers, who make it their boat, that they can command out of their Tombs the Souls of the deceas'd, that they may be, by them, inform'd of what they deire to know, is o much the more enormous, in that they have made an Art of it, call'd by them the Black Art, or the Art of Conjuration, a name as ridiculous as the precepts whereof it conits; which having no ground but what they derive from the capriccio's and fantatick extravagances of thoe Impotors, they ufficiently detroy themelves; o
as there needs nothing ele to dicover their palpable vanity; no more then there is to make appear the errour of thoe, who, to confirm that diabolical invention, maintain, that there are abundance of effects above thoe of Nature, which are to be attributed to thoe ouls eparated from their bodies, epecially that of foretelling things to come, and informing thoe thereof who conult them; it being conider'd, that, beides the gift they have of Science, which is common to them with all pirits diengag'd from matter, they have a particular inclination of doing good to men, by advertiing them of thoe things which o much concern them. But this is not only aburd in it elf, but alo impious, and contrary to Chritian Faith, which teaching us that there are but three places, where thee ouls have their abode, to wit, Paradice, Hell, and Purgatory, it is to be believ'd, that thoe which are confin'd to the lat never come out thence, but upon a pecial permiion of God, which he ometimes grants them, that they may ollicit the uffrages of the Living; thoe of the damned are further from being in a capacity to get out of that infernal prion, to which Divine Jutice hath condemn'd them, to be there eternally tormented; And the Bleed Spirits are yet more unlikely to quit their blisful State and the joys of Paradice, wherewith they are inebriated, to atisfie the vain curioities of thoe who invocate them, and for the mot part make ue of them rather to compas the michievous Sorceries and uch like Crimes whereof that Black Art makes profeion, then to procure good to any one; or if it happen that at any time they do any, 'tis in order to the doing of ome greater michief afterwards, uch as may be that of Supertition and Idolatry, whereto thee pirits inclining thoe who invocate them, and requiring of them uch Sacrifices and Adorations as are due only to the Deity, it is more then a preumption, that they cannot be the ouls of the Bleed, but downright Devils, who, transform'd into Angels of Light, impoe upon thoe who are o willing to be educ'd.
