The Second aid, That as the employments of the Devils are different, o is there alo a remarkable difference in their natures, which depends principally on the places of their abode, according to which, if we may believe Orpheus, ome of them are Celetial or Fiery, ome Aery, ome Watery, and ome Terretrial and Subterraneous; and among thoe the Aerial, to whom Plato attributes the invention of Magick, are by the Students of that Art, accounted to be the mot ingenious to deceive men, by reaon of their more eaie putting on of the groer parts of the air, and their appearing under what forms they pleae; and conequently, it will be no hard matter for them to aume that of the bodies of deceas'd perons, and, by that counterfeit appearance, to deceive the credulity of thoe, who are perwaded, that, by this art of Conjuration, they may be oblig'd to make a particular dicovery of themelves; and it is an obervation of Ananias, in
the third Book of the Nature of Devils, when a dying peron preented his right Hand to ome other, who thereupon joyn'd Hands with him. Nor is this any thing les upertitious than for the aid two perons to make a mutual promie one to the other, that he, who hall die firt of the two, hall appear to the urvivor, to give him an account what condition he is in; ince that, in thee Apparitions, it is always to be fear'd, that they are the Evil Spirits, whoe main deign is to educe them that aume their places, and do appear intead of thoe whom we think we ee.

The Third aid, That he thought it not very trange that the Souls of the deceas'd, having till a certain remembrance of thoe with whom they convers'd in this Life, and to whom they are till oblig'd by ome tie of affection, uch as was that of the Rich man in Hell towards his living Brethren, hould alo have an Inclination to ait them as much as they can. It may therefore be inferr'd, that, with the permiion of God, they do appear, when they are earnetly intreated to do it. For, not to peak of Moes and Elias, who appear'd on Mount Thabor, the day of the Transfiguration; the Prophet Jeremy and Onias appear'd to Judas Macchabaeus, as the Soul of Samuel did to Saul; to whom the Holy Scripture attributing the gift of Prophecy, that apparition was not illuory, nor procur'd by the Devil auming the hape of that Prophet, but certain and real, in which that Holy Man preented himelf, and, out of the deire he had to bring that King, for whom he ometime had a great affection, into the way of alvation, he remontrated to him the judgments of God, which would fall upon him, if he turned not from the evil of his wayes.

The Fourth aid, That though there be nothing but confuion among the Evil Spirits, yet is there to be imagin'd a certain Order in their Nature, and uch a Subordination among them, that there are Superiours and inferiours, whereof ome have a overeignty over others. Thence it comes, that among the Magicians, who have unhappily ingag'd themelves in their ervice, thoe who have given up their Names to a Devil of a uperiour Hierarchy, force the others to obey them, and may exercie the ame uperiority over the Spirits of a lower Clas, as their Mater can. It is to thee Regent or principal Magicians, that ome would attribute the priviledge of calling up the Souls of the dead, and, for want of them, the Evil Spirits of an inferiour Order, whom they hew to thoe who conult them; or when they cannot do that, they think it enough to procure an appearance of Spectres and Shades, by that cured Art of Conjuration, ditinguih'd for that reaon into Necromancy and Sciomancy, whereof the former makes the dead appear, or rather Devils, with their very Bodies, and their Clothes and other marks, which they had during their being here: The other hews only Phantames, which have ome reemblance of them, yet make a
hift to anwer their Quetions who come to enquire of them. And whereas the whole mytery is full of impotures, they omit nothing that may caue terrours, that o mens pirits being prepoes'd, they might give the greater credit thereto. It was the opinion of ancient Paganim, which firt exercis'd this Art, that the Souls of the dead might be evocated, by pouring on the ground Wine, Milk, and Honey, and mixing it with the blood of certain Animals newly kill'd, the entrails whereof, being till hot, were afterwards carried three everal times about two Altars, garnih'd with three black or blew fillets, and a Cyprus. But when they were perwaded that thoe Souls of the deceas'd, which they call'd Manes, were incens'd againt them, they appeas'd them with black Victims, cating their entrails dipp'd in Oyle, into a fire laid on their Sepulchres made of uch Trees as bear no fruit, gave them Incene, cat Wine with the hollow of the Hand, and exercis'd uch Ceremonies for the mot part ridiculous; which alo were commonly perform'd at mid-night, and in Caves and ubterraneous places, there being not any thing they thought more contrary to thoe Spirits of darknes, than the light of the day, and epecially the riing of the Sun. Thence it proceeded, that Homer ends his lyes into obcure places, there to conult the Soul of Tireias; and Virgil makes Aeneas decend under ground, to learn of the Sibyl what he had to do. The Poets alo have feign'd that Orpheus decended into Hell, to fetch thence his Wife Eurydice; and the Hitory of Pauanias tells us, that, to appeae the Ghot of Cleonica, whom he had kill'd, by mitake, and for which act he was continually tormented in the night time, he offer'd ome uch acrifices to it in an obcure place call'd Heraclea, where having appear'd to him, he told him, that he hould be deliver'd out of all his ufferings as oon as he were return'd into Lacedaemonia; as accordingly he was, having been there tarv'd to death with hunger in the Temple of Pallas, where he had taken Sanctuary, to avoid the fury of his Fellow-citizens, by whom he was puru'd.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXIII. Of Natural Magick.
div.p:
NAtural Magick hath degenerated extreamly in thee lat Ages, wherein it is grown as execrable, even to the very name of it, as it was honourable at the beginning, as thoe of Tyrant and Sophit were heretofore denominations generally eteem'd, but now they are abhorr'd. The ill ue which ome have made thereof, is, the true Caue of this treatment of Natural Magick, which they have fill'd with vanities and impotures, whereas it is in it elf not only the noblet, but alo the mot ancient
of all the Sciences. For it is conceiv'd to have begun above four thouand years ince in Aegypt, under Zoroater the Grandon of Noah, whence it was pread among the Babylonians, the Chaldaeans, and the Perians, among whom the Magi were in o great authority, that, with the Myteries of Religion, they were intruted with the Civil Government and the conduct and tuition of the Kings, who were never admitted to the Crown, till they had been fully intructed in that Dicipline. By this it was that Orpheus and Amphion came to be o powerful, as to draw brute beats and tones after them; and hereby King Solomon came to be the wiet of all men; and, latly, by the tudy of this, Apollonius Tyanaeus, Pythagoras, Socrates, and the other Sages of Antiquity acquir'd the eteem they were in. But what adds much to the recommendation of it, is, that by its means the three Magi, or Wie Men in the Gopel, who were Kings, came from the Eat, where this Science flourihed, having found out that the Star which they aw, being different from all the others, yet no Meteor kindled by ome Natural Caue, was an extraordinary ign which God had been pleas'd to make appear unto them, to give them notice of the Birth of his Son; there being no rational ground to imagine they were down-right Magicians, as Theophylact conceiv'd in his Commentaries upon Saint Matthew; at leat this is certain, that, after the adoration of our Saviour, they abolutely renounc'd that Diabolical Magick, if it be uppos'd they had any tincture of it before. For as to this latter, which is grounded upon ome compact with the Devil, who thereby obliges himelf to do trancendent things for him with whom he hath contracted, being a kind of Idolatry it is generally abhorr'd and condemn'd by all, ince it makes ue of pernicious means to attain its end, which is ever bad. But uch is not the other, whoe end, and the means it employes to compas it being good and lawful, there is no doubt, but it may be lawfully ued. Beides, as Pellus and Proclus, two perons well kill'd in thee matters, have very well oberv'd this lat kind, call'd Natural Magick, is only an exact and perfect knowledge of the ecrets of Nature, by means whereof, conequently to the Obervations which ome eminently-curious perons make of the motions of the Heavens, and the influences of the Starrs, with the Sympathies and Antipathies which are almot in all ublunary bodies, they apply things o jutly one to another, and with uch an exact conideration of time, place, manner, and proportion, that they work prodigious effects; which, the more credulous, and uch as are ignorant of the correpondence there is between thee Effects and their Caues, look upon as Miracles and Enchantments. Such as were thoe of the Magicians of Pharaoh, who could turn their Rods into Serpents, make the Rivers of Aegypt red as blood, and fill the whole Country with Froggs, but were not able to go any further, to imitate the other Miracles of Moes, which they were forc'd to acknowledg wrought by the Finger of God. Nor
are the Effects of Artificial Magick les wonderful, not only in repect of its Predictions obervable in Judiciary Atrology, Agriculture, Medicine, the Art of Navigation, and others, grounded upon very probable Conjectures, but alo of its operations, as well true as fale, or illuory. The true ones are grounded on the Principles of the Mathematicks, epecially on thoe of the Mechanicks, which are the noblet and mot neceary part thereof, and on which do depend all the Water-Engines, Machins moving of themelves, and other Inventions wherewith the Ancients wrought uch Effects as were accounted miraculous. Such were, that Man's Head of bras made by Albertus Magnus, which fram'd an articulated Man's Voice, in imitation of that of Memnon; the glazen Sphere of Archimedes, the motions whereof naturally repreented thoe of the Celetial Orbes; his Burning-glaes, wherewith he burnt the Fleet of the Romans, who beieg'd the City of Saragoa where he then was; the wooden Dove of Archytas, which flew up and down with the other Doves; as did the little Birds of Boëtius made of Copper, which had this further advantage, that they could ing melodiouly; as could alo thoe which the Emperour Leo caus'd to be made of Gold; Malleable Glas, and uch other admirable Effects of this Art, for that reaon called by Hero, Thaumaturgica. Thoe which it produces by illuion and jugling, depend on ome leightnes of hand, and couening tricks, uch as are us'd by the Profeors of Legerdemain, to delude our Senes, and make things appear otherwie than they are. Such a performance was that mention'd by Joephus, in the xviii. Book of his Antiquities, ued by that fale Meias, Barchochabas, who to gain himelf the eteem of the true one, had the knack of vomiting flames of Fire out of his Mouth as he poke, by means of a lighted piece of Towe, which he could order as occaion erv'd; which trick, uch another Impotor hew'd more cleverly, by means of a nut-hell fill'd with Brimtone and Fire. And it is a thing now generally known, that, by certain Artifices no way diabolical, one may make a company of people itting at the Table look as if they were dead, or like o many Tawny-Moors; nay, if we believe Pliny, in the xxviii. and xxxv. Books of his Hitory, they may be made to look as if they had the Heads of Aes or Hores.

The Second aid, That, according to the Doctrine of Paganim, re-advanc'd ince the Light of Chritianity by the Marcionites and the Manichees, as there were two Gods, one called Oromazus, the Author of all good, who was the Sun; the other, Arimanes, Authour of all michief; o there were two kindes of Magick whereof one, coniting of an exact knowledge, and application of things in order to a good end, is commendable, and known by the imple denomination of Magick, which they affirm to be an invocation of thoe Genii, who are our Guardians and Benefactors, in order to the procuring of
ome good either to our elves or others: The other called Mangania, which they exercied by the invocation of the bad Genii or Daemons, was ever condemn'd as pernicious, as having no other deign then to do michief by Sorceries and Witchcraft. And though the grounds of that Doctrine are contrary to the Truth of Chritian Faith, yet ince it aures us that there are good and bad Angels, which were the Genii of Paganim; there is ome probability, that as thee lat incline us to Idolatry, Supertition, and other Impieties, to divert us from the worhip of the true God, by the tudy of the Black Art; o is it the main buines of the former, by a dicovery of the Secrets of Nature, which is the White and Natural Magick, to incline us to an acknowledgement of the Author of it. In like manner, as we find, according to the Apotle, that, in the order which God oberves for the good of his Church and the furtherance of our Salvation, there are divers Gifts, uch as are thoe of knowledge, healing, working of miracles, prophecying, peaking of trange languages, and the like; all which do notwithtanding depend on the ame Spirit of God, who dipenes them according to his good pleaure: So the Devil, who endeavours to imitate the Works of God, does the like, in the ditribution of thoe Talents, which he communicates to his intruments, to employ them upon different occaions, the better to accommodate himelf to the diverity of their inclinations, whom he would abue, which is his principal deign. He furnihes thoe whoe retles curioity will needs know things to come, with Oracles and Predictions; he entertains the vain with impotures and illuions; the envious with Charms and Sorceries; the revengeful, and uch as are inclin'd to uch implacable paions, are uggeted with all the michievous contrivances, which that pervere Spirit is at all times ready to teach any who are deirous to be his Diciples, to whom the practice of his intructions prove as fatal, as they are intended, to be to thoe, againt whom they are employ'd.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXIV. Of the Moles and Marks appearing in the Face.
div.p:
AS the Face is the highet part of the Body, as to cituation, and the mot delicate, as being the manion of the external Senes, which cannot act without the aitance of the Spirits, whereby that delicacy is imprinted in it; o does it accordingly lie more expos'd to as well internal as external injuries, then the other parts, which are not o much in ight, nor of o exquiite a complexion. And as the leat flaw in a Diamond, or
a fair Looking-glas is oon perceiv'd by uch as look attentively on them, o thee Marks are o much the more obervable in the Face, then in any other part of the body, the more uceptible it is thereof, by reaon of its clearnes and delicacy. I may add to this a thing which would be very improbable, if we had not the aurance of experience for it; to wit, that there is not any mark though ever o little, in the face, but doth denote ome other, which though not apparent, it is nevertheles eaie for uch as are expert to conjecture whereabout it is, by the inpection of thoe that are manifet. Thus if there be a mark in the midt of the Fore-head, it hews that there is uch another in the midt of the breat; but it will be towards one ide or other of this latter, inclining towards one of the arms, if the mark in the Forehead be not exactly in the middle of it, that is, incline any thing to the right or left ide: as it mut be on the briket or lower part of the breat, if it appear at the extremity of the forehead towards the root of the noe, between which and the parts devoted to generation, there is uch a correpondence, that the implet ort of people draw conequences of their good or bad dipoition, from the length or figure of the noe. But the more intelligent, not contenting themelves with this conjecture, affirm, that, according to the different cituations of thoe marks, there are the like correpondent to them in thoe parts, as well of the Man as of the Woman; for whether thoe on the former be in the middle, on the right ide or the left, thoe on the other parts are exactly anwerable to them. The everal obervations which have been made of thee correpondences of marks in the Women we hall leave to the examination of the Female Phyiognomits, o far as the parts before-mentioned are under conideration, and confine our elves to the Men. In thee, the mark which is apparent on the highet part of the noe towards the root, as we call'd it before, where the pace is between both eyes, always denotes another at the bottom of the Yard, near the Teticles; between which and the Ey-lids there is o great a correpondence, that thoe little pecks or warts which are many times to be een on the latter, are the ignificators of the like in the former; even with that obervance of proportion, that if it be on the upper-lid, thoe marks will be on that part of the Cods which is nearet the Yard; if it be on the lower, they hall be on that part which is nearet the Fundament. Moreover, from the appearance of one of thee marks upon one of the Ey-brows, it is concluded, that there is as much on the houlder on the ame ide, which is at a greater or leer ditance from the Back-bone, the nearer to or further off the other is from the pace which is between both the eys. There is the like correpondence between the Cheeks and the Thighs, for if they have a mark jut in the middle, the thigh hall be marked jut in the ame part, and on the ame ide; if they be near the noe, the thigh hall be marked near the groin; if they incline towards the ears, the
correpondent marks will be towards the buttocks. The mark appearing between the Eye and the eminent part of the Cheek, dicovers one under the Arm-pit; that on the tip of the Ear, hews there hould be one on the upper part of the Arm. It is inferr'd alo from the mark upon the upper lip adjoyning to the Noe, in that pace which makes a eparation been the Notrils, that there is another anwerable thereto in the Peritonaeum, betwixt the Fundament and the Cods; and from thoe on the Chin and the lower Lip, that there are others about the bottom of the belly. But though thee rules are grounded on rational conjectures, yet are they not infallible, no more then thoe of Phytognomy, whereof they are a part; as is alo Metopocopy, which judges of the ecret inclinations by the inpection of the Face. The econd aid, That, as Man comprehends in himelf an abbreviation of all the rarities of the World; o does his Face comprehend all thoe of his body, whereof it is an extract. So that as the greater world is known by Man's body, which is the leer, it is no hard matter to make a dicovery of this lat by the face, which indeed is les as to volume, but o well compos'd and proportion'd, that it may well be look'd upon as the mot accomplih'd Mater-piece of Nature, who in the tructure thereof hath imitated Geography, which, not able to hew us all the inhabitable Earth, preents us with an epitom of it in a Map; or behaves her elf like a Whole-ale-Merchant, who does not expoe all his commodities, but thinks it enough to hew patterns thereof, whereby a judgment may be made of their value. Thus it is that there may be a dicovery made of the mot ecret motions within, by the figure and compoition of the parts of the face, inamuch as thoe of the other parts of the body depending on them, there is a judgment made of the one by the other, and conequently of the actions and inclinations, which are commonly anwerable to the contitution and temperament of the parts. But it is omewhat hard to make this judgment by the imple marks of the Face, whether they proceed from Nature, as thoe do which Children bring along with them into the World, and depend on the imagination of the Mothers, which is an external caue; or from ome other Caues, as the heat of the entrails, the abundance of gros and terrene humours, and the denity of the pores of the kin, which, checking them in their way, makes them appear in freckles, pecks, and other kinds of pots in the face? For, thee caues never being contant, but ubject to much variety, according to the everal occurrences which either augment or diminih them, it is impoible to make a certain judgment of a thing, which is in a continual change.

The Third aid, That the aid Art of gueing at the marks of the mot ecret parts of the body by the inpection of thoe of the face, is o ancient, that the Phyician Melampus, cited in Homer, Ody. lib. xv. deliver'd certain precepts of it, above three thouand years ince; and after him, Avenzoar, Septalius, Taxilius,
and everal others have cultivated it, and endeavour'd to hew the probability of certain reaons, which they ground principally upon the correpondence there is between the face and its parts, and all the other parts of the whole body of Man. It conits in two heads, to wit, in the proportion of greatnes or meaure, or in the reemblance of colour, conitency, figure, cituation, number, or uch other condition, which may be common between them. The firt correpondence between the face and the ret of the body, coniting in greatnes, which comprehends the three dimenions, length, breadth, and profundity, is o enible, that thoe who have exactly meaur'd all the parts of it, have found, that the face is the ninth part of the greatnes of the body, making the ditributions of thoe paces o jut that no one exceed another; provided that the body be well compos'd, and that there be no defect in the conformation, nor any coniderable diorder in the temperament of the whole, or its parts. The firt of thee paces comprehends the face it elf; the econd is from the throat to the brisket, where the xiphoidal Gritle is; the third reaches below the Navil; the fourth paes by the groin to the beginning of the haunches; the fifth and ixth comprehend the whole extent of the thigh; at the end whereof is the eventh, which with the eighth take up the whole pace from the knee to the heel, as the ninth does that of the whole foot: wherein as there are three new regions called Thare, Metathare, and the Toes, o are there as many in the Face. The firt whereof, which is the manion of widom, is from the beginning of the hair to that of the noe, where there is an interval between the Eye-brows. The econd, which is that of beauty, comprehends all from that intertitium, to the end of the noe; and the third, where the eat of goodnes is, reaches to the lower part of the chin. Now thee different intervals are in like manner obervable in the other paces, with o exact a proportion, that the countenance is not only anwerable to any one of thoe paces, which, with it, make up the whole greatnes of man's body; but there is alo a correpondence between every part of it, and thoe of each of the aid paces, as between the highet, the midt, and the lowet part, and that which is in the ame cituation, as between right and right, and left and left. So that as the face is not only the meaure of the whole body, being repeated nine times, but alo the leat parts of the face bearing the ame proportion to thoe of the ret of the body, it hould eem, that rational conequences may be drawn of the marks of thoe parts that are out of our ight, by thoe of the Face which are apparent to us. For if it be conider'd, that, beides the correpondence there is between them as to quantity, there is yet another, which we aid was that of reemblance, which makes a trict affinity between them, and uch as is particularly obervable between the Forehead and the Breat; the Ey-brows, and the Shoulders; the cavities of the Ey-brows, and
the Arm-pits; the Ears, and the Arms; the Chin, and the Groin; the Cheeks, and the Thighes, and o of the ret; thoe who have this knowledge, may eaily ghes at the Warts, the Moles, and marks that are out of our ight, by thoe which are apparent to us; it being probable, that as Nature hath mark'd the one with one ign, which is as it were the Seal he hath et to her work, it mut needs be found after the ame manner in that counter-part, between which and the other, there is an alliance, not only by reaon of its ubtance and compoition, but upon the account of everal other Accidents, which make them alike. Thus the Fore-head by reaon of its plain figure in the middle, and circular towards the extremities, and by its olidity is a ufficient repreentation of the Breat. The eminent cituation of the Eye-brows dicovers the correpondence there is between them and the houlders, which are the mot elevated parts of the Body; and the cavities of the Eyes which is under the Eye-Brows, have ome alliance with thoe of the Armpits, which are under the Shoulders. The Cheeks, by reaon of their flehy and muculous compoition, have a relation to the Thighs, and particularly, to the Buttocks, which are ituated in the midt of the Trunk, as the Cheek is in the Face, between the Fore-head and the Chin. The Mouth and the Chin have alo a great proportion with the Belly and the Groin, the former being ituated in the lower part of the Face, and the latter at the lower part of the Belly; as alo upon this account, that they are equally flehy, and oft in their uperiour parts, and, in their inferiour parts, bony and hard. But this correpondence is yet more enible between the Mouth of the Woman and her ecret parts, and between the Lips of both thoe parts, which for that reaon have the ame name; as there is the like between the Noe, the Eye-brows, and the Eyes, and the Genitals of a Man, the Teticles and the Cods. Nor can there be any ign more manifet, than uch as appear in thoe places; whence there may be inferr'd the marks of thoe which Nature hath o much conceal'd; which though o far out of ight, are nevertheles manifet to uch perons as have the curioity to tudy this correpondence. But there is uch an aociation between the Hand and the Foot, as well in regard of their compoition and tructure, as for the employments they are both put to; that the marks about the Hand and Fingers, have others anwerable to them on the ame parts of the Foot, in a correpondent order and dipoition one to another.

The Fourth aid, That to find out the reaon of this Proportion and Sympathy, we mut not confine our elves to ublunary Caues, but attribute an Effect o well order'd, and o regular to a Caue anwerable thereto. For my part, I cannot aign any but what is derived from the Heavens, whoe motions and influences being the general Caues of what-ever happens here below, that is contant and regular, it is to them that we ought
to attribute an exactnes, which is o certain, that it very eldom micarries. Thence it comes that the Profeors of Atrology, with ome ground of reaon, affirm, that as there is no Plant o inconiderable but hath its ignature imprinted on it by that Star, which hath a predominancy over it; o is there a far tronger reaon, than Man hould have his ignature, which, as they maintain, is et upon him as a eal, by the Star on which he hath a dependance; it being certain that the even Planets have an Empire over every part which they govern. Thus Ptolemy aignes to Saturn the right Ear, the Spleen, the Bladder, and the Bones; to Jupiter, the Hands, the Lungs, the Liver, the Blood, and the Seed; to Mars, the left Ear, the Reins, and the Teticles; to the Sun, the Brain, the Eyes, and the Nerves; to Venus, the Noe, the Mouth, and the Genitals; to Mercury, the Tongue, the Undertanding, and Ratiocination; to the Moon, the Mouth of the Stomack, and the Stomack it elf. But they attribute thee marks of the Face to the motion of the Stars of the eighth Sphere, which are as it were expreions of the different Inclinations, which every one naturally hath, and which are betow'd on him at his Nativity; but with this Caution, that it is hard to explicate them, unles a Man can decipher thoe Characters, and find out the true ignification thereof, which is the chiefet of all Sciences.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXV. Of Auguries and Aupices.
div.p:
THere never was any Opinion o erroneous, but it met with ome Abettors; nor any thing in point of practie o extravagant, but was in ome meaure authoriz'd. Of this quality is that of Auguries. For, though Cicero, when he was Augur, aid omewhat on the behalf of them, yet in his econd Book of Divination, he could not forbear dicovering their aburdity, and charging them with vanity and foolery. And yet this Opinion was in uch veneration among the Romans, who were otherwie the mot prudent of any Nation in the world, that they ent yearly ix Children, Sons of the mot eminent Senators, into Tucany, to learn of the Inhabitants thereof (who it eems were well kill'd in it) the Science of foretelling things to come by the flight, inging, or chirping of Birds, ince generally known by the name of Augury. Nay, this veneration is the more remarkable in this repect, that they would not undertake any thing of importance, till they had firt conulted the Colledg of Augurs, which was firt etablih'd by Romulus, who had alo been intructed therein, having order'd it to conit only of three perons, according to the number of the Tribes. But that number
was afterwards increas'd to 24. who were conulted about what-ever concern'd that great Empire, and they continu'd till the time of the Elder Theodoius; when it was uppres'd, having till then been o coniderable by the nobility and merit of thoe whereof it conited, that they were the Arbitrators of all Counels and Deliberations, which were not taken, till their judgements had been firt had. Nay, they had this further advantage above all other Magitrates, that they could not be put out of their places upon any account whatoever, but continu'd during their lives in that dignity, as Fabius Maximus did, who was Augur ixty two years. Nor was it only requiite that that they hould be free from crimes, but alo from all bodily imperfection, the leat defect of Body being accounted a lawful Caue, to hinder an Augur from taking place among the ret; it being, as Plutarch affirms in his Problems, an undecent thing for any one to preent himelf before the Gods, and to treat of the Myteries of Religion, with anything of uncleannes or imperfection about him. Nay, they thought any thing of that kind o contrary to the aid Ceremony, that, to be the more uccesful in the performance thereof, it was requiite that the Birds and other Creatures whereof they made ue in their Auguries, hould be as free from any defect as the Augurs themelves. In the mean time, they requir'd o much repect from the people, that, not thinking it enough to have the Lictors march before them with the Faces, as was done before the chiefet Magitrates, they had for a further badge of their dignity, a tick crooked at one end, call'd Lituus, which was that of Kings. And indeed, they aum'd to themelves o great authority, that they confirm'd the Elections of Dictators, Conuls, and Roman Praetors, whom they many times took occaion to depoe, under pretence that they had been elected contrary to the will of their Gods, whereof they pretended to be the only Interpreters. They took upon them alo the knowledge and dicovery of things to come, by carefully oberving certain extraordinary accidents, which urpriz'd all others by their udden and unexpected coming to pas, and which, by a certain Science and long Obervation, they affirm'd to be the ignificators of what was to come. And this they derived principally from the Heavens, and the different Apparitions of the Air, epecially from Thunder and Winds; then from Prodigies and miraculous effects of Nature; and afterwards from four-footed Beats, but epecially from Birds, from which comes the name to that kind of Divination, called Aupicium & Augurium, wherein thoe Divinators fore-told things conceal'd, and uch as hould come to pas by the inging and flight of Birds. They alo made the ame Predictions by oberving how the young ones, being taken out of a cubb, where they had been kept, took the food laid before them. For if thee devour'd it with a certain greedines, o as that ome fell to the ground, the Omen was fortunate, and ignifi'd all happines
to the Conulter; whereas, on the contrary, it ignifi'd ill-luck, if they would not meddle with it at all. And this Opinion was o trangely rooted in the Minds of ome upertitious people, that Titus Livius, and Valerius Maximus attribute the Caue of two ignal defeats of the Romans (one under the Command of Publius Claudius, in the firt Punick War; and the other under that of Flaminius, in the econd) to their contempt of thee Auguries.

The Second aid, That of all the everal kinds of foretelling ecret things, he thought not any more rational than that which was done by the means of Birds, called Ornithomantia; the Nature of which Creatures being very ancient, and in a manner celetial, they eem to be more uceptible of the impreions of the Heavens, whereof they are the Inhabitants, and which are the true Caues of what-ever happens here below, than any other Animals which have their abode either in the Earth or Waters. Thence it comes, that the Eagle which oars up higher than any other of the Volatile Common-wealth, hath been the mot eteem'd in the buines of Auguries, by the Profeors of this Art, who alo give him the preheminence, as to the contancy and vivacity of his Sight, taking it for a ignification of good luck, when he began his flight on the right ide; and that epecially, if it were o violent, that the noie of his wings might be heard. Thus Aritander, having een an Eagle flying from the Camp of Alexander the Great towards that of his Enemies, deriv'd thence an Augury of his Victory; as Tarquinius Pricus did the like of his coming (as he afterwards) did to the Crown from this accident, that an Eagle came and took his Cap off his Head, and et it on again, after he had kept it a good while in the Air. But Tarquinius Superbus had for an Augury of his exile and the los of his Kingdom, the violence done by ome Vultures to ome young Eagles, which they cat down out of their Net. Such another Augury had Dionyius the Tyrant, when, in his preence, an Eagle, having natch'd away with his beak a dart out of the hands of one of his Guard, cat it into the Sea; oon after which accident, he was hamefully unthron'd, and forc'd away. Yet does this Bird always denote happines, and goodluck, as do alo the Vultures; to twelve whereof, which were een by Romulus, while he was laying the foundations of Rome, it is conceiv'd, that that Metropolis of the world ows it fortune and continuance. Darius, having een two of them torn to pieces by o many Hawks, conceiv'd a hope of enjoying, as he did, the Kingdom of Peria; but he lot it, together with his Life, after his meeting with a great number of Swallows, as he march'd in the head of his army to engage againt the Scythians. And it is believ'd, that they had been alo fatal to Pyrrhus King of the Epirotae, upon whoe Tent thoe troubleom Birds were een; as they had alo been on the Ship wherein Mark Anthony was, before his dyater. The greater kind of Owl hath always been accounted o unlucky,
that one day, being got into the Capitol, under the Conulhip of S. Papellius Iter, and Lucius Pedonius, there was a particular olemnity perform'd, for the expiation of the City, which the Augurs affirm'd to have been polluted by that unlucky Bird: which yet was not uch to Agrippa, of whom it is oft related, that the aid ill-look'd Bird having appear'd to him in prion, it prov'd an augury of his retauration to the Kingdom of Judaea, whereof he had been dipoes'd. The ordinary Owl is alo of ill preage; for having one day pearch'd on the top of Pyrrhus's Lance, in his expedition againt the Argians, it was his misfortune to loe the battle. The Ravens are no les unlucky; for they were the fore-runners of the bloody civil War between Sylla and Marius; and their crokings forehew'd death to Alexander the Great, when he made his entrance into Babylon, and did the like to Cicero, while he was avoiding the Ambuhes of his inveterate enemy Antony. The Madge-howlets, the Scritch-owls, the Cormorants, and other uch mournful and melancholy Birds, make a ufficient dicovery of their fatal predictions, by the death of thoe who hear them. The Pilots fear nothing o much as to ee the Cranes flying towards them, and returning back the ame way again; that return advertiing them, that they are threatned with ome extraordinary tempet. The Stork hath always been favourable to Aupices, and look'd upon as a Meenger of Concord, as the Hawk, and the Buzzard, epecially where there was any thing done in order to marriage, or about the acquiition of riches, which the Falcon, whereof the latter is a Species, was conceiv'd to preage with o much certainty, that the Thucans built the City of Capua only upon their perceiving of one of them during the time of their Augury. The Wood-pecker and the Hern have alo made o happy preages, that every one reaum'd new courage in the heat of a battel, when they appeared in ight of the Souldiers. The Nightingal, which having pearch'd on the lips of Steichorus whilt he was yet a Child in the Cradle, ung there, was a preignification of that weetnes, which was afterwards to flow from his delightful Poems; as the Bees which made hony on thoe of Plato were a preage of his Eloquence. Though it mut be acknowledg'd concerning thee lat, that the Augurs were otherwie conceited of them; for having oberved great numbers of them in Brutus's Camp, they oblig'd him to quit it, o to avoid the misfortune that threatned him, and which happen'd to the Great Pompey, in whoe Ships thee Bees were een in exceive numbers before the Pharalian defeat. But thee obervations are not o contantly certain, but that there may be much diverity among them by whom they have been made. Hence is it that Homer, among all the good Auguries, gives the precedence to the Dove, which others will not have to be uch, but only when he is accompany'd, otherwie being alone they hold that he boads ome ill luck; as the Swan
does to all but Mariners. But among the ret, the ordinary Hen, when ever he makes a noie omewhat like the crowing of the Cock, foretells ome ignal misfortune, though that of the Cock himelf be numbred among thoe auguries that denote good ucces, as having forehewn victory to Themitocles, the night before he gain'd the battel againt Xerxes, and been reputed a Solar animal, from the correpondence there is between him and the Sun, whoe motions he declares by his crowing, which upon that account is formidable even to Lyons.

The Third aid, That there are two kinds of Auguries, the Natural, and the Artificial: The former depends on the connexion there is between the Effects and the Agents whereby they are produc'd; which connexion being known, it is no hard matter to give a conjecture of things to come, whereof uch as are clear-ighted oberve the neceity of their coming to pas, by reaon of the trict connexion there is between them, and the caues whereby they are produc'd. This is confirm'd by the infallible predictions which are made not only at Sea by Pilots, who foreee Tempets and winds by uch igns as eldom fail; but alo by imple Labourers and Hubandmen on the Land, who do the like in the changes of weather. Now this kind of Augury is as rational as the other is aburd, as being a frivolous invention, grounded on certain obervations, which are for the mot part vain and impertinent. Such among the ret, is the diviion it hath made of the Heavens into its twelve Houes, which are the Regions or Spaces whereto thoe Augurs confin'd the extent of their predictions, which they made with their Augural taff, without which the Auguries, according to their judgment, were of no validity, nor was there any more account to be made of them, then of what might be deriv'd from uch accidents as happen without or beides expectation, or rather preent themelves, whence they were commonly called Oblative Auguries. But thoe which happen'd conformably to the circumtances of time and place, which thoe Divinators had limited, and when they thought of them, were called Impetrative. And this is one of the conditions oberv'd in their dicipline, wherein there was no account made of what the Augur affirm'd that he had not particularly oberv'd, no more then then there was of any, thing that pas'd beyond the compas of the places deign'd to that function. For the better obervance of the ceremonies thereof, the Augural Houe was not cover'd but lay open to the air, which, for the better carrying on of the work, hould be clear and erene, out of a fear that the rain or wind might hinder their making an exact obervation of the flight and different motions of the Birds; in the choice whereof they were o hard to pleae, that they employ'd them not in their preages, but only towards the Spring. After which, epecially towards the month of Augut, they made no account of them, in regard they were not then in o much vigour, nor in o good cae, yet did they appoint
uch a dependance among them, that the Auguries taken from thoe that were inferiour, gave place to the others of a higher quality. So that if a Crow chanced to pas by, while they were attentively divining by the flight of a Dove, this lanter aupice was to no purpoe, no more then would be that of other Birds upon the arrival of the Eagle, which alo would ignifie nothing upon the fall of a thunderbolt, which diturbed all their myteries, with much more reaon then a Rat might do, which had no ooner appear'd in the Aembly, but the whole Ceremony was put off to another more convenient time. True it is then, that ome advantages may be made of Birds, in order to the drawing of auguries and preages of natural effects, uch as are rain, thunder, tempets, winds, heat, drought, cold, frot, now, hail, and other changes of weather, produc'd by the impreions of the Heavens, the Elements, and other Caues, as well general as particular; but not to make any predictions thence of uch events and accidents as depend on an infinite number of circumtances of time, place, and perons, who being purely free agents, their actions are wholly voluntary, and conequently impoible to be predicted, what artifices oever may be us'd to do it. Whereto we may add this Remark, that thoe artifices being full of abundance of vain and pernicious obervations, the entence of condemnation pat againt them is jut, not only that of the Canon and Civil Laws, which everely punih uch as make ue thereof, but alo that pronounc'd by the mouth of God, who expresly forbids his people in the twentieth chapter of Leviticus, to make their ouls abominable by beat or by fowl, threatning with death the Wizard, and him that had a familiar Spirit.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXVI. Whether thoe Children who are born with Cawls about their whole or ome parts of their Bodies are always fortunate, and why?
div.p:
CHildren do ordinarily come naked out of their Mother's Wombs, when, after their truggling with Nature, they begin their entrance into the World with crying and tears, acknowledging their weaknes, and the mieries they are likely to be expos'd to in the equele of their lives. Yet there are ome Children excepted from this general Rule; and thence is it that ome would have them exempted from the misfortunes common to all the ret, upon this accompt, that they are born with cawls about them, that is, are encompas'd by a membrane, which
comes over their heads and their houlders, call'd by the Greeks Amnios, which is the innermot of the three membranes, wherein the wombe-lodg'd infant is enwrapped, called by ome Midwives the Coife, or Biggin of the Child, by others the Childs hirt, and in ome places known by the name of the Silihow, by reaon of its tender and delicate intertexture, which other Children quit in their Mothers wombs, before they come out thence, with the other Membrane called Chorion, of which together with that mas of fleh which had erv'd them for a cuhion and upport during the time of the praegnancy, are fram'd the Secondines or After-burthen, o called, becaue it comes not out till after the Child is born. And as thee Children born thus cawl'd and coif'd with this tunicle (which like a large Hood or Capouch covers their heads and necks) eem not to participate of the nakednes of the others, who bring nothing into the World; o is it to be imagin'd, that they are not o much ubject to the mieries and calamities ineparable from the common life of other men, inamuch as their beginning being different from that of others, who come after the ordinary way into the World, upon the core of this pecial priviledge, of having their heads furr'd and cover'd, the conequence of it ought in all probability to be extraordinary, and full of happines, whereof if this coif be not the caue, yet have ome at leat oberv'd that it hath always been the ign, and that all thoe who have been born after that manner have been very fortunate. The Hitory of Antoninus, irnamed Diadumenus, related by Aelius Lampridius, in his Life, confirms this obervation: For being born with uch a coif, he afterwards came to the overaign dignity of the Empire, in the management whereof all things ucceeded according to his wihes. Nay, it hath been generally believ'd, that good fortune was o contant an attendant of this Coif, that all thoe who were deirous to compas their affairs carry'd it about them, epecially Advocates, who made ue thereof, to gain reputation in their publick pleadings, being to that end very careful to buy them of the Midwives, who, knowing the excellency thereof, old them at a very dear rate, after they had urreptitiouly got them away from the children, they had received into the World. For thoe who have made it their buines to enquire more trictly into this obervation, maintain, that he who brings this natural coif with him into the world is to expect all manner of good fortune, even o far as to be invulnerable, provided he be careful to have it always about him, or, (what contributes more to that effect) to eat it, as is over-upertitiouly done by ome. But the contrary will happen to the Child, if he be robb'd of that precious exuvium or coat, or it be ecretly taken from him, to be given to another, who, by that tranlation thereof, will receive the whole benefit of it.

The Second aid, That though the foreaid perwaion ufficiently detroy'd it elf, there being no connexion or correpondence
between the accidents of humane life and that hirt, which ometimes comes over the whole Body of the Child, commonly falls not much below the Shoulders, and many times does only cover the Face like a Mak; yet have many been of Opinion, that it contributed much to happines and the advantage of good fortune; inomuch that Saint John Chryotome, in everal of his Homilies, peaks againt thoe of his time, who made ue thereof to gain eteem; which a Clergy-man named Praetus, being deirous to acquire, by the means of uch a Coif, bought of a Midwife, he was very highly cenur'd, as Balamon affirms in his Commentaries upon the Canons of the Apotles. And Paulus Jovius, an Author of great repute, oberves, on the Nativity of Ferdinand Daval, that the Coif he brought with him from his Mothers Womb, contributed much to his being happy and belov'd of all. From all which we may make this inference, that there is nothing o extravagant, but may meet with Favourers and Abettors. For I may lay it down for certain, that this Opinion hath no other ground than what it hath found in the weak Brains of thoe Midwives, who having nothing in them but the name, have inenibly catter'd thee errours into the Minds of the vulgar, with whom the wiet being oblig'd to comply in matter of Language, it comes to pas at lat, that what was before but a common aying, finds a degree of aent among the mot coniderate. Nay, what is not any longer to be endur'd, they think it not enough to maintain this groundles perwaion, but there are ome o ridiculous, as to derive a new kind of Divination from it, which they call Amniomantia, whereby they promie to foretel what-ever happines or unhappines hould befall a Child newly born, by the colour of that Membrane, whereof they affirm that the rednes ignifies good ucces, and that the blacknes or blewnes of it denotes the contrary. To which they add another kind of Divination, call'd Omphalomantia, which teaches them to judge by the knots of the tring, whereby the Child is faten'd to the After-burthen, how many Children more the Mother hall have; who, according to their judgement, will be Males if thoe interections be of a colour inclining to black, and Females if they be white; which Obervations are not only impertinent, but alo impious and upertitious.

The Third aid, That the common perwaion, of the happines attending Children born with thee Coifs, is well-grounded, provided that it be taken in the ene wherein the Phyicians, who, in all probability, are more likely to be the Authors of it, than thoe imple Women who receiv'd it from them, would have it to be undertood; to wit, that thoe who thus born cover'd with that fortunate Membrane, (in regard they are not put to o much trouble, nor uffer o great violence in the paage, by reaon of its being open and eaie) come forth cloath'd out of their Mothers Wombs, without being oblig'd to leave behind them the Membranes, wherein they had been enclos'd in the
Matrix; whereas mot other Children are forc'd to quit them at their coming into the World, by reaon of the Obtructions they meet with in their paage through thoe narrow treights, which conequently, is o much the more painful and laborious to them, than it is to uch as are coifed, who are not to be imagin'd ever the more happy, as to the remainder of their lives, whereof the good or bad conduct are the true Caues of their happines or unhappines, and not that Coif, which can neither produce nor ignifie them.

The Fourth aid, That thoe Children, who are born thus coifed, are not only more happy in their Birth, but they are alo uch in all the actions of their lives, as being commonly more peaceable, and of a more quiet Contitution, than uch as leave that Membrane within their former lodgings; who are accordingly more turbulent and retles, and, for that reaon, have not thoe ininuations; whereby the former are recommended. For in thee, the moderation of their manners and demeanour conequent to that of their humours, gaining the hearts of all thoe with whom they convere, raies them into the general eteem of all, and o facilitates their acceion to Honours and Employments; it being certain, that there may be ome judgment made of the coure of Life a Man is likely to take, by the deportment of his Child-hood; o is it no hard matter to give a ghes at the ame, by that of the Infant, when he makes his firt ally out of his Mothers Womb, which is one of the mot remarkable tranactions of his Life. Whence it may be inferr'd, that that firt coming abroad being free from the trouble and agitation, whereof all others are enible, and which makes them forget their Veture which is left behind by the way, they ought accordingly to be dipenc'd from the misfortunes incident to others, and enjoy a particular happines.

The Fifth aid, That the mot retles and mot turbulent perons, are commonly the mot happy in this world, whereas thoe who endeavour to walk according to the trict rules of Modety and Reervednes, do not carry on their buines o well, as the former do, who confidently attempt any thing, and imagine themelves the favourites of Fortune. And thence it is that he, on the other ide, is o aitant to them, that though it be granted the Children born cloth'd are more meek and moderate than thoe who come into the World after the common rate, yet would the clean contrary to what is pretended follow from it. For, intead of being cherih'd by Fortune, it is eldom that he miles on them, but is much more kind to thoe tirring and tumultuary Spirits, who many times obtain greater favours of her than they durt hope for, had they demean'd themelves towards her with les earnetnes and importunity.

The Sixth aid, That if every Man be the Artizan of his own Fortune, thoe who are of the bet Contitution and tronget Temper, ought to be more happy than others, whoe irregularity
of humors does manifetly caue that of their Actions and Fortunes. Now the Children born with Cawls and Coifs about them, eem to be les vigorous, and of a weaker dipoition than thoe who come into the World without any; inamuch as the latter, being more earnet and violent, are no ooner enible of the time of their Deliverance, but they courageouly break through the Chains whereby they are detain'd, the Membranes whereby they are encompas'd, which thoe others having neither the Strength nor Courage to do, it gives a great preumption, that they will expres but little upon other more preing occaions, and conequently, they will content themelves with the mediocrity of their Conditions, and not apire to any thing extraordinary.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXVII. Of Antiperitais.
div.p:
SO great is the Indulgence of Nature, that he thought it not enough to betow Being and Exitence on the things he hath produc'd; but he hath alo imprinted in them a trong Inclination to preerve it, by fortifying them againt the aaults of their Contraries, the preence whereof ets them on uch an edge, that they become o much the more active. And this is not only confirm'd in Animate Beings, uch as are Plants and Animals, which vigorouly oppoe what-ever is hurtful to them, by o powerful a Vertue, that Men have been forc'd to find out a particular name for it, to wit, Antipathy; but alo in other Inanimate Bodies, which generouly tand upon the defenive, when they are et upon by External Agents, whoe contrary qualities coming to engage againt them, they redouble their Forces, and rally all together as it were into a Body, the better to receive the Charge. This is that which the Philoophers call Antiperitais, which is a vigorous reitance of the Subject, caus'd by the contrariety of an Agent, which encompaes it of all ides, purpoely to detroy or corrupt it. It will be to no purpoe to enter into any Dipute concerning the Exitence of that which we call Antiperitais; but we hall lay it down for granted, though it be conteted by Cardan and ome other Philoophers, who maintain, that Water, Air, and the other Subterraneous Bodies, are not actually colder at one time than at another, but only eem to be uch to our Senes, which, though they hould be detitute of all qualities, are then endu'd therewith, o that the ame Well-water which eems to be hot in Winter, by reaon of the coldnes that is in the Touching, eems cold in Summer, by reaon of the heat of the ame Organ, which judges of it comparatively. For the contrary is een, in
that Well-water, in Summer, being tranported into a hot place, is there nevertheles cold; and the fumes and hot vapors which exhale from Springs and Wells in Winter, do ufficiently demontrate, that, during the aid eaon, the water is endu'd with a true and real heat, too enible to be accounted imaginary. But this Antiperitais is further more olidly confirm'd by Experience, whereby we ee that fire burns more violently, and is more parkling in great Frots, or in the hade, than in hot weather, or when it lyes expos'd to the beams of the Sun. In like manner, a little Water cat upon a great Fire, makes it more violent than it was before; and the Ventricles of our Bodies, according to the Opinion of Hippocrates, in his Aphorims, are hotter in Winter than in any other eaon of the year; whence it comes that we are apt to feed more plentifully, and Digetion is then better perform'd. Nay, if we but go down into our Cellars, we hall find that the heat is more enible there in Winter; but in Summer, when all things are corch'd and burnt up on the urface of the Earth, all Subterraneous Places are o much the colder, the deeper they are, and the nearer they approach to the Centre; towards which, Cold, which is one of the natural qualities of the Earth, gathers together, and reunites it elf thereto, that o it may be ecur'd from the heat, whereby it is encompas'd of all ides. And as it is to this, that the generation of Metals in the entrails of the Earth is principally attributed; o mot of the Meteors which are fram'd in the two Regions of the Air, owe theirs to this ame Cold, which coming to encompas, and as it were to encloe the hot and dry Exhalation which makes the Winds, Lightning, Thunder, and Thunder-bolts, as alo that which makes the Comets in the Middle Region of the Air; thee unctuous and eaily-enflam'd vapors, being encompas'd of all ides, by the extream coldnes of that Air which encloes them, they, in order to their Conervation, re-unite, and take fire, after the ame manner as the Rayes of the Sun darted againt ome Opake Body, or reflected by Burning-glaes, et on fire the mot olid Bodies, on which they are repercus'd; as it is related of Archimedes, who by uch an Artifice, conum'd the Ships of Marcellus, who beieg'd the City of Saragoa in Sicily. Which intance erves as well to prove Antiperitais, as the manner whereby it is wrought, to wit, by the repercuion of the intentional Species of the Subject caus'd by its contrary. Thus then it comes, that the Water of Springs and Wells is cold in the Summer, in regard the Species of the cold, forc'd by the Water towards the heated Air which is all about it, are darted back again by that oppoite heat to the place whence they came; whereupon being thrut cloer together, they there re-inforce and augment the Cold; which happens not o in Winter, when the Species of the coldnes of the Water, meeting with no Obtruction in the Air, endu'd with the like quality, ininuate themelves into it without any reitance; and o not being reflected
nor forc'd back towards the Water, it is not then o cold as in Summer.

The Second aid, That the intentional Species, being not deign'd to act, but only to make a dicovery of the beings from which they flow, as may be een in thoe of all enible Objects, which thee Species repreent to the Organs that are to judge of them, cannot contribute any thing to the vigor of the action obervable in the Antiperitais; which he conceiv'd hould rather be attributed to the imple form of the Subject, which having an abolute overeignty over the qualities employ'd thereby, in order to Action, renders them more or les active, according to the need it tands in of them. And as eething Water taken off the Fire becomes cold of it elf, without any other aitance than that of its proper ubtantial form, which hath the property of re-intating it elf in that degree of Cold, which is naturally due unto it; o ought it with greater reaon to have an equal right of preerving that ame quality, when it is aaulted by its contrary, Heat; without having any recoure to thoe Emiions of Species, which, though we hould grant the Tactile qualities (what is much in dipute) yet would not be able to caue an Antiperitais, inamuch as being ineparable from them, if the intentional Species of the coldnes of Well-water were directed towards the warm'd Air, it hould take along with it the coldnes, and, conequently, it hould be o far from acquiring any new degree of coldnes thereby, that it would loe much of that which it had before. For ince it is the Nature of thee Intentional Species to be otherwie incapable, by reaon of their immateriality, of producing any Corporeal and Material Effect, uch as is the augmentation of the degrees of any active quality, as Heat and Cold are, there being not any contrariety between the Species thereof, no more than there is between thoe of • ll other Bodies, whereof they are the Images, there is not any reaon that obliges the Intentional Species of the Cold to retreat and cloe together, when they come to meet with thoe of Heat, or Heat it elf no more than there is that the Species of this latter quality hould make the other more vigorous by their reflection.

The Third aid, That it mut be acknowledg'd, that the Species of Cold and Heat, and the other firt Qualities were not contrary among themelves, as being in their own Nature inalterable and incorruptible, as the other Intentional Species are, which come near the Condition of Spirits: Yet does it not follow thence, that thee Species cannot be reflected, inamuch as the Viible Species, Light and Voice, which alo have no contraries, are not for that the les re-percus'd by Mirrours and other olid Bodies, or thoe hollow places which make Echoes.

The Fourth aid, That it is not ufficient, in order to the giving of a reaon of that effect, to attribute it to the ubtantial
form of every Agent, but it is to be referr'd to a uperiour caue, uch as is the Soul of the world; whoe function it being to preerve every thing in its intirenes, and to be aitant thereto, when it comes into any danger, as it happens when it is aaulted by its contrary, then bent upon its detruction, there lies a certain engagement on this firt caue, to relieve it in o great an extremity, by upplying it with new forces to help it out of that oppreion. Thence it comes that our Cellars are warm in Winter, and cool in Summer, as are alo all other ground-rooms and low places; That Water hrinks up and frames it elf into little drops, when it is pilt on dry ground, whereas it preads abroad and is diffus'd in moit places; That Lime is et on fire by the cating of water upon it; That the fire burns better in froty than in hot weather; That Wine drinks more cool out of a Glas that had been warm'd; That the coldnes of Snow caues an extraordinary heat in their hands who handle it; and, That generally all tactile qualities are rendred more active, by the oppoition of their contraries, by reaon of the concoure, and the aitance they then receive from that general Caue, which concerns it elf in their preervation. Of this we may give an intance in Politicks, affirming, that the procedure of the forementioned Caue is much like that of great Potentates, who, in a war between ome petty Princes or neighbouring States, if they find one party ready to be abolutely ruin'd, upply it with uch forces as hall enable it to recover it elf, o to bring the everal interets into an Aequilibrium, whereof there is as great a neceity in Nature, which is kept up by that proportion, wherein all things find their ubitence, as their detruction proceeds only from their diproportion and inequality.

The Fifth aid, That we are not to look for the reaon of Antiperitais any otherwhere, than in the Subjects themelves, wherein we find the action, whoe intenenes and augmentation are to be referr'd, not to that of the degrees of the active qualities, but to their compreion and reinforcement, which renders them more enible, in regard they are more material, as may be eeen in a red-hot iron, the heat whereof burns much more violently, then that of a fire of Straw or Aqua-vitae.

The ixth aid, That according to the principles which allow all things to participate of a certain degree of entiment, this condenation, or compreion of the degrees of heat or cold, ought to be the effects of a enitive Agent, which having a knowledge of what may be hurtful or beneficial to it, withdraws within it elf the qualities which preerve it intire, when it is pres'd upon by others that are more violent, and uch as the meeting whereof might be prejudicial thereto, which it forces from it, in order to Action. And herein it is that the good of every thing conits; inamuch as every thing hath being only o far as it hath action, when it is aited by friendly qualities, and the like; and by this means it is that Cold and Heat act more
vigorouly, when they are oppos'd one to the other; and that our cavities are hotter in Winter, by reaon of the compreion of the Spirits and the natural Heat; which are the more diffus'd in Summer, in regard this latter goes to meet with its like, as a little fire is put out by a great one, and a weaker light obcur'd by a clearer.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXVIII. Of the Sympathetical Powder.
div.p:
THough this Powder be now as much out of eteem as it was in vogue, oon after the firt finding of it out, for the expeditious curing of wounds: yet will it haply be a buines of ome advantage to examine their Motives, who firt made, and publickly old it; as alo thoe of uch as have ometimes made ue of it with good ucces. And whereas novelty procures a certain eteem to Remedies as well as to other things, o this Sympathetical Powder found o great belief at its firt coming abroad, among Perons addicted to a military life, who were immediately flatter'd with a peedy and eaie curing of their mot mortal wounds by the means thereof, without any trouble of making inciions or dilatations, many times more painful then the hurt it elf, that we have had ome perons thee lat Campagnes, though detitute of learning and experience, who had the ubtlety to raie uch a mit before the eyes of the generality with this Powder, that they concluded this remedy to be true balm, and the only Panacea, or All-heal of all wounds. But time having dicover'd the vanity of it, as alo the impotures of thoe by whom it was o highly recommended, it hath been clearly found out, that there are few people in this age, but are either deceiv'd themelves, or make it their main buines to deceive others. For in fine, this Powder is as much cry'd down at preent as ever it was cry'd up; and there is nothing left of it, but the inolent name of Sympathetical, impos'd upon it by the Authors thereof, in imitation of the Unguent of the ame name, wherewith Goclenius, and ome other Phyicians, endeavour'd to make good the Magnetick cure of wounds, wherein they only dres'd the arms or other intruments, by which they were given, and apply'd the convenient remedies thereto. But in regard they could not always come at the arms, which had done the michief, to keep up their practie, and to make the cure yet more eaie, thee uptart Doctors be thought themelves ome years ince, of another expedient to compas their deigns, that is, found out a remedy, wherewith they make it their boat, that they will cure all orts of hurts, only by applying this powder to ome piece of Cloth, which had been us'd either to bind up, or make clean the wounded part. And whereas there are two kinds of wounds,
one imple, which makes a olution of continuity in the oft and flehy parts of the body, uch as are the veins, the arteries, the nerves, and the mucles; the other, compound, which happens ih the olid parts, epecially where bones are broken; thee Gentlemen have accordingly two different kinds of Sympathetical Powder; to wit, a imple, and a compound. The former is made with Roman Vitriol, which is our green and tranparent Coppres, which they beat or pound not over mall, and dipoing it upon papers, in uch quantities as they think fit, lay it in the Sun, when he makes his entrance into the firt degree of the Sign Leo, and leaving it there for the pace of three hundred and ixty hours, which make jut fifteen days, anwerably to the like number of degrees, which that Planet travels over, in the pace of a year in the Zodiack. During this time it is calcin'd into an exquiite whitenes, and then they take it in, and keep it carefully in ome temperate place, that is not too moit, that is, uch as may not be likely to melt it, for fear it hould by that means loe its vertue; for which reaon alo it is taken in during its calcination, in the cool of the evening, and in the night-time, and when the air is inclinable to rain, or over-moit. But there mut be a great care taken, that it be not tirr'd with any intrument of iron, when this powder is either in the preparation, or ready made up; thee Authors affirming, that it takes away its vertue, intead whereof they order, that the Artit hould make ue of a little Willow-tick, which is of great efficacy in thee magnetick cures. The compound Sympathetical Powder is made of the ame Vitriol, prepar'd after the ame manner, and the Gum called Tragacantha, exactly pulveriz'd, mixt together in equal quantities; intead whereof, others put Gum-Arabick, Sarcocolla, the roots of the great Comfrey, and the five-leav'd Tormentile, or uch other vulnerary and atringent Plants. However thee kinds of Sympathetical Powder may differ, as to the compoition of them, yet in the ue of them, they oberve the ame circumtances. For though the imple wound require the powder of the ame name, and the compound, where there is any fracture, requires the compound powder, yet is the manner of employing them till the ame. And to that end, as well in wounds newly receiv'd, as thoe that are of ome tanding, and degenerated into ulcers, they apply a clean cloth made of hemp or flax, to receive the blood from them, or the matter, wherewith being imbibed, they cat the powder upon it, then fold up the cloth, incloing it in another; and being thus wrapp'd one in the other, they are laid up in ome temperate place, unles it be when the wound is extreamly enflam'd, or very cold. If either of thee happen, they remove the cloths from the place where they were firt laid, dipoing them into ome cold place, uch as may be a Cellar, or ome other cool room; if the part affected be exceively hot; and on the contrary, into an Oven or Stove, if it be threatned
with a Gangrene, or the extinguihing of the natural heat; and they dayly continue the dreing of thee wounds after the ame manner, till they are perfectly cur'd; till which time they carefully preerve all the cloaths imbu'd with the blood or matter that came from them. But what palpably dicovers the vanity of this practice, is, that they affirm the wound to be perfectly cur'd by this means, how great a ditance oever there may be between the wounded part, and the Sympathetical Powder, which, they ay, equally produces its effect afar off as near at hand. Which is contrary to Reaon, whereby we are intructed, that every agent being confin'd to certain limits in its action, beyond which it can do nothing; it is impoible that this powder hould at o diproportionate a ditance, produce the effect which they would attribute thereto, nay though it were granted it might, if it were immediately apply'd to the place affected.

The Second aid, That if all Agents were oblig'd to follow that general Rule, whereby they are retrain'd from acting otherwie then upon the Subjects they touch, either by themelves, or by ome vertue iuing from them, it would be a very hard matter to give a reaon of the action of that Sympathetical Powder upon the wounds it cures, without making ue of the aitance of common Surgery, which are many times more inufferable then the hurts about which they are employ'd. But ince there is a great number of the like intances in Nature, it will be no harder tak to find atisfaction in the caues of this, then in thoe of all the ret, which act at a ditance, without any enible tranmiion from the Agent to the Patient; as for intance, of the Loadtone, which draws iron to it; of the North-Star, which does the ame with the Loadtone; of the Moon's cauing the ebbing and flowing of the Sea; of the Sun's concocting Metals and Minerals in the bowels of the Earth; and of an infinite number of others, which act upon ubjects at a ditance, by certain occult qualities. Which qualities, in regard they are manifet and enible in the Loatone, are commonly call'd Magnetick; uch as is alo the cure conequent to the application of this powder on the blood, or matter taken from the wound, which is thus treated ympathetically, and whereof the action is withall animated by that univeral Spirit, whoe general interpoition and concurrence being requiite to all Agents, in order to the proecution and advancement of their operations, it may be concluded, that he does expres it in this Powder, whoe vertue he conveys to the wounded part, by means of the blood, which iu'd from it, which though eparated from the body, there is however ome conformity and correpondence between it and its whole.

The Third aid, That he thought it a very trange humour, to attribute to Roman Vitriol, and the Gum Tragacantha the vertue of curing that at a ditance, which they cannot do near at
hand, and that, being apply'd to the wounds about which they are employ'd. True it was that they were ometimes cur'd by that kind of procedure; but that it was not to be look'd on as a miracle wrought by the Sympathetical Powder, but as a pure effect of Nature; on which the curing of maladies principally depending, as Hippocrates affirms, there needs no more for the effecting that of a wound, then to take away all heterogeneous bodies, to reunite the gaping of the wound, and to keep it clean and at eae; for the natural heat, with its balm, the radical moiture and the Spirits, will advance the cure in that condition, more then all the uppurating, mundifying, cathoeretick, and epuletick medicines, which Art commonly makes ue of. Thence it comes, that the Maters of this new doctrine give a great charge, to thoe who would make ue of their Sympathetical Powders, to keep the wounds very cloe, after they have wah'd them with Urine, Sal-water, or Wine, and to take away the plinters of the broken bones, as alo the clotted and congeal'd blood, and the other heterogeneous bodies which might hinder the reunion. And this indeed is no hard matter for them to do in the imple flehy wounds; but they never could do it in thoe which are accompany'd with fractures, openings of great Veels, hurts in ome coniderable part of the body, or uch other extraordinary accidents. Otherwie that effect being above the reach of the remedy, which is incapable of producing that cure, if it happen by that means, and after that manner, it cannot be wrought otherwie then by vertue of a ecret compact with the evil Spirit, who will be forward enough to promote the welfare of the body, in thoe who hould make ue of this remedy, conditionally that they may run the hazard of detroying their ouls.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXXXIX. Whether there be any uch Creatures as the Ancients conceiv'd the Satyrs to be?
div.p:
NOvelty and things extraordinary, if we may credit the Profeors of Artificial Memory, have o great a power and influence over our minds, that they do not only force them to attention, when the objects are preent, but do alo much more excite, and better conerve the pecies then ordinary things can. This it was that oblig'd divere Poëts and Hitorians to peak of Hydra's, Chimaera's Bailisks, Satyrs, Centaurs, and everal other things invented out of pleaure or wantonnes, uch as have no ground in truth, and are pure poetical fictions. For thoe who have endeavour'd a more trict examination of the power of Nature, have found the intermixture of thee pecies a thing impoible, not only in repect of the matter, which was to receive the
Soul, whereto he is determinated by a certain proportion, but alo in repect of the form which is indiviible, epecially the Rational Soul. Whence it comes, that the Poet Lucretius peaks very learnedly, and affirms, that there cannot be any Centaurs, whereof the reaon is the ame with that of Satyrs; nay the Generation of Satyrs, according to the reaon alledged by him, is much more impoible than that of Centaurs. Becaue, aith he, if that intermixture of a Man's and Hore's nature were admitted, and it be withall uppos'd that Hores are come to their full trength in three years, at which period of time Children are hardly taken from their Nures breats, how is it to be imagin'd, that montrous Animal hould be in its beginning and vigour at the ame time? Beides, a Hore being accounted old, when Man enters into his youth, how hould the one come to dye, when the other were arriving to his greatet vigour? Now Goats being horter-liv'd then Hores, there is yet les likelihood of feigning an Animal, coniting of a mixture of uch a nature and Man's. For which reaon, Pliny, in Book 7. of his Natural Hitory, affirms, that a Hippocentaur being foal'd in Thealy, died the very ame day, and for the continuation of the miracle, was kept in hony (which is acknowledg'd to be an excellent Balm) and publickly expos'd to the view of all. Virgil places them at the entrance of hell, upon this reflection, that uch things as are contrary to Nature cannot ubit. And St. Hierom, in the Life of S. Paul the Hermit, relating how a Centaur had appear'd to S. Anthony, quetions whether it were a real Centaur, or the evil Spirit, under uch a form, and in the proecution of his dicoure, eems to conclude it a pure illuion of the Devils, ince he drove it away with the Sign of the Cros. So that we are not to attribute thee Satyrs to any thing, but the licentiounes which the Poëts have always aum'd to themelves, as well as the Painters, to dare and undertake any thing, without any regard to the rule given them by Horace, not to make an intermixture and coincidence of trange and oppoite nature; and that Satyrs, that is, half-men, half-goats, were to be dipos'd among the Hydra's and Chimera's, in as much as by them they would only repreent men that were very active, lacivious, clownih, and much inclin'd to railery: and thence alo the Satyrical Poëm came to have its denomination, as being a compoition or farce of a Kitchin, whence ome would have it to decend. Which fiction is ufficiently jutify'd by the divine Nature which they attributed to thoe Satyrical Animals, and by the other fabulous tories of Pan, whom they affirm to be the god of thoe Satyrs, as alo of the Shepherds. We are therefore to make no other account of this invention, then of all the other productions of their Imagination, what root oever they may have taken in the minds of the Ancients; in regard that being throughly examin'd it may be ranked among thoe eneles Old-wives tales, wherewith they amue little Children. Unles we would rather refer thee Satyrs to the illuion of Devils, who aume
their hapes, to abue illy Women. And thence it is that they are, by ome, called Incubi.

div.head: CONFERENCE CCXL. Whether it be better to bury or to burn the bodies of the Dead?
div.p:
ALL the World eems to be very much concern'd in this buines, inamuch as there being not any man but his coming into this world necearily infers his departure out of it; and that conequently, a eparation of Body and Soul, every man ought accordingly to conider, what will become, after death, of that other part of himelf, unles he hath dicarded all entiments of humanity, and hath aum'd the humour of the Cynick whom his friends having aked, where he would be dipos'd after his death, he deir'd they would leave him in the place where he died, without troubling themelves any further. Whereupon they demanding of him whether he was not afraid his body might be devour'd by Dogs, he anwer'd, that he hould be no more enible of their bitings then of the gnawings of worms, if he were put into the earth; but however they would do well to lay his taff by him, to frighten thoe Dogs that hould come near his body. There are whole Nations who have made choice of the bowels of thee Animals for their burial, epecially the Hyrcanians, who kept Dogs purpoely that they might be devour'd bp them after their departure. The like was done heretofore by the Medes and Parthians, who thought it les honourable to be interr'd, then to be devour'd by Dogs and Birds of prey, epecially Vultures, to which the Inhabitants of Colchos and Iberia expos'd the Carcaes of thoe who in their life-time had done gallant actions, but always burnt thoe of the cowardly.
