Nay, what is abolutely inhumane, (though Chryippus, an ancient and eminent Philoopher, approves it in a dicoure upon that Subject) ome were o barbarous, as to eat the fleh of their Fathers, and Mothers, and bet Friends, out of a perwaion, that it was one of the greatet demontrations of piety, to give their nearet Relations a burial in their own bellies. The Perians religiouly preerv'd them in their Houes, after they had enclos'd them in wax, to prevent putrefaction: which was better done by the Aegyptians, with honey, alt, bitumen, roin, cedar, aloes, myrrh, and uch perfumes, which have preerv'd their
Mummyes to this time. The Scythians did the ame with ice and now, wherewith they cover'd the bodies of the deceas'd, to ecure them from corruption. The Pythagoreans us'd, to the ame purpoe, the leaves of Poplar, Myrrh, and Aloes, wherewith they cover'd their dead; after which manner M. Cato deir'd to be buried, as Lycurgus was, in Olive-branches. The Aethiopians inclos'd theirs in Glas; the Thracians and Troglodites put theirs under heaps of tones; the Hyperboreans and Icthyophagi buried them in the waves of the Sea; the Poeonians, in Lakes; and the Inhabitants of Caria though no Sepulchre more honourable for thoe who died for their Country, then that of their own Arms, wherein they buried them; as they did Perons of Quality in the High-ways, that they might be the more conpicuous, and epecially in Mountains which were only for the burial of Kings; whence came the cutom of erecting Obeliks and Pyramids on their Tombes. But though there were a great diverity in this kind of burying, yet it conited principally in this, that ome made choice of the Earth, others of the Fire, for their epulture. The former is not only more natural and more rational, but alo more advantageous than the latter, ince there is nothing more cononant to natural reaon, then to return to the earth thoe bodies; which having been fram'd thereof, cannot be better conign'd then to the boom of that Mother; wherein being once enclos'd, they infect not our Air with corruption and malignant exhalations, as they may when cat into the fire, the heat whereof forcing the fumes and infected vapours of thoe Carcaes to a great ditance, they may corrupt the purity of the Air, and prejudice their health who are preent at thoe funeral Piles, which, for that reaon, the Law of the Twelve Tables expresly forbad to be et on fire within the City of Rome, let the corruption might be communicated to the neighbouring Houes, but provided it hould be done without the walls.

The Second aid, That though the general way of burying the dead now is to enterre them, yet methinks that of burning them, and preerving their ahes, is more noble and honourable, in regard the Fire excells the Earth in purity, as far as it trancends it in its vicinity to Heaven, the qualities whereof it communicates to the bodies it conumes, purifying and preerving them from all putrefaction, and making them o clear and tranparent, that, according to the common opinion of Theology, in the general conflagration, the World and all bodies comprehended within it, will be vitrify'd, by means of the fire. It is therefore more honourable to have our bodies conum'd by that Element, then to have them devour'd by Worms and Putrefaction; whereof fire being an enemy, and the Embleme of Immortality, there can be no better expedient to ecure our deceas'd Friends from oblivion, then that of burning their bodies, whereof we have either the bones or ahes left, which may be preerv'd whole Ages; there being yet to be een the Urns of
the ancient Romans full of uch precious depoita, as thoe who put their Friends into the ground can never ee. Add to this, that it is a rational thing to make a ditinction between Man Beat, which they do not, who, burying both, treat them after the ame manner; whereas if Man's body were burnt, and that of the Beat left to rot in the ground, it would erve for a certain acknowledgment of the diproportion there is between them; and that as the latter is of a mean and depicable condition, it is accordingly dipos'd into the Earth, which is under the other Elements, and as it were the Common-hore of the World; whereas the former being deign'd for Immortatality, Fire, which is the mot enible Hieroglyphick thereof is more proper for it then the earth; (wherein if we were not carry'd away rather by opinion than reaon, and that Tyrant of three Letters in the Latin Tongue, as a learned Author calls Cutom, did not corrupt our judgment) it were more rational to bury the bodies of Malefactors, then to burn them as is commonly done.

The Third aid, That if we may judge of the goodnes of a thing by its Antiquity, the way of interring the dead will carry it, as having been from the beginning of the World. Holy Scripture tell us, that Abraham bought a Field for the burial of himelf and his; and that a dead body having been dipos'd into the Sepulchre, where the bones of Elizeus were, was rais'd to Life. In other Hitories we find, that mot Nations practis'd it, epecially the Romans, till the time of Sylla, who was the firt whoe Body was burnt at Rome; which dipoal of himelf he order'd, out of a fear he might be treated as Marius had been, whoe bones he caus'd to be taken out of the ground, and cat into the River. From that time they began to burn the Bodies of the Dead, which continu'd till the Reign of the Antoninus's, when the Cutom of burying them came in again, and hath ince been us'd by all Nations, whoe univeral conent gives a great preumption, that this manner is to be preferr'd before any other. Add to this, that our Saviour would have his precious body o dipos'd, and the Holy Church, which is divinely inpir'd, eems to mind us of the ame thing, when, upon Ah-wedneday, he tell us, that we are dut, and that into dut we hall return.

The Fourth aid, That there were five ways of dipoing the dead. One is, to put them into the ground; another, to cat them into the water; the third, to leave them in the open air; the fourth, to burn them; and the lat, to uffer them to be devour'd by Beats. This lat is too inhumane to find any Abettors, but among Barbarians; Men are more careful to prevent the corruption of Water and Air, without which they cannot live, then to uffer carrions and dead carkaes, which would caue infections and inupportable tinks; o that the contet is only between Fire and Earth. For my part, I give the
precedence to the former, whoe action is more expeditious than that of the other Elements, which require a long time to conume dead bodies; whereas Fire does it in an intant. Whereto I may add this, that there cannot be any other more likely expedient, whereby men may ecure themelves from thoe contagious infections, which many times occaion dieaes, epecially when they are attended by Malignancy. Nay however, it is to be wih'd, whether dead bodies be buried or burnt, that it hould be done out of the City, and that the Law of the Decemviri, to wit, Hominem mortuum in urbe ne epelito, neve vrito, were till punctually oberv'd.
